input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Dennis Vermillion holds the positions of President and CEO, Mark Thies serves as Executive Vice President, Treasurer and CFO, Kevin Christie is the Senior Vice President of External Affairs and Chief Customer Officer, and Ryan Krasselt occupies the role of Vice President, Controller and Principal Accounting Officer.
Our diluted share earnings for Q4 2020 were $0.85, an increase from $0.76 in Q4 2019.
The company's full-year diluted share earnings decreased from $2.97 in 2019 to $1.90 in 2020.
I'll now hand over to Dennis to continue the discussion.
As we enter 2021 amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, we hope you're maintaining your health and safety.
Reflecting on the past year, I'm immensely proud of our staff's resilience in facing pandemic-related challenges, consistently delivering energy to our customers, and advancing our business objectives.
We remain committed to supporting those in our communities who are facing difficulties and have the greatest needs.
Avista and its Foundation contributed over $4 million in charitable donations throughout 2020 to assist community organizations experiencing increased demand for services in our service areas.
Our 2020 financial performance exceeded our projections, with Mark set to provide more detailed information shortly.
We've nearly completed the installation of smart electric meters and natural gas modules across Washington, marking one of our largest-ever projects.
This new infrastructure will enable customers to access more up-to-date information for better energy consumption management.
The technology allows us to send proactive high energy usage alerts, helping customers avoid unexpected high bills at month's end.
Beyond billing, smart meter data is enhancing our power grid's reliability and efficiency, leading to improved customer service.
For instance, we now have greater insight into our system, allowing for faster power outage detection and restoration.
We made progress towards our clean energy objectives with the Rattlesnake Flat Wind Farm becoming operational last December.
The project's construction created clean energy jobs in local communities, and its 57 wind turbines will now supply 50 average megawatts of affordable, clean, renewable energy to our customers, sufficient to power 38,000 homes for years to come.
In response to the ongoing wildfire threat in our region, we've implemented a new 10-year wildfire resiliency plan to enhance defense strategies and operational practices for a more robust system.
We anticipate investing approximately $330 million over the plan's 10-year duration to implement its components.
We're pleased to announce that Avista has once again been named one of the World's Most Ethical Companies for 2021 by Ethisphere, a global leader in defining and promoting ethical business practices.
This marks our second consecutive year receiving this recognition.
We are one of only nine honorees in the energy and utilities sector based on their evaluation.
For 2021, a total of 135 honorees were recognized across 22 countries and 47 industries.
We recently published Avista's 2021 Corporate Responsibility Report on our avistacorp.com website, and I encourage you to review it when you have the opportunity.
This material offers a comprehensive overview of our activities and how we're meeting our obligations to various stakeholders.
The site also contains links to Avista's reports on various industry and financial ESG disclosures.
The revised content reinforces Avista's ongoing dedication to corporate responsibility and transparency with our stakeholders.
Regarding regulatory submissions, we submitted two-year general rate cases in Idaho in January.
As you're aware, we filed general rate cases in Washington in 2020.
We're continuing to navigate the regulatory processes in both these states.
We take our duty to deliver safe, dependable energy at reasonable prices very seriously.
We strive to make wise financial investments in our infrastructure, control our expenses, and identify the best ways to serve our customers while keeping energy costs down.
For instance, our suggested tax customer credit would fully counteract an immediate rise in electric and natural gas bills for our Washington customers.
In Oregon, new rates became effective on January 16 this year, and we plan to submit another rate case in the latter half of 2021 in Oregon.
Moving forward, we remain committed to operating an excellent utility and continue to invest wisely in maintaining and upgrading our infrastructure to provide reliable energy service to our customers.
We are announcing our earnings guidance for 2021, 2022, and 2023 with consolidated ranges of $1.96 to $2.16 per diluted share for 2021, $2.18 to $2.38 for 2022, and $2.42 to $2.62 per diluted share for 2023.
This trajectory puts us on course to achieve our allowed return by 2023.
Finally, the board recently increased our dividend by 4.3% to an annual dividend of $1.69 per share, marking the 19th consecutive year of dividend increases for our shareholders, which I believe demonstrates the board's commitment to maximizing shareholder value.
We anticipated a challenging start to this year.
Not the company, but the Blackhawks, who have actually begun quite well after a slow first four games.
Five rookies have scored their first NHL goals, which is quite thrilling for hockey enthusiasts.
For the company in Q4, Avista Utilities contributed $0.81 per diluted share, up from $0.67 the previous year.
Our earnings improved mainly due to higher utility margin and customer growth.
Also in Q4, the Oregon and Washington Commissions joined Idaho in allowing the deferral of certain COVID-19 related expenses for potential future recovery.
Moreover, Avista Utilities' earnings surpassed expectations due to higher utility margin and lower income taxes, partially offset by increased operating expenses.
Regarding COVID-19, as mentioned earlier, we've now received accounting orders in all our jurisdictions to defer costs and benefits associated with the pandemic, to be addressed in future proceedings with each commission.
We anticipate a gradual economic recovery that will still result in some reduced load and customer growth in 2021.
We anticipate improvements in our economy to begin in the latter half of 2021.
We have regulatory mechanisms and decoupling in place to lessen the impact of load changes on our residential and some commercial customers.
Regulatory mechanisms cover more than 90% of our income, as you may remember.
As mentioned by Dennis, we remain dedicated to making necessary investments in our utility infrastructure.
We project capital expenditures of approximately $415 million for 2021, with AEL&P expecting around $7 million and our other businesses about $15 million.
Regarding our financial flexibility, we had $270 million available under our committed credit line at Avista Utilities as of December 31, and we issued approximately $72 million in stock during 2020.
We plan to issue about $75 million in equity or stock and up to $120 million in long-term debt in 2021.
As Dennis stated, we are providing guidance not just for 2021, but also for 2022 and 2023.
These ranges aim to bring us back to earning our allowed return by 2023, and our guidance assumes timely and appropriate rate adjustments in all our jurisdictions relative to our future capital expenses.
We faced regulatory lag in 2020 and expect this to persist through the end of 2022 due to our ongoing infrastructure investments and delayed filings.
As discussed earlier, we postponed filings last year due to the pandemic in Washington and Idaho.
Dennis previously mentioned these delays.
We anticipate our cases in Washington and Idaho, along with new rates, to provide some relief in 2021 and start reducing the regulatory lag.
Moving forward, we will aim to further reduce debt and align our returns more closely with those authorized by 2023.
Following 2023, we expect our earnings to grow by 4% to 6%.
Our 2021 guidance reflects unrecovered structural costs estimated to reduce the return on equity by about 70 basis points, and timing lag, which we're trying to minimize through rate cases, has reduced it by approximately 100 basis points.
This results in an expected return on equity for Avista Utilities of about 7.7% in 2021.
We are projecting operating cost growth of around 3% and customer growth of about 1% annually, which is a slight improvement from previous customer growth figures.
For 2021, we expect Avista Utilities to contribute between $1.93 and $2.07 per diluted share, and the midpoint of our guidance doesn't include any expense or benefit under the ERM.
We currently expect the ERM to be in a benefit position within the 75% customer, 25% company sharing band, which is anticipated to add $0.05 per diluted share.
For 2021, we expect AEL&P to contribute between $0.08 and $0.11 per diluted share, and our outlook for both Avista Utilities and AEL&P assumes normal precipitation and hydroelectric generation for the year, among other variables.
We anticipate a loss between $0.05 and $0.02 per diluted share for our other businesses as we continue to develop future opportunities.
We will invest some money in the next couple of years to boost those earnings over the next five years, and we look forward to these opportunities.
These opportunities are present both in our service territory and in funds.
Our guidance typically only includes normal operating conditions and does not incorporate any unusual or non-recurring items until their effects are known and certain.
Summary:

earnings guidance of $2.42 to $2.62 per diluted share in 2023.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Ray Young, our chief financial officer, will explain the factors driving our performance, as well as provide an overview of corporate results and financial highlights.
Juan will then present our future outlook.
Our group achieved an exceptional fourth quarter performance.
The adjusted segment operating profit reached $1.4 billion, showing a 23% increase compared to the same period in 2020.
Our adjusted EBITDA for the past four quarters totaled $4.9 billion, surpassing last year's figure by $1.25 billion.
We met our goals with a trailing four-quarter average adjusted ROIC of 10%.
This performance marked a robust conclusion to an outstanding 2021.
We achieved a record-breaking adjusted earnings per share of $5.19 for the entire year.
The full-year adjusted segment operating profit amounted to $4.8 billion.
This remarkable performance was evident throughout the entire organization.
The Ag Services and Oilseeds team's efforts to enhance their business portfolio and strengthen their operational model continued to yield superior results in a favorable market environment.
AS&O generated a full-year 2021 operating profit of $2.8 billion, with each subsegment performing at or near record levels.
Carbohydrate solutions executed exceptionally well, delivering full-year operating profits of $1.3 billion.
The team is advancing the evolution of carbohydrate solutions through various initiatives, including the Peoria dry mill sale, a sustainable aviation fuel MOU, an agreement with LG Chem, growth in the biosolutions platform, a project to reduce carbon emissions at major processing facilities, and the development of carbon capture and storage capabilities.
The nutrition team once again demonstrated industry-leading revenue and operating profit growth, with full-year revenues increasing by 16% and full-year operating profit reaching $691 million, representing a 20% year-over-year increase.
We continued to enhance our nutrition business through strategic investments in growing demand areas, such as soya protein, PetDine, Deerland, and FISA, expanding our presence in alternative proteins, pet food and treats, functional probiotics and enzymes, and flavors in Latin America and the Caribbean.
During our recent Global Investor Day, we presented our strategic plan and reaffirmed our balanced financial framework for value creation, which includes using our strong cash flows for both growth investments and shareholder distributions.
We are confident in our plan, which is why we are pleased to announce an 8% increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.40 per share.
We take pride in our record of 90 uninterrupted years of dividends and over 40 years of consecutive annual dividend increases, and we are glad to continue fulfilling our commitment to creating shareholder value.
It has been an excellent year, and we are enthusiastic about the future.
Our ongoing efforts to improve ADM and align it with global trends in food security, health and well-being, and sustainability, along with the steady advancement of our productivity and innovation initiatives, will contribute to our 2022 results.
I will provide more details about the upcoming calendar year shortly.
The Ag Services and Oilseeds team concluded an impressive year by successfully navigating supply chain challenges to deliver results comparable to the extremely strong prior-year quarter.
The Ag Services team performed well in an environment of continued strong global demand, including significantly increased export volumes for customers outside of China.
Global trade saw substantial year-over-year growth, driven by effective risk management and improved results in global ocean freight.
Ag Services achieved robust results, only marginally below the exceptional fourth quarter of 2020 when we experienced unusually high export margins.
Crushing performed well in response to the sustained strong demand for both soybean meal and vegetable oil.
Decreased performance in EMEA compared to a very strong fourth quarter in 2020 and roughly $250 million in net negative timing effects versus negative $125 million in the previous year's quarter led to overall lower results year-over-year.
The majority of these negative timing impacts are anticipated to reverse in the first half of 2022.
The refined products and other teams significantly improved their performance compared to the previous year, driven by high volumes and margins for refined oils in North America and better biodiesel margins in North America and EMEA, which compensated for weaker South American results due to the reduced biodiesel mandate.
Wilmar's equity earnings increased compared to the previous year.
Looking forward, we anticipate a strong first quarter from Ag Services and Oilseeds, surpassing the first quarter of 2021 and comparable to the recently concluded fourth quarter.
Carbohydrate solutions' fourth quarter results were more than twice those of the same quarter in the previous year.
In the Starches and Sweeteners subsegment, including ethanol production from our wet mills, results declined compared to the fourth quarter of 2020, due to increased input costs, particularly energy costs in EMEA, as well as reduced wheat milling volumes, partially offset by continued strong ethanol margins.
North American sweetener and starch volumes remained largely unchanged year-over-year.
Vantage corn processor results once again significantly improved year-over-year, driven by historically high industry ethanol margins resulting from strong demand relative to supply, as well as increased sales volumes due to production at the two dry mills that were inactive in the previous year's period.
Looking ahead, we expect the first quarter for carbohydrate solutions to be similar to or slightly better than the strong first quarter of 2021.
The nutrition business concluded a year of steady and robust growth, with fourth quarter revenues increasing by 19% year-over-year, 21% on a constant currency basis, with 26% higher profits year-over-year, and maintained strong EBITDA margins.
Human Nutrition had an excellent fourth quarter, with revenue growth of 21% on a constant currency basis and substantially higher profits.
Flavors continued its growth trajectory, primarily driven by improved product mix in EMEAI and continued strong performance in North America, partially offset by weaker APAC results.
In specialty ingredients, overall profits for the fourth quarter were comparable to the year-ago period as strong demand for plant-based proteins offset the impact of one-time insurance proceeds in the fourth quarter of 2020.
Health & wellness improved compared to the prior-year quarter as the business continued to deliver growing profits in bioactives and fermentation.
Animal nutrition revenue increased by 21% on a constant currency basis, and operating profit was significantly higher year-over-year, primarily driven by continued strength in amino acids.
Looking ahead, we expect nutrition to continue growing operating profits at a rate of 15% or more for calendar year 2022, with the first quarter similar to the first quarter of 2021, featuring continued revenue growth offset by some higher costs early in the year and the absence of the one-time benefits observed in the first quarter of the previous year.
Let me conclude with a few observations about the Other segment and some corporate line items.
Other business results improved substantially, primarily due to higher captive insurance underwriting results, as the prior-year quarter included larger intracompany insurance settlements.
For calendar year 2022, we anticipate other business results to be similar to 2021.
However, for the first quarter, we expect a loss of approximately $25 million due to currently planned insurance settlements.
Net interest expense increased year-over-year due to higher short-term borrowings.
In the corporate lines, unallocated corporate costs of $276 million were lower year-over-year, primarily due to increased variable performance-related compensation expense accruals in the prior year, partially offset by higher IT offering in project-related costs and transfers of costs from business segments into centralized centers of excellence in supply chain and operations.
We expect total corporate expenses, including net interest, unallocated costs, and other corporate expenses, to be around $1.2 billion for the 2022 calendar year, as I mentioned at Global Investor Day, with net interest remaining steady, corporate unallocated slightly increasing, and other corporate costs slightly decreasing.
The fourth quarter of 2021 saw an effective tax rate of about 21%, in contrast to 8% the previous year.
For the 2021 calendar year, the effective tax rate was approximately 17%, an increase from 5% in 2020.
The yearly increase was primarily attributed to shifts in the geographical distribution of earnings and current-year specific tax items, mainly valuation allowance and return to provision adjustments.
For the full year 2022, we anticipate the effective tax rate to fall between 16% and 19%.
Our financial position remains strong, with a net debt-to-total capital ratio of approximately 28% and about $9 billion in available liquidity.
I trust that many of you were able to attend our Global Investor Day last month.
We demonstrated our consistent strategic progress, from improving ROIC through capital cost and cash management, to achieving strategic growth and margin enhancement, including establishing a global Nutrition business, to our current focus on productivity and innovation.
Allow me to briefly discuss our outlook for the 2022 environment.
In Ag Services and Oilseeds, we foresee a continued favorable global demand landscape.
Given the reduced crop yield in South America, with the extent of the shortfall yet to be determined, we expect global agricultural commodity buyers to rely more heavily on the U.S. market for their needs, assuming a normal U.S. crop later this year.
Regarding oilseeds, we're beginning 2022 with robust soy crush margins.
As discussed at Global Investor Day, we believe that growing demand for meal and vegetable oil as a feedstock for renewable green diesel should continue to support a positive environment this year, with our soy crush margins ranging from 45 to $55 per metric ton.
If these conditions materialize, we believe Ag Services and Oilseeds has the potential to achieve operating profit in 2022 that is comparable to or exceeds that of 2021.
For carbohydrate solutions, we anticipate a stable demand and margin environment for our starch and sweetener products compared to 2021.
We expect the industry ethanol landscape to remain favorable, supported by domestic demand recovering to pre-COVID levels, energy costs driving increased exports, and improved clarity on regulations.
With this in mind, we're projecting higher ADM ethanol volumes and EBITDA margins averaging between $0.15 and $0.25 for the calendar year.
Additionally, we expect our biosolutions platform to deliver another year of solid growth as we continue to evolve the carbohydrate solutions business.
Overall, we anticipate carbohydrate solutions to generate full-year operating profit slightly below their exceptional 2021 performance.
In nutrition, we expect continued growth in demand for our unmatched portfolio of nutrition ingredients and systems, along with the benefits from our recent acquisitions.
Given these factors, we project 15-plus percent operating profit growth in 2022, revenue growth exceeding 10%, and EBITDA margins above 20% in human nutrition and high single digits in animal nutrition, aligning with the targets we outlined at our Global Investor Day.
As we look ahead to 2022, we see a positive demand environment across our portfolio.
We also consider areas where we can improve.
While our execution was strong in 2021, we continually identify opportunities for enhancement.
We aim to do even more to meet the growing demand in 2022.
Considering all these factors, we are optimistic about another very strong performance in 2022 as we progress toward our strategic plan's next earnings milestone of six to $7 per share.
Summary:
output:
compname reports outstanding results: fourth quarter earnings per share of $1.38, $1.50 on an adjusted basis; full year 2021 earnings per share of $4.79, $5.19 on an adjusted basis.
announcing 8% increase in quarterly dividend.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will refer to non-GAAP metrics during our call today.
I'm very thankful for their daily efforts in moving us forward.
We continue to focus on factors within our control.
Despite major economic changes in fiscal '20, several aspects went according to plan: replacement part sales outperformed new equipment and first-fit products, gross margin improved year-over-year, we cut discretionary spending while investing in growth areas, and we maintained a strong financial position while returning money to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks.
We're starting fiscal '21 with clear objectives and motivated employees.
We don't expect robust market conditions overall this year, but our diverse business model and strong operational capabilities make me confident we can advance our strategic initiatives in any economic climate.
We'll discuss our long-term opportunities later in the call.
I'll now provide a brief overview of fourth quarter sales.
Total sales for the quarter were $617 million, with sequential increases in June and July.
Sales decreased by 15% compared to last year, aligning with our early August forecast.
Both segments experienced similar declines.
However, there was considerable variation within the results.
Our first-fit businesses in the Engine segment are under the most strain.
On-Road sales in the fourth quarter dropped 44% from the previous year.
The U.S., which makes up the largest portion of On-Road sales, accounted for most of the decline as the cyclical slowdown in Class 8 truck production was worsened by the pandemic.
It's worth noting that On-Road first-fit in the U.S. represents only about 3% of total Donaldson sales, so our overall exposure to that market is limited.
Off-Road sales decreased by 24% in the quarter.
More than half of the decline was attributed to Exhaust and Emissions.
There were pre-buys in Europe last year related to an upcoming regulatory change, and new programs for our Exhaust and Emissions products haven't yet reached significant volumes.
In the U.S., production of heavy-duty Off-Road equipment remains low, particularly for the construction and mining sectors.
Conversely, Off-Road sales in China increased by nearly 50% in the fourth quarter.
The Chinese government is investing to stimulate activity, which is benefiting our Off-Road business.
Additionally, we continue to secure new programs with local manufacturers, some of which involve PowerCore.
These are new customer relationships in the country that produces more heavy-duty equipment than anywhere else in the world.
We're learning how to best support these local manufacturers and we understand this will come with order fluctuations, but our team in China is motivated as we see the potential for significant long-term growth.
Engine aftermarket sales trends were predictably better than our first-fit businesses.
Aftermarket sales in the fourth quarter decreased by 11%, reflecting a mid-teens decline for sales through our independent channel.
The trends in our independent channel are largely consistent with the third quarter.
U.S. sales fell due to the collapse of the oil and gas market combined with slowing transportation activity.
In Latin America, utilization is declining across the region as the spread of the virus compounds the impact of geopolitical uncertainty.
Fourth quarter sales in Eastern Europe remain strong as we continue to gain market share.
Sales through the OEM channel of aftermarket experienced a more modest, low-single-digit decline.
In the U.S., large customers reduced inventory to match demand, which was partially offset by strong growth in China as we continue gaining share with local customers.
In fact, aftermarket sales in China reached a record level last quarter and we see a long runway as we expect to continue winning new programs with innovative technology.
Our portfolio of innovative products performed well in the fourth quarter.
This portfolio comprises nearly a quarter of total aftermarket revenue and fourth quarter sales increased in the low-single digits.
For almost two decades, we have been improving, expanding, and reinventing our offering related to these razor-to-sell razor-blade products.
After all this time, we still maintain very high retention rates.
These products create a significant opportunity for growth and relative stability in our Engine business.
Therefore, we will continue investing in new technologies for the foreseeable future.
Aerospace and Defense sales decreased by 3% in the fourth quarter, driven by weak sales of products for commercial helicopters.
The decline was partially offset by a strong increase in sales for ground defense vehicles, though some of the growth is timing-related as key distributors built up inventory in the quarter.
I also want to inform you about a change to our strategic portfolio classification.
Starting in fiscal '21, we are reclassifying the defense business from mature to critical core.
Our mature businesses are focused on generating cash that allows for investment elsewhere, while critical core businesses aim to drive market share gains in existing markets through new technology, services, and relationships.
The Defense business has secured new programs with our robust engineering capabilities, and we expect these wins will deliver solid returns over a long time horizon.
Moving to our Industrial segment, fourth quarter sales decreased by 15%, largely due to the Dust Collection business within Industrial Filtration Solutions (IFS).
Sales of new dust collectors and replacement parts declined as customers continue to postpone investment and reduce output.
The quote-to-order cycle remains extended, with large projects being put on hold while smaller, essential projects tend to move forward.
Nevertheless, our value proposition continues to resonate.
Fourth quarter sales of our Downflo Evolution dust collection systems increased in the low teens, and sales of those replacement parts grew by more than 30%.
The Downflo family of products currently represents only about 15% of total dust collection sales, but it has grown rapidly as customers appreciate its space and energy-saving features, and we value the ability to retain the aftermarket.
We are also expanding the dust collection business through our e-commerce platform, shop.
We recently enabled guest orders, and we are encouraged by the results.
While the incremental revenue is still small, we have seen a significant number of new dust collection customers.
With our robust sales and delivery model, we believe the simplicity of our e-commerce platform gives customers another reason to choose Donaldson.
Process Filtration sales in the fourth quarter decreased in the low-single digits after an increase of more than 10% last year.
The decline was driven by new equipment sales, while replacement parts sales were approximately flat compared to the previous year.
We continue to make progress penetrating the highly valuable food and beverage industry.
We position ourselves as an engaged partner and promote our ability to quickly fulfill orders with products that can help improve efficiency in our customers' processes.
The pandemic gave us the opportunity to demonstrate this value proposition to our food and beverage industry customers, and our Process Filtration team delivered.
We remain very excited about this market, so we will continue to invest in expanding the sales force and adding new tools to drive this profitable business.
Special Applications sales decreased by 10% in the fourth quarter.
Sales of Disk Drive declined compared to the previous year, following a significant increase in Q3, while reduced automotive demand led to lower Venting Solutions sales.
GTS revenue rose 6% in Q4, primarily due to strong performance in small turbines.
The GTS division achieved another increase in profit, both in absolute terms and as a percentage.
We altered the GTS marketing approach four years ago.
We decided to concentrate on replacement parts and small turbines, while being selective about large turbine projects.
The GTS team has executed their strategy exceptionally well, as reflected in the results.
We recently decided to integrate our Saudi Arabian joint venture into our main operations.
We are continuing to optimize and streamline GTS to improve profitability.
Given the GTS team's performance and future prospects, we are now categorizing GTS as a mature business within our portfolio.
The GTS division has successfully transitioned from recovery to driving profitability, and is now in a strong position.
The achievements in GTS are not unique within our company.
Our organization is full of talented individuals working collaboratively to deliver results and create value for all stakeholders.
This is why I feel confident about our future prospects.
Before handing over to Scott, I'd like to briefly discuss fiscal 2021.
We're uncertain about the duration of the pandemic and its ultimate impact on our business.
Given these uncertainties, we'll focus on factors within our control: prioritizing employee health and safety, meeting customer commitments, pursuing global growth opportunities, implementing margin improvement initiatives, and maintaining a balanced approach to expense management, including strategic investments.
Scott will provide more details about fiscal 2021.
Like many companies, we had to quickly adapt to new working methods over the past six months, and our employees performed excellently during this time.
We enhanced our collaboration, strengthened relationships with customers and suppliers, and maintained operations in critical sectors worldwide with minimal disruption.
Overall, I'm very impressed by our team's accomplishments.
As we enter fiscal 2021, we have a solid foundation.
However, market conditions remain uncertain.
Given the range of possible outcomes, including the timing and nature of the eventual recovery, we are not providing detailed guidance at this time.
We will, however, share some of our planning assumptions for 2021.
I'll discuss these later in the call, but first I'll comment on our fiscal 2020 results.
Our decremental margin was a notable highlight.
We achieved 20% in the fourth quarter and 18% for the full year.
These results are better than our historical averages.
Let me elaborate on some specifics.
Operating expenses decreased by 10% to $125 million in Q4, remaining flat sequentially and reaching our lowest Q4 level in four years.
Discretionary spending was significantly reduced, partly due to pandemic-related travel restrictions, while we maintained investments in strategic growth areas like Process Filtration, Dust Collection, and Connected Solutions.
We'll continue to balance expense management with strategic investments, and we're pleased with our Q4 performance.
We're also satisfied with our gross margin performance.
Q4 gross margin increased by 20 basis points year-over-year, and our full-year rate rose by 50 basis points despite headwinds from lower sales and higher depreciation related to capacity expansion projects.
Many of these projects are now complete, which is why our planned capital expenditures for fiscal 2021 are significantly lower than the $122 million invested last year.
We're now focusing on optimization opportunities enabled by these investments.
We aim to reduce our cost structure while maintaining or improving service levels.
While benefits from these initiatives will increase over time, our list of optimization projects gives me confidence that we can deliver strong returns on these new assets.
Lower raw material costs are helping to offset the impact of reduced leverage on gross margin.
We've seen favorable pricing for steel, media, and petroleum-based products, and our procurement team is driving additional savings while strengthening our supplier network and improving terms.
Regarding pricing, while it hasn't been a major contributor to the year-over-year gross margin increase, it hasn't been a headwind either.
We have more flexibility to influence pricing in many of our replacement parts businesses, and teams like those in the independent channel of Engine Aftermarket have consistently executed our pricing strategy effectively.
This makes a significant difference, especially in the current economic environment.
A favorable sales mix is also contributing to gross margin improvement.
In Q4 and for most of the year, we've seen mix benefits as replacement parts comprise a larger share of total sales.
To some extent, these mix benefits are intentional.
We invest in technology to secure first-fit programs that drive aftermarket retention.
As we progress through an economic cycle, our strong base of recurring revenue provides relative stability and some gross margin support.
Replacement parts now account for 64% of total sales, giving us confidence in the resilience of our business model.
Before moving further down the P&L, I'll briefly discuss segment profit margins.
The Engine segment's story aligns with the consolidated results.
Mix benefits and lower raw material costs offset the loss of leverage, resulting in a year-over-year margin increase of 20 basis points in Q4.
In the Industrial segment, the loss of leverage was amplified by continued investments in our strategic growth businesses.
We expect Industrial margins to recover, helping us achieve our goal of improving the company's overall margins over time.
Returning to the P&L, Other income was $2.7 million in Q4 compared to an expense of $0.5 million in the prior year.
Improved performance in our joint ventures benefited fiscal 2020, while the prior year's Q4 expense reflected a charge related to our global cash optimization initiatives.
These initiatives, which allowed us to streamline our legal and fee structure, were enabled by tax reform.
We excluded last year's charge from the calculation of adjusted earnings per share, as well as a non-recurring charge related to tax reform legislation.
With that in mind, it's best to compare the reported Q4 tax rate of 21.1% with the prior year's adjusted tax rate of 21.4%.
While the difference between rates is not significant, I'll note that current and prior year rates were well below our typical expectations.
The Q4 2020 rate benefited from a favorable mix of earnings across jurisdictions, while the 2019 adjusted rate included a non-recurring benefit related to the favorable settlement of an audit.
Looking ahead to fiscal 2021, we anticipate our full-year tax rate to increase from 2020, aligning more closely with our long-term estimate of 24% to 27%.
Regarding our financial position, we're satisfied with where we ended the year.
Our net-debt-to-EBITDA ratio stood at 0.9, and in Q4 we cleared a $50 million term loan while reducing our revolving credit by $110 million.
We cautiously drew from our credit line early in the pandemic to strengthen our financial position.
Despite ongoing market uncertainty, we feel secure in our position and no longer require the additional financial buffer.
As anticipated in the current climate, accounts receivable decreased significantly compared to last year.
Stock levels also declined.
We aim to make additional improvements this year by aligning with demand.
Our cash conversion rates for Q4 and the full 2020 fiscal year improved substantially to 165% and 103% respectively, and we aim to surpass 100% again this year.
Our sales projections for fiscal 2021 generally align with recent trends.
Sales are expected to fluctuate considerably by region and market, with replacement parts and new market products likely to outperform the company average.
We anticipate lower sales in the first half of 2021 compared to the previous year due to the pandemic's onset timing.
August sales are tracking about 10% below last year's figures.
Total August sales will be less than July's, which is typical for the season.
Regional sales patterns in August mirror those of the fourth quarter.
The Asia-Pacific region is performing best compared to last year, led by growth in China.
Europe is doing better, partly due to currency effects, while the U.S. and Latin America face the most challenges.
As predicted, some of our more stable businesses like Engine Aftermarket and Process Filtration are showing relative strength, with both growing in Europe while new equipment sales remain under pressure.
For fiscal 2021 gross margin, benefits from product mix and lower raw material costs will decrease as we compare against strong advantages in the previous year.
Simultaneously, we will implement optimization projects to set the stage for long-term gross margin improvements.
Our fiscal 2021 operating expenses will have both positive and negative factors.
Reestablishing our annual incentive compensation plan creates a $13 million cost increase, and we plan to invest more in our strategic growth businesses and technology development.
We intend to largely offset these increases through expense control, likely benefiting from pandemic-related restrictions and comparing against higher spending in the first half of the previous year.
If a suitable opportunity arises, we may explore additional optimization initiatives.
We plan to buy back at least 1% of outstanding shares in fiscal 2021 to counter any dilution from stock-based compensation.
Any repurchases beyond this level will depend on macroeconomic conditions, investment opportunities, and our balance sheet metrics.
If conditions improve, it's reasonable to consider exceeding the 1% goal in fiscal 2021.
Broadly speaking, our objectives for the new year align with our long-term strategic plan.
We will seek growth and market share opportunities in our Advance & Accelerate business portfolio, implement optimization initiatives to boost gross margins, manage discretionary expenses while making targeted investments, and maintain our strong financial position through disciplined capital deployment and working capital management.
These are factors within our control, and I'm confident in our ability to deliver in 2021.
I have some news to share before handing the call back to Tod.
After five years as our Investor Relations Director, Brad will be moving to Belgium to become Finance Director of our Europe-Middle East region.
The exact timing is uncertain due to COVID, but he's committed to ensuring a smooth transition once we find his replacement.
You've done an outstanding job, and congratulations on your exciting new role with Donaldson.
We'll certainly miss you in this position, but we're all thrilled about this great opportunity for you.
I'm confident in our ability to handle the complexities of the current environment and to create long-term value by meeting our customers' evolving needs.
We have strong relationships with our customers, ranging from global brands to small business owners.
Our aim is to solve our customers' complex filtration challenges, enabling them to efficiently produce great products, and I believe we're succeeding in this goal.
Let me provide some examples to illustrate this.
In our Engine segment, our Filter Minder team launched a wireless monitoring system to help fleet managers optimize maintenance schedules for On-Road and Off-Road equipment.
Our system integrates with existing telematics and fleet management infrastructure, making it easy for customers to adopt this valuable technology.
We're also expanding connected solutions into the dust collection market with our IQ offering.
This service provides customers with real-time monitoring of their equipment performance, helping them reduce energy costs and minimize unplanned downtime.
We've made adoption easy; our IQ setup works with any brand of dust collector and the retrofit process is straightforward.
Our e-commerce platform is another tool helping customers operate more efficiently.
donaldson.com has global reach and features like real-time availability and personalization, making it easy for customers to find what they need and place new or repeat orders.
As always, new technology is crucial to our success, and we continue to expand our technologies and solutions to drive growth.
Many of our Engine customers aim to improve fuel economy and reduce emissions, and our products can help them achieve these goals.
We've demonstrated that consistent use of our PowerCore products can help end-users improve fuel economy while providing value to our OEM customers by allowing them to retain more of their parts business.
We still see many opportunities with diesel engines and growing potential with alternative powertrains like hybrid solutions and hydrogen fuel cells.
Hybrid platforms leverage our existing portfolio of air and liquid solutions, presenting good opportunities with that equipment.
Fuel cells have different needs, and we have a specialized air filtration system designed specifically for those requirements.
In addition to our air systems, we also offer venting products and specialized membranes for fuel cells.
Our technical capabilities position us well to participate in this growing market.
We're also pursuing non-Engine markets like food and beverage.
Process filtration sales were about $15 million in fiscal 2020, an increase of over 60% in the past three years.
We continue to invest in new technologies and are building capabilities to facilitate future expansion into life sciences.
Our long-term success depends on our team, so we're committed to making our company a great place to work.
We have a strong culture that values integrity, commitment, respect, and innovation.
We also maintain a continuous improvement mindset, recently creating a diversity, equity, and inclusion council to identify and implement practices that will strengthen our company.
We're also progressing with our sustainability practices.
We began developing our global sustainability strategy last year.
We've engaged our stakeholders and identified numerous projects to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, energy consumption, and wastewater.
Implementing and maintaining sustainable practices is another way we work towards our purpose of advancing filtration for a cleaner world.
I'm proud of our achievements as One Donaldson and look forward to another successful year ahead.
Summary:

full-year sales trends are expected to vary widely by geography and market.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The crisis has presented an opportunity for our company to showcase its adaptability.
We enhanced our interactions with retailers.
Our marketing approach was adjusted.
We reallocated resources to product categories that consumers value most.
New production milestones were achieved for VITAFUSION, ARM & HAMMER laundry products, and ARM & HAMMER baking soda.
We've redirected personnel to concentrate on e-commerce.
We've been taking initiative to capitalize on opportunities arising from the crisis and are expanding our manufacturing capabilities both internally and through new partnerships.
The flexibility and durability of the Church & Dwight team is evident in our performance.
We remain focused on ensuring employee safety, meeting consumer and retailer needs, supporting our local communities, and maintaining the strength of our brands.
Our factory, warehouse, and laboratory staff have done an outstanding job of staying safe, which has enabled us to maintain our supply chain operations.
Our office-based employees continue to work from home and are doing an excellent job managing the company.
Let's now discuss the results.
The third quarter was another remarkable period.
We saw a 13.9% increase in reported sales and adjusted earnings per share of $0.70.
In Q3, we experienced significant year-over-year growth in revenue, earnings, and operating cash flow, driven by a substantial increase in demand for many of our products.
Organic sales grew by 9.9%, fueled by higher consumption.
In terms of e-commerce, we were already in a strong position before COVID and well-established online.
Our online sales in Q3 increased by 77% across all retailer websites.
Gummy vitamins serve as a good example.
In 2019, 8% of our annual sales were online.
This year, we anticipate about 14% of our total sales to be online.
Remember, we started the year aiming for online sales to account for 9% of global consumer sales.
It was 10% in Q1, 13% in Q2, and 13% again in Q3.
We expect the full year to be close to 13% as well.
We continue to study U.S. consumer purchasing behaviors.
The findings are not surprising.
Consumers remain worried about store stock shortages and delivery issues with websites.
People report consolidating their shopping trips and continuing to stockpile to ensure they have enough products for a couple of weeks at a time.
Looking at year-to-date shipment and consumption patterns, our brands remain generally balanced across the 15 categories in which we compete.
Our brands experienced widespread consumption growth in Q3.
We observed double-digit consumption growth in several products including VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS gummy vitamins, ARM & HAMMER baking soda, OXICLEAN, FLAWLESS, ORAJEL, NAIR, FIRST RESPONSE pregnancy kits, and cleaners.
In the Household category, our laundry business consumption increased by 4%, and ARM & HAMMER cat litter rose by 8%.
Water flossers are another bright spot, with consumption turning slightly positive in Q3.
Although our Lunch & Learn activities remain significantly reduced, we plan to address this with increased advertising.
In addition to VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS, we expect water flossers to benefit from the increased consumer focus on health and wellness.
BATISTE dry shampoo continues to be affected by social distancing, with consumption down 10%, but this is an improvement from Q2 when consumption was down 22%.
TROJAN consumption decreased by 6% in Q3, but this was also an improvement from Q2 when it was down 15%.
It's clear that consumers have prioritized health and wellness.
VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS gummy vitamins experienced the highest consumption growth of any of our categories in Q3, up 49%.
The overall category consumption was even higher.
We anticipate that consumer demand for gummy vitamins will remain strong.
We have new third-party production capacity coming online in late Q4 to capitalize on this trend.
Consumers are focusing not only on health and wellness but also on cleaning, home cooking, and new grooming routines.
At a recent investor conference, I mentioned consumer research suggesting it takes 66 days to form a new habit.
Only time will tell if these new behaviors will lead to permanently higher levels of consumption.
However, if they do persist, we believe we are well-positioned to benefit.
Regarding private label products, our exposure is limited to five categories.
Private label market shares have remained largely unchanged throughout the first, second, and third quarters of this year.
Our international business achieved double-digit organic growth in the quarter, driven by strong performance in our Global Markets Group (GMG) and Canada.
In October, our GMG business is off to another strong start, and we continue to see robust point-of-sale recovery in Canada and Europe.
After three consecutive quarters of growth, our Specialty Products business contracted by 3.4% in Q3, primarily due to the poultry segment.
Turning to new products, innovative offerings will continue to attract consumers even in the current economic climate.
VITAFUSION introduced several new gummy vitamin products to their lineup.
To take advantage of growing consumer focus on immune health, we introduced POWER ZINC and Elderberry gummies.
We debuted ARM & HAMMER CLEAN & SIMPLE, a detergent containing just six ingredients plus water, compared to typical liquid detergents with 15 to 30 ingredients.
In the latter half of the year, we released ARM & HAMMER ABSORBx clumping cat litter, which is 55% lighter than our standard litter.
Let's now discuss the future outlook.
We're experiencing an outstanding year.
We now anticipate full year adjusted earnings per share growth of 13% to 14%, significantly exceeding our long-term goal of 8% annual earnings per share growth.
Due to our strong performance, we have increased our full year projection for sales growth to approximately 11% and organic sales growth to about 9%.
As we've stated numerous times before, we manage Church & Dwight with a long-term perspective to maintain our consistent growth model.
During the second half, we seized the opportunity to boost our marketing expenditure for new products and made additional investments in the company.
As we approach the end of the year, we are developing our plan for 2021.
We are highly confident that we will achieve our consistent growth model in 2021.
We will provide a detailed outlook for next year in February.
To conclude, I'd like to remind everyone of the many reasons to be confident in Church & Dwight.
Our company is well-positioned to thrive in both favorable and challenging economic conditions.
The product categories we operate in are largely considered essential by consumers.
Some of our categories are likely to benefit from the current situation.
We offer a mix of value and premium products.
Our leading brands hold the top one or two positions in their respective categories.
We have minimal exposure to private label products.
We've just experienced some of our strongest growth quarters ever.
With a robust balance sheet, we remain open to acquiring businesses that enhance total shareholder return.
We believe our company is more robust and adaptable than ever before.
Lastly, we possess the resources, pragmatism, and drive to ensure our brands continue to perform well in the future.
Rick will now provide details on the third quarter.
Let's begin with earnings per share.
Third quarter adjusted earnings per share, excluding an acquisition-related earnout adjustment, increased 6.1% to $0.70 compared to $0.66 in 2019.
As mentioned in previous calls, the quarterly earnout adjustment will persist until the end of the earnout period.
Better-than-expected sales performance enabled the company to invest more in marketing.
Reported revenue rose 13.9%, reflecting continued increased consumer demand for our products.
Organic sales grew 9.9%, driven by a 10.2% volume increase, partially offset by 0.3% unfavorable product mix and pricing, mainly due to new product support.
Volume growth was fueled by higher consumption.
Let's examine the segments.
Organic sales increased by 10.7%, primarily due to higher volume.
Growth was led by VITAFUSION and L'IL CRITTERS gummy vitamins, WATERPIK oral care products, ARM & HAMMER liquid laundry detergent, and OXICLEAN stain fighters.
We're often asked to reconcile Nielsen reporting with our organic results.
This quarter, tracked consumption for our brands was 7.7% compared to an organic sales increase of 10.7%.
In the current environment, one might assume this is due to restocking retailer inventory, but that's not the case.
We saw 400 basis points of benefit from strong growth in untracked channels, mainly online, and a 100 basis point drag from couponing to support new products.
The positive news is that consumption and shipments are balanced, both in the low double digits.
Consumer International achieved 11.6% organic growth due to higher volume, offset by lower price and product mix.
This represents a significant recovery for our international business from a flat Q2.
Growth was primarily driven by the Global Markets Group and Canada.
For our SPD business, organic sales decreased 3.4% due to lower volume, offset by higher pricing.
The lower volume was mainly due to the nondairy animal and food production in sodium bicarbonate business.
Regarding gross margin, our third quarter gross margin was 45.5%, a 110 basis point decrease from last year.
Gross margin was impacted by a 110 basis point drag from tariffs and a 90 basis point impact from acquisition accounting.
To complete the Q3 gross margin bridge: a 100 basis point benefit from price/volume mix; 160 basis points from productivity programs, offset by an 80 basis point drag from higher manufacturing costs, inflation, and increased distribution costs; as well as a 90 basis point drag from COVID-related expenses.
Concerning marketing, spending increased by $45.7 million year-over-year as we invested in our brands.
Marketing expense as a percentage of net sales rose 230 basis points to 13.8%.
For SG&A, Q3 adjusted SG&A decreased 30 basis points year-over-year, primarily due to leverage from strong sales growth.
Total expenses amounted to $12.3 million, with a $3.9 million reduction primarily due to decreased interest costs resulting from lower rates.
Our tax rate for the quarter decreased by 430 basis points to 17.3% from 21.6% in 2019, mainly because of increased tax benefits from stock option exercises.
Let's now discuss our cash position.
In the first three quarters of 2020, operating cash flow rose by 29% to $798 million, thanks to substantially higher cash earnings and improved working capital management.
As of September 30, we had $549 million in cash reserves.
We maintain our annual capital expenditure plan of about $100 million as we begin to increase our manufacturing and distribution capabilities, primarily in laundry, litter, and vitamin products.
As I mentioned at the Barclays conference in September, we anticipate increasing our capital expenditure to approximately 3.5% of sales over the next few years for these capacity-related investments.
Furthermore, as stated in the release, the company may resume stock buybacks in the future due to its strong cash position.
For the fourth quarter, we anticipate reported sales growth of about 9% and organic sales growth of roughly 8%.
As Matt pointed out, we're experiencing strong consumption across many of our product categories.
Moving on to gross margin.
We previously projected a 150 basis point contraction in the second half, but now we're forecasting a 190 basis point decrease.
This change is primarily attributed to one-time supply chain expenses.
We also expect significant expenses, and we've projected them to remain flat for the year as a percentage of sales, implying an increase in Q4.
We also foresee a lower tax rate.
Consequently, we expect Q4 adjusted earnings per share to be between $0.50 and $0.52, excluding the acquisition earnout adjustment, as we conclude 2020 with momentum.
Regarding our full-year outlook, we now project approximately 11% sales growth for 2020, surpassing our previous 9% to 10% range.
We're also increasing our full-year organic sales growth forecast to about 9%, up from our earlier 7% to 8% projection.
We've raised our cash from operations outlook to $975 million, a 13% increase compared to last year.
Regarding gross margin, we expect it to decrease by 20 basis points for the year, mainly due to acquisition accounting effects, COVID-related costs, additional manufacturing and distribution capacity investments, and higher tariffs on WATERPIK.
Concerning tariffs, recall that in 2018, we were subject to Tier two tariffs, for which we received an extension in 2019.
That exemption expired and wasn't renewed as of Q3 2020.
We're continuing to work on mitigating this impact.
To elaborate further on gross margin, I previously stated that the first half of the year saw a 150 basis point increase, while the second half would see a 150 basis point decrease.
Thus, our previous outlook for the year was flat.
Last quarter, I also explained the investments we were making in the latter half of 2020.
These included a new third-party logistics provider, external storage for surplus inventory, initial engineering for capacity expansion, VMS outsourcing costs, as well as other investments in automation, consumer research, and analytics.
We're now projecting a 190 basis point decrease for the second half, or a 20 basis point decrease for the entire year, which implies a 250 basis point decrease for the quarter.
We've incurred some non-recurring supply chain costs.
Here are a few examples: First, due to our exceptional growth, we're adding a new 3PL distribution center, as I mentioned last quarter.
This quarter, we again experienced stronger sales, resulting in duplicate external storage locations and a new 3PL distribution center that wasn't operational.
Consequently, we temporarily incurred duplicate costs.
We're also in the process of making "make first buy" decisions, which will likely lead to some asset write-offs in Q4.
We're conducting lean training across our plants.
Lastly, due to our excellent results this year, we have higher incentive compensation costs that are reflected in COGS.
Our full-year tax rate is expected to be 19%, and we've also increased our adjusted earnings per share growth forecast to 13% to 14%.
Now that we've covered the outlook, I'd like to discuss FLAWLESS briefly.
As mentioned in the release, we recorded an earnout benefit of about $50 million in the quarter in reported earnings.
We exclude any earnout adjustments from our adjusted EPS calculations.
Some context on this change: We acquired the business for $475 million upfront with a $425 million earnout tied to year-end 2021 sales.
That sales target represented over a 15% CAGR for three years, starting from a baseline of $180 million in trailing sales.
The revised 3-year CAGR for this business is now closer to 8%.
Consequently, the earnout liability decreases, and earnings increase.
We remain optimistic about this business, and the strong consumption growth over the past six months is an encouraging sign for the future.
As Matt mentioned, the company is well-positioned as we enter 2021.
Matt and I are now ready to answer any questions you may have.
Summary:

q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.70 excluding items.
sees q4 sales up about 9 percent.
sees 2020 reported sales growth raised to 11%.
2020 organic sales growth raised to 9%.
2020 adjusted earnings per share growth raised to 13%-14%.
2020 cash from operations raised to $975 million.

Bullet points: • 13.9% increase in reported sales • 9.9% organic sales growth • Adjusted earnings per share of $0.70 • 77% increase in e-commerce sales • 49% consumption growth in gummy vitamins • 11% sales growth forecast for 2020 • 9% organic sales growth forecast for 2020 • 13% to 14% adjusted earnings per share growth forecast for 2020 • 20 basis point decrease in gross margin for the year • 19% full-year tax rate • 13% to 14% adjusted earnings per share growth forecast for 2021. Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I will commence today by examining guest cruise activities and providing an overview of our first quarter financial flows.
Subsequently, I will share an update on reservation trends and conclude with projections for adjusted EBITDA and net profit.
Let's now focus on guest cruise operations.
In the initial quarter of 2022, we resumed operations on 10 more vessels, resulting in 60% of our fleet capacity being operational for guest cruises throughout the entire first quarter.
This marked a significant increase from 54% during the final quarter of 2021.
As of now, 75% of our fleet capacity has resumed guest cruise operations.
Our ability to continually adjust to the ever-changing environment has been one of our key strengths throughout the pandemic.
During the first quarter, we continued to demonstrate this flexibility by adjusting restart dates to optimize our guest cruise operations.
We now anticipate that each brand's entire fleet will be operational for their respective summer seasons, which historically generate the majority of our operating income.
I'm pleased to announce that just last week, we revealed plans to restart operations in Australia at the end of May, following the government's announcement that cruising would be permitted from April.
The occupancy rate for the first quarter was 54% across operational ships.
We didn't expect to achieve our historical occupancy rates of over 100% for the first quarter, as many of these voyages were confirmed only a few months before departure, resulting in shorter than usual booking lead times.
Nevertheless, we had anticipated first quarter occupancy would surpass the 58% achieved in the fourth quarter of 2021.
We began the quarter with over 55% cabin occupancy booked and expected to improve upon that during the quarter.
However, during the first quarter of 2022, the Omicron variant impacted bookings for near-term sailings, leading to higher cancellations due to increased pre-travel positive test results, challenges in obtaining timely pre-travel tests, and the disruption Omicron caused to society during this period.
These factors hindered our ability to build on our cabin occupancy book position for the first quarter of 2022, resulting in a 54% occupancy rate, lower than the 58% achieved in the fourth quarter of 2021.
Despite these challenges, we hosted over one million guests during the first quarter, representing nearly a 20% increase from the fourth quarter of 2021.
Once again, our brands performed exceptionally well, with Net Promoter Scores remaining elevated compared to pre-COVID levels.
Revenue per passenger day for the first quarter of 2022 increased by approximately 7.5% compared to the strong performance in 2019, despite the absence of our lucrative world cruises and exotic voyages this year.
Our revenue management teams maintained pricing when we experienced an impact on bookings for near-term sailings, optimizing our long-term prospects for future revenue and pricing.
Once more, our onboard and other revenue per diems significantly increased in the first quarter of 2022 compared to the same period in 2019, partly due to bundled packages and onboard credits used by guests from cruises canceled during the pause.
We experienced substantial growth in onboard and other per diems on both sides of the Atlantic.
Onboard revenue growth was primarily driven by increases in bar, casino, retail, spa, and internet services.
In recent years, we've seen a growing trend of guests selecting more comprehensive package options.
The benefits of these all-inclusive packages will ultimately be reflected in our onboard and other revenue streams.
These bundled packages have made it harder to distinguish between passenger ticket revenue and onboard spending.
For accounting purposes, we divide the total guest payment between these two categories.
Consequently, our total cruise revenue metrics provide the best indication of our overall performance.
Regarding expenses, our adjusted cruise cost excluding fuel per available lower berth day (ALBD) increased by 25% in Q1 2022.
I've used the term "adjusted cruise costs" instead of "net cruise costs," which we previously employed.
The calculation method for adjusted cruise costs and net cruise costs remains identical.
Five main factors contributed to the rise in adjusted cruise costs without fuel per ALBD: partial fleet pause, restart expenses, increased dry dock activity, enhanced health and safety measures, and inflation.
Due to partial fleet pause and increased dry dock days in Q1, costs were spread over fewer ALBDs.
The second quarter will see another doubling of dry dock days compared to 2019, impacting adjusted cruise cost without fuel per ALBD.
We expect many of these cost-increasing factors to cease in 2022 and not recur in 2023.
Given these factors, we anticipate a significant improvement in adjusted cruise costs excluding fuel per ALBD from H1 2022 to H2 2022, with a projected low double-digit increase for the full year 2022 compared to 2019.
I will now present an overview of our first quarter cash flows.
Our liquidity at the end of Q1 2022 was $7.2 billion, down from $9.4 billion at the end of Q4.
We believe our current liquidity position remains strong.
The change in liquidity during the quarter was primarily due to four factors: firstly, an improved negative adjusted EBITDA of $1 billion, resulting from the resumption of cruise operations despite the omicron variant's impact.
We had anticipated a greater improvement in adjusted EBITDA, but the omicron variant hindered our ability to increase occupancy, limiting the improvement.
Secondly, we invested $400 million in capital expenditures, net of export credits.
Thirdly, we made $500 million in debt principal payments.
The fourth item was $400 million in interest expenses for the quarter.
Let's examine reservation patterns.
Booking volumes for upcoming voyages have shown an upward trend since mid-January.
Recent weekly booking numbers have reached their highest levels since the resumption of passenger cruise operations.
We improved our booked occupancy for the latter half of 2022 during the first quarter, though not at the usual pace of a typical wave season due to the omicron variant.
Consequently, the cumulative advanced booking position for the second half of 2022 is at the lower end of the historical range.
Nevertheless, we believe we are well-positioned with our current second half 2022 booking status, given the recent increase in reservation volumes, coupled with closer-in booking patterns and our anticipation of an extended wave season.
We anticipate that occupancy will gradually increase throughout 2022 and return to historical levels in 2023.
Notably, I'm pleased to report that prices for these bookings in the second half of 2022 remain higher, with or without future cruise credits (FCCs), adjusted for bundled packages, compared to 2019 sailings.
Our cumulative advanced booking position for the first half of 2023 remains at the higher end of the historical range, also at increased prices with or without FCCs, normalized for bundled packages, compared to 2019 sailings.
This is a significant accomplishment, considering that pricing for 2019 sailings is a challenging comparison as it was a peak year for historical yields.
I'll conclude with our adjusted EBITDA and net income projections.
We recognize that booking trends are a key indicator of our business's health.
With improved recent booking trends leading the way and driving customer deposits higher, positive adjusted EBITDA is within reach.
We expect ship-level cash contribution to grow in the coming months as more vessels return to service and we increase our occupancy percentages.
However, as mentioned, adjusted EBITDA for the first half of 2022 has been or will be affected by restart-related spending and dry dock expenses, as 39 ships, over 40% of our fleet, will have undergone dry dock during the first half of fiscal 2022.
Considering all these factors, we anticipate monthly adjusted EBITDA to continue improving and become consistently positive at the start of our summer season.
We still expect a net loss for the second quarter of 2022 on both a U.S. GAAP and adjusted basis.
However, we anticipate a profit for the third quarter of 2022.
For the full year, we expect a net loss.
Looking ahead to brighter prospects in 2023, with the entire fleet back in service year-round, 8% more capacity than 2019, an improved fleet profile with nearly a quarter of our capacity consisting of newly delivered ships, continued momentum on our outstanding Net Promoter Scores, and occupancy returning to historical levels, we are eager to provide memorable vacation experiences to nearly 14 million guests and potentially generate greater adjusted EBITDA than in 2019.
Summary:
