input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Tom Ferguson, CEO; Philip Schlom, CFO; and David Nark, SVP of marketing, communications, and IR are participating in today's call.
The company faces various risks, including fluctuations in customer demand, raw material costs, political and economic conditions in its markets, currency exchange rates, financing availability, and the impact of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic on its customers and operations.
The third quarter marked our fifth consecutive period of strong performance following COVID-related disruptions in early 2020.
Their continued dedication has enabled us to achieve these impressive results.
Total revenue increased by 2.3% to nearly $232 million compared to last year, or 4.1% when accounting for the SMS divestiture.
The metal coatings division saw a 15.4% increase in sales to over $133 million, while infrastructure solutions experienced an 11% decrease to about $99 million.
We are satisfied with our strong quarterly performance.
Our consistent cash flow generation allowed us to return capital to shareholders this quarter.
We achieved a net income exceeding $21 million and earnings of $0.85 per diluted share, showcasing our businesses' resilience and our employees' commitment.
Our companies capitalized on last year's restructuring efforts to enhance profitability while maintaining their commitment to customer service and quality.
We also saw benefits from reduced interest expenses and a lower tax rate of 22% in the third quarter.
In line with our value creation strategy, we bought back over 148,000 shares for $7.6 million and paid out $4.2 million in dividends.
Our metal coatings division achieved a 24.5% operating margin on $133 million in sales.
This led to a 14% increase in operating income compared to the previous year.
The margin improvement was largely attributed to enhanced operational efficiency and productivity, along with better pricing despite rising costs for zinc, labor, and energy.
Despite ongoing COVID-related challenges, we successfully acquired Steel Creek Galvanizing in South Carolina.
This facility, completed in 2019, features extensive automation and is the most modern in our portfolio.
Our team is enthusiastic about the growth potential in this previously unserved region.
The metal coatings division continues to deliver excellent results while navigating labor shortages and rising costs.
Our infrastructure solutions segment showed continued improvement in profitability, benefiting from cost-cutting measures implemented last year.
Sales were down about 8% when accounting for the SMS divestiture.
The infrastructure solutions segment generated over $9 million in operating income, with margins improving by 140 basis points to 9.3% compared to the previous year.
The segment faced increasing labor constraints and material delays due to COVID-related supply chain disruptions, including customer-supplied components.
One international WSI project was significantly affected by a COVID outbreak, which was well-managed but resulted in lower profitability.
We remain committed to strategic sales initiatives across our electrical and industrial platforms and are optimistic about finishing the fiscal year strongly.
For fiscal year 2022, despite ongoing COVID-related uncertainties in various sectors, we are narrowing our earnings per share guidance based on strong performance in the first three quarters and a favorable outlook for the remainder of the year.
We expect annual sales between $865 million and $925 million, with earnings per diluted share ranging from $3 to $3.20.
The upcoming quarter is not expected to be significantly affected by the recent acquisition as we are concentrating on integration in these initial months.
The metal coatings division continues to prioritize expanding sales, including utilizing our spin galvanizing facilities at multiple locations, improving operational efficiency, and enhancing customer service as inflation drives up labor and operational costs.
Our infrastructure solutions division is guardedly optimistic as it begins the fourth quarter with some positive momentum in order activity, especially in the electrical sector.
The WSI division is seeing positive results from the expanded Polish facility, though internationally, the business still faces occasional project delays due to COVID-19 outbreaks at certain client locations.
As mentioned previously, some projects originally scheduled for autumn will now be completed in the fourth quarter.
We also have some projects typically slated for spring that are set to begin earlier than usual.
The electrical division is concentrating on operational efficiency and expanding its e-house and switchgear operations.
We anticipate better-than-usual performance in the fourth quarter due to project extensions from the third quarter.
Our outlook for the spring maintenance season is quite positive based on the number of quotations, but we remain cautious due to ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks at client sites.
For the remainder of fiscal year 2022, AZZ will continue to implement our strategic growth plans to increase shareholder value while preparing for a strong start to fiscal 2023.
We remain steadfast in our dedication to providing exceptional customer service.
Our strong cash flow generation is attributed to initiatives that promote operational excellence, strict cost management, maintaining pricing discipline, and emphasizing timely collection of receivables within our operational divisions.
We are certain that our businesses continue to be crucial for improving and maintaining infrastructure, so we persist in driving profitable growth and enhancing shareholder value.
Orders received in the third quarter totaled $248 million, an increase of $53.6 million or 28% compared to the same quarter in the previous year.
Our book-to-bill ratio remained steady at 107%, consistent with the previous quarter and significantly higher than the 0.86 ratio from the same quarter last year.
As Tom mentioned, we have observed consistently strong markets for our metal coatings segment and continue to see improving conditions in our infrastructure solutions segment.
Sales for the third quarter of fiscal 2022 were $231.7 million, an increase of $5.1 million or 2.3% compared to the prior year's third quarter sales of $226.6 million.
Compared to the same quarter last year, metal coatings segment sales increased by $17.8 million, which was partially offset by lower sales in the infrastructure solutions segment, primarily in the industrial division where we implemented significant restructuring measures in the middle of last year.
The company generated a gross profit of $57 million, compared to $54.7 million in the third quarter of the previous year.
Our gross margin for the third quarter was 24.6%, up from 24.1% in the same quarter last year, as both segments continue to show improvement.
Operating income for the quarter was $30.1 million, a $2.2 million or 8% improvement compared to $27.9 million in the third quarter of the previous year.
Our earnings per share were $0.85, which is $0.09 higher than the reported earnings per share of $0.76 and adjusted earnings per share of $0.80 in the third quarter of the previous year.
The previous year was affected by our loss on the divestiture of Southern Mechanical Services (SMS). EBITDA for the third quarter was $39.8 million, unchanged from the third quarter of the previous year.
Year-to-date sales through the third quarter of fiscal 2022 were $678 million, a 5.4% increase from the previous year's third quarter year-to-date sales of $643 million.
Excluding the impact of SMS divestitures, sales would have increased by 8.6% year-over-year on a pro forma basis.
Net income for fiscal 2022 year-to-date was $62.4 million, which is $38.9 million or 166% higher than the reported net income of $23.5 million for the same period in the previous year, and $23.1 million or 58.9% above the adjusted net income from the prior year-to-date period, during which the company had recorded impairment and restructuring charges, net of tax, of $15.8 million.
Earnings per share on a year-to-date diluted share basis is $2.48, compared to $0.90 reported in the previous year and $1.50 on an adjusted basis.
Current year-to-date earnings per share improved by $0.98 or 65.3% compared to the year-to-date 2021 results.
We maintain a robust financial position while continuing to provide returns to our investors through dividends and stock buybacks.
Key capital allocation details for the year are as follows.
At the quarter's end, total outstanding debt amounted to $192 million, comprising $150 million in senior notes due in 7 and 12 years, and $42 million drawn from our revolving credit facility.
This represents a $13 million increase in borrowings since the end of the previous fiscal year.
The rise in borrowings is primarily attributed to ongoing share repurchases, increased receivables, and higher inventory levels due to improved business volumes.
So far, we've invested $19.1 million in capital projects and expect to invest approximately $32 million this year, slightly less than our earlier projection of $35 million.
Ongoing supply chain issues have continued to affect and postpone our planned capital expenditures.
We bought back $7.6 million worth of outstanding shares during the quarter, and have repurchased 712,000 shares totaling $28.9 million year-to-date.
We have consistently declared and paid quarterly dividends.
For the nine-month period ending November 30, 2021, cash generated from operations totaled $49.7 million, a decrease of $9.7 million or 16.4% compared to the same period last year.
While higher earnings positively impacted operating cash flows, this was more than offset by increased receivables due to higher sales and increased inventories, mainly resulting from higher zinc costs in our metal coatings.
We remain active in mergers and acquisitions, having recently acquired a galvanizing operation in South Carolina that will enhance our Southeast presence and is expected to be profitable within its first year of operation, as Tom mentioned earlier.
We are closely monitoring several key indicators.
In the metal coating segment's Galvanizing business, we are closely watching fabrication and construction activity, material and labor cost inflation, and OSHA's COVID vaccine mandate.
For the surface technologies platform, our main focus is on expanding our customer base and improving operational performance.
In infrastructure solutions, domestic turnaround and outage activity has normalized.
The upcoming spring season looks promising, though we remain cautious due to COVID, especially regarding international customers.
The electrical platform is benefiting from increased spending on transmission distribution and utilities, as well as growing activity in data centers and battery energy storage.
Regarding our strategic review of infrastructure solutions and our goal to become primarily a metal coatings company, we have made significant progress on a few strategic options aimed at achieving this objective.
Due to confidentiality agreements, we cannot provide further details at this time.
We remain committed to our metal coatings growth strategy and aim to achieve 21% to 23% operating margins, with galvanizing performance remaining stable while we continue to enhance Surface Technologies.
We will continue to pursue acquisitions, particularly in metal coatings, and hope to complete one more before the end of this fiscal year.
For infrastructure solutions, our focus is on profitability and cash flow.
This segment should benefit from more typical turnaround outage seasons and strong markets for renewables, transmission and distribution, utilities, battery energy storage, data center e-houses, and switchgear.
We released our inaugural ESG report last quarter and will continue to strive for improvement in these areas.
Lastly, while we typically provide guidance for the upcoming fiscal year at this time, we will not be doing so for fiscal year 2023.
Although we are committed to providing sales and earnings per share guidance, we may not be able to do so until we can incorporate the results of our work on strategic options.
Summary:

azz inc - qtrly sales of $231.7 million, up 2.3% versus last year.
azz inc - reaffirming fiscal year 2022 sales guidance and anticipate annual sales to be in the range of $865 million to $925 million.
azz inc - sees earnings per share to be in the range of $3.00 to $3.20 per diluted share for fiscal year 2022.

Context:You can access mdu.com and navigate to the Investors section.
Dave Goodin, MDU Resources' President and CEO, and I will be heading up today's quarterly earnings call.
While the company believes its expectations are founded on reasonable assumptions, the actual outcomes may vary significantly.
In Q2 2021, we achieved earnings of $100.2 million or $0.50 per share, which is comparable to Q2 2020's earnings of $99.7 million, also at $0.50 per share.
Our quarterly results were affected by increased stock-based compensation and healthcare expenses, amounting to roughly $4.2 million after tax.
Our Q2 consolidated results were additionally impacted by a $5.4 million decrease in investment returns on certain benefit plans compared to the same period in 2020.
Despite these factors influencing the quarter's performance, all our operations showed strong performance in the first half of the year, with consolidated revenues growing by 3.5% and earnings increasing by $27.5 million year-to-date.
Our utility operations earned $9.6 million in Q2, down from $11.2 million in Q2 2020.
The Electric Utilities segment reported earnings of $10.3 million for the quarter, a decrease from $12.2 million in the same period last year.
The decline in earnings was primarily due to higher operation and maintenance costs, including increased labor-related expenses such as stock-based compensation and healthcare, as mentioned earlier, as well as higher generating station expenses.
Reduced benefit plan investment returns also negatively affected the results.
The decrease was partially offset by improved adjusted gross margin, driven by a 6.9% rise in retail sales volumes.
During the quarter, sales volumes increased for industrial and commercial customers but decreased for residential customers as COVID-19 pandemic effects began to reverse and people returned to work with businesses reopening.
The adjusted gross margin also benefited from higher demand revenues and increased revenues associated with transmission interconnect projects.
Our natural gas utility segment reported a reduced seasonal loss of $700,000, an improvement from the $1 million seasonal loss in the same period last year.
The quarter saw an increase in adjusted gross margin due to approved rate recovery and 2% customer growth.
Transportation revenues also rose due to higher volumes transported to the company's electric generation customers.
The decreased loss was partially offset by higher operation and maintenance expenses, mainly labor-related costs as previously mentioned, and lower returns on certain benefit plan investments.
The pipeline business earned $9.2 million in Q2, slightly up from $9 million in Q2 2020.
The increase in earnings was primarily driven by higher nonregulated project revenues and increased allowance for funds used during construction.
This increase was partially offset by higher operation and maintenance expenses related to the previously mentioned increase in nonregulated projects and higher payroll costs.
Let's now discuss the construction businesses.
Construction services reported record Q2 earnings of $28.9 million, surpassing the previous year's record of $27.9 million.
Sales revenue reached a new second quarter record of $525.6 million, showing a 6% increase compared to the same period last year.
The need for construction services remains strong in both internal and external specialized contracting sectors.
There was robust demand for commercial and industrial work in interior specialized contracting, particularly in manufacturing, while exterior contracting saw increased workloads due to high demand from the utility sector.
The rise in earnings was also attributed to reduced depreciation, depletion, and amortization expenses, resulting from decreased intangible amortization related to earlier acquisitions.
Our construction materials division reported earnings of $51.4 million for the second quarter, compared to $53 million in the same quarter of the previous year.
Income increased by 2% to $633.8 million.
The drop in earnings was mainly due to higher selling, general, and administrative expenses from increased labor-related costs, as previously discussed.
The quarter was also impacted by lower returns on certain benefit plans.
These factors were partially offset by reduced interest expenses resulting from lower average interest rates.
This concludes the financial highlights for the quarter.
I will now go through each of our business segments to highlight some notable drivers in the quarter and provide more details about the organic growth items mentioned in yesterday's press release.
We'll begin with our regulated energy delivery platform.
Our electric and natural gas utility businesses now serve approximately 1.15 million customers.
Our utility employees continue to focus on organic growth and infrastructure improvements to safely and efficiently serve our customers.
We anticipate strong customer growth across our service area, surpassing the national average and ranging between 1% and 2% compound annual growth.
The electric utility completed the decommissioning activities on the coal-fired Unit I at the Lewis & Clark generating station in the second quarter and began decommissioning in July.
We plan to retire Units I and II at Heskett Station near Mandan, North Dakota early next year, which are the company's last wholly owned coal-fired facilities.
Our generation portfolio's nameplate capacity before these retirements was 48% coal and will decrease to 31% in 2023 upon completion of the proposed Heskett IV natural gas-fired peaking unit.
Our natural gas utility, along with our pipeline business, WBI Energy, recently announced a project to increase natural gas service to Wahpeton, North Dakota, while also providing natural gas service for the first time to Kindred, North Dakota.
This project is driven by customer contracts requiring more firm natural gas supply than our current infrastructure can provide to Eastern North Dakota.
The project involves building approximately 60 miles of 12-inch pipeline from our existing facilities at Mapleton, North Dakota to Wahpeton.
It will add 20 million cubic feet per day of natural gas capacity and is estimated to cost about $75 million.
Subject to regulatory approvals, construction is expected to start in early 2024 with completion later that year.
Regarding our pipeline operations, we're thrilled that WBI Energy received final FERC authorization in early July, permitting the commencement of construction on the North Bakken expansion project in Western North Dakota
This $260 million endeavor will increase our system's daily natural gas transportation capacity by 250 million cubic feet, elevating WBI's total pipeline capacity to over 2.4 Bcf per day, while helping to mitigate natural gas flaring in the area and enabling Bakken producers to transport natural gas to market
Work commenced here in mid-July
Given favorable weather conditions during the building period, we anticipate the project to be operational by year-end
Let's now discuss Construction
Our Construction Services Group experienced an exceptional second quarter, with robust demand for both interior and exterior specialized contracting
CSG reported unprecedented second quarter revenues and earnings, along with a record-breaking backlog of $1.32 billion at the end of June
Competition remains fierce in all sectors, but we're confident that our customer relationships, skilled workforce, and service quality will help us secure and execute profitable projects
As a reminder, revenue projections for this business in 2021 remain between $2.1 billion and $2.3 billion, with margins similar to or slightly better than 2020
Lastly, at our construction materials division, despite a slight year-over-year decline in earnings, Knife River is performing near record levels, narrowly missing last year's record second quarter earnings while continuing to generate record revenues
Demand and pricing for aggregates and ready-mix concrete are strong across several markets
Construction materials reported a backlog of $912 million at quarter-end, a 4% increase from the previous year
Revenue projections for this business also range from $2.1 billion to $2.3 billion, with margins comparable to our 2020 levels
We remain optimistic about our construction businesses and continue to explore strategic acquisition opportunities that will enhance our existing footprint and appropriately expand our operations, while earning attractive returns on invested capital
As mentioned in yesterday's news release, we are very positive about the discussions surrounding infrastructure funding packages at both federal and state levels across our operational areas
With combined construction backlog at an all-time high of $2.23 billion as of June 30, we believe we are well-positioned to capitalize on these multi-year growth opportunities
While we believe these infrastructure proposals will provide additional opportunities in some of our core business areas, such as surface transportation improvements, renewable energy, power grid modernization, broadband, and more, these proposals are not included in our earnings per share guidance of $2 to $2.15 for 2021 or in our 5-year capital investment plan
Overall, we are very satisfied with our performance in the first half of the year
MDU Resources' focus has been and continues to be on generating significant long-term value through the execution of our business plans, organic growth projects, and targeted acquisitions
We maintain a strong balance sheet, solid credit ratings, and a good liquidity position
For the past 83 consecutive years, we have provided a competitive dividend for our shareholders and have increased it for the last 30 years
As always, MDU Resources is dedicated to operating with integrity and prioritizing safety while creating superior shareholder value, and we continue to act in accordance with our tagline of Building a Strong America
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'll highlight our 2020 achievements, outline my projections for 2021, and discuss our future plans.
Stephen will then provide a detailed analysis of our fourth quarter results and 2021 forecast.
We ended the year on a high note with fourth quarter performance surpassing expectations.
Despite the challenges and uncertainties of the pandemic year, we delivered another robust quarter.
Our operations showcased flexibility and determination to produce excellent financial outcomes, despite revenue pressures and declines in some of our target markets.
This trend persisted throughout the year.
We promptly implemented measures to protect our employees' health and safety at the start of 2020.
Our teams worked diligently to adapt our manufacturing and supply chains multiple times during the year to meet our customers' evolving needs.
We excelled in serving customers while continuing to enhance efficiency and productivity.
We acted swiftly to manage expenses effectively.
As a result, we delivered exceptional margins for our shareholders, generated strong free cash flow, and strengthened our balance sheet.
Notably, our customer performance metrics reached record levels in service, punctual delivery, and quality.
We achieved the best safety record in the company's history by year-end.
Our factory productivity and supply chain initiatives contributed significantly to our financial success.
We also managed to introduce several employee training and development programs.
I'm particularly impressed by how our employees found ways to work safely and innovate, not just to complete tasks, but to improve our processes.
It's no coincidence that we completed over 100 Lean Kaizen improvement projects in 2020, despite the constraints of social distancing, remote work, and COVID-19 precautions.
In December, we acknowledged these achievements by awarding all our employees worldwide, except the executive team, a $1,000 appreciation bonus.
I'm proud of how our employees united to support each other, work safely during the pandemic, and continue to deliver excellent results for customers.
Let me now share some thoughts on the outlook for this year and beyond.
Our Machine Clothing segment's target markets seem to be improving.
We finished last year with a strong order book, which is promising for this year and beyond as the global economy recovers.
As a leader in machine clothing, we're well-positioned to grow with our customers, particularly in the expanding tissue and packaging sectors.
Our long-standing strategy of continuous investment in technology and product development, coupled with operational discipline, has proven beneficial during the worst market downturn in over a decade.
Consider this: during a global pandemic recession, our MC segment increased its adjusted EBITDA margin by 170 basis points in 2020.
Even more impressively, since 2015, our MC segment has expanded its adjusted EBITDA margin by over 500 basis points.
We're also optimistic about our Engineered Composites segment's future, although it's a longer-term prospect as 2021 is expected to face challenges from the pandemic and the downturn in commercial aerospace and air travel.
Throughout 2021, we anticipate slower production on some AEC lines due to excess inventory in our facilities and in our customers' supply chains, particularly for components of the Boeing 737 MAX, 787, and to a lesser extent, the F-35.
To continue managing costs, and in response to Boeing's recent downward revision of 787 demand, we implemented a workforce reduction in our Salt Lake City facility, where we produce 787 frames, just yesterday.
While 2021 is expected to be slower due to inventory reduction, we anticipate long-term growth in Engineered Composites.
We're well-positioned in both military and commercial markets with solid programs such as the CH-53K, JASSM missile, F-35, and LEAP.
Our position on LEAP engines with Safran should see early growth in the recovery, as narrow-body aircraft, which the LEAP engine powers, are expected to lead commercial aerospace out of the recession, with domestic air travel likely to recover first.
Now, let me discuss our strategy.
Albany International has a 125-year history of innovation and developing new materials that benefit our customers.
We're committed to continuing this legacy by focusing on developing the next generation of engineered materials and advanced composites to help our customers enhance their products and production processes.
Our Machine Clothing segment leads in PMC by offering a comprehensive range of advanced material belts used on paper machines, which operate at high speeds in harsh environments.
We've built a reputation for continuously improving our belt technology, durability, and performance.
Our advancements enable our customers to produce higher quality paper products reliably at lower overall production costs under demanding conditions.
This technology-intensive collaborative partnership is highly valued by our customers.
In our Engineered Composites segment, we continue to advance the state of the art in advanced composites, including our proprietary 3D woven composite material used in LEAP engine fan blades and cases.
In 2020, despite the pandemic, we collaborated closely with Safran to further improve our 3D woven composite materials and reduce manufacturing costs, ensuring we'll be even more competitive as commercial aerospace rebounds.
We also expanded our collaboration with new customers and for new applications to diversify our customer base and develop future growth areas.
Our technology development for the Wing of Tomorrow program with Airbus has continued through the pandemic.
While this program is longer-term, it's crucial that we secure an early position and contribute our technology to design the next generation of aircraft.
In the medium and near term, we have other ongoing R&D efforts, which I call incubator projects, in both military and commercial areas.
For instance, our R&D team is supporting a major prime OEM in developing next-generation hypersonic materials and structures using our proprietary 3D woven composite materials.
We also have projects in unmanned vehicles, higher temperature materials, and thermoplastics.
We believe the current downturn in commercial aerospace is temporary and that long-term market forces will drive energy efficiency and continued replacement of metallic components with lighter composites.
This trend will become more important as the industry seeks to reduce its environmental impact with the next generation of more efficient aircraft.
Our commercially proven 3D woven composite technology can meet the need for lighter weight and high strength, and we intend to increase our participation in the most demanding structural applications in aerospace.
As a company, we remain committed to investing in technology and product development of advanced materials for organic growth.
In fact, we're increasing our R&T budgets in both segments in 2021.
This is a crucial part of our capital allocation strategy.
Organic growth has been driven not only by our investment in hard capital such as new products, tooling, and production equipment but also by our investment in intellectual capital - the expertise, time, and effort necessary for successfully developing new products and process know-how over time.
We employ a disciplined approach to investments and success metrics.
Our capital allocation decisions are guided by anticipated shareholder returns, prioritizing projects with the best risk-adjusted outcomes.
Overall, we feel positive about what lies ahead.
Our robust financial position and strong cash flow enable ongoing growth investments.
I'll now pass the presentation to Stephen.
I will discuss the quarterly results followed by our initial business outlook for the upcoming year.
Q4 total company revenue was $226.9 million, down 12% from $257.7 million in the same period last year.
Excluding currency effects, net sales dropped 13.6% year-over-year this quarter.
In Machine Clothing, after accounting for currency impacts, net sales decreased 6.6% year-over-year, with declines across most major product categories, partly offset by engineered fabrics growth.
Publication grades saw the largest decline at over 21% on a constant currency basis, accounting for about 17% of our MC sales this quarter.
Nevertheless, we observe indications of an improving machine clothing market overall.
While packaging and tissue grades declined year-over-year this quarter due to factors mentioned in Q3, the decreases were significantly smaller than in Q3.
Additionally, Q4 segment net sales exceeded Q3 and slightly surpassed our expectations.
Engineered Composites net sales, adjusted for currency effects, fell 23.5% compared to last year, mainly due to significant reductions in LEAP and Boeing 787 program revenue, partially offset by growth in F-35 and CH-53K platforms.
This quarter's ASC LEAP program generated nearly $25 million in revenue, compared to $48 million in the same quarter last year.
However, Q4 ASC LEAP revenue increased substantially from Q3, rising 48% as all three ASC LEAP facilities operated for the full quarter.
The company's Q4 gross profit was $91.3 million, a 5.5% decrease from the same period last year.
Overall gross margin improved by 280 basis points from 37.5% to 40.3% of net sales.
MC segment gross margin rose from 50.2% to 50.9% of net sales, driven by favorable exchange rates, increased efficiencies, and product mix.
AEC gross margin improved from 19.6% to 21.7% of net sales, primarily due to favorable program revenue mix, partially offset by a smaller net favorable change in long-term contract profitability.
We recognized a $500,000 net favorable change in estimated long-term contract profitability this quarter, compared to a $3.3 million improvement in Q4 2019.
Q4 selling, technical, general and research expenses increased from $51.3 million to $54.8 million year-over-year, and rose from 19.9% to 24.1% of net sales.
The expense increase was mainly due to higher incentive compensation and increased foreign currency revaluation losses, partially offset by reduced travel expenses.
The higher incentive compensation in Q3 and Q4 2020 included $3.9 million in corporate accruals for the special $1,000 employee bonus mentioned by Bill.
Total company operating income was $35.0 million, down from $43.6 million in the prior year quarter.
Machine Clothing operating income decreased by $4.9 million due to lower gross profit, higher STG&R expense, and increased restructuring costs, while AEC operating income fell by $2.1 million due to lower gross profit and higher STG&R expense, partially offset by lower restructuring costs.
Other income and expense in the quarter resulted in net income of $490,000 compared to a $350,000 expense in the same period last year.
The improvement was primarily due to more favorable foreign currency revaluation effects.
The Q4 income tax rate was 13.5% compared to 24.8% in the prior year quarter.
Due to a foreign currency revaluation gain at an entity with no tax provision requirement, the tax rate for adjusted earnings per share is slightly higher at 17.8%.
This 17.8% tax rate is significantly lower than the full-year rate.
For the entire 2020, our tax rate, excluding discrete items, was 28.4%, compared to 28% for 2019.
The lower Q4 rate, mainly due to adjustments of earlier quarters' provisions, increased adjusted earnings per share by $0.12.
If we had known the final full-year rate earlier, that $0.12 would have been recognized as additional adjusted earnings per share in previous quarters.
Q4 net income attributable to the company was $27.5 million, a 5.5% decrease from $29.1 million last year.
The reduction was primarily due to lower operating income, partially offset by the lower tax rate and improved other income and expense.
Earnings per share was $0.85 this quarter compared to $0.90 last year.
After adjusting for foreign currency revaluation effects, restructuring expenses, pension curtailment charges, and CirComp acquisition and integration costs, adjusted earnings per share was $0.89 this quarter compared to $0.97 last year.
Adjusted EBITDA decreased 10.4% to $57.3 million for the most recent quarter compared to the same period last year.
Machine Clothing adjusted EBITDA was $50.9 million, or 35.3% of net sales, down from $52.8 million, or 35.1% of net sales, in the prior year quarter.
AEC adjusted EBITDA was $21.3 million, or 25.7% of net sales, down from last year's $24.2 million, or 22.6% of net sales.
Regarding our balance sheet, net debt decreased by about $46 million in Q4.
Consequently, our absolute leverage ratio dropped from 0.89 at the end of Q3 to 0.74 at the end of Q4.
The net debt reduction was mainly due to strong Machine Clothing segment operating cash flow and lower capital expenditures, primarily from reduced LEAP program spending.
Now I'll discuss our expectations for the coming year by comparing it to 2020 and providing initial 2021 financial guidance.
We anticipate another strong performance year in the Machine Clothing segment.
For the full year 2020, we achieved net sales of about $573 million, down 5% from about $601 million in 2019.
Q4 2020 orders increased about 6% compared to Q4 2019.
This marked a significant change from the first three quarters when cumulative segment orders had decreased compared to 2019.
This trend gives us confidence as we enter 2021.
We expect Q1 2021 sales to increase compared to the relatively low Q1 2020 levels.
Our initial net sales guidance for the segment is $570 million to $590 million.
Machine Clothing had an exceptionally profitable year in 2020, generating $216 million in adjusted EBITDA.
Three factors will make it challenging to achieve similar results in 2021.
As previously mentioned, we benefited from favorable foreign exchange rates in 2020, particularly with the weak Brazilian real and Mexican peso, currencies in which we have more expenses than revenues.
Overall, favorable exchange rates added over $6 million to adjusted EBITDA in 2020 compared to 2019 rates.
However, some of these beneficial effects had diminished by year-end.
For instance, the Mexican peso weakened from under 20 pesos per U.S. dollar in Q1 2020 to almost 25 in Q2, but returned to under 20 by year-end.
In 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we experienced significantly reduced travel expenses in the segment compared to previous years.
While this boosted the bottom line by about $6 million, it wasn't ideal for business, as we rely on strong customer relationships to understand their needs and drive product development and support.
We anticipate resuming our previous level of travel in 2021, although Q1 travel may still be affected by COVID.
We continue to face pressure on input costs, particularly in logistics where sea, rail, and air freight expenses are much higher than 12 months ago.
Typically, we experience over $4 million in input cost pressure annually, and there's reason to believe this could be higher in 2021.
As usual, we expect to be unable to recover all of the increased costs through price increases.
We will, of course, strive to implement cost-saving measures to offset as much of the remainder as possible.
Despite these three pressures on profitability, we expect the Machine Clothing segment to have another strong year of profit performance and are providing initial adjusted EBITDA guidance of $195 million to $205 million for the segment.
For Engineered Composites, 2020 was a difficult year in terms of revenue.
Overall, segment revenue declined by about $125 million in 2020 compared to 2019, mainly due to lower sales on LEAP, 787, and other commercial programs, offset by growth in military programs.
Unfortunately, 2021 will see a continuation of some of these trends, with the year shaping up to be one of finished goods inventory destocking across our customers' supply chains.
For the ASC LEAP program, we expect to continue producing components for the LEAP-1B variant, which powers the 737 MAX, at very low levels.
Although the 737 MAX is re-entering service, there's considerable finished goods inventory in the channel at Boeing, Safran, and our own facilities, on which we've already recognized revenue as we do so at the time of production, not delivery.
In 2021, we currently expect to make components for fewer than 150 LEAP-1B engines, far below the 1,000-plus engine shipsets we'd expect to deliver annually in the long term.
For LEAP-1A, there's much less finished goods inventory in the channel, and we expect to produce components for well over 500 engine shipsets in 2021.
Overall, while the total number of ASC LEAP engine shipsets produced in 2021 is expected to be somewhat higher than in 2020, this is offset by the absence of certain recoverable non-recurring expenses recognized as revenue in 2020, resulting in roughly flat revenues for ASC from 2020 to 2021.
Our next largest commercial program, producing frames for the Boeing 787, also faces finished goods inventory destocking challenges.
In 2020, we had already seen some effect from Boeing's decision to reduce the 787 build rate, and our revenues from the program in 2020 were down over 20% from 2019.
However, as Boeing further reduced the 787 build rate, there has been an increased buildup of our finished goods in Boeing's supply chain, resulting in drastic reductions in order quantities for delivery in 2021.
Additionally, we expect our start-up of production of the 787 aft fuselage frames will now shift from late 2021 into mid-2022 as it will take longer to consume the parts already in the supply chain that were produced by the previous supplier.
Overall, in 2021, we expect our revenues on the 787 frames program to be $30 million to $35 million lower than in 2020.
On the military side, we support the Lockheed Martin F-35 through several contracts for different parts, including wing skins, edge seals, and engine components at both our Salt Lake City and Boerne locations.
F-35 has been and remains a very important platform for us.
In 2020, we recognized over $85 million of revenue on the platform overall, up more than 25% from 2019.
However, during 2020, Lockheed Martin produced finished F-35s at a lower rate than originally predicted due to pandemic-related supply chain issues and consumed fewer sustainment parts.
As a result, during 2020, there was a buildup of our finished goods in the F-35 supply chain; a situation we expect will reverse in 2021.
This year, to rebalance the supply chain, we expect our build rate will be lower than Lockheed Martin's aircraft completion rate.
We now expect our F-35 revenues in 2021 to be more than $15 million lower than in 2020.
We see similar patterns in several smaller commercial programs across the segment where the revenue on those programs in 2021 will be close to $15 million lower than in 2020.
All of these reductions will be offset by growth on other programs, most notably on the CH-53K.
Overall for the Engineered Composites segment, we are providing initial guidance for net sales of $275 million to $295 million.
Regarding Engineered Composites segment profitability, 2020 was a strong year with adjusted EBITDA margins over 26%, largely enabled by three factors: strong operating performance evidenced by about $10 million in net favorable adjustment to long-term contract profitability; a sales mix benefit as the majority of revenue decline from 2019 to 2020 was on the ASC LEAP program, which has a lower than average profit margin; and despite the revenue decline, there was limited loss of fixed cost absorption as the cost-plus nature of the ASC LEAP program allowed us to still recover all fixed costs of operating our three ASC facilities.
Unfortunately, those factors will not help us again in 2021.
The lower revenue in 2021 at our non-ASC facilities, especially our Salt Lake City operation where all our 787 work and most of our F-35 work is performed, will create upward pressure on plant overhead rates.
While we've announced a workforce reduction at our Salt Lake City facility, that alone won't offset these rate pressures.
In such an environment, it will be difficult to achieve the lower unit production costs required to deliver significant improvements to long-term contract profitability.
This is a change from recent years when growing revenue at our non-ASC facilities created a tailwind to long-term contract profitability.
In 2021, we'll see a product mix hit as the roughly $40 million to $50 million revenue decline we expect this year is on fixed price programs, which have a higher than average profit margin.
Unlike 2020, we'll suffer from a loss of fixed cost absorption due to the fixed price nature of the programs with declining revenues.
As a result, the decremental margins will be much larger than the average margins on those programs.
It's not unusual for our fixed price programs to have EBITDA contribution margins in the 30% to 40% range.
Due to the impact of these three factors in 2021, we expect not only the top line reduction discussed earlier but also EBITDA margins for the segment to fall from the 26.1% level delivered in 2020 into the low 20s.
Therefore, we are providing initial 2021 guidance for Engineered Composites adjusted EBITDA of $55 million to $65 million.
At the company level, we are providing initial 2021 guidance as follows: revenue between $850 million and $890 million; effective income tax rate of 28% to 30%; depreciation and amortization between $70 million and $75 million; capital expenditures of $50 million to $60 million; GAAP and adjusted earnings per share between $2.40 and $2.80; and adjusted EBITDA between $195 million and $220 million.
While we're not providing explicit cash flow guidance for 2021, we expect the free cash flow we generate in 2021 will be well above the roughly $100 million generated in 2020.
In 2021, we expect R&D expenses to be more than 25% higher than in 2020, reflecting ongoing investments in both segments mentioned earlier.
We are very pleased with the company's overall performance in 2020.
Despite challenging operating environments, both segments met customer needs and delivered outstanding performance while maintaining a safe working environment.
Although it appears we have one more year of channel destocking ahead before returning to growth in the Engineered Composites segment, we remain very excited about the future prospects for both segments.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $0.85.
q4 sales fell 12 percent to $226.9 million.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $0.89.
sees fy 2021 revenue $850 million to $890 million.
sees 2021 gaap and adjusted earnings per share of between $2.40 and $2.80.
sees 2021 capital expenditures in range of $50 million to $60 million.
pred_output: 2020 was a challenging year due to the pandemic, but the company still delivered strong financial results. The Machine Clothing segment had a good year, with revenue down 5% from 2019. The Engineered Composites segment had a difficult year, with revenue down 20% from 2019. The company is providing guidance for 2021, with revenue expected to be between $850 million and $890 million, and adjusted EBITDA expected to be between $195 million and $220 million. input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Please refer to Slide 2 for additional details on calculating these pro forma metrics.
Pro forma comparisons for current and prior periods incorporate results from recent acquisitions and the PA Consulting investment.
We are also providing adjusted pro forma net revenue comparisons that exclude the impact of the extra week in Q4 fiscal 2020.
Let's move on to the agenda on Slide 3.
Steve will start by providing an update on our strategic progress and Jacobs' future ESG initiatives.
Bob will then discuss our performance across business lines.
Kevin will provide a more detailed analysis of our financial results, followed by updates on our Focus 2023 and M&A initiatives, as well as a review of our balance sheet and cash flow.
I will now hand it over to Steve Demetriou, our Chair and CEO.
Moving to Slide 4.
Before discussing our results, I'd like to mention that we're finalizing our new strategy.
We'll be holding an investor event in the week of March 7 to provide an in-depth look at the next phase of Jacobs' transformation.
Three key initiatives have been identified.
Firstly, we're implementing a purpose-driven plan, grounded in our values and strong culture, to maximize our next growth stage.
Secondly, we've identified and allocated investment resources to capitalize on three long-term growth opportunities: global infrastructure modernization, climate response, and industry digitization.
Thirdly, we're taking a transformative approach to seize these opportunities by unleashing Jacobs' innovation potential, expanding our technology ecosystem, and accelerating our trajectory of profitable growth and sustainable cash flow generation.
We're excited to unveil this strategy at our upcoming investor event.
Now, let's review our financial performance.
I'm satisfied with our strong fourth quarter and fiscal year results, with net revenue growing 7% year-over-year.
Adjusted EBITDA increased by 12% in the quarter and 18% for the full year.
Backlog at the end of the fourth quarter was up 12% year-over-year and 7% on a pro forma basis.
PA Consulting continued to deliver exceptional results with 41% revenue growth.
More importantly, PA achieved this growth while maintaining adjusted operating profit margins of 24%.
For the full year, PA's revenues exceeded $1 billion, significantly surpassing our deal investment model expectations.
Looking ahead, we now have certainty regarding unprecedented U.S. infrastructure funding with the recent passage of the $1.2 trillion Infrastructure and Jobs Act.
More broadly, global infrastructure modernization and national security needs are accelerating as our government and commercial clients address climate change challenges, advance digitization strategies, and tackle increasing cyber threats.
Additionally, our advanced facilities business is expected to show significant growth, driven by demand for additional semiconductor manufacturing capacity and post-pandemic life sciences priorities.
Given these strong growth dynamics, we're introducing fiscal 2022 guidance for double-digit adjusted EBITDA growth.
Looking beyond 2022, we anticipate our strong organic growth will result in approximately $10 per share of adjusted earnings per share in fiscal year 2025.
Moving to Slide 5.
Reflecting on climate change, it's globally recognized that humanity is at a critical juncture in efforts to limit global warming.
Jacobs and PA participated in the recent UN Climate Change Conference COP26 in Glasgow to demonstrate our commitment to reinventing tomorrow through immediate and sustained action in transitioning to a net-zero economy.
We stood alongside business, financial, and government leaders, as well as activists and students, to ensure our voice was heard.
We engaged in activities to accelerate solutions to keep the world on track to meet the critical 1.5 degree Celsius trajectory, while preparing to adapt to inevitable climate change impacts.
Turning to Slide 6, given our business nature, Jacobs' greatest opportunity to positively address climate change comes from the sustainable and resilient solutions we co-create and deliver with our clients.
To lead this effort, we've established a new Office of Global Climate Response and ESG to ensure sustainability is integrated into all our solutions across markets and geographies.
We're accelerating our established partnerships with public and private sectors to advance net-zero carbon outcomes, climate resilience, natural and social capital, and ESG business transformation, aligning with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
We currently generate approximately $5 billion in ESG-related revenue annually and expect significant growth over the next several years, driven by strong capabilities in energy transition, decarbonization, climate adaptation, and natural resource stewardship.
Our culture is a competitive advantage.
Our people possess the knowledge, curiosity, and client trust to fulfill our purpose of creating a more connected, sustainable world.
Moving to Slide 7 to review Critical Mission Solutions.
During the fourth quarter, our CMS business maintained its strong performance.
Total CMS backlog increased 16% year-over-year, 7% on a pro forma basis, to $10.6 billion, driven by strategic new wins in cyber and intel, and nuclear and remediation.
Our CMS strategy focuses on creating recurring revenue growth and margin expansion by offering technology-enabled solutions aligned with critical national priorities.
Three market trends we see offering continued strong growth include cyber, commercial space, and 5G technology for national security.
Starting with cyber and intelligence, we're observing several major emerging threats to national security.
First, cyber attacks on mission-critical infrastructure, which are increasingly stealthy and as disruptive as traditional attacks.
Second, the speed and complexity of near-peer threats, requiring real-time coordination between space and other domains as nation-state sponsored attacks intensify.
Third, the adoption of data-intensive AI-based applications is dramatically increasing the need for real-time data security and integrity.
Funding to address these threats is partially reflected in the unclassified federal government spending on cyber in FY '22, expected to exceed $20 billion, up 10% from the previous year.
We anticipate spending within classified budgets to be even higher.
During the quarter, we were awarded a $300 million, seven-year contract with the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency to modernize NGA's ability to rapidly gain and share insights from cross-domain inventory, including top-secret data classification.
Within the classified budget, we secured a $170 million, five-year new contract to develop highly secure and hardened software applications leveraging the latest advances in AI and machine learning.
We recently completed the BlackLynx acquisition, which provides software-enabled solutions for automating data collection at the edge and quickly gaining insights from extremely large volumes of structured and unstructured data.
Our strong presence across the DoD and intelligence community, along with our digital enablement center, will provide the momentum for BlackLynx to commercialize and scale their solutions, resulting in highly profitable recurring revenue.
We also recently announced a strategic investment and distribution agreement with HawkEye 360, which will enhance our digital intelligence suite of technologies with their RF spectrum analytics and collection automation offering.
Regarding space, with significant capital being infused into commercial space companies, space tourism is becoming more affordable, and other emerging opportunities such as satellite-based technologies and space debris impact assessment are accelerating.
We currently support commercial space companies with manufacturing process optimization, system and subsystem prototype work, and test facility studies and projects.
As commercial space matures, we are positioning our solutions for these emerging opportunities.
During the quarter, we were notified of a significant increase to the ceiling of our contract at Marshall Space Flight Center, which also supports Artemis and SLS.
The U.S. Space Force selected Jacobs for a five-year contract to provide software and system support for its Patriot Excalibur system, which coordinates scheduling, training, and status of U.S. Space Force aircraft.
Lastly, our telecom business had a strong quarter.
We anticipate the rollout of 5G investment from clients like AT&T, Verizon, DIRECTV, T-Mobile, and Dish Network to accelerate in 2022 and beyond.
The recently passed Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill allocates $2.5 billion for 5G implementation at U.S. military installations, while the Department of Defense is making significant investments in 5G technology to support national priorities
We anticipate continued strong demand for our offerings in 2022
The CMS sales pipeline remains strong, with over $30 billion in potential new business opportunities projected for the next 18 months, including $10 billion currently under evaluation and an improving profit margin outlook
Let's move on to Slide 8, where I'll review our People & Places Solutions division
We ended the year with solid financial results, achieving 7% year-over-year backlog growth and annual net revenue increases
I'll discuss our performance across the key areas of climate response, pandemic solutions, infrastructure modernization, and digitization
Let's begin with climate response
As the top-ranked global environmental consulting firm, Jacobs is spearheading efforts to mitigate climate change impacts, facilitate the transition to a clean energy net-zero economy, and provide rapid response to natural disasters
This quarter, Jacobs secured a multi-year contract with the U.S. Army's Engineer Research and Development Center to implement nature-based solutions that enhance climate resilience across Department of Defense facilities
Jacobs has been chosen to reimagine New York's Rikers Island, transforming the site through a comprehensive community revitalization project with a focus on equity, resilience, and multi-use development, incorporating our innovative social value analysis
As the initial phase of a 20-year citywide program, Jacobs' plan will consolidate four aging wastewater facilities into a state-of-the-art water resource recovery facility capable of processing 1 billion gallons per day, including a renewable energy hub
In the transportation sector, our experts have developed advanced charging technology enabling clients to transition to decarbonized operations, a key focus of economic stimulus packages
Our transit team continues to secure contracts supporting clients with asset, operational, and technology shifts towards green fleets
For instance, we recently won and initiated a hydrogen rail facility study with Caltrans
Our ongoing work with Brisbane Metro continues to showcase cutting-edge green transit solutions
With exponential growth predicted in the electric vehicle market, Jacobs has become the preferred firm for supporting leading EV battery and vehicle manufacturing companies worldwide
We've doubled our EV business in the past year and anticipate continued expansion
We also announced a strategic partnership and investment in Microgrid Labs, a provider of commercial fleet electrification and infrastructure solutions, including their proprietary SaaS platform
The transition to a green economy is driving increased investments in hydrogen and renewables
Our team is delivering diverse solutions for various clients, from our involvement in the Bacton Energy Hub Consortium in the U.K. to energy transmission plans for potential offshore wind development in the U.S. and additional contracts with Iberdrola's Renewables Avonlie Solar Farm and the Swanbank waste-to-energy facility in Australia
Turning to the theme of pandemic response
With ongoing supply chain disruptions, healthcare system challenges, and semiconductor chip shortages, Jacobs is gaining momentum with multi-year backlog across sectors, securing new wins in biopharma such as the next phase of a new $2 billion biotechnology facility
Jacobs has successfully won several healthcare opportunities in the U.S., Europe, and Australia as they reassess pandemic response operations
The most significant aspect of global supply chain disruption involves semiconductor shortages
As the world's leading technical services provider to the semiconductor industry, we are well-positioned for substantial growth in the electronics sector this year and expect our electronics business to accelerate further over the next several years
In fact, Jacobs is engineering several major investments for large chip manufacturers
Projects like Intel's new Arizona Fab, which Jacobs is designing, are scheduled to be fully operational in 2024
The new fab will manufacture Intel's most advanced process technology and represents the largest private investment in Arizona's history
Interconnected with climate response, pandemic solutions, infrastructure modernization, and digital transformation are driving long-term transformative growth with significant wins across all markets
Globally, we continue to secure pioneering transportation projects across all sectors and modes
In highways, we were recently selected by Transport for New South Wales, along with consortium partners, to undertake the $1.2 billion Warringah Freeway upgrade project to accommodate a third road crossing Sydney Harbour
In Ports and Maritime, we won the sustainable ports design and program management contract for King Abdul Aziz Port in Dammam, Saudi Arabia
In air transportation, we were chosen as the integrated program manager for the Solidarity Transport Hub in Poland, a greenfield airport and multimodal project including a high-speed rail network with an initial planned capacity of 45 million passengers
The program is of national significance and will set the benchmark for zero-carbon delivery, serving as a sustainable transportation platform for Eastern Europe's future travel demands
Our long-standing relationships and existing framework agreements supported major wins with U.S. State Departments of Transportation and Transport for London, reinforcing our market-leading position in solving our clients' most complex transportation challenges
In summary, we see continued investment across the P&PS client sectors
We are already experiencing exciting global wins in the first quarter of our new fiscal year, indicating that we are well-positioned to develop and deliver unmatched value and capability to our clients as investment momentum builds from the U.S. Infrastructure Act and other economic stimulus initiatives
Moving on to PA Consulting on Slide 9
As Steve mentioned, PA continues to exceed expectations, supported by an extension of consultative services to the U.K.'s National Health Service
PA's efforts have expanded into longer-term vaccine deployment, testing and tracing, and future pandemic preparedness planning
Additionally, PA's growth is being enhanced by recent digital solution wins for confidential U.S. biopharmaceutical clients in the areas of cell and gene therapy and next-generation patient care models
We continue to make progress on our synergy growth and long-term collaboration
The Jacobs-PA team recently secured a biotechnology manufacturing plant expansion project to provide an end-to-end lifecycle solution incorporating critical digitized clinical trial information into the process design and facility layout
Furthermore, we continue to receive joint strategic consultancy awards in the transportation sector globally
I look forward to our continued success with collaborative and integrated offerings for our customers
At COP26, PA showcased its deep ESG expertise and successfully unveiled its innovative EV battery charging technology, ChargePoint
Moreover, PA received industry recognition for their jointly developed COVID-19 awareness and situational intelligence tool with Unilever
The business exceeded current expansion targets for the year and is well-positioned for continued future growth
Let's turn to Slide 10 for a financial overview of fourth quarter results, followed by our fiscal year review
As we have previously communicated, our fiscal fourth quarter 2020 had 14 weeks compared to our normal 13-week quarters, which impacted our quarter year-over-year growth rate by 7% and our full year growth rate by 2%
Fourth quarter gross revenue increased 2% year-over-year, and net revenue was up 7%
Including the pro forma impact from all acquisitions and adjusting for the extra week in the previous year, net revenue was up 6% for the quarter
Adjusted gross margin in the quarter as a percentage of net revenue was 27.2%, up 370 basis points year-over-year
Consistent with last year, the year-over-year increase in gross margin was driven by a favorable revenue mix in both People & Places and CMS, as well as the benefit from PA Consulting, which has a strong accretive gross margin profile of nearly 50%
We will continue to focus on increasing gross margins as we bring higher-value solutions to market for our clients
Adjusted G&A as a percentage of net revenue increased year-over-year to 17%
Within G&A, during the quarter, we incurred an approximate $20 million or $0.12 per share charge related to a legal settlement cost, which affected both GAAP and our adjusted results
This charge was related to a CH2M legacy matter concerning a previously completed product advisory arrangement
GAAP operating profit was $252 million and was mainly impacted by $46 million of amortization from acquired intangibles
Adjusted operating profit was $303 million, up 17%
Our adjusted operating profit to net revenue was 10%, up 85 basis points year-over-year on a reported basis
GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations rounded to $0.34 per share and included $0.45 primarily related to U.K. statutory tax rate changes and other tax-related items, $0.40 related to the final mark-to-market of the Worley stock and related FX impact, $0.23 of net impact related to amortization of acquired intangibles, $0.10 of transaction and other related costs, and $0.06 from Focus 2023 and other restructuring costs
Excluding these items, fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share was $1.58, including the $0.12 burden from the previously discussed legal matter
PA's strong performance added $0.23 of accretion, net of additional interest, during the quarter.
Fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA reached $310 million, rising 12% compared to last year and accounting for 10% of net revenue.
Let's now discuss our bookings.
Our Q4 revenue book-to-bill ratio was 1.3, setting us up well for the anticipated growth momentum in fiscal year 2022.
We'll now review our full fiscal year 2021 results on Slide 11.
Gross revenue grew by 4% while net revenue increased by 7%.
Net revenue rose 3% for the entire year when considering the pro forma impact of all acquisitions and adjusting for the extra week in the previous year.
We've been improving our portfolio with higher-value solutions, as evidenced by the gross margin as a percentage of net revenue reaching 26% for the year, an increase of 235 basis points from the previous year.
We anticipate mid-single-digit reported revenue growth in Q1 of fiscal 2022, with faster growth in the second half driven by U.S. infrastructure spending and new awards in our CMS business.
GAAP operating profit totaled $688 million, primarily affected by $261 million in purchase price consideration for the PA Consulting investment and $150 million in amortization of acquired intangibles.
Adjusted operating profit grew 23% to $1.188 billion, representing 10% of net revenue.
Adjusted EBITDA increased 18% year-over-year to $1.244 billion, accounting for 10.6% of net revenue and slightly exceeding the midpoint of our revised fiscal 2021 outlook.
GAAP earnings per share was $3.12, impacted by several factors including PA Consulting purchase price consideration, amortization of acquired intangibles, U.K. tax changes, Focus 2023 charges, and partially offset by gains from the sale of Worley and C3.
Excluding these items, adjusted earnings per share reached $6.29, surpassing the midpoint of our updated outlook.
PA Consulting contributed $0.48 to the adjusted earnings per share figure.
Before discussing LOB performance, I'd like to mention our ongoing efforts to optimize our real estate footprint.
We anticipate a potential non-cash impairment charge of $60 million to $70 million in the first half of fiscal 2022 as we finalize the plan.
Our new office layout will support virtual work options, leveraging new technology and more collaborative spaces.
In Q4 2021, CMS revenue decreased by 5% year-over-year, but was relatively flat on a pro forma basis when adjusting for the extra week in Q4 2020.
The transition away from two lower-margin contracts impacted CMS revenue growth, resulting in a $175 million year-over-year revenue decrease during the quarter.
Excluding this contract roll-off and adjusting for the extra week last year, pro forma CMS revenue grew by double digits year-over-year.
We expect a $210 million year-over-year impact from these contract roll-offs in Q1 2022, which will end in Q2.
Consequently, we anticipate a slight year-over-year decrease in reported revenue for Q1 2022, despite stronger underlying growth.
We expect CMS growth to improve throughout the year, resulting in a mid-to-high single-digit full year 2022 growth rate.
CMS operating profit for Q4 increased by 7% to $115 million, with operating profit margin rising 100 basis points year-over-year to 9.1%.
For the full year, CMS operating profit grew 20% to $447 million, with an 8.8% operating profit margin.
The improvement in operating margin for both the quarter and the year was due to our focus on higher-margin opportunities across the business.
We expect the operating profit margin to remain in the mid-8% range throughout fiscal 2022.
Regarding People & Places, Q4 net revenue was unchanged year-over-year.
Accounting for the extra week, P&PS grew net revenue by approximately 8% year-over-year in Q4 and 2% for fiscal year 2021.
P&PS total operating profit decreased year-over-year in Q4 due to a $20 million legal settlement cost mentioned earlier.
Excluding this cost, operating profit would have increased by 8% in Q4.
For the fiscal year, operating profit rose by 5%, or 8% excluding the legal settlement.
PA's performance included $273 million in revenue and $66 million in operating profit for the quarter.
Q4 revenue grew by 41% year-over-year, or 32% in sterling.
Q4 adjusted operating profit margin was 24%, meeting our expectations.
For the full year, PA Consulting's revenue increased by 33% (24% in sterling), with an adjusted operating profit margin of 23%.
Non-allocated corporate costs totaled $55 million for the quarter and $190 million for the full year.
These costs increased year-over-year as expected, primarily due to higher medical costs and IT investments related to new working methods.
We anticipate non-allocated corporate costs to range from $200 million to $250 million in fiscal 2022, reflecting continued increases in medical costs and other investments.
These corporate costs, along with Focus 2023 and CMS and P&PS investments, will precede our expected acceleration in revenue growth and profit later in 2022.
As a result of these increased investments ahead of growth, Q1 profitability and earnings per share are likely to remain relatively flat compared to Q4 results, with improvement in Q2 and further acceleration in the second half of the year.
Turning to Slide 13 to discuss our cash flow and balance sheet.
We generated $176 million in reported free cash flow during the fourth quarter, with DSO showing strong improvement again.
The quarter's cash flow included $22 million related to restructuring and $16 million for a real estate lease termination as we adapt to virtual working.
For the year, free cash flow was $633 million, mainly impacted by the $261 million PA purchase price consideration treated as post-closing compensation.
Nevertheless, our reported free cash flow represented 133% conversion against our reported net income.
For fiscal year 2022, we aim for an adjusted free cash flow conversion at or above one time.
Due to our strong cash flow, we ended the quarter with $1 billion in cash and $2.9 billion in gross debt, resulting in $1.9 billion of net debt.
Our pro forma net debt to adjusted expected 2022 EBITDA is approximately 1.3 times, demonstrating the strength of our balance sheet.
During the quarter, we sold our Worley stock for $370 million and executed a $250 million accelerated share repurchase program.
We will continue to monitor for any significant dislocation in our share price, given the strong long-term secular growth opportunities for our company.
Given our strong balance sheet and free cash flow, we remain committed to our quarterly dividend, which was increased by 11% earlier this year to $0.21 per share.
We are introducing our fiscal 2022 outlook for adjusted EBITDA to range from $1.37 billion to $1.45 billion, representing double-digit growth at the midpoint.
Our adjusted earnings per share outlook for fiscal 2022 ranges from $6.85 to $7.45.
We anticipate a multi-year benefit from the U.S. Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act to support our growth in the second half of fiscal 2022.
Looking beyond this year, we see substantial opportunities for sustained organic growth driven by infrastructure monetization, climate response, and digital transformation.
We anticipate approximately $10 of adjusted earnings per share through fiscal 2025.
At our in-person investor event in March, we will provide more details on our long-term strategy and financial model.
