input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Ron Tsoumas, our Chief Financial Officer, is accompanying me today
We'll commence with the business highlights presented on Slide 4
The company's revenue for the quarter amounted to $288 million
Our organic growth, when excluding favorable currency translation, increased by 45% compared to the previous year
It's important to mention that the first quarter of the previous year was considerably affected by the pandemic
During this year's first quarter, our team encountered fluctuations in customer demand and challenges in the supply chain
These challenges encompassed the ongoing shortage of semiconductor chips, supply chain disruptions related to the pandemic, and congestion at ports, all of which put pressure on both sales and margins
Our team once again worked hard to address many of these challenges, allowing us to deliver results within our projected ranges for the quarter
Nevertheless, these fluctuations in demand and disruptions in the supply chain continued to necessitate corrective measures, such as expedited shipping and premium pricing for components
As of now, we anticipate these conditions to persist at least until the end of the calendar year
While we have reaffirmed our full-year guidance, persistent headwinds may cause our performance to fall below the midpoint of the ranges, as the situation remains highly volatile and challenging
The sales growth we experienced in the first quarter was attributed to increased demand across most of our businesses, with a particular focus on the automotive and commercial vehicle markets
We also saw growth in our Dabir business, although it continues to be hindered by the pandemic, limiting our opportunities for product evaluation in hospital operating rooms and ICUs
In terms of orders, we secured substantial awards for electric vehicle (EV), cloud computing, and e-bike applications
Regarding EVs, we reported last quarter that sales for EV applications constituted 13% of consolidated sales
This quarter, EV sales accounted for 16% of consolidated sales, and we expect this figure to remain in the mid-teens for fiscal 2022
Methode's combination of user interface, LED lighting, and power distribution solutions is proving successful in the EV sector
During the quarter, we further reduced our debt, generated positive operating cash flow, and continued to return capital to our shareholders
We have sufficient liquidity, enabling us to execute our stock buyback program, through which we purchased $7.6 million of shares in the quarter, and to pay our dividend, which increased from $0.11 to $0.14 per share during the quarter
We maintained our balanced approach to capital allocation
Moving on to Slide 5
Methode had another strong quarter in terms of business awards
These awards continue to capitalize on key market trends such as vehicle electrification and cloud computing
The awards mentioned here represent some of the key business wins for the quarter and amount to over $30 million in annual business at full production
In the vehicle electrification sector, we secured awards for power distribution and LED lighting programs
We continue to win programs with OEMs globally in both automotive and commercial vehicle applications
In non-EV automotive, we were awarded programs for power, lighting, and traditional switch applications
In cloud computing, we observed demand for our power distribution and transceiver products in data center applications
We continue to be involved in the expansion of e-bikes, which employs our unique magneto elastic sensor technology.
Our business awards are advancing our strategic goal of increasing both customer and geographic diversity, building upon the previous year.
Let's move to Slide 6.
As I've noted in recent discussions, our business awards in the past couple of years have positioned us to compensate for the sales decline from our largest auto program.
As a result, we are seeing improvements in our customer and program diversity.
Our electric vehicle, commercial vehicle, and cloud computing divisions have contributed to our customer diversification efforts.
While GM and Ford have been and are expected to remain valuable customers who have driven Methode's past growth, we have deliberately and systematically expanded our client base in recent years.
Our business outside of GM and Ford expanded to represent two-thirds of our total sales in fiscal 2021.
To summarize, despite ongoing demand fluctuations and supply chain challenges, we are still positioned to achieve strong organic growth for fiscal 2022.
First quarter sales reached $287.8 million in fiscal year '22, compared to $190.9 million in fiscal year '21, representing an increase of $96.9 million or 50.8%.
The year-over-year quarterly comparisons include a positive foreign currency impact on sales of $10.3 million in the current quarter.
The increase was primarily due to lower sales in the prior year quarter resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, and higher sales of electric and hybrid electric vehicles, which accounted for 16% of sales in the first quarter of fiscal year '22, aligning with our previous statement that electric and hybrid electric vehicle sales would make up mid-teens of our fiscal year '22 consolidated sales.
Additionally, stronger commercial vehicle sales contributed to the robust sales growth.
First quarter net income rose by $8.4 million to $29.1 million or $0.76 per diluted share, up from $20.7 million or $0.54 per diluted share in the same period last year.
Net income improved due to increased sales and favorable currency translation, partly offset by higher income tax expense, increased costs from supply chain disruption, higher selling and administrative expenses, and lower other income.
First quarter gross margins were higher in fiscal year '22 compared to fiscal year '21, mainly due to increased sales, partially offset by higher material costs, increased logistic expenses including freight, and supply chain shortages.
Fiscal year '22 first quarter margins were 24.9% compared to 23.6% in the first quarter of fiscal year '21.
The negative impact of supply disruption and higher logistics costs, including freight, on the first quarter of fiscal year '22 gross margin was nearly 300 basis points.
These elevated costs experienced in the first quarter are expected to persist further into fiscal year '22.
Moreover, we anticipate some cost inflation in the remainder of the current fiscal year.
First quarter selling and administrative expenses as a percentage of sales decreased to 11.4% compared to 13.9% in the fiscal '21 first quarter.
The fiscal year '22 first quarter percentage decrease was attributable to increased sales related to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on fiscal '21 sales, partly offset by higher stock-based and performance-based compensation expenses.
The first quarter of fiscal year '22 selling and administrative expenses percentage was consistent with our historical norm, which should result in an efficient flow-through from gross margin to operating income.
In addition to the gross margin and selling and administrative items mentioned earlier, two other non-operational factors significantly impacted net income in the first quarter of fiscal year '22 compared to the same quarter last fiscal year.
Firstly, income tax expense in the first quarter of fiscal year '22 was $5.7 million or 16.4% compared to a net tax benefit of $5.1 million in the first quarter of fiscal year '21.
The effective tax rate was lower in the first quarter of fiscal year '21 due to discrete tax benefits of $7.8 million in the quarter or $0.20 per diluted share.
Without the discrete tax benefits, the effective rate would have been 17.2%.
The year-over-year tax expense increase was $10.8 million.
Secondly, other income net was lower by $1.6 million, primarily due to reduced international government assistance between the comparable quarters.
Moving to EBITDA, a non-standard financial indicator.
The EBITDA for the first quarter of fiscal year 2022 was $48.5 million, compared to $29.3 million in the same timeframe of the previous fiscal year.
EBITDA saw a positive influence from increased operating income, partly counteracted by reduced other income.
Free cash flow, a non-standard financial measure, is calculated as the net cash from operating activities minus capital expenditures.
The first quarter of fiscal year 2022 saw a negative free cash flow of $6.2 million, in contrast to a positive $4.8 million in the first quarter of fiscal year 2021.
This decline was primarily attributed to unfavorable changes in working capital, particularly inventory, stemming from logistical challenges and increased capital spending.
Despite experiencing negative free cash flow in the first quarter of fiscal year 2022, we anticipate improvements for the rest of the fiscal year.
We expect to maintain our track record of generating consistent cash flows, enabling adequate funding for future organic growth, acquisitions, and shareholder returns.
In the first quarter of fiscal year 2022, we allocated approximately $15.9 million to capital expenditures, compared to $11.6 million in the same period of fiscal year 2021.
The higher first quarter capital expenditure aligns with our expectation that fiscal year 2022 would see increased investment compared to the previous year, estimated to range between $53 million and $57 million.
Our robust balance sheet allows us to continue investing in our businesses to foster organic growth in the future.
We also actively seek opportunities for inorganic growth and maintain a balanced approach to returning capital to shareholders.
During the first quarter of fiscal year 2022, we decreased our gross debt by $4.7 million.
Since acquiring Grakon in September 2018, we have reduced our gross debt by nearly $123 million.
We recently announced two capital allocation initiatives.
On March 31st, we introduced a $100 million share repurchase program, of which we executed $7.6 million in repurchases during the first quarter of fiscal year 2022.
Since the program's approval, we have bought back $15.1 million worth of shares at an average price of $46.45.
Additionally, we raised our quarterly dividend from $0.11 to $0.14 per share, a 27% increase.
We concluded the first quarter with $207.9 million in cash.
As mentioned earlier, we have reaffirmed our previously issued guidance for earnings per share and annual outlook.
External factors and their potential impact on our financial results continue to pose ongoing challenges.
While we have reconfirmed our full-year guidance, persistent headwinds may cause our performance to fall below the midpoint of the projected ranges, as the situation remains fluid and challenging.
The revenue projection for the entire fiscal year 2022 ranges from $1.175 billion to $1.235 billion.
The diluted earnings per share forecast spans from $3.35 to $3.75 per share.
This range accounts for uncertainties stemming from supply chain disruptions affecting semiconductors and other materials for both Methode and its customers.
From a sales perspective, lower revenue could result from supply disruptions affecting us or our customers, potentially leading to reduced demand for our products or hindering our ability to meet customer needs.
Ongoing supply chain issues would also negatively impact gross margins due to additional expenses from premium freight, factory inefficiencies, and to a lesser extent, tariffs and other logistical factors, including port congestion.
Rising costs for materials, freight, and labor present a constant and dynamic challenge, and it remains unclear when these factors will stabilize.
That concludes my remarks.
I believe we're prepared to take questions.
Summary:
output:
q1 earnings per share $0.76.
reaffirms fy earnings per share view $3.35 to $3.75.
sees fy sales $1.175 billion to $1.235 billion.
q1 sales $287.8 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Kevin Blair, the president and CEO, will commence the presentation.
We kindly request that you restrict yourself to a single question and one follow-up inquiry.
Throughout the presentation, we will be referencing non-GAAP financial metrics related to the company's performance.
Kevin Blair will now provide a summary of the quarter's results.
Our team achieved another strong quarter, showing growth in revenue and earning assets while maintaining cost control that led to a 5% decrease in year-over-year quarterly expenses.
Moreover, we continue to observe an improving credit outlook, resulting in a reduction of our allowance.
We have successfully achieved $75 million in pre-tax run rate benefits through the second quarter as part of our Synovus Forward initiatives and investments, with an additional $100 million expected by the end of 2022.
Let me briefly remind you of our performance thus far compared to our expectations at the start of the year.
We indicated that we would achieve loan growth, excluding PPP loans, with acceleration in the latter half of the year.
We also stated that we would enhance our deposit mix and reduce our funding costs to stabilize the margin.
Furthermore, we committed to implementing efficiency measures to restore positive operating leverage while effectively managing the uncertain credit environment and delivering the planned benefits from Synovus Forward.
I'm happy to report that we are meeting these objectives and finished the first half of 2021 with significant momentum, feeling optimistic about future growth and expansion opportunities.
Our commercial loan pipelines have returned to pre-pandemic levels, with continued growth in C&I outstandings and commitments, and line utilization slightly increased during the quarter.
Clients maintain strong liquidity, allowing us to further optimize our deposit mix and again reduce our funding costs this quarter.
We anticipate this trend to persist in the current low-rate environment.
Our Wealth and Treasury and Payment Solutions divisions are performing exceptionally well.
Ongoing growth and operating margin expansion in these fee income-generating business units will help counterbalance the industry-wide decline in mortgage activity.
Criticized and classified loans decreased for the quarter, further indicating that the heightened credit concerns arising from the pandemic continue to diminish and suggest the opportunity to gradually reduce the allowance toward day one CECL levels.
During the first half of the year, we continued to invest in Synovus' future, focusing on key priorities to enhance customer experience and generate new sources of growth.
Some examples include: our Treasury and Payment Solutions business introducing a new suite of integrated receivable solutions called Synovus Accelerate AR.
This solution has been well-received, and the sales pipeline is already growing, creating a new revenue stream while significantly benefiting our customers by saving them time and money.
We have also transferred approximately 25,000 business clients to Synovus Gateway, our new digital platform for business and commercial banking.
With enhanced functionality and capabilities, we are simplifying business operations for our customers and promoting higher levels of client retention.
Lastly, our smart analytics tool, which we've previously discussed, has been further implemented across our bankers and markets, and is beginning to impact pipeline growth and opportunities to increase our share of wallet from customers.
The second quarter reminded us that our focus on delivering a personalized and value-added customer experience is important and will continue to provide a foundation for future growth.
Industry-wide consumer satisfaction surveys once again demonstrate that our clients are more satisfied and loyal than those of our competitors.
We also received two awards of excellence for our family office during the quarter.
These scores and accolades are not success in themselves, but rather confirmation that our efforts and approaches are having meaningful impacts on our customers.
For all these reasons, as well as the vibrant economic expansion we expect to continue in the Southeast, we remain confident in our path forward.
Turning to Slide 3, which presents our financial highlights for the quarter.
Total adjusted revenue of $489 million, adjusted expenses of $268 million, and a $25 million reversal of provision for credit losses resulted in adjusted net income of $179 million or $1.20 diluted earnings per share.
Without adjustments, net income was $178 million or $1.19 diluted earnings per share.
Pretax run rate benefits from Synovus Forward of $75 million have increased by $25 million from the first-quarter results.
Our ongoing work on completed and future initiatives continues to reinforce our confidence in achieving an aggregate pre-tax run rate benefit of $100 million by year-end 2021 and $175 million by the end of 2022.
Total loans, excluding PPP loans, increased by $194 million in the second quarter.
Growth in the quarter was achieved in our core C&I portfolio, as well as third-party consumer lending, given the persistent high liquidity environment.
Despite robust production levels, elevated prepayment activity remains a challenge in our commercial and consumer real estate portfolios.
Core transaction deposits grew by $702 million or 2%, led by core noninterest-bearing deposits growth of $601 million or 4%.
Given the current loan-to-deposit ratio, we continue to strategically rebalance the deposit base by reducing higher-cost categories, including CDs and broker deposits.
Key credit metrics remained stable with the NPA ratio decreasing by 4 basis points to 46 basis points, and the ACL coverage remains strong.
A more favorable economic outlook and a 14% reduction in criticized and classified loans supported further allowance releases.
The ACL ratio, excluding PPP loans, declined 15 basis points to 1.54%.
We maintain a well-capitalized position with the CET1 ratio increasing to 9.8%, while completing nearly half of our $200 million share repurchase authorization in the quarter.
We also executed additional earning asset growth activities to monetize excess liquidity while maintaining capital above our operating target.
As shown on Slide 4, we concluded the quarter with earning assets of $51 billion.
Total loans decreased by $569 million, primarily due to PPP balance declines of $763 million.
While gross production levels continue to improve, the liquidity environment continues to exert downward pressure on loan demand.
Although our customers are utilizing less of their line commitments, we are consistently growing overall commitments through new client relationships and deeper existing relationships.
The annualized growth rate in total commitments over the past two years exceeds 3% compared to an annualized increase in funded loan balances of approximately 1%.
A significant portion of that growth will translate into funded balances once C&I line utilization begins to normalize closer to the long-term average of 46 to 47%.
Based on market intelligence and discussions with our clients, we believe increases in line utilization will occur later in the cycle as client liquidity diminishes.
Our base assumption included in our loan growth guidance is that line utilization will remain near current levels through year-end.
While commitment growth will support longer-term loan growth, our confidence in the near-term forecast is based on continued strong production, growth in the commercial loan pipeline, and our expectation that the elevated level of payoffs and paydowns will subside.
Another factor supporting our confidence in loan growth is more recent monthly data.
In June, total loans, excluding changes in PPP balances, grew by approximately $200 million.
In the second quarter, further declines in consumer mortgage and HELOC portfolios of $98 million and $74 million, respectively, continued to be impacted by accelerated prepayment activity and excess liquidity.
CRE loan declines of $173 million this quarter largely resulted from accelerated payoffs as many owners are selling with the expectation that capital gains taxes will increase in 2022.
C&I balances, excluding changes in PPP, increased $220 million with $469 million in commitment growth while C&I line utilization remained near historic lows.
A normalization in C&I line utilization would lead to over $700 million in funded balances.
We funded about $150 million in second round P3 loans, minus unearned fees, which partly counterbalanced $927 million in forgiveness.
P3 balances at quarter-end totaled $1.6 billion.
Additional information on P3 loan activity can be found in the appendix.
Given the current liquidity situation, we expanded the securities portfolio by roughly $616 million and the third-party consumer portfolio by about $273 million.
The risk profile of acquired assets was similar to those from the first quarter, focusing on mortgage-backed securities and secured third-party consumer loans.
Investment securities made up 17% of total assets at quarter-end and may increase further as we seek advantageous uses of liquidity in the latter half of 2021.
As illustrated on Slide 5, we maintained growth in core transaction deposits, which rose by $702 million or 2% compared to the previous quarter.
This was primarily due to core noninterest-bearing deposit growth of $601 million or 4%, which compensated for planned reductions in higher-cost deposits.
We successfully lowered our total deposit costs in the second quarter, decreasing from 22 basis points to 16 basis points, a reduction of 6 basis points.
This was achieved through optimizing deposit mix with a continued emphasis on strategically reducing high-cost time deposits, as well as lowering the expense associated with interest-bearing deposits.
Although the rate of CD maturities will significantly decrease, there are still opportunities to enhance deposit mix and reduce rates on other interest-bearing deposits as we move through the second half of 2021.
In June, total deposit costs were 15 basis points, and we anticipate further reductions in total deposit costs this year.
Slide 6 displays net interest income of $382 million, a $8 million increase from the previous quarter.
NII grew as benefits from asset growth, reduced deposit costs, and day count outweighed the decrease in P3 fee income.
The net interest margin of 3.02%, a 2 basis point decline, was mainly affected by P3 forgiveness as P3 fee accretion decreased by $5 million from the previous quarter.
Other factors are comparable to recent quarters, with asset repricing headwinds being offset by further reductions in liability costs.
As anticipated, slower prepayment activity in the latter part of the quarter helped improve the yield on the securities portfolio, supporting both margin and NII.
Based on current mortgage trends, we expect a slight further improvement in that yield in the third quarter as the impact of a full quarter of more normalized prepay activity is realized.
The slowdown in prepayment activity resulted in a $3 million reduction of premium amortization in the second quarter, down from $20 million in the first quarter.
Regarding asset sensitivity, we remain positively exposed to potential increases in interest rates.
This dynamic continues to be supported by the aforementioned shifts in our balance sheet, including funding mix, with the estimated exposure being split between both short-term and long-term rates.
As of June 30th, our loan portfolio is 54% variable and approximately 30% of those variable rate loans have floors at or above short-term index rates of 25 basis points.
Based on current market conditions and our expectations for loan growth, we reiterate our expectation that quarterly net interest income, excluding P3 fee accretion, should increase in the second half of the year driven by loan growth, deployment of liquidity, a deceleration of prepayments and further deposit cost reductions.
Using the quarter-end forward curve and absent rate hikes, we expect a NIM of approximately 3%, excluding the impact of P3, with headwinds from the lapse of P3 fee accretion being offset by the continued deployment of excess liquidity and with notable upside coming from increases in either short-term or long-term interest rates.
As we've shared previously, we estimate NIM dilution of approximately 6 basis points per $1 billion of excess cash on deposit at the Federal Reserve.
Slide 7 shows a total adjusted noninterest revenue of $106 million, down $6 million from the previous quarter.
The continued strength in fee revenue reflects diversified growth across our fee revenue sources, partially offsetting the ongoing normalization of the mortgage business from record-high production levels.
Core banking fees were $41 million, up $3 million.
Increases were widespread, led by $1 million increases in account analysis fees that benefit from our treasury and payment solutions team and our recently in-sourced merchant business.
NSF, or overdraft fees, which have received significant attention throughout the industry, remained unchanged at $6 million, accounting for less than 6% of noninterest revenue and 1.3% of total revenues.
Net mortgage revenue declined $8 million in the second quarter to $14 million due to reductions in secondary production and gain on sale.
This remains above pre-pandemic levels, and we expect continued normalization in the second half of 2021.
Increases in fiduciary revenues of $3 million helped offset decreases in other areas, including capital markets income.
Assets under management grew 3% in the quarter and 28% from the previous year.
The expansion of wealth management and other fiduciary services, particularly in South Florida, will continue to provide significant growth opportunities.
Total noninterest expense of $271 million is highlighted on Slide 8.
Adjusted noninterest expense was $268 million up $2 million from the prior quarter and down $6 million from the prior year.
Adjusted items include the impact of an earn-out liability, nonqualified deferred compensation and restructuring fees primarily related to branch closures.
Employment expense of $159 million was down $1 million from the prior quarter as seasonal decreases in payroll taxes was partially offset by an increase in pay days, as well as commissions and other variable compensation.
Expenses of $42 million associated with occupancy, equipment and software increased $1 million from the previous quarter, largely due to an increase in the repairs and maintenance.
As Kevin will discuss later, we continue to evaluate and optimize our branch and non-branch real estate for additional efficiency opportunities.
Other expenses of $67 million were up $3 million primarily due to the $4 million increase in third-party processing fees associated with the expenses from additional P3 forgiveness and third-party consumer loans.
Our commitment to prudent expense management and profitable growth allows us to continue to invest in strategically compelling high-return growth vectors.
We have reduced our head count 6% year over year, approximately 85% of which was on the support side.
This reduction in headcount is a key priority in our expense management efforts, However, there are some offsetting costs as we promote team members who are taking on more responsibility and continue to hire customer-facing team members.
Our expectations for expenses and benefits from Synovus Forward remain unchanged.
Slide 9 highlights stable credit metrics, which remain near historical lows.
We continue to see improvement in the overall economic outlook, which is reflected in the reversal of provision for credit losses of $25 million and a 14% reduction in criticized and classified loans.
Support for the ratings improvements comes from client conversations and cash inflows.
As shown in the appendix, cash inflows from March to May are each up more than 10% compared to the same period from 2019, which we use as a pre-pandemic baseline.
The annualized net charge-off ratio for the quarter was 0.28%.
We expect net charge-offs to remain relatively stable in the second half of the 2021, assuming no material change in the economic outlook.
During the second quarter, the NPA ratio declined 4 basis points to 46 basis points.
Criticized and classified loans fell 14%, and we expect further reductions as we progress through the rest of the year.
The ACL ratio of 1.54%, excluding P3 loans, was down 15 basis points from the prior quarter and 27 basis points from the end of the year.
We continue to use a multi-scenario framework in our CECL modeling and a sign of 40% weighting to adverse scenarios, 55% weighting to the base scenario and 5% weighting to an upside scenario.
As noted on Slide 10, the CET1 ratio increased 1 basis point to 9.75% as a result of strong performance.
The building capital was deployed via risk-weighted asset growth, share repurchases and our common equity dividend.
During the second quarter, we bought back $92 million worth of shares from the $200 million authorized for 2021, leading to a 1.3% decrease in average diluted outstanding shares.
In July, we've conducted about $15 million more in share repurchases.
Given the current economic conditions and outlook, we anticipate completing the entire authorized repurchase in the latter half of the year.
We'll strategically allocate capital from our balance sheet to shareholders while maintaining our CET1 ratio above the 9.5% target.
We're in a strong position to achieve our key strategic goals, with a focus on profitable growth, particularly through multi-solution relationships.
At 2020's start, we introduced our Synovus Forward plan to boost earnings potential through strategic actions aimed at improving efficiency and accelerating revenue growth.
The Synovus Forward initiatives align with our strategy to build a high-growth, low-risk, adaptable bank capable of increasing market share in our attractive southeastern markets.
As mentioned earlier, we've continued to increase our Synovus Forward pre-tax run rate benefits throughout Q2, now reaching about $75 million.
Slide 11 illustrates that we've achieved these results through a mix of cost-cutting and revenue-boosting initiatives.
Based on our progress and ongoing execution, we're confident we'll meet the 2021 and 2022 targets of $100 million and $175 million, respectively.
Our expense reduction success has primarily come from three areas: lowering third-party expenditures, reducing headcount, and consolidating branch and corporate real estate.
About $50 million of the $75 million pre-tax run rate benefit achieved by quarter-end is related to these specific efficiency measures.
We plan to increase savings in each of these areas and introduce new initiatives to achieve an additional $30-40 million in pre-tax benefits by the end of 2022.
Future efficiencies will be driven by further third-party savings, workforce optimization, reduced branch and non-branch square footage, process automation, and additional tax strategies.
We've also seen success on the revenue side of Synovus Forward, with $25 million in pre-tax run rate benefits.
The Treasury and Payment Solutions pricing-for-value initiative has resulted in annualized pre-tax run rate benefits of about $12 million in Q2.
We've implemented a broad-based price increase, supported by the competitive landscape, improved products and services, and a commitment to providing proactive, needs-based advice.
With a new pricing tool and the ongoing low-rate environment, we've reduced our cost of funds more than initially expected and now have a better capability to manage customer rate elasticity in a future higher-rate environment.
Other areas of incremental revenue include in-sourcing our merchant business, expanding our merchant sponsorship business, and broadening solutions like trade finance and international payment and currency capabilities.
Future plans aim to achieve $60-70 million in pre-tax revenue benefits, primarily through analytics, new products and solutions, balance sheet management strategies, and ongoing talent and specialty team expansion.
We're making progress on our commercial analytics pilot, called the SMART tool, with encouraging feedback and utilization from bankers who are using actionable leads and insights to generate new sales and expand existing client relationships.
We plan to pilot in Q3 and roll out company-wide in Q4.
We've also started developing our retail analytics program to increase our share of wallet among consumer and wealth customers while reducing attrition.
We're growing our premium finance and specialty lending businesses, adding strong teams in attractive specialized verticals, and launching targeted, innovative products and capabilities for new revenue growth.
Synovus Forward represents a continuous improvement mindset, not just a set of initiatives.
Our team members are focused on innovation and finding new ways to increase efficiency and drive revenue.
Regarding technology, we believe our competitive advantage will come from combining our high-touch approach with high-tech investments and partnerships.
We're enhancing both consumer and commercial client digital experiences, partnering with suitable fintechs to develop and deliver new products and solutions, and planning to transition to a modern core over time in a controlled manner.
We'll continue to focus on increasing online origination capabilities and exploring new technological opportunities, especially in payment and banking-as-a-service areas.
Moving to Slide 12, we've updated our 2021 outlook with a few key changes.
For loan growth, we still expect to be within our 2-4% guidance, excluding P3 loans and third-party consumer loans, but likely at the lower end due to unexpected elevated prepayment activity.
This assumes line utilization remains low and prepayment activity normalizes.
Third-party consumer loans, not included in this guidance, represent $1.5 billion in period-end balances, up $776 million in 2021.
We plan to continue this strategy while excess liquidity persists and future purchase returns remain attractive.
We're increasing our expectations for total adjusted revenue and expense, considering them together as some revenue-generating areas have associated expenses.
We remain committed to achieving positive operating leverage, a top priority for 2021.
Our updated guidance doesn't assume significant interest rate changes, though we're more asset-sensitive now, meaning any rate increase would significantly boost net interest income.
Our capital management target now includes a CET1 ratio of 9.5% or higher.
Strong performance and a stable economic outlook may result in a CET1 ratio above 9.5%, even after completing the entire $200 million share repurchase authorization this year.
Additional tax strategies are expected to result in an effective tax rate of 22-24%.
These actions position us for success in the second half of 2021 and long-term, strengthening our currency and providing opportunities for strategic growth, both organic and inorganic.
We're excited about the second half of 2021 and our future of work operating environment rollout this quarter.
Our balance sheet is well-positioned for growth with strong capital and liquidity, our team members are delivering passionately, and our pipelines show clients are ready to grow their business with Synovus as their partner.
Summary:
output:
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.20.
q2 earnings per share $1.19.
pred_output: 1. The company achieved strong quarterly results, with revenue and earning assets growing, and cost control leading to a 5% decrease in year-over-year quarterly expenses. 2. The company's credit outlook is improving, with a reduction in criticized and classified loans and a reversal of provision for credit losses. 3. The company has successfully achieved $75 million in pre-tax run rate benefits through the second quarter as part of its Synovus Forward initiatives and investments, with an additional $100 million expected by the end of 2022. 4. The company has updated its 2021 outlook, with loan growth expected to be within its 2-4% guidance, excluding P3 loans and third-party consumer loans, and total adjusted revenue and expense increasing. 5. input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:My name is Christine Marchuska and I serve as the vice president of investor relations at Diebold Nixdorf.
Investors are advised to read the shareholder letter for more details on the company's progress.
We've made a recent announcement about an upcoming change in our CEO position.
Shortly, we'll hear from our current president and CEO, Gerrard Schmid, as well as Octavio Marquez, who will be taking over as Diebold Nixdorf's next chief executive.
In his address, Gerard will discuss the current business climate, our achievements in 2021, and introduce Octavio.
Our chief financial officer, Jeff Rutherford, will then present the company's financial results, including quarterly and annual highlights, along with our projections for 2022.
We'll then open the floor for questions.
For more information on these topics, please refer to the company's regular and yearly SEC filings.
Please note that future events may cause this information to become outdated.
I'll now turn the call over to Gerrard.
I'm glad to be speaking with you today.
We encountered exceptional difficulties in 2021 due to the ongoing pandemic.
I'm happy to announce that we achieved our goals in the fourth quarter.
The final months of 2021 required intense and detailed effort.
We scrutinized every potential area for improvement.
This ranged from supply chain and logistics to financial transactions.
What outsiders deemed impossible, we proved feasible.
We've once again demonstrated our resilience and strength.
Although supply chain and logistical issues were major concerns in 2021, it's worth noting that we delivered more ATMs, self-checkout units, and point-of-sale devices than in 2020.
This showcases the durability of our business model.
While the pandemic has disrupted our lives and forced us to reconsider the future, we've repeatedly shown our ability to create a flexible company that challenges norms and excels in execution.
The current situation has highlighted the rapidly changing consumer demands and the necessity for self-service options wherever possible.
We are ideally positioned to provide these solutions and growth opportunities for our clients, whether they're in banking, grocery, or retail.
We help them create more digital, flexible, and effective customer experiences.
In the retail sector, evolving consumer behavior and changing labor dynamics have increased demand for self-service and automation, with growth driven by customer interest in self-service solutions.
In 2021, we experienced above-market growth in Europe for self-service hardware, services, and software.
We also made progress in other markets, such as the United States and Australia.
In banking, we continue to see strong demand for cash recyclers as banks reconsider their branch layouts and move towards automation and efficiency in their real estate use.
Our engagement with major U.S. customers has grown.
In 2021, our order levels in the Americas were 16% higher than in 2020 and 17% higher than pre-pandemic levels in 2019.
Let me now highlight our world-class services organization.
Both we and our customers consider this one of our greatest assets, often playing a crucial role in DN winning new business and expanding existing relationships.
It also opens up opportunities in new areas like electric vehicle (EV) charging stations, which I'll discuss later.
In 2021, we continued improving our service delivery by reaching a milestone with connected devices for our all-connected data engine.
We now have about 150,000 banking self-service devices connected to the solution, representing approximately 122% year-over-year growth in connected devices.
Our technology uses real-time Internet-of-Things capabilities to support our predictive maintenance offering, significantly reducing customer downtime.
Similarly, in retail, we continue to provide value and services to our customers.
I must mention an ongoing success story with one of our key customers, a major UK-based retailer.
This client depends on us for flawless execution and excellent service across over 25,000 checkout lanes.
We successfully maintained 100% uptime for point-of-sale and self-checkout systems during the two busiest shopping days of the year.
Our efforts helped the retailer enhance customer satisfaction by reducing queues and wait times, resulting in increased sales compared to the previous year.
This marks the tenth year in a row that we've met this performance target.
It's a clear demonstration of our service capabilities.
We replicated this successful program with another major European retailer, proving it's a reproducible model for the retail industry.
We believe that meeting or surpassing our customers' service expectations creates a solid foundation for introducing additional technology.
Both retailers placed more orders for self-checkout systems with us in December.
We were pleased to see retailers' continued trust in our ability to provide high-quality services to them and their customers.
To complement our strong service offerings, I'd like to briefly discuss our progress in the fourth quarter regarding electric vehicle charging stations, particularly in Europe.
The EV charging industry is currently fragmented, with various players including startups, medium-sized businesses, and large electronics corporations competing in the market.
Moreover, there are multiple roles along the value chain that lack consistency.
This is a substantial and expanding market with considerable demand.
By 2026, the number of public EV charging stations in Europe and the United States will surpass the number of ATM machines.
With more EV drivers, especially in Europe where home charging is less common, and the shift towards electric vehicles in rental, fleet, and public transportation, there will be an increased need for public charging stations.
There are currently over 40 significant chargepoint operators globally, and we are in discussions with many of them.
Our global service capabilities, including our technicians, expertise in global spare parts logistics management, and multilingual help desks, have appealed to several market participants who lack these skills as they aim to expand their businesses.
As of Q4 2021, we have contracts for several thousand charging stations in Europe and the US, with a near-term pipeline three times the size of our current base.
The team aims to service over 30,000 charging stations by the end of 2022.
A notable recent success I'd like to highlight is our partnership with Compleo, a leading full-service provider of charging technology in Europe.
This partnership agreement will provide a comprehensive range of managed services for initially over 1,000 of Compleo's DC fast charging stations in public locations across Germany, with potential for expansion.
Finally, as you're aware, diversity and sustainability have been key priorities for our company.
I'm proud to report that in 2021, women made up over 60% of our senior hires at the vice president level and above.
We also made significant environmental progress, reducing our scope one and two carbon emissions by 6%.
Our shareholder letter provides more details on our achievements in this area.
I want to express my gratitude to our teams for their hard work and dedication in this crucial area.
Over the last four years, we have undertaken a comprehensive restructuring and transformation initiative.
The company has made substantial strategic and operational advancements.
We have increased profitability, gained market share through our DN series and self-checkout solutions, and entered new growth markets.
I'm proud that we've achieved these goals while also delivering four consecutive years of improvements in customer satisfaction.
We begin 2022 with a robust backlog, an experienced executive team, and operations that have proven resilient despite the pandemic and challenging macroeconomic conditions.
As we look forward to moving beyond the pandemic and building momentum in growth areas like EV charging services and payments, while continuing to optimize our core businesses in retail and banking, it's the appropriate time for Octavio to take on the CEO role.
Many of our customers and employees are already familiar with Octavio.
He has been leading our global banking segment, which accounts for approximately 70% of the company's revenues, and he is deeply committed to our customers and our business.
He has a thorough understanding of our operations and is the ideal person to guide Diebold Nixdorf into the future.
I will remain on Diebold Nixdorf's board of directors until my term concludes at the 2022 shareholder meeting.
I will also work closely with Octavio and the rest of the leadership team as an advisor for several months to ensure a smooth transition.
It has been an immense honor to serve as CEO of Diebold Nixdorf.
I believe we have significantly improved the operational and strategic direction of the organization.
I'll now turn the call over to Octavio for a brief introduction.
It has been a pleasure to be part of our journey under your guidance.
I am genuinely excited to lead Diebold Nixdorf moving forward.
Since 2014, I've been employed at Diebold Nixdorf, where I've had the opportunity to contribute to our transformation into a leading provider of self-service banking and retail technology.
I've had the privilege of collaborating closely with our customers worldwide.
Initially, I worked with our Latin American clients, then managed our American banking customer segment, and for the last year and a half, I've been working closely with our global banking customers.
I've witnessed firsthand the crucial role we play for our customers and how we can continue to innovate to provide them with a wider range of solutions.
Our passionate and talented workforce has been crucial to the company's progress.
I'm also excited about our growth prospects, such as our strong self-checkout growth in retail, our managed services initiatives in banking and retail, as well as our newer but equally promising opportunities in payments and EV charging services.
We've been diligent in improving our company's efficiency, and I'm eager to further enhance our execution.
The team and I value your contributions and wish you success in your future endeavors.
In the coming year, we anticipate overcoming the global macro challenges we've faced by utilizing our mitigation strategies and delivering results for our customers and shareholders.
Diebold Nixdorf is well-positioned to capitalize on the strong demand for our products and solutions as customers continue to seek our market-leading devices, services, and software.
The market is shifting towards a self-service automation focus driven by consumer preferences.
Please refer to our shareholder letter for the complete financial details from the quarter and full year.
I will now highlight some of our key performance metrics.
In Q4, total revenue was $1.6 billion, a 4% decrease from Q4 2020 as reported, and a 1% decrease excluding the $22 million foreign currency impact and $13 million impact from divested businesses.
Adjusted for foreign currency and divestitures, product revenue increased by about 4%, services revenue decreased by approximately 6%, and software revenue increased by roughly 3% compared to Q4 2020.
During the quarter, we experienced delayed revenue due to extended outbound transport times and inbound component delays.
This mainly affected the US, Latin America, and certain APAC countries, increasing our revenue deferral to 2022 by $30 million to a total of $150 million.
Sequentially, total revenue increased by approximately 11%.
Full-year 2021 revenue was $3.905 billion, driven by demand for our DN series ATMs, particularly our cash recyclers, self-checkout devices, and tax services, offset by about $150 million of deferred revenue due to supply chain and logistics challenges.
Year-over-year, 2021 revenue was approximately flat compared to 2020 as reported, and also flat excluding a $74 million foreign currency benefit and $60 million impact from divested businesses.
Adjusted for foreign currency and divestitures, product revenue increased by about 4%, services revenue decreased by approximately 4%, and software revenue increased by roughly 2% for the full year 2021.
In Q4, we reported adjusted EBITDA of $126 million and an adjusted EBITDA margin of 11.9%.
Q4 adjusted EBITDA results reflect a reduction in operating expenses fully offset by the decline in gross profit due to revenue deferral and non-billable inflation of approximately $30 million.
Full-year 2021 adjusted EBITDA was $450 million, at the lower end of our guidance range primarily due to supply chain challenges, which increased revenue deferral to approximately $150 million, with non-billable inflation for the year at about $15 million.
Last week, we delivered free cash flow of $407 million for Q4, resulting in $101 million for fiscal year 2021.
This record Q4 free cash flow was achieved through tremendous efforts by our sales, operations, and finance teams.
Q4 marks the conclusion of the DN Now transformation and restructuring program.
Going forward, we will not present non-GAAP adjustments to earnings except for the amortization of intangible purchase accounting assets and, when appropriate, non-recurring items such as M&A activities.
Our revenue guidance for full-year 2022 is $4 billion to $4.2 billion, reflecting approximately $150 million in revenue deferral from 2021 to 2022, organic growth and pricing growth, partially offset by model divestitures and terminated low-profit service contracts, and potential ongoing logistics and supply chain disruptions.
While we're encouraged by the demand for our solutions, our guidance range also reflects caution regarding the timing of global logistics and supply chain environments.
Our adjusted EBITDA outlook is $440 to $460 million, considering gross profit growth due to increased revenue and a modest gross margin expansion of about 100 basis points, partially offset by an increase in operating expenses.
Adjusted EBITDA will likely be weighted toward the second half of 2022 as our pricing and incremental cost management actions begin to take effect, and volume builds throughout the year.
Our free cash flow outlook is $130 to $150 million, reflecting our EBITDA outlook, normalization of working capital, and conclusion of the DN Now transformation and restructuring program and related payments.
It's worth noting that our free cash flow guidance doesn't include any benefit from a potential debt refinancing.
For Q1, we expect gross margin to be comparable to Q4 2021 due to continued non-billable inflation.
Additionally, we'll see an increase in Q1 operating expenses due to wage inflation and growth in infrastructure investments.
As such, we expect Q1 to be the low point for 2022 operating profit and margin.
That concludes my review of the results.
With the transition to a new CEO just announced, I'll hand it over to the operator.
Summary:
output:
qtrly gaap loss per share $0.49; qtrly non-gaap earnings per share $0.06.
sees fy 2022 total revenue $4.0 billion - $4.2 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations may be revised based on emerging information or future occurrences.
Assured Guaranty achieved exceptional results in 2021 through a combination of insurance production, loss mitigation, and capital management strategies.
The year was marked by numerous significant achievements, including earning $470 million in adjusted operating income, an 84% increase from 2020.
We achieved a twofold increase in adjusted operating income per share, reaching $6.32 per share.
All three of our shareholder value indicators reached unprecedented levels.
Throughout the year, shareholder's equity per share increased by 9% to $93.19.
Adjusted operating shareholder's equity per share grew by 13% to $88.73, while adjusted book value per share rose by 14% to $130.67.
We bought back $10.5 million common shares, approximately 14% of our outstanding shares as of December 31, 2020, at an average price of $47.19.
These repurchases amounted to $496 million, and when combined with $66 million in dividends, we returned a total of $562 million to shareholders.
We generated $361 million in PVP during 2021 through robust new business production across our financial guarantee markets: U.S. public finance, international infrastructure finance, and global structured finance.
Direct PVP surpassed $350 million for the third consecutive year, compared to an average annual direct PVP of $210 million from 2012 to 2018, making the past three years our most successful in over a decade for direct new business production.
We led the U.S. public finance bond insurance industry to its highest market penetration in twelve years, with more than a 60% share of new issue insured par sold.
Taking advantage of exceptionally low interest rates, our U.S. holding company issued a total of $900 million in 3.15% 10-year and 3.60% 30-year senior debt to refinance $600 million of debt with higher coupons ranging from 5% to almost 7%.
As a result, annual debt service savings will amount to $5.2 million through the next maturity date.
Our financial guarantee production was well-distributed across all our markets.
U.S. public finance PVP of $235 million included its second-best direct production in at least a decade, surpassed only by the previous year's result, while $79 million of international infrastructure PVP marks the fourth year out of the last five that we have exceeded $75 million of direct PVP in that sector.
Global structured finance PVP at $47 million was the second-best in direct production since 2012.
Our markets and economic environment presented both opportunities and challenges during 2021, with U.S. municipal bond issuance reaching a record par amount of $457 billion.
This partly reflected investors' increased demand for tax-exempt paper in anticipation of higher tax rates and continued limitations on state and local tax deductions at the federal level.
Additionally, issuers were eager to take advantage of extremely low municipal interest rates to refinance bonds issued in the past at higher rates, with the option to execute tax-exempt advance refunding still unavailable.
Many issuers also turned to the taxable market to replace higher coupon tax-exempt debt.
Total insured market volume increased to 8.2% of par issued, the highest annual rate over the past 12 years, up from 7.6% during 2020 and 5.9% during 2019.
We believe this increased penetration in 2021 indicates that the risk of unpredictable developments, which was highlighted by the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, has made a lasting impression on investors.
We have also demonstrated that Assured Guaranty possesses the underwriting and risk management skills to build an insured portfolio that experienced minimal claims from the economic disruption caused by the pandemic, most of which have already been reimbursed.
The $37.5 billion of insured par in 2021 represented a 10% annual increase, following a 43% increase the prior year, resulting in a 57% growth of the insured market in just two years since 2019.
Assured Guaranty's production was a driving force behind this growth, as we captured over 58% of new issue insured par sold in 2020, and more than 60% in 2021.
Our highest annual market share since 2013, our $23 billion of insured new issue volume in 2021 was almost $3 billion more par than we insured in 2020, and was generated by more than 8,000 individual transactions.
An important trend in recent years has been the use of our guarantee to help launch some of the municipal bond market's largest transactions, indicating growing institutional demand for the security, relative price stability, and significant market liquidity our guarantee can provide.
We guaranteed $100 million or more on each of 48 large issues launched in 2021, up from 39 transactions in 2020 and 22 in 2019.
Notably, we continue to add value on credits with underlying ratings in the double-A category from one or both of S&P and Moody's, insuring 109 such AA transactions totaling more than $3.5 billion of insured par.
U.S. public finance constitutes the largest part of our uniquely diversified financial guarantee strategy.
Our three-pronged strategy also targets insurable transactions in both infrastructure finance outside the United States and structured finance throughout the world.
This approach helps us during periods when one market or another shows temporary weaknesses, and it drives great results in years like 2021, when we are thriving in all three of our markets.
Further illustrating the diversity of our business, in 2021, we guaranteed financing of Spanish solar power facilities and UK higher education and healthcare projects.
Additionally, we worked with a UK water company to extend a debt service reserve guarantee, which is a unique product we developed as an alternative to bank liquidity facilities.
We also provided a number of secondary market guarantees.
Our European business was historically based in the UK, which previously allowed us to operate throughout the European Union.
We have long been active and continue to believe that plentiful and diverse opportunities exist.
Our Paris subsidiary, which we opened in 2020 to serve continental Europe more effectively, especially now that the UK has left the European Union, further grew its business around originations in 2021.
An important part of our global structured finance business is to provide institutions like banks and insurance companies with tools to optimize the capital utilization of their asset portfolios.
During the year, we guaranteed large insurance securitizations and significantly increased our CLO activity.
Our guarantees of CLOs attract new investors who might otherwise be discouraged by the higher capital requirements on uninsured CLOs.
We are seeing more opportunities to help investors reduce the capital consumption of both existing structured finance exposures and new investments.
The new business we wrote across all of our markets in 2021 enabled us to increase the year-end net par amount of our insured portfolio for the first time in many years.
We believe the trend going forward will be to continue increasing the par amount of our insured portfolio and increase our deferred premium revenue, which will further stabilize and grow our future earnings.
We have continued to reduce the risk in our insured portfolio and believe we can continue to do so as we continue to write new investment-grade business.
The portion of our insured portfolio rated below investment grade dropped to just over 3% by the end of 2021.
Nearly half of our below investment grade net par exposure relates to Puerto Rico, but we anticipate this figure will fall below 2.5% and continue decreasing as more Puerto Rico settlements are implemented, following court-approved resolutions for certain credits scheduled for mid-March this year.
Significant progress was made in 2021 regarding Puerto Rico's debt restructuring after years of complications, with creditors and the Commonwealth agreeing to support the Oversight Board's final restructuring plan for the central government, which received court approval in January 2022.
The Commonwealth government is expected to exit bankruptcy in mid-March.
The court also set the stage for favorable consideration of additional agreements supporting other Puerto Rico restructurings, such as those for highways and transportation authorities.
These developments indicate Puerto Rico's long-standing debt issues are being resolved satisfactorily, positioning the island for fiscal stability in the coming years, according to the Oversight Board's latest fiscal plan.
We achieved notable success in both our financial guarantee business and made substantial progress towards our asset management business objectives in 2021.
As one of the top 25 collateralized loan obligation (CLO) managers by assets under management, our overall investment performance was robust, allowing us to capitalize on the record-breaking CLO market.
We introduced six new CLOs in 2021, representing $2.5 billion in assets under management, more than doubling our 2020 issuance, and converted non-fee earning AUM to fee-earning AUM by divesting nearly all CLO equity held by Assured IM legacy funds where we had been rebating management fees.
These efforts resulted in an increase of CLO management fees from $23 million in 2020 to $48 million in 2021.
We also reset and refinanced 10 CLOs in the United States and Europe.
In the asset-backed sector, we closed a continuation fund for an auto finance investment.
The healthcare portfolio managed by Assured Healthcare Partners continued to expand as capital was deployed.
We believe Assured Guaranty's success in 2021 largely reflected growing market recognition of our financial strength, the security we provide to investors, and the benefits we deliver to bond issuers and other clients, underpinned by our careful underwriting, disciplined risk management, and persistent loss mitigation efforts.
The proven resilience of our financial guarantee business model and our strategic approach to capital management have enhanced our ability to protect policyholders and create shareholder value.
We believe this increased appreciation of our guarantee's value could drive higher demand as interest rates rise.
We anticipate market conditions in 2022 and beyond will differ significantly from those in 2021, as the Federal Reserve works to control inflation, the impact of COVID-19 diminishes, geopolitical events continue to disrupt markets, and municipal governments prepare for the end of extraordinary federal support.
Rising interest rates, widening credit spreads, and increased volatility tend to boost demand for financial guarantees.
We believe Assured Guaranty is better positioned for long-term success than ever before in our history.
Our financial strength is at an all-time high.
Most of the credit challenges in our legacy insured portfolio have been resolved.
Our markets are extensive, our opportunities diverse, our human capital exceptional, and our business model has been proven through multiple economic cycles.
We are committed to meeting the high expectations of our policyholders, clients, and shareholders.
Our fourth quarter 2021 adjusted operating income was $273 million, or $3.88 per share, a substantial increase from the fourth quarter 2020 adjusted operating income of $56 million, or $0.69 per share.
The primary factor driving the increase in fourth quarter 2021 total adjusted operating income was the insurance segment, where adjusted operating income grew by 134% from $109 million in Q4 2020 to $277 million in Q4 2021.
This improvement largely resulted from our loss mitigation strategies, particularly for our Puerto Rico exposure.
After years of negotiations and loss mitigation efforts, we are close to resolving $1.4 billion in gross par associated with our Puerto Rico GO, PBA, CCDA, and PREPA exposures.
The increased certainty of the settlement, Puerto Rico's improved economic outlook, and the higher value of our actual and expected recoveries under the settlement agreements were the main drivers of the $186 million economic benefit in the fourth quarter of 2021.
In Q4 2021, we sold a portion of our salvage and subrogation recoverables related to certain matured Puerto Rico GO and PREPA exposures, generating proceeds of $383 million and realizing some of our expected recoveries early.
We continued to sell portions of our GO, PBA, and PREPA salvage and subrogation recoverables in 2022, resulting in additional proceeds of $133 million.
The prices at which we realized these recoveries, along with observed market pricing for similar instruments and the forward interest rate environment, are reflected in our updated assumptions regarding the value of the remaining recovery bonds and contingent value instruments we expect to receive in various Puerto Rico settlements.
Other components of the insurance segment also performed well in Q4 2021.
Total income from investments, comprising net investment income on the fixed maturity portfolio and equity in earnings on short-term funds and other alternative investments, increased to $111 million from $94 million in Q4 2020.
Investments in Assured IM funds and alternative investments collectively generated $44 million in equity in earnings of investees in Q4 2021, compared to $24 million in Q4 2020, with the increase mainly due to a significant fair value gain on a specific private equity fund investment.
Equity in earnings of investees, which reflects mark-to-market movements in Assured IM funds and other alternative investments, is more volatile than net investment income from the fixed maturity portfolio and will fluctuate between periods.
Our fixed maturity and short-term investments, which constitute the largest portion of our portfolio, generated net investment income of $67 million in Q4 2021, compared to $70 million in Q4 2020.
As we reallocate fixed maturity assets to alternative investments, net investment income from fixed maturities may decline, but we are targeting enhanced long-term returns of over 10% on the alternative investment portfolio, exceeding our projected returns on the fixed maturity portfolio.
Regarding premiums, scheduled net earned premiums slightly decreased to $91 million in Q4 2021 from $94 million in Q4 2020.
Premium earnings from refundings and terminations were $20 million in Q4 2021, compared to $65 million in Q4 2020 when two large transactions were refunded.
The asset management segment reported an adjusted operating loss of $3 million in Q4 2021, an improvement from the $20 million loss in Q4 2020.
The asset management segment's improved results are mainly due to higher management fees from strategies introduced after acquiring Blue Mountain in 2019, and the absence of a one-time $13 million impairment charge on a lease right of use asset in 2020
Asset management fees at the segment level reached $21 million in Q4 2021, up from $20 million in Q4 2020
Increased fees from healthcare opportunity funds and CLOs outweighed the decrease in fees from wind down funds as investors continued to receive distributions
Wind down funds' AUM decreased to $582 million by December 31, 2021, down from $1.6 million a year earlier
The effective tax rate in Q4 2021 was 15.1%, compared to 12.7% in Q4 2020, which included the release of a reserve for uncertain tax positions
The adjusted operating income's overall effective tax rate varies between periods based on the proportion of income in different tax jurisdictions
The fourth quarter concluded a year of successful implementation of our strategic plans
Our achievements are reflected in the 2021 full year adjusted operating income of $470 million, which includes a $175 million pre-tax loss on debt extinguishment, or $138 million after tax
Despite the debt extinguishment charge, the full year 2021 adjusted operating income showed an 84% increase compared to the 2020 figure of $256 million
The insurance segment was the main contributor to this increase, with $722 million in adjusted operating income for 2021, up from $421 million in 2020
U.S. public finance saw improvements due to increased recovery assumptions for Puerto Rico exposures and U.S. RMBS benefits, mainly resulting from home price appreciation
Economic loss development, excluding deferred premium revenue effects, resulted in a $287 million benefit in 2021
The entire portfolio's loss expense in 2020 was $204 million, primarily related to Puerto Rico
For the full year, total income from the investment portfolio reached $424 million in 2021, compared to $371 million in 2020
The investment returns on the portion of the portfolio invested in Assured IM funds showcase a crucial aspect of the asset management segment's benefits, not just as a fee-earning business but also as an investment advisor for our insurance segments
Assured IM funds in which insurance subsidiaries invested generated $80 million in gains for 2021, up from $42 million in 2020
The gains were spread across all strategies, particularly healthcare, CLOs, and asset-based, resulting in a year-to-date return of 20.8%
Third-party alternative investments also produced gains of $64 million in 2021, an increase from $19 million in 2020
These gains more than compensated for the reduced net investment income on the available-for-sale fixed maturity portfolio, which decreased to $280 million in 2021 from $310 million in 2020
The year-over-year difference was primarily due to lower average balances, fixed maturity portfolio reinvestment yields, and income from loss mitigation securities
Total net earned premiums and credit-driven revenues amounted to $438 million in 2021, down from $540 million in 2020, including premium accelerations of $66 million and $130 million, respectively
In the asset management segment, we made significant progress in 2021
We attracted new third-party capital for our CLO, healthcare, and asset-based strategies
We increased fee-earning CLO AUM by issuing $2.8 billion in CLOs and selling CLO equity from legacy funds, while continuing to liquidate assets in wind-down funds
The asset management segment's operating loss improved from $50 million in 2020 to $90 million in 2021, mainly due to an increase in management fees from $59 million in 2020 to $76 million in 2021
Higher fees from CLOs and opportunity funds more than offset the decline in fees from wind-down funds
The increase in opportunity fund fees was primarily due to new healthcare funds launched in late 2020, which raised additional third-party capital in late 2021
The corporate division reported an adjusted operating loss of $253 million in 2021, including a $175 million loss on debt extinguishment, or $138 million after tax
This resulted from $600 million in debt redemptions mentioned earlier, with the charge representing an acceleration of expenses that would have occurred over time
In the previous year, the corporate division's adjusted operating loss was $111 million
The debt redemptions were financed using proceeds from $900 million in new 10-year and 30-year debt issuances, reducing the average coupon on redeemed debt from 5.89% to 3.35% and decreasing our 2024 debt refinancing needs by $170 million
The debt refinancing also generated annual debt service savings of $5.2 million until the next maturity date and provided flexibility for continued share repurchases
We accomplished this without significantly affecting our debt leverage or interest coverage ratios, using the additional $300 million from debt issuances primarily for share repurchases
In Q4 2021, we repurchased 3.7 million shares for $192 million at an average price of $51.47 per share
This brings the full year 2021 purchases to 10.5 million shares, or $496 million, representing 14% of total shares outstanding at the beginning of the year
The ongoing success of this program helped drive our per-share book value metrics to record highs as of December 31, 2021
After the quarter ended, we repurchased an additional 1.7 million shares for $91 million
Since starting our repurchase program in January 2013, we have returned $4.2 billion to shareholders, resulting in a 69% reduction in total shares outstanding
The cumulative effect of these purchases benefited adjusted operating shareholder's equity per share by over $37 and adjusted book value per share by $65, driving these metrics to new record highs
Regarding liquidity, the holding companies currently have cash and investments of approximately $274 million, with $124 million in AGL
These funds are available for liquidity needs or to pursue strategic initiatives to enhance our business or repurchase shares for capital management
This week, the Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of an additional $350 million of common shares
Under this and previous authorizations, the company is now authorized to purchase $364 million of its common shares
Additionally, we declared a dividend of $0.27 per share, a 13.6% increase from the previous dividend of $0.22 per share
Looking ahead to 2022 and beyond, we are optimistic that our largest single BIG exposure, Puerto Rico, will be substantially resolved by year-end
We expect the interest rate environment to be more conducive to new insurance business production and that the asset management segment and alternative asset strategies will continue to contribute to the company's progress toward its long-term strategic goals
Summary:
output: q4 adjusted non-gaap operating earnings per share $3.88.
