input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:My name is Jeff Kotkin and I serve as the Vice President of Investor Relations at Eversource Energy.
Today's speakers include our new President and CEO, Joe Nolan, and our Executive VP and CFO, Phil Lembo.
Joining us are John Moreira, our Treasurer and Senior VP for Finance and Regulatory, as well as Jay Buth, our VP and Controller.
We sincerely hope that everyone on the call is in good health and that your loved ones are safe and well.
I'm excited about the opportunity to meet many more of you in the coming years and share my positive outlook and enthusiasm for Eversource's future and its strong investment potential.
I'm thankful to the Eversource Board of Trustees and Jim for entrusting me with the leadership of this exceptionally dedicated and high-performing organization.
By approving these changes at the executive level, the Eversource Board is demonstrating its faith in our long-term strategy, which focuses on our core regulated business and includes an exciting investment in offshore wind.
In today's world, customer service, safety, and reliability are more crucial than ever before.
We must always remember that our 4.3 million customers are the reason we exist; they are our highest priority.
Our customers foot the bills and deserve the dependable and secure utility service that we are obligated to provide.
In the coming decades, we will invest tens of billions of dollars in our energy and water delivery systems, which will play a vital role in preparing New England for a clean energy future, and we anticipate being a key driver of that clean energy transition.
However, I must first address our company's relationship with Connecticut.
We employ thousands of people in Connecticut who work tirelessly each day to provide our 1.7 million natural gas, water, and electric customers with the most reliable and responsive service possible.
During emergencies, which we've experienced far too frequently over the past year due to unprecedented storm levels, our employees work up to 16-hour shifts for as long as necessary to ensure that our customers' service is restored quickly and safely, even during a pandemic.
Therefore, it was deeply upsetting for me to read certain parts of the Tropical Storm Isaias decision released on April 28th.
It failed to acknowledge the dedication of our hardworking employees in the company I've been chosen to lead.
Our customers, PURA, and our company all share the same goal: excellent service every day of the year.
And when severe weather strikes, we aim to restore power as safely and quickly as possible.
The women and men of Eversource work diligently every day to meet these expectations.
The PURA report on storm response clearly identified areas for improvement.
We recognize that we need to enhance not only our response plan but also our relationship with PURA.
This was evident from the April 28 decision and subsequent notice of violation.
I can assure you that we have received this message loud and clear and are already taking steps to improve on both fronts.
Shifting our focus to our clean energy initiatives.
You may be aware of the climate legislation that Massachusetts Governor Baker signed into law earlier this spring.
Among its many provisions, the law will permit each of the state's utilities to construct up to 280 megawatts of solar generation, allowing NSTAR Electric to increase its solar generation in rate base from 70 megawatts to 350 megawatts.
As Phil mentioned during our year-end earnings call, we have allocated approximately $500 million for this initiative from 2022 to 2025.
Another aspect that directly affects us is the 2,400 megawatt expansion of Massachusetts' offshore wind authorization, increasing it from 3,200 megawatts to 5,600 megawatts.
This expansion will help maintain Massachusetts' position at the forefront of offshore wind development in the United States.
As shown on Slide 2, there are now over 10,000 megawatts of unawarded offshore wind authorizations in Southern New England and New York, with Massachusetts set to award up to 1,600 megawatts later this year.
In fact, Massachusetts issued its RFP just last Friday.
Our offshore wind partnership with Orsted is very important to me.
Having initiated this relationship and worked closely with our partner in recent years, it is a crucial element of our clean energy growth strategy.
We have already seen several positive offshore wind developments this year.
As shown on Slide 3, in early January, the Bureau of Ocean Management (BOEM) released its draft environmental impact statement on the South Fork project.
Comments were received by late February, and we anticipate seeing the final EIS this summer.
The Bureau of Ocean Energy Management is expected to decide on our final federal permits for the project in January 2022.
If the January timeline is met, we anticipate starting construction in early 2022 and finishing the project by the end of 2023.
Furthermore, the New York Public Service Commission granted the required state siting permit for the project in late March, while East Hampton's local authorities approved the necessary real estate rights.
Now let's discuss Revolution Wind.
BOEM recently published a timeline for evaluating the 704 megawatt project.
The schedule indicates that a final environmental impact statement will be released in March 2023, with a final decision on the construction and operating plan expected by late July 2023.
The publication of this timeline marks a significant advancement for the project.
Revolution Wind and South Fork are among only three projects in the Northeast to reach this important stage.
In the coming months, we and Orsted will examine the BOEM and Rhode Island permitting processes to estimate a construction timeline for Revolution Wind.
We anticipate receiving BOEM's review schedule for our 924 megawatt Sunrise Wind project later this year.
We continue to make considerable headway in preparing for the start of construction.
Recently, we've announced agreements with two crucial ports that will serve as construction staging areas.
New London, Connecticut will be the hub for turbine assembly, while Providence, Rhode Island will focus on foundation construction.
These communities will experience substantial economic benefits from their involvement in our construction activities, including hundreds of direct jobs.
We are also very optimistic about the positive signals coming from Washington.
President Biden has emphasized his backing for offshore wind development along the Atlantic coast and has enlisted several cabinet members to support this initiative.
The aim is to have approximately 30,000 megawatts of offshore wind turbines operational in the U.S. by 2030.
We expect to contribute significantly to this output through our collaboration with Orsted.
More than 1,750 megawatts are already under contract to supply power to Connecticut, New York, and Rhode Island.
I'm looking forward to speaking with many of you at the upcoming AGA Virtual Conference.
I'll now hand the call over to Phil.
Let's begin with Slide 4, which shows that earnings were $1.06 per share in the first quarter, compared to $1.01 per share in the same period last year.
Both years' results included after-tax costs related to our recent acquisition of Columbia Gas of Massachusetts assets, amounting to $0.02 per share this year and $0.01 per share in 2020.
The Electric Distribution and Natural Gas Distribution segments showed the most notable year-over-year changes.
Electric Distribution earned $0.27 per share in this year's first quarter, down from $0.39 per share in the same period last year.
This decrease was primarily due to two main factors.
First, we recorded a $30 million charge, or $0.07 per share, mainly reflecting $28.4 million in customer credits and an additional $1.6 million penalty to be paid to Connecticut.
These penalties stem from a Notice of Violation issued by Connecticut regulators last week, regarding our power restoration performance following Tropical Storm Isaias last August.
The regulatory review of this penalty is set to conclude in mid-July this year.
Additionally, Electric Distribution results were negatively impacted by roughly $20 million in higher storm-related expenses in the first quarter of 2021, compared to a relatively quiet and mild first quarter in 2020.
We experienced 31 separate storm events across our three states this quarter, in contrast to limited activity in Q1 2020.
Conversely, our Natural Gas Distribution segment showed a significant increase in earnings, now being about 50% larger than a year ago.
It earned $0.43 per share in the first quarter of 2021, up from $0.26 per share in the same period last year.
The improved results were primarily due to the addition of Eversource Gas of Massachusetts, which contributed $0.14 per share in the quarter.
We also saw higher revenues at NSTAR Gas and Yankee Gas, partially offset by increased O&M and depreciation expenses.
It's worth noting that the transition process for Eversource Gas of Massachusetts continues to progress exceptionally well.
We are transitioning from NiSource systems to Eversource platforms, aiming to cut expenses and enhance customer service
Significant progress has been made, with over 80% of business processes now transferred to Eversource from NiSource
Customers, communities, and staff are responding positively to Eversource's ownership of the distribution system, and we are meeting or surpassing our set financial and operational goals
In the Electric Transmission segment, our earnings per share increased from $0.38 in Q1 2020 to $0.39 in Q1 2021
The improved results were primarily due to increased investment in transmission facilities, partially counteracted by dilution from additional share issuance
Our Water Distribution segment's earnings rose from $2.1 million in Q1 2020 to $3.6 million in Q1 2021
The improvement in results was mainly attributable to reduced interest expenses and a lower effective tax rate
Aquarion recently announced plans to acquire a small investor-owned water system operating in Connecticut, Massachusetts, and New Hampshire
The company, called New England Service Company, provides water to approximately 10,000 customers across three states and has a rate base of about $25 million
This acquisition aligns with our growth strategy for our water delivery business
Pending timely regulatory approvals, we anticipate finalizing the transaction by year-end and expect it to be immediately accretive in 2022
We are maintaining our long-term earnings-per-share growth rate projection in the upper half of the 5% to 7% range
We have adjusted our 2021 earnings guidance to account for customer credits, now projecting earnings per share towards the lower end of the $3.81 to $3.93 range, including a $0.07 per share impact from the credits
While our main operating companies don't have pending base rate reviews, we have several ongoing regulatory dockets in Connecticut
PURA has identified a 90 basis point reduction in our authorized distribution ROE, likely to be addressed in the current CL&P interim rate decrease proceeding
Based on PURA's revised schedule, we believe any ROE reduction would not take effect until October 1st this year
To provide context, CL&P's current authorized ROE is 9.25%, with approximately $5 billion of rate base
PURA recently finalized an interim decision on the recovery of certain tracked costs by CL&P, with some changes to be implemented on June 1st and others deferred until October 1st
The interim decision incorporated several positive modifications from an earlier draft, which we appreciate
PURA is also reviewing other dockets, including potential grid modernization initiatives, AMI electric vehicle programs, and storage
We were disappointed by recent developments regarding FERC's ongoing notice of proposed rulemaking concerning incentives for utilities participating in regional transmission organizations
FERC will be accepting comments and replies on the proposed changes before making a final decision
As a general guideline, a 10 basis point reduction in our transmission ROE affects consolidated earnings by about $0.01 per share
We've completed $450 million in debt issuances this year, primarily to repay maturities at Eversource parent and Aquarion in Connecticut
We haven't issued additional equity this year beyond our ongoing dividend reinvestment and employee incentive programs
We continue to expect to issue approximately $700 million of new equity through an after-market program at various points during our forecast period
Our operations have had a strong start this year, with electric reliability in the top industry quartile
Our safety record has improved further, with fewer employee injuries compared to Q1 2020
All three of our natural gas utilities are exceeding their emergency response requirements
Aquarion's water quality is consistently surpassing its target
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 earnings per share of $1.06.
q1 earnings per share $1.06.
reaffirmed projected long-term earnings per share growth rate in upper half of range of 5 to 7%.
estimates it will earn toward lower end of 2021 recurring earnings per share guidance of $3.81 to $3.93 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Yesterday evening, we made public the outcomes of our Q4 for the 2021 fiscal year, which can be found in the IR portion of our site.
To offer a clearer picture of our operational performance, we utilize certain non-GAAP financial metrics that involve modifications to GAAP outcomes.
It's important to note that any presented non-GAAP financial measures should not be viewed as substitutes for the financial measures mandated by GAAP.
Erica will delve into the specifics of the business segments and corporate finances.
One year ago today.
I discussed our readiness to succeed as the recovery unfolds, and I believe 2021 demonstrates that we were indeed prepared.
The 2021 fiscal year was exceptional for Cabot, as we bounced back from the COVID-induced lows of 2020 to achieve record-breaking results.
We attained this through a blend of exceptional execution and our dedication to fostering growth via distinctive investments.
I'd like to take a moment to reflect on the year's achievements.
The Cabot operational model is grounded in commercial and operational excellence, and our proficiency in these areas drove our outstanding performance in fiscal year 2021.
We achieved a record adjusted earnings per share of $5.02 and a total segment EBIT of $550 million.
Our emphasis on cash management resulted in an unprecedented discretionary free cash flow of $353 million.
The economic landscape in 2021 demanded resilience and adaptability, and I'm immensely proud of how the Cabot team worked tirelessly to meet our customers' changing needs.
Our team is driven by the desire to serve our customers and innovate alongside them.
This task was made more challenging in 2021 due to the numerous global supply chain disruptions faced by companies and the ongoing evolution of necessary COVID safety protocols, which altered our usual working methods.
Furthermore, companies encountered rapidly increasing input costs, necessitating dynamic commercial management.
Our teams collaborated closely with our customers to navigate this environment, and we were successful in our pricing strategies to maintain robust margins and invest in supporting our customers' long-term supply requirements.
The 2021 fiscal year marked the sixth year of our advancing the core strategy, and I'm very satisfied with our execution record and the growth prospects for our company.
Adjusted earnings per share has grown at a compound annual rate of 11% since the inception of our strategy, surpassing our 7% to 10% target.
Our approach has been characterized by a focus on growth centered around our core segments and disciplined execution.
While we're pleased with our results since 2015, I'm even more excited about the growth opportunities ahead and the progress we made in 2021.
Our growth strategy is based on the principle of investing from positions of strength and in areas where we believe we have a competitive advantage.
Several highlights from 2021 are particularly noteworthy.
Our unrivaled portfolio of conductive carbon additives and our strong customer-focused model led to a doubling of revenue in our battery materials business compared to the previous year.
We're advancing with the conversion of our Xuzhou, China plants to specialty carbons, and this investment will drive growth across our wide range of specialty carbon applications while freeing up additional capacity to support battery materials.
Our inkjet business is well-positioned to capitalize on the shift from analog to digital printing in the commercial and packaging segments, and we secured multiple OEM qualifications in 2021, setting us up for growth as inkjet presses penetrate these markets.
Lastly, we're continuing to execute a project to construct a specialty compounds production line in Cilegon, Indonesia, which will enable us to meet customer demand for black masterbatch in this high-growth region.
While growth and execution are highlights of 2021, these accomplishments have been achieved with sustainability at the forefront.
We continued our sustainability journey in 2021 with several notable achievements.
First and foremost, we pledged to align our disclosures with the recommendations of the Task Force for Climate-Related Financial Disclosure (TCFD) and engaged a third party to help us assess climate risks and opportunities following the TCFD guidelines.
We plan to share the results of this work in the coming months.
Despite the challenging operating environment of 2021, I'm very proud of our performance in employee safety.
Our total recordable incident rate of 0.34 keeps us firmly among the top-performing chemical and industrial companies.
We also completed a major air emissions control project at our carbon black manufacturing facility in Louisiana.
This investment in control technology will improve air quality by substantially eliminating nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide emissions and ensure that we can support our customers' supply needs sustainably over the long term.
Additionally, waste heat from the plant is being recovered and used to generate up to 50MW of cogeneration power without creating any additional emissions.
In August, we unveiled a new $1 billion revolving credit facility with pricing linked to our credit ratings and performance in reducing sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions.
This deal underscores our dedication to sustainability and was among the first such agreements in the U.S. chemical sector.
As a chemical industry, we must attract diverse and talented individuals from the next generation to pursue careers in chemistry.
Cabot is participating in the Future of STEM Scholars Initiative (FOSSI), which aims to create opportunities for students from historically black colleges and universities to enter and excel in STEM careers within the chemical industry.
We are proud to be a founding sponsor of this initiative, which will have a significant and transformative impact on both the students and our industry.
We achieved excellent financial results and made significant progress towards our strategic goals in 2021.
This comprehensive success demonstrates the strength of our portfolio and the exceptional quality of our team.
I'd like to share a few thoughts on the fourth quarter.
I'm happy to report strong fourth quarter results, with adjusted earnings per share of $1.11.
This performance was 63% higher than the same period last year, despite challenges from the semiconductor chip shortage, ongoing global supply chain issues, and increased maintenance spending due to the timing of turnarounds.
We maintained momentum in battery materials, ending the year with EBITDA within our previously stated range of $15 million to $20 million.
Cash flow from operations was robust at $100 million for the quarter, despite the impact of higher raw material costs.
Let's begin by examining the results of the Reinforcement Materials segment.
In the fourth quarter and full year of fiscal 2021, EBIT for Reinforcement Materials grew by $8 million and $167 million respectively, compared to the same periods in the previous year.
These increases were primarily due to improved unit margins and higher volumes.
Margins improved due to higher spot pricing, especially in Asia.
The volume increases in the fourth quarter and full year of fiscal 2021 were attributable to a strong recovery across all regions from the COVID-related impacts in fiscal 2020.
Fourth quarter results were also affected by higher costs related to plant maintenance.
Globally, volumes rose by 6% in the fourth quarter compared to the same period last year, with 6% growth in the Americas, 5% in Europe, and 7% in Asia.
Higher volumes were driven by strong demand across all regions as the replacement tire market remained robust.
For the first quarter of fiscal 2022, we anticipate a sequential increase in EBIT due to lower fixed costs from reduced plant maintenance spending and a modest increase in volumes as demand for replacement tires remains solid.
Turning to Performance Chemicals, EBIT increased by $20 million in the fourth quarter and $93 million for the full year compared to the same periods in fiscal 2020, primarily due to improved product mix, stronger volumes, and higher customer pricing.
The improved product mix was driven by increased sales in automotive and conductive carbon applications within our specialty carbons and compounds product line.
Pricing improved year-over-year in our fumed silica product lines, particularly in China.
Year-over-year volumes in the fourth fiscal quarter grew by 2% in performance additives but decreased by 8% in formulated solutions.
Volumes were impacted during the quarter, largely due to two plant outages as discussed in last quarter's call.
This segment experienced increased maintenance costs in the fourth fiscal quarter as expected, but these higher costs were offset by $7 million in insurance proceeds related to a claim from earlier in fiscal 2021.
Looking ahead to the first quarter of fiscal 2022, we expect sequential volume growth as one of the impacted plants has resumed operations and we anticipate positive growth in our battery materials product line.
We foresee higher input costs in the first quarter that will temporarily impact results until our latest round of announced price increases and surcharges can be fully implemented to recover the rising costs.
Regarding Purification Solutions, EBIT in the fourth quarter of 2021 increased by $4 million compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020, and full year EBIT increased by $7 million.
These increases were driven by lower fixed costs resulting from the sale of the mine in Texas and the related long-term activated carbon supply agreement, as well as the positive impact of improved pricing in our specialty applications.
Looking ahead to the first quarter of fiscal 2022, we expect EBIT to decline sequentially due to seasonally lower volumes and higher maintenance costs associated with planned turnaround activities.
Now, let's discuss corporate items.
We concluded the quarter with a cash balance of $168 million, and our liquidity position remains strong at approximately $1.3 billion.
In Q4 of fiscal 2021, operational cash flows amounted to $100 million, including a $4 million reduction in working capital
Q4 fiscal 2021 saw capital expenditures of $80 million, with an additional $20 million allocated for dividend payments
Throughout fiscal 2021, operational cash flow reached $257 million, encompassing a $222 million rise in net working capital
The increase in working capital was primarily attributed to higher raw material costs affecting inventory and accounts receivable, as price increases were passed on to customers
Business growth year-on-year also contributed to the increase
Capital expenditures for fiscal 2021 totaled $195 million, covering targeted growth investments and U.S. EPA compliance projects
For fiscal 2022, capital expenditures are projected to range between $225 million and $250 million
This projection includes ongoing U.S. EPA compliance spending and increased investment in high-confidence, high-return growth projects
Growth-related capital includes upgrading our new China carbon black plant for specialty carbon production, expected to be operational in the latter half of 2022
We are also developing a new specialty compounds unit in Indonesia and planning capacity expansions in battery materials and inkjet
During the fiscal year, an additional $80 million was used for dividend payments
The operating tax rate for fiscal 2021 was 27%, with an expected range of 27% to 29% for fiscal 2022
Looking forward to 2022, I am enthusiastic about our growth prospects
Allow me to outline our key objectives for the coming year
Our first priority is to conclude 2022 tire customer agreements, with positive expectations as supply security remains crucial for customers
Demand is strong and projected to remain robust across all regions
Low inventory levels throughout the supply chain and ongoing global transportation challenges are increasing the value of local supply
Our second focus is to progress various strategic growth investments across the company
In battery materials, we plan to increase capacity at our carbon nanotube facility in Zhuhai, China
The conversion of our Suzhou plant to specialty carbons will provide 50,000 metric tons of additional capacity and allow our network to support battery materials growth
We anticipate completing our new specialty compounds production unit in Indonesia later in 2022, strengthening our position in the rapidly growing ASEAN region
Lastly, we aim to maintain our track record of delivering earnings growth and strong cash flow while preserving our investment grade rating and industry-leading dividend
This overview should provide insight into our 2022 priorities
To conclude my prepared remarks, I'll discuss our outlook for the year
We're pleased with the momentum from fiscal 2021 and optimistic about the new year
We anticipate improved performance in Reinforcement Materials starting in Q2, based on expected positive outcomes from our 2022 customer agreements
We expect improved results across all Performance Chemicals product lines, with above-market growth in battery materials and inkjet products
Based on these factors, we project adjusted earnings per share for fiscal 2020 to range from $5.20 to $5.60
First quarter results are expected to align with the fourth quarter, with performance improving throughout the year
Regarding cash flow, we anticipate strong free cash flow from year-over-year earnings growth, partially offset by increased working capital to support growth
Cash flow will be allocated to fund advantageous growth investments, dividends, and opportunistic share repurchases
Overall, I'm very optimistic about our company's current position and future direction
Our growth opportunities are more promising than ever during my tenure as CEO
The long-term fundamentals of our businesses remain strong
Our end markets are robust, and we continue to perform at a high level
Looking ahead, we believe we have a winning combination: a talented team, an excellent portfolio of growth-oriented businesses, and a strong balance sheet
These factors position us to achieve our strategic objectives and maintain our industry leadership and growth
Summary:
output:
compname reports fourth quarter diluted earnings per share of $0.50 and adjusted earnings per share of $1.11.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.11.
sees fy 2022 adjusted earnings per share $5.20 to $5.60.
coterra energy qtrly believe robust end-market demand will continue.
coterra energy - in our reinforcement materials segment, expect fy to benefit from higher volumes.
coterra energy - in performance chemicals segment, anticipate particular strength in battery materials and inkjet packaging in fy.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In line with our goals, our communities, guided by field staff, have continued operations and resident services while following CDC guidelines and local regulations.
Our corporate staff has adapted well to the new work environment, maintaining support for field teams and advancing strategic objectives.
I believe we've achieved some of our best work in the company's 27-year history during its most challenging period.
The next generation of ACC employees seems to be learning a lot about our business from their parents each day.
At the start of the pandemic, in accordance with our company values and objectives, we promised that no resident would lose their home due to inability to pay rent on time.
We pledged to be understanding of the financial difficulties our residents and their parents might face due to COVID and government shutdowns.
We also committed to being the best possible partner to our long-term ACE university associates.
Honoring these commitments resulted in short-term financial impacts reflected in the quarter's results.
At our off-campus apartments and on-campus communities leased in the open market, an average of 93.7% of residents paid rent in April, May, and June.
For those facing hardship, we provided nearly $9 million in direct financial assistance to over 6,500 residents and their parents through our hardship program.
We offered an additional $15 million in financial relief to students and parents at ACE on-campus communities where our university partners manage leasing, rent collection, and residence life.
Our waiving of rent payment and collection fees resulted in over $2 million of budgeted revenue not being collected this quarter.
As the team will discuss, this $24 million in financial relief and waived fee income accounts for most of our reduced revenue this quarter.
We offset some of this through expense reductions that didn't compromise the quality of service to our residents.
With most current leases ending soon and a new academic year approaching, unlike typical apartment renters, student tenants' financial situations may improve somewhat.
As many remember from college or parenting college students, each year students can apply for needs-based financial aid including grants, scholarships, and loans.
In spring and summer 2019, when financial aid assessments were made for the current academic year, the US economy was near all-time highs with record-low unemployment across demographics.
These favorable economic conditions likely influenced students' financial aid applications based on their and their parents' financial status at that time.
When COVID hit in March 2020, mid-academic year, many students and parents saw their income decrease significantly without additional financial aid support.
In contrast, as students applied for financial aid in spring and summer 2020 for the upcoming year, those experiencing financial hardship due to the pandemic are likely to qualify for more aid than the previous year.
We believe this needs-based increase in financial aid typically occurs during US recessions, possibly contributing to the student housing industry's resilience during economic downturns.
Looking ahead to the next academic year, while we don't expect a full return to normalcy in fall 2020, we're cautiously optimistic based on four factors.
First, universities are focusing on policies to promote safe academic delivery, facilitating some in-person instruction. Currently, 63 of our 68 served universities plan some in-person classes.
Second, universities now have data on COVID's impact on 18-22 year olds and understand how modern student housing facilitates sanitization and isolation during outbreaks.
Third, students desire to be in a college environment with peers rather than at home, even if instruction is mostly online.
Fourth, we're seeing continued improvement in overall leasing data, with above-normal activity in traffic, applications, leases, and renewals at our open market properties as of July 17.
As reported, with 5-11 weeks before classes start, we're 90% pre-leased for the upcoming year, 340 basis points behind last year.
While the variance to last year increased from 230 basis points in our May 31 update, the gap at our open market properties has decreased since then.
The recent velocity trends in traffic, applications, leases, and renewals suggest this variance should continue to decrease for our core properties.
I'll now break down our cautious optimism in terms of ongoing risks and opportunities that may affect our final leasing numbers.
First, focusing on risks, we routinely manage three categories in every annual lease-up: renewal skips, relet requests, and no-shows.
We aim to relet any accommodations that become available for these reasons before classes begin.
A renewal skip occurs when a current leaseholder who signed a renewal lease for the next year vacates their apartment and stops paying rent, effectively skipping out on both leases.
These students are removed from our pre-leasing statistics due to their definitive actions.
So far, we've had 178 renewal skips, consistent with historical levels.
Regarding potential no-shows and relet requests, we started our management process earlier than usual to identify students not planning to return and those wanting help releasing their accommodations.
These potential no-shows and relet leases are included in our current pre-leasing numbers, as they always have been at this point.
We typically attempt to release these accommodations until the end of the lease-up process, then remove any actual no-shows and unsuccessful relets from our final statistics.
Historically, we only lose 35-60 basis points of final occupancy due to this process, which is reflected in our reported final leasing statistics.
Our final fall lease-up occupancy, averaging 97.5% over the years, has always accounted for these impacts.
We believe our diligent management of this process contributes to our occupancy rates typically exceeding the industry average by 200 basis points.
This year, we've implemented an extensive communication process to engage with residents about their plans, without directly asking if they intend to take possession or no-show.
For our open market properties, we currently have 72,009 leases for fall, with 28,057 renewals and 43,952 new leases, the latter presenting a higher no-show risk.
We've made 64,029 phone calls and had direct conversations with 68% of new leases and 20% of renewals.
Currently, we're seeing an increase in potential no-shows and relet requests compared to last year, though we're unsure how much of this increase is due to COVID versus our expedited process.
As of July 20, we've identified 689 potential no-shows compared to 135 last year.
Concerning relet requests, we presently have 1,563 for this year compared to 956 last year.
The total potential no-show relet for this year currently represents about 230 basis points of possible lost occupancy versus 110 basis points last year.
Historically, the number of no-shows typically rises in early August, coinciding with the first rent payment due date.
For instance, last year, the 135 potential no-shows as of July 20 peaked at 446 on August 5.
Through our standard procedures, we effectively managed the final impact to only 38 basis points of decrease due to actual no-shows and successful reletting.
We will vigilantly monitor rent payments and increases in potential no-shows during early August to determine if normal or above-average increases occur or if our efforts to expedite these processes actually accelerated identification of potential no-shows and relets earlier than usual.
As of July 20, the combined no-show and relet net difference compared to last year is 1,161, representing 120 basis points of potential lost occupancy.
Reletting both no-show and relet requests in the COVID environment will likely be more difficult.
This year, with fewer properties fully leased and often lacking waiting lists to facilitate this process, we'll need to rely mainly on increased traffic, applications, and leasing velocity compared to last year to fill these potential no-shows and relet requests.
Regarding opportunities that may further boost our leasing velocity beyond historical levels in the late stages of our lease-up, I'd like to discuss universities' fall housing de-densification activities due to COVID.
Each of these alternative uses has returns on paper equal to or exceeding the development's planned primary purpose.
Regarding San Francisco State University, officials have ordered a significant reduction in available on-campus housing for fall 2020 as part of efforts to decrease density.
Our project operates under a marketing and licensing agreement, with San Francisco State handling leasing administration for this academic year.
Following discussions with the University, we expect the project to open at 60% capacity with single occupancy configuration this fall.
There's a possibility of returning to full designed bed capacity for spring and summer 2021, and we'll continue to monitor the situation and collaborate closely with the University.
Concerning USC Health Sciences phase two, we are currently 72% pre-leased and are processing ongoing leasing activity and the no-show procedure for fall.
We will offer a comprehensive update on all fall deliveries during the Q3 call.
Turning to our on-campus P3 business.
We have a robust pipeline of on-campus development with 10 projects at various pre-development stages.
We expect to close and begin construction on our third-party project at Georgetown University in Q3 this year as initially planned.
However, due to COVID-19 disruptions, our third-party projects at Concordia, University of California, Berkeley, Upper Hearst and University of California, Irvine, are likely to be delayed until next year.
We currently anticipate closing and starting construction on all three projects in 2021, with Concordia aiming for delivery in fall 2022 and UC Berkeley and UC Irvine targeting fall 2023 delivery.
We continue to advance in the early stages of pre-development on our previously announced projects at MIT, Virginia Commonwealth University, Princeton, Northeastern, UC Berkeley and West Virginia University.
The final structure, scope, feasibility, fees and timing for all pre-development projects have not yet been determined.
Overall, while some procurement and housing initiatives have been temporarily delayed or suspended due to COVID-19, we continue to pursue numerous active procurements and see a promising future pipeline of on-campus development opportunities.
As Bill mentioned, universities nationwide have had to reduce density in on-campus housing, primarily affecting older traditional dorms with shared bathrooms.
Consumer preferences have also favored more modern apartment and suite-style accommodations that allow for easier sanitization and isolation within units if necessary.
Additionally, due to de-densification, reduced revenue streams, and related financial impacts, universities will use off-balance sheet financing structures to update their housing stock, including both project-based financing and equity-based models like our ACE program.
We anticipate that these factors will further accelerate the need to modernize outdated on-campus housing using P3 financing methods, and believe ACC is well-positioned as the established best-in-class partner to capitalize on this growing opportunity.
In addition to what we believe will be an expanding on-campus opportunity, ACC is also preparing to execute on opportunistic investments that may arise from the COVID-19 crisis and corresponding economic environment.
Given that our recent cost of public equity remains disconnected from private market valuations, it's prohibitive for us to execute on many investments in the current environment.
As such, we are expanding our joint venture equity strategy to pursue external growth.
We have engaged a financial advisor and are currently seeking equity sources for a joint venture or fund in which ACC would invest minimal equity or contribute existing assets as a minority general partner.
In addition to our existing partnership with Allianz, identifying external equity partners will allow ACC to pursue external growth off-balance sheet, while also offering further access to liquidity via dispositions if the current economic crisis continues.
We plan to use this off-balance-sheet structure to execute our proven core competency of identifying and implementing investment opportunities that drive outsized returns for both ACC and our strategic capital partners.
ACC will benefit through earnings per share and FFO growth from generating fees and potential promotes upon outperformance while requiring minimal equity investment to preserve our balance sheet for more accretive investments.
We will keep the market informed as we make progress.
Looking ahead to the fall 2021 academic year, we continue to see favorable reductions in new supply across our owned markets.
Within ACC's 68 markets, we are tracking 17,600 beds currently under construction for 2021, with a potential additional 1,200 beds planned but not yet under construction, reflecting a 14% to 20% decline in new supply following the current year's 20% decrease.
Even if all planned beds were delivered for fall 2021, this would be the lowest number of beds delivered in our markets since 2011.
We will update the market regarding these potential deliveries on our third quarter call.
As reported last night, total FFOM for the second quarter of 2020 was $50.9 million or $0.37 per fully diluted share.
As discussed, Q2 was significantly impacted by COVID-19 effects and associated governmental shelter-in-place orders implemented across the country.
While we can't completely isolate every pandemic-related item, we believe approximately $23 million to $24 million in FFOM was lost due to pandemic-related situations this quarter.
Overall, owned property revenue was negatively impacted by $32.4 million due to COVID-related rent relief, lost summer camp revenue, increased bad debt, waived fees, and other items.
Partially offsetting the lost revenue, owned property operating expenses were $8 million lower than originally budgeted as we reduced spending in all areas except for the uncontrollable insurance and property taxes.
As a result of the lower than originally budgeted property NOI, ground lease expense was approximately $500,000 less due to reduced outperformance rent paid to our university ground lessor partners.
Joint venture partners' noncontrolling interest in earnings was approximately $1.2 million lower.
Additionally, third-party management fee income was approximately $1 million lower and FFOM contribution from our on-campus participating properties was almost $800,000 lower due to universities refunding a portion of spring rents at properties in both business segments.
Lastly, we created approximately $800,000 in G&A and third-party overhead expense savings relative to our original plan for the quarter.
Due to continued uncertainty created by the pandemic and the ultimate effect of university actions regarding curriculum delivery for the 2021 academic year, we are not issuing new 2020 earnings guidance at this time.
However, we want to make you aware of some additional pandemic impacts expected as we close out the current academic year in the first couple of months of the coming quarter.
July will be the last month of current in-place leases at most of our properties, and we expect delinquencies will not differ significantly from recent months.
We also anticipate additional refunds in our on-campus ACE portfolio for the remainder of the summer term, expected to range from approximately $1.5 million to $2.5 million, which should still keep us within the originally communicated range of expected refunds.
Regarding other income, we continue to expect little to no summer camp business, and we are continuing to waive late fees and convenience fees through the remainder of the current academic year, which combined is expected to result in a $5 million to $6 million loss in other income in the third quarter.
As William discussed, we now believe it's likely that the three third-party development projects at the University of California, Irvine, Berkeley and Concordia University originally scheduled to commence in 2020 will be delayed until 2021.
These projects were expected to contribute a combined $4 million in development fee income in 2020.
While there will be some continued financial impacts of the pandemic in the immediate future, the consumer sentiment and university policies Bill discussed give us confidence that our operating results will return to normalized levels in the long term.
Meanwhile, we have a strong, healthy balance sheet and substantial liquidity to absorb the disruption.
We further improved the Company's balance sheet liquidity in June with a well-received 10-year $400 million bond offering, using the proceeds to reduce the outstanding balance on the Company's $1 billion revolving credit facility.
As of June 30, we had over $800 million available on our revolver, with no remaining debt maturities in 2020 and a manageable $167 million in secured mortgage debt maturing in 2021.
As detailed on page S15 of our earnings supplemental, including all projects currently under development for delivery through 2023, we have only $279 million in remaining development capital needs.
As of June 30, the Company's debt to total asset value was 40.9% and net debt to EBITDA was 7.6 times.
Although our leverage ratios are temporarily elevated relative to our historically communicated targets due to the short-term COVID-related disruption discussed, we feel confident about the capital plan outlined on page S15, which will bring the Company's debt to total assets back into the mid-30% range and debt to EBITDA back to the high-5 times to low-6 times range.
Summary:

q2 same store net operating income decreased by 20.9 percent versus q2 2019.
anticipates about $1.5 to $2.5 million in rent refunds in q3 of 2020.
no remaining debt maturities in 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Before commencing, I'd like to note that Earl is a recent addition, having joined less than a month ago following the end of the fiscal year; while he's quickly adapting to the business, please direct any post-call inquiries to Investor Relations.
It's surprising that we're already discussing our fourth quarter results as 2020 comes to a close.
Conversely, we're about to review only the second complete quarter showing COVID-19's financial impact.
Our fourth quarter revenue was approximately $1.5 billion.
This shows a 9.9% decrease compared to last year, but a significant sequential improvement from our over 15% decline in Q3.
Our diverse clientele once again demonstrates our business's resilience.
The Technology & Manufacturing sector grew by nearly 7%, while Business & Industry and Education sectors showed only slight revenue decreases.
As anticipated, our Aviation segment was the main cause of our organic decline compared to the previous year.
Technical Solutions also experienced a substantial revenue drop and continued to face challenges with site access, affecting churn rates.
On a positive note, Technical Solutions has a healthy backlog of committed work and a strong pipeline for 2021.
Considering all factors, the quarter's revenue performance was satisfactory.
Regarding profitability, we saw continued demand for higher-margin COVID-related work orders and our enhanced cleaning program, particularly in Business & Industry and Technology & Manufacturing sectors.
Our variable labor model and ability to adjust staffing based on demand protected our financial performance, and we continued to see profit advantages by efficiently managing labor as we scaled and consolidated staff during the quarter.
This has been a key factor in our financial performance throughout the pandemic.
Due to these factors, we increased earnings on both a GAAP and adjusted basis compared to last year.
Income from continued operations increased to $53.1 million or $0.78 per share.
On an adjusted basis, we achieved $46.7 million or $0.69 per share.
Adjusted EBITDA margin rose to 6.2% from 5.6% last year.
These results are even more impressive considering they include a non-cash reserve we took for an entertainment-related project within our Technical Solutions segment.
This was a unique client situation and not indicative of our broader project portfolio within Technical Solutions.
This had a 120 basis point impact on our adjusted EBITDA margin and earnings.
Even including this unusual event, our performance continues to show consistent strength and execution quarter after quarter.
2020 will be remembered as a transformative year for ABM in many ways.
The pandemic has shifted public perception, with professional Class A janitorial services now undeniably viewed as essential and non-discretionary.
Facility owners must now prove they're providing clean, healthy, and safe spaces that occupants can trust.
This will not only be required but will also reflect on their brand.
Our EnhancedClean service response gives clients peace of mind through studied protocols and practices that maintain facility safety, setting us apart from competitors.
As a company with over 110 years of history, ABM has endured and grown through many global events.
However, 2020 tested us in unprecedented ways, and I've never been more inspired by our organization.
I'd like to highlight some of our team's specific accomplishments.
Since March, we've been at the forefront of battling a pandemic that has disrupted nearly every industry.
While navigating a constantly changing environment as we learned more about the virus, we prioritized the health and safety of our employees and clients above all else.
Our procurement team excelled in providing PPE and maintaining our global supply chain when others in our industry struggled to meet surging demands.
We also joined forces with large cleaning contractors to form the Cleaning Coalition of America, representing our industry which played a crucial role in restoring our country.
The Coalition aims to advocate for vaccine priority for our industry and has developed a focused campaign to raise awareness about what distinguishes best-in-class providers.
At ABM, we take pride in proactively developing our own expert-backed certified programs to address our clients' needs with disinfection protocols, including specialized training and signage, electrostatic spraying of disinfectant, and air filtration.
This is all supported by one of our most comprehensive marketing campaigns to date.
It's important to recognize that we mobilized multiple cross-functional task forces across all critical areas of our business, enhancing our adaptability and creating lasting improvements beyond the pandemic.
These task forces led to improved operating procedures for labor management, sales, and financial activities.
For instance, our approach to collections resulted in generating over $450 million in cash flow from operations and $420 million in free cash flow, both company records.
This translates to nearly $1 billion in liquidity, including $400 million in cash, which is an extremely advantageous position during these uncertain times.
As we enter 2021, we aim to capitalize on this momentum and shift from a defensive to an offensive strategy.
Starting with our executive team, we recently announced several appointments to better align our internal organizational structure with our business strategies.
Earl is an experienced finance executive who joins us from Best Buy, a leading Fortune 500 provider of consumer technology products and services with 125,000 employees in North America.
Earl held various executive positions in finance, and most recently was responsible for leading enterprise capital project planning, transformation and procurement, as well as supporting digital and technology and global real estate.
During his time at Best Buy, Earl also spearheaded several strategic initiatives targeting labor and logistics.
Earl joined less than three weeks ago but is quickly familiarizing himself with our business.
I'm also pleased to announce that Rene Jacobsen has been promoted to Chief Operating Officer and will lead all of our client-facing industry groups.
In his eight years at ABM, Rene has consistently driven our operational performance and service excellence, and his leadership was undoubtedly crucial in our successful navigation of 2020.
As COO, he will provide strategic guidance for our operations and drive financial results across all our platforms.
Rene will continue to work closely with Sean Mahoney, our new President of Sales and Marketing.
Since Sean joined ABM in 2017, we've broken sales records each year, achieving another record in 2020 with new sales at $1.2 billion - an impressive accomplishment in any year, but especially in a year when much of the economy was at a standstill.
The combined leadership of Rene and Sean proved to be a powerful force for our operations and sales teams in 2020 and will undoubtedly exceed our expectations in 2021.
Regarding 2021, we will be sharing our refreshed business strategy later in the year, which builds on the positive changes and acceleration we saw with our 2020 vision.
At that time, we will review our technology plan and path toward a digital platform for our employees and clients.
As mentioned last quarter, some of our near-term investments involve restarting IT projects that were put on hold due to the pandemic, such as our ERP system and data management roadmap.
Some investments will be novel due to opportunities emerging from the pandemic, like EnhancedClean and its associated program development.
Regarding that, from a return on investment perspective, we ended the year with over $300 million in revenue from our EnhancedClean program and COVID-related activities.
We have exciting marketing and sales initiatives planned in the coming months to further accelerate growth and differentiate ourselves in the market.
We will take a responsible approach to investments given the uncertain environment, while balancing long-term planning with intense focus on near-term developments.
Conditions remain unpredictable, especially as we operate through the winter season.
COVID cases are increasing nationwide and you've likely observed or experienced various levels of closures in your own areas.
Unfortunately, the business environment is no more predictable now than it was three months ago.
Clients are generally planning for the short-term as they respond to resurgences, causing occupancy fluctuations, and they can't yet forecast when most employees will return to workplaces.
While vaccine news is positive, the timeline for widespread availability and uptake is still unknown, which could affect the timing of recovery and reopenings.
As a result, our visibility remains limited and we are not providing guidance for the full 2021 fiscal year as you would expect.
However, we will share our expectations for the upcoming first fiscal quarter.
We anticipate this will be the only time we provide such a short-term outlook, given the unique circumstances.
For Q1, we project GAAP earnings of $0.53 to $0.58 per diluted share, or adjusted earnings of $0.60 to $0.65 per diluted share.
These ranges represent significant year-over-year increases compared to last year's $0.41 and $0.39 respectively.
We also expect adjusted EBITDA margin between 6.1% and 6.4%, an expansion from 4.3% last year.
Currently, we believe revenue declines due to COVID-19 may have bottomed out.
Sequentially, we may see organic declines similar to or slightly better than Q4.
We anticipate continued strong demand for pandemic-related work orders and EnhancedClean throughout Q1.
The investments I mentioned earlier should continue in Q1, reflected in both our segment profit and corporate lines.
Generally, investments will continue throughout fiscal 2021, but the scale and timing will depend on our long-term strategy and the broader recovery outlook.
Earl will provide more details on assumptions for the quarter and year, which remain fluid.
If we gain better visibility for the full year by Q2, we would plan to provide full-year guidance at that time.
This mission has never been more meaningful than it is now.
Our value to clients has increased as our teams have acted as brand ambassadors and demonstrated the operational excellence that distinguishes ABM from competitors.
Nine months ago, we couldn't have predicted how 2020 would conclude for ABM.
We not only surpassed our pre-COVID expectations, but actually reached our long-term EBITDA margin target range of 5.5% to 6% ahead of schedule.
Our 2020 vision strategy has culminated in a pivotal transition, leading us into the next phase of growth and excellence, building on a strong foundation to propel us forward.
Next year will mark our 50th anniversary on the NYSE, and we look forward to commemorating this milestone in ABM's history.
While last year was certainly memorable for our organization, I'm now excited about the opportunities ahead and more enthusiastic than ever.
I'll now hand it over to Earl to discuss our financial results.
I'm thrilled to join the ABM team.
I quickly recognized that the culture here is exceptional and unique.
Even in my first few weeks, I've observed an extraordinary drive for collaboration and execution that clearly sets ABM apart.
As I delve deeper into the business over the coming months, I look forward to developing and sharing my perspectives on our financial strategies in future calls.
Now, let's review our quarterly results.
Quarterly revenue was $1.5 billion, a total decrease of about 9.9% compared to last year, reflecting our second full quarter of COVID-19 revenue declines, particularly in Aviation and Technical Solutions.
Partially offsetting this revenue decline was continued demand for higher margin work orders we've been providing to clients during the pandemic, especially in Business & Industry and Technology & Manufacturing.
GAAP income from continuing operations was $53.1 million or $0.78 per diluted share compared to $48.1 million or $0.71 last year.
These results reflect ongoing favorable claims trends related to health insurance reserves.
We saw a $21.3 million benefit in self-insurance adjustments, of which $6.2 million was related to the current year.
On an adjusted basis, income from continuing operations for the quarter increased to $46.7 million or $0.69 per diluted share compared to $44.7 million or $0.66 last year.
Similar to Q3, our GAAP and adjusted earnings growth versus last year was primarily driven by a significant increase in higher margin work orders as clients respond to COVID-19, as well as continued management of direct labor to align with demand for legacy services.
Partially offsetting these results was a $17.6 million reserve for notes receivable related to a project with a unique family entertainment customer in the Technical Solutions segment.
We are currently working with the client to resolve this issue.
Additionally, operational investments in areas like our EnhancedClean program continued, which was reflected in our operating segment results.
We also resumed certain corporate projects, such as IT investments, that were previously paused as we prioritized business continuity during the pandemic.
This amounted to approximately $10 million for the quarter.
Year-over-year, Q4 also had one fewer workday, equating to about $6 million in labor expense savings.
I'll discuss the workday schedule for fiscal 2021 later, but Q4 of fiscal 2021 will be comparable with 65 days.
Our overall performance this quarter resulted in adjusted EBITDA of approximately $92.5 million at a margin rate of 6.2% compared to $93 million or 5.6% last year.
Now, let's review our segment results.
As a reminder, these results reflect the ongoing impact of COVID-19 on revenue.
Operating profit reflects the shift toward higher margin work orders, labor adjustments for legacy service demand, and operational investments such as EnhancedClean.
B&I revenues were $794.3 million, down just 1.6%.
We're encouraged by the sequential top-line improvement compared to a 6.3% decline last quarter.
The negative effects of the pandemic on our parking and entertainment sectors persisted this quarter, mirroring the situation in Q3.
To counterbalance this COVID-related downturn and the reduction in some lower-profit activities, we experienced steady demand for higher-margin pandemic-related services.
This resulted in a more advantageous mix of B&I operations, leading to a growth in operating profit of over 65% to $84.7 million, with a margin rate of 10.7%.
Our T&M division has also shown remarkable resilience during the pandemic.
Quarterly revenue reached $245.5 million, a 6.7% increase compared to the previous year.
Operating profit grew by more than 30% to $23.5 million, resulting in an operating margin of 9.6%.
This division primarily consists of crucial service providers such as biopharma, logistics, and industrial manufacturing.
Consequently, demand has been driven by work orders and EnhancedClean services, more than making up for any COVID-related and other account losses throughout the year.
In the education sector, we reported revenue of $212.2 million, reflecting the new academic year and the implementation of hybrid models across our K-12 and higher education portfolios.
The operating profit of $15.1 million, or 7.1% margin, reflects labor-related savings due to modified staffing at site locations during the pandemic.
As many of us are likely experiencing with our own children today, there remains significant variability in this sector as different cities respond to resurgences, especially leading up to the holiday season.
We continue to monitor developments and collaborate with our clients to address both daily cleaning and disinfection needs, as well as long-term budget constraints, where our technical solutions offering can be appealing.
Aviation reported revenues of $141 million and an operating profit of $3.5 million, clearly demonstrating the pandemic's ongoing dramatic impact on the industry.
However, as mentioned last quarter, our aim was to reach at least a breakeven position by the fourth quarter.
We are pleased to have ended the year profitably.
Moving on to Technical Solutions, which reported revenues of $123.1 million compared to $175.5 million last year.
It's worth noting that this segment experienced exceptional growth last year, surpassing 25% during Q4 of fiscal '19.
In addition to tougher comparisons, site access has been hindered by the pandemic.
Backlog remains in our healthy range, which we've historically defined as above $150 million.
We are closely monitoring our ability to progress through these projects.
The operating loss of $3.6 million was caused by a reserve of notes receivables related to a single entertainment customer and associated with the client's increased credit risk resulting from the pandemic, which we continue to pursue.
Regarding cash and liquidity, we generated a record $198.7 million in cash flow from operations and free cash flow of $189.6 million for the quarter.
This resulted in $457.5 million in cash flow and $419.5 million of free cash flow for the year.
These results include $101 million in deferred U.S. payroll taxes due to the CARES Act, which will be due in 2021 and 2022.
Even without this, these are record figures for the year.
Due to our strong cash position, we concluded the quarter with total debt, including standby letters of credit, of $883.4 million and a bank adjusted leverage ratio of 2.1 times.
Additionally, we ended the quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $394.2 million.
During the quarter, we paid our 218th consecutive quarterly cash dividend, totaling approximately $12.3 million.
To summarize our annual results, total revenues were approximately $6 billion, a 7.9% decrease compared to last year.
The revenue decline was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on business operations, mainly during the third and fourth quarters of this year.
Our GAAP income from continuing operations for fiscal 2020 was $0.2 million.
On an adjusted basis, income from continuing operations for the year was $163.5 million or $2.43 per diluted share.
Adjusted EBITDA for the year increased by 6.6% to $361.9 million, and we concluded the fiscal year with an adjusted EBITDA margin of 6%.
Regarding our guidance outlook, we are providing guidance for the first quarter of fiscal 2021.
We currently expect GAAP earnings per share to range from $0.53 to $0.58 and adjusted earnings per share to range from $0.60 to $0.65.
Adjusted EBITDA margin is anticipated to be between 6.1% to 6.4%.
This guidance assumes organic growth will be sequentially flat to slightly improved compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020.
We anticipate higher margin work orders and labor efficiencies to continue into the first quarter.
As Scott discussed extensively, we plan to invest in fiscal 2021.
The first quarter will see the same level of investments as the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020, approximately $10 million.
The first quarter will also have one fewer working day compared to last year, potentially leading to approximately $6 million in lower labor expenses.
However, we are preparing for possible higher payroll taxes beginning in January for SUI, FUI, as well as federal taxes such as FICA.
Regarding interest, based on our operating expectations for the first quarter and our current cash position, we do not anticipate an increase in borrowings compared to the fourth quarter.
Therefore, interest expense should decrease slightly due to the continuing amortization of our term loan.
The tax rate for the quarter is expected to be approximately 30%.
This rate excludes discrete tax items such as the work opportunity tax credit and the tax impact of stock-based compensation awards, which we currently expect will total less than $1 million in Q1.
Concerning cash flow, we assume government-related benefits in the U.K. and U.S., such as the CARES Act, will not recur.
This should be considered when evaluating free cash flow for the new fiscal year.
However, we achieved higher free cash flow due to improved operational practices in response to the pandemic.
We intend to maintain these standards and disciplines.
Lastly, regarding taxes, in fiscal '20, our full-year impact for the Work Opportunity Tax Credit was $4 million, reflecting the pandemic's effect on traditional hiring practices.
Currently, WATSI is expected to expire on December 31 of this calendar year.
However, we are closely monitoring Congress for related action, including a potential extension of WATSI.
Following such strong results for 2020, I look forward to sharing more information with you in the coming quarters.
Summary:
