input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations are not assurances of forthcoming achievements or occurrences and are founded on current management expectations.
Real outcomes and events may vary significantly.
Elements that could lead to differing results include factors outlined in our Q3 2021 Form 10-Q report, our 2020 yearly report on Form 10-K, and other recent SEC submissions.
Moreover, some comments may allude to non-GAAP financial metrics.
I'm delighted to announce that AIG experienced another exceptional quarter as we continue to gain traction and implement our strategic objectives.
We persist in fostering underwriting excellence across our portfolio.
We're implementing AIG 200 to instill operational superiority in all our endeavors.
We are progressing with the separation of the life and retirement division from AIG.
And we're exhibiting an ongoing dedication to prudent capital management.
I will begin my comments with an overview of our consolidated financial performance for the third quarter.
I will then examine our general insurance results, where we continue to demonstrate market leadership in addressing risk issues for clients while delivering enhanced underwriting profitability and more stable outcomes.
I'll also discuss certain market dynamics, particularly in the property sector, as well as recent catastrophe activity and related reinsurance considerations as we approach year-end.
Following that, I'll review results from our life and retirement business, which we continue to prepare for independence.
I will also provide an update on the substantial progress we're making on the operational separation of life and retirement from AIG and our effective execution of AIG 200.
I will then discuss capital management, where our short-term priorities remain consistent with those I've previously outlined: debt reduction, returning capital to shareholders, investing in our business through organic growth and operational enhancements.
Lastly, I will conclude with our recently announced senior executive changes that further position AIG for long-term success.
These appointments were made possible due to our strong internal talent pool and significantly enhance the leadership team across our organization.
Beginning with our consolidated results.
As I mentioned, AIG had another outstanding quarter, continuing the excellent trends we've experienced throughout 2021.
In the face of a very active catastrophe season and the persistent global pandemic, our global team of colleagues continue to perform exceptionally well, delivering value to our clients, policyholders and distribution partners.
Adjusted after-tax income in the third quarter was $0.97 per diluted share compared to $0.81 in the same quarter last year.
This outcome was driven by significant improvements in general insurance profitability, very good results in life and retirement, continued expense discipline and savings from AIG 200, and execution of our capital management strategy.
In general insurance, global commercial drove robust top line growth.
We were particularly pleased with our adjusted accident year combined ratio, which improved 280 basis points year over year to 90.5%.
These excellent general insurance results validate our strategy to vastly improve our portfolio quality and build a top-performing culture of disciplined underwriting.
One data point that I believe demonstrates our incredible progress is our accident year combined ratio for the first nine months of 2021, which was 97.7%.
This represents a 770-basis-point improvement year over year, with 600 of that improvement coming from the loss ratio and 170 from the expense ratio.
In life and retirement, we again had solid results primarily driven by improved investment performance and increased call and tender income.
This business delivered a return on adjusted segment common equity of 12.2% for the third quarter and 14.3% for the first nine months of the year.
We recently achieved an important milestone in the separation process by closing the sale of a 9.9% equity stake in life and retirement to Blackstone for $2.2 billion in cash.
We continue to prepare the business for an IPO in 2022 and will begin moving certain assets under management to Blackstone.
We ended the third quarter with $5.3 billion in parent liquidity after redeeming $1.5 billion in outstanding debt and completing $1.1 billion in share repurchases.
Year-to-date, we have reduced financial debt outstanding by $3.4 billion and have returned $2.5 billion to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
We expect to redeem or repurchase an additional $1 billion of debt in the fourth quarter and to repurchase a minimum of $900 million of common stock through year-end to complete the $2 billion of stock repurchase we announced on our last call.
Through these actions, we've clearly demonstrated our ongoing commitment to active and thoughtful capital management.
Now, let me provide more detail on our business results in the third quarter.
I will start with general insurance, where, as I mentioned earlier, growth in net premiums written continued to be very strong and we achieved our 13th consecutive quarter of improvement in the adjusted accident year combined ratio.
Adjusting for foreign exchange, net premiums written increased 10% year over year to $6.6 billion.
This growth was driven by global commercial, which increased 15%, with personal insurance flat for the quarter.
Growth in commercial was balanced between North America and International, with North America increasing 18% and International increasing 12%.
Growth in North America commercial was driven by excess casualty, which increased over 50%; Lexington Wholesale, which continued to show leadership in the E&S market and grew Property and Casualty by over 30%; financial lines, which increased over 20%; and Crop Risk Services, which grew more than 50% driven by increased commodity prices.
In international commercial, financial lines grew 25%, Talbot had over 15% growth and Liability had over 10% growth.
Additionally, gross new business in global commercial grew 40% year over year to over $1 billion.
In North America, new business growth was more than 50% and in International, it was more than 25%.
North America new business was strongest in Lexington, financial lines and retail property.
International new business came mostly from financial lines and our specialty businesses.
We also had very strong retention in our in-force portfolio, with North America improving retention by 200 basis points and International improving retention by 700 basis points.
Strong momentum continued with overall global commercial rate increases of 12%.
In many cases, this is the third year where we have achieved double-digit rate increases in our portfolio.
North America commercial's overall 11% rate increases were balanced across the portfolio and led by excess casualty, which increased over 15%.
Financial lines, which also increased over 15% and Canada, where rates increased by 17%, representing the 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit rate increases.
International commercial rate increases were 13% driven by EMEA, excluding specialty, which increased by 22%.
U.K., excluding specialty, which increased 21%.
Financial lines, which increased 24% and Energy, which was up 14%, its 11th consecutive quarter of double-digit rate increases.
Turning to global personal insurance.
We had a solid quarter that reflected a modest rebound in net premiums written in travel and warranty, offset by results in the private client group due to reinsurance cessions related to Syndicate 2019 and non-renewals in peak zones.
Shifting to underwriting profitability.
As I noted earlier, general insurance's accident year combined ratio ex CAT was 90.5%.
The third quarter saw a 150-basis-point improvement in the accident year loss ratio ex CAT and a 130-basis-point improvement in the expense ratio, all of which came from the GOE ratio.
These results were driven by our improved portfolio mix, achieving rate in excess of loss cost trends, continued expense discipline and benefits from AIG 200.
Global commercial achieved an impressive accident year combined ratio ex CATs of 88.9%, an improvement of 290 basis points year over year and the second consecutive quarter with a sub-90% combined ratio result.
The accident year combined ratio ex CAT for North America commercial and international commercial were 90.5% and 86.8%, respectively, an improvement of 370 basis points and 210 basis points.
In global personal insurance, the accident year combined ratio ex CATs was 94.2%, an improvement of 220 basis points year over year driven by improvement in the expense ratio.
Given the significant progress we have made to improve our combined ratios and our view that the momentum we have will continue for the foreseeable future, we now expect to achieve a sub-90% accident year combined ratio ex CAT for full year 2022.
After three years of significant underwriting margin improvement, we believe that the sub-90% accident year combined ratio ex CAT is something that not only will be achieved for full year 2022, but that there will continue to be runway for further improvement in future years.
As I said earlier, the third quarter was very active, with current industry estimates ranging between $45 billion and $55 billion globally.
We reported approximately $625 million of net global CAT losses with approximately $530 million in commercial.
The largest impacts were from Hurricane Ida and flooding in Europe, where we saw net CAT losses of approximately $400 million and $190 million, respectively.
We have put significant management focus into our reinsurance program, which continues to perform exceptionally well to reduce volatility, including strategic purchases for wind that we made in the second quarter.
Reinsurance recoveries in our International per occurrence, private client group per occurrence and other discrete reinsurance programs also reduced volatility in the third quarter.
We expect any fourth quarter CAT losses to be limited given that we are close to attaching on our North America aggregate cover and our aggregate cover for rest of the world, excluding Japan.
We have each and every loss deductibles of $75 million for North America wind, $50 million for North America earthquake and $25 million for all other North America perils and $20 million for international.
Our worldwide retention has approximately $175 million remaining before attaching in the aggregate, which would essentially be for Japan CAT.
Since 2012, excluding COVID, there have been 10 catastrophic events with damages surpassing $10 billion, with 9 of those occurring between 2017 and Q3 of this year.
The average catastrophe losses over the past 5 years have reached $114 billion, representing a 30% increase from the 10-year average and a 40% rise from the 15-year average.
Catastrophe losses exceeded $100 billion through 2021, with $90 billion already recorded by the third quarter.
This marks the fourth time in five years that natural disasters have surpassed this threshold.
Three key observations can be made.
Firstly, while catastrophe models were generally accurate over the past two decades, this has not held true for the last five years.
Secondly, in the past five years, models have underestimated expected values by 20% to 30% at lower return periods, with wildfire inclusion significantly increasing these figures.
Thirdly, industry losses compared to model predictions at the lower end of the curve have been insufficient, necessitating rate adjustments to reflect the substantial increase in catastrophe frequency.
To tackle these issues, AIG has heavily invested in its catastrophe research team to develop an independent risk assessment in this new environment.
This includes wind, storm surge, flood, and various other international perils.
AIG will continue to utilize new scientific studies, improvements in vendor models, and their own claims data to refine their risk perspectives over time, ensuring appropriate pricing of catastrophe risks.
Across the portfolio, AIG's strategy and primary focus has been and will remain delivering risk solutions that meet client needs while aligning with their risk appetite, considering terms and conditions, strategic limit deployment, and acknowledging increased frequency and severity.
The significant emphasis on this critical work is reflected in AIG's financial results throughout 2021, with improving combined ratios both including and excluding catastrophes.
Turning to life and retirement, earnings remain strong in the third quarter, supported by stable equity markets, slightly improving interest rates compared to Q2, and significant call and tender income.
Adjusted pre-tax income for Q3 was approximately $875 million.
Individual retirement, excluding sold retail mutual funds, maintained upward momentum with 27% year-over-year sales growth.
The largest retail product, Index Annuity, saw a 50% increase compared to the same quarter last year.
Group retirement collectively increased deposits by 3%, with new group acquisitions ahead of the previous year but below a robust second quarter.
Management continues to actively address impacts from low interest rates and tighter credit spreads, with the previously provided range for expected annual spread compression remaining unchanged as third-quarter base investment spreads fell within the annual 8 to 16 basis points guidance.
Regarding the operational separation of life and retirement, considerable progress has been made on multiple fronts.
The goal is to achieve a clean separation with minimal business disruption, emphasizing speed, execution, operational efficiency, and thoughtful talent allocation.
Numerous work streams are in execution mode, including designing a target operating model for a successful stand-alone public company, separating IT systems, data centers, software applications, real estate, and material vendor contracts, and determining transition service requirements while minimizing their duration with clear exit plans.
An IPO is expected in Q1 2022 or potentially Q2, subject to regulatory approvals and market conditions.
Due to the sale of the affordable housing portfolio and execution of certain tax strategies, there are no longer constraints on how much of life and retirement can be sold in an IPO.
Currently, AIG expects to retain over 50% interest immediately following the IPO and continue consolidating life and retirement's financial statements until ownership falls below 50%.
The timing of further secondary offerings will depend on market conditions and other relevant factors.
Regarding AIG 200, the program continues to advance and remains on track to deliver $1 billion in run-rate savings across the company by the end of 2022, against a cost to achieve of $1.3 billion.
$660 million of run-rate savings are already executed or contracted, with approximately $400 million recognized in the income statement to date.
Similar to the underwriting turnaround that created a culture of underwriting excellence, AIG 200 is fostering a culture of operational excellence that is becoming standard practice across AIG.
Recently announced senior leadership changes reflect the significant progress made during the first nine months of 2021 across strategic priorities and the momentum heading towards year-end.
Mark will assume the newly created role of Global Chief Actuary and Head of Portfolio Management for AIG on January 1, leveraging his critical role in repositioning AIG over the past three years.
Shane Fitzsimons will take over as Chief Financial Officer on January 1, bringing strong leadership that has accelerated aspects of AIG 200 and instilled discipline in finance transformation, strategic planning, budgeting, and forecasting processes.
Elias Habayeb has been named Chief Financial Officer of life and retirement, bringing deep expertise about AIG and ensuring a seamless transition.
Overall, management is pleased with the team, third-quarter results, and the tremendous progress being made across AIG.
The strong adjusted earnings of $0.97 per share and profitable general insurance calendar quarter combined ratio of 99.7% including catastrophes are particularly noteworthy.
Year-over-year adjusted earnings per share improvement was driven by a 750-basis-point reduction in the general insurance calendar quarter combined ratio, strong growth in net premiums written and earned, and a related 280-basis-point decrease in the underlying accident year combined ratio excluding catastrophes.
Life and retirement also produced strong adjusted pre-tax income of $877 million, with a healthy adjusted ROE of 12.2%.
The quarter's strong operating earnings and consistent investment performance helped increase adjusted book value per share by 3% sequentially and nearly 9% compared to one year ago.
The strength of the balance sheet and strong liquidity position were highlights, with continued progress on leverage goals, including a GAAP debt leverage reduction of 90 basis points sequentially and 350 basis points year-over-year to 26.1%.
In general insurance, achieved profitable growth, demonstrable volatility reduction, and smart cycle management increase confidence in achieving the stated goal of a sub-90% accident year combined ratio excluding catastrophes for full year 2022, rather than just exiting 2022.
Current market conditions persist in strength and show resiliency, with AIG's global platform continuing to see rate strengthening internationally, adding to overall uplift unlike more U.S.-centric competitors.
International commercial rate increases now surpass those in North America, in some areas meaningfully so.
These rate increases continue to outstrip loss cost trends globally across a broad range of assumptions and contribute to additional margin expansion.
Over the three-year period from 2019 through 2021, product lines achieving cumulative rate increases near or above 100% include excess casualty (both admitted and non-admitted), property lines (both admitted and non-admitted), and financial lines.
These levels of tailwind are expected to continue driving earned margin expansion into the foreseeable future.
In the current inflationary environment, products with inflation-sensitive exposure bases act as inflation mitigants and are subject to additional audit premiums as the economy recovers.
U.S. portfolio loss cost trends are now estimated at 4% to 5%, gravitating toward the upper end of this range.
U.S. loss cost trends range from approximately 3.5% to 10%, depending on the line of business.
AIG is integrating near-term inflationary impacts into rating and portfolio tools and not lowering any line of business loss cost trends, as lighter claims reporting may be misconstrued due to COVID-19 societal impacts.
All North America commercial lines loss cost trends, except for workers' compensation, are materially lower than corresponding rate increases.
The strong market and significant underwriting transformation at AIG have driven other aspects of the portfolio affecting loss ratios, with cumulative rate changes substantially outpacing cumulative loss cost trends in many lines and classes of business.
These factors result in significantly lower loss ratio estimates between 2018 and 2021.
Typically, external discussions on this topic end prematurely.
In actuality, this is just the beginning of a more comprehensive analysis.
Several other elements can substantially improve the profitability of underlying businesses, including: contract terms and conditions, which can be as impactful as pricing; a more balanced distribution of insured risk quality, enhancing rate adequacy and reducing adverse selection; strategic allocation of capacity across insurance layers, leading to preferred positioning and client retention; and reinsurance that reduces volatility and net losses.
Even modest positive impacts from each of these factors would further reduce the 2021 projected loss ratio beyond what rate versus loss trend alone would indicate.
These effects are real and currently occurring.
There are at least four reasons why insurers book product lines at this implied profitability level.
Insurers take on varied risks from others, with exposures changing yearly, making precise on-level projections difficult.
Most policies are occurrence-based, allowing for challenges to policy language for years or decades, potentially including novel liability claims.
Many lines are highly volatile, even with perfect underwriting.
Setting an overly optimistic initial loss ratio increases the likelihood of future unfavorable development.
These issues necessitate caution when establishing initial loss ratio estimates for most commercial insurance lines.
We will now discuss our third quarter reserve review.
This quarter, we reviewed approximately $42 billion in reserves, bringing the year-to-date total to about 90% of carried pre-ADC reserves.
I'll explain the results of our quarterly reserve analysis, which showed minimal net change, confirming our strong overall reserve position.
Prior-year development was $153 million favorable on a pre-ADC basis, $3 million favorable post-ADC, and $50 million favorable when including the $47 million ADC amortization on the deferred gain.
This indicates our reserves remain adequate, with balanced favorable and unfavorable development across business lines, resulting in an improved yet neutral reserve alignment.
Before examining the quarter by segment, let's remove some distracting elements to focus on the core details.
This quarter's reserve analysis should be viewed as conducting all scheduled product reviews, then overlaying two seemingly unrelated impacts from a large subrogation recovery for the 2017 and 2018 California wildfires.
The subrogation recovery directly reduced North America personal insurance reserves by $326 million and required reversing a previously recorded $206 million reinsurance recovery in North America commercial Insurance, as the attachment point was no longer reached.
These subrogation recovery impacts resulted in $120 million of net favorable development.
Excluding these impacts, the total general insurance prior year development was $70 million unfavorable, rather than the $50 million favorable mentioned earlier.
This provides a better framework for discussing the underlying reserve movements this quarter.
The $70 million global unfavorable development comprises $85 million unfavorable in global catastrophe losses and $50 million favorable in global non-catastrophe or attritional losses.
The $85 million unfavorable catastrophe development stems from minor adjustments to multiple 2019 and 2020 events.
The $15 million non-catastrophe favorable development results from $255 million unfavorable in global commercial offset by $270 million favorable development, mainly from short-tail personal lines in the 2020 accident year, predominantly in our International book.
In line with our reserving philosophy, we are cautious about reacting to this $270 million favorable indication until the accident year matures further.
North America commercial experienced $112 million unfavorable development, driven by approximately $400 million strengthening in financial lines, offset by favorable development in other lines, led by workers' compensation with about $200 million from accident years 2015 and prior, and roughly $100 million across various other units.
North America financial lines were negatively impacted by primary public D&O, mainly in complex national accounts and private not-for-profit D&O, as well as some excess coverage mostly in public D&O, with 90% coming from accident years 2016 to 2018.
International commercial had $143 million unfavorable development, including financial lines strengthening of about $300 million in D&O and professional indemnity, primarily in the UK and Europe, but with more dispersed accident year impacts.
Favorable development was led by specialty businesses at roughly $110 million, with an additional $50 million from various lines and regions.
As Peter mentioned, our recent changes to underwriting culture and risk appetite, combined with strong market conditions, are now reflected in our financial results.
U.S. financial lines, through careful underwriting and risk selection, has significantly reduced exposure to securities class actions (SCAs) in recent years.
This underwriting shift is evident in the proportion of SCAs covered by U.S. operations, decreasing from 42% of all U.S. federal security class actions in 2017 to just 14% through nine months of 2021.
This is significant as 60% to 70% of public D&O loss dollars historically come from SCAs.
The North America private not-for-profit D&O book has also undergone substantial transformation.
The policy retention rate between 2018 and 2021 is just 15%, while cumulative rate increases over the same period are nearly 130%.
This intentional shift in risk selection criteria from large private companies and nonprofit universities and hospitals to a more balanced middle market book will drive substantial profitability improvements.
International financial lines has implemented similar underwriting actions with comparable three-year cumulative rate increases and unified global underwriting authority for U.S.-listed D&O exposure through collaboration with the U.S. Chief Underwriting Office.
In summary, our reserving approach remains prudent and conservative.
This is demonstrated by our gradual recognition of attritional improvements in short-tail lines from accident year 2020 and the decision to strengthen Financial Line reserves, despite interpretive challenges from a difficult claims environment, recent changes in internal claims operations, and potential COVID-19 impacts on claim reporting patterns.
These underwriting actions over recent years bolster our confidence in our overall reserve position across both prior and current accident years.
Regarding life and retirement, the year-to-date ROE has been a strong 14.3% compared to 12.8% in the first nine months of last year.
Third quarter APTI saw higher net investment income and fee income, offset by the unfavorable impact of the annual actuarial assumption update, which reduced ROE by about 250 basis points annually and earnings per share by $0.15.
The main impact was in Individual retirement, associated with fixed annuity spread compression.
Life insurance reflected a slightly elevated COVID-19-related mortality provision, but our exposure sensitivity of $65 million to $75 million per 100,000 population deaths proved accurate based on reported third quarter COVID-related deaths in the U.S.
Non-COVID-19 mortality was also slightly elevated in the period.
In Individual retirement, excluding Retail Mutual Funds, net flows were positive $250 million this quarter, compared to net outflows of $110 million in the prior-year quarter, largely due to recovery from COVID-19-related sales disruptions.
Previously communicated sensitivities to yield and equity market movements affecting APTI remain valid.
New business margins generally remain within our targets at current new money returns due to active product management and disciplined pricing.
In other operations, the adjusted pre-tax loss before consolidations and eliminations was $370 million, $2 million higher than the prior-year quarter, driven by higher corporate GOE primarily from increased performance-based employee compensation, partially offset by higher investment income and lower corporate interest expense from year-to-date debt redemption activity.
Overall net investment income on an APTI basis was $3.3 billion, a $78 million increase from the prior-year quarter, primarily reflecting higher private equity gains.
Life and retirement benefited most due to asset growth, higher call and tender income, and strong private equity returns.
General insurance's NII declined about 6% year-over-year due to continued yield compression and underperformance in hedge fund positions.
General insurance has a higher percentage allocation to private equity and hedge funds, which may change in the future.
Regarding share count, our average total diluted shares outstanding in the quarter were 864 million, and we repurchased approximately 20 million shares.
The end-of-period outstanding shares for book value per share purposes was about 836 million, expected to be around 820 million at year-end 2021, depending on share price performance and additional share repurchases.
Lastly, our primary operating subsidiaries remain profitable and well-capitalized, with general insurance's U.S. pool fleet risk-based capital ratio for the third quarter estimated between 450% and 460%, and the life and retirement U.S. fleet estimated between 440% and 450%, both above our target ranges.
Summary:

qtrly total general insurance net premiums written increased 11% to $6.6 billion from prior year quarter.
qtrly total general insurance underwriting income was $20 million compared to an underwriting loss of $423 million in prior year quarter.
qtrly earnings per share $1.92; qtrly adjusted after-tax earnings per share $0.97.
as of sept 30, 2021, book value per common share was $77.03, an increase of 1% fromdecember 31, 2020.
repurchased $1.1 billion of aig common stock and redeemed $1.5 billion of debt in quarter.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In the second quarter of 2020, our consolidated earnings were $0.26 per diluted share, a decrease from $0.38 in the same period of 2019.
The year-to-date consolidated earnings for 2020 stood at $0.98 per diluted share, compared to $2.14 in the previous year.
I will now hand over the conversation to Dennis.
We sincerely hope everyone is maintaining their health and safety during these challenging times.
It's surprising to realize that we've been dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic for five months already.
I continue to be motivated daily by our employees' unified efforts in responding to the crisis on all fronts.
I'm extremely proud of our organization's vigilance and adaptability to rapidly changing policies and procedures in the states we operate in.
I value their endurance, determination, and professionalism as we collectively navigate this unprecedented situation to establish a new normal, all while continuing to provide essential energy to our customers.
Our highest priority remains safeguarding the wellbeing of our customers, employees, contractors, and communities.
As regional economies in our service areas experience uneven recovery, we're doing our utmost to assist struggling customers.
Recently, the Avista Foundation distributed over $500,000 to support 37 organizations across our service area.
In total, our foundation has provided more than $1.5 million in aid so far this year.
Despite most of our employees working remotely, we've maintained our ability to complete crucial tasks across our operations.
Wildfires remain a significant concern for our industry and company, particularly during this season.
Prior to the wildfire season, we improved our 10-year wildfire resilience plan to enhance our existing measures for preventing, mitigating, and reducing wildfire impacts, aiming to minimize potential fires and related service interruptions.
Our team developed this plan over the past year through internal workshops, industry research, and collaboration with state and local fire agencies.
The plan focuses on key areas including grid fortification, vegetation control, situational awareness, operations and emergency response, and worker and public safety.
We anticipate spending approximately $330 million to implement the plan's components over its 10-year duration.
We're eagerly anticipating the completion of construction on the Catalyst Building and the Scott Morris Center for Energy Innovation.
We're excited for the buildings to open next month, realizing Scott Morris' vision of creating the world's five smartest blocks.
This will allow Avista to continue innovating and testing new ideas about energy sharing in a shared economy model.
Our findings could potentially shape the future grid's operation and provide a revolutionary new model for the entire utility industry.
Last year, we set a goal to provide our customers with 100% clean electricity by 2045 and 100% carbon-neutral resources by 2027.
In line with this goal and our 2020 Integrated Resource Plan, we are inviting proposals from renewable energy project developers capable of constructing, owning, and operating up to 120 average megawatts.
We aim to acquire the production from renewable energy sources, encompassing power, capacity, and related environmental benefits.
This will enable us to reduce our reliance on market purchases and fossil fuel-based generation, which is crucial for achieving our objectives.
Regarding performance, our Q2 consolidated earnings met expectations, and we're progressing well towards meeting our 2020 earnings projections for Avista Utilities, AEL&P, and our other ventures.
Therefore, we are reaffirming our 2020 consolidated earnings guidance range of $1.75 to $1.95 per diluted share.
To conclude, one final note.
Our Senior VP, Chief Legal Counsel, and Corporate Secretary, Marian Durkin, retired on August 1.
Throughout her time with us, Marian identified our business requirements and established our legal department from scratch, developing it into the strong team it is today.
As compliance has become increasingly important across various sectors, Marian also consolidated the company's compliance efforts and elevated our compliance department significantly.
Additionally, under Marian's guidance, Avista was recently recognized as one of Ethisphere's World's Most Ethical Companies.
I have some exciting information to share.
I'm thrilled about this.
Due to the pandemic, the Blackhawks qualified for the playoffs and are currently tied 1-1 with Edmonton, with a game scheduled for tonight.
For those on the East Coast, it's a late 10:30 game, but I encourage you to stay up and cheer for my Blackhawks.
In Q2 2020, Avista Utilities contributed $0.26 per diluted share, down from $0.32 in 2019.
The decrease in earnings compared to Q2 2019 was due to lower electric utility margin resulting from higher power supply costs and reduced loads related to COVID-19, partially offset by rate relief and customer growth.
We also experienced lower operating expenses in Q2 2020.
The Energy Recovery Mechanism in Washington provided a small benefit of $0.4 million this year, compared to a larger benefit of $6 million in 2019.
Year-to-date, we recognized a pre-tax benefit of $5.6 million in 2020, compared to $3.5 million in 2019, all related to the ERM.
Regarding COVID-19 impacts on our results, we recorded an additional $3.3 million in bad debt expense year-to-date and anticipate the total incremental amount to be $5.7 million for the full year, including the first half, compared to our initial forecast.
In July, the Idaho Commission issued an order allowing us to defer certain costs, net of any decreased costs and other benefits related to COVID-19.
In Q2, we deferred $1.1 million of bad debt expense associated with this order.
Compared to normal, Q2 saw a decrease of about 6% in overall electric loads, with approximately 10% decrease in commercial and 14% decrease in industrial, partially offset by a 4% increase in residential loads.
These load decreases reduced earnings by about $0.03 in Q2, and we expect continued lower loads for most of the year, with a gradual recovery towards year-end.
We anticipate offsetting most of the lower utility margin through cost management efforts, which is reflected in our consolidated guidance.
A gradual economic recovery is anticipated, but unemployment is expected to remain high, suppressing load and customer growth into 2021.
Regulatory mechanisms, including decoupling, help alleviate the impact of load changes on our revenues for residential and certain commercial customers.
Regulatory mechanisms cover more than 90% of our utility revenue.
In the second quarter, we experienced supply chain delays due to COVID-19, ranging from two to six weeks in some instances.
We don't anticipate these delays to significantly affect our planned projects, and we remain committed to investing in our utility infrastructure, with expected spending of about $405 million in 2020.
As of June 30, we had $160 million available under our $400 million credit line and $100 million in cash from a term loan.
We extended our credit line agreement by one year to April 2022 during the second quarter.
This year, we plan to issue approximately $165 million in long-term debt and up to $70 million in equity, including $24 million issued through June.
We are reaffirming our 2020 guidance with a consolidated range of $1.75 to $1.95.
At Avista Utilities, we expect the COVID-19 impacts of increased operating expenses, bad debt, reduced industrial loads, and higher interest to be largely offset by anticipated tax benefits from the CARES Act and implemented cost reduction measures.
We have requested deferred accounting treatment in all of our jurisdictions.
The Idaho Commission has allowed us to defer certain COVID-19 related costs, net of any decreased costs and other benefits, with recovery subject to future determination of appropriateness and prudency.
Regulatory lag is expected to continue until 2023, with rate cases filed in Oregon in March 2020 and planned for Washington and Idaho in the fourth quarter of this year.
After 2023, we anticipate long-term earnings growth of 4% to 6%.
Regarding specific segment ranges:
Avista Utilities is expected to contribute between $1.77 and $1.89 per diluted share.
The midpoint of our range excludes any ERM expense or benefit, but we currently expect a benefit in the 90/10 sharing band, adding $0.06 per diluted share.
Our Avista Utilities outlook assumes normal precipitation, temperatures, and hydroelectric generation for the rest of the year, along with implemented cost reduction measures to mitigate COVID-19 related expenses.
AEL&P is projected to contribute between $0.07 and $0.11 per share in 2020, assuming normal precipitation and hydroelectric generation for the remainder of the year.
Other businesses are expected to incur a loss between $0.09 and $0.05 per diluted share.
Our guidance typically includes only normal operating conditions and excludes unusual items like settlement transactions or acquisitions and dispositions until their effects are known and certain.
The duration and severity of the COVID-19 pandemic cannot be predicted.
More severe and prolonged economic restrictions and business disruptions will have a greater impact on our operations, results, financial condition, and cash flows.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q2 earnings per share $0.26.
q2 earnings per share $0.26.
reaffirms fy earnings per share view $1.75 to $1.95.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Joining me for today's call are our Chief Executive Officer, Vic Grizzle, and our Chief Financial Officer, Brian MacNeal.
Results may vary significantly from projections or expectations.
You can find both on our company's website.
I'm pleased to be here today to discuss our first quarter performance.
We've had a strong beginning to what we anticipate will be a year of significant growth for Armstrong.
Throughout the quarter, we continued to observe gradual improvement and recovery in our markets.
Our company-wide daily shipping rates showed progressive improvement, gaining momentum towards the quarter's end and continuing to accelerate into April.
This quarter's comparison is against the last period of pre-pandemic market conditions, as COVID-19 had minimal impact on our base period.
In the first quarter of 2021, adjusted revenue reached $253 million, a 2% increase from the previous year, propelled by sales from our 2020 acquisitions, which more than compensated for pandemic-related volume decreases in our core business.
Adjusted EBITDA of $85 million showed a 12% decrease from last year, affected by COVID-related volume reductions, ongoing investments in growth strategies, and the reinstatement of spending that was postponed when the pandemic began.
The Mineral Fiber division has begun the year as anticipated.
Our Mineral Fiber daily shipping rate demonstrated its third consecutive quarter of sequential improvement as people return to workplaces and markets continue to reopen.
Pricing on comparable products surpassed input cost inflation, product mix improved with premium offerings outperforming other product lines, and channel mix remained a challenge, though less pronounced, due to relatively strong sales in the lower-priced home center channel.
The channel mix issues experienced during the pandemic have already begun to diminish and are not expected to be a hindrance moving forward.
The regional mix challenges we faced in recent quarters have lessened as New York City and the other six major metropolitan areas we've highlighted are now performing similarly to the rest of the country.
In terms of operations, our Mineral Fiber plants performed well, maintaining solid productivity despite challenges posed by winter storms.
Our WAVE joint venture also performed admirably, successfully pricing ahead of rising steel costs to deliver strong first-quarter results.
Our architectural specialty business achieved impressive top-line growth of 25% compared to the same quarter last year, driven once again by our 2020 acquisitions of Turf, Moz, and Arktura.
A notable highlight of the quarter was the acceleration in order intake, with sequential organic order intake reaching record levels, resulting in a stronger-than-anticipated backlog.
We continue to be encouraged by our success rate on projects and our ability to differentiate our offerings from competitors.
Given our robust backlog, we remain confident in achieving our 2021 sales projection of over 30% growth.
During the quarter, we maintained our investment in architectural specialties to further enhance our capabilities and capacity, supporting our expectation of continued strong growth in this segment.
The integration of our three new acquisitions is progressing well, and I remain excited about the potential for incorporating their technology and design capabilities across the Armstrong platform.
Our acquisition pipeline is robust and continues to expand, and we possess the financial resources, liquidity, and willingness to execute additional acquisitions and partnerships.
Regarding the overall macroeconomic environment and market conditions, markets have improved and are showing signs of gaining momentum.
I am encouraged by the trends we're observing in the data and by the tone of conversations with our customers and distribution partners.
Bidding activity continued to improve throughout the quarter, and more projects delayed last year are being reactivated.
GDP estimates are being revised upward, which is a positive leading indicator for increased renovation activity.
CEO confidence is rising and return-to-office statistics are improving, signaling a desire and expectation for market recovery.
There's a strong desire to bring students and teachers back to classrooms where they can be most productive, and to reunite work teams for effective collaboration, innovation, and networking.
These trends, along with the potential for trillions of dollars in government infrastructure spending, including funds specifically earmarked for school renovations, are fostering greater optimism and a more favorable economic backdrop.
Alongside the stronger economic outlook, inflationary pressures are intensifying.
The raw material most affected in our operations thus far has been steel, used primarily in our WAVE joint venture for manufacturing suspension systems.
Consequently, starting in December, we have implemented five price increases totaling over 40%.
This has been a challenging task for both our sales teams and distribution partners to manage, but they have performed well, as evidenced by WAVE's first-quarter results.
We are also experiencing rising input and freight costs in our Mineral Fiber and Architectural Specialties segments.
As a result, we have announced a larger-than-usual 10% price increase on Mineral Fiber products and moved the effective date up to May, earlier than normal.
This is in addition to the 7% increase implemented in February.
In Architectural Specialties, we have also raised prices on standard products and are adjusting our quoting processes for custom projects.
With these actions, I remain confident that we will once again achieve like-for-like price realization greater than input cost inflation.
Overall, both segments are operating at a high level.
Fortunately, we have not experienced any supply chain disruptions, allowing for outstanding service levels.
Thanks to our recent digitalization initiatives, we are maintaining closer connections with our customers and partners than ever before, supporting a strong project backlog position.
Our teams are effectively implementing pricing strategies to combat inflation.
Given our strong operational status, positive first quarter results, and market expectations for the rest of the year, we are maintaining the full-year 2021 guidance provided in February.
I will discuss our first quarter 2021 results and our full-year forecast.
We'll start with our consolidated first quarter results on Slide 4.
Adjusted sales increased by 2% compared to last year, reaching $253 million.
These adjusted sales include roughly $700,000 in purchase accounting adjustments related to our acquisitions in 2020.
This adjustment will not be applied in future quarters.
Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 12% and EBITDA margins reduced by 520 basis points.
This reduction was anticipated due to ongoing pressure from COVID-related demand decreases, continued investments in growth initiatives, and the reinstatement of costs that were temporarily cut last year.
Additionally, it's worth noting that when examining our adjusted EBITDA reconciliation in the appendix on slide 12, Q1 2020 earnings as reported were significantly affected by our Q1 pension annuitization.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.84 were 23% lower than the previous year's results.
This figure includes $6 million or $0.09 of amortization expense related to our 2020 acquisitions.
Adjusted free cash flow decreased by $13 million compared to the previous year.
Our financial position remains robust, ending the quarter with $397 million in available liquidity, including $122 million in cash and $275 million available on our revolving credit facility.
Although net debt of $587 million was $43 million higher than Q1 2020, our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.9 times, calculated under our credit agreement terms, remains well below our covenant threshold of 3.75 times.
We have significant flexibility in this measure.
We repurchased 126,000 shares for $10 million at an average price of $79.60 per share in the second quarter.
Since the start of our repurchase program in 2016, we have bought back 9.9 million shares at a cost of $616 million, averaging $62.57 per share.
We currently have $584 million remaining in our repurchase program, which ends in December 2023.
Slide 5 outlines our Mineral Fiber segment results.
Sales decreased by 5% compared to last year due to COVID's impact.
Mineral Fiber shipments ended the quarter positively, with March shipments matching the previous year on a rate-per-day basis.
As of Friday, April's month-to-date daily ship rate has increased by 58% compared to last year and surpasses 2019 levels.
Positive like-for-like pricing and favorable product mix continued, but channel mix negatively impacted the fall-through rate this quarter.
We expect this to be the final quarter affected by this channel mix fall-through rate issue.
Mineral Fiber segment adjusted EBITDA declined by 10% due to COVID-related volume decreases, increased SG&A spending to support growth investments, and the reinstatement of temporary cost reductions from 2020.
The Mineral Fiber plants performed well, generating productivity that improved the bottom line.
Input cost inflation was temporarily offset by inventory valuations, but inflation is clearly increasing and driving our proactive pricing actions.
WAVE has been implementing price increases ahead of rising steel costs.
Turning to our Architectural Specialties (AS) segment on Slide 6.
Adjusted sales grew by 25% compared to last year, reaching $13 million as the 2020 acquisitions of Turf, Moz, and Arktura contributed $17 million in the quarter, more than compensating for the $4 million organic sales decline due to COVID.
EBITDA for our AS segment decreased by $3 million as EBITDA contributions from the 2020 acquisitions were outweighed by AS organic performance.
Sales for our AS organic business remain inconsistent as projects were delayed beyond the first quarter, and we made growth investments in both capacity and capability to support our top-line expectations for AS.
We remain confident in our sales guidance for the AS business due to the positive trajectory of order intake in the first quarter.
As sales increase throughout the year, we anticipate EBITDA margins will improve.
Slide 7 illustrates the factors influencing our consolidated adjusted EBITDA results for the quarter, including a breakdown of the impact from our 2020 acquisitions.
Sales from our acquisitions essentially balanced out organic volume declines.
AUV positively contributed, driven by like-for-like pricing in the Mineral Fiber segment, but was offset by higher SG&A expenses.
Slide 8 displays adjusted free cash flow performance for the quarter compared to the first quarter of 2020.
Cash flow from operations decreased by $13 million due to lower earnings.
It's important to note that the first quarter typically has the weakest free cash flow generation as we build inventory to meet strong summer demand.
We remain confident in our ability to achieve the 19% free cash flow margin we've projected for the year.
The ninth slide provides a summary of our projections for 2021.
We are maintaining our forecast of 10% to 13% sales growth, 9% to 13% adjusted EBITDA increase, 5% to 15% rise in adjusted earnings per share, and a free cash flow yield of 19%.
The beginning of April has been promising, and we are hopeful about the emerging trends for the second quarter.
It's premature to modify our yearly forecast, and we will offer an updated guidance in July when we have more information.
Slide 10 reconfirms the expected sales pattern for 2021.
We don't usually share this information as our seasonal trends are typically consistent year after year.
However, due to the disruptions in 2020, the year-over-year sales pattern will be unusual in 2021, so we've included this information to provide more insight.
To sum up, I remain optimistic about the prospects for 2021, with improving health and economic conditions, an evolving range of healthy spaces products, and new digital tools and capabilities, Armstrong is in a strong position to enhance our value creation model in 2021.
Before we move to the Q&A session, I'd like to discuss a few key initiatives in the company, specifically ESG, Healthy Spaces, and our new digital platform Kanopi by Armstrong.
In our previous call, I mentioned that ESG would be a priority for us in 2021 and beyond.
As we expand our history of community involvement and corporate responsibility, it's becoming increasingly important to all our stakeholders and aligns well with our mission, history, culture, and strategy.
As many of you have noticed, we recently launched a redesigned sustainability section on our website that highlights our three focus areas: People, planet, and product, and establishes our 2030 goals in these areas.
Furthermore, work is progressing and on schedule to complete our first sustainability report this summer.
This comprehensive report will address the requirements of GRI, SASB, and TCFD.
Given the significance of this work, I want to acknowledge the considerable effort and dedication of our teams in documenting our achievements so far, establishing a baseline for improvement, and developing meaningful long-term goals.
We will provide more updates on this important initiative as we progress, which aligns well with our strategic focus on Healthy Spaces.
As Healthy Spaces continues to be a key factor in economic recovery, ceilings are becoming increasingly important.
As the finishing element of an interior space, ceilings play a crucial role in managing air flow, providing optimal ventilation, and delivering acoustic performance and design aesthetics.
These trends are revitalizing the ceiling category and making it more relevant for current and future healthy indoor space needs.
This development is particularly favorable for Armstrong.
As the long-standing category leader, Armstrong is gaining recognition as a thought leader on the importance of comprehensive space planning, design, and construction, and the impact this approach can have on people's confidence and well-being while indoors, where we spend most of our time.
We believe that our growth investments in 2020 will yield results in 2021, with gains from new Healthy Spaces solutions and our new digital capabilities.
Our product innovations are well-aligned with post-pandemic market demands.
Healthy Spaces is not just a temporary trend, but a lasting change.
While Healthy Spaces has always been important, the pandemic has permanently altered our definition of health and our expectations for indoor spaces.
Architects, designers, facility managers, and business owners are seeking solutions to bring people back into commercial spaces and make them more suitable for future use.
As offices reduce density and large collaborative spaces become the norm, the need for acoustic performance in ceilings will increase, along with the need for improved cleaning and air flow management.
Ceilings are central to providing these solutions.
Our 24/7 Defend product line, including AirAssure, CleanAssure, and VidaShield ceiling solutions, is specifically designed to improve air quality and ventilation sustainably.
It's encouraging that despite being launched just five months ago, 24/7 Defend products have been sold across all our core sectors: office, education, healthcare, retail, and transportation.
This clearly demonstrates the wide-ranging potential for Healthy Spaces.
These product innovations, timed for the Healthy Spaces trend, combined with our new digital platform Kanopi by Armstrong, position Armstrong well to capitalize on the evolving market recovery opportunity.
Launched earlier this year, Kanopi by Armstrong (with a lowercase 'k') is available online at kanopibyarmstrong.com.
Kanopi uses artificial intelligence and machine learning to provide early access and enhanced visibility to a large portion of the market opportunity that we previously couldn't efficiently track.
This technology allows us to influence Armstrong solutions and simplifies the purchasing process.
Kanopi offers facility owners and managers a comprehensive solution, including diagnostic tools, consulting, and pre-certified installation services.
User-friendly and supported by our top-tier distribution network, Kanopi is tapping into pent-up renovation demand in smaller commercial spaces and driving Mineral Fiber volume growth.
Initial results are promising.
We are seeing growth across all key metrics: website traffic, orders, order value, and sales.
Each month has significantly outperformed the previous one, and I expect this trend to continue throughout the year.
Once again, we are encouraged by the improving market conditions and the increasing relevance of the ceiling category.
We are particularly excited about the upcoming market opportunities that Armstrong is well-positioned to capture, enabling us to fulfill our commitment to deliver strong results for our shareholders and our mission to make a positive impact by creating healthier spaces where we live, work, learn, heal, and play.
Summary:
output: maintaining 2021 guidance: net sales of +10% to +13% and adjusted ebitda of +9% to +13%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Scott Oaksmith, Senior Vice President of Real Estate and Finance, will be accompanying them.
We are grateful for your participation.
I'm happy to announce that Choice Hotels continued to achieve impressive RevPAR growth in the third quarter, significantly outperforming the industry.
We continue to increase our market share across all segments we operate in.
Based on these performance trends, we anticipate exceeding 2019 RevPAR and adjusted EBITDA levels for the full year 2021.
By consistently executing our long-term strategy, we have positioned Choice Hotels to capitalize on post-pandemic trends favoring leisure travel, limited service hotels, and extended stays.
Moreover, our business traveler demand has recovered to levels comparable to the third quarter of 2019.
The third quarter was outstanding, marking our strongest quarter of the year.
Our RevPAR grew by 11.4% compared to the third quarter of 2019, surpassing our previous quarterly RevPAR projections.
In fact, RevPAR has exceeded 2019 levels for five consecutive months, with this trend continuing into the fourth quarter.
For more than 18 months, we've maintained significantly higher RevPAR index share gains against competitors compared to 2019.
This trend continued in the third quarter, with our RevPAR index increasing by nearly four percentage points compared to 2019 versus local competitors, reflecting ongoing growth in both weekday and weekend RevPAR index as reported by STR.
Choice's ability to continue gaining market share even as the broader industry recovers demonstrates that our strategic investments are yielding results and gives us greater confidence in our future revenue trajectory.
Due to our strategic investments before and during the pandemic, we are better positioned today to capitalize on significant growth opportunities in the long term, which we expect will create value and elevate our performance to new heights.
The most impressive aspect is our continued strong performance through both rate improvement and occupancy share gains.
Choice's average daily rate growth has outpaced the industry in the third quarter, thanks to our new revenue management tool and expanded capabilities.
Additionally, our comprehensive merchandising strategy has enabled us to achieve occupancy share gains compared to local competitors.
We continue to make substantial investments that are improving our owners' performance and contributing to our brand's superior results.
Earlier this year, we introduced a new revenue management capability designed to enhance our franchise owners' ability to effectively drive top-line revenue.
This tool represents a significant improvement that we were able to provide to our franchisees at a crucial point in the recovery.
As the first mobile-enabled revenue management app, it allows our franchisees to more effectively manage their channels, rates, and inventory by adapting to local market trends in real-time through repricing and competitive rate shopping multiple times daily, from virtually anywhere.
This enhanced capability has contributed to Choice gaining significant RevPAR index share, specifically driving average daily rate index gains versus local competitors, and we expect this trend to continue.
The acceptance rate of pricing recommendations by our franchisees has been significantly higher than with our previous tool, demonstrating our owners' confidence in the solutions we provide.
This tool, combined with expert advice from our experienced revenue management consultants, is helping our franchise owners swiftly execute the right pricing strategy, which is particularly important in an inflationary environment.
Simultaneously, we continue to improve unit economics for our franchisees, focusing on investments like housekeeping upon request that reduce their ownership costs while driving continued performance improvements.
Recently, we deployed a new digital registration capability integrated with our property management system.
This cost-effective cloud-based solution is designed to streamline the hotel registration process for front desk staff, reduce labor costs, expedite check-in, and enhance our guests' overall experience.
Furthermore, our recent brand investments are designed to appeal to future guests while providing a compelling return on investment for our franchisees.
A few weeks ago, we introduced a new Cambria hotel prototype option designed for secondary and leisure markets.
We're excited about Cambria's future growth potential, as we expect this prototype will allow developers the flexibility to build at a lower cost, expanding the markets available for growth while maintaining our design-forward experience.
I will now provide a brief update on our key segments, where 11 out of our 12 brands achieved RevPAR index gains versus their local competitors in the third quarter compared to 2019.
Our strategic investments in the extended-stay segment have allowed us to quadruple the portfolio size over the past five years, reaching 467 domestic units with a domestic pipeline of nearly 310 hotels.
This segment, a significant growth engine for the company, expanded by over 45 hotels in the third quarter year-over-year and now represents over 10% of our total domestic rooms.
In addition to strong unit growth, we've also driven impressive RevPAR growth across our extended stay brands.
Specifically, when compared to the third quarter of 2019, our extended-stay portfolio grew RevPAR by over 18%, driven by occupancy levels of 82% and a 9% increase in average daily rate.
This outperformed the industry's RevPAR change by over 20 percentage points.
The WoodSpring Suites brand celebrated a key milestone with the recent opening of its 300th hotel.
The brand's pipeline expanded by over 20% year-over-year as of the end of September, reaching nearly 160 domestic hotels, further demonstrating developer demand for this brand due to its cycle resilience.
We expect that WoodSpring's robust pipeline will provide a strong platform for future brand growth.
Overall, we are pleased with the significant increase in developers' interest in extended stay projects.
In the third quarter, we executed two dozen extended-stay domestic franchise agreements, an 85% increase year-over-year and a 20% increase compared to 2019 levels.
Additionally, the first hotel for our newest extended-stay brand, Everhome Suites, is currently under construction and scheduled to open next summer, with nearly 20 additional projects already in the pipeline.
Our mid-scale brands, which represent over two-thirds of our total domestic room portfolio and approximately half of the total domestic pipeline, continued to outperform the segment's RevPAR growth.
Our mid-scale and upper mid-scale portfolio grew RevPAR by nearly 10%, driven by average daily rate growth of over 9%, outpacing the industry's mid-scale and upper mid-scale segment growth by nearly seven percentage points when compared to the third quarter of 2019.
Our flagship brand, Comfort, recently celebrated the highest number of conversion hotel openings since 2014, while increasing new construction agreements threefold in the third quarter year-over-year.
The Comfort brand's domestic unit growth exceeding 2% and RevPAR index outperformance against local rivals showcase the appeal of this iconic brand to both hotel developers and guests.
Our upscale portfolio saw significant growth in the third quarter year-over-year, with domestic room count increasing by nearly 22%, driven by Cambria and the Ascend Hotel Collection.
The upscale portfolio also set a record for domestic openings in the first three quarters of the year.
Cambria continued its positive trajectory, expanding by over 9% to 58 units year-over-year, with 17 projects under active construction at September's end and five more hotels slated to open this year.
In August, we marked the opening of a Cambria hotel in the heart of Napa Valley, one of the world's premier wine regions.
Our upscale portfolio improved its RevPAR index compared to local competitors and surpassed the industry's RevPAR change by 15 percentage points while raising the average daily rate by 11% compared to the third quarter of 2019.
This progress demonstrates the attractiveness of Choice Hotels' value proposition in the upscale segment for current and potential owners.
The strong performance across our entire brand portfolio confirms our strategy of growing in key segments, which we believe will further enhance the long-term revenue intensity of our system.
Regarding demand trends, we continued to see improvements in our weekday occupancy index share during the third quarter compared to 2019.
We believe these share gains are partly driven by long-term consumer trends, such as remote work and increased early retirements, which give Americans more flexibility in their leisure travel timing.
We noticed guests extending their trips into shoulder days of the weekend, giving us optimism about future travel trends following the busy summer season.
We also observed a higher proportion of revenue coming from longer stays compared to 2019.
Like our broader occupancy share gains, these weekday demand increases were achieved through our merchandising capabilities and strategy, using targeted promotions at optimal times for the right customers.
Our investments have allowed us to capitalize on demand that historically drove our core business while attracting a larger share of leisure travelers.
While our most loyal Choice Privileges members continued to spend more at our hotels during the third quarter, we also successfully appealed to new customers, increasing their revenue contribution compared to 2019 levels.
We see ongoing momentum in business travel trends, with potential for further growth.
We've witnessed sequential quarter-over-quarter increases in business travel bookings in the third quarter of 2021, with overall business performance similar to 2019 levels.
As a customer-focused company, Choice constantly seeks innovative ways to better serve evolving consumer needs and anticipate future guest expectations.
We are the first lodging company to collaborate with Bakkt, a digital asset marketplace, allowing us to offer guests more currency options and redemption methods.
Our 50 million-plus Choice Privileges loyalty members can now convert their rewards points to cash for Bitcoin purchases, transfer points to friends, or use them online or in-store wherever Apple Pay or Google Pay is accepted.
Regarding franchisee business delivery and brand demand, we saw growth compared to 2019 and 2020 through increased revenue contribution from choicehotels.com and other proprietary digital channels in the third quarter.
These channels significantly improve our owners' profitability by delivering strong rates at the lowest cost, making them a key focus for enhancing our value proposition.
Given our strong value proposition, it's unsurprising that Choice maintains an industry-leading franchisee voluntary retention rate and our franchise owners continue to develop our brands.
Bolstered by our compelling value proposition and record performance, we continue to see demand for new franchise contracts.
In the third quarter, we awarded 89 new domestic franchise agreements, a 10% increase over the same period in 2020.
Demand for our new construction brands in the third quarter increased by over 50% year-over-year.
We're excited to announce that our WoodSpring brand expanded internationally in late October, entering the Canadian market with a commitment for more than 15 units from a well-known developer and operator.
Our development team dedicated to promoting diverse ownership of Choice franchise hotels among underrepresented and minority owners has awarded 18 franchise contracts year-to-date through September, bringing the total to over 280 since the program's inception 15 years ago.
More than half of the 18 agreements this year were awarded to women entrepreneurs.
These accomplishments are due to the resilience and hard work of our dedicated associates.
We remain committed to investing in and supporting our associates, and we're proud to be the only hotel company recently recognized as a Best Work-life Balance Employer by Comparably.
We're confident in our continued ability to create value and deliver results for owners and shareholders through strategic investments, strong performance, and an award-winning culture focused on diversity, equity, and belonging.
I'll now hand over to our CFO.
I hope you and your families are well.
I'll provide additional insights on our third quarter results, update you on our liquidity and capital allocation, and share our outlook for the future.
As discussed previously, we're comparing our financial performance and RevPAR results to 2019 for a more meaningful analysis of trends, as the prior year's quarterly results were significantly impacted by the pandemic.
For the third quarter of 2021 compared to the same period in 2019, total revenues, excluding marketing and reservation system fees, were $166.5 million, an 8% increase.
Adjusted EBITDA rose 18% to $133.2 million, driven by improving RevPAR performance, revenue-intensive unit growth, and strong effective royalty rate growth, combined with continued cost discipline.
Our adjusted EBITDA margin expanded to 80%, a seven percentage point increase.
As a result, our adjusted earnings per share were $1.51 for the third quarter, a 10% increase versus 2019.
Turning to our three key revenue levers, starting with royalty rate, which remains a significant source of our revenue growth.
The company's domestic effective royalty rate rose by 0.08% year-on-year to about 5% in comparison to Q3 2020.
This outcome demonstrates the ongoing enhancement of our value offering to franchise owners, their sustained interest in associating with our established brands, and the promising outlook of our pipeline.
It further confirms the validity of our long-term past, present, and future investments on behalf of our franchisees.
We anticipate maintaining the current growth trajectory of this factor for the entire year of 2021 and growing at our historical rate in the future as owners continue to seek Choice Hotels' proven ability to deliver strong top-line revenues that maximize return on investment while helping reduce their total ownership costs.
Our domestic systemwide RevPAR outperformed the overall industry by 16% in Q3, showing an 11.4% increase compared to 2019.
Specifically, our average daily rate increased by nearly 9%, and our occupancy levels rose by almost two percentage points compared to the same quarter in 2019.
Our Q3 results indicated that we continue to surpass the primary chain scale segments in which we compete, as reported by STR, by six percentage points compared to 2019.
Notably, our strong RevPAR trends have persisted into Q4.
As we've mentioned in previous calls, we've long focused our brand strategy on driving growth across the higher value and more revenue-intensive upscale, extended-stay, and mid-scale segments.
The investments we've made continue to yield results, as these strategic segments have allowed us to significantly outperform the industry in RevPAR growth and achieve gains compared to our local competitors.
Allow me to highlight a few impressive performance achievements for our brands in Q3.
As a reminder, we're comparing the growth figures with the same period in 2019.
Our WoodSpring brand achieved 23% RevPAR growth, reaching an average occupancy rate of nearly 86% and experiencing an 11% increase in average daily rate.
Ascend Hotels saw their average daily rate grow by over 17% and outperformed the upscale segment's RevPAR growth by more than 20 percentage points.
Simultaneously, the Comfort family increased RevPAR by over 8%, reflecting a 9% rise in average daily rate.
Lastly, both our Cambria and MainStay Suites brands gained 12 percentage points in RevPAR index compared to their local competitors.
More specifically, our average daily rate and occupancy improved from the previous quarter, and our average daily rate index and occupancy index continue to increase compared to 2019, resulting from our investments in revenue management tools for our franchisees and the merchandising capabilities and strategy we've implemented.
Our third revenue lever is units and rooms growth, which benefits from the absolute size of our portfolio and the revenue intensity of the totals.
To ensure the long-term quality of our brand portfolio, we continue to terminate underperforming economy hotels at the lower end of the portfolio, as well as quality hotels that cannot maintain mid-scale brand standards.
We believe these actions will not only ensure an even stronger brand portfolio over time, but we also expect these targeted terminations to present an opportunity for royalty revenue growth as we plan to replace these hotels with higher quality and more revenue-intensive units.
Nevertheless, we continue to expand the overall size of our domestic franchise system.
Across our more revenue-intensive brands in the upscale, extended-stay, and mid-scale segments, we observed stronger unit growth, increasing the number of hotels by 2% and rooms by 2.6% year-over-year.
Our developers are increasingly optimistic about the long-term fundamentals of the lodging industry.
In fact, one-third of total domestic franchise agreements awarded in Q3 were for new construction contracts, representing an increase of more than 50% compared to the same quarter of the previous year.
At the same time, demand for our conversion brands from January to September increased by 25% year-over-year.
Let me share a few highlights on specific brands.
The Ascend Hotel Collection leads the industry as the first launch and currently the largest soft brand, expanding its domestic room count by 27% year-over-year.
Simultaneously, Clarion Point has nearly doubled its portfolio year-over-year, ending Q3 with nearly 35 hotels open in the U.S. and 15 additional hotels awaiting conversion this year.
Our MainStay Suites mid-scale extended-stay brand portfolio expanded to nearly 100 domestic hotels open, representing more than 30% unit growth year-over-year.
Finally, our suburban extended stay portfolio of 70 domestic hotels open experienced 13% year-over-year unit growth.
Now, a few words about our liquidity profile and an update on capital allocation.
As a result of our strong performance, the company has an even stronger liquidity position.
Specifically, at the end of Q3 2021, the company had over $1 billion in cash and available borrowing capacity through its revolving credit facility.
We are also pleased to report cash flow from operations of $142.8 million for Q3 2021, a 53% increase compared to Q3 2019.
Currently, our gross debt-to-EBITDA leverage levels remain at the low end of our target range of 3 to 4 times.
At the end of Q3 2021, our net debt-to-EBITDA leverage level was at 1.8 times.
These impressive results, combined with our strong liquidity and confidence in our ability to generate high levels of cash, leave us well-positioned to continue growing our business and returning excess cash flow to shareholders well into the future.
From January through October, we have returned over $35 million to our shareholders in the form of cash dividends and repurchases of our common stock.
We will continue to monitor the environment for other investment opportunities and evaluate capital returns in the context of our leverage levels, market conditions, and our overall capital allocation strategy.
Finally, let's discuss our expectations for the future.
We currently expect full-year domestic RevPAR to surpass 2019 levels and grow by approximately 1% compared to full-year 2019.
Assuming the broader RevPAR and economic recovery trends continue, we now expect our 2021 adjusted EBITDA to exceed 2019 levels and range between $382 million and $387 million, even with planned incremental investments in Q4.
Our view is reinforced by our Q3 results, which extend our strong year-to-date financial performance, broader macro trends, and our continued investments to support growth for the remainder of 2021 and beyond.
We will continue to evaluate the impact of COVID-19 across the business, and we'll provide further updates in February during our next earnings call.
In conclusion, we remain confident in our long-term strategic approach and resilient business model. Coupled with our disciplined capital allocation strategy and strong balance sheet, we believe these strengths will allow us to further capitalize on growth opportunities and drive outsized returns for years to come.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.51 excluding items.
q3 revenue rose 4 percent to $323.4 million.
domestic revpar for 2021 expected to surpass 2019 levels and grow at approximately 1%, as compared to full-year 2019.
adjusted ebitda for 2021 is expected to exceed 2019 levels and range between $382 million and $387 million.
