input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We'll also be covering certain non-standard financial metrics.
Today's participants include our CEO Steve Strah, CFO Jon Taylor, and Vice Chairperson John Somerhalder.
Several other executives will be available for questions later.
Our first quarter 2021 results showed GAAP earnings of $0.62 per share and operating earnings of $0.69 per share, at the higher end of our projected range.
As Jon will explain, our performance reflects successful implementation of investment strategies, increased weather-adjusted residential usage, and strict control of operating costs.
I was recently appointed as FirstEnergy's CEO and joined the Board of Directors.
I'm grateful for the Board's confidence in me since becoming President last May and Acting CEO in October.
I take great pride in FirstEnergy and our employees' dedication to serving customers and communities.
I'm honored to continue leading the company through current challenges and towards long-term stability and success.
As we move FirstEnergy forward, I'm prioritizing employee and customer safety.
We're focused on embedding ethics, accountability and integrity into our culture, supported by a robust compliance program.
We're implementing FE Forward to maximize our potential, deliver long-term results, and increase near-term financial flexibility, while investing in infrastructure growth like electrification, grid modernization, and renewable integration for customer benefit.
I'll provide updates on the DOJ investigation, regulatory matters, our FE Forward initiative, and other business developments.
John Somerhalder will discuss the Board and management's efforts to establish a compliance culture based on the highest ethical standards.
As mentioned previously, we're taking decisive action to rebuild our reputation, focus on the future, and cooperate with ongoing government investigations.
We've initiated talks with the DOJ about resolving this matter, potentially through a deferred prosecution agreement.
We can't predict the timing, outcome, or impact of a possible DOJ resolution at this time.
We aim to take a comprehensive and transparent approach with stakeholders across all matters under review.
This aligns with changes we're making to our political and legislative engagement.
We've ceased all contributions to 501(c)(4) organizations.
We've suspended all other political disbursements, including from our PAC.
We've limited our involvement in political processes.
We've suspended or terminated various political consulting relationships.
We'll expand our disclosures on political spending for greater transparency.
We've committed to posting updates on our website about corporate political activity, trade association relationships, and our revised corporate political activity policy.
A comprehensive and open approach is also central to our regulatory activities.
In Ohio, we're taking proactive steps to reduce regulatory uncertainty for our utilities.
This includes crediting Ohio utility customers about $27 million in late March.
This covers revenues collected through the decoupling mechanism plus interest, our partial settlement with the Ohio Attorney General to stop collecting decoupling revenues, and our decision not to seek recovery of lost distribution revenues from Ohio customers.
These actions fully address the requirements of Ohio House Bill 128 and the related rate impact of House Bill 6 on our customers.
These are important steps to move past this issue.
In other Ohio regulatory matters, we've updated our testimony in the ESP quadrennial review case with individual company SEET values.
We're in settlement discussions with interested parties on this and the consolidated 2017, 2018, and 2019 SEET cases.
We're engaging with regulators to refund customers for certain vendor payments in each affected jurisdiction.
In Ohio, at the PUCO's request, our annual Rider DCR audit has been expanded to review these payments.
Outside Ohio, our regulatory focus is on customer-oriented initiatives supporting the transition to a cleaner climate.
JCP&L filed a petition with the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities for approval of its EV driven program.
If approved, this four-year, $50 million program would offer incentives and rate structures to support EV charging infrastructure development in our New Jersey service area, aiming to accelerate EV adoption and benefit residential, commercial, and industrial customers.
The Pennsylvania PUC approved our five-year, $390 million energy efficiency and conservation plan, supporting the PUC's consumption reduction targets.
We completed the sale of JCP&L's 50% stake in the Yards Creek pump-storage hydro plant, receiving $155 million in proceeds.
We declared our intention to divest Penelec's Waverly New York distribution assets, which cater to approximately 3,800 customers, to a local cooperative.
The transaction, pending regulatory approval, will streamline Penelec's operations by concentrating solely on Pennsylvania clientele.
In our fourth quarter briefing, we introduced FE Forward, our company-wide initiative to transform FirstEnergy into a more robust, efficient industry leader that delivers exceptional value to customers and shareholders.
We anticipate that the FE Forward initiatives will provide a more contemporary experience for our clients, with efficiencies in operations and capital expenditures that can be strategically reinvested into our business, supporting our growth and investments in a more intelligent and environmentally friendly electric grid, while maintaining affordable electricity rates.
During the initial stage of the project, we assessed our processes, business practices, and cultural norms to identify areas for improvement.
Although our safety and reliability performance is robust, we discovered opportunities in numerous areas to enhance and automate processes, adopt a more strategic approach to operating expenditures, and modernize experiences for our customers and employees.
We've identified over 300 opportunities and are now delving deeper into these concepts, developing detailed, executable plans as we prepare for implementation starting later this quarter.
Examples of this work include improving planning and scheduling through system integration to enable our employees to deliver their best to our customers, utilizing advanced technologies like drones and satellite imagery to enhance our vegetation management programs, employing predictive analytics and web-based tools to offer our customers more self-service options and improve their experience, and leveraging purchasing power to optimize payment terms.
As part of these efforts, we plan to evaluate the appropriate timing to initiate rate cases on a state-by-state basis to best support our customer-focused strategic priorities.
We will also remain attentive to emerging technologies, smart grid, electric vehicle infrastructure, and our customers' evolving energy needs as we consider ways to reduce our carbon footprint.
We've had a strong start to the year, and yesterday we reaffirmed our 2021 operating earnings guidance of $2.40 to $2.60 per share.
Our leadership team is dedicated to upholding our core values and behaviors and executing our proven strategies as we prioritize our customers in everything we do.
We will take the necessary steps to fulfill our promise to make FirstEnergy a better company, one that is respected by our customers, investors, regulators, and employees.
It's an honor and a pleasure to join you today.
I'd like to begin by sharing my impressions of FirstEnergy after nearly two months in this position.
This company has a solid foundation, including a commitment to improve governance and compliance, a dedication to customers by embracing innovation and technology to ensure the strength, resilience, and reliability of its transmission and distribution businesses, a deeply ingrained safety culture, and strong potential to deliver significant value to investors through customer-focused growth.
Since joining the team, I've been supporting senior leadership in advancing the company's priorities, strengthening our governance and compliance functions, and improving our relationships with external stakeholders, including regulators and the financial community.
Steve discussed our business priorities, so I will focus my comments today on our compliance work, including remedial actions.
First, I'd like to provide an update on our internal investigation, which has uncovered no new material issues since our last earnings call.
The focus of the internal investigation has shifted from a proactive investigation to continued cooperation with ongoing government investigations.
Management and the Board, with assistance from the compliance subcommittee of the Audit Committee, have been collaborating to establish a best-in-class compliance program.
Through these efforts, we have identified improvement opportunities in five broad categories: governance, risk management, training and communications, concerns management, and third-party management.
As part of these efforts, FirstEnergy is committed to enhancing its compliance culture to be best-in-class.
Some of the actions completed to date include hiring our Senior Vice President and Chief Legal Officer, Hyun Park, in January; Antonio Fernandez, who joined as Vice President and Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer last week; and myself.
On the Board side, Jesse Lynn and Andrew Teno from Icahn Capital joined us in March.
The Board has also nominated a new Independent Member, Melvin Williams, for election at the Annual Shareholders Meeting when Sandy Pianalto's term ends next month.
I believe the insights and experience of these new leaders are helping to complement a very committed and confident Board and management team.
In March, the Board affirmed our confidence in Steve by appointing him CEO.
Steve has consistently demonstrated the integrity, leadership skills, strategic acumen, and deep knowledge of our businesses required to position FirstEnergy for long-term success and stability.
These changes, along with the Board's reinforcement of the executive team's commitment to setting the appropriate tone at the top, support a culture of compliance going forward.
For example, we recently held an event where the Chairman and the Chair of the Compliance subcommittee addressed the company's top 140 leaders regarding expectations to act with integrity in everything we do.
Our legal department recently completed training on up-the-ladder reporting, and we have enhanced our onboarding process for new employees and third parties regarding expectations around our code of business conduct.
Over the next few months, the company will take many more steps to enhance our compliance program, such as continuing to build the new, more centralized compliance organization under Antonio's leadership; addressing our processes, policies, and controls, including additional oversight for political contributions; continuing to emphasize our values and expectations in ongoing communications with our employees; incorporating compliance into our goals and performance metrics and holding all employees to the same standards regardless of title; enhancing channels for incident reporting and developing thorough and objective processes to investigate and address allegations of misconduct; and ensuring increased communications with and training of employees regarding our commitment to ethical standards and integrity of our business procedures, compliance requirements, our code of business conduct, and other company policies, as well as understanding and utilizing the process for reporting suspected violations of law or the code of business conduct.
We have also enhanced our internal controls around disbursements to require additional approvals, targeted reviews of any suspicious payments, and a reassessment of approval levels across the entire company.
Additionally, in the area of disbursements, we will update and clarify policies and procedures, conduct training, and institute a regular audit program that reviews payments and services performed.
A detailed list of the corrective actions we are taking can be found on Pages 8 and 9 of our first quarter FactBook.
Over the next several months, we expect to make significant progress in the areas of compliance led by Antonio's organization, which will continue to be overseen by the Board and the newly established management steering committee for Ethics and Compliance.
Through these efforts, we expect the material weakness associated with the tone at the top to be remediated by the time we file our fourth quarter earnings.
Our leaders are continuing to emphasize the importance of compliance and working to regain the trust of employees and our stakeholders by modeling appropriate behavior and consistently communicating that compliance and ethics are core values, just like safety.
We are committed to ensuring that employees understand what is expected of them and feel comfortable reporting ethical violations without fear of repercussions.
By consistently stressing the significance of adhering to our plans and vision, as well as showing exemplary leadership, we aim to instill trust in our staff that the executives and directors are taking appropriate, decisive steps to advance the company.
I'm confident that we've gained valuable insights from recent obstacles and are implementing the right measures to emerge as an improved, more resilient organization with promising prospects.
I'll now hand over to Jon Taylor to discuss the first quarter performance and provide a financial update.
We've introduced new information in three key areas within our Investor FactBook.
Our initiatives to support a more environmentally friendly and efficient power grid, additional information about our balance sheet, including our funds from operations target and the actions we're taking to reach our objectives, and enhanced disclosures on environmental, social, and governance matters.
It's worth mentioning that we continue to provide more comprehensive information on return on equity, including more detailed sensitivity analyses.
We reported GAAP earnings of $0.62 per share and operating earnings of $0.69 per share for the first quarter of 2021, with the latter being at the higher end of our projected range.
The 2021 GAAP results include two exceptional items: regulatory charges for customer reimbursements related to previously collected Ohio decoupling revenues and expenses linked to the ongoing investigation.
Our distribution business results for this year's first quarter, compared to 2020, show increased residential usage on both actual and weather-adjusted bases, as well as growth from additional riders and rate increases, such as DCR and grid modernization in Ohio, the distribution system improvement charge in Pennsylvania, and the implementation of our base rate case settlement in New Jersey.
These positive factors were partially counterbalanced by a $0.10 per share impact due to the absence of Ohio decoupling revenues and our decision to forgo collecting lost distribution revenues from residential and commercial customers.
Our total distribution deliveries for the first quarter of 2021 decreased by 2% on a weather-adjusted basis compared to last year, reflecting a 2% increase in residential sales as customers continued to spend more time at home, a 7% decline in commercial sales, and a 3% decrease in industrial sales.
It's important to note that total distribution deliveries through the first quarter align with our internal load forecast, with residential demand 2% higher than anticipated, while industrial load is 2% lower.
In our regulated transmission business, earnings declined due to higher net financing costs, which included an adjustment to previously capitalized interest, partially offset by the impact of rate base growth at our ATSI and MAIT subsidiaries.
In our corporate segment, results show lower operating expenses, offset by the absence of a first quarter 2020 pension OPEB credit related to Energy Harbor's emergence from bankruptcy, as well as higher interest expense.
We've had a strong start to the year and are reaffirming our operating earnings guidance of $2.40 to $2.60 per share for 2021.
We've also introduced second quarter guidance of $0.48 to $0.58 per share.
Additionally, our strong focus on cash management helped drive a $125 million increase in adjusted cash from operations and a $185 million increase in free cash flow compared to our internal plan for the first quarter.
Regarding other financial updates, our 2021 debt financing plan remains on schedule.
In March, FirstEnergy Transmission issued $500 million in senior notes in a robust, well-supported bond offering that highlighted the strength of our transmission business.
The offering was oversubscribed and comparable to an investment-grade offering.
We used the proceeds to repay $500 million in short-term borrowings under the FET revolving credit facility.
We also repaid $250 million at the FirstEnergy Holding Company.
In April, we successfully issued $200 million in first mortgage bonds at MonPower, which also received strong support.
This aligns with our earlier commitment to reduce short-term borrowings and our goal to improve our credit metrics at FirstEnergy, regain investment-grade status as quickly as possible, and maintain strong credit ratings at our utilities.
We continue to provide regular updates to the rating agencies on our business and are collaborating with them to develop a clear outline of what's needed for FirstEnergy to regain investment-grade credit ratings.
Key milestones include governance and compliance changes at our company, resolution of the DOJ investigation, and solid credit metrics.
Regarding longer-term financing needs, through the execution of FE Forward, we have reduced our debt financing plan by approximately $1 billion through 2023, primarily at the FirstEnergy and FirstEnergy Transmission holding companies.
Furthermore, as previously mentioned, equity is a crucial part of our overall financing plan, with intentions to raise up to $1.2 billion of equity over 2022 and 2023.
As stated before, we will adjust these plans as necessary and are exploring various alternatives to raise equity capital in a manner that could be more beneficial to all stakeholders.
These actions, combined with new rates at JCP&L and our 60% plus formula rate capital investment program, will generate $150 million to $200 million of incremental cash flow annually, while maintaining relatively stable adjusted debt levels through 2023, all of which will support our targeted 12% to 13% FFO to debt range.
Regarding our pension, our funding status was 81% as of March 31, up from 78% at the end of last year, resulting in a $500 million reduction in our unfunded pension obligation, which improves our adjusted debt position with the rating agencies.
The extended funding timeframe permitted under the American Rescue Plan, along with the modification of interest rate stabilization rules, means that we don't anticipate any funding requirements for the foreseeable future, assuming our plan achieves a 7.5% expected return on assets.
Although we plan to make contributions to the pension next year, this legislation provides us with additional discretion and flexibility to make voluntary contributions as we evaluate our capital allocation plans.
As Steve mentioned, discussions have begun with the Department of Justice.
While no contingency has been reflected in our consolidated financial statements, we believe it's probable that we will incur a loss in connection with the resolution of this investigation.
However, we cannot yet reasonably estimate the amount.
Lastly, President Biden recently introduced the American Jobs Plan, which includes a corporate tax increase and proposed minimum tax, as well as potential opportunities related to a proposed infusion into electric vehicle infrastructure and the energy grid.
It's clearly very early in the process, but the corporate tax provision could be slightly cash positive for us if implemented in its current form.
Our solid first quarter results and expectations for the year reflect our strong operating fundamentals and the continued success of our strategies to modernize and enhance our distribution and transmission systems.
As we move our company forward, we are intensely focused on unlocking opportunities and increasing value for our shareholders, customers, and employees.
Let's now open the call for your questions and answers.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:As mandated by applicable SEC regulations, we offer comparisons of any non-GAAP financial metrics to the most closely related GAAP measures on our website.
I am now pleased to turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, David Hult.
In Q4, we finalized the game-changing acquisitions of Larry H. Miller, Total Care Auto (powered by Landcar), Kahlo Chrysler Jeep Dodge, Arapahoe Hyundai-Genesis, and the Stevinson Automotive Group, collectively representing about $6.6 billion in yearly revenue.
These purchases involve the appropriate brands in expanding markets and align with Asbury's corporate culture.
We anticipate leveraging our combined capabilities and expanding together, and I'm thrilled to welcome our new team members to the Asbury family.
Asbury achieved unprecedented success in 2021.
Throughout the year, we increased adjusted EBITDA by 94% and adjusted earnings per share by 112%.
We achieved an adjusted operating margin of 8.1%.
We successfully incorporated excellent dealerships in targeted high-growth markets and completed the implementation of Clicklane, our online transaction platform, across all legacy Asbury locations.
Despite challenges in the new vehicle market, we attained record profitability by enhancing our new vehicle margins, boosting used vehicle sales, and expanding our parts and service operations, all while sustaining improved employee productivity and utilizing our robust cash flow for acquisitions.
Our diverse business lines enable us to adapt and consistently deliver strong earnings regardless of market conditions.
We plan to implement Total Care Auto in our existing stores and introduce Clicklane to our recent acquisitions, allowing us to further increase our earnings.
Our balance sheet remains robust due to our record performance and strong cash flow.
Our adjusted operating cash flow for 2021 was $632 million, a $189 million increase from 2020.
Our net leverage ratio at the end of this quarter was 2.7 times.
We will continue to utilize our free cash flow to manage our leverage and maximize shareholder returns through share repurchases and acquisitions.
I'd like to provide a brief update on our five-year plan.
Our same-store adjusted revenue grew by nearly 12% last year, surpassing expectations.
Clicklane continues to produce impressive results, generating over $570 million in additional revenue for three quarters in 2021.
Despite lower new vehicle inventory levels, Clicklane contributed an additional 7% to our same-store growth.
As previously mentioned, we had a highly successful year in terms of acquisitions.
Given these results, we remain fully confident in the execution of our growth strategy.
Based on our 2021 performance, we will revise our five-year plan during our Q1 2022 earnings call.
I will now pass the call to Dan to discuss our operational performance.
We achieved strong results, enabling us to deliver an impressive gross margin of 20.4%, an all-time record and a 370 basis point increase compared to the fourth quarter of last year.
Our teams continue to maximize employee productivity, resulting in adjusted SG&A as a percentage of gross profit of 54.3%, a 710 basis point improvement over the previous year.
Our total revenue for the quarter increased by 19% year-over-year, and total gross profit rose by 46%.
We improved our adjusted operating margins for the quarter from 6% in 2020 to 8.9% in 2021, and we will continue to optimize our portfolio in the future.
Now, I will discuss our same-store performance compared to the fourth quarter of 2020, unless otherwise specified.
Starting with new vehicles.
Given current market conditions, we remain focused on being opportunistic with our inventory and improving gross profits to maximize profitability.
Our new average gross profit per vehicle was $6,335, an increase of $3,441 or 119% from the same period last year.
All segment margins showed significant improvement compared to the prior-year period.
By the close of December, our new vehicle stock was valued at $207 million with an eight-day supply, which was 32 days less than the previous year.
We anticipate the supply days to stay low as we enter 2022, with a slight increase expected towards the year's end.
Let's now discuss pre-owned vehicles.
Our used retail sales volume grew by 15%, with a gross margin of 8.2%, equating to an average profit of $2,623 per vehicle.
Our performance led to a 64% increase in retail gross profit.
Our used vehicle inventory at quarter-end was $402 million, representing a 34-day supply, which is three days more than last year.
The ratio of used to new vehicles for the quarter stood at 109%.
Our consistent and robust growth in F&I resulted in a $213 increase to $1,961 per vehicle sold compared to the same quarter last year.
In Q4, our front-end yield per vehicle rose by $2,169 to reach a record high of $6,362.
Now, let's look at parts and service.
Our parts and service revenue grew by 13% this quarter.
Warranty revenue decreased by 19%.
Our customer-paid revenue continues to show healthy recovery, growing by 17%.
We reached a new record of over 149,000 online service appointments, a 16% increase from the same quarter last year.
Increasing online service appointments benefits customer experience, retention, conversion rates, margins, and shareholder returns.
After three full quarters of Clicklane implementation in all legacy stores, we'd like to share some performance data.
In Q4, we sold over 5,000 vehicles through Clicklane, with 47% being new and 53% used.
91% of these transactions were with customers new to Asbury's dealership network.
Average transaction time remained consistent with the previous quarter: 8 minutes for cash deals and 14 minutes for financed deals.
The total variable front-end yield was $4,298, and the F&I front-end yield was $1,846.
The average credit score is higher than the average at our physical stores.
80% of financing applicants received instant approval, while an additional 10% needed some offline assistance.
90% of applicants were approved for financing.
43% of Clicklane sales included trade-ins, with 78% of these trades reconditioned and resold to consumers, yielding a total front-end of $4,490.
92% of Clicklane deliveries occur within a 50-mile radius of our stores, allowing us to retain these new customers for parts and service.
As expected, Clicklane customers are converting at higher rates than traditional internet leads.
In the first few months after launching Clicklane, about 60% of sales were new vehicles.
We can't fully assess Clicklane's potential until inventory levels normalize.
We remain enthusiastic about Clicklane's continued growth.
You've all created outstanding organizations that align with our goal of being the most customer-focused automotive retailer.
Our future looks promising, and I'm eager to meet all of you.
I'll now pass the call to Michael to discuss our financial performance.
I'd like to present some financial highlights from what was another record-breaking quarter for our company.
In comparison to the same period last year, our efforts to manage gross profit and control expenses resulted in a fourth quarter adjusted operating margin of 8.9%, a 290 basis point increase and an all-time high.
Adjusted net income grew by 89% to $163 million, while adjusted earnings per share rose by 68% to $7.46.
The fourth quarter 2021 net income was modified to account for acquisition expenses and related financing costs of $289 million or $1.02 per diluted share.
The fourth quarter 2020 net income was adjusted to reflect a gain of $3.9 million or $0.15 per diluted share from dealership divestiture.
Our fourth quarter 2021 earnings per share were negatively affected by the interest and additional shares issued as part of the acquisition financing completed before the acquisition closure, in addition to the aforementioned net income adjustments.
Had the financing concluded simultaneously with the Larry H. Miller acquisition, our adjusted earnings per share for the fourth quarter would have benefited by $0.87 due to reduced interest expenses and fewer outstanding shares.
Let's review the full year 2021 results in comparison to 2020.
The adjusted operating margin reached an all-time high of 8.1%, a 240 basis point increase.
Adjusted net income surged by 120% to $549 million, and adjusted earnings per share grew by 112% to $27.29.
Our effective tax rate decreased from 24.8% in 2020 to 23.7% in 2021.
We acquired $6.6 billion in annualized revenue this quarter.
To fund the acquisitions, we issued debt and equity offerings totaling approximately $2.1 billion, arranged a syndicated mortgage facility of about $700 million, and borrowed from our expanded syndicated credit facility.
We invested approximately $34 million in capital expenditures during the quarter.
We generated $632 million in adjusted operating cash flow for the year.
Our financial position remains strong, ending the quarter with about $437 million in liquidity, including cash (excluding Total Care Auto), floorplan offset accounts, and availability on both our used line and revolving credit facility.
At the quarter's end, our net leverage ratio was 2.7 times, below our target of three times.
As David mentioned earlier, our board has approved an increase in our share repurchase authorization from $100 million to $200 million.
For 2022, we anticipate a tax rate of roughly 25% to 26% and capital expenditures of about $150 million.
This figure excludes real estate purchases and potential lease buyout opportunities that we consider financing transactions.
Our primary goals are: Ensure a smooth transition for all new team members; optimize capital allocation to maximize shareholder returns; continue developing and expanding Clicklane, implementing this fully transactional tool across our recent acquisitions nationwide; integrate Total Care Auto, our insurance and F&I product provider, across all Asbury dealerships to increase our F&I PVR; implement company-wide training to foster the growth and development of our employees; and maintain our industry-leading operating margins and SG&A.
I'd like to share our expectations for this year.
We're optimistic about 2022.
We foresee favorable conditions for automotive retail and expect demand to outpace supply for most of the year.
We anticipate a gradual improvement in inventory levels during the second half of 2022 as OEM production increases.
Consequently, we're planning our business based on a SAAR of 15.5 million to 16 million units and vehicle margins similar to 2021.
We'll remain flexible and alert to adapt to changing conditions.
SG&A as a percentage of gross profit should continue to benefit from proactive expense management and improved employee productivity.
We aim to continue delivering strong results for our shareholders, partner effectively with our OEMs to steward their brands, and provide an environment where our team members can thrive while offering the most customer-focused experience in automotive retail.
To conclude, I want to address all Asbury team members.
Our ability to add high-quality stores that share our commitment to serving customers and engaging with communities is a direct result of your efforts.
You've enabled us to thoughtfully expand our core business by aligning with our vision.
People are the key differentiator in any organization, and you're making Asbury a better workplace and creating an environment that attracts business.
Summary:
output:
increase in company's share repurchase authorization by $100 million, to $200 million.
qtrly used vehicle retail unit volume increased 27%; used vehicle retail revenue increased 53%.
q4 adjusted earnings per share of $7.46 per diluted share.
qtrly revenue of $2.7 billion, an increase of 19%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Greg Wright, Chris Sharp, and Corey Dyer, who hold executive positions, are present and will answer questions.
Please consult our 10-K and subsequent SEC filings for a comprehensive overview of business-related risks.
Net income reconciliations can be found in the supplementary package submitted to the SEC and accessible on our website.
We've improved our product range with a notable increase in contributions from our sub-1 megawatt and interconnection category.
We reinforced our commitment to sustainability by releasing our third yearly ESG report.
For the second consecutive quarter, we've increased our revenue and EBITDA projections, paving the way for accelerated cash flow growth.
We further improved our financial position by redeeming high-interest preferred stock and issuing low-cost, long-term fixed-rate debt.
Our strategy for creating long-term value is based on a global, interconnected, and sustainable approach.
We made progress in these areas during the second quarter.
Our company continues to expand globally.
We achieved strong results and bookings across all regions once again.
Our comprehensive product offering continues to grow, with record sub-1 megawatt bookings in Q2 and regional peaks in both EMEA and APAC.
The sub-1 megawatt category, including interconnection, represented nearly half of our total bookings, showing customers' enthusiasm for PlatformDIGITAL in their digital transformation efforts.
I will address our sustainable growth initiatives on Page 3.
In June, we received the Green Lease Leader Gold award for the third consecutive year from the Institute for Market Transformation and the U.S. Department of Energy.
We remain the sole data center provider to receive this recognition, which acknowledges Digital Realty's leadership in incorporating green leasing provisions to align our interests with customers and promote high-performance, healthy buildings.
During Q2, we released our third annual ESG report, detailing our 2020 sustainability efforts, including using 100% renewable energy across our European and U.S. colocation portfolios, meeting 50% of our global energy needs, and progressing towards our science-based target.
Our ESG report showcases various ongoing initiatives, including diversity, equity, inclusion efforts, and community involvement.
Digital Realty is dedicated to being an active community member and giving back to the areas where we operate globally.
We promote and celebrate community involvement and employee engagement through our Do Better Together initiative.
We recently emphasized our commitment to transparency and accountability in our diversity, equity, and inclusion journey by publishing our EEO-1 report.
Recent events have shown that ESG is more important than ever for our business.
I'm proud of our leadership in this area as we work towards delivering sustainable growth for all stakeholders, including investors, customers, employees, and the communities we serve worldwide.
Let's review our investment activity on Page 4.
We continue to invest in our global platform with 39 ongoing projects worldwide as of June 30, adding nearly 300 megawatts of capacity, mostly scheduled for delivery in the next 12 months.
We're investing heavily in EMEA with 19 projects totaling over 150 megawatts under construction.
Most of this capacity is highly connected, including projects in Frankfurt, Marseille, Paris, and Zurich.
Demand remains strong across these metros, attracting service providers and enterprise customers globally, contributing to the region's outstanding Q2 performance in the up-to-1 megawatt category.
In North America, over half of our construction capacity is in Portland and Toronto, two hot markets often overlooked in favor of traditional North American data center locations.
We've had great success in these two metros recently.
We have 30 megawatts under construction in Hillsboro, Oregon, now fully pre-leased, while our Toronto connected campus is gaining momentum as Canada's premier hub for global cloud service providers and enterprise customers.
In Asia Pacific, we're accelerating organic growth in this underserved region.
We opened our third data center in Singapore, a 50-megawatt facility permitted before the construction moratorium.
Demand for this scarce capacity is strong, and we have another 18 megawatts largely presold and set to open this quarter.
We're also opening MC Digital Realty data centers in Japan soon.
As the world watches Tokyo for the Olympics, we're opening a new facility poised to win the gold medal.
We're also opening another data center in Osaka this quarter and our first carrier-neutral offering in Seoul, Korea, in Q4.
We're very excited about the Seoul opportunity.
Earlier this month, we announced plans to enter India in partnership with Brookfield Infrastructure.
Considering our successful collaboration on the Ascenty platform in Latin America, our complementary abilities and knowledge, and the substantial growth potential in India, we are thrilled to broaden our presence in this strong and vibrant market
Let's examine the macroeconomic situation on Page 5
We are privileged to be operating in an industry driven by long-term demand factors
Our position as industry leaders gives us a special perspective to identify global trends as they emerge on PlatformDIGITAL
The increasing significance of data gravity for Global 2000 companies is the first of these trends
We introduced the Data Gravity Index last year, our market intelligence tool that predicts the increasing intensity of enterprise data creation and its gravitational effect on global IT infrastructure across key global markets
We published an industry manifesto earlier this year, promoting connected data communities to guide cross-industry collaboration, address data gravity challenges, and usher in a new era of growth opportunities for all companies
We recently announced a partnership with Zayo to enhance interconnection business by creating an open fabric-of-fabrics
This initiative will allow multinational enterprises to connect vast data sets through fabric and orchestration, addressing the challenges of exploding data sets and increasing data gravity issues
Third-party research continues to emphasize the growing importance of data gravity
Gartner, a Market Intelligence firm, recently conducted its 6th annual survey of chief data officers, revealing that less than 35% of these executives reported their businesses achieving their data sharing goals, including data exchange with external sources that drive revenue-generating business outcomes
Problems often arise due to multiple data hosting and processing locations, combined with the need for appropriate security measures and the inability to overcome latency issues with direct private interconnection between numerous counterparties
PlatformDIGITAL was created to address these challenges
Digital transformation is exacerbating this enterprise data and connectivity issue
Recent studies show that enterprise workflows use an average of 400 unique data sources while exchanging data with 27 external cloud products
Digital Realty's enterprise and service provider clients are using PlatformDIGITAL to overcome these challenges by setting up their own data hubs and using interconnection to securely exchange data within and across multiple metro areas
Our industry leadership is being recognized by experts and influencers
Digital Realty was named a global leader by IDC MarketScape for data center colocation and interconnection services for the second consecutive year, further acknowledging our continuously improving customer capabilities
This recognition reflects our successful implementation of the PlatformDIGITAL roadmap, offering unique and differentiated value to customers with our purpose-built, comprehensive global capabilities
Cloudscene recently ranked Digital Realty as the top provider of data center ecosystems in EMEA for the second year in a row
Digital Realty was ranked second in both North America and Latin America and moved up three positions to number 5 in Asia Pacific
GigaOm published their analysis of edge infrastructure capabilities in July
Digital Realty was ranked as an industry leader across multiple criteria in three broad categories
Our capabilities were rated highest in vendor positioning and evaluation metrics comparison and second in key criteria comparison
Given the resilience of the demand drivers underpinning our business and the relevance of our platform in meeting customer needs, we believe we are well-positioned to continue delivering sustainable growth for customers, shareholders, and employees, regardless of future macroeconomic conditions
Let's review our leasing activity on Page 7
We signed total bookings of $113 million in the second quarter, including a $13 million contribution from interconnection
Network and enterprise-oriented deals of 1 megawatt or less reached a record high of $41 million, demonstrating our consistent momentum and the growing success of PlatformDIGITAL as we continue to capture a larger share of enterprise demand
The average lease term was over eight years
We acquired 109 new customers during the second quarter, with strong performance across all regions, further demonstrating the strength of our global platform
The geographic and product mix of our new activity was well-balanced, with APAC and EMEA each contributing about 20%, the Americas representing nearly 50%, and interconnection responsible for just over 10%
The megawatt or less plus interconnection category accounted for almost half of our total bookings, with particular strength in the cloud, content, and financial services sectors
Regarding specific wins during the quarter and around the world, we secured a top five cloud service provider to anchor our new Tokyo campus
Shortly after this significant customer deployment, Japan's most popular social media application chose PlatformDIGITAL on the same campus
NAVER, the leading Korea-based cloud provider serving the greater APAC region, selected our new carrier-neutral facility in Singapore to support data-intensive workloads for their high-performance computing and AI-intensive technology-based platform
A European broadcaster is using PlatformDIGITAL in Vienna and Frankfurt to restructure their network, focusing on data-intensive interconnection with benefits in performance, scalability, and cost savings
A Global 2000 enterprise data platform is adopting PlatformDIGITAL in Amsterdam, Dublin, and Frankfurt to manage workloads across hundreds of ecosystem applications, delivering improved performance, security, cost savings, and simplicity
In London, PlatformDIGITAL is supporting a top three global money center bank's efforts to strengthen their business continuity capabilities without compromising their data-intensive interconnection requirements
On the continent, our connectivity and operational capabilities are helping two independent fintech customers improve performance and enhance access to their connected data communities
Finally, in North America, a life sciences digital marketing firm chose PlatformDIGITAL to improve their network architecture and enable future growth
Let's examine the details on Page 9 of our backlog report.
The current backlog of signed but not yet started leases decreased slightly from $307 million to $303 million, as lease commencements slightly exceeded new space and power lease signings this quarter.
The time between lease signing and commencement was slightly longer than our typical average, at just over seven months.
Let's now look at renewal leasing activity on Page 10.
We renewed $178 million worth of leases in the second quarter, in addition to signing new leases.
The average lease term for renewals signed in Q2 was just under 3 years, reflecting more enterprise deals under 1 megawatt.
We kept 77% of expiring leases, with slightly positive cash releasing spreads on renewals, also indicating more sub-1 megawatt renewals overall.
Regarding Q2 operating performance, overall portfolio occupancy decreased by 0.6% as we introduced new capacity across six metro areas during the quarter.
Same capital cash NOI growth was -1.5% in Q2, mainly due to the churn in Ashburn at the year's start.
Note that the Westin Building in Seattle, Interxion platform in EMEA, Lamda Helix in Greece, and Altus IT in Croatia are not yet in the same-store pool, making these comparisons less representative of our current business than usual.
Let's review our economic risk mitigation strategies on Page 11.
The U.S. dollar fluctuated in Q2 but remained lower than last year's average, providing a slight FX benefit.
We manage currency risk by issuing debt in local currencies as a natural hedge, so only our net assets in each region are exposed to currency risk economically.
Besides managing credit and foreign currency exposure, we also mitigate interest rate risk by converting short-term variable rate debt into longer-term fixed rate financing.
Given our strategy of matching long-lived assets with long-term fixed-rate debt, a 1% change in benchmark rates would impact full year FFO per share by about 0.75%.
Regarding earnings growth, Q2 core FFO per share was unchanged year-over-year but decreased 8% from last quarter due to a $0.12 non-cash deferred tax charge related to the UK's higher corporate tax rate, effective in Q2.
Excluding this unexpected tax charge, we exceeded our internal forecast due to better-than-expected top-line performance, slight FX benefits, and operating expense savings, partly due to reduced property-level spending during the COVID-19 pandemic.
We are increasing our full-year projections for total revenue and adjusted EBITDA for the second time this year, reflecting our business's underlying momentum.
The deferred tax charge impacts core FFO per share but not AFFO, as it's non-cash.
Most guidance factors remain unchanged, but we're reducing our expected recurring CapEx spend for the rest of the year, setting the stage for accelerated cash flow growth.
The bridge chart on Page 12 shows we expect our bottom-line results to improve sequentially for the rest of the year as the deferred tax charge is removed from the quarterly run rate and our underlying business momentum continues to accelerate.
We still anticipate some normalization in our cost structure, with increased property-level operating expenses that were postponed due to COVID, and higher G&A expenses as we return to the office and resume normal travel. Your model should account for these increased costs.
Finally, let's examine the balance sheet on Page 13.
We completed the sale of non-core assets in Europe for $680 million late in Q1, which reduced Q2 adjusted EBITDA by about $10 million.
Consequently, net debt to adjusted EBITDA was slightly elevated at 6x at Q2's end but is expected to return to our long-term range over the year through asset sale proceeds and cash flow growth as signed leases commence.
Fixed charge coverage decreased slightly, also reflecting the short-term impact of asset sales, but remains well above our target and near an all-time high at 5.4x, demonstrating the success of our proactive liability management.
We continue to implement our financial strategy of maximizing available capital options while minimizing costs and extending liability duration to match our long-lived assets.
In mid-May, we redeemed $200 million of preferred stock at 6.625%, bringing total preferred equity redemptions over the past 12 months to $700 million at an average coupon of just over 6.25%, effectively reducing leverage by 0.3 turns.
We issued 0.5 million shares through our ATM program in mid-June, raising about $77 million.
In early July, we raised an additional $26 million by selling our remaining Megaport stock.
We also entered the Swiss bond market in early July, raising approximately $595 million through a dual tranche offering of Swiss green bonds with an average maturity of over 6.5 years and an average coupon of about 0.37%.
This successful execution of our financial strategy showcases the strength of our global platform, which provides access to a wide range of public and private capital, distinguishes us from competitors, and allows us to prudently fund our growth.
As shown on Page 13, our average debt maturity is nearly 6.5 years, and our average coupon has decreased to 2.2%.
Less than half of our debt is U.S. dollar-denominated, reflecting our global platform's growth and serving as a natural FX hedge for investments outside the U.S. 90% of our debt is fixed rate to protect against rising rates, and 98% is unsecured, offering maximum flexibility for capital recycling.
Lastly, as seen on the left side of Page 13, we have a clear runway with minimal near-term debt maturities and manageable amounts in future years.
Our balance sheet is prepared to withstand challenges and poised to support growth opportunities for our customers worldwide, in line with our long-term financing strategy.
Andrew, please begin the Q&A session.
Summary:
output: q2 revenue rose 10 percent to $1.1 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Joining me today are Jenna Foger, Peter Moglia, Steve Richardson, and Dean Shigenaga.
As Michael Jordan stated, some individuals desire things to occur, some hope for them to happen, while others make them a reality.
Alexandria turns ideas into reality.
Let's briefly discuss key aspects of the second quarter: unprecedented demand for Alexandria's laboratory spaces and the crucial lab operations that accompany them.
Alexandria is leading the charge in meeting the historic and unparalleled demand from many of our over 750 tenants for current growth needs and critically important future expansion.
The fundamental drivers of demand are stronger than ever before.
Rent increases continue unabated, with no excess supply currently visible.
We're proud of our nearly 7% quarter-over-quarter FFO growth per share, over 40% rental rate increase, almost 18% NOI growth, nearly 8% same-store NOI growth, and an annual NOI run rate exceeding $1.3 billion, not to mention about $545 million in additional revenue from our development and redevelopment pipeline.
Alexandria clearly has a demonstrable pricing advantage in each of our cluster markets.
When life science tenants make a choice, they typically prefer Alexandria's lab spaces and our operational excellence based on our critical lab operations.
Nature Biotechnology magazine wrote in April: 2020 was a year of broken records.
Biotech played a crucial role, and the pandemic attracted a flood of private and public investors.
The pandemic seemingly reinforced the need for long-term, value-focused investors of all types to have exposure to life sciences.
Life science demand has indeed reached an all-time high as the world has recognized the importance of next-generation therapies in addressing current and future complex healthcare challenges.
Jenna will elaborate on this further.
I'll highlight a couple of points for now.
The pandemic has emphasized the importance of supporting the National Institutes of Health and investing in basic science, which are crucial for maintaining U.S. leadership in life sciences and maximizing national preparedness for current and future health challenges.
There's currently a proposal to increase the fiscal year '22 NIH budget to $51 billion, nearly a 20% increase from fiscal year '21.
The FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research (CDER) approved 23 new molecular entities in the first half of 2021, putting it on track to surpass 2020's near-record high of 53 approvals.
Following a historic 2020, venture capital in Life Sciences continues at a robust pace, with almost $36 billion raised in the first half of 2021, on track to exceed 2020's all-time high of $46 billion.
This unprecedented level is likely to persist throughout the year due to substantial available funds for life science investments and increased participation from institutional, generalist, and traditional life science investors.
Following a record-breaking 2020 for IPOs and follow-on offerings, the first half of this year has continued to set new highs, with over $8 billion raised in 52 IPOs and over $17 billion raised in numerous follow-ons, positioning 2021 to be a record-breaking year for public market investment in life sciences.
R&D has continued with remarkable productivity and resilience through COVID, enabling the industry to swiftly deliver novel vaccines and therapies to combat the global pandemic.
New biology, drug discovery platforms, and increasing focus on complex medicines as the future of therapeutic innovation have all demonstrated the life science industry's ability to effectively address current and future healthcare challenges and provide strong returns to investors.
A final note would be that, similar to how Project Warp Speed brought together a historic public-private partnership between the government and private biotech and pharmaceutical companies to rapidly research, develop, and commercialize COVID vaccines in record time, as well as ensure timely manufacturing and supply, we truly need a 21st-century infrastructure package, not the 20th-century package currently being debated in Congress.
We need to make the U.S. self-sufficient in semiconductor production, as we currently only produce about 11% to 13%, and self-sufficient in next-generation manufacturing of complex medicines.
As Joel highlighted last quarter and continues to be reinforced by the fundamentals he just shared, there's a significant paradox in this pandemic moment for the life science industry.
Despite the challenges of recent months, COVID has illuminated the power of science and the industry's ability to transform the future of human health.
Not only have many of our tenants in the industry, as Joel mentioned, risen to the challenge of combating global pandemics, but R&D and bioinnovation have generally persisted with remarkable productivity, resilience, and advancements throughout this period.
We cannot stress enough how crucial it is for us to preserve, prioritize, and continue to catalyze this groundbreaking innovation that has and will continue to save countless lives.
Turning to a COVID-specific update for a moment.
A total of 3.7 billion vaccine doses have been administered worldwide, with nearly 10% of these doses in the U.S. alone.
Approximately 57.5% of the vaccine-eligible population in our country (those 12 and over) have been fully vaccinated with either Pfizer or Moderna's 2-shot mRNA-based vaccine or Johnson & Johnson's single shot.
This represents just over 49% of the total U.S. population, and we hope this number of fully vaccinated individuals will continue to rise steadily.
These figures are astounding.
Before we discuss where we are now, I want to emphasize that despite the COVID fatigue we all continue to feel, even with some relief from easing restrictions over the past few months (albeit with the likely return of some new ones), none of our progress in the recovery process should be taken for granted.
The fact that the biopharma industry, spearheaded by many of our tenants, was equipped with the knowledge, resources, and technology to create safe and effective vaccines to combat a novel viral pathogen would have been unimaginable just a few decades ago.
The fact that our tenants Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson were able to develop, conduct robust clinical trials, manufacture, and distribute billions of vaccines at scale in less than 12 months is truly unprecedented.
These vaccines achieved astounding safety and efficacy rates in the 90-plus percent range when the FDA had set the original bar at 50%, with an amazingly low incidence of side effects reported from the millions of people who have now received them.
The collaboration between the biopharma industry, government, and many other public and private agencies to ensure all of this transpired at a pace and level sufficient to provide adequate vaccine supply to inoculate the entire U.S. population, unlike most nations around the world, should not be undervalued.
The tireless efforts of the FDA in reviewing thousands of COVID-19-related applications to maximize the availability of high-quality testing and safe and effective vaccines and therapies against COVID-19 cannot go unrecognized.
So where are we now?
It's been just over 18 months since the first U.S. COVID case was reported on January 21, 2020.
Yet despite all of the progress with vaccines, countries around the world are still very much combating new COVID-19 surges, driven most recently in part by the increasing prevalence of the so-called Delta variant.
In the U.S., this highly contagious Delta variant, approximately 50% more transmissible with 1,000 times higher viral load, accounts for at least 83% of COVID cases.
Average daily confirmed COVID case counts now exceed 50,000, which is five times that of the mid-June lows, with hospitalizations and deaths rising as well.
However, as worrying as this trend may seem, breakthrough infections (those occurring in vaccinated people) are still relatively uncommon.
The vast majority of these breakthrough cases have not caused serious illness, hospitalization, or death.
More than 95% of people hospitalized for COVID-19 are unvaccinated, and the vaccines still remain effective even against the Delta variant.
While they may not entirely prevent transmission, they do seem almost entirely able to prevent severe disease and death.
Regarding vaccine safety, there have been very few adverse events reported overall (less than seven per million), with nearly all cases resolving without long-term side effects.
As such, the strong safety and efficacy profile will likely lead to full FDA approval for mRNA-based vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna this fall.
Regarding pregnancy and women of childbearing age, though data is more limited, based on the safety data generated to date and our understanding of how vaccines work in the body, the CDC encourages pregnant women to get vaccinated, especially given that pregnant and recently pregnant women are at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19.
Regarding children, Pfizer has an emergency use authorization for children over 12, and the FDA is urging Pfizer and Moderna to expand their studies in children aged five to 11.
Looking ahead, the evolving data on the duration of immunity and COVID-19 variants of concern suggests that COVID-19 and the need for vaccines and boosters will likely persist long-term.
However, the faster we can vaccinate the population in this country and increase access to vaccines in the rest of the world, the more effectively we can slow the emergence of new variants and the sooner we can turn this virus into a less deadly pathogen, even if still contagious.
Given that COVID will likely remain on the planet for the foreseeable future, therapies will continue to be important in mitigating the severity of COVID-19, such as the recently authorized antibody treatments from our tenants Bayer and GSK.
Equally important is continued COVID testing, both for active virus in symptomatic individuals and surveillance testing across the population to detect new outbreaks, sequence emerging variants, and track overall transmission.
Lastly, I want to address the FDA, which has received somewhat relentless criticism over the past several months despite their herculean COVID efforts while maintaining a near all-time record high pace of new drug approvals, as Joel highlighted.
This criticism has been mounting due to several factors, including the lack of a fully appointed FDA commissioner, the growing backlog of review requirements for new investigational drug applications given the strong pace of innovation in our industry, the lack of fully approved vaccines despite their authorization under the emergency use authorization pathway, and most recently, the historic and highly controversial approval of Biogen's Aduhelm to treat Alzheimer's disease.
This marked the first approval for this chronic neurodegenerative condition in almost 20 years, impacting over 6 million individuals in the United States alone.
The FDA's unwavering dedication during the COVID-19 pandemic to expedite the evaluation of numerous COVID-related applications for tests, treatments, and vaccines was crucial in keeping the nation from falling behind, despite the record number of industry submissions.
This achievement is remarkable and deserves the highest praise.
The FDA plays a vital role in guaranteeing the safety of all pharmaceuticals available in the U.S. while striking a balance between effectiveness and timeliness.
The upcoming leadership and productivity of the agency, to be revealed by November this year, is of paramount importance to everyone.
The FDA is essential for maintaining the momentum and vigor of biomedical innovation in our nation.
The biopharmaceutical industry is emerging from the COVID-19 crisis into a new era of unprecedented biotechnological and scientific advancement.
The global community now recognizes the value of this sector and the potential of cutting-edge medicines, as demonstrated by Moderna and Pfizer's innovative vaccines addressing current and future health challenges.
Undoubtedly, the contradictory nature of this pandemic has reaffirmed Alexandria's commitment to dedicating our business, enthusiasm, and purpose to propelling this crucial industry forward.
I'd like to provide some historical context for the growing demand, which has resulted in rapid leasing of Alexandria's large-scale campuses.
At Alexandria's Investor Day in December 2017, we presented an ambitious plan to nearly double the company's yearly rental income from just over $800 million to $1.5 billion by the end of 2022.
We are happy to report that our annualized revenues for Q2 2021 have already surpassed $1.5 billion.
The Alexandria team has achieved this lofty goal more than a year ahead of schedule.
The company has also expanded its essential operating asset base and development pipeline from 29 million square feet at the end of 2017 to 62 million square feet by the end of Q2 2021.
This represents remarkable growth, more than doubling the company's footprint, and importantly, concentrated in our core areas with disciplined execution, ensuring the continuation of high-quality cash flows.
When questioned in 2020 about whether the robust leasing activity for Alexandria's large campus platform was perhaps a temporary spike driven by COVID-19, the second quarter of this year's leasing volume of over 1.9 million square feet - the highest quarterly leasing volume in company history - further demonstrates the company's unique position as a trusted partner to the expanding life science industry, providing a lasting and sustainable competitive edge in the market.
I'll review some exceptional highlights, including leasing performance.
As mentioned, the 1.9 million square feet leased represents the highest quarterly leasing activity in the company's 27-year history.
Page two of the supplemental indicates that the 3.4 million square feet under construction is 80% leased, and the additional 3.6 million square feet expected to begin construction in 2021-2022 is 89% leased or in negotiations.
This strong leasing and our growth pipeline provide excellent clarity, and these projects will generate additional revenues exceeding $545 million.
We also have outstanding core results.
This quarter saw cash increases of 25.4% and GAAP increases of 42.4%.
Occupancy remained solid at 94.3% in the operating portfolio, which would have been 98.1% if not for the 1.4 million square feet of vacancy in recently acquired properties, which offer potential near-term incremental annual rental revenues surpassing $55 million.
Regarding market health, demand continues to accelerate for Alexandria's branded and highly desirable large campuses, while supply remains constrained across all our markets in 2021, with no disruptive large-scale projects expected to be completed in 2022-2023.
We're closely monitoring Greater Boston's ground-up pipeline, which is 56% leased.
In the San Francisco area, we're tracking leasing activity at two or three ground-up lab projects.
As previously noted, there have been no significant lab sublease spaces put on the market for several quarters.
In conclusion, the first half of 2021 continues Alexandria's strong performance, and our focus on operational excellence has positioned the company well to enhance its industry-leading brand.
I will now provide updates on our development pipeline and construction cost trends, comment on recent asset sales, and report on some transactions that indicate the private market's continued strong appetite for life science assets.
As Steve and Joel mentioned, we're experiencing unprecedented demand and have responded by implementing our unique life science strategy at an accelerated pace, expanding our collaborative campuses and asset base in each of our cluster markets.
A significant indicator of the life science industry's health is our substantial expansion in almost all our markets.
In many of our submarkets, the supply-demand imbalance has been exacerbated by a lack of near-term expansion opportunities, leading Alexandria to push the boundaries of those markets.
Examples include successful ventures into Watertown and Seaport in Greater Boston, new large campuses in Sorrento Mesa, expansion of San Diego's Science sector to the north and east, and a highly successful large campus underway in San Carlos.
This high demand, combined with our experienced development teams, resulted in another productive quarter for Alexandria.
In Q2, we delivered 755,565 square feet across five assets in South San Francisco, San Carlos, Long Island City, San Diego, and the Research Triangle.
This is twice what we delivered in Q1, and these deliveries will generate over $31 million in annual rental revenue over the next year.
Additionally, this unprecedented demand has led to improved quarter-over-quarter leasing numbers and leases under negotiation, despite adding two new assets with minimal marketing time.
Notable assets contributing to this outcome include 840 Winter Street in Waltham, Massachusetts, showcasing our ability to meet demand for next-gen manufacturing facilities; 3160 Porter Drive in Palo Alto, a joint effort with Stanford to commercialize the University's most innovative science; and 5505 Morehouse in Sorrento Mesa, benefiting from Alexandria's placemaking expertise and strong demand drivers in San Diego.
We expect to commence construction on another 3.6 million square feet across 19 properties this year and next, which are already 89% leased or under negotiation.
These properties will collectively add approximately $545 million in annual rental revenue once fully delivered.
Construction costs remain elevated, with some trades and commodities holding steady while others continue at unexplainable and unprecedented levels.
Lumber prices have shown positive trends, potentially foreshadowing what may happen with other commodities.
A year ago, lumber was $500 per thousand board feet, about $100 above its historical norm.
It peaked at $1,700 in early May but has since dropped to $600 and continues to decline.
This drop resulted from many residential projects being put on hold due to high lumber prices, allowing mills to catch up and stabilize pricing.
A similar correction due to decreased demand is expected to eventually normalize all construction commodities.
Copper prices have shown signs of dropping but remain twice their historical norms.
Alternatives like aluminum are being considered to alleviate pricing pressures, and widespread adoption could lead to price stabilization.
Despite promising news with lumber and copper, rolled steel remains volatile with no signs of stabilizing.
Rolled steel is used in metal decks, studs, and ductwork, significantly impacting multilevel buildings with large HVAC needs, such as lab buildings.
We must maintain high-end cost escalation assumptions despite the noted drop in some commodities.
The reported reason is both a commodity and labor issue at shops that create products from raw materials.
COVID-19 caused many to shut down, and when demand exploded, shops struggled to bring back labor.
Attempts to solve this by scheduling longer shifts were hampered by insufficient rolled steel supplies, keeping prices high, with metal studs up 75% since January.
We assure you that we're closely monitoring commodities and developing strategies to counter these increases.
By employing prudent underwriting practices, we will maintain our track record of delivering projects punctually and within budget.
I'll finish by discussing our recent sales and mentioning a few recently announced comparables.
While I previously mentioned our record-breaking 4% cap rate at 213 East, I'd like to add that we also achieved an impressive 9.6% unlevered IRR and a 56% value creation margin, calculated by dividing our gain by gross book value.
We attained a remarkable 12% unlevered IRR and 61% value creation margin on this sale, showcasing the high-quality assets we've developed and continue to develop in Seattle and other locations.
Apart from the Alexandria transactions, there are a couple of noteworthy deals in our submarkets that demonstrate the high value private investors are placing on life science properties currently.
In Sorrento Mesa, a property called The Canyons, comprising just over one-third lab and manufacturing space with the rest being office, sold at a 4.48% cap rate and $575 per square foot.
The cash flow comes from a credit-worthy tenant with no immediate upside potential, indicating the yield a private investor was willing to accept in a submarket that would have commanded a cap rate above 6% not long ago.
Similarly, another comparable comes from Rockville, Maryland, which some analysts recently considered a 7% cap rate submarket.
A U.S. insurance company purchased 9615 Medical Center Drive in the Shady Grove submarket, adjacent to several Alexandria properties, for a 5.18% cap rate and $610 per square foot.
The property is a leasehold interest subject to a long-term ground lease owned by Alexandria.
With that, I'll hand it over to Dean.
We reported outstanding operational and financial results for the first half of 2021 and provided a robust outlook for the rest of the year.
Second quarter revenue and net operating income increased by 16.6% and 16.8% respectively compared to the same period in 2020.
Second quarter NOI rose 6.9% compared to the first quarter of 2021.
Venture investment gains included in FFO per share totaled $25.5 million for the second quarter, consistent with the first quarter of 2021.
Looking at the past two quarters, we raised our FFO per share outlook by $0.03 when reporting first quarter results.
During the second quarter, we further increased our FFO per share outlook by $0.02.
This $0.02 increase was announced in a Form 8-K filing on June 14, when we had clear visibility into the strong core results for the quarter.
Same-property NOI growth in the first half of 2021 benefited from our high-quality tenant base, with 53% of annual rental revenue coming from investment-grade rated or large-cap publicly traded companies.
Same-property NOI growth for the first half of 2021 was robust at 4.4% and 7.4% on a cash basis.
Strong rental rate growth on lease renewals and releasing of space was the primary factor in improving our 2021 same-property net operating growth outlook to 2% to 4% and 4.7% to 6.7%, increases of 30 and 40 basis points respectively.
While our 2021 acquisitions have primarily been driven by tenant demand for current and future development and redevelopment projects, some acquisitions included operating properties with potential for growth through vacancy lease-up.
These operating properties contributed to NOI growth in the first half of 2021.
It's worth noting that leasing up 1.4 million rental square feet of vacancy at these properties will generate over $55 million in additional annual rental revenue.
Our reported occupancy as of June 30 was 94.3%, or 98.1% excluding vacancy from recently acquired properties.
Importantly, disregarding recently acquired properties, our occupancy is set to improve by 100 basis points in 2021.
We believe it's crucial to highlight the strategic advantages of having a team with extensive experience in designing, constructing, and operating sophisticated laboratory office buildings, as well as long-standing partnerships with innovative tenants.
As mentioned earlier, we have one of the highest credit-quality tenant rosters in the REIT industry.
We boast one of the highest adjusted EBITDA margins in the REIT industry at 69%.
We reported our lowest accounts receivable balance since 2012 at $6.7 million, which is remarkable considering our total market capitalization exceeded $26 billion as of June 30.
We continue to report consistently high collections, with 99.4% for July.
We achieved record leasing activity with over 3.6 million rentable square feet executed in the first half of this year.
This pace significantly surpasses the strong leasing volume of 2020 and is on track for exceptional rental rate growth ranging from 31% to 34% and 18% to 21% on lease renewals and releasing of space, with the latter figures on a cash basis.
As a trusted partner with access to over 750 tenants in our portfolio, we are well-positioned to capture the substantial demand from our tenant roster and life science industry relationships.
We have an exciting pipeline of projects under construction, totaling 3.4 million rentable square feet, 80% of which is leased or in negotiations.
Near-term project starts, 89% leased or under negotiations, total 3.7 million square feet.
Combined, these projects amount to about 6.9 million square feet, 90% of which is related to space requirements from existing relationships.
These projects will generate an impressive increment in annual rental revenue exceeding $545 million, a 34% increase above the annualized second quarter rental revenues of $1.6 billion.
Importantly, we also anticipate starting additional projects between now and December 2022.
Our venture investments portfolio continues to demonstrate our science and technology team's exceptional talent for underwriting high-quality innovative entities.
As of June 30, unrealized gains were $962 million on an adjusted cost basis of $990 million.
Realized gains on our venture investments for the second quarter were $60.2 million, including $34.8 million excluded from FFO per share.
For the first half of 2021, we realized gains totaling about $57.7 million related to significant gains in three investments that were excluded from FFO per share as adjusted.
We're pleased that the venture investment program is generating capital exceeding our initial 2021 forecast, potentially reaching over $100 million for the entire year.
Turning to our robust and flexible balance sheet that supports our strategic growth initiatives.
We continue to maintain one of the strongest balance sheets in the REIT industry, providing access to attractive long-term capital costs.
We remain on track to achieve a net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio of 5.2 times by year-end.
Our fixed charge coverage ratio for the fourth quarter has increased to over five times.
We maintain significant liquidity of $4.5 billion as of June 30.
We're in a solid position regarding debt maturities, with our next maturity of only $184 million due in 2024.
While it's difficult to predict when property owners will decide to sell, two to three transactions accounted for about half of our 2021 acquisition target.
For the remainder of the year, we aim to be highly selective with acquisitions.
Our team is advancing several important dispositions, primarily focused on partial interest sales in high-value, low cap rate properties for reinvestment into our strategic value creation development and redevelopment projects.
To date in 2021, we have completed $580 million in dispositions at cap rates between 4% and 4.2%.
We have about $1.4 billion in process at various stages and expect to pursue additional dispositions that will exceed the top end of our current range of $2.2 billion.
We are targeting approximately $1 billion in dispositions to close in the third quarter and the remainder in the fourth quarter.
Importantly, each of these pending transactions will continue to highlight the tremendous value we have created and continue to create for our stakeholders.
This guidance updates our previous guidance for the year disclosed in our Form 8-K dated June 14.
We narrowed the guidance range from $0.10 to $0.08 for both earnings per share and FFO per share.
EPS was updated to a range of $3.46 to $3.54, and FFO per share as adjusted was updated to a range of $7.71 to $7.79, maintaining the midpoint of $7.75 for FFO per share diluted as adjusted.
As a reminder, since our initial FFO per share guidance for 2021, we have increased the midpoint of our guidance by $0.05, representing a 6.1% increase over 2020.
I'd also like to express our team's gratitude for the continued recognition by an independent panel of judges for a sixth NAREIT Gold Award for Communication and Reporting Excellence to the investment community.
Operator, we can now proceed to questions.
Summary:
output: sees 2021 funds from operations per share, as adjusted $7.71 to $7.79.
