input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations are founded on our current perspective and understanding.
Future outcomes may vary significantly due to potential risks and uncertainties.
Some of the information presented today includes non-GAAP financial metrics.
These alternative financial measures should be considered in conjunction with, not as a substitute for, our GAAP results.
Tom will offer insights on our performance and provide an overview of the current operational landscape.
Bernadette will subsequently present details of our Q2 results and revised fiscal 2022 projections.
We're satisfied with the enhancements in our production and supply chain operations, as well as the progress in our financial performance this quarter, and I'm impressed by how the Lamb Weston team has managed this challenging economic environment.
We achieved strong sales, and robust demand across our food service channels drove volume growth, while our recent pricing strategies began to counteract inflationary pressures.
Furthermore, our efforts to stabilize our manufacturing operations are progressing well, including increasing staff in our processing facilities to enhance production rates and output.
Collectively, our sales and operational momentum led to sequential gross margin improvement in the quarter, positioning us well to manage the upcoming cost pressures from this year's exceptionally poor potato harvest in the Pacific Northwest.
Although our operations and financial results haven't yet reached our desired levels, we're on track to meet our financial goals for the year, and our investments in capacity and productivity will position us well for higher margins and sustainable long-term growth.
Before Bernadette delves into the specifics of our second quarter results and outlook, let's briefly review the current operational landscape, starting with demand.
In the United States, overall french fry demand and restaurant traffic remained strong during the quarter, particularly at quick-service restaurants where demand has consistently exceeded pre-pandemic levels.
Full-service restaurant traffic was also robust during the quarter but remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Recently, restaurant traffic has declined as the spread of COVID variants has reduced consumer interest in on-site dining and as restaurants have temporarily closed due to staff shortages.
While we expect this COVID wave will continue to dampen demand for on-site dining in the near future, we don't anticipate it will significantly affect traffic or demand at quick-service restaurants.
Demand at non-commercial outlets also improved during the quarter but remained below pre-pandemic levels.
As with on-site dining, we expect the spread of COVID variants will impact near-term demand.
The french fry attachment rate in the U.S., which measures how often consumers order fries when visiting restaurants or other food service outlets, continues to exceed pre-pandemic levels.
This supported our out-of-home fry demand during the quarter.
The increase in the fry attachment rate has been consistent since the pandemic began, and we don't foresee this changing in the near future.
French fry demand in U.S. retail channels during the quarter was up by mid-teens compared to pre-pandemic levels, and we expect it to remain strong in the near term as the pandemic continues to affect demand in out-of-home channels.
Outside the U.S., demand in Asia and Oceania has been strong, although a shortage of shipping containers and disruptions to ocean freight networks continue to hinder our ability to fully serve customers in these markets.
Demand in Europe, which is served by our Lamb Weston/Meijer joint venture, has also been strong, although consumer reactions and the impact of recently imposed government lockdowns may reverse some of the recovery in restaurant traffic and fry demand in the near term.
Overall, we're encouraged by the resilience of demand and long-term trends for the category, but we anticipate some near-term softness due to another COVID wave in the U.S. and our key international markets.
Regarding pricing, we're making good progress in implementing recent pricing actions to manage input cost inflation.
In the second quarter, we began to see the initial benefits of price increases that took effect in the summer in our foodservice and retail segments, as well as in some of our international businesses.
We expect the benefit of these price increases to grow as the year progresses.
In December, we began implementing another round of pricing actions in our foodservice and retail segments.
While these actions didn't affect our second quarter results, we'll see a gradual benefit from them over the next six months.
In our global segment, we saw some benefit from pricing actions in the second quarter but expect to see a greater impact during the latter half of the year.
This reflects price increases related to contract renewals as well as the benefit of price escalators for most of the global contracts that aren't up for renewal this year.
We expect these price increases across our business segments will collectively mitigate much, but not all, of our cost inflation pressures.
We'll continue to assess the pace and scope of further cost inflation and may take additional pricing actions as the year progresses.
Regarding costs, input cost inflation remains the primary driver of the increase in our cost per pound during the quarter.
Commodity and transportation costs each rose by double digits, and we expect this trend to continue through fiscal 2022, especially as our raw potato costs significantly increase in the second half of the year.
Beyond cost inflation, we're making good progress in stabilizing our supply chain to improve costs, production rates, and throughput.
We've taken steps to simplify our manufacturing processes and drive savings through a series of productivity initiatives, eliminating underperforming SKUs, and increasing potato utilization rates.
Importantly, after making changes to how we staff production crews, compensation, and other incentives, we've steadily reduced our staffing shortfall.
We're working to continue this positive trend but recognize it's challenging in a very difficult labor environment.
The impending implementation of government-mandated COVID testing and vaccine regulations may also slow our progress and that of our suppliers in attracting and retaining workers in the near term.
Regarding the crop, the yields and quality of potato crops in our primary growing regions in the Columbia Basin, Idaho, and Alberta are well below average due to extreme heat over the summer.
Similar to previous years, we had contracted with farmers to purchase potatoes to meet our production needs, assuming an average crop year.
However, due to the extreme heat, the contracted acres yielded fewer potatoes and the quality is also poor.
As a result, we're purchasing our remaining potato needs in the open market to meet our production forecast.
We were able to reduce the number of potatoes we'd otherwise have been required to purchase in the open market by successfully partnering with our customers to secure changes in product specifications.
Given that raw potato supply is tight and fry demand has largely recovered, we've been purchasing open potatoes at a premium to contracted potato prices.
When possible, we've been securing them from nearby growing regions, but we've also transported potatoes from the Midwest and Eastern North America, resulting in increased transportation costs.
We included an estimate of these additional costs in our updated earnings outlook.
We'll begin to see more of the financial impact of this year's poor crop, including the high cost of open market potatoes, in our third quarter results.
In summary, we feel positive about our financial and operational progress this quarter.
The overall demand environment is solid but may soften in the near term due to another COVID wave, and we're implementing the right pricing and operational strategies to navigate this challenging environment.
As Tom mentioned, we're happy with our quarterly performance.
We saw robust sales and solid demand across our North American restaurant and foodservice channels, increased volume, and implemented price adjustments.
We believe our pricing strategies and cost-reduction measures have positioned us well to handle the current challenging business climate and support long-term sustainable profitable growth.
In particular, our quarterly sales grew by 12% to just over $1 billion.
This marks only the fourth time in Lamb Weston's history that we've exceeded $1 billion in quarterly sales.
Our sales volumes increased by 6%.
The foodservice segment drove volume growth, reflecting the ongoing year-over-year recovery in on-premise dining and strong shipments to major chain restaurant customers in North America served by our global segment.
Our retail segment saw increased sales volumes of branded products, but overall segment volume decreased primarily due to reduced shipments of private label items.
While our overall volume growth was strong this quarter, it was hampered by industry-wide upstream and downstream supply chain issues, including delays in obtaining spare parts, edible oils, and other key materials for our factories, as well as labor shortages affecting production rates and output at our processing facilities.
In our global segment, volume growth was also limited by the scarcity of shipping containers and disruptions at ports and in ocean freight networks.
We anticipate these production and logistics challenges, along with the short-term impact of COVID variants, will restrict our volume growth at least until the end of fiscal 2022.
Our price mix rose by 6% as we realized benefits from previously announced pricing actions across all four segments.
We began implementing product pricing actions in the first quarter as the main strategy to counter inflationary cost pressures, typically taking a couple of quarters for these actions to fully materialize in the market.
We've also taken steps to more frequently adjust the freight rates we charge customers to better reflect market rates.
In the past, we only adjusted these rates once or twice annually.
The majority of the price mix increase this quarter reflects these product and freight pricing actions, with favorable mix contributing only modestly.
This quarter's gross profit decreased by $18 million as the benefit of increased sales was outweighed by higher manufacturing and transportation costs per pound.
Double-digit inflation in commodities and transportation costs accounted for nearly 90% of the cost per pound increase.
Of these two factors, commodities played a larger role, led again by edible oils, particularly canola oil, which nearly doubled compared to the same quarter last year, as well as ingredients like wheat and starches used in batter and other coatings, and containerboard and plastic film for packaging.
Freight costs increased, especially for ocean freight and trucking, as global logistics networks continued to face challenges.
Our costs also rose due to an unfavorable mix of higher-cost trucking versus rail to meet service obligations for certain customers.
As Tom noted, we also experienced higher costs per pound compared to last year due to additional expenses and inefficiencies caused by lower production rates and throughput at our factories, resulting in fewer pounds to cover fixed overhead.
Lost production days and unplanned downtimes were primarily due to labor shortages across our manufacturing network, including COVID-related absenteeism.
While the cost drivers in the first two quarters of the year have been largely consistent, we began to see initial benefits from our pricing and cost-mitigation actions discussed in our previous earnings call during the second quarter.
As a result of these efforts, our gross margin increased sequentially by 500 basis points to over 20% compared to the first quarter.
Although pricing actions provided the larger boost to the sequential improvement in gross margins, our production rates and throughput also improved, mainly due to our efforts to stabilize factory labor.
While still below average, labor retention rates showed modest improvement compared to the first quarter, and the number of new applicants has remained steady.
With increased stability, we were able to increase factory throughput.
Additionally, our portfolio optimization efforts are yielding benefits.
We've eliminated underperforming SKUs to streamline our portfolio and boost factory throughput.
We've also successfully collaborated with our major customers to secure changes in product specifications, mitigating some of the operational impact of this year's poor potato crop quality.
In summary, although our run rate and cost structure are not yet at desired levels, we're pleased with the significant sequential progress made this quarter and believe we're well-positioned to navigate the challenging near-term environment of increased costs and poor potato crop quality.
Shifting focus from cost of sales.
Our SG&A increased by $7 million this quarter, primarily due to two factors.
First, it reflects higher labor and benefit costs, as well as increased sales commissions associated with higher sales volumes.
Second, it includes a $2.5 million increase in advertising and promotional expenses as we increased support for our retail products.
While these expenses have increased compared to last year, they remain below pre-pandemic levels.
The rise in SG&A was partially offset by reduced consulting expenses related to improving our commercial and supply chain operations as those projects concluded, as well as fewer expenses in the current quarter related to the design of a new enterprise resource planning system.
We incurred approximately $2 million in ERP-related expenses this quarter, primarily consisting of consulting fees.
This is down from about $5 million in similar expenses in the same quarter last year.
We plan to resume our efforts in the second half of fiscal 2022 to design the next phase of our new ERP system.
Diluted earnings per share for the quarter were $0.22, a decrease of $0.44.
About $0.28 of this decline was related to costs associated with redeeming and writing off previously unamortized debt issuance costs for senior notes originally issued during our spin-off from ConAgra in November 2016.
We've identified these costs as items affecting comparability in our non-GAAP results.
Excluding the impact of these items, adjusted diluted earnings per share were $0.50, a decrease of $0.16 due to lower income from operations and equity method earnings.
Turning to our segments.
Our global segment's sales increased by 9% this quarter.
Price mix rose by 5%, reflecting a balance of higher freight charges, pricing actions related to customer contract renewals, and inflation-driven price escalators.
Volume increased by 4%.
The volume increase was driven by higher shipments to large chain restaurant customers in North America, while logistics constraints limited our international shipments.
Overall, the global segment's total shipments continued to exceed pre-pandemic levels.
The global segment's product contribution margin, which is gross profit minus A&P expenses, decreased by 13% to $81 million.
Higher manufacturing and distribution costs per pound outweighed the benefits of favorable price mix and increased sales volumes.
We will now discuss our foodservice segment.
Revenue grew by 30%, with volume increasing 22% and price/mix rising 8%.
The sales volume increase was driven by recovering demand from smaller restaurant chains, independent eateries, and non-commercial customers.
Price mix improvement resulted from initial product and freight pricing actions implemented earlier this fiscal year, as well as favorable mix.
Foodservice product contribution margin increased 19% to $104 million, as positive price mix and higher sales volumes outweighed increased manufacturing and distribution costs per pound.
Let's move on to our retail segment.
Price mix rose 5%, reflecting early benefits from pricing actions in our branded portfolio, higher freight charges, and improved mix.
Sales volume decreased 4% as branded product volume growth was offset by reduced private label shipments, due to losses in certain low-margin business.
Retail shipments were also affected by industry-wide supply chain constraints and production disruptions mentioned earlier.
Retail product contribution margin fell 29% to $21 million.
The decline was caused by higher manufacturing and distribution costs per pound, a $2 million increase in A&P expenses, and lower sales volumes.
Regarding our liquidity and cash flow.
Our liquidity remains strong.
At the end of the first half of fiscal 2022, we had nearly $625 million in cash and $1 billion available on our undrawn revolver.
In the first half, we generated over $205 million from operations.
This is approximately $110 million less than the same period last year, primarily due to lower earnings.
We invested almost $150 million in capital expenditures during the first half, continuing construction of our chopped and formed expansion in American Falls, Idaho and new processing lines in American Falls and China.
We're working hard to manage material, equipment, and labor availability issues to keep our capital projects on schedule.
In the first half, we returned $145 million to shareholders, including nearly $70 million in dividends and $76 million in share repurchases.
This includes $50 million of share repurchases in the second quarter alone.
We recently announced a 4% increase in our quarterly dividend rate, amounting to about $144 million annually, and a $250 million increase to our current share repurchase plan, demonstrating our confidence in the long-term potential of our business.
We now have approximately $344 million authorized for share repurchases under the updated plan.
During the quarter, we redeemed and issued nearly $1.7 billion of senior notes.
This increased our average debt maturity from four to over seven years and reduced our annual interest expense by about $8.5 million.
We remain committed to our capital allocation priorities.
Our primary focus is reinvesting in our business, both organically and through M&A.
We then aim to return free cash flow to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases over time.
Regarding our updated outlook.
We still expect our full-year sales growth in fiscal 2022 to exceed our long-term target of low to mid-single digits.
We anticipate price mix in the third quarter will increase sequentially compared to the 6% rise in the second quarter, as previously announced product pricing actions continue to take effect across our core segments.
We expect volume growth in the third quarter to slow compared to the 6% growth in the second quarter due to COVID variants impacting restaurant traffic and demand, ongoing industry supply chain constraints and labor challenges affecting production, and global logistics disruptions and container shortages impacting domestic and export shipments.
We anticipate further deceleration in the fourth quarter as we begin to compare against higher volumes from the previous year.
Regarding earnings, we continue to expect net income and adjusted EBITDA including joint ventures will face pressure throughout fiscal 2022 due to significantly higher potato costs in the second half, resulting from the poor crop, double-digit inflation for key inputs and freight, and higher SG&A expenses.
For the full year, we expect our gross margin to be 600 to 700 basis points below our pre-pandemic rate of 25% to 26%, suggesting a target range of 18% to 20%.
This is a revision from our previous outlook of 17% to 21%.
We narrowed the range for several reasons.
We're confident about the implementation of our product and freight price increases.
We expect to build on the progress made in the second quarter to stabilize our supply chain operations and achieve savings through our cost-mitigation efforts.
However, we anticipate that improvements in our operations and costs will be gradual, reflecting broader labor market challenges likely to persist through fiscal 2022.
We also have a clearer understanding of the net cost impact from this year's exceptionally poor potato crop.
We'll begin to see the full financial impact of the poor potato crop in the third quarter, continuing through most of the second quarter of fiscal 2023.
We expect SG&A expenses to increase by $100 million to $110 million in the third and fourth quarters as we begin planning the second phase of our new ERP project.
Equity earnings will likely remain under pressure due to input cost inflation and higher manufacturing costs in Europe and the U.S.
We project interest expense to be around $110 million, excluding the $53 million associated with redeeming senior notes in the second quarter.
This is lower than our previous estimate of approximately $115 million.
Our estimates for total depreciation and amortization expense of about $190 million, an effective tax rate of approximately 22%, and capital expenditures of around $450 million remain unchanged.
In summary, we're seeing the benefits of our pricing actions, which led to sequential improvements in our top line and gross margin this quarter.
Along with pricing actions, we're progressing with our cost-mitigation initiatives, positioning us to manage the impact of the poor crop.
For fiscal 2022, we continue to expect net sales growth above our long-term target of low to mid-single digits, and we've narrowed our previous target gross margin rate based on our sales and cost outlook.
To conclude, we're pleased with our progress this quarter and are taking appropriate steps in pricing and supply chain operations to navigate this challenging environment.
We're on track to meet our targets for the year and believe we'll return to pre-pandemic profit levels after the impact of the poor crop subsides in the first half of fiscal 2023.
We remain committed to investing in growth and creating long-term value for our stakeholders.
Summary:
output:
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.50.
q2 earnings per share $0.22.
q2 sales rose 12 percent to $1.007 billion.
sees fy 2022 net sales growth above long-term target range of low-to-mid single digits.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The year commenced exceptionally well, with our first-quarter consolidated net income reaching $64.4 million and earnings per share at $0.59
These figures represented increases of 93% and 90% respectively compared to the same period last year, driven by improved performance in both our utility and banking sectors
During Q1, Hawaiian Electric saw benefits from ongoing savings generated by the comprehensive cost management initiative launched last year
These savings will be reflected in customer rates starting June, and along with other timing factors, we anticipate the utility will remain within the full-year guidance range announced in February
American's Q1 performance demonstrates effective execution in a climate that remains difficult for bank profitability
Our results were enhanced by a release of provisions as we continue to prudently manage credit in Hawaii's improving economic landscape
As Greg will elaborate, we're revising our bank guidance and consolidated HEI guidance upward for the year to reflect this improvement
We're observing a strengthening local economy as Hawaii continues to effectively manage the virus and vaccine distribution progresses
Unemployment decreased to 9% in March
Though still above the national average, it's trending positively, having fallen from a peak of nearly 24% a year ago
We've witnessed substantial growth in tourism arrivals this year
Recently, we've had several days where arrivals have neared pre-pandemic levels
Currently, almost all our arrivals are from the U.S. mainland, as the COVID situation and vaccination efforts abroad have been more challenging than domestically
Hawaii's real estate fundamentals are robust and continue to support the conservative portfolio mix at the bank
From January to March, Oahu's sales volumes increased by 19% for single-family homes and 53% for condos
Median prices also rose by 17% to $950,000 for single-family homes and 4% to $450,000 for condos
In its March outlook, the University of Hawaii Economic Research Organization expedited its forecast for the state's economic recovery by 18 months, now projecting GDP growth of 3.7% in 2021 and 3.1% in 2020
Hawaii's COVID-19 cases have remained significantly lower than the mainland
As of May 6, the seven-day rolling average was 94 for the state, ranking fifth lowest per capita among U.S. states
40% of our residents are now fully vaccinated, with over half having received at least one dose
While this is promising, we're aware that we're still in the early stages of Hawaii's economic recovery, and uncertainty remains regarding the pandemic's trajectory
At the utility, our main priorities continue to be cost efficiency, transitioning to the new PBR framework, and advancing our clean energy future
We and our stakeholders are adapting to the new PBR framework, designed to align our interests as we collaborate to increase renewable energy and decarbonize our economy in an affordable, reliable, resilient, and equitable manner
Our dedication to cost efficiency positions us favorably as we transition into PBR
The utility has successfully implemented efficiencies and achieved savings to fulfill our management audit savings commitment and the customer dividend
We'll begin returning these savings to customers through the Annual Revenue Adjustment (ARA) when PBR takes effect on June 1
Cost management will remain a priority as we operate under PBR
We've been collaborating with stakeholders to finalize the new PBR performance incentive mechanisms (PIMs), as well as the scorecards and metrics we'll report on going forward
We anticipate the PUC will soon issue an order outlining the parameters of the new PIMs
As we've previously stated, achieving our shared clean energy and decarbonization goals must be done in a "kakou" manner, a Hawaiian term meaning it requires everyone working together
We're striving to bring projects from Hawaii's largest-ever renewable energy and storage procurement online as quickly as possible
We are fully committed to this endeavor, which is challenging given the number of projects, the scale of this procurement relative to our small system, community considerations, land constraints, and the need to ensure reliability on isolated island grids
We're actively collaborating with independent power producers, government agencies, and other stakeholders to overcome obstacles and expedite project completion
Last week, the PUC instructed us to establish regulatory liabilities to track costs to customers resulting from delays in commercial operations of approved Stage 1, Stage 2, and CBRE Phase 1 projects
Although we don't believe we're liable for any amount, we think the PUC's intention may be to track rather than record costs before a determination is made
Consequently, we'll be seeking reconsideration or clarification
Last week, the PUC also conditionally approved our agreement for the Kapolei Energy Storage project, a standalone battery project that will help ensure reliability when the Oahu coal plant retires and enable integration of more renewable energy
While technically an approval, the order imposes conditions that may prevent us and the developer from proceeding with this project
The regulatory process allows us to voice our concerns to the PUC, and we'll be filing a motion for reconsideration on Monday
Another key focus is accelerating the addition of more distributed energy resources (DERs) and demand response
On May 3, we submitted our recommendations to achieve this acceleration while emphasizing the importance of equity and fairness in program design
We're advancing programs to benefit all customers, including expanding our community solar program, proposing a rooftop rental program, and procuring aggregated grid services from DERs
Grid modernization is crucial for facilitating faster deployment and effective use of demand response and DERs
In March, the PUC approved our proposal to shift from an opt-in to an opt-out approach for advanced meters in targeted areas, allowing us to deploy advanced meters more rapidly and thus enabling operational efficiencies and more advanced rate programs
Regarding the bank, American continues to perform well in a challenging environment
In Q1, we maintained strong mortgage production and deployed an additional $150 million of ASB CARES or Paycheck Protection Program loans to support small businesses in round two of that program
Year-to-date, that amount has increased to over $170 million
Record deposit growth, largely driven by federal stimulus, continues to outpace lending opportunities in this early stage of Hawaii's economic recovery
We're taking a balanced approach to managing our portfolio, optimizing fee income and loan portfolio growth in a low interest rate environment
While net interest margin remains under pressure, record-low funding costs and balance sheet growth are helping increase net interest income in line with our expectations
The release of credit loss reserves in our first quarter reflects our customers' resilience and the improving credit risk environment as Hawaii's economy starts to recover.
We are maintaining a conservative approach in managing our credit loss reserves.
American has maintained its efforts to control costs, resulting in reduced noninterest expenses in Q1 while investing in our anytime, anywhere banking transition.
The bank's increased profitability is enabling a higher dividend payment to HEI.
We're speeding up our digital transformation to allow customers to bank with us at any time and place.
Currently, 44% of deposits are made through self-service channels like ATMs and mobile, which is more than twice the pre-pandemic levels.
Customer satisfaction has improved across all channels during this period.
We're upgrading our digital offerings to simplify banking for our customers.
This includes new online financial wellness tools, upgrading ATMs, improving our mobile app, expanding online services, and opening digital centers where our staff will assist customers with digital banking solutions.
Greg will now present our financial results and outlook.
Greg, please take it from here.
Let's review our first quarter results.
Consolidated earnings per share were $0.59 compared to $0.31 in the same quarter of the previous year.
Both the utility and bank showed strong performance, demonstrating the resilience of our company and Hawaii's economy, which is showing signs of strengthening recovery.
The utility's earnings reflect reduced O&M expenses due to cost-cutting efforts and delayed generation overhauls, along with increased revenues from our annual rate adjustment mechanism, including timing-related charges for target revenue recognition to eliminate seasonal impacts.
The bank benefited from releasing credit loss provisions as certain credits improved, and we observed stable credit trends amid an improving economic outlook.
While the holding company's loss aligns with expectations, we increased charitable contributions during the quarter, including a $2 million donation to support our community during challenging times.
Compared to the same period last year, consolidated trailing 12-month ROE improved by 80 basis points to 10%.
Utility ROE increased by 160 basis points to 9%, and bank ROE, which we assess on an annualized basis, was 16%.
The utility outlook remains unchanged, but ROE expectations will be affected by management audit savings and customer dividend, as O&M cost reductions that improved quarterly earnings will be used to reduce customer bills under PBR.
The utility's net income for the quarter was $43.4 million, compared to $23.9 million in Q1 2020.
The main factors contributing to the variance were $10 million lower O&M expenses compared to Q1 last year.
Three key factors led to lower O&M: reduced staffing and improved efficiency from ongoing cost management; timing-related items, including higher bad debt expense in Q1 2020 due to COVID-19, which has since been deferred; and fewer generating facility overhauls, some of which will occur later this year.
There were also higher costs in 2020 related to an increased environmental reserve and increased outside service costs for the PBR docket and other customer service projects.
In addition to lower O&M, we saw a $5 million revenue increase from higher rate adjustment mechanism revenues; a $4 million revenue increase due to timing of target revenue recognition, which will have no net impact on 2021 and is due to a change in methodology eliminating seasonality in recognizing target revenues within the year; a $1 million lower enterprise resource planning system implementation benefit to be passed on to customers; and $1 million lower nonservice pension costs due to a reset of pension costs in rates following a final rate case decision.
These were partially offset by $1 million higher depreciation.
Regarding utility performance drivers for the rest of the year, we don't expect significant contributions from performance incentive mechanisms in 2021.
We currently have about $22 million in COVID-related costs, primarily bad debt expense, accrued in a deferred regulatory asset account.
We will continue deferring COVID-related costs through June 30.
The moratorium on customer disconnections is in place until May 31, 2021, and we continue to work with customers on extended payment plans and other bill assistance options.
We plan to file a separate application for cost recovery once actual costs are known.
We will also file a request to continue deferring COVID-related costs beyond June 30.
As mentioned, our O&M expense benefited from the timing of overhauls.
We expect some of these overhauls to occur later this year, in line with our annual guidance.
The utility's ability to achieve accelerated management audit savings commitment is a key driver of O&M expenses.
The utility is on track to achieve the savings needed to meet the annual $6.6 million commitment, which will be returned to customers starting June 1.
Utility capital investments for the quarter, approximately $60 million, were lower than planned due to unexpected delays.
Some delays were caused by extended repairs at one of our substations, limiting work on other parts of the electric system.
We also experienced additional design work requirements for T&D projects, COVID travel limitations, and meter deployment delays affecting our grid modernization work.
Despite these delays, we still expect to meet our utility capital investment plan for 2021.
We are maintaining our capex and rate base growth guidance from the previous earnings call, expecting 2021 capex of about $335 million to $355 million, reflecting rate base growth of 4% to 5%.
Regarding the bank, ASB's net income for the quarter was $29.6 million, compared to $15.7 million last quarter and $15.8 million in Q1 2020.
The increase primarily reflected moderation of the elevated credit risk environment as Hawaii's economy begins to recover, and results benefited from a release of credit loss reserves, which I'll discuss further.
Net interest income reflects the impact of strong deposit growth, lower loan demand, and increased growth of our investment portfolio.
Noninterest income benefited from strong mortgage origination and sales, in line with plan despite being below the prior year's quarter.
Noninterest expense remained in line with the plan as ASB continues to focus on strategic investments to drive efficiency and productivity.
ASB's net interest margin compressed 17 basis points during the quarter.
NIM was 2.95% compared to 3.12% in Q4 2020.
The low interest rate environment and record deposit growth both contributed to NIM compression.
$3.1 million in fees from PPP lending and a record low cost of funds helped mitigate pressure on asset yields.
The mean expense of capital decreased by 0.01% from the previous quarter and 0.16% from the year before, reaching 0.08%
We anticipate ongoing challenges due to low interest rates and excess liquidity resulting from strong deposit growth and reduced reinvestment yields
As a result, we're adjusting our NIM guidance range to between 2.80% and 3%
We expect that growth in the balance sheet should still result in net interest income meeting yearly projections
In Q1, the bank reduced its provision for credit losses by $8.4 million, compared to increases of $11.3 million in Q4 and $10.4 million in Q1 of the previous year
This change reflects improvements in commercial loan credit ratings, decreased exposure to riskier but profitable consumer unsecured loans, and lower net charge-offs as Hawaii's economy begins to recover and the credit risk environment improves
ASB's net charge-off ratio for the quarter decreased to 0.18%, down from 0.36% in Q4 and 0.44% in Q1 2020
Nonaccrual loans increased slightly to 1%, up from 0.89% in Q4 and 0.90% the previous year
We maintain a cautious stance as we observe Hawaii's economic recovery
Our allowance for credit losses, at 1.73% at the end of the quarter, was the highest among our Hawaiian peers
We are observing positive trends in loan deferrals across ASB's portfolio
Almost all deferred loans have resumed regular payment schedules
Current active deferrals make up only 0.2% of the total loan portfolio
We have seen a decrease in delinquencies in the higher-risk commercial and consumer portfolios
While there has been a slight increase in delinquencies in the residential portfolio, it remains low-risk and is secured by appreciating Hawaii real estate
These factors have contributed to a reduction in the overall risk profile of our loan portfolio
ASP continues to manage liquidity and capital conservatively, maintaining sufficient liquidity and robust core capital ratios
The bank has access to approximately $4 billion in available liquidity from various reliable sources
ASB's Tier one leverage ratio of 8.33% was well above the required level for being considered well-capitalized
Looking ahead, given our portfolio's lower risk profile, we plan to manage closer to an 8% or higher Tier one leverage ratio while aiming for competitive profitability metrics, growth in ASB dividends, and maintaining a strong capital position
We anticipate higher bank dividends to HEI this year than previously indicated in our February guidance, due to ASB's strong performance, outlook, and efficient capital structure
We now project dividends of approximately $50 million to $60 million, up from the previously estimated $40 million
For the quarter, the ASB Board has approved a $23 million dividend to HEI
We do not currently anticipate the need to issue any external equity in 2021 at HEI unless we identify significant additional accretive investment opportunities
We are dedicated to maintaining an investment-grade profile
At the utility, we're pleased to report recent credit rating upgrades by S&P to BBB flat and Moody's to Baaone, both with stable outlooks
Regarding our guidance, we're reaffirming our previously issued utility guidance
Although the utility had a strong first quarter, we'll be returning cost savings to customers starting June 1 and expect additional overhauls later in the year
Additionally, while the first quarter benefited from higher revenues due to a methodology change to remove seasonality in recognizing target revenues, some of that will reverse later in the year
However, we are revising our banking consolidated guidance
Our updated guidance is $0.67 to $0.74 per share, increased from our prior guidance of $0.52 to $0.62
We're adjusting our NIM expectations at the bank to 2.8% to 3%, down from 2.90% to 3.15%
The impact on net interest income should be offset by balance sheet growth
Given improving credit dynamics and outlook for the Hawaii economy, we now expect provision to range from $0 to $10 million, which we believe remains appropriately conservative given continued uncertainty for the economy until we see increased vaccination levels and the eventual return of international travel
We anticipate that stronger bank profitability will lead to consolidated earnings growth as well as increased bank dividends to the holding company
We're raising HEI earnings per share guidance to $1.90 to $2.05 per share
I'm proud of our employees' dedication and our companies' resilience as we continue to provide essential electricity and banking services and deliver solid financial results while helping Hawaii achieve its ambitious climate goals and recover stronger
We recently published our second consolidated ESG report, which includes our ESG priorities and our first Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures-aligned reporting
We're evaluating the implications for our companies of the Biden administration's goal to reduce carbon emissions by 50% from a 2005 baseline by 2030
We believe our goals and plans in Hawaii and our ongoing efforts position us well to achieve a net-zero future
We're updating our planning and analysis, and we'll provide further updates in the future
Lastly, we bid farewell to Rich today as he departs American to pursue other opportunities
Rich achieved significant accomplishments during his more than 10 years leading American
Rich leaves American in excellent condition, as demonstrated by ASB's strong first quarter earnings and Greg's earlier comments
Under Rich's leadership, ASB has grown its assets, expanded its customer base, products and services, and improved operational efficiency
He and his team have provided excellent customer service and simplified banking for customers
Ann Teranishi, currently the bank's Executive Vice President of Operations, will succeed Rich as President and CEO later today
Ann is a strong, collaborative leader with extensive banking industry knowledge and a 14-year track record of success at American
We look forward to Ann's leadership
Summary:
output: q1 earnings per share $0.59.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Additional details can be found in our latest annual Form 10-K report, subsequent quarterly Form 10-Q reports, and other SEC filings.
I'm glad to join you today.
Labcorp continues to fulfill its mission of enhancing health and lives by utilizing scientific advancements, cutting-edge technology, and innovative approaches.
This enables us to implement our strategy, deliver robust results for stakeholders, and effectively address global issues such as the pandemic.
Our company concluded an exceptional 2021 with another impressive quarter, setting the stage for continued success in 2022 and beyond.
In Q4, we generated $4.1 billion in revenue, achieved $6.77 in adjusted earnings per share, and produced $548 million in free cash flow.
For the entire year, we recorded $16.1 billion in revenue, $28.52 in adjusted earnings per share, and $2.6 billion in free cash flow.
Our core business continued to improve during the quarter, with diagnostics and drug development revenues growing by 8.8% and 8.2% respectively.
In the diagnostics sector, core business organic volume increased as both specialized and routine procedures saw year-over-year growth.
The drug development division finished the year with a solid trailing 12-month net book-to-bill ratio of 1.25 and a robust backlog of $15 billion, representing a $579 million increase from the third quarter.
Furthermore, decentralized clinical trial awards increased by 62% compared to the previous year.
Shifting focus to the pandemic.
Our ongoing response exemplifies how innovation can drive success.
For almost two years, Labcorp has devoted substantial resources to curbing the spread of the virus.
We are proud of our accomplishments so far, although the emergence of variants like Omicron and surges in infection rates indicate that our work is not complete.
We continue to utilize Labcorp's comprehensive capabilities to expand testing access, identify and monitor new variants, and advance vaccine and treatment development.
In the fourth quarter, COVID testing volumes exceeded expectations.
To date, we have conducted over 74 million COVID tests, with approximately 8.6 million performed in the fourth quarter.
This increased demand persisted into the new year, although current volume is significantly lower than in December or January.
Even during the latest surge, COVID PCR test results were typically available within one to two days on average.
As we have done throughout the pandemic, we are maintaining high capacity levels to respond quickly to spikes in testing needs.
We continue to invest in equipment, increased staffing levels, and our supply chain.
Additionally, we remain prepared and staffed to support further drug development work for vaccines, including boosters or additional therapies.
The company's COVID-related innovations during the quarter included the introduction of observed self-collection for COVID PCR testing at over 1,000 patient service centers.
At the beginning of the fourth quarter, we announced FDA Emergency Use Authorization for a combined COVID and flu at-home collection kit.
These offerings reflect our efforts to make COVID testing faster, easier, and more accessible.
Now I'll discuss our enterprise strategy, where we made significant progress in 2021.
I'll provide a few highlights to give you an idea of our growth and forward momentum.
In oncology, we made substantial progress in strengthening our position as a leader by expanding diagnostic offerings and clinical trial opportunities.
Simultaneously, we fulfilled our commitment to improve access to cancer care.
Last year, we established our oncology business unit and introduced our enterprise oncology offering.
Genomic profiling of tumors is crucial for identifying the most effective targeted therapy for oncology patients.
In December, we announced our agreement to acquire Personal Genome Diagnostics (PGDx).
The company has a strong portfolio of innovative liquid biopsy and tissue-based products that complement our existing capabilities.
Through PGDx's kitted solutions, we can provide oncologists access to tumor profiling at the hospitals where patients are treated or centralized to one of our laboratories.
These solutions may also enable us to expand tumor profiling globally to help our pharmaceutical sponsors find the right novel treatment for patients.
We anticipate the transaction will close in the first quarter of this year.
Other exciting additions to our oncology test menu included clonoSEQ, the first and only FDA-cleared test for monitoring residual blood cancer, and OmniSeq INSIGHT, a pan-cancer tissue-based sequencing test for individuals with late-stage solid tumors.
All of these offerings can assist physicians in making more informed treatment decisions for their patients and help bring new cancer medicines to market.
In 2021, we intensified our customer focus and integrated technology and data throughout our business.
This included enhancements to the patient experience in our service centers.
These upgrades aimed to create a seamless journey from appointment scheduling to service center visits to easier access to results.
Our acquisition of Ovia Health strengthened our position as a vital source of information for women's health, which we support through diagnostic, genetic, and specialty testing expertise as well as clinical trials.
We will continue to identify opportunities to enhance Ovia Health's innovative platform that provides family planning, pregnancy, and parenting support.
Additionally, we began deploying Labcorp Diagnostic Assistant.
This new tool delivers a detailed view of a patient's lab history along with clinical insights directly to the point of care to inform diagnostic decisions.
We opened an automated kit production line in Belgium in the spring.
In the fourth quarter, we opened an integrated laboratory in Singapore, which enhances our bioanalytical services in the Asia Pacific region.
Just this month, we announced the launch of Labcorp OnDemand, which builds on the success of Pixel by Labcorp.
This suite of health tests and services offers easy and convenient access to a wide variety of trusted tests.
It's another way that Labcorp is meeting people where they are and offering more options for people to stay healthy.
Throughout the year, we pursued numerous opportunities with long-term and high-growth potential.
We accomplished this through tuck-in deals and strategic acquisitions including: OmniSeq, Ovia Health, PGDx, and Myriad Autoimmune's Vectra test, which analyzes biomarkers to measure rheumatoid arthritis.
Yesterday, we announced a comprehensive strategic agreement with Ascension, one of the largest health systems in the United States.
Through our new long-term relationship with Ascension, we will manage its hospital-based laboratories in 10 states, and we will purchase select assets of its outreach laboratory business for approximately $400 million.
The projected annual revenue for the first year from the merged hospital business and laboratory asset acquisition is anticipated to range between $550 million and $600 million.
Initially, operating margins are expected to be lower than segment margins, but they are projected to improve annually.
The deal is predicted to boost our earnings and cash flow in the first year and should recover its capital costs by the second year.
This represents a significant opportunity for us and is one of the most important transactions of its kind in the industry.
It broadens our clinical services across multiple states nationwide and builds upon our proven history of establishing similar partnerships.
The agreement with Ascension also highlights our capacity to assist health systems in navigating industry-wide changes.
As part of our collaboration, we will investigate clinical trial and oncology opportunities that improve patient access to care.
We are enthusiastic about this new partnership and look forward to welcoming new team members to Labcorp.
We have also entered into agreements with other hospitals and health systems, including North Memorial Health based in Minnesota.
We remain enthusiastic about our strong merger and acquisition pipeline and anticipate more activity in the coming months.
In 2021, we delivered top-quality service to our customers and patients, and made significant investments in our workforce.
Labcorp has consistently received recognition for the impact of our work and the value we place on our employees.
We were once again included in Fortune magazine's list of World's Most Admired Companies.
For the fifth year in a row, the Human Rights Campaign Foundation named Labcorp as the best workplace for LGBTQ+ equality.
Newsweek also recognized us as one of America's most responsible companies for 2022.
In 2021, our management and board of directors, along with external advisors, conducted a thorough review of our organizational structure and capital allocation strategy.
As part of our comprehensive structural review, we engaged in extensive discussions with third parties and considered a wide range of options, including major acquisitions, divestitures, spinning off businesses, and merging those businesses with strategic partners.
The board unanimously determined that the company's current structure best serves the interests of all stakeholders at this time.
Nevertheless, we maintain that Labcorp's shares are undervalued in the market.
To address this, we have announced several initiatives aimed at increasing shareholder value.
These initiatives include introducing a dividend starting in the second quarter of 2022 and implementing a $2.5 billion share repurchase program, with $1 billion being repurchased on an accelerated basis.
We are also launching a new LaunchPad business improvement initiative targeting $350 million in savings over the next three years.
Today, in addition to providing guidance for 2022, we will also share a longer-term outlook.
Beginning with our first quarter results, we will offer additional business insights through enhanced disclosures.
Going forward, we are dedicated to achieving profitable growth through investments in science, innovation, and new technology.
As we implement our strategy, management and the board will continue to explore all avenues for enhancing shareholder value.
In summary, our strong core business performance, combined with significant progress on our strategic priorities in 2021, positions us for long-term success.
This gives us great confidence in our longer-term, growth-oriented outlook, which Glenn will discuss along with our 2022 guidance.
I am proud of the achievements of the Labcorp team in 2021 and am excited about the future as we continue to deliver value for all our stakeholders.
I will begin my remarks by reviewing our fourth quarter results, followed by a discussion of our performance in each segment, our full-year guidance for 2022, and conclude with our longer-term outlook through 2024.
The quarter's revenue was $4.1 billion, representing a 9.7% decrease compared to the previous year due to a 10.3% decline in organic revenue and 0.1% from divestitures, partially offset by 0.6% from acquisitions and a 10 basis point favorable impact from foreign currency translation.
The 10.3% decrease in organic revenue was caused by a 15.3% reduction in COVID testing, partially mitigated by a 5% increase in the company's organic base business.
The quarter's operating income was $731 million, or 18% of revenue.
We incurred $93 million in amortization and $79 million in restructuring charges and special items during the quarter.
Excluding these items, the quarter's adjusted operating income was $902 million, or 22.2% of revenue, compared to $1.4 billion or 31.8% in the previous year.
The decrease in adjusted operating income and margin was due to reduced COVID testing.
Excluding COVID testing, the base business experienced higher adjusted operating income and margins compared to the previous year's base business, due to organic growth and LaunchPad savings, partially offset by increased personnel costs.
The quarter's tax rate was 19.3%.
The adjusted tax rate, excluding restructuring charges, special items, and amortization, was 24.6% compared to 24.8% in the previous year.
Looking ahead, we continue to expect an adjusted tax rate of approximately 25%, excluding any impact from potential tax reform.
The quarter's net earnings were $553 million, or $5.75 per diluted share.
Adjusted earnings per share, which exclude amortization, restructuring charges, and special items, were $6.77 in the quarter, down from $10.56 in the previous year.
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $698 million, compared to $775 million a year ago.
The decrease in operating cash flow was due to lower cash earnings, partially offset by favorable working capital.
Capital expenditures totaled $150 million, compared to $99 million in the previous year.
As a result, free cash flow for the quarter was $548 million, compared to $675 million in the previous year.
During the quarter, we used $1 billion of our cash flow for our accelerated share repurchase program and invested $171 million in acquisitions.
Now, I will review our segment performance, starting with diagnostics.
The quarter's revenue for diagnostics was $2.6 billion, a 16.9% decrease compared to the previous year due to a 17.8% decline in organic revenue, partially offset by 0.7% from acquisitions and a 20 basis point favorable impact from foreign currency translation.
The decrease in organic revenue was due to a 21.8% reduction in COVID testing, partially offset by a 4.1% increase in the base business.
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2019, the compound annual growth rate for base business revenue was 5%, primarily due to organic growth.
Total volume decreased by 8.7% compared to the previous year, as organic volume decreased by 8.9%, partially offset by 0.3% acquisition volume.
The decrease in organic volume was due to a 14.6% decline in COVID testing, partially offset by a 5.7% increase in the base business.
Price mix decreased by 8.2% compared to the previous year due to a 7.2% reduction in COVID testing and a 1.6% decrease in the base business, partially offset by 0.5% from acquisitions and 0.2% from currency.
Diagnostics organic base business revenue growth was 7.2% compared to its base business in the previous year, with 8.1% coming from volume, partially offset by a 1% decline in price mix.
The decrease in pricing mix was mainly attributed to the rebound of our Canadian operations, which have a lower average order price.
The adjusted operating income for diagnostics in the quarter was $776 million, representing 29.6% of revenue, compared to $1.2 billion or 39.1% in the previous year.
The reduction in adjusted operating income and margin was caused by a decrease in COVID testing.
COVID testing margins declined compared to the previous year, primarily due to a volume decrease of about 50%, while the company maintained its capacity.
Base business margins improved compared to last year, driven by organic base business growth and LaunchPad savings, partially counterbalanced by increased personnel expenses.
Diagnostics successfully achieved its target of delivering approximately $200 million in net savings from its three-year LaunchPad program.
I will now examine the performance of the drug development segment.
The quarterly revenue was $1.5 billion, a 3.9% increase from last year, due to organic base business growth of 7.9% and acquisitions of 0.3%, partially offset by a 4% decrease in COVID testing performed through its centralized business and divestitures of 0.3%.
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2019, the compound annual growth rate for base business revenue was 9.9%, mainly driven by organic growth.
The segment's adjusted operating income was $206 million, or 14.2% of revenue, compared to $248 million or 17.8% in the previous year.
The decline in adjusted operating income and margin was primarily due to reduced COVID testing.
In the base business, higher personnel and other inflationary costs, as well as investments in oncology capabilities, were partially offset by organic growth and LaunchPad savings.
We continue to exclude the enterprise component of drug development bonus expense, which is reflected in corporate unallocated and amounted to $11 million for the quarter.
Although margins decreased in the quarter, they improved for the full year compared to 2020, and we anticipate further margin increases in 2022.
For the trailing 12 months, net orders and net book-to-bill remained strong at $7.3 billion and 1.25, respectively.
The backlog at the quarter's end was $15 billion, an 8.7% increase compared to last year.
We expect approximately $5 billion of this backlog to be converted into revenue over the next 12 months.
I will now discuss our 2022 guidance, which assumes foreign exchange rates effective as of December 31, 2021, for the full year.
The guidance includes the slowdown we experienced in January due to Omicron, which we expect to recover throughout the rest of the quarter.
The enterprise guidance also incorporates the impact of currently anticipated capital allocation, with free cash flow targeted for acquisitions, share repurchases, and dividends, which we will initiate in the second quarter.
We anticipate enterprise revenue to decline between one and a half to six and a half percent compared to 2021.
This guidance range includes the expectation that the base business will grow seven and a half to 10%, while COVID testing is expected to decline 60% to 75%.
We expect diagnostics revenue to decrease between 11 and a half to 17 and a half percent compared to 2021.
This guidance range includes the expectation that the base business will grow three and a half to 6%.
COVID testing revenue is projected to decline 60% to 75%.
At the midpoint of our base business guidance range, the compound annual growth rate compared to 2019 would be 4.4%, primarily driven by organic growth in both volume and price mix.
We anticipate drug development revenue to increase 7% to 9.5% compared to 2021.
This guidance includes the negative impact of foreign currency translation of 40 basis points.
The guidance range also includes the expectation that the base business will grow seven and a half to 10% compared to 2021.
Given the available capacity in diagnostics, we've assumed that no COVID testing will be performed in the drug development central lab business in 2022.
We expect to benefit from broad-based growth across all three businesses, contributing to continued margin improvement in the segment.
At the midpoint of our base business guidance range, the compound annual growth rate compared to 2019 would be 11.3%.
Our adjusted earnings per share guidance is $17.25 to $21.25 compared to 2021 adjusted earnings per share of $28.52.
The adjusted earnings per share guidance reflects the expectation of lower COVID testing in 2022, while the base business continues to grow profitably.
Free cash flow is projected to be between $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion compared to $2.6 billion in 2021.
I will now discuss our longer-term outlook, which reflects our current view of the business from 2022 to 2024.
We expect enterprise base business organic revenue to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 4% to 7% compared to 2021.
We also anticipate revenue growth from acquisitions to represent additional annual growth of 2% to 3%.
We expect diagnostics base business organic revenue to grow at a two and a half to four and a half percent CAGR compared to 2021.
This outlook is higher than historical growth, driven by a continued recovery in our base business relative to 2021, broad-based growth including hospitals and health systems, and the lower incremental impact of PAMA in the outlook period.
We anticipate drug development base business organic revenue to grow at a 7% to 10% CAGR compared to 2021.
This outlook is higher than our historical growth, and we have added capacity and inorganic investments in the last few years in our faster-growing early development and late-stage clinical businesses.
As we continue to prioritize profitable growth, we expect enterprise margin expansion of 30 to 50 basis points on average annually through the outlook period compared to 2021, which was approximately 14 and a half percent.
This margin expansion is partly due to the company's LaunchPad initiative, which is expected to deliver $350 million of cost savings over the time period to help offset inflationary costs.
We expect adjusted earnings per share to grow at an 11% to 14% CAGR compared to 2019 adjusted earnings per share of $11.32.
We continue to use 2019 as the base year comparison for earnings growth to better reflect the earnings potential of the company excluding COVID testing.
The adjusted earnings per share outlook reflects the expectation that both base businesses will continue to grow profitably organically.
Additionally, we expect to benefit from capital allocation directed toward accretive acquisitions and share repurchases while maintaining our targeted gross debt leverage of two and a half to three times.
For additional comparison purposes, we've included in the supplemental deck on our investor relations website a view of 2021 fourth quarter and full year results, 2022 guidance, and our longer-term outlook.
In conclusion, the company delivered another quarter of strong performance.
We remain committed to playing a crucial role in response to the global pandemic while also growing our base business.
For 2022, we expect to drive continued profitable growth in our base business, while COVID testing volumes are anticipated to decline throughout the year.
Furthermore, our longer-term outlook is expected to deliver double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth driven by top-line growth, margin improvement, and capital allocation.
We will now take questions.
Summary:

q4 revenue $4.1 billion.
labcorp- full-year 2022 guidance: adjusted earnings per share of $17.25 to $21.25 and free cash flow of $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion.
labcorp - longer-term outlook (2022-2024): base business organic revenue compound annual growth of 4%-7% versus 2021.
labcorp - longer-term outlook (2022-2024) base business average annual margin expansion of 30 bps to 50 bps versus 2021.
labcorp - longer-term outlook (2022-2024) adjusted earnings per share compound annual growth of 11%-14% versus 2019.
labcorp sees fy 2022 total labcorp enterprise revenue down 6.5% to down 1.5%.
labcorp sees fy 2022 total drug development revenue up 7.0% to up 9.5%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today, you will hear prepared statements from each of them
Jim will present an overview of the financial situation and provide a strategic update, while John will give an operational summary and Devina will delve into the financial details
John will elaborate on our performance in terms of yield and volume, which generally refers to internal revenue growth or IRG from yield or volume, unless otherwise specified
During the presentation, Jim, John, and Devina will talk about operating EBITDA, which is defined as income from operations before depreciation and amortization
All comparisons will be made against the third quarter of 2020, unless stated differently
Net income, EPS, operating EBITDA and margin, operating expenses, and SG&A expense results have been adjusted to exclude certain items that management believes do not accurately reflect our core business performance or operational results, in order to improve comparability
These adjusted measures, along with free cash flow, are considered non-GAAP measures
Visit wm.com for reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measures and additional information about our use of non-GAAP measures and non-GAAP projections
The time-sensitive information provided during this call on October 26, 2021, may not be accurate at the time of a replay
Our third-quarter results showcased the exceptional cash-generating ability of our business model, as we produced nearly $1.2 billion in cash from operations
Our strong performance puts us on track to achieve the higher full-year financial outlook we provided last quarter, despite facing some of the highest inflation rates in years, along with labor and supply chain constraints
Almost every sector of the economy, including government and private businesses, has been impacted by these unprecedented inflationary and supply chain challenges
This surge in inflation intensified throughout the third quarter, during which we experienced approximately $60 million in labor inflation and about $100 million in inflation across other operating cost categories
Our overall underlying labor inflation for the third quarter was 8.7%
That's the challenging aspect
The positive aspect is that the business continues to perform well, as evidenced by our expectation to finish the year within our previously adjusted operating EBIT raise, adjusted operating EBITDA, and free cash flow guidance ranges
We anticipate exceeding our prior revenue range due to effective price execution and improving volumes
John, Devina, and I will discuss our short-term and medium-term strategies to address these labor and inflationary pressures
As expected, our disciplined pricing strategies are the primary tool to combat cost inflation
Our pricing programs achieved a core price of 4.6% and collection and disposal yield of 3.5% in the third quarter
The residential line of business continues to show outstanding performance with a yield of 5%, while MSW yield improved to 3.5%
However, it's important to note that price escalations for about 40% of our revenue are linked to an index, often based on the previous year's performance, resulting in a delay in adjusting index pricing when costs increase as rapidly as they have
It's crucial to understand that a portion of the remaining 60% of our business won't receive the full 7% to 10% price increases we believe are necessary to cover rising costs until their next price increase cycle
For example, a customer who received a 4% increase in May won't get the full cost recovery price increase until the following May
Nevertheless, we're observing a favorable pricing environment across our open market businesses, as evidenced by our lowest level of rollbacks in over a decade
We're intensely focused on directly addressing the labor challenges
John will discuss the quarterly impact and our immediate actions to address this issue
Strategically, we view this acute challenge as an opportunity to accelerate the automation of certain jobs
We've previously stated that we consider the automation of certain high-turnover positions as both a competitive advantage and a risk-mitigation strategy in today's labor market, where certain jobs no longer attract the interest they once did
Recent examples include the customer setup role, which we've just finished fully automating, and the 35-plus percent reduction in labor we've seen where we've upgraded and rebuilt our single-stream recycling plants
Given the success of these rebuilds and the recent labor inflation challenges, we've accelerated the retooling of the remaining single-stream plants and expect to address 90% of single-stream volume by the 2023-2024 timeframe
In the quarter, we observed some of the positive impacts of those new single-stream plants in our outstanding performance in our recycling business
Recycling earnings and margins reached record levels, propelled by high demand for recycled materials and excellent performance from new cutting-edge Material Recovery Facilities.
Our renewable energy division also delivered impressive results, with continued robust growth driven by increased Renewable Identification Number sales and higher pricing.
WM is ideally positioned to assist current and future clients with their evolving sustainability requirements, thanks to our extensive experience, ongoing growth in sustainability solutions, and unmatched asset network.
There is a growing demand for recycled content as our customers increasingly seek circular solutions for their materials.
We've increased the amount of plastics we recycle by 25% since 2019, due to our emphasis on extracting more plastic from the waste stream.
Our annual sustainability report, released earlier this month, highlights recycling and renewable energy as two key growth areas.
The report details WM's progress towards our sustainability goals and outlines investments made to advance our sustainability efforts.
This year's report specifically highlights the individuals behind WM's progress over the past year and their contributions to caring for customers, neighbors, the environment, and communities across North America.
The quarter's key takeaway is that we achieved higher-than-anticipated volume and revenue growth, positioning us favorably for 2022.
We successfully navigated an unexpectedly severe and rapidly evolving challenge from inflation, supply chain issues, and labor shortages, while still expecting to meet our 2021 guidance targets.
This challenge provides an opportunity to take more decisive action in strategic areas such as automation, sustainability, and workforce planning, further distinguishing ourselves in the industry.
They continue to excel, driving another quarter of double-digit growth in revenue, operating EBITDA, and free cash flow.
Despite a challenging operating environment, our team continues to perform exceptionally well, generating over 7% organic revenue growth in the collection and disposal business during the third quarter.
This growth, combined with the ongoing integration of Advanced Disposal, resulted in a more than 14% increase in operating EBITDA.
As Jim mentioned, we're experiencing pressure on labor and other cost categories, which we're addressing through pricing strategies, controllable cost management, efficiency improvements, and workforce planning.
Adjusted operating expenses as a percentage of revenue rose by 180 basis points to 62.2% in the third quarter due to inflationary costs, supply chain constraints, and stronger-than-expected volume growth.
The costs associated with hiring and training new employees particularly impacted labor expenses in the third quarter.
Overtime hours also increased as the team adjusted to meet higher-than-anticipated collection volumes.
We anticipated much of this labor pressure affecting our costs and proactively made market wage adjustments earlier in the year to address potential labor shortages and meet growing demand.
We're also working to automate various roles where we foresee long-term challenges in attracting and retaining employees.
In the residential sector, we're still working through the final 40% of our routes, including those from ADS that aren't fully automated, while remaining highly selective about the business we take on, as evidenced by our yield and volume results in the third quarter and recent years.
While we're now incurring costs related to these investments, we're only beginning to see the benefits.
The labor market and supply chain constraints intensified in Q3, coupled with robust volume growth, have also added pressure to our fleet operations.
Repair and maintenance costs are rising as we hire additional technicians and incur overtime hours to address the continued strong volume growth in our collection lines of business.
We've also had to temporarily reintroduce some of our higher-cost trucks to meet volume demands.
Additionally, our third-party subcontractors at transfer stations are facing similar pressures and passing on increased costs to us.
Overall, efficiency in the collection business improved in the third quarter when adjusting for increased training hours.
The core aspects of our business remain strong, and we're committed to recovering cost increases through pricing, removing the most expensive trucks from service, and reducing the most costly hours of the day.
I'd like to highlight several positive aspects of the quarter.
Regarding our strong revenue performance, third-quarter collection and disposal volume grew by 3.8%, surpassing our expectations.
We continue to observe strong volume driven by economic reopening, with commercial volume up 4.6% and special waste volume up by 16.6%, and we anticipate continued solid performance in the fourth quarter.
Customer metrics were also strong during the quarter.
For the second consecutive quarter, service increases surpassed service decreases by more than double, and the churn rate was 8.7%.
Net new business for small and medium-sized business customers has grown by over 10% so far this year.
The incorporation of Advanced Disposal is progressing well.
Approximately 70% of the acquired operations have been integrated into our billing and operational systems, and we expect to transfer almost all ADS customers by year-end.
We've reached $26 million in annual run rate synergies in the third quarter, bringing the total for the year to $60 million.
Including the $15 million of annual run rate synergies achieved in Q4 2020, we're on course to hit $100 million by year-end.
We anticipate capturing an additional $50 million in 2022 and 2023 through a mix of cost and capital savings.
As observed throughout the year, strong volume growth, high recycling commodity prices, and increased collection and disposal core price continued to drive top-line growth beyond expectations in Q3.
Consequently, we are updating our revenue forecast for the year once again.
The company's total revenue growth is now projected to be between 17% and 17.5%, with yield and volume in our collection and disposal business at about 6.5%.
This projection also assumes continued strength in recycled commodity prices and RIN values.
We are reaffirming our most recent 2021 adjusted operating EBITDA guidance of $5 billion to $5.1 billion, representing an increase of about 17% from the previous year at the midpoint and nearly 5% higher than our initial outlook for the year.
Q3 SG&A was 9.7% of revenue, showing a 40-basis-point improvement compared to 2020.
Our results include approximately $16 million in increased digital investments as we develop technology to enhance customer engagement and reduce our long-term cost to serve.
We continue to focus on managing our controllable spending, ensuring that we allocate funds to initiatives that will improve our business.
Q3 net cash provided by operating activities reached $1.18 billion, a 15% increase.
The growth in cash from operations continues to be driven by our substantial increase in operating EBITDA, including contributions from the ADS acquisition and lower interest costs.
Despite a slight unfavorable working capital comparison in Q3, primarily due to the timing of cash from CNG credit and our deferral of payroll taxes in 2020, overall improvements in working capital demonstrate the benefits of the tools we're implementing to enhance our systems and processes.
Capital spending in Q3 amounted to $464 million, bringing total capital expenditures for the first nine months of the year to $1.13 billion.
Our 2021 capital spending pace has been slower than planned due to supply chain constraints and extended construction project timelines.
As mentioned last quarter, we are proactively advancing capital investment, particularly in recycling, where we anticipate strong returns.
Investments in recycling technology and equipment at our MRFs are expected to reach about $200 million for the year.
While we still aim for full-year capital spending at the lower end of our $1.78 billion to $1.88 billion guidance range, 2021 spending could fall below targeted levels, with some expenditures shifted to 2022, mainly due to supply chain constraints.
We generated $773 million in free cash flow during Q3.
Through September, our business has generated $2.29 billion in free cash flow, putting us on track to meet our full-year target of $2.5 billion to $2.6 billion.
We've returned over $1.7 billion to shareholders in the first nine months, paying $730 million in dividends and repurchasing $1 billion of our stock.
We still expect to repurchase up to our full authorization of $1.35 billion in 2021.
Our leverage ratio at the end of Q3 was 2.71 times, as our strong business performance and successful integration of the acquired ADS business led to achieving our targeted leverage ratio ahead of schedule.
As we approach the end of 2021, our teams are focusing on accelerating our disciplined pricing programs, managing controllable costs, positioning WM as an employer of choice, and capturing growing volumes.
We are confident that our strategy will lead to a strong finish for 2021.
Summary:
output:
compname says total company revenue growth in 2021 is expected to be between 17% and 17.5%.
compname says adjusted operating ebitda is expected to be between $5.0 billion and $5.1 billion in 2021.
