input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Yesterday evening, we disclosed the financial outcomes for the second quarter of our 2021 fiscal year, with reports available in the Investor Relations area of our site.
To enhance clarity regarding our operational performance, we utilize certain non-GAAP financial metrics that involve adjustments to the standard GAAP results.
It's important to note that any presented non-GAAP financial measurements should not be viewed as substitutes for the financial metrics mandated by GAAP.
Erica will provide an overview of the financial outcomes for both our business segments and corporate operations.
I'm thrilled with the outstanding operational results we achieved this quarter, as we witnessed continued robust performance across our various business lines.
This quarter, we achieved a second consecutive record-breaking adjusted earnings per share of $1.38 and a segment EBIT of $149 million.
The adjusted earnings per share saw a 79% increase compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2020, primarily due to strong volumes across all regions, healthy unit margins, meticulous operational execution, and impressive performance in our targeted growth initiatives.
The Cabot team exhibited remarkable operational flexibility despite ongoing COVID restrictions, weather-related disruptions, and constraints in global shipping markets.
This operational adaptability was made possible by the exceptional efforts of our commercial and supply chain teams, as well as the robustness of Cabot's manufacturing network.
During the quarter, we observed strong volumes in the tire and automotive sectors, along with sustained strength in our infrastructure, packaging, and consumer-driven applications.
We're pleased to note improvements in automotive production and passenger car miles driven, although they generally remain below pre-COVID levels.
Conversely, truck miles driven are particularly strong, fueling a substantial replacement tire market.
With both automotive and tire markets projected to remain below previous peaks in the 2021 forecast, we're optimistic about our growth potential in the coming years.
In the short term, COVID cases remain stubbornly high in certain areas, particularly across Europe, South America, and India.
While vaccines offer hope, the economic recovery is likely to remain uneven and struggle to reach its full potential until the public health crisis is completely resolved.
Raw material prices continued to rise across most value chains, and our businesses were no exception.
We successfully implemented price increases to offset these rising costs, which, combined with favorable product mix, resulted in robust unit margins.
Examining our major segments, Reinforcement Materials achieved record EBIT performance this quarter with $89 million, driven by strong customer demand and favorable Asia pricing.
Performance Chemicals results improved significantly compared to the previous year, with segment EBIT of $58 million versus $31 million last year, as the business achieved double-digit volume growth in both Performance Additives and Formulated Solutions, and benefited from a favorable product mix.
Overall, I'm very satisfied with how we've navigated the pandemic, and I believe Cabot is emerging from the COVID crisis as a stronger company.
Our customers increasingly value our global manufacturing footprint, service capabilities, and leading product portfolio.
Although the 2020 recession necessitated a strong focus on cost and cash preservation, we continued to maintain our assets and make crucial investments in sustainability and long-term growth.
One of our most exciting growth investments is in the battery sector, and I'd like to provide an update on our progress in this area.
We're witnessing a genuine turning point in demand for electric vehicles and energy storage as pressure to reduce greenhouse gases intensifies.
Cabot is well-positioned to support this transition with our leading portfolio of highly engineered, conductive carbon additives and formulation capabilities.
Our business is showing strong growth this year, and we expect this trend to continue into the future.
I'll begin with some observations about the overall market.
Lithium-ion batteries are experiencing rapid growth and are expected to maintain a 25% to 30% compound annual growth rate through 2030, with electric vehicles serving as the primary growth driver as countries establish CO2 reduction goals and accelerate the shift away from internal combustion engines.
Further technological advancements in batteries are crucial to enabling this transition, and the materials industry will play a vital role in efforts to reduce costs and increase range.
Cabot currently serves this market by offering a variety of materials and formulations for use in energy storage applications.
These materials can be categorized into two groups: conductive carbon additives, which include conductive carbon black, carbon nanostructures, and carbon nanotubes, and non-carbon additives, which include products in our fumed metal oxides business.
Although conductive carbon additives comprise a small portion of battery composition, they are crucial to its function.
These additives facilitate the movement of electrons into and out of the active phase during battery charging and discharging cycles.
Two types of conductivity are necessary for effective performance: short-range and long-range conductivity.
Different shapes and properties of conductive carbon additives provide varying levels of conductivity performance.
Carbon nanotubes excel in long-range conductivity, while conductive carbon blacks are superior for short-range conductivity.
Consequently, there is no single ideal additive for this application.
The ability to offer various types of conductive carbon additives and their blends is essential to provide customized solutions that meet specific customer needs.
Several factors set Cabot apart in the conductive carbon additive industry.
We have established an unparalleled global presence and application expertise to support our customers as they expand manufacturing worldwide.
In recent years, we have built a leading technical support team through the establishment of our Asia Technology Center and the R&D capabilities acquired from Sanshun.
This expertise, combined with our global manufacturing network, makes us highly attractive to our customers.
Through organic growth and strategic acquisitions, including the recent Sanshun purchase, Cabot is the only carbon additive supplier with proven commercial capabilities in conductive carbon black, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanostructures, and dispersions.
This diverse range of conductive carbon additives allows us to create tailored solutions for our customers and collaborate on future technologies.
Cabot has a long history of innovation in challenging technical applications.
Our experience in the CMP market for semiconductors and inkjet printing has provided valuable practices and protocols that will be crucial for the battery market.
We anticipate that the battery application will become a significant contributor to the Performance Chemicals segment's financial performance in the coming years.
The current market for conductive carbon additives in lithium-ion batteries, including both CNTs and conductive carbon black, is valued at approximately $400 million.
We project this market to grow to about $1 billion in value by 2025.
Our energy materials business is performing well in fiscal 2021, with projected revenue of around $80 million for the year.
Over the past five years, revenue has grown at a compound annual growth rate of about 50%, including the acquisition of our CNT business in China.
Although we are making substantial investments to drive qualification and enhance our technical capabilities, EBITDA is expected to be between $15 million and $20 million in fiscal year 2021.
We are optimistic about the potential of this emerging application and will continue to support customers and capitalize on the opportunities in energy storage.
I will begin by discussing the results of the Reinforcement Materials segment.
The Reinforcement Materials segment achieved record operating results with EBIT of $89 million, a 46% increase compared to the same quarter of fiscal 2020, mainly due to significantly higher volumes across all regions and improved unit margins driven by favorable spot pricing in Asia.
Globally, volumes increased by 18% in the second quarter compared to the same period last year, primarily due to 30% growth in Asia and 10% higher volumes in the Americas and Europe.
Higher volumes were driven by key end market demand that continued to recover from COVID-related impacts in fiscal 2020.
Results also benefited from higher margins due to continued strong pricing in Asia, which included a second consecutive quarter of price increases ahead of rising feedstock costs.
Looking ahead to the second half of 2021, we expect volumes to remain strong.
We also anticipate higher feedstock cost flow-through in Asia, while fixed costs are expected to increase due to the timing of planned plant maintenance spending, following delayed spending in 2020 and the first half of this fiscal year.
Turning to Performance Chemicals, EBIT increased by $27 million compared to the second fiscal quarter of 2020, primarily due to strong volumes across the segment and improved product mix, driven by increased sales in automotive applications.
Year-over-year volumes increased by 10% in Performance Additives and 14% in Formulated Solutions, driven by increases across all our key product lines from higher demand levels and some customer inventory replenishment during the quarter.
We anticipate overall volumes to remain robust for the latter half of fiscal 2021
We expect a slight decrease in demand for automotive applications due to the semiconductor chip shortage, which will negatively affect product mix compared to the first half of the year
We foresee higher fixed costs in the second half of the fiscal year due to the timing of expenditures
EBIT in Purification Solutions for Q2 2021 decreased by $1 million compared to Q2 2020
The decline in demand for mercury removal applications was partly compensated by reduced fixed costs, resulting from the sale of our Marshall, Texas mine and associated long-term supply agreements
For the second half of fiscal 2021, we anticipate EBIT improvement driven by seasonally higher volumes
I'll now discuss corporate matters
We concluded the quarter with $146 million in cash and maintain a strong liquidity position of approximately $1.3 billion
In Q2 of fiscal 2021, operating activities generated $65 million in cash flow, including an $80 million increase in working capital
The working capital increase was primarily due to growth-related networking capital as accounts receivables rose with higher sales and inventory increased from purchases of more expensive raw materials
Q2 capital expenditures were $40 million, and we expect full-year capital expenditures to be around $200 million
This estimate includes ongoing EPA-related compliance spending and capital for upgrading our new China carbon black plant to produce specialty products
Additional cash uses during the quarter included $20 million for dividends
Our year-to-date operating tax rate was 28%, and we project an operating tax rate between 27% and 29% for the fiscal year
We are delighted with the record-breaking results in Q2 2021, as volumes continue to recover from the COVID-related lows experienced in fiscal 2020 and excellent execution across the organization
We achieved another record-setting quarter in reinforcement materials and very strong results in the performance chemicals segment
I am pleased with the team's execution throughout the first half of the year
Our manufacturing plants continue to operate effectively in the COVID environment to meet customer needs
We reached an important milestone in our sustainability journey by completing the air pollution control project at our Franklin, Louisiana plant
We are progressing with the integration of our CNT acquisition in China, and our inkjet investments are on track to deliver growth in the packaging segment
We continue to improve our work methods to drive more efficient and effective processes through digital solutions implementation
I'm proud of the Cabot team for their efforts to strengthen our foundation and establish our platform for sustainable growth
Regarding our current outlook, we continue to observe robust and widespread demand globally, including in our key tire, automotive, and industrial end-use markets
We believe the underlying demand will remain strong during the second half of the year
Given this demand outlook, we expect some impact from higher raw material costs in Asia, moderating volumes in automotive applications due to the semiconductor chip shortage, and higher fixed costs as we perform necessary maintenance and turnarounds to ensure we can meet customer demand in 2022
Based on these factors, we project adjusted earnings per share for the full year to be between $4.70 and $4.95
We expect our cash and liquidity to remain robust
Networking capital increases, driven by a sharp recovery in demand and a steady rise in oil prices, should moderate in the second half of the year
We anticipate better conversion of our strong EBITDA to operating cash flow as this occurs
We expect operating cash flow for the year to cover our cash needs for capital expenditures and dividends
Our debt to EBITDA ratio was 2.3 times at the end of March, and we anticipate further reduction by year-end
The strength of our culture and the resilience of our employees have been more evident than ever during these challenging times
Summary:
output:
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $4.70 to $4.95.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.38.
for h2 of fiscal year, anticipate continued demand strength across our segments.
for h2, expect some impact from flow-through of higher raw material costs in asia.
for h2, expect some impact from moderating volumes into automotive applications due to semi-conductor chip shortage.
for h2, expect some impact from increased fixed costs due to timing of scheduled maintenance activities.
pred_output:
2021 Q2 Financial Results
• Record-breaking adjusted earnings per share of $1.38
• Segment EBIT of $149 million
• 79% increase in adjusted earnings per share compared to Q2 2020
• Strong volumes across all regions, healthy unit margins, and impressive performance in targeted growth initiatives
• Record EBIT performance in Reinforcement Materials with $89 million
• Performance Chemicals results improved significantly with segment EBIT of $58 million
• Outlook for full-year adjusted earnings per share between $4.70 and $4.95

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our consolidated earnings per diluted share decreased from $0.26 in Q2 2020 to $0.20 in Q2 2021.
Year-to-date consolidated earnings per diluted share increased from $0.98 in 2020 to $1.18 in 2021.
I'll now hand over to Dennis for further discussion.
I trust you're having a good summer and keeping safe.
Most remaining pandemic-related restrictions were lifted in Washington State on June 30.
We're pleased to see continued recovery in our local economies.
We're observing higher energy consumption and steady customer growth.
We're closely monitoring the pandemic situation, including variants and case numbers in our areas, like many other companies.
We're prepared to adapt our operations as necessary while continuing to support those in need.
Let's review some key points from our second quarter performance.
We faced a tough second quarter, including an extreme heat wave that brought several days of record-breaking triple-digit temperatures to the region.
Spokane's temperature reached a new all-time high of 109 degrees on June 29, with even higher temperatures recorded in some neighborhoods.
On that day, Avista experienced its highest energy usage in the company's 132-year history due to increased customer demand.
The extreme heat and record energy consumption put stress on parts of our electrical system, causing some grid equipment to overheat.
The heat affected six of our 140 distribution substations.
We implemented protective outages for customers served by the most heat-affected equipment to prevent overloading and avoid extensive, costly damage to our electric system.
We managed to reduce customer impact through system adjustments during the event.
We thank our customers who experienced outages for their understanding.
The extended heat wave led to higher customer energy consumption, which was the main cause of increased net power supply costs, negatively impacting the Energy Recovery Mechanism (ERM).
The Pacific Northwest has experienced hotter and drier weather than usual, resulting in reduced hydroelectric generation and higher power prices.
We had to rely on more expensive thermal generation and purchased power to meet the additional demand.
Consequently, Avista Utilities' earnings were lower than expected in the second quarter.
AEL&P's earnings met expectations for the second quarter and are on track to meet full-year guidance.
Our other businesses performed well, exceeding expectations due to investment gains and the sale of certain subsidiary assets related to the Spokane steam plant.
Avista continues to prioritize wildfire resilience.
Our region has been extremely dry throughout spring and summer, and combined with high temperatures, the wildfire risk is significant.
Avista has been operating in "dry land mode" since late June to reduce the risk of wildfires that could occur when reactivating power lines in response to current conditions.
Under typical circumstances, these lines in rural or forested areas are usually reactivated automatically.
However, during the present dry weather, Avista's staff physically inspects the outage area before reactivating a line.
This approach may take longer to restore power but reduces the potential fire hazard.
This procedure aligns with Avista's wildfire resilience plan, which was introduced last year, expanding on long-standing prevention and response strategies.
Avista has pledged to implement a comprehensive 10-year wildfire resilience plan that includes enhanced defense strategies and operational practices for a more robust system.
Regarding regulatory issues, we are satisfied to have reached a unanimous settlement in our Idaho general rate case.
The newly established rates are equitable for our customers, the company, and our shareholders, and will enable Avista to continue receiving a fair return in Idaho.
Our Washington general rate cases are progressing through the regulatory process.
Our hearings have concluded, and we anticipate a decision by the end of September.
In Oregon, we plan to submit a rate case in the fourth quarter of 2021.
We are reaffirming our 2021 earnings guidance with a consolidated range of $1.96 to $2.16 per diluted share.
While maintaining our consolidated range, we are modifying our 2021 segment ranges by decreasing Avista Utilities by $0.10 per diluted share and increasing other by $0.10 per diluted share.
For 2022, we are reducing consolidated earnings guidance by $0.15 per diluted share to a range of $2.03 to $2.23 per diluted share.
For 2023, we are reaffirming our earnings guidance with a consolidated range of $2.42 to $2.62 per diluted share.
Although we anticipate challenges in 2022 due to regulatory lag, we are confident in our ability to meet our earnings guidance for 2023 and achieve our allowed return.
Moving forward, we will maintain our focus on utility operations while making prudent capital investments to maintain and upgrade our infrastructure, ensuring safe, reliable, and affordable energy for our customers and communities.
Everyone is eagerly anticipating the Blackhawks' next acquisition, which is a Spokane native.
We've acquired Tyler Johnson, a two-time Stanley Cup Champion who hails from Spokane.
We're quite excited about this development.
That concludes your Blackhawks update.
As Dennis mentioned, we're reaffirming our 2021 earnings guidance, lowering our utility guidance for 2021 and 2022, and confirming our 2023 consolidated guidance.
I'll elaborate on our guidance.
Our projections assume, among other factors, timely and appropriate rate relief in our jurisdictions.
This is crucial as we require - as Dennis noted, we've settled our Idaho case.
We're still awaiting approval from the commissions, which we expect before those rates take effect on September 1.
For 2021, we anticipate Avista Utilities will contribute between $1.83 and $1.97 per diluted share, with the lower end of our guidance for 2021 and 2022 for Avista Utilities primarily due to increased regulatory lag.
This is primarily attributed to increased capital expenditures driven by growth and higher-than-anticipated depreciation costs.
We believe this is merely a matter of timing, and as we prepare for our upcoming Washington general rate case, to be submitted early in Q1 2022, we anticipate it will be a multi-year rate plan as mandated by new legislation.
Our aim is to incorporate all capital investments through the end of the rate plan period into rates, striving to achieve our authorized return by 2023.
Furthermore, as Dennis noted, we have observed an increase in both actual and projected net power supply expenses.
While the midpoint of our guidance range excludes any ERM-related benefits or expenses in Washington, the rise in power supply costs has diminished our chances of reaching the upper half of the guidance range.
Our current ERM projection indicates a surcharge position within the 90-10 company sharing band, which is expected to reduce earnings by $0.08 per diluted share.
It's worth noting that in the previous quarter, our ERM estimate for the year was in a beneficial position, anticipated to contribute $0.06 per diluted share.
Moreover, we are absorbing additional net power supply costs under the PCA in Idaho.
For 2021, as Dennis mentioned, we anticipate AEL&P will contribute between $0.08 and $0.11.
We've raised the range in our other businesses by $0.10, effectively counterbalancing the utility reduction, largely due to a range of $0.05 to $0.08 per diluted share resulting from investment gains and the profit from the Spokane Steam Plant sale.
Our guidance typically only accounts for normal operating conditions and excludes unusual or non-recurring items until their effects are known and certain.
Let's now discuss the earnings for the second quarter.
Avista Utilities contributed $0.11 per diluted share, down from $0.26 in 2020.
Compared to the previous year, our earnings declined due to higher net power supply costs, as Dennis mentioned, mainly caused by increased customer demand during the heat wave and lower-than-normal hydroelectric generation due to hot and dry conditions.
Our hydroelectric generation is approximately 91% of our normal expectations for this year.
The ERM in Washington also experienced a significant shift.
We recorded a pre-tax expense of $7.6 million in Q2 2021, compared to a pre-tax benefit of $0.4 million in 2020.
Year-to-date, we've recognized $3.3 million in expenses for 2021, compared to $5.6 million in benefits for 2020.
In addition to higher power supply costs, we also incurred increased operating expenses in the quarter, primarily due to the timing of maintenance projects, as many were postponed in 2020 due to COVID-19, whereas in 2021, we resumed our original schedules and conducted maintenance in the second quarter.
The increased maintenance costs were partially offset by lower bad debt expense as we continue to defer bad debt through our COVID-19 regulatory deferrals.
Let's now discuss capital expenditures.
As Dennis mentioned, we remain committed to investing necessary capital in our utility infrastructure.
We currently project Avista Utilities to increase capital expenditures to $450 million in 2021, $445 million in 2022, and $445 million in 2023.
This represents increases of $35 million in 2021, and $40 million each in 2022 and 2023.
These increases are primarily to support continued customer growth.
Our customer growth rate is approximately 1.5%, up from previous expectations of 0.5% to 1%.
We plan to issue about $140 million in long-term debt and $90 million in common stock, including $16 million already issued through June for common stock in 2021.
The increase in long-term debt and common stock issuance is intended to fund the higher capital expenditures.
Summary:
output:

q2 earnings per share $0.20.
confirming 2021 consolidated earnings per share guidance with a range of $1.96 to $2.16.
lowering our 2022 consolidated earnings guidance to a range of $2.03 to $2.23 per diluted share.
for 2023, confirming earnings per share guidance with a consolidated range of $2.42 to $2.62.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Arnold Donald, the President and CEO of Carnival Corporation & plc, is speaking.
I'm accompanied on this call by our Chairman, Micky Arison, CFO David Bernstein, and Beth Roberts, Senior VP of Investor Relations.
We're ecstatic to resume our core business of providing exceptional, unforgettable vacation experiences to our customers.
Our staff members are delighted to be back on the ships, which is evident in the fantastic experiences our guests are having.
The onboard spending by guests is exceeding expectations, and our customer satisfaction scores are remarkably high.
I've recently visited several ships in the United States and overseas.
The vessels are in pristine condition, and the crew is full of enthusiasm.
There's a remarkable atmosphere on board.
Our safety measures have been effective, starting with a smooth boarding process, allowing us to increase occupancy levels rapidly as we bring more ships back into service.
Our brands have performed exceptionally well in this initial return to service phase, despite significant international travel restrictions limiting our usual diverse itinerary options, as well as operational requirements in certain areas that restrict our typically high occupancy levels.
Our itinerary planners devised innovative deployment alternatives, our marketing team made them accessible with minimal investment, our yield managers priced them appropriately to reach occupancy targets, and paired them with package deals to drive exceptionally high onboard revenue.
Despite the additional safety measures, our crew delivered an outstanding guest experience.
This combination allowed us to offer cruise vacations on a large scale while generating significant cash from these modified voyages.
While we don't usually share this level of information, we wanted to give you an idea of why we consider the restart highly successful, beyond the enthusiasm of our guests and crew and the unprecedented customer satisfaction scores.
It was challenging because most of our voyages, while cash flow positive, were programs that couldn't be compared to 2019 and would typically be priced lower than the 2019 alternatives.
For instance, in the UK, we could only offer cruises for seniors without any port stops, which were not comparable in ticket prices to peak season Mediterranean or Baltic sailings offered in summer 2019.
Nevertheless, even with occupancy restrictions, these cruises generated cash for our stakeholders.
They facilitated the return of our workforce and successfully served guests, resulting in high satisfaction levels.
For Carnival Cruise Line, we were able to offer itineraries more comparable to 2019, with revenue per passenger day up 20% compared to 2019, including the impact of incentives from previous cancellations, despite the last-minute nature of the bookings.
In fact, Carnival Cruise Line restarted more ships from U.S. ports than any other cruise brand and still achieved over 70% occupancy, all of which combined to generate an even greater cash contribution.
Carnival Cruise Line continues to be a top-performing brand.
Although the Delta variant and its impact on consumer confidence has created numerous operational challenges for us to navigate in the short term and led to some booking volatility in August, it hasn't significantly affected our overall plan to return our entire fleet to guest operations by spring 2022.
In our previous quarterly update, we anticipated a dynamic environment, which has indeed been the case.
Adaptability has been crucial for us over the past 18 months, and we continue to manage aggressively to optimize our performance in this ever-changing landscape.
While we're not yet at full occupancy by design, we have individual sailings with over 4,000 guests.
So far this year, we've carried over half a million guests.
On any given day, we're successfully hosting around 50,000 guests, and we expect this number to increase as we introduce more capacity and increase occupancy in the coming months.
The Delta variant has certainly impacted our protocols, which will continue to evolve based on local conditions.
In markets like the U.S. with higher case counts, we've quickly implemented additional safety measures, such as extra testing requirements and indoor mask mandates, with all U.S. sailings operating under CDC vaccination requirements.
Our protocols exceed the terms of the conditional sailing order and are much stricter than comparable land-based alternatives.
Our top priority remains compliance, environmental protection, and the health, safety, and well-being of everyone - our guests, the people in the communities we visit and serve, and of course, our Carnival family, both onboard and onshore.
The Delta variant has also disrupted our supply chain, affected the timing of destination openings, and created increased uncertainty, reflected in the broader travel sector and our booking trends.
We quickly adjusted our deployment by postponing the start date for some select voyages.
For some of our more exotic winter itineraries, like our popular world cruises, we rebooked guests for our 2023 departures.
We've effectively managed our near-term capacity to optimize the current environment, as we said we would.
The changes we've made to our fleet rollout pace will optimize our cash position in the short term.
Looking ahead, we're still working towards resuming full operations by spring, in time for our crucial summer season when we generate most of our operating profit.
We have sufficient liquidity to see us through to full operation.
We continue to focus prudently on cash management to ensure flexibility under various scenarios.
The current environment, while unpredictable, has improved significantly since last summer and should improve further by next summer if vaccine rollout and therapeutic advancements continue at their current pace.
In markets like the UK, where vaccination rates are already higher, consumer confidence remains strong, and we're seeing positive momentum.
We've announced the resumption of guest cruise operations for 71 ships across eight of our nine brands through next spring.
We're evaluating the remaining ships through next spring, focusing on maximizing future cash flow while providing an excellent guest experience that prioritizes public health.
Even at this early stage of our rollout, our ships are generating positive cash flow.
Based on our current rollout plan, we expect the company's overall cash from operations to turn positive early next year.
Looking ahead, we believe we have the potential to generate higher EBITDA in 2023 compared to 2019, given our modest growth rate, additional capacity, and improved cost structure.
Regarding booking trends, we're well-positioned to build on a solid book position and intentionally constrained capacity for the rest of 2021 and into the first half of 2022.
Here are the paraphrased sentences:
Given current demand and limited capacity, we are concentrating on maintaining prices.
Despite recent uncertainty from the Delta variant impacting travel decisions broadly, we continue to hold prices steady.
We've made future cruise bookings available earlier for 2023, seeing strong demand and favorable pricing for these advance reservations.
Building on that success, we've begun offering 2024 sailings even sooner.
These initiatives contributed to a $630 million rise in customer deposits, particularly long-term deposits.
Deposits for bookings over 12 months out are triple historical levels, partly due to our proactive efforts to offer more future inventory.
We anticipate guest deposits will keep growing as we resume more ship operations and increase occupancy.
These positive trends persist despite significantly reduced marketing expenditures.
We're focusing on cost-effective channels like direct marketing to our extensive database of over 40 million past guests, and leveraging media coverage from new ship launches and restart news.
Most crucially, we are delivering excellent guest experiences.
Personal recommendations remain the primary reason people take their first cruise.
As mentioned, our Net Promoter Scores are exceeding historical averages on ships that have resumed service.
We continued our track record of responsible financial management this quarter.
We completed two refinancing transactions, among other efforts, significantly reducing annual interest expenses.
We have numerous refinancing opportunities ahead and are pursuing them aggressively.
Importantly, we've made further progress in our sustainability initiatives.
We recently published our 11th Annual Sustainability Report, "Sustainable from Ship to Shore," available on our sustainability website.
The report expands on our 2020 goal achievement, detailing our 2030 goals and 2050 aspirations.
It highlights six focus areas guiding our long-term sustainability vision, including climate action, circular economy, sustainable tourism, health and well-being, diversity and inclusion, and biodiversity conservation.
These areas align with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.
Climate action is a top sustainability priority.
We aim to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.
Despite 25% capacity growth, our absolute carbon emissions peaked in 2011 and will remain below those levels.
We're working to transition to alternative fuels and investing in low-carbon technologies.
Due to the pause in operations, 2020 sustainability metrics aren't comparable to previous years.
However, the report contains valuable information on our sustainability progress despite an incredibly challenging year.
COVID-19 severely impacted our company, but I'm proud of our collective efforts to sustain our organization through these difficult times, including our actions for guests, stakeholders, and our Carnival family.
I believe our pandemic response demonstrates our company's sustainability.
I again express deep gratitude to our shipboard and shoreside team members who consistently went above and beyond.
I'm humbled by the dedication shown over the past 18 months.
We continue to make positive progress.
Throughout the pause, we've proactively prepared to resume operations as an even stronger company.
Our strategic decision to retire 19 ships has left us with a more efficient fleet, reducing our capacity growth to about 2.5% annually from 2019 through 2025, down from 4.5% pre-COVID.
We've strategically rebalanced our portfolio through ship exits, transfers, and newbuild schedule adjustments to optimize asset allocation, maximize cash generation, and improve return on invested capital.
While capacity growth is limited, we'll benefit from exciting new ships across our brands, capitalizing on pent-up demand and generating enthusiasm around our restart.
We'll achieve structural cost benefits in 2023 by introducing larger, more efficient ships while retiring our least efficient vessels.
With our aggressive actions, optimized portfolio, and reduced capacity, we're well-positioned to capitalize on pent-up demand and emerge as a leaner, more efficient industry leader.
We've secured sufficient liquidity to sustain us until full operations resume.
Once fully operational, our cash flow will primarily drive our return to investment-grade credit over time, creating greater shareholder value.
I'll begin with an overview of our guest cruise operations and third quarter monthly average cash burn rate.
Then I'll update you on booking trends and conclude with insights into our refinancing activities.
Regarding guest cruise operations, it's wonderful to discuss operations again.
We began the quarter with only five ships in service.
During Q3, we successfully restarted ships across eight brands.
We ended the quarter with 35% of our fleet capacity in service.
We plan to restart 27 more ships in Q4 and December.
By New Year's Day, we anticipate having 55 ships, or nearly 65% of our fleet capacity, back in service.
For Q3, occupancy was 54% across operational ships.
Our brands performed exceptionally well.
Occupancy increased progressively throughout the quarter, reaching 59% in August from 39% in June and 51% in July.
Our North American brands' occupancy reflects our policy of vaccinated cruises, which currently limits the number of families with children under 12 who can sail with us.
Our European brands' occupancy is affected by capacity restrictions, including social distancing requirements for Continental European brands and a 1,000-person limit per sailing for part of the quarter in the U.K. In the third quarter, North American brands had 68% occupancy, while European brands had 47%.
Despite current limitations on itinerary offerings, which excluded many high-yielding, destination-rich routes offered in 2019, revenue per passenger cruise day in the third quarter of 2021 increased compared to a strong 2019.
As Arnold mentioned, our guests are having an excellent experience, resulting in exceptionally high Net Promoter Scores.
Satisfied guests typically lead to improved onboard revenue.
Our onboard and other revenue per day increased significantly in the third quarter of 2021 compared to the same period in 2019, partly due to bundled packages and onboard credits used by guests from cruises canceled during the pause.
We saw substantial growth in onboard and other per diem revenue on both sides of the Atlantic.
The main contributors to onboard revenue increases were bar, casino, shops, spa, and Internet services.
In the past two years, we have offered more bundled package options, which our guests have increasingly chosen.
We will continue to see the benefits of these bundled packages in onboard and other revenue, as we did in the third quarter of 2021.
The distinction between passenger ticket revenue and onboard revenue is becoming less clear due to these bundled packages.
For accounting purposes, we divide the total price paid by guests between these two categories.
The best way to evaluate our performance is by looking at our total cruise revenue metrics.
As previously indicated, the ships in service during the third quarter were cash flow positive.
They generated nearly $90 million in ship-level cash contribution.
This was achieved with only a two-month U.S.-based restart during the third quarter, as our North American brands began guest cruise operations in early July.
We anticipate the ship-level cash contribution to increase as more ships return to service and we improve our occupancy percentages.
For those modeling our future results, it's important to note that ship operating expenses per available lower berth day (ALBD) in 2022 are projected to be higher than in 2019, despite the benefit of 19 smaller, less efficient ships leaving the fleet. This is due to the cost of part of our fleet being in pause status during the first half of 2022, restart-related expenses, and the cost of maintaining enhanced health and safety protocols.
Keep in mind that because part of the fleet will be in pause status during the first half, we are spreading costs over fewer ALBDs.
We expect most of these costs and expenses to end with 2022 and not recur in fiscal 2023.
Our monthly average cash burn rate for the third quarter of 2021 was $510 million, which was better than our previous guidance and in line with the $500 million per month for the first half of 2021.
The improvement compared to our guidance was due to the timing of capital expenditures, which are now likely to occur in the fourth quarter, and some other minor working capital changes.
With certain capital expenditures now shifting to the fourth quarter, the company expects its monthly average cash burn rate for the fourth quarter to be higher than the monthly average rate for the first nine months of the year.
Other positive factors affecting the fourth quarter include restart expenditures to support not only the 22 ships restarting during the fourth quarter but also additional ships restarting in the first quarter of 2022, along with a significant increase in dry dock days during the fourth quarter, driven by the restart schedule.
All these expenditures have been anticipated, and given the announced restarts, many are now occurring in the fourth quarter.
We are forecasting positive cash flow from the 50 ships that will have guest cruise operations during the fourth quarter.
ALBDs for the fourth quarter are expected to be 10.3 million, which is approximately 47% of our total fleet capacity.
Regarding booking trends, our booking volumes for all future cruises during the third quarter of 2021 were higher than booking volumes during the first quarter.
This trend continued over the first couple of months of the third quarter, leading us to expect that the third quarter would end with higher booking levels than the second quarter. However, we achieved this despite lower booking volumes in August when the Delta variant impacted travel and leisure bookings generally.
The impact on bookings in August was primarily seen on near-term sailings, but it quickly stabilized within the month.
Our cumulative advanced book position for the second half of 2022 is ahead of a very strong 2019 and has reached a new historical high.
Pricing for our second half 2022 bookings is higher than pricing for 2019 sailings at the same time, driven partly by the bundled pricing strategy for several of our brands, excluding the dilutive impact of future cruise credits (FCCs).
Including the dilutive impact of FCCs, pricing for our second half 2022 bookings is now in line with pricing for 2019 sailings at the same time.
This improved position results from positive pricing trends we observed during the third quarter.
This is a significant achievement, considering that pricing for 2019 sailings is a challenging comparison as it was the high watermark for historical yield.
Regarding our refinancing activities, we are focusing on pursuing opportunities to extend maturities and reduce interest expenses.
To date, through our debt management efforts, we have reduced our future annual interest expense by over $250 million per year.
We have completed cumulative debt principal payment extensions of approximately $4 billion, improving our future liquidity position.
The $4 billion extension results from three actions: first, the July refinancing of 50% of our first lien notes for $2 billion; second, the completion of European debt holiday amendments, which deferred $1.7 billion of principal payments (to be made over a five-year period beginning in April 2022); and third, the extension of a $300 million bilateral loan with one of our banking partners.
Looking ahead, given the support from debt capital market investors and commercial banks, we will pursue additional refinancing opportunities to significantly reduce our interest expense and extend our maturities over time.
Summary:

carnival corporation & plc provides third quarter 2021 business update.

carnival corp - voyages for q3 of 2021 were cash flow positive and company expects this to continue.
carnival - booking volumes for all future cruises during q3 of 2021 were higher than booking volumes during q1 2021, albeit not as robust as q2 2021.
carnival corp - monthly average cash burn rate for q3 of 2021 was $510 million.
carnival corp - also opened bookings for further out cruises in 2023, with unprecedented early demand.
carnival corp - company expects monthly average cash burn rate for q4 to be higher than the prior quarters of 2021.
carnival corp - expects monthly average cash burn rate for q4 to be higher than prior quarters of 2021.
carnival corp - expects a net loss on both a u.s. gaap and adjusted basis for quarter and year ending november 30, 2021.
carnival - consistent with gradual resumption of guest cruise operations, continues to expect to have full fleet back in operation in spring 2022.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our keynote presenters today are our President and CEO Mark Parrell, Chief Operating Officer Michael Manelis, and Chief Financial Officer Bob Garechana.
Whether you're performing essential maintenance or concierge duties on-site, engaging with potential clients remotely using our new contactless leasing system, or working from home in various corporate roles that keep Equity Residential running smoothly, you're helping our company continue to operate.
Let's now discuss our business operations.
The past seven weeks can be best characterized as resilient.
We collected approximately 97% of our usual cash intake from our residential business in April.
Although no sector of our nation's economy will be completely shielded from the impending recession, we believe our property portfolio, with residents earning an average annual household income of $164,000 and often employed in technology and other knowledge-based industries, will perform comparatively well.
Our operations team has also demonstrated resilience.
When the pandemic reached its peak in mid-March, Michael Manelis and his team swiftly adapted, significantly modifying our leasing and service operations over a few weeks.
Michael and his team quickly developed a contactless process for leasing that made our customers feel at ease.
In terms of service, we concentrated on essential maintenance tasks and cleanliness, helping our current residents feel secure and comfortable living with us during this pandemic.
Michael will provide more details about all of this shortly.
When lockdowns were first announced, our leasing activity decreased significantly, but demand has since increased, as mentioned in our release.
We view this recent uptick in demand as further evidence that our properties and markets will continue to be attractive living options for our target demographic.
Overall, we believe our people and properties have shown resilience with a capital R throughout this crisis.
We've further strengthened our already robust balance sheet, as Bob Garechana will explain shortly.
We're also actively preparing for our properties to operate with fuller staffing as lockdowns across the country are eased.
We'll keep the safety of our employees and residents in mind as we restructure our business.
Equity Residential has historically performed well during downturns, and we expect this time to be no different.
We're optimistic about our operational performance given these circumstances and anticipate opportunities to add high-quality assets to our platform as the economy navigates through this recession.
Lastly, we withdrew guidance in our release.
We're unable to accurately estimate the ongoing impact of the pandemic and the timing and nature of the reopening process on our business.
This makes it impossible to provide the high-quality near-term business projections you're accustomed to receiving.
We've provided substantial information on April's preliminary results, which we hope is helpful.
Today, I'll offer a brief summary of our operations over the past 45 days.
Before the COVID-19 pandemic, we had a strong start to the year.
Our occupancy was exceeding expectations, and we were well-prepared for the main leasing season.
Then COVID-19 struck, forcing us to adapt our operations to this unprecedented challenge.
I'd like to begin by recognizing the dedication and hard work of our employees during these extraordinary times.
Their ability to quickly adjust operations while maintaining a strong focus on our customers, properties, themselves, and their families is truly inspiring.
Governors in our markets mandated shelter-in-place orders in early to mid-March.
For us, this meant that our more than 150,000 residents began staying at home 24/7.
In response to the shelter-in-place orders, we implemented several key operational changes.
We shut down shared facilities, enhanced sanitization, and swiftly adapted our website and AI responses to shift the entire sales process online.
Using video content and virtual sales conversations enabled us to maintain business operations without interruption.
This transformation would typically have required several months to complete.
We restricted access to the office to promote social distancing while keeping the business operational by implementing staff rotations to reduce on-site employee numbers.
Comparing mid-March to the same period in 2019, we observed a 50% decrease in traffic and applications.
Nevertheless, we continued to receive over 375 new applications weekly through March's end, which we interpret as a validation of our new leasing approach.
With fewer visitors coming through the front entrance, we've prioritized retaining current residents.
We're currently offering residents the opportunity to renew their leases without any increase in rent.
Overall, retention rates in April and May have improved, with renewals now in the mid to upper 60% range, representing a 300 basis point increase from last April and nearly 800 basis point increase from last May.
New York is showing the strongest renewal rates, approaching 70% for March, April, and May.
Despite this positive retention, our overall occupancy has decreased by 130 basis points since March 31.
We anticipate the impact on occupancy to be most significant in the second quarter, establishing a new baseline from which we hope to see improvement as stay-at-home orders are lifted.
Allow me to provide some insight into April's performance.
Early in April, we began to notice an uptick in demand, with both traffic and leasing activity rebounding by nearly 30% and now trending similarly to last year.
In fact, we received over 900 applications last week, a substantial improvement from the 375 we were averaging in late March, which is very encouraging for us.
Given the activity in the past 45 days, we'd like to see that volume increase even more to compensate for the lower demand we experienced in March and to match the higher number of applications we typically receive in May.
It's evident that our high-quality, well-situated portfolio continues to attract prospective residents.
While the pandemic is certainly a deterrent, people still need to move due to life changes such as new jobs or relationships.
On Page 13, we've reported the first quarter and April monthly pricing statistics by market.
I'd like to remind everyone that this is just one month of data, and longer periods are usually necessary to establish definitive trends.
Mark highlighted the strength and quality of our resident base.
This is demonstrated by the fact that we received a very robust 97% of cash collections in April compared to our March collections.
This resilience resulted in a 5.4% delinquency rate, which is quite good given these unprecedented circumstances.
Notably, Seattle and Denver were our markets with the lowest delinquency at below 3%, while Los Angeles lagged behind at close to 8%.
The rest of our markets were clustered around the average.
We've also analyzed property types, and in most of our markets, our garden-style or more suburban properties have experienced higher delinquency rates than our mid-rise, high-rise urban locations.
As we navigate the ongoing disruptions caused by COVID-19, we remain strategic in our pricing approach.
As of today, our base rents are down 4% compared to the same week last year.
Let me provide some insight into notable markets.
Overall, Seattle is our strongest market, demonstrating great resilience with limited delinquency and the best overall revenue growth performance in the portfolio.
New York presents a mixed picture.
While it boasts the strongest retention of any market, it hasn't exhibited the recovery signs seen in other areas regarding traffic and applications.
In the long run, we anticipate the New York market will thrive due to limited new supply and expanding technology companies.
We're optimistic that leasing activity will pick up as the heavily impacted New York region overcomes the worst of the pandemic.
We began 2020 expecting Los Angeles to face significant challenges due to new supply pressures.
The COVID situation will undoubtedly exacerbate this.
Despite recent improvements in applications, we anticipate this market will continue to struggle with significant pricing pressures as new supply becomes available.
What's our next move?
We're currently in the initial stages of adapting our properties for the new reality.
We anticipate changes will occur gradually.
Currently, the new normal will emphasize enhanced cleaning protocols at properties, redesigning common areas like fitness centers and lounges to ensure social distancing, striking a balance between virtual leasing and customer engagement, and implementing staggered work shifts to limit on-site employee numbers.
These are difficult times, but our business is adaptable, and our teams are ready to deliver.
We've updated our disclosures to better represent our current business situation.
We've done this by providing April operational and collection data, separating our same-store performance into residential and nonresidential categories, and offering updates on liquidity and balance sheet information.
This includes revising the schedules on Pages 10 through 12 of the release.
We've defined several key terms at the end of the release to ensure clarity and specificity in our disclosure.
The new disclosure includes a breakdown of nonresidential operations for our same-store portfolio.
This minor component of our business accounts for 4% of total revenues, primarily consisting of ground floor retail and public nonresident parking at our well-situated apartment communities.
Ground floor retail comprises about two-thirds of this 4%, with public nonresident parking making up the remainder.
As expected, many retail tenants renting our space have been significantly affected by stay-at-home orders.
This is reflected in the 58% April collection rate for all retail, which, while lower than desired, may be higher than many other retail landlords.
Drugstores, bank branches, and national chains occupying many of these spaces have generally continued paying rent, while local small businesses have struggled.
For nonresident parking, we've observed an approximately 30% decrease in parking volume for April due to the lack of public events and increased work-from-home arrangements.
We expect this may improve as stay-at-home orders are gradually lifted.
Our balance sheet ended the first quarter in a strong position with a net debt to normalized EBITDA of 4.9 times and nearly $1.8 billion in liquidity under our revolving credit facility.
After the quarter's end, we further strengthened our position by securing an attractively priced 2.6% or $195 million 10-year GSE loan and selling an asset in the San Francisco Bay Area.
Currently, over 84% of our total NOI is unencumbered, with about $150 million in commercial paper outstanding and readily available liquidity exceeding $2.2 billion under our revolving credit facility, which matures in 2024.
This liquidity is more than adequate to cover our expected development expenses, minimal debt maturities in 2020, and address our next significant debt maturity in December 2021.
Our balance sheet is well-prepared to withstand challenges and capitalize on potential opportunities.
Summary:
output: equity residential withdraws full year 2020 earnings guidance.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The Company has no requirement to revise this data.
Whitestone's Q2 earnings release and supplementary operational and financial information have been submitted to the SEC and can be accessed on their website in the Investor Relations area.
We'll now hear from Jim Mastandrea, Chairman and CEO, who will provide an update on our Q2 results.
My comments will concentrate on our achievements.
I'll discuss the demand factors related to these outcomes, offer insights into our operations and strategic direction, after which Dave will provide financial details for the quarter.
I'm delighted to begin by stating that we have an excellent business with outstanding properties that we manage efficiently.
We experienced a record-breaking second quarter in 2021, maintaining our focus on leasing to drive growth and support our dividends, resulting in a core payout ratio of 41%.
This confirms the quality of our portfolio in generating cash flow, enhancing our balance sheet and mitigating risk.
Our Q2 leasing efforts increased total occupancy to 89.9%, a 120 basis point improvement from Q1, showcasing increased demand from new businesses entering our markets, where typically 15 to 20 new tenants represent a 1% occupancy increase.
We attribute this growing interest to various factors, including our properties' location, quality, and maturity, as well as tenants expanding their businesses to multiple Whitestone locations.
Our properties are also benefiting from population shifts and a strong recovery in Sunbelt markets, where we target properties in densely populated, high-income neighborhoods within the fastest-growing cities in Texas and Arizona.
We recorded a net income per share of $0.12, up from $0.03 in the previous quarter and $0.01 from the prior year.
FFO core per share rose 13% to $0.26 from $0.23 in the previous quarter and increased 18% from $0.22 in the prior year.
Our improved per-share earnings stem from adding new essential service-focused tenants to our existing base of grocery stores, restaurants, salons, pet care centers, drugstores, banks, financial advisories, medical outpatient centers, health and wellness facilities, and other services.
We expanded our asset base organically and through off-market acquisitions of properties we believed had significant potential and would benefit from applying our business model principles and processes, streamlining property management, reconfiguring and redeveloping our community centers, and adding features to attract more visits and extend consumer time at the properties.
This is evidenced by an almost 18% increase in foot traffic at our 59 centers during the first half of the year.
As an example of projects that increase traffic to our centers, we've installed outdoor misting systems in Arizona for customer comfort during the three hottest months when temperatures can average 100 degrees.
We currently manage five million square feet of space, generating $30.6 million in revenue for Q2.
We curate the tenant mix within each property.
With over 1400 tenants serving customers from surrounding neighborhoods, our properties remain active 18 hours a day, seven days a week.
A proactive example driving increased visits is the rotation of coffee and cars events at our Market Street property in Scottsdale, Arizona, and our Starwood property in Plano, Texas.
These events showcase high-end sports cars and appeal to a wide range of car enthusiasts and families.
On a given Saturday each month, we accommodate up to 150 cars at each location, with owners and admirers returning as customers for our local tenants.
Increased foot traffic to our centers is a crucial driver of tenant sales and attracts potential new tenants to our properties.
Our tenants typically occupy around 3,000 square feet of space and provide e-commerce resistant services.
They are entrepreneurial businesses that generate sales revenue while keeping the American dream alive, with a tenant profile centered on entrepreneurial risk and financial investment to grow their businesses.
In the REIT industry, these tenants are often referred to as small businesses.
They make up a large portion of our overall tenant base and recovered more quickly from COVID than some larger tenants.
They paid their rent and demonstrated resilience, as owners and founders of local and regional businesses prioritize their companies, which support their families, livelihoods, and futures, aligning with our high collection levels.
As they recover, Whitestone reported industry-leading collections, with our model tested and proven during COVID.
Our culture emphasizes personalized service to tenants, with property managers and associates taking a hands-on approach.
This teamwork strengthening Whitestone-tenant relationships gives us a competitive edge over other retail centers in our local neighborhood markets.
Our service-oriented culture resulted in leasing spreads of 6.8% on new and renewal leases in the second quarter, weighted average.
We anticipate this trend continuing, as we secure annual lease increases of 2% to 3% on new and renewal tenant leases and pass through triple net expenses, helping us hedge against inflation.
Another source of revenue growth is increasing our leasable square footage.
Expanding existing properties without additional land costs or development expenses proves highly lucrative.
Our portfolio contains roughly 230 million in potential development and redevelopment projects that we anticipate will significantly enhance value.
The variety of our tenant mix also considerably affects our financial standing.
For our company, individual tenants can influence our income by over 2.9%.
As our profits grew in the second quarter, we bolstered our financial position and reduced our debt-to-EBITDA ratio by 1.2 turns to 8.2 turns.
We've consistently focused on decreasing our debt service leverage.
We're also dedicated to reducing our G&A expenses as a percentage of revenue.
We're making progress as our asset portfolio grows and our income increases.
G&A as a percentage of revenue was 14.6% in the second quarter, an improvement from 15.7% the previous year.
We resumed our acquisition strategy in July, purchasing Lakeside Market in Plano, an affluent Dallas suburb.
It's anchored by HEB, a renowned Texas grocery chain, with their first flagship store in the Dallas area.
We acquired Lakeside Market for 53.2 million, with significant potential from leasing the current 19% vacant space, increasing rental rates, and developing additional pad sites to expand leasable area.
We're currently negotiating with other property owners in our target markets of Dallas, Austin, Houston, and Phoenix.
Long-time property owners in our markets recognize the benefits of diversifying risk across a large portfolio of quality properties, gaining liquidity through stock sales, and receiving tax-efficient transactions using our OP unit currency.
In return, Whitestone benefits from expanding our asset base, reducing capital costs, and improving economies of scale.
Dividends play a crucial role in the REIT structure.
Our dividend is sustainable, with a payout ratio of 41% of FFO Core in the second quarter.
I'd like to elaborate on our dividend and policy.
We've consistently paid 131 monthly dividends since our 2010 IPO, totaling over 300 billion in shareholder payouts during this period.
We raised our dividend by $0.01, or 2.4%, in March 2021, reflecting our strong recovery.
Our policy involves regular dividend evaluations, considering factors such as profitable growth, cash flow, and progress towards long-term shareholder value creation.
We use excess cash flow to fund internal development projects, acquisitions, and debt reduction.
I'd like to discuss our approach to achieving long-term value goals and increasing our valuation.
Our primary focus on creating and driving long-term real estate value is central to all our activities.
As we increase occupancy, develop our land, and make strategic acquisitions, the inherent value in our assets will begin to reflect in our valuation.
Although the market doesn't yet fully recognize the value we're creating, we trade at a significant discount to our true worth.
We're confident that as we continue to grow occupancy, revenue, and cash flow, the investment community will recognize our value.
Achieving our long-term goals depends on our assets.
Our portfolio of high-quality real estate across thriving markets, combined with high demand for our nearly full centers, is highly valuable.
Our rental income generates stable, reliable cash flow.
Our prime locations, property quality, and strong operational performance are evident in our ability to extract value from our properties and successfully acquire new assets from our extensive pipeline, keeping us at the forefront of our industry as we expand.
To recap, a decade ago, we developed a contrarian business model focusing on entrepreneurial, e-commerce-resistant tenants.
Starting with a modest asset base of about 150 million, we've grown to 59 properties in eight major cities, over 1,400 tenants, and approximately 1.5 billion in real estate value today.
We remain committed to executing our plan and are pleased to present our second quarter results.
I'll now hand over to Dave Holeman for a more detailed analysis of our financial performance.
I'm grateful for the chance to share some excellent second quarter results.
Throughout the quarter, our superior geographic focus and carefully planned tenant mix have led to robust revenue and profit growth, while our long-term strategy and daily operations have enabled us to make substantial progress towards our objectives of expanding our infrastructure and enhancing our debt position
The metropolitan areas where we operate continue to experience significant population influx and business relocations, generating employment opportunities from other regions of the nation
This is clearly demonstrated by the year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter increases in top-line revenue, property net operating income, net income, and FFO core per share for both the second quarter and year-to-date periods
This expansion is fueled by our robust leasing activities, resulting in higher occupancy rates and strong positive leasing spreads
The growth is attributed to lowered debt levels and borrowing expenses, increased scale of our G&A infrastructure, and profitable asset sales
Second quarter total revenue reached $30.6 million, representing a 5% increase from the first quarter and an 11% rise from the second quarter of 2020
The revenue growth was attributed to a sequential 1.2% rise in occupancy and a 0.7% improvement compared to Q2 2020
We are also benefiting from a 1.2% sequential increase and a 1.9% year-over-year rise in our ABR per square foot, along with reduced uncollectibility reserves
Property net operating income for the quarter was $22 million, showing a 4% sequential increase and a 10% rise from the second quarter of 2020
Our Q2 same-store net operating income grew by 8.4% compared to Q2 of 2020
Quarterly net income was $0.12 per share, up from $0.03 per share in the first quarter and $0.01 per share in the same quarter of the previous year
Funds from operations core reached $0.26 per share in the quarter, marking a 13% increase from the first quarter and an 18% rise from the second quarter of 2020
Our quarterly leasing activity continued to build on our strong first quarter performance, with 35 new leases representing 75,000 square feet of newly occupied space
Our new lease activity for the first half of the year is 100% higher on a square foot basis than 2020, and 40% higher than 2019
Leasing spreads on a GAAP basis have been positive 8% over the past 12 months, with second quarter leasing spreads increasing by 3.1% on new leases and 7.9% on renewal leases signed
Our annualized base rent per square foot on a GAAP basis at the end of the quarter grew 1.2% to $19.95 from $19.71 in the previous quarter, representing a 1.9% increase from a year ago
Total occupancy stood at 89.9%, with all our markets experiencing increased quarter-over-quarter occupancy, led by our Dallas market with a 3.6% increase
Austin and Phoenix both grew 0.8% from the first quarter, while Houston grew 0.6% from the first quarter
Our collections for the quarter were very strong, returning to normal pre-COVID levels
Reflecting the high collection levels, our reserve for uncollectible revenue for the quarter was $143,000, or approximately 1.5% of our revenue, down from $529,000 or 1.8% of revenue in the first quarter, and $2.3 million or 7.9% of revenue in the second quarter of 2020
Our total tenant receivables improved 8.4% from the first quarter and 13.5% from a year ago
Our interest expense was 5% lower than a year ago, reflecting our reduced debt levels
At quarter end, we had $21.3 million in accrued rents and accounts receivable
This amount includes $16.4 million of accrued straight line rents and $1.5 million of agreed upon deferrals
Our agreed upon deferral balance has decreased by 34.4% since year-end, indicating that tenants are honoring their payment plans
Regarding our balance sheet, we have implemented various measures to strengthen our liquidity since early last year
Our total net debt is $601.3 million, down $48 million from a year ago, improving our debt to gross book real estate cost ratio to 52% from 56% a year ago
Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio also improved by 1.2 times from the first quarter to 8.2 times
Considering our post-quarter acquisition and continued focus on deleveraging, we anticipate our debt-to-EBIT ratio to be approximately eight by year-end, indicating significant progress towards our long-term debt reduction goals
At quarter end, we have $160.5 million of undrawn capacity and $55.1 million of borrowing availability under our credit facility
During the second quarter, we sold approximately three million common shares through our ATM program, generating $25.4 million in net proceeds for the company
After the quarter, we acquired Lakeside Market in Plano, Texas for $53.2 million, financing the acquisition with approximately $30 million in equity, $10 million in debt from our corporate credit facility, and $13 million from cash flow and cash on hand
These results demonstrate the strength of Whitestone's strategic geographic focus and business models
We are optimistic about the acquisition of Lakeside Market and look forward to continuing to deliver value to all of Whitestone's stakeholders
We will now open the lines for questions
Summary:

compname reports q2 ffo core per share of $0.26.
qtrly revenues of $30.6 million versus $27.6 million in 2q 2020.
qtrly ffo core per share of $0.26.
