input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:David Zalman will commence by summarizing the key points of the recent quarter's performance.
Following him, Asylbek Osmonov will present an overview of our latest financial data, and Tim Timanus will discuss our lending operations, including the quality of our assets.
Interested parties can participate in the live call by following the instructions provided by our moderator, Jamie.
Allow me to provide the standard disclaimers before we begin.
We are satisfied with our second quarter 2020 results and the timely completion of Legacy's operational integration in early June.
The former Legacy employees, now part of Prosperity, have been exceptional, and their dedication and efforts were crucial for the smooth integration.
We remain optimistic about the merger and look forward to continuing to develop the finest bank possible.
In the second quarter of 2020, we demonstrated impressive annualized returns on average tangible common equity of 19.98% and on average assets of 1.61%.
Our earnings for the second quarter of 2020 were $130.9 million, compared to $82 million for the same period in 2019, representing an increase of $48.6 million or 59.1%.
Our diluted earnings per share for the second quarter of 2020 were $1.41, up from $1.18 for the same period in 2019, showing an increase of 19.5%.
The second quarter 2020 earnings per share of $1.41 includes a $0.22 income tax benefit, a $0.06 charge for merger-related expenses, and a $0.03 charge for the writedown of fixed assets related to the merger and some CRA funds.
In total, there was a $0.22 benefit to earnings and $0.09 in deductions, primarily related to the merger.
As of June 30, 2020, loans totaled $21.025 billion, an increase of $10.4 billion or 98.6% compared to $10.587 billion on June 30, 2019.
Our quarter-over-quarter loans increased by $1.898 billion or 9.9% from $19.127 billion on March 31, 2020, with $1.392 billion of this increase attributed to SBA Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans.
Mortgage warehouse loans also saw an increase of $843 million in the second quarter of 2020 compared to the first quarter.
Our core loans, excluding those held for sale, the warehouse purchase program, and PPP loans, decreased by $311 million.
However, part of this decrease was due to the intentional removal of loans identified during our due diligence of Legacy.
We experienced strong loan growth early in the second quarter, but it slowed as businesses reduced operations or shut down in response to various government orders.
As of June 30, 2020, our deposits totaled $26.153 billion, an increase of $9.265 billion or 54.9% compared to $16.888 billion on June 30, 2019.
Our quarter-over-quarter deposits increased by $2.326 billion or 9.8% from $23.826 billion on March 31, 2020.
Typically, our deposits are lower in the second quarter compared to the first quarter, and then start to increase in the third and fourth quarters.
However, this year, second quarter deposits are higher.
A significant portion of this increase is due to PPP loans, as well as reduced customer spending and increased saving.
Asset quality has always been and will continue to be one of our bank's primary areas of focus.
I've consistently stated that you'll appreciate us during prosperous times but truly cherish us during hardships, which is proving accurate once again in this pandemic and oil market downturn.
Non-performing assets amounted to $77.9 million, equivalent to 28 basis points of the quarterly average interest-earning assets as of June 30, 2020.
We're continuing to offer assistance to our borrowers through loan extensions and postponements when feasible.
Net charge-offs for the second quarter of 2020 totaled $13 million.
Of these write-offs, $12.4 million were associated with PCD loans that had specific reserves of $28.5 million, which we acquired during the merger.
To date, $16.1 million in specific reserves have been transferred to the general reserve, in addition to the $10 million provision for loan losses in the second quarter.
Merger and acquisition activities have decreased during this pandemic.
While some discussions are ongoing and a few deals may be in progress, we anticipate that M&A activity will increase as businesses resume operations and economic conditions improve.
Scale appears to be increasingly important now, particularly with reduced net interest margins, the need for enhanced technology, and the possibility of additional regulatory requirements if there's a change in government leadership.
One illustration is the increased volume at our customer service center, with many elderly clients seeking to set up online and mobile banking services that they previously showed no interest in.
The Blue Chip consensus forecast predicts that the fourth quarter 2020 GDP will conclude at -5.6% compared to the fourth quarter of 2019.
However, they project a positive 4.8% GDP for the fourth quarter of 2021 relative to the fourth quarter of 2020.
They also predict an unemployment rate of 9.4% for the fourth quarter of 2020, compared to an unemployment rate of 6.9% for the fourth quarter of 2021.
These projections suggest a promising outlook for 2021.
We are optimistic about our company's future prospects.
Despite frequent changes in our operating environment and economy, we remain committed to addressing any challenges that arise and prioritizing the needs of our customers and employees.
Prosperity continues to emphasize building core relationships, maintaining strong asset quality, and running the bank efficiently while investing in evolving technology and product distribution channels.
We plan to continue expanding the company both organically and through mergers and acquisitions.
Our goals are to develop future leaders, ensure every customer interaction is smooth and enjoyable, and maintain safe and sound operations.
I'll now hand over the discussion to Asylbek, our Chief Financial Officer, to elaborate on some of the specific financial results we've achieved.
Net interest income before credit loss provisions for the three-month period ending June 30, 2020 was $259 million, up from $154.8 million in the same period of 2019, representing an increase of $104.1 million or 67.2%.
This increase was primarily attributed to the merger with LegacyTexas in November 2019 and loan discount accretion of $24.3 million in the second quarter of 2020.
The net interest margin on a tax-equivalent basis was 3.69% for the three months ending June 30, 2020, compared to 3.16% for the same period in 2019 and 3.81% for the quarter ending March 31, 2020.
Excluding purchase accounting adjustments, the core net interest margin for the quarter ending June 30, 2020 was 3.33%, compared to 3.14% for the same period in 2019 and 3.36% for the quarter ending March 31, 2020.
For the quarter ending June 30, 2020, non-interest income amounted to $25.7 million, a decrease from $30 million in the same period of 2019.
The non-interest income for the current quarter was impacted by a $3.9 million writedown of certain assets and overall effects of the COVID-19 crisis.
Non-interest expenses rose to $134.4 million for the quarter ending June 30, 2020, compared to $80.8 million in the same period of 2019.
The merger with LegacyTexas and one-time expenses of $7.5 million related to the core system conversion in June were the main reasons for the increase.
Besides the merger-related costs, the second quarter results also showed higher expenses due to increased mortgage activities.
Now that the core system conversion and operational integration are complete, we don't expect any significant merger-related expenses in the future, and we anticipate realizing the remaining cost savings starting in the third quarter of 2020.
We project these additional savings to be approximately $7 million to $9 million per quarter.
This, combined with savings from the first and second quarters, will align with our previously announced 25% reduction in non-interest expenses.
The efficiency ratio increased to 46.56% for the quarter ending June 30, 2020, up from 43.74% in the same period of 2019 and 42.9% for the quarter ending March 31, 2020.
When excluding the $7.5 million in merger-related expenses, the efficiency ratio for the quarter ending June 30, 2020 was 43.97%.
As of June 30, 2020, the bond portfolio had a weighted average life of 2.69 years and expected annual cash flows of about $2.3 billion.
At the end of the quarter on June 30, 2020, our nonperforming assets totaled $77,942,000, representing 37 basis points of loans and other real estate.
The nonperforming assets as of June 30, 2020 comprised $71,595,000 in loans, $187,000 in repossessed assets, and $6,160,000 in other real estate.
Of the $77,942,000 in nonperforming assets, energy credits accounted for $12,173,000 or 16%, with $12,73,000 being service company credits and $100,000 being production company credits.
Since June 30, 2020, $15,786,000 has been removed from the nonperforming assets list through the sale of collateral, representing 20% of the nonperforming assets.
Net charge-offs for the quarter ending June 30, 2020 amounted to $13,01,000.
During the quarter ending June 30, 2020, $10 million was added to the allowance for credit losses.
The average monthly new loan production for the quarter ending June 30, 2020 was $871 million, including $1.430 billion in PPP loans booked during the quarter.
As of June 30, 2020, outstanding loans totaled $21.025 billion.
The loan portfolio as of June 30, 2020 consisted of 39% fixed rate loans, 36% floating rate loans, and 25% loans with specific reset intervals.
The fixed rate percentage increased slightly due to the inclusion of PPP loans.
Summary:
output:
prosperity bancshares, inc q2 earnings per share $1.41.
q2 earnings per share $1.41.
loans increased $1.898 billion or 9.9% during q2 2020.
qtrly net interest income before provision for credit losses was $259.0 million compared with $154.8 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Joining me on this call are our new President and CEO Denise Paulonis, along with CFO Marlo Cormier.
I'm excited to be here after about a month in my role, and I'm eager to connect with our analysts and shareholders soon.
Having been on Sally Beauty's board since 2018, I bring a valuable insider's perspective and thorough understanding of the business from day one.
I see a great chance to apply my leadership abilities and retail/finance expertise to usher the company into a new phase of lucrative growth, building on the capabilities developed during the past four years of transformation.
The company has undergone a complete overhaul in every area, including technology, marketing, merchandising, supply chain, HR, finance, and talent, creating a strong foundation for future growth.
I'm extremely proud of our outstanding team who tackled this challenge and helped us evolve into a contemporary, dynamic omnichannel beauty retailer poised for long-term success.
Before discussing our future plans, I'd like to highlight some key achievements from the past year.
For the full fiscal year 2021, net sales increased by 10%, gross margins surpassed 50%, and adjusted earnings per share rose by over 97%.
We also generated robust operating cash flow of $382 million.
We maintained consistent performance throughout the year and ended fiscal 2021 with fourth-quarter results surpassing expectations, demonstrating strong operational execution.
We're particularly pleased to observe ongoing momentum and consistency across the business despite the various impacts of the pandemic.
As we begin our new fiscal year, our goal to attract and retain color customers remains a key part of our strategy, supported by ongoing trends in self-expression through hair, product sustainability and innovation, and the growing number of independent stylists, all of which reinforce the strength of our color and care business.
Prioritizing customers and improving their experience with us is crucial to our success.
We continue to focus on the customer through personalization, inspiration, education, and training.
We're also committed to creating the most convenient shopping experience for our customers through our comprehensive omnichannel platform and various fulfillment options, allowing customers to get products how and when they want them, faster than ever before.
In light of this, we'll concentrate on four strategic growth areas to drive top-line growth in fiscal 2022: maximizing our digital platform, enhancing loyalty and personalization, delivering product innovation, and improving our supply chain.
Let's start with digital.
As we increasingly become the premier source for color inspiration, education, and training, we aim to create a user-friendly, reliable omnichannel platform for both DIY enthusiasts and stylists.
At BSG, we completed crucial strategic initiatives in fiscal 2021 that positioned us to become the go-to platform for stylists.
We revamped the CosmoProf website, introduced new value-added ordering services, and implemented same-day delivery.
Additionally, we'll be connecting our store network to the CosmoProf app this month to further enhance same-day delivery.
In essence, our BSG stylists can now access CosmoProf's entire inventory on their phones and receive products within two hours.
Combining these initiatives truly positions BSG as a valuable resource for the stylist community, providing them with the tools they need to operate their businesses efficiently and profitably.
At Sally, we've observed a positive customer response to our expanded fulfillment model and continue to gain traction with BOPIS, ship from store, and rapid two-hour delivery.
In our most recent quarter, Sally U.S. and Canada stores fulfilled 34% of e-commerce sales, with BOPIS accounting for 22%, ship from store for 8%, and rapid two-hour delivery (launched mid-quarter) representing 4% of Sally U.S. and Canada e-commerce sales.
The adoption of these new fulfillment options demonstrates our ability to scale new tools and capabilities to meet our customers' strong desire for convenience.
We're also intensely focused on improving inventory availability across our store and distribution center network through our new JDA platform, enabling customers to access our inventory however they choose to shop and receive most products in just two to three hours.
As we continue to scale and optimize our full suite of omnichannel services for both Sally and BSG customers, we believe e-commerce can reach 15% or more of sales in the coming years.
In fiscal 2021, global e-commerce sales penetration was just over 7%.
Importantly, we know that an omnichannel customer at Sally U.S. and Canada spends approximately 75% to 80% more with us annually than a brick-and-mortar customer, making this not just a sales channel shift but a significant growth opportunity.
Moving on to our second growth pillar: loyalty and personalization, which is closely tied to our digital strategy.
As many of you know, the rise of personalization has changed the fundamental expectations in retail.
With our rapidly growing loyalty program and a new focus on personalization, we have a significant opportunity to drive increased customer engagement and sales.
At Sally U.S. and Canada, approximately 74% of our fourth quarter sales came from our loyalty program.
At BSG, because stylists must register to shop with us, we have data on 100% of our customers.
Roughly 8% of our BSG's quarterly sales were generated by our Rewards Credit Card, which was introduced about a year ago.
These figures are impressive, and we've only begun to tap into the potential of this asset.
In the coming fiscal year, we plan to use data science to engage customers with inspiration, education, and tailored offers at every interaction point.
For Sally customers, this involves suggesting product usage, sending timely replenishment reminders, and incorporating DIY education at crucial stages of their journey.
For BSG customers, this means highlighting new product arrivals, prompting stylists to restock their backbar, and sending notifications to replenish essential style products.
We anticipate these strategies will increase customer lifetime value by reducing churn, increasing per-transaction spending, and boosting purchase frequency.
We will also increase our investment in digital marketing and social media campaigns to boost traffic and sales in the upcoming fiscal year.
Our ongoing marketing initiative, YOU by Sally, continues to garner significant attention from customers and industry professionals.
The campaign, which celebrates hair color's transformative power, has received extensive coverage from beauty editors and garnered millions of views on social media platforms.
Our third growth strategy focuses on product innovation.
The upcoming fiscal year will feature a significant influx of innovation across Sally and BSG, with much of it driven by our own efforts.
We have a robust pipeline of new products, including both our own and third-party brands across various categories.
We will maintain our focus on and support for sustainable and clean products, which are increasingly preferred by customers and command premium prices.
We believe our expertise in color and care provides a logical pathway and powerful platform for establishing new brands that extend beyond our current offerings.
Our first initiative is a new exclusive line of vivid hair colors for Sally called Strawberry Leopard, which was launched to positive reception in October. This Gen Z-focused brand demonstrates our ability to attract younger consumers through self-expression.
Alongside the launch, we created a dedicated digital platform for Strawberry Leopard that immerses consumers in the brand's essence and enables direct shopping.
As the brand gains momentum, we anticipate exploring opportunities for expansion into additional distribution channels, including mass retailers, beauty stores, and third-party e-commerce platforms.
The innovation pipeline at BSG is equally promising, beginning with Olaplex's new toning shampoo launched in September.
Olaplex exemplifies a high-profile brand that consistently innovates and remains a key partner for us.
Looking ahead, we're committed to staying at the forefront of innovation, with plans for new product and brand launches to excite consumers in 2022 and beyond.
Moving to our fourth growth pillar, a crucial aspect of our customer-first approach is enhancing our supply chain to ensure consistent availability of color and care products.
Much of the groundwork has been completed, and we're now implementing the final phase of JDA integration.
The system is operational in all BSG locations and most Sally stores.
We're currently deploying JDA to our remaining locations and fully integrating it with our North Texas distribution center.
Upon completion, we'll have a highly automated, integrated network with industry-leading capabilities in inventory forecasting, localized assortment, pricing and promotions, and stock management.
We believe our initiatives under these four growth pillars will enable us to achieve 3% to 4% top-line growth and generate strong operating cash flows this year.
This reflects our ability to maintain robust gross margins while mitigating inflationary pressures through careful cost control, pricing strategies, and store optimization.
Our 90-store optimization pilot is ongoing.
We continue to gather and analyze data from the sample, and I'm pleased to report that we're significantly surpassing our sales transfer targets.
In fiscal 2022, we plan to launch a multi-year program designed to maximize the value of our extensive store portfolio while offsetting inflationary pressures.
By streamlining our fleet, we can enhance productivity and profitability while providing a convenient omnichannel experience that benefits our customers.
We're entering fiscal 2022 with a solid infrastructure, a well-defined growth strategy, and favorable industry dynamics that support the significant opportunities ahead of us.
In the coming months, I look forward to collaborating with the team to develop additional growth opportunities that will drive our business and create substantial shareholder value in 2023 and beyond.
We're pleased to end the year with strong fourth-quarter performance, exceeding the expectations we provided in our previous earnings call and reflecting robust consumer demand as we emerge from the pandemic.
Revenue growth, solid gross margins, and careful cost management led to strong earnings and cash flow.
Net sales grew by 3.4%, and same-store sales increased by 2.1%, demonstrating strong consumer demand with only minor impacts from pandemic-related restrictions in Europe.
Fourth-quarter traffic and conversion trends remained consistent with patterns observed throughout the pandemic.
While traffic decreased, units per transaction, average unit retail, and average ticket all increased compared to the previous year.
Essentially, customers are shopping less frequently but purchasing more during each transaction with us.
Global e-commerce sales reached $71 million, accounting for 7.1% of total net sales, compared to $63 million in the prior year.
The annual growth demonstrates continued robust performance as we expand our digital capabilities and execute our strategic plans for fulfillment and customer engagement.
Regarding gross profit, we attained a fourth quarter gross margin of 50.6%, demonstrating our capacity to sustain strong performance above our 50% goal.
Compared to the previous year, gross margin decreased by 50 basis points, indicating a higher proportion of BSG sales, which had a lower margin profile during the quarter.
Regarding operating expenses, fourth quarter SG&A amounted to $387 million, a 5% increase from the previous year, mainly due to higher labor costs and planned increases in marketing expenditure.
For the upcoming fiscal year, we expect SG&A dollars to rise and the rate to increase slightly compared to the previous year.
Our forecast considers increased labor and freight costs, higher expenses planned in our international markets due to a full reopening in 2022, as well as investments across our growth areas that Denise mentioned earlier.
We believe our store optimization program will help offset wage inflation starting in the latter part of 2022 and more significantly in 2023.
Let's now discuss earnings.
We achieved strong profitability in Q4.
Adjusted operating margin was 11.7%, adjusted EBITDA margin was 14.5%, and adjusted diluted earnings per share rose to $0.64.
Examining segment results.
Sally Beauty experienced strong consumer demand in the U.S. Same-store sales grew by 2.3% and e-commerce sales totaled $29 million for the quarter.
For Sally U.S. and Canada, the color category increased by 4%, while vivid colors grew by 5%, accounting for 28% of our total color sales as comparisons normalized to the previous year.
Other categories also performed well.
Styling tools sales increased by 31% and textured hair sales rose by 16%.
Sally's gross margin decreased slightly, reflecting strong product margins offset by higher distribution and freight costs.
Segment operating margin increased to 18.1% compared to 18% in the previous year.
In the BSG segment, same-store sales grew by 1.7% as salons returned to more normal capacity levels in almost all of our U.S. markets.
E-commerce sales amounted to $42 million for the quarter.
The color category grew by 9%, hair care increased by 5% driven by Olaplex, and styling tools sales rose by 9%.
BSG's gross margin and profitability reflected the same dynamics we observed in Q3.
Specifically, we're seeing higher sales from our larger volume, full-service customers emerging from the pandemic, and these customers tend to have lower margins.
Segment operating margin decreased slightly compared to the previous year, reaching 13.3%.
Regarding the balance sheet and cash flow, we concluded fiscal 2021 in a strong financial position.
For the entire fiscal year, we generated $308 million in free cash flow and paid off approximately $420 million of debt.
We ended the quarter with $401 million in cash and cash equivalents and no outstanding balance on our asset-based revolving line of credit.
Inventories as of September 30th totaled $871 million, a 7% increase from the previous year as we reinvested in our inventory levels following pandemic-related disruptions.
Additionally, we were pleased that our strong performance throughout fiscal 2021 helped reduce our net debt leverage ratio to 1.69 times by the end of September.
Now, let's discuss our full-year fiscal 2022 guidance.
We are optimistic about the business's position heading into 2022 and expect to achieve the following: net sales growth between 3% and 4%, a net store count decrease of approximately 1% to 2% primarily driven by Sally U.S. stores as we continue to optimize our portfolio.
We anticipate gross margin expansion of 40 to 60 basis points, GAAP operating margin growth of 90 to 110 basis points, and adjusted operating margin approximately equal to 2021.
The business has shown remarkable resilience over the past 18+ months, and our teams have done an excellent job navigating the dynamic macro environment.
As the business continues to strengthen and generate strong cash flows, you can expect us to prioritize strategic growth investments and return cash to shareholders through the restart of our share buyback program.
As a reminder, during the fourth quarter, our Board of Directors approved an extension of our share repurchase program through September 2025, which currently has over $700 million remaining under the authorization.
We are also exploring opportunities to further optimize our capital structure, which could result in additional interest expense savings.
Lastly, I want to mention a housekeeping item related to disclosure.
Starting in fiscal 2022, we will replace our same-store sales metric with comparable sales, which will include sales from our full-service divisions and franchise operations, including any related e-commerce sales.
In 2022, for each quarter, we will disclose both current and prior-year comparable sales under the new definition.
I'll now ask the operator to open the call for Q&A.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today I'm accompanied by Tom Greco, our CEO and President, and Jeff Shepherd, our CFO and Executive Vice President.
We sincerely hope you and your loved ones are well and in good health.
Their unwavering commitment to delivering exceptional customer service enabled us to achieve another quarter of increased sales, improved adjusted margins, and a substantial rise in earnings per share.
We've been making investments in our team and operations over several years to transform and better utilize Advance's resources.
During the third quarter, this allowed us to match our performance on top of our strongest quarterly comparable store sales growth from 2020.
We achieved a 3.1% increase in comparable store sales while maintaining an identical 13.3% two-year stack compared to the second quarter.
As anticipated, this was driven by the ongoing recovery of our professional segment and gradual improvements in major urban markets.
By prioritizing DIY consumers and Pro customers in every decision, we've been able to swiftly adapt to changing needs.
The third quarter was characterized by an overall shift back to Professional services and a return to in-store shopping for DIY customers.
In the Professional segment, we're observing increasing strength in certain areas, as the ongoing return to office of professional workers in large urban centers catches up with the rest of the country, similar to last year's trend.
Our diverse digital and physical asset base has allowed us to quickly respond to these changing channel dynamics in the current climate.
Furthermore, we also achieved significant improvements in our adjusted gross margin rate of 246 basis points, primarily due to our category management initiatives.
Our adjusted SG&A costs as a percentage of net sales were 209 basis points higher as we compared to a unique quarter in Q3 2020.
As we've mentioned over the past year, our SG&A costs were unusually low in Q2 and Q3 of 2020.
This was due to an exceptionally high DIY sales mix and measures we implemented last year during the early stages of the pandemic, which were not repeated.
Overall, we achieved an adjusted operating income margin expansion of 37 basis points to 10.4% compared to Q3 2020.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share of $3.21 increased by 21.6% compared to Q3 2020 and 31% compared to the same period in 2019.
Our year-to-date adjusted earnings per share have increased by approximately 50% compared to 2020.
Year-to-date, our balance sheet remains robust with a 19% increase in free cash flow to $734 million, while returning a record $953 million to our shareholders through share repurchases and quarterly cash dividends.
In line with the first half of the year, several industry-related factors, combined with operational improvements, contributed to our sales growth and margin expansion in Q3.
The number of vehicles on the road continues to grow slightly.
The average age of vehicles is increasing, and perhaps most importantly, the number of miles driven continues to improve compared to both 2020 and 2019.
More broadly, the chip shortage continues to affect the availability of new vehicles and is contributing to a surge in used car sales.
This benefits our industry as consumers are keeping their vehicles longer and investing in repairs and maintenance.
As we all know, over the past 18 months, the pandemic altered consumer behavior across our industry, leading to a surge in DIY omnichannel growth in 2020, while the Professional business declined.
However, as the economy continues to reopen and miles driven steadily increase, our Professional business is now consistently surpassing pre-pandemic levels, as discussed last quarter.
Regional performance was led by the Southwest and West.
Category growth was led by brakes, motor oil, and filters as miles-driven reliant categories improved compared to the softer 2020.
We also saw continued strength in DieHard batteries, which led the way on a two-year stack basis.
Each of these categories performed well due to diligent planning between our merchant and supply chain teams, enabling a strong competitive position despite global supply chain disruptions.
At the same time, we faced challenges in Q3 as we strategically transitioned tens of thousands of undercar and engine management SKUs to our own brand.
Importantly, these in-stock positions have now significantly improved, and we're confident these initiatives will help drive future margin expansion.
Overall, comp sales were positive in all three periods of Q3, led by Professional.
DIY omnichannel delivered slightly positive comp growth in Q3, while comparing against high double-digit growth from the previous year.
Within Professional, we navigated a very challenging global supply chain environment to meet our customers' needs.
The investments we've made in our supply chain, inventory positioning, and dynamic assortment tool have put us in a favorable competitive position.
We've implemented the dynamic assortment tool in all company-owned US stores as well as over 800 independent locations.
Our MyAdvance portal and embedded Advance Pro catalog continues to be a differentiator for us, while driving online traffic.
Our online sales to Professional customers continue to grow as we enhance the speed and functionality of Advance Pro.
We remain committed to providing our industry-leading assortment of parts for all Professional customers.
This will help enable us to grow first call status and increase share of wallet in a very fragmented market.
Additionally, we expanded DieHard to our Professional customers.
Following a recent independent consumer survey, DieHard secured its claim as America's most trusted auto battery.
During Q3, we announced a multi-year agreement with our national customer Bridgestone to sell DieHard batteries in more than 2,200 tire and vehicle service centers across the United States.
With this systemwide rollout during Q3, we replaced their previous battery provider, making us the exclusive battery supplier across all Bridgestone locations.
Regarding our independent business, we added 16 net new independent Carquest stores in the quarter, bringing our total to 44 net new this year.
We continue to grow our independent business through differentiated offerings for our Carquest partners, including our new Carquest by Advance banner program, which we announced earlier this month.
As we continue to build and strengthen the Advance brand and our DIY business, Carquest by Advance adds DIY relevance for our Carquest-branded independent partners, while providing incremental traffic and margin opportunities.
We've recently rolled out this new initiative to our independent partners and look forward to further expansion over time for both new and existing Carquest independents.
Turning to DIY omnichannel, comparable store sales were slightly positive in Q3.
Our DIY omnichannel business showed robust double-digit comparable sales growth during the third quarter of 2020.
We are continuously improving our offerings and implementing our long-term plan to set our DIY business apart and gain market share.
In the third quarter, we continued to utilize our Speed Perks loyalty program effectively, with VIP membership increasing by 13% and our ELITE members, who represent the highest spending customers, growing by 21%.
The previous year, the introduction of our Advance Same Day services facilitated a significant increase in e-commerce growth.
This year, as DIY customers returned to physical stores, in-store sales led our DIY sales growth.
This was partly anticipated due to a planned decrease in inefficient online discounts, which substantially improved gross margins.
Let's discuss margin expansion.
We once again improved our adjusted operating income margin this quarter.
Similar to the second quarter, this was primarily due to category management actions within gross margin, where our key strategies played an important role.
We are now seeing benefits from our newly implemented strategic pricing tools and capabilities.
Like other businesses, we're experiencing inflation that's higher than expected.
Nevertheless, our team has been able to adapt quickly in this dynamic environment, as industry pricing remains reasonable.
Through strategic sourcing, vendor income improved compared to the previous year, alongside continued strong sales growth.
Lastly, our own brand revenue grew by double digits, outpacing our overall growth this quarter as we expanded the Carquest brand into new categories.
Carquest products have a lower unit price than comparable branded items, which as expected, reduced comp and net sales growth for the quarter.
However, the profit margin for our own brands is significantly higher and contributed to the expansion of adjusted gross margin in Q3.
Moving on to supply chain matters.
We continue to make advancements in our productivity initiatives.
In the third quarter, the benefits from these initiatives were outweighed by widely reported disruptions and inflationary pressures within the global supply chain.
Consequently, we did not leverage our supply chain during the quarter.
We finished rolling out cross-banner replenishment (CBR) for the initially planned group of stores in the quarter.
Completing this milestone is generating cost savings by reducing stem miles from our distribution centers to stores.
Throughout our implementation, our team identified additional stores that will be included over time.
Additionally, we're proceeding with the implementation of our new Warehouse Management System (WMS), which is helping to achieve further improvements in fill rate, on-hand accuracy, and productivity.
We've successfully transitioned to our new WMS in about 36% of our distribution center network, measured by unit volume.
As previously mentioned, we follow WMS with a new Labor Management System (LMS), which promotes standardization and productivity.
We're on track to complete the WMS and LMS implementations by the end of 2023, as discussed in April.
Moreover, our efforts to consolidate and integrate WORLDPAC and Autopart International (AI) are also progressing as planned, with completion expected by early next year.
This is enabling accelerated growth, gross margin expansion, and SG&A savings.
Gross margin expansion in this area comes from the expanded distribution of AI's high-margin owned brand products, such as shocks and struts, to the larger WORLDPAC customer base.
Lastly, as we expand our store network, we're also enhancing our supply chain capabilities on the West Coast by adding a much larger and more modern distribution center in San Bernardino.
This facility will serve as the consolidation point for supplier shipments for the Western US and enable rapid e-commerce delivery.
Additionally, we've begun work to consolidate our distribution center network in the Greater Toronto area.
Two separate distribution centers, one Carquest and one WORLDPAC, will be moved into a single brand-new facility that will allow us to better serve the growing demand in the Ontario market.
We continue to implement our initiatives to improve both sales and profit per store while reducing corporate SG&A.
As mentioned in our Q2 call, we faced both planned and unplanned inflationary cost pressures compared to the previous year in Q3.
SG&A challenges include higher than anticipated store labor costs per hour, increased incentive compensation, and higher delivery costs associated with the recovery of our Professional business.
Jeff will discuss these and other SG&A details shortly.
We remain on track with our sales and profit per store initiative, including our goal of achieving average sales of $1.8 million per store by 2023.
Regarding new locations year-to-date, we've opened 19 stores, six new WORLDPAC branches, and added 44 net new locations to the Carquest independent family.
This brings our net new locations to 69, including stores, branches, and independents during the first three quarters.
Separately, we're actively working to convert the 109 locations in California that we announced in April.
However, we're experiencing construction-related delays, primarily due to a much slower-than-normal permitting process.
This is attributable to stricter guidelines associated with COVID-19, which were exacerbated by the surge of the Delta variant.
We now expect the majority of store openings planned for 2021 to shift into 2022.
As a result, we're incurring start-up costs within SG&A for the remainder of the year, while realizing less than planned revenue and income.
The positive news is that we remain confident that once converted, these stores will contribute to our growth trajectory.
The final area of margin expansion is reducing our corporate and other SG&A costs.
We've begun to realize some cost benefits related to the restructuring of our corporate functions announced earlier this year, in addition to savings from our continued focus on team member safety.
In Q3, we saw a 22% reduction in our total recordable injury rate compared to the previous year.
Our rate of injuries resulting in lost time decreased by 14% compared to the equivalent period in 2020.
Employee safety is just one aspect of our broader environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives at Advance.
Our aim to propel a world in motion is exemplified by our goal, announced last April, to achieve top-tier total shareholder returns from 2021 to 2023.
While striving for this target, we're also dedicating efforts to ESG matters.
As part of this pledge, we initiated our first materiality assessment earlier this year to help prioritize our ESG efforts.
We finished this assessment in the third quarter and are now working to conclude the findings.
The outcomes will be included in our 2021 Corporate Sustainability Report, which we plan to release in mid-2022.
Before handing over to Jeff, I'd like to acknowledge our team members and generous customers for their support in our recent American Heart Association fundraiser.
This year, we implemented a new in-store technology allowing customers to round up their purchases at checkout.
This simplified customer participation and helped us achieve a record-breaking campaign total of $1.7 million.
The goals of this organization resonate deeply with everyone in the Advance family.
Our net sales grew by 3.1% to $2.6 billion in the third quarter.
Adjusted gross profit margin increased by 246 basis points to 46.2%, mainly due to our ongoing category management strategies, including strategic pricing, sourcing, private label expansion, and favorable product mix.
Similar to the previous quarter, these gains were partially offset by inflation in product and supply chain costs, as well as an unfavorable channel mix.
In this quarter, inflation for the same products was about 3.6%, which was anticipated in our annual plan and was the most significant challenge we faced within gross profit.
We're collaborating with all our suppliers to minimize costs where possible.
For the year to date, adjusted gross margin improved by 184 basis points compared to the same period in 2020.
As anticipated, our third-quarter SG&A expenses increased due to several factors we discussed earlier in the year.
As a percentage of net sales, our adjusted SG&A increased by 209 basis points, primarily due to labor costs, which included a significant increase in hourly rates and higher incentive compensation compared to the previous year.
We also incurred higher delivery expenses for serving our Professional customers and about $10 million in startup costs related to the conversion of our California locations in the third quarter.
Year-to-date, SG&A as a percentage of net sales remained relatively stable compared to the same period in 2020, increasing by only 9 basis points year-over-year.
While we've reduced our COVID-19-related expenses by $13 million year-to-date, the health and safety of our team members and customers remains our top priority.
Our adjusted operating income rose to $274 million in the third quarter, compared to $256 million a year ago.
On a rate basis, our adjusted operating income margin expanded by 37 basis points to 10.4%.
Our adjusted diluted earnings per share increased by 21.6% to $3.21, compared to $2.64 in the third quarter of 2020.
Compared to 2019, adjusted diluted earnings per share was up 31% in the quarter.
Our free cash flow for the first nine months of the year was $734 million, a 19% increase from last year.
This increase was primarily driven by improvements in our operating income and our continued focus on working capital metrics, including our accounts payable ratio, which expanded by 351 basis points compared to the third quarter of 2020.
Our capital investments for the first three quarters of the year totaled $191 million.
We continue to prioritize maintaining adequate liquidity while returning excess cash to shareholders.
In the third quarter, we returned approximately $228 million to our shareholders by repurchasing 1.1 million shares at an average price of $205.65.
Year-to-date, we've returned approximately $792 million to our shareholders by repurchasing nearly 4.2 million shares at an average price of $189.43.
Since restarting our share repurchase program in the third quarter of 2018, we've returned over $2 billion through share repurchases at an average share price of about $164.
Additionally, we paid a cash dividend of $1 per share in the quarter, totaling $63 million.
We remain confident in our ability to generate substantial cash from our business and expect to return excess cash to our shareholders through a balanced approach of dividends and buybacks.
As disclosed in yesterday's SEC 8-K filing, we recently completed the refinancing of our new five-year revolving credit facility.
The previous facility was due to expire in January 2023, and with bank markets returning to pre-pandemic levels, we took the opportunity to secure our liquidity for another five years.
This included improved pricing and terms while also increasing the overall facility size to $1.2 billion.
We have strong relationships with our banks, and this commitment allows us to secure future financial flexibility.
More details about this facility can be found in our 8-K filings.
Regarding our updated full-year outlook, we are raising our 2021 sales and profit guidance to reflect positive year-to-date results and our expectations for the rest of the year.
In the first four weeks of the fourth quarter, we continue to see sales strength in our two-year stack, remaining consistent with what we delivered in the last two quarters.
This guidance incorporates continued top-line strength, ongoing inflationary pressures, and up to an additional $10 million in startup costs in the fourth quarter related to our West Coast expansion.
As mentioned, the construction environment in California remains challenging, resulting in a reduction of our guidance for new store openings and capital expenditures.
Consequently, we're updating our full-year 2021 guidance to net sales of $10.9 billion to $10.95 billion, comparable store sales of 9.5% to 10%, adjusted operating income margin rate of 9.4% to 9.5%, a minimum of 30 new stores this year, a minimum of $275 million in capital expenditures, and a minimum of $725 million in free cash flow.
In conclusion, we're very excited about our current momentum and remain focused on executing our long-term strategy while delivering top-quartile total shareholder return over the 2021 to 2023 period.
Summary:

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The presentation includes certain non-standard financial metrics.
Let's now examine our financial performance for the third quarter of fiscal 2021.
Despite ongoing operational challenges due to COVID-19, we are quite satisfied with our quarterly and full ski season results for 2020-2021 in North America.
Performance improved as the season advanced, mainly due to increased destination visits at our Colorado and Utah locations, including better lift ticket sales compared to the previous quarter.
The third quarter saw only a 3% decline in destination, mountain resort, and regional ski area visits compared to the same period in fiscal 2019.
Whistler Blackcomb's performance suffered due to Canada's closed borders preventing international visitors, including Americans, and an unexpected early closure on March 30, 2021, following a health order from British Columbia's government.
Whistler Blackcomb experienced nearly a 60% drop in total visits for the third quarter compared to the same period in fiscal 2019.
Although visitation and revenue trends improved throughout the quarter, our additional business lines continued to be significantly affected by COVID-19-related restrictions, especially in food and beverage services and ski instruction.
We maintained strict cost control measures throughout the quarter and continued to operate our additional business lines at reduced capacity.
As previously mentioned, we are very pleased with our overall quarterly results and the full 2020-2021 North American ski season performance.
It's worth noting that in the previous year, we announced the premature closure of our 2019-2020 North American ski season for all ski areas, lodging facilities, and retail rental stores due to the COVID-19 pandemic, beginning March 15, 2020.
These actions significantly impacted our financial results for the third fiscal quarter of 2020.
Furthermore, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and resulting operational restrictions continued to negatively affect our results for the third fiscal quarter of 2021.
Vail Resorts reported a net income of $274.6 million or $6.72 per diluted share for the third quarter of fiscal 2021, compared to $152.5 million or $3.74 per diluted share in the same period last year.
The resort reported EBITDA of $462.2 million in the third fiscal quarter, compared to $304.4 million in the same period last year.
The current year's ski season saw particularly strong demand at our Colorado and Utah destination resorts.
The resort-reported EBITDA margin for the third quarter was 52%, surpassing both the previous year's 43.9% and the fiscal 2019 third quarter's 50.2%.
These results demonstrate our stringent approach to cost management and a higher proportion of lift revenue compared to other business lines relative to previous periods.
Let's now consider our projections for fiscal 2021.
Vail Resorts, Inc. anticipates a fiscal 2021 net income between $93 million and $139 million.
The company projects a resort-reported EBITDA range of $530 million to $570 million for fiscal 2021, with an estimated margin of about 28.9% based on the midpoint of the guidance range.
Our forecast assumes all operations are functioning in accordance with current health protocols and capacity limits.
Present demand patterns are expected to persist.
We anticipate normal weather conditions for Australia's East season and North America's summer season, without any impact from potential COVID-19-related closures.
The forecast specifically excludes any effects from possible demand or operational disruptions linked to the ongoing lockdowns in Victoria, Australia.
We maintain a robust liquidity position.
As of April 30, 2021, our total cash and available credit amounted to roughly $2 billion, comprising $1.3 billion in cash, $419 million in U.S. credit availability under the Vail Holdings agreement, and $203 million under the Whistler Credit Agreement.
Our net debt stood at 2.8 times the trailing 12-month total reported EBITDA as of April 30, 2021.
We remain optimistic about our business model's strong cash flow generation and stability, and will continue to prudently manage our capital, prioritizing high-return projects, ongoing investment in our workforce, and strategic acquisition opportunities.
Although we are not reinstating the dividend this quarter, we remain dedicated to returning capital to shareholders, and our board will regularly assess the economic and public health situation to determine the appropriate time for dividend reinstatement.
We are highly satisfied with our season pass sales to date, with customers showing great enthusiasm for our pass products' enhanced value proposition, partly driven by the 20% price reduction for all passes in the upcoming season.
Pass product sales for the 2021-2022 North American ski season through June 1, 2021, saw a significant increase compared to sales through June 2, 2020, for the 2020-2021 season, though this comparison is not indicative of performance trends due to the absence of spring sales deadlines in 2020 because of COVID-19.
In comparison to sales for the 2019-2020 North American ski season through June 4, 2019, pass product sales for the 2021-2022 season up to June 1, 2021, increased by about 50% in units and 33% in sales dollars.
The pass product sales figures are adjusted to include Peak Resorts' pass sales in both periods and eliminate currency fluctuations by applying a consistent exchange rate of $0.83 between the Canadian and U.S. dollars for Whistler Blackcomb in both periods.
For context, pass product sales for the entire selling season through December 6, 2020, compared to the full season through December 8, 2019, increased by approximately 20% in units and 19% in sales dollars.
Compared to pass product sales for the 2019-2020 season through June 4, 2019, we observed robust unit growth among renewing passholders and even stronger growth among new passholders, including previous lift ticket or pass buyers who didn't purchase a pass last season and completely new customers.
We experienced our most significant unit growth in destination markets, particularly in the Northeast, and also saw strong growth across our local markets.
Relative to the period ending June 4, 2019, the effective pass price decreased by 10%, compared to the 20% price reduction we implemented this year.
Our reduced pricing strategy has encouraged passholders to allocate part of their savings towards purchasing more expensive pass options.
We anticipated that lowering prices would lead to higher renewal rates, upgrades to premium passes, and attract more visitors to our facilities.
We are optimistic about these emerging trends in pass sales, which we believe support our projections for the upcoming year and the anticipated long-term advantages of enhancing customer lifetime value.
The outcomes of pass sales surpassed our initial projections regarding the impact of the 20% price cut.
Nevertheless, the majority of our pass selling period is still ahead, and it remains uncertain whether these trends will persist through autumn.
Furthermore, we are delighted that ongoing Epic Australia pass sales, concluding on June 15, 2021, have increased by approximately 43% in units through June 1, 2021, compared to the same period ending June 4, 2019, indicating significant growth following the acquisition of Falls Creek and Hotham in April 2019.
In light of the recent COVID-19-related restrictions in Victoria, Australia, we will be monitoring any potential effects on Epic Australia pass sales.
Investing in our resorts and enhancing guest experiences remains one of our top priorities.
As previously disclosed, we will be completing several key projects this summer and fall, subject to regulatory approvals.
In Colorado, we are proceeding with a 250-acre lift-served terrain expansion in Beaver Creek's signature McCoy Park area, further enhancing the resort's upscale family-oriented experience.
We also intend to install a new four-person high-speed lift at Breckenridge to serve the popular Peak 7, replace Keystone's Peru lift with a six-person high-speed chairlift, and upgrade Crested Butte's Peachtree lift to a new three-person fixed-grip lift.
At Okemo, we plan to complete a transportation improvement project, including upgrading the Quantum lift from a four-person to a six-person high-speed chairlift and relocating the existing four-person Quantum lift to replace the Green Ridge three-person fixed-grip chairlift.
These enhancements will significantly improve uplift capacity, further elevate the guest experience, and fulfill our $35 million capital plan for the season.
We continue to prioritize investments that will advance our company-wide technological improvements to support our data-driven approach, guest experience, and corporate infrastructure.
As part of these initiatives, we are investing in resources and technology to enhance our customer service, including significant increases in call center staffing and self-service technology that will enable our guests to better manage their own accounts.
We will also maintain our investment in ongoing maintenance capital to support infrastructure across our resorts.
As we approach the coming year, we recognize that talent and staffing will be crucial to our success, as always.
We have announced plans to increase our minimum entry wages in Colorado, Utah, Washington, and California to $15 per hour, while also implementing substantial increases in entry wages at our Eastern resorts, which will be determined based on local market conditions.
This represents our largest discretionary investment in operating expenses this year, which we believe will be partially offset by other savings we will carry forward from this year to the next.
I am profoundly grateful for the dedication our teams continue to demonstrate throughout these unprecedented circumstances.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We released our Q4 and full-year 2020 financial results earlier today.
You can find the report on our company website at oshkoshcorp.com.
Our speakers today are Wilson Jones, CEO; John Pfeifer, President and COO; and Mike Pack, EVP and CFO.
I remain extremely impressed by the diligence and focused execution of Oshkosh employees as we navigate the ongoing challenges posed by the COVID-19 crisis.
It's worth emphasizing again that our employee-centric culture has been crucial in achieving strong results despite adversity.
Dedicated Oshkosh staff and their commitment to our robust culture enabled us to surmount major obstacles this year, including unpredictable customer demand, supply chain disruptions, workforce shortages, and numerous other issues.
I want to express my sincere gratitude to all 15,000 of our employees and our loyal suppliers who have worked tirelessly and risen to the occasion during these difficult times to continue meeting our customers' expectations.
As a reminder, our Q4 call differs slightly from other quarterly calls as I'll discuss both quarterly highlights and full-year results before handing over to John and Mike.
In Q4, we achieved sales of nearly $1.8 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $1.30.
Similar to our Q3 performance, we've managed the factors within our control while swiftly addressing challenges beyond our influence.
This approach allowed us to increase adjusted operating income in our defense, fire & emergency, and commercial segments compared to last year, while achieving consolidated adjusted decremental margins of 19%.
In our largest segment, access equipment, we delivered 23% adjusted decremental margins during a quarter where revenues declined by nearly 40%.
John will provide more details on individual segments, but the access equipment markets in North America and Europe remain weak, and the timing of recovery is uncertain.
We're encouraged by utilization data nearing pre-pandemic levels and believe the market is stabilizing.
We'll be closely monitoring rental industry metrics and engaging in annual purchase discussions with our customers in the coming months.
We're announcing a 10% increase in our quarterly cash dividend to $0.33 per share.
This marks our seventh consecutive annual increase and reflects our confidence in our business model and long-term outlook.
Undoubtedly, 2020 has been one of the most memorable years in recent history due to the global pandemic's significant disruptions, and I'm proud of our team's efforts and achievements.
For instance, our access equipment segment overcame a nearly $1.6 billion year-over-year sales decline to deliver an impressive 8.5% full-year adjusted operating margin.
Our fire & emergency segment achieved two consecutive quarters of record adjusted operating margin percentages to end the year.
Our commercial segment posted its highest full-year adjusted operating income margin in over a decade at 7.5%.
Defense successfully ramped up the JLTV program despite numerous pandemic-related challenges.
These accomplishments amid the pandemic demonstrate our strengths as a diversified global industrial company.
We concluded the year strongly with solid Q4 performance.
Throughout the year, we implemented both temporary and permanent cost-cutting measures across the company.
Mike will discuss how these actions will impact our 2021 cost structure in his section.
I'd like to highlight some of our teams' excellent work in corporate responsibility, focusing on ESG.
While we don't typically discuss ESG metrics on earnings calls, our efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and energy usage, along with our employee engagement and safety performance, are among many areas that we believe set Oshkosh apart from other companies.
We continue to receive recognition from agencies that track and evaluate company performance on these important non-financial measures, which we believe further underscores our commitment to excellence, long-term value, and sustainability.
Wilson mentioned the pandemic, and I'd like to provide an update since several of our facilities, including our headquarters, are in a Wisconsin region currently experiencing some of the nation's highest COVID-19 spread rates.
Across the company, we've focused on maintaining employee safety and preventing virus spread, with a good track record in doing so.
However, the recent resurgence is creating some workforce availability and supplier delivery challenges.
It's crucial that we maintain robust safety procedures that meet or exceed CDC guidelines.
This is challenging as many of us are experiencing pandemic fatigue.
But like Wilson, I'm proud of our team members and our ability to stay focused and effective.
Let's begin our segment discussions with access equipment.
We've been carefully managing our access equipment business during a period of significant double-digit sales declines while still delivering strong adjusted decremental margins and impressive overall adjusted operating margins.
In fact, we've set a new benchmark for financial performance during an industry downturn.
We appreciate our team members' efforts and performance during these times.
Our positive Q4 results are significant, given the low demand for access equipment, primarily resulting from lower equipment utilization, leading to reduced capital expenditure by rental company customers in North America and Europe.
Q4 sales were down nearly 40%, so we continue to operate our facilities on reduced schedules.
We've implemented both temporary and permanent cost reduction measures in the business as we weather this challenging period.
This approach is considered responsible in our view.
We continue to invest in JLG as the industry's innovation leader, and we remain optimistic about its long-term prospects, which is crucial to highlight.
We anticipate releasing innovative products in the future as a result of our ongoing investments.
We are striking a delicate balance between cost-cutting measures and the ability to increase production when market conditions improve.
For approximately half of the available production weeks in the first quarter, our U.S. facilities will operate at reduced capacity.
As circumstances change and our customers inform us of their plans, we will make decisions for the rest of 2021.
To meet demand when the market rebounds, we are keeping our workforce engaged.
We are maintaining close contact with our suppliers, as they are crucial to our ability to ramp up production when the market recovers.
According to recent data, North American fleets are aging, with aerial equipment averaging around 55 months old, which we believe is a positive indicator for future demand.
While we are confident in the recovery of the North American access equipment market, the exact timing remains unclear.
We anticipate lower sales in the first half of the year compared to the previous year.
We are in the early stages of discussions with our rental company customers and expect to have a clearer picture of the second half of the year before our next earnings call.
As mentioned last quarter, China's economy continues to recover, which we believe will lead to double-digit sales growth in the region for the foreseeable future.
Our defense segment performed well this quarter but has been facing workforce availability challenges due to the pandemic's significant impact on our ability to schedule personnel and production.
Despite these difficulties, which intensified late in the fourth quarter and continued into early this month, our operations teams have delivered strong results for our U.S. government customer and increased revenues by over 11% for the year.
The successful expansion of the JLTV program throughout the year has been a key factor and provides a solid foundation as part of our large backlog in the segment.
In October, our team was pleased to receive an expected order for 322 JLTVs from the Belgian Ministry of Defense.
The contract with our NATO ally, valued at more than €115 million, further demonstrates our success with the world's best light protected tactical wheeled vehicle.
We plan to begin shipping the vehicles in 2023 and anticipate announcing more international JLTV orders in 2021.
We won this order by competing against an established competitor, which we believe showcases the superior cost and performance characteristics of the JLTV product.
I'd like to address the recently enacted Continuing Resolution, or CR.
While CRs were once uncommon for government funding, they have become standard practice over the past 10 to 12 years.
Our programs of record remain funded under the CR, so it does not pose an issue for 2021.
Fire & Emergency achieved a record-breaking quarterly adjusted operating income of 16.4% in the fourth quarter.
Our F&E team has performed exceptionally well, navigating through supplier issues, customer travel restrictions, and other operational challenges, many of which were caused by COVID-19.
The simplification strategy adopted by F&E several years ago, combined with cutting-edge product innovation, provides the framework for the team to operate its business at such a high level.
We are ending the year with a strong backlog, supported by a record-breaking order year of nearly $1.3 billion, despite the negative impacts of COVID-19.
Aging fire truck fleets and the availability of new technologies support our positive long-term outlook for the F&E market.
However, tight municipal budgets may limit demand in the near term.
Fire & Emergency is prepared to face this challenge with a market-leading lineup of high-quality custom and commercial fire trucks and RF units.
We continue to invest in new technologies, such as our Fotokite Situational Awareness System and alternative powertrain options, which you'll hear more about in the coming quarters.
Our commercial segment has consistently improved throughout the year despite pandemic-related challenges.
The team delivered strong margins and higher year-over-year adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter, even with lower revenues.
Our commercial team achieved its highest full-year adjusted operating income margin in over a decade.
This is particularly impressive given the market impacts from COVID-19, which halted construction in many areas of the country and temporarily reduced demand for waste collection at businesses earlier in the year.
Much of our recent success can be attributed to simplification efforts, disciplined cost management, and the introduction of our new S-Series 2.0 Front Discharge Concrete Mixer, which is generating excitement and helping us win new customers.
During our last call, we announced restructuring plans to move rear discharge concrete mixer production from Minnesota to Ontario, Canada, as part of our strategy to simplify the business with a focused factory approach.
I'm pleased to report that the transition is progressing as planned, and we expect a successful completion over the next few months.
We believe this will position us to drive sustained margin improvements.
Before concluding this segment, I want to mention our commitment to electrification as a means to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and provide our customers with options for their future fleet plans.
Early in the fourth quarter, several companies announced plans for electric RCVs in the U.S. market.
We are proud to be working on electrification solutions across all of our businesses at Oshkosh.
This is especially applicable to RCVs, as we are collaborating with a chassis manufacturer to supply five electric RCV units for use in Boise, Idaho during the summer of 2021.
I want to conclude by commenting on the positive attitude and culture we observe from the commercial team.
Their hard work in driving business and operational improvements, along with their commitment and dedication, is unparalleled and reflected in our results.
This concludes our discussion of our business segments.
Effective execution enabled us to achieve 19% adjusted decremental margins overall and 23% adjusted decremental margins in access equipment during the fourth quarter.
Total net sales for the quarter were $1.8 billion, representing an 18.7% decrease compared to the same quarter last year.
The main factor contributing to the decline was a 39% reduction in access equipment segment sales.
Access equipment sales were adversely affected by reduced customer demand, primarily due to COVID-19.
As John noted, our customers remain wary about purchasing equipment due to uncertainties surrounding the pandemic and the associated weakness in nonresidential construction activity.
The consolidated adjusted operating income for the fourth quarter was $124.1 million or 7% of sales, compared to $203.1 million or 9.2% of sales in the same quarter of the previous year.
Access equipment segment adjusted operating income decreased due to lower sales and unfavorable manufacturing absorption resulting from planned shutdowns during the quarter, partially offset by the benefits of temporary cost reduction measures related to COVID-19.
Defense segment adjusted operating income rose due to improved product mix and higher sales volume, partially counterbalanced by less favorable cumulative contract adjustments and increased engineering and proposal expenses in the current year quarter.
Fire & emergency segment operating income increased in the current year quarter due to improved price-cost dynamics and better absorption, partially offset by lower sales volume.
Commercial segment fourth quarter adjusted operating income grew due to reduced spending in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and favorable material costs, partially offset by unfavorable product mix and lower sales volume.
Adjusted earnings per share for the quarter were $1.30, compared to $2.17 in the fourth quarter of 2019.
The fourth quarter results were boosted by $0.02 per share from share repurchases completed in the previous 12 months.
Lastly, we generated robust free cash flow during the quarter, resulting in a full-year free cash flow of $238 million.
This is a commendable achievement in a year marked by rapid declines in customer demand, which put pressure on working capital.
The COVID-19 pandemic continues to create uncertainty in the timing of customer demand in both our access equipment and commercial segments.
On the other hand, strong backlogs in our defense and fire & emergency segments provide good visibility well into 2021.
However, as John mentioned earlier, recent increases in COVID-19 infection rates are causing workforce availability and supply chain issues, particularly in Wisconsin, where a significant portion of production for our defense and fire & emergency segments takes place.
This situation is creating production and labor efficiency risks for these two segments and is also likely to impact final truck inspections by customers in the fire & emergency segment.
Considering these factors, including the ongoing uncertainty of the pandemic, we are not in a position to provide quantitative expectations for 2021 at this time.
We are actively engaging in discussions with our key customers in the access equipment and commercial segments to understand their requirements for 2021, but we anticipate softer year-over-year demand in the first half of 2021 compared to 2020.
The demand for access equipment remains uncertain for the second half of the year, but we expect to have better clarity during the first quarter earnings call as we gain further insight into the trajectory of the pandemic and our customer requirements for 2021.
At access equipment, we are implementing two-week production shutdowns per month in the United States during the first quarter of 2021 to better align production with customer requirements.
In the second quarter of 2020, we implemented decisive actions that reduced our 2020 pre-tax costs by approximately $120 million.
The reductions were evenly distributed across three areas: salary reductions and furloughs, incentive compensation, and project travel and other discretionary spending.
As we previously discussed, these cost reductions were largely temporary, and we expect them to return to our expense run rate in 2021.
Additionally, we discussed permanent cost reduction actions during our last earnings call in the access equipment and commercial segments, totaling $30 million to $35 million once complete.
We anticipate these actions will benefit 2021 by approximately $20 million.
Recently, we implemented additional permanent cost reductions totaling $15 million for 2021, which reduced corporate and segment operating expenses.
Therefore, we expect to benefit from a total of $35 million in permanent cost reductions in 2021, growing to $45 million to $50 million by 2022.
The return of costs that drove the temporary cost reductions in 2020 will be a challenge to margins in 2021.
However, we continue to manage our business in a disciplined manner and will respond to ongoing uncertainty with our established strategies.
Our balance sheet remains strong with available liquidity of approximately $1.4 billion, consisting of cash of approximately $600 million and availability under our revolving line of credit of approximately $800 million.
We expect a modest increase in capital expenditures to approximately $120 million in 2021.
While we are not providing quantitative financial expectations today, we expect to provide them later in the year.
We have just completed a year in which we delivered nearly $5 of adjusted earnings per share amid a global pandemic, and we believe we are well-positioned moving into 2021 with our strong balance sheet and cash position.
Our defense and fire & emergency backlogs provide visibility well into 2021, and we took aggressive actions early during the pandemic to lower our costs.
Our culture at Oshkosh is strong, and we have an outstanding group of leaders and team members who have effectively managed production and supply chain disruptions and kept Oshkosh on a positive path since the pandemic began.
We can't let up as the threat is still present, but I'm reassured by the strength and resilience of our people and believe we will deliver solid sales and earnings performance over the long term.
Summary:

q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.30 excluding items.
compname announces 10 percent increase in quarterly cash dividend to $0.33 per share.
not providing a quantitative outlook for fiscal 2021.
consolidated net sales in q4 of fiscal 2020 decreased 18.7 percent to $1.78 billion.

The company reported Q4 sales of $1.8 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $1.30. The access equipment segment was impacted by reduced customer demand, but the defense and fire & emergency segments performed well. The company implemented cost-cutting measures and reduced its debt. Oshkosh expects to provide quantitative financial expectations later in the year. The company's balance sheet remains strong, and it has a strong backlog in its defense and fire & emergency segments. The company is well-positioned to deliver solid sales and earnings performance over the long term. The company is committed to electrification and is working on solutions across all its businesses.
