Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:AMG began 2021 in a robust position, with our first-quarter results reflecting the ongoing momentum in our operations.
The company's economic earnings per share of $4.28 showed a 35% year-over-year increase, marking our strongest first quarter ever, primarily due to a 23% growth in EBITDA and continued share buybacks.
We anticipate accelerated growth in our business for the second quarter and throughout 2021, driven by exceptional affiliate investment performance, the impact of our strategic initiatives, and notably, increased activity and new investments.
Our growing free cash flow and available capital, combined with a favorable environment for establishing new partnerships, present a significant opportunity to invest in high-quality firms in areas of secular growth, as demonstrated by our recent investments in OCP Asia and Boston Common.
By executing our strategy diligently, including returning excess capital to shareholders, we will further enhance our earnings and free cash flow generation, positioning us to create substantial long-term shareholder value.
Over the past year, our affiliates have built upon their long-term performance records, showcasing their ability to excel during volatile periods.
Outstanding investment performance during this time resulted in substantial first-quarter performance fees, increased asset levels, and improved organic growth.
As performance-driven improvements in organic growth trends continue across our business, we're observing investors reallocating portfolios as economies reopen globally.
Investors are allocating more funds to high-quality active managers, particularly independent firms, to navigate market volatility, safeguard capital, and achieve superior outcomes.
AMG is benefiting from increased demand for fundamental equities and liquid alternatives, especially in our top-performing value-oriented affiliates and active ESG strategies, in addition to ongoing growth in private markets, specialty fixed income, and wealth management.
We expect our organic flow profile to continue improving as these trends persist and as we add new affiliates operating in areas of secular demand.
AMG-led distribution efforts are contributing additional growth and momentum to our affiliates' new business activities, further supporting this improving profile.
Nearly two decades ago, we began developing AMG-led distribution resources to complement our affiliates' existing sales efforts.
Over the past two years, we strategically evolved our platform to benefit our affiliate partners and their clients, focusing on the largest growth opportunities while better aligning our affiliates' in-demand products with the success of AMG distribution efforts.
We have repositioned our U.S. retail wealth distribution, aligning it with our institutional distribution strategy.
This change offers a more competitively priced, higher quality, and more differentiated set of strategies exclusively managed by AMG affiliates.
With this repositioning complete, our distribution platforms are now more strategically compelling to both existing and new affiliates, as well as our clients, due to increased focus, resources, and alignment.
As part of our strategy, we will continue to evolve our AMG-led distribution resources to reflect the changing composition and needs of our affiliates and their clients over time.
AMG's enduring business model, which provides a permanent solution for independent firms, allows us to be a true strategic partner to our affiliates, distinct from any institutional competitor in the market today.
Our partnership model is straightforward: we enhance our affiliates' ability to grow across generations while preserving their investment independence and operational autonomy.
We offer a uniquely broad set of partnership solutions to independent firms, having expanded our offerings over the years beyond succession planning to include minority investments, growth capital, and centralized distribution services on behalf of our affiliates.
As a result of this evolution and our strong competitive position, AMG's partnership approach is now even more attractive to a wider range of independent firms worldwide.
Our new investment strategy is generating both growth and returns.
Our partnership approach not only self-selects for growing firms, but our discipline in structuring new investments also generates meaningful returns for our shareholders across various business outcomes.
Over the past two years, we have significantly increased our focus and resources devoted to identifying and executing new partnerships with independent firms.
We have concentrated our prospecting efforts on independent firms operating in areas of strong secular growth and client demand, including private markets, fixed income alternatives, the Asia Pacific region, ESG, and multi-asset solutions.
With this enhanced focus, we expect new investments to be a significant source of future earnings growth.
As we continue to execute on our growing opportunity set throughout 2021, each new affiliate will immediately contribute to our earnings.
The full impact of AMG's earnings power and growth profile will become fully apparent starting in 2022.
Demonstrating the momentum in new investments, we recently announced our second partnership this year.
OCP Asia, recognized as a leader in Asian private credit, has consistently delivered excellent returns for its clients.
There is strong cultural alignment between AMG and OCP Asia, and OCP's key principals were attracted to our partnership approach and the opportunity to expand their client reach through our global distribution capabilities.
This new partnership enhances and diversifies our exposure to both private markets and Asia, where we see increasing allocations.
We are excited to partner with Stu, Teall, Dan, and the broader team as they continue to provide differentiated investment returns and capitalize on their growth initiatives.
The strategic and growth investments made in the past two years are beginning to show results and will become more apparent in upcoming quarters.
Since early 2019, we've added six new affiliates to our portfolio.
We have put resources into expanding our current affiliates.
We've expanded our range of partnership solutions.
Our strategic capabilities have been improved.
We have restructured our distribution platform.
We've significantly strengthened our capital position and bought back nearly a fifth of our outstanding shares.
We've accomplished all this while revitalizing AMG's entrepreneurial spirit and re-establishing an ownership mentality throughout the organization.
Looking forward, our business has considerable momentum, and we anticipate AMG's growth to accelerate.
With strong affiliate investment performance, improving organic growth outlook, and increasing opportunities to invest in excellent partner-owned firms, we're confident in our ability to capitalize on our substantial opportunities and continue to create value for shareholders.
As mentioned in our fourth-quarter discussion, focused execution of our strategy is yielding significant growth, as evidenced once again by our strong first quarter performance.
Our earnings power and cash flow generation are increasing, and our unique ability to deploy capital across a wide range of opportunities to grow EBITDA and earnings per share sets us apart.
Looking ahead, our value proposition for independent partner-owned firms, combined with an increasingly favorable environment for active managers, positions AMG well to compound earnings growth over time and generate substantial shareholder value.
Our first-quarter results demonstrate the significant momentum we're experiencing across our business.
Adjusted EBITDA grew 23% year-over-year to $247 million, driven by strong affiliate investment performance and the impact of our growth investments.
Economic earnings per share increased by 35% year-over-year to $4.28, further boosted by share repurchase activity.
Net client cash flows for the quarter showed significant improvement compared to previous periods, with flows representing the majority of our EBITDA turning positive, excluding certain quantitative strategies.
Continued strength in private markets, specialty fixed income, and wealth management strategies continue to drive strong flows.
Increased demand for fundamental equity and liquid alternatives, particularly top-performing value and impact-oriented strategies, also contributed as clients adjust their portfolios for a post-pandemic world.
Examining performance across our business, excluding certain quantitative strategies:
In alternatives, fundraising remains robust at Pantheon, Baring, EIG, and Comvest as clients steadily increase global private market allocations, resulting in net inflows of $2.8 billion in the first quarter.
Performance in this category is exceptional, with our affiliates deploying dry powder into attractive return opportunities, including Asia private equity, global secondaries, coinvestments, and credit.
Our private markets segment continues to be a significant source of earnings growth, accounting for nearly 20% of management fee EBITDA with increasing future carried interest potential.
We continue to add high-quality partnerships in this sector, including our investment in OCP Asia, which I'll discuss further shortly.
In liquid alternatives, our affiliates are delivering strong performance across relative value fixed income amid ongoing bond market volatility, as well as in concentrated long-only strategies.
We're seeing increased client interest in this category as investors seek alternative sources of yield and return.
Capula, Garda, and ValueAct continue to generate excellent investment performance, resulting in strong performance fees and demonstrating the attractiveness and resilience of these strategies.
In fundamental equities, we continue to see strong performance across various affiliates.
U.S. equities reported net inflows of $300 million.
The outperformance of value strategies following a decade of headwinds is leading to increased client conversations, benefiting high-quality independent firms like River Road and Yacktman.
Global equities experienced net outflows of $3.9 billion, driven by redemptions in regionally focused strategies.
Affiliates continue to deliver strong investment performance across various strategies, including at Harding Loevner, Veritas, and Artemis.
Multi-asset and fixed income strategies continue to generate steady long-duration inflows, and we expect ongoing client demand trends to support future growth.
These strategies produced $900 million in net client cash flows during the quarter, primarily driven by ongoing demand for municipal bond strategies at GW&K and stable growth across our wealth management affiliates.
Affiliate investment performance and capital inflow trends are progressing positively as customers increasingly seek independent active managers for superior investment results.
We are shifting our business focus towards areas of long-term growth through investments in current and new affiliates, which will improve our organic growth outlook in the future.
Let's now examine the financial details.
In the first quarter, adjusted EBITDA reached $247 million, showing a 23% increase compared to the previous year, primarily due to strong affiliate investment results.
The adjusted EBITDA included $42 million in performance fees, reflecting exceptional results in certain liquid alternative strategies.
Economic earnings per share grew by 35% year-over-year to $4.28, further enhanced by share buyback activities.
Now let's discuss specific modeling elements for the upcoming quarter.
We anticipate adjusted EBITDA to range between $210 million and $220 million based on current AUM levels, reflecting our market blend, which saw a 3% increase as of last Friday.
This estimate includes performance fees up to $10 million and the impact of our latest investments in OCP Asia and Boston Common.
It's worth noting that the second and third quarters typically have lower performance fees due to the timing of performance fee crystallization.
Our share of interest expense was $27 million in the first quarter, and we expect it to remain similar in the second quarter.
Controlling interest depreciation was $2 million in the first quarter, with a similar level expected for the second quarter.
Our share of reported amortization and impairments totaled $41 million in the first quarter, with an expected decrease to $35 million in the second quarter.
Our effective GAAP and cash tax rates were 24% and 20% respectively in the first quarter, with similar levels expected for the second quarter.
Intangible-related deferred taxes amounted to $9 million in the first quarter, with an expected increase to $11 million in the second quarter.
Other economic items were negative $15 million, including the mark-to-market impact on GP and seed capital investments.
For the second quarter, we anticipate other economic items, excluding any mark-to-market impact on GP and seed, to be $1 million for modeling purposes.
Our adjusted weighted average share count for the first quarter was 43.2 million, with an expected decrease to approximately 42.4 million for the second quarter.
Regarding our balance sheet and capital allocation, we are in an excellent position with substantial liquidity access and a flexible long-term debt profile.
We continue to seek ways to enhance our capital structure.
Our strong and growing free cash flow allows us to invest capital through disciplined strategy execution, including new investment partnerships that create significant long-term value.
We prioritize investing in high-growth businesses in areas of sustained demand.
New investments generally grow faster than our existing business in terms of both cash flows and revenues, enhancing our organic growth profile and EBITDA growth.
These new investments not only contribute immediately to our EBITDA but also allow us to finance a portion of the purchase price with debt and often achieve additional tax benefits, improving returns for our shareholders.
As we implement our strategy, we maintain a disciplined approach to pricing and structure, aiming for risk-adjusted returns well above our cost of capital across various potential scenarios.
Overall, new investments generate immediate earnings and organic growth while being strategically crucial for the long-term growth and sustainability of our business.
Our recent investment in OCP Asia exemplifies the value of investing in new affiliates.
We acquired a minority stake in the company through a revenue-sharing agreement, with a structure designed to minimize earnings volatility.
The business is experiencing double-digit organic growth and is priced to deliver attractive returns across various scenarios.
We anticipate the investment will contribute an additional $0.20 to economic earnings per share in 2021 and $0.33 in 2022, including $16 million of EBITDA in 2022.
Our renewed emphasis on disciplined capital allocation ensures that every dollar invested is evaluated using a common framework, allowing us to make growth investments that clearly meet our risk and return criteria while returning excess capital to shareholders through share repurchases.
In the first quarter, we bought back $210 million worth of shares, bringing our total share repurchases to nearly 20% of outstanding shares over the past two years.
We aim to continue reducing our share count through repurchases over time and remain on track to repurchase $500 million of shares this year, subject to market conditions and the timing of new investments.
We are well-positioned to compound earnings growth through new investments, investment performance, cash flows, and share repurchases.
The momentum in our business is accelerating, and the combination of our strategy, capital position, and favorable investment environment for growth highlight the numerous reasons to be optimistic about AMG's future.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today I'm joined by Rodney McMullen, Kroger's chairman and CEO, as well as CFO Gary Millerchip.
Our SEC filings provide an in-depth analysis of factors that could significantly impact our business operations.
We'll be hosting a business update with a tour of our new Kroger delivery fulfillment center in Florida on March 4, 2022.
We're hoping you can attend.
The holiday season is when we typically excel.
As we progress through the holidays, we're confident in our ability to deliver.
We're extremely pleased with our third quarter performance and the ongoing momentum in our operations.
We achieved positive identical sales excluding fuel for the quarter.
Our digital sales grew by triple digits on a two-year stack, and we've revised our full year 2021 forecast upwards.
Our adaptability and the dedication of our exceptional staff are enabling us to manage current labor and supply chain challenges while offering the freshest food at competitive prices across our integrated ecosystem.
Consumers are showing more normal behaviors, while also eating more at home due to its affordability, convenience, health benefits, and family-oriented nature.
Customers engaged in larger gatherings with loved ones compared to the previous year.
They also continued to cook at home before and during the holiday, opting for premium products to enhance their culinary experience.
These factors support our belief that the shift towards eating at home is a lasting change rather than a temporary one.
With most people eating at home and grocery stores maintaining the majority of food consumption, it's crucial that we offer customers flexibility in how they shop with us.
Our comprehensive seamless ecosystem is designed to meet our customers' changing needs.
Simultaneously, 84% of consumers indicated they will continue to shop online at the same rate or more in the future.
Our seamless ecosystem is specifically designed to accommodate these seemingly conflicting behaviors.
We're aware that inflation is affecting customers as well.
82% of consumers surveyed nationwide are feeling the impact of inflation, and one in four are not confident about their financial situation.
We're using our data and personalization capabilities to help customers maximize their food budgets.
We provide value when customers need it most through personalized promotions, bulk offerings, and special holiday deals.
While price remains a key concern, customers continue to prioritize fresh food options, and we're meeting this demand by emphasizing freshness.
We saw growth in Natural & Organic sales as customers continue to prefer healthier options.
Our fresh departments outperformed the company's overall identical sales excluding fuel during the quarter.
We had a record-breaking quarter in alternative farming products, which include new produce growing methods like vertical and indoor farming.
These offerings increase customers' access to produce harvested at peak freshness.
We're proud to announce that Home Chef became a $1 billion brand on an annual basis in the third quarter, as convenient meal solutions and innovative products have clearly resonated with our customers.
Kroger is committed to delivering a customer-focused, seamless experience that requires no compromises, regardless of how customers choose to shop with us.
We introduced three new offerings this quarter that support our plan to double digital sales and profitability by 2023.
First, Boost by Kroger enhances our industry-leading loyalty program by providing additional savings and personalized offers to members.
Initial engagement in the program has exceeded our internal expectations.
Second, we launched Kroger Delivery Now in collaboration with Instacart.
This unique convenience and immediacy service positions us to win more shopping trips from existing customers and attract new customers to the Kroger ecosystem by offering the largest selection of quality fresh products at affordable prices in 30 minutes.
What's remarkable about this offering is that it was profitable from day one, contributing to our goal of doubling digital profitability by 2023, as announced during our 2021 investor day.
Third, we announced a strategic partnership with Bed Bath & Beyond and buybuy Baby to expand our current marketplace offerings and provide Kroger shoppers easy access to essential home and baby products.
This exclusive offering will be available through Kroger.com and in a small-scale physical store pilot at select locations starting in 2022.
We continue to be satisfied with the performance of our customer fulfillment centers in Groveland, Florida and Monroe, Ohio, which are surpassing internal expectations.
We're particularly proud of our Net Promoter Scores, driven by our teams delivering an exceptional experience for our customers, and we're excited to host you in Groveland early next year.
Regarding our supply chain, we're confident in our ability to meet customer needs during the holidays and beyond.
This is due to our teams' excellent planning well in advance to maintain a fully stocked, fresh, and welcoming customer experience.
In fact, our customers took action to prepare for today's supply chain constraints back in the spring.
Leveraging lessons from pandemic operations, we maintained additional warehouses initially added for COVID support to ensure customer service throughout the holiday season.
We opted to invest heavily in our supply chain during 2021, enabling us to meet customer needs now and into 2022.
We're utilizing various strategies, including our own fleet, and collaborating closely with suppliers to reduce customer inconveniences.
Our recent hybrid recruitment event resulted in over 64,000 new employees joining us this quarter.
We're enhancing our industry-leading employee benefits, including educational support, professional development, health programs, and ongoing wage improvements.
On the first anniversary of our initiative addressing racial injustice, we're pleased to share our progress.
More than 405,000 employees have completed diversity and inclusion training.
We've expanded our strategic partnerships with Historically Black Colleges & Universities and Hispanic-serving institutions from six to 17.
Our foundation has granted over $3 million to organizations promoting equity and inclusion, and we increased our diverse supplier spending by 21% to $4.1 billion last year, progressing towards our $10 billion annual goal by 2030.
While more work remains, we're enthusiastic about updating stakeholders on our ongoing progress.
Kroger excels at managing our business effectively in all operational environments.
We maintain our focus on customer satisfaction and operational excellence to benefit customers, employees, communities, and shareholders.
Our execution focus, balanced approach to investments, cost management, and alternative profit growth are positioning us well for the future.
Our model has proven resilient across economic scenarios, as demonstrated in the third quarter with top and bottom-line growth despite inflation, labor shortages, and supply chain issues.
Identical sales without fuel grew 3.1% as we delivered across our ecosystem, with customers indicating sustained higher food-at-home consumption.
Adjusted FIFO operating profit and earnings per share increased year-over-year, growing at compound annual rates of 22% and 29% respectively compared to 2019.
Third quarter earnings were affected by two unusual items excluded from adjusted earnings per share.
We conducted an annuity buyout and lump-sum distribution for our retirement plan, resulting in an $87 million pre-tax non-cash charge.
This fully-funded company pension plan is currently 100% funded due to previous actions to freeze the plan and protect benefits.
Kroger recorded a $47 million benefit, primarily due to favorable income tax audit outcomes covering multiple years.
I'll now provide more details on our quarterly operating results.
Our identical sales without fuel increased 14% on a two-year stack basis.
Digital sales grew 103% on a two-year stack.
We've previously mentioned that digital growth won't be linear, especially as we cycle last year's sales spike and customers return to in-store shopping.
New digital offerings and customer fulfillment centers give us confidence in meeting our digital sales and profitability targets.
We'll share more about our digital strategy at the March business update.
We continued to improve digital profitability, achieving our best-ever cost to serve for pickup orders.
Third quarter gross margin was 21.66% of sales.
The FIFO gross margin rate, excluding fuel, decreased 41 basis points year-over-year, mainly due to higher supply chain costs and price investments, partially offset by sourcing benefits.
Our investment met expectations and was fully funded by cost savings and OG&A improvement.
Given recent inflation trends and our outlook, we recorded a higher LIFO charge of $93 million, compared to $23 million last year, representing a $0.07 earnings per share headwind versus 2020.
The OG&A rate decreased 49 basis points, excluding fuel and adjustment items, despite continued associate investments and wage increases, reflecting our team's excellent cost-saving execution in a dynamic environment.
We're on track to deliver $1 billion in cost savings for 2021.
Our alternative profit business had a record third quarter and is set to deliver the high end of our expected $100 million to $150 million incremental operating profit range in 2021.
Kroger Personal Finance showed increased strength, and Kroger Precision Marketing launched a new programmatic advertising marketplace, highlighting our advertising capabilities.
Fuel remains a crucial part of our value proposition, especially when prices are high.
We saw a significant increase in customers actively engaging with our fuel program this quarter.
Sales volume increased by 5% in the third quarter, surpassing market growth rates.
Fuel prices at retail averaged $3.24 this quarter, up from $2.15 in the same period last year.
Our fuel margin per gallon was $0.42, an increase from $0.37 in the same quarter of 2020.
I would like to offer some additional insights on how we are actively addressing inflation.
We are currently experiencing a more unstable inflationary environment.
During the third quarter, Kroger observed higher product cost inflation across most categories.
We are carefully managing these price increases.
Our teams are doing an outstanding job, striving to minimize the impact on our customers and our financial model by utilizing our data and collaborating closely with our suppliers.
We are transferring higher costs to customers when appropriate.
In certain key areas, we are opting not to pass on cost increases and continuing to invest in value for our customers.
We are investing strategically, using our proprietary data to be tactical in our pricing and personalization with the aim of securing long-term customer loyalty.
We also believe our brands are an even more crucial differentiator for Kroger in an inflationary environment, providing customers with an unparalleled combination of excellent value and quality.
Let's now discuss our financial strategy.
Kroger is operating from a strong position and continues to generate robust free cash flow, as demonstrated by our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio reaching a record low of 1.68 in the third quarter.
While we continue to identify attractive opportunities to invest in the business to expand our competitive advantage and drive sustainable revenue and earnings growth, our capital expenditures for 2021 are now expected to be lower than our initial guidance range of $3.4 billion to $3.6 billion.
This is due to delays in project implementations, primarily caused by COVID-19-related supply challenges.
Kroger continues to provide returns to shareholders.
We repurchased $297 million of shares during the quarter, and have repurchased $1 billion of shares year to date.
Since 2000, we have now returned over $20 billion to shareholders through share repurchases at an average price of $16.45 per share.
As of the end of the third quarter, $511 million remains available under the current Board authorization announced on June 17, 2021.
We look forward to sharing more about our plans for future use of excess cash to drive sustainable growth and create value for our shareholders at our business update in March.
As Rodney mentioned, we continue to make significant investments in our associates.
In addition to the $350 million in hourly rate investments already planned for this year, we have committed to further investments in the fourth quarter, amounting to an additional $100 million on an annualized basis.
During the third quarter, we finalized new labor agreements with the UFCW for associates in our Columbus and Mid-Atlantic divisions, covering more than 4,500 associates.
We are still negotiating contracts with the UFCW for store associates in Houston, Lake Charles, Freeport, Dallas meat, Little Rock, Memphis, Portland, and Denver.
Our financial results are impacted by inefficiencies in healthcare and pension costs, which most of our competitors do not face.
We continue to engage with our local and international unions, which represent many of our associates, about the importance of growing our business profitably, which will help us create more jobs and career opportunities and enhance job security for our associates.
Now I'll discuss our expectations for the remainder of 2021.
Due to the momentum in our third quarter results and sustained trends in food at home, we are increasing our full year guidance.
We now anticipate identical sales without fuel for the full year to be between negative 0.4% and negative 0.2%, and a two-year identical sales stack of between 13.7% to 13.9%.
There are still some uncertainties as we look ahead, and our guidance of positive ID sales excluding fuel of between 1.5% to 2.5% in the fourth quarter reflects this.
We expect adjusted net earnings per diluted share to range from $3.40 to $3.50.
We anticipate our adjusted FIFO operating profit to be between $4.1 billion and $4.2 billion, reflecting a two-year compounded annual growth rate of 17% to 18.4%.
The midpoint of our adjusted earnings per share range for 2021 now equates to full year results approximately in line with our 2020 results, despite cycling the unique COVID-19-related demand spike last year.
Our guidance fully accounts for the investments in our customers and associates I mentioned earlier, as well as increased marketing to support the exciting new digital initiatives we launched in the third quarter.
It also reflects the latest projection for LIFO.
Since we recorded a LIFO credit in the fourth quarter last year, LIFO is now expected to be a $0.13 headwind to earnings per share in the fourth quarter.
Overall, we are very proud of our results, which are projected to be significantly better than our original guidance for the year.
In summary, Kroger is executing its key financial and operational initiatives and continues to invest in strategic priorities that will deliver attractive and sustainable total shareholder return of 8% to 11% over time.
We believe our business is emerging stronger through the pandemic and, through the investments we are making, is well-positioned to grow beyond 2021.
Kroger's strong year-to-date results are the product of our customer focus, our incredible associates who bring our vision and values to life, and our commitment to providing fresh, affordable food to everyone.
The strength of our teams has never been more evident.
With each new challenge, they rise to the occasion, whether by implementing solutions to minimize supply chain disruptions, delivering the freshest produce to our customers, or using our data to offer personalized promotions that surprise and delight.
Our team is bringing our competitive advantages to life.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Scott Barbour, our President and CEO, and Scott Cottrill, our CFO, are present with me today.
A copy of the document has been submitted to the SEC in an 8-K filing.
We experienced a robust second quarter in fiscal 2021, with revenue growing by 10% as market conditions and business activity remain positive.
I'm grateful to our clients for collaborating with us in innovative ways to cater to the construction industry.
We achieved strong results in key growth regions, including Florida, the Carolinas, Tennessee, Georgia, and Utah, as well as across the southern and southeastern United States.
Overall, we benefited from our nationwide presence, geographical diversity, and increased residential market exposure through Infiltrator and targeted homebuilder programs at ADS.
Infiltrator surpassed revenue expectations once again, achieving 63% sales growth in the second quarter.
Infiltrator continues to experience double-digit growth in tanks and leach field products, particularly in Florida, the Carolinas, Georgia, Tennessee, and Alabama.
Remember that Infiltrator's results cover only two months of the previous year's quarter, due to the acquisition's completion on July 31, 2019.
In the residential sector, legacy ADS sales grew by 15% this quarter.
We observe positive trends in new construction, repairs, renovations, and on-site septic systems.
Orders, backlog, and sales remained strong throughout the period, with minimal impact from the earlier slowdown in residential construction starts.
Overall, we are well-positioned for growth in the residential market.
At the beginning of the cycle, ADS products and marketing strategy are geared towards the land development phase, while Infiltrator products come into play near the end of the cycle as construction nears completion.
Furthermore, both Infiltrator and ADS have a repair and renovation component that is thriving as home improvement activities and existing home sales continue to increase.
Approximately one-third of Infiltrator's sales are related to repairs and renovations, while at ADS, this exposure is addressed through our retail and national accounts.
The company's exposure to the residential market has increased to 38% of domestic sales, compared to 28% at the same time last year.
Sales in our nonresidential sector showed modest growth, led by strong increases in HP Pipe and Storm Tech retention detaching chambers, as we continue to benefit from our involvement in horizontal construction.
We are closely monitoring the segments of the nonresidential market that continue to perform well, such as data centers and warehouses, as well as regions experiencing growth like the southeast and Atlantic Coast.
Importantly, we believe ADS is well-positioned to continue outperforming the market due to our conversion strategy, national coverage, and comprehensive water management solutions.
Based on current market conditions, we anticipate the second half of the year to be similar to what we experienced in the first six months.
Agricultural sales decreased slightly this quarter, as we had anticipated due to a challenging comparison period.
Nevertheless, the agricultural sales team has had an excellent first half of fiscal 2021, with sales up 14% year-over-year.
Additionally, the fall selling season is off to a strong start as we continue to benefit from the programs we implemented, including organizational changes, new product introductions, and improved execution in the agriculture market.
International sales grew by 3%, driven by double-digit growth in our Canadian business.
The construction and agriculture sectors in Canada are performing favorably.
In contrast, Mexico's performance is lagging, having been more heavily affected by the COVID-19 crisis.
High demand is resulting in some constraints at regional and product-specific levels.
As we enter this part of the season, delivery times and stock levels are under pressure.
Given the robust demand and our aim to better exploit opportunities in our primary markets, we are increasing our capital expenditures, which we anticipate will reach between $80 million and $90 million this fiscal year.
Our investment priorities will be enhancing safety, expanding capacity for future growth, and boosting productivity.
We plan to replenish finished goods inventory in the latter half of the year by maintaining steady production at our facilities during traditionally slow periods, preparing both ADS and Infiltrator for optimal customer service and regular lead times.
This replenishment will be contingent on second-half demand, the implementation of new capital, and managing COVID-19-related issues such as employee retention, absenteeism, and local conditions.
This situation aligns with the environment we've been navigating since the onset of the pandemic.
We're also investing in talent, including the recent hiring of a senior executive to boost new product launches, marketing, and innovation.
I'm delighted to announce that Brian King joined our organization in September to spearhead this initiative as the Executive Vice President of Product Management and Marketing.
Brian brings 25 years of successful product management experience, and we're thrilled to have him on our team.
Turning to our financial performance.
We achieved another record-breaking quarter in terms of adjusted EBITDA.
Overall adjusted EBITDA margin rose by 820 basis points, with a 640 basis point increase in the legacy ADS business.
This improvement was driven by favorable material costs, leverage from growth in Pipe and Allied Products, implementation of our operational initiatives, and contributions from proactive cost-saving measures we implemented earlier this year.
Infiltrator also reached record profitability this quarter due to strong demand, favorable material costs, contributions from our synergy programs, and continued execution of their proven business model.
The synergy programs are on track to meet the run rate targets we previously announced.
Looking ahead to the second half of the year, we are optimistic as our order book, project tracking, book-to-bill ratio, and backlog all remain positive.
We anticipate normal seasonal patterns to apply in the second half of our fiscal year, with installation activity slowing in colder regions.
We also face some profitability challenges in the third and fourth quarters, including rising costs for materials and labor.
We are working to counteract these challenges through pricing adjustments, operational efficiency initiatives, and our synergy programs.
To conclude, we performed exceptionally well this quarter.
We're prioritizing safety, navigating the COVID-19 environment, serving our customers, and driving new levels of profitable performance.
Despite ongoing uncertainty in the broader market, we are well-positioned to capitalize on residential development and horizontal construction while continuing to achieve above-market growth through our material conversion and water management solution strategies.
We remain committed to executing our plans efficiently as we aim to build upon our strong performance in the first half of fiscal 2021.
Our second quarter fiscal 2021 financial results are presented on slide six.
Revenue grew by 10%, with our legacy ADS business increasing by 4% and our Infiltrator business expanding by 63%.
The residential market led the growth in our legacy ADS business, with a 15% increase in sales, continuing to show robust performance.
As Scott mentioned, our nonresidential market remains stable, with particular strength in horizontal construction, data centers, and warehouses.
Sales remained strong throughout the quarter, and this trend has persisted into October.
Infiltrator experienced growth across its product range, particularly in leach field and tank product lines.
Infiltrator continued to benefit from the strong repair and remodel market, as well as growth in single-family housing construction.
Their material conversion strategy further accelerated this growth.
In terms of profitability, adjusted EBITDA rose by $56 million or 47% compared to the previous year.
The legacy ADS business saw an increase of $33 million or 35% in adjusted EBITDA, with excellent performance from our sales, operations, procurement, and distribution teams.
ADS is well-positioned to take advantage of the current market stability due to our industry-leading position, national relationships, wide range of products and services, and diversity in geography and end markets.
These factors make us the preferred partner and industry leader, resulting in margin expansion and strong financial results for the quarter.
Infiltrator's adjusted EBITDA grew by $21 million or 86%, benefiting from high demand, favorable pricing, reduced input costs, improved productivity, and our synergy programs.
We now turn to slide seven.
Our free cash flow increased by $112 million to $257 million, compared to $135 million in the first half of fiscal 2020.
These impressive free cash flow results were driven by strong sales growth and profitability in the first half of fiscal 2021, as well as successful implementation of our working capital initiatives.
Our working capital decreased to approximately 20% of sales, down from 22% at the same time last year.
Additionally, our trailing 12-month pro forma leverage ratio is now 1.5 times, slightly below our target range of 2 to 3 times leverage.
We concluded the quarter in a strong liquidity position, with $204 million in cash and $339 million available under our revolving credit facility, totaling $543 million in liquidity.
The positive changes to our capital structure have resulted in no significant debt maturities until 2026.
While we are satisfied with our conversion of adjusted EBITDA to free cash flow in the first half of this year, we will need to make strategic investments in working capital and capex during the second half to position ourselves for expected growth and support productivity initiatives in both the legacy ADS and Infiltrator businesses.
We continue to evaluate potential bolt-on acquisitions through our disciplined acquisition process.
Lastly, on slide eight, we presented our guidance for fiscal 2021.
Based on our performance to date, order activity, backlog, and current market trends, we anticipate net sales to range from $1,790,000,000 to $1,840,000,000, representing growth of 7% to 10% over last year; adjusted EBITDA to range from $495 million to $515 million, representing growth of 37% to 42% over last year, and we expect to convert our adjusted EBITDA to free cash flow at a rate of around 60% for the full year, driven by our strong results as well as the investments we just discussed.
Please open the line for questions, operator.
Summary:
output: sees fiscal 2021 adjusted ebitda is expected to be in range of $495 to $515 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will examine the results from the initial three months of 2021 today.
Joining me on the call are our CEO Norman Schwartz, CFO Ilan Daskal, COO Andy Last, Life Science Group President Annette Tumolo, and Clinical Diagnostics Group President Dara Wright.
Our actual outcomes may significantly differ from these projections and expectations, and we cannot predict the full impact or length of the COVID-19 crisis.
We are uncertain if Bio-Rad's pandemic response will be effective, if the demand for our COVID-19 products will remain stable, or if we can meet that demand.
We'll also mention non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP diluted income per share, which are financial measures not defined by generally accepted accounting principles.
Before delving into the first quarter details, I'd like Andy Last, our COO, to update us on Bio-Rad's operations given the current global pandemic situation.
As anticipated, COVID continues to affect our operations, but as previously stated, we've adapted well to this environment, and our global workforce continues to perform excellently.
We maintain our focus on three key areas: ensuring employee safety, maintaining manufacturing to supply products and support customers, and advancing our core strategies.
We remain very satisfied with our employee safety measures despite rising COVID cases in some global regions.
Our internal COVID transmission rates stay extremely low, and we're beginning to see benefits from vaccination programs.
In Q1, we've maintained our 2020 work-from-home policies and continue to closely monitor the pandemic as we consider the appropriate timing for a broader return to the workplace.
Entering Q2, we expect the pandemic to continue impacting us for at least another quarter, but we're confident in our ability to meet customer demands while advancing our core strategies and new product development goals.
As the global economy moves towards recovery, we're closely monitoring our supply chain, as increased demand for raw materials could potentially cause constraints and extend higher-than-usual logistics costs.
Assuming positive global progress in controlling COVID, we anticipate operations beginning to return to more normal practices in the year's second half.
Let's now review the first quarter results.
First quarter 2021 net sales were $726.8 million, a 27.1% increase from $571.6 million in Q1 2020.
Currency-neutral sales increased by 23.4%.
The first quarter's year-over-year revenue growth was affected by a challenging comparison due to about $10 million in revenue carried over to Q1 2020 related to the December 2019 cyber-attack.
We experienced currency-neutral growth across all three geographic regions.
We continued to see strong demand for COVID-19 testing and related research products.
Generally, most academic and diagnostic labs are now operating at about 90% capacity, an improvement from Q4.
We estimate COVID-19-related sales were approximately $94 million this quarter.
First quarter 2021 Life Science Group sales were $366.5 million, compared to $227.2 million in Q1 2020, a 61.3% increase on a reported basis and a 56.9% increase on a currency-neutral basis.
The year-over-year growth in the first quarter was driven by continued strength in COVID-19-related qPCR products.
We also saw strong double-digit year-over-year sales growth in Droplet Digital PCR, Western Blot, and antibody products.
Process Media, which can fluctuate quarterly, experienced strong double-digit year-over-year growth this quarter compared to the same quarter last year.
Excluding Process Media sales, the core Life Science business grew 56.2% on a currency-neutral basis compared to Q1 2020.
The Life Science segment experienced currency-neutral year-over-year sales growth across all geographic regions.
Besides increased adoption of Droplet Digital PCR in BioPharma, strong demand was observed for the QX ONE in COVID wastewater testing, and we quickly launched well-received COVID variant assays.
Experts continue to emphasize the superior sensitivity of Droplet Digital PCR.
The Clinical Diagnostics Group's sales reached $358.5 million in Q1, up from $340.3 million in the same period last year, representing a 5.4% increase in reported terms and a 2.2% rise on a currency-neutral basis.
The Diagnostics Group experienced robust growth in diabetes and quality control products during the first quarter.
We observed a resurgence in non-COVID related market demand, with diagnostic laboratories operating at approximately 90% of pre-pandemic levels.
The revival of routine testing and elective procedures is ongoing.
Geographically, the Diagnostics group experienced growth in the Asian market.
The first quarter of 2021 saw a GAAP gross margin of 55.1%, compared to 55.5% in Q1 2020.
The decrease in the current quarter's gross margin percentage was primarily due to restructuring-related expenses announced earlier this year, partially offset by improved product mix, reduced service costs, and higher manufacturing efficiency.
Acquisition-related amortization recorded in cost of goods sold amounted to $4.6 million, up from $3.9 million in Q1 2020.
Q1 2021 SG&A expenses totaled $225.9 million, or 31.1% of sales, compared to $193.7 million, or 33.9% in Q1 2020.
The year-over-year increase in SG&A expenses was mainly attributed to restructuring costs and higher employee-related expenses, partially offset by a $5 million cybersecurity insurance settlement related to the 2019 cyber-attack and reduced discretionary spending.
Acquisition-related amortization recorded in SG&A for the quarter reached $2.4 million, up from $2 million in Q1 2020.
R&D expenses in Q1 amounted to $73.9 million, or 10.2% of sales, compared to $49.3 million, or 8.6% in Q1 2020.
The year-over-year increase in R&D expenses was due to restructuring costs and increased project spending.
Q1 operating income was $100.9 million, or 13.9% of sales, compared to $74.4 million, or 13% in Q1 2020.
Examining the non-operating section of the income statement.
The change in fair market value of equity securities holdings added $1.179 billion of income to the reported results, primarily related to Sartorius AG share holdings.
Interest and other income resulted in net other income of $16.9 million during the quarter, compared to $3.3 million of expense last year.
Q1 2021 included $19 million of dividend income from Sartorius, which was declared in Q1 this year.
In 2020, the Sartorius dividend was announced in the second quarter.
The effective tax rate for the quarter was 24.7%, up from 23.7% in Q1 2020.
The tax rates for both periods were influenced by the substantial unrealized gain in equity securities.
The year-over-year increase in the effective tax rate was attributed to the restructuring initiative announced earlier this year.
Reported net income for the first quarter reached $977.4 million, with diluted earnings per share of $32.38.
This represents an increase from the previous year, largely due to changes in the valuation of Sartorius holdings.
Transitioning to the non-GAAP results.
When examining the results on a non-GAAP basis, we have excluded certain unusual and unique items that impacted gross and operating margins, as well as other income.
We have removed $4.6 million for amortization of purchased intangibles, $24 million for restructuring-related costs, and a minor legal reserve benefit from the cost of goods sold calculation.
These adjustments increased the non-GAAP gross margin for Q1 2021 to 59%, compared to 55.9% in Q1 2020.
Non-GAAP SG&A expenses in Q1 2021 were 25.4%, down from 33.3% in Q1 2020.
For non-GAAP SG&A, we've excluded $34.7 million in restructuring-related expenses, $4.4 million in legal-related costs, and $2.4 million for amortization of purchased intangibles.
We've taken out $16.9 million of restructuring-related expenses from R&D costs.
As a result, the non-GAAP R&D expense for Q1 was 7.9%.
These non-GAAP adjustments collectively raised the quarterly operating margin from 13.9% (GAAP) to 25.8% (non-GAAP).
This non-GAAP operating margin of 25.8% is higher than the 13.9% non-GAAP operating margin in Q1 2020.
We've also excluded some items below the operating line, including the $1.179 billion increase in Sartorius equity holdings value and $1.8 million loss from venture investments.
Our Q1 non-GAAP effective tax rate was 23.6%, lower than the 25.7% in Q1 2020.
Changes in the geographical distribution of earnings affected the tax rate.
The non-GAAP net income for Q1 2021 reached $157.4 million, or $5.21 per diluted share, up from $57.6 million and $1.91 per share in Q1 2020.
Let's examine the balance sheet.
At the end of Q1, total cash and short-term investments were $1.025 billion, an increase from $997 million at the end of 2020.
In Q1, we bought back 89,506 shares of our stock for $50 million, at an average price of about $559 per share.
Net cash from operations in Q1 2021 was $114 million, compared to $63 million in Q1 2020.
The increase is primarily due to higher operating profits.
Q4 2021 adjusted EBITDA was $232 million or 31.9% of sales, and 29.3% excluding the Sartorius dividend.
Q1 2020 adjusted EBITDA was $107.4 million or 18.8% of sales, not including the 2020 Sartorius dividend.
Q1 2021 net capital expenditures were $19.5 million, with depreciation and amortization at $32.7 million.
Now, let's discuss the guidance.
We initially projected 4.5% to 5% non-GAAP sales growth and a non-GAAP operating margin between 16% and 16.5% for the year.
Despite ongoing uncertainty about the COVID-19 pandemic's duration and impact, based on Q1 results and current outlook, we now expect currency-neutral revenue growth for 2021 to be between 5.5% and 6%.
This includes estimated COVID-related sales of $170 million to $180 million, up from our previous estimate of $150 million to $160 million.
We expect most 2021 COVID-19-related sales to occur in the first half of the year, and we still anticipate a gradual return to pre-pandemic activity and a more normal business mix.
We now project full-year non-GAAP gross margin to be between 56.5% and 57%, up from our previous guidance of 56.2% to 56.5%.
We also expect full-year non-GAAP operating margin to be about 17%, and full-year adjusted EBITDA margin to be around 22%, up from our previous guidance of 21%.
Summary:

q1 non-gaap earnings per share $5.21.
q1 earnings per share $32.38.
q1 sales rose 27.1 percent to $726.8 million.
for full year 2021 anticipates non-gaap currency-neutral revenue growth of approximately 5.5 to 6.0 percent.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The SEC filings for our company are available in the Investors section of our website at unum.com
The third quarter 2021 net income included several after-tax items: a $9.6 million impairment loss on internal-use software, $15.5 million amortization of reinsurance costs, a $143.3 million reserve decrease from assumption updates, and a negligible $100,000 investment portfolio loss
Third quarter 2020 net income included $18.6 million in after-tax costs for an organizational update and a $3.8 million after-tax investment portfolio gain
Excluding these items, third quarter 2021 after-tax adjusted operating income was $210.5 million compared to $245.9 million in the same quarter last year
Our business lines experienced growth in revenue with good returns
We acknowledge the ongoing impact of COVID-19 on our short-term results
While COVID-19 has negatively affected our core returns, we remain confident in the long-term profitability of our business
I'll begin by discussing overall operations before addressing COVID-19 trends
It's worth noting that core premium growth has been consistent and in line with our previous projections
In the third quarter, Unum US saw a 1.2% year-over-year increase in premium income
Colonial Life achieved slightly positive results after three quarters of negative comparisons, while our International divisions also showed positive premium trends
This premium growth is gaining momentum as sales increase, customer retention remains strong, and employment growth and wage inflation benefit our business
Excluding COVID-19 impacts, we are encouraged by the performance and income contributions from our other business segments
Our supplemental and voluntary lines, Colonial Life, International businesses, and Closed Block segment all demonstrated generally stable results and made significant contributions to income this quarter
We are also satisfied with our overall investment performance this quarter
We saw another quarter of strong returns from alternative investments and higher than usual bond call premiums
The underlying credit quality of our portfolio is excellent, and our investment team remains vigilant in analyzing our credits amid changing market conditions
Despite these strengths, we were significantly impacted by the evolving COVID-19 pandemic
Given our broad customer base across the U.S., we have been affected by the resurgence of infections, hospitalizations, and mortality caused by the Delta variant
Throughout the pandemic, we've found that national mortality and infection rates are the best indicators of COVID-19's impact on our results
This quarter, we also need to consider how the demographics of incremental mortality specifically relate to our customer base
For context, U.S. COVID-19 mortality in the third quarter increased significantly to about 94,000 lives, nearly double the 52,000 in the second quarter
This dramatic increase occurred rapidly and consistently throughout the quarter
Just 90 days ago, most experts estimated third quarter mortality at around 44,000 deaths, an estimate that more than doubled over the quarter
The increase in overall mortality has significantly impacted our industry, particularly our Unum US group life business, though we also saw effects in our voluntary benefits lines
CDC data shows that working-aged individuals accounted for about 40% of COVID-19 mortality in the third quarter, double the proportion seen in Q4 2020 and Q1 2021 before widespread vaccination
This demographic shift affects us in three ways
First, we see higher impacts in the working-age population, our primary customers covered by our group and voluntary products
Additionally, these younger working-age individuals tend to have higher benefit amounts than we've seen previously
Lastly, the Delta variant has led to a resurgence of infections and hospitalizations, resulting in more claims in our short-term disability business and pressure on our group disability benefit ratio
While COVID-19 impacts are evident in our quarterly results, we believe that as the pandemic comes under better control through increased vaccinations and improved treatments, we will see strong growth and profitability in our business
The COVID-19 recovery has been delayed longer than anticipated due to the Delta variant, but we expect to see a recovery ahead
Given this outlook, we're excited to begin deploying a portion of the company's excess capital in ways we believe will create value for our shareholders
Our capital position remains very strong, with $1.6 billion in holding company cash and a weighted average risk-based capital ratio of about 380% for our traditional U.S.-based life insurance companies
This allows us to deploy some capital to enhance shareholder value while maintaining a healthy position for future opportunities
We recently announced a $250 million share repurchase authorization approved by our Board, which we plan to initiate in the fourth quarter with a $50 million accelerated share repurchase
We expect to continue this program through the end of 2022
In addition to share buybacks, we plan to accelerate recognition of the premium deficiency reserve for the Long-Term Care Block by a similar amount over the same period
We see value in accelerating this recognition ahead of the original seven-year schedule and could potentially complete it by the end of 2024 under certain market conditions
Even with these additional capital allocations, we will maintain a strong capital position and flexibility
While we remain optimistic long-term, given the pandemic's volatility, we will postpone our traditional December Analyst Meeting to the first quarter of 2022 to discuss our full-year outlook
Key areas to focus on include continued premium growth in our core business lines for 2022 and the impact of our capital deployment plans
We expect the pandemic's impact to decrease over the next year, but anticipate the fourth quarter of this year to be similarly affected as the third quarter
We are monitoring national numbers, and as the Delta wave subsides, we look forward to returning to the growth and profitability we believe we can deliver
I'll now hand over to Steve to cover the details of the third quarter results
I will also describe our adjusted operating income results by segment, excluding the impacts from our GAAP reserve assumption updates
The most significant component of the actuarial reserve review was the release of $215 million before tax in the Unum US long-term disability line
Claim reserves should represent our best estimate of future liability, and since the last GAAP reserve review, investments in our operations have improved our claims management, resulting in better claim recoveries over recent years, which we now believe are sustainable
As a result, these reserves have been adjusted to better reflect expected claim costs
This reserve update will have minimal impact on our future earnings expectations from this line or the expected benefit ratio
The reserve review also determined that reserves should be increased in three lines within the Closed Block reporting segment
For the Closed Group Pension Block, policy reserves were increased by $25.1 million before tax
Before-tax claim reserves for the Closed Disability Block increased by $6.4 million.
The Long-Term Care claim reserves saw a pre-tax increase of $2.1 million.
These reserve adjustments, while not included in adjusted operating income, added $0.70 per share to the Company's book value.
COVID significantly affected the Unum US segment's results this quarter, causing higher mortality rates, increased average claim amounts in group life insurance, and more short-term disability claims in group disability coverage.
The Unum US segment's adjusted operating income fell to $88.5 million in the third quarter from $179.3 million in the second quarter.
Excluding reserve assumption updates, the Unum US group disability line's adjusted operating income decreased to $39.5 million in the third quarter from $59.9 million in the previous quarter.
The main reason for the decline was a rise in the benefit ratio to 78.9% in the third quarter from 74.7% in the second quarter, primarily due to increased short-term disability claims related to the COVID Delta variant and current external conditions.
Sequential quarterly premium income slightly decreased, but we were encouraged by a 2.6% year-over-year growth.
While short-term disability results faced challenges this quarter, our long-term disability line met expectations as increased new claim incidence, mostly from STD claims transitioning to LTD status, was offset by continued strong claim recoveries.
We anticipate the overall group disability benefit ratio will likely remain elevated as COVID and current external factors continue to impact our STD results.
We believe COVID is a key factor in the higher group disability line benefit ratio and expect improvement as direct COVID impacts diminish over the first part of next year.
Unum US group life and AD&D adjusted operating income declined from $5.2 million in the second quarter to a loss of $67.1 million in the third quarter.
This quarter-to-quarter decrease of about $70 million was mainly due to the changing COVID impacts Rick mentioned in his comments.
We were affected by the worsening COVID-related mortality, with national deaths rising from 52,000 in the second quarter to approximately 94,000 in the third quarter, along with a shift in age demographics towards greater impacts on younger working-aged individuals.
Estimated COVID-related excess mortality claims for our Group Life Block increased from about 800 claims in the second quarter to over 1,900 claims in the third quarter.
Consequently, our results reflect mortality at a level representing approximately 2% of reported national figures, compared to a 1% rate experienced through 2020 when mortality was more pronounced in the elderly population.
With a higher percentage of working-age individuals affected, we also saw an increase in average benefit size from around $55,000 in the second quarter to over $60,000 this quarter.
Non-COVID-related mortality did not significantly impact third-quarter results compared to second-quarter experience.
For the fourth quarter, we currently expect U.S. COVID-related mortality to worsen further to approximately 100,000 deaths.
With continued higher mortality among working-aged individuals, we believe group life results will remain under pressure, with the expected fourth-quarter loss similar to or potentially worse than the third-quarter experience.
Unum US supplemental and voluntary lines' adjusted operating income increased slightly from $114.2 million in the second quarter to $116.1 million in the third quarter, both representing very good quarters that generated adjusted operating returns on equity exceeding 17%.
Examining the three primary business lines:
We continue to be very satisfied with the performance of the individual disability recently issued block of business, which has produced strong results throughout the pandemic.
We continue to observe very favorable new claim incidence trends and recovery levels in this block.
The voluntary benefits line also reported a strong income level, though slightly lower quarter-to-quarter.
The increase in the third-quarter benefit ratio to 46.6% from 44.2% in the second quarter was due to increased COVID-related life insurance claims, which offset generally favorable results in other VB product lines.
Utilization in the dental and vision line improved, leading to a decrease in the benefit ratio to 75% this quarter from 77.1% in the second quarter.
Regarding premium trends and drivers, total new sales for Unum US increased by 7.7% in the third quarter year-over-year, compared to declines experienced in the first half of the year.
For employee benefit lines including LTD, STD, group life, AD&D, and stop-loss, total sales declined by 2.5% this quarter, mainly due to lower sales in the large case market and generally flat sales in the core market (under 2,000 lines).
Sales trends in our supplemental and voluntary lines rebounded strongly in the quarter, increasing 21.8% overall compared to the year-ago quarter.
We observed sharp year-over-year increases in the recently issued individual disability line (up 22.9%) and in the dental and vision line (up 48.2%).
Voluntary benefit sales also recovered following lower year-over-year comparisons in recent quarters, growing 13.7% in the third quarter.
We also noticed overall favorable persistency trends for our major product lines in Unum US.
Our group lines combined showed a slight increase to 89.4% for the first three quarters of 2021 compared to 89.1% last year.
Both the voluntary benefits and dental and vision lines also showed year-over-year improvements, while the individual disability line declined slightly.
The solid persistency numbers and improving sales trends provide a good tailwind for premium growth as we conclude this year and move into 2022.
The Unum International segment had a very good quarter with adjusted operating income increasing to $27.4 million in the third quarter from $24.8 million in the second quarter, continuing the improving trend in income over the past several quarters.
The main driver of these results is our Unum UK business, which generated adjusted operating income of £18.4 million in the third quarter compared to £16.8 million in the second quarter.
The reported benefit ratio for Unum UK improved to 79.2% in the third quarter from 82.5% in the second quarter.
The underlying benefits experience was favorable for our Group Income Protection Block, primarily due to lower new claim incidence, although claim recoveries continue to lag our expectations somewhat.
The Group Life Block experienced adverse mortality primarily from non-COVID-related claims incidence and higher average size.
We did not see much impact from COVID in our UK Life Block this quarter.
Benefits experience in Unum Poland was also favorable this quarter, helping generate a slight improvement in adjusted operating income.
Premium growth for our International businesses was also favorable this quarter compared to a year ago.
Looking at the growth on a year-over-year basis and in local currency to neutralize the benefit we saw from the higher exchange rate, Unum UK generated growth of 2.9% with strong persistency and the continued successful placement of rate increases on our in-force block.
Additionally, sales in Unum UK rebounded in the third quarter, increasing 40.2% over last year.
Unum Poland also generated growth of 12.5%, continuing the low double-digit premium growth this business has been producing.
Colonial Life's results are in line with our expectations for the third quarter, with adjusted operating income of $80.1 million compared to the record quarterly income of $95.8 million in the second quarter.
As with our other U.S.-based life insurance businesses, Colonial's life insurance block was negatively impacted by COVID-related mortality, which was the primary driver in pushing the benefit ratio to 55.9% in the third quarter compared to 51.7% in the second quarter.
We estimate that adverse COVID-related claims experience in the life block impacted results by approximately $16 million, the worst impact we have seen from COVID throughout the pandemic and a level that is likely to persist through the fourth quarter.
Experience in the other lines, including accident, sickness and disability, and cancer and critical illness, remained in line with our expectations and continue to drive strong earnings for this segment.
Moreover, net investment income saw a 25% sequential rise in Q3, primarily due to unusually high bond call activity during this period.
We anticipate that the advantage to net investment income from bond calls will not persist at this level in Q4.
We were delighted to observe the improving trend in Colonial Life's premium growth, which remained stable year-over-year this quarter after experiencing declines in the previous three quarters.
The improving premium trend is driven by a continued rebound in Colonial Life's sales activity, increasing 28.6% year-over-year this quarter and showing a 21.1% increase for the first three quarters of 2021 compared to last year.
Colonial Life's persistency continues to show a promising trend at 78.9% for the first three quarters of 2021, over a percentage point higher than the previous year.
In the Closed Block segment, adjusted operating income, excluding reserve assumption updates and amortization of reinsurance costs related to the recently closed Closed Block individual disability reinsurance transaction, was $109.8 million in Q3 and $111.2 million in Q2, both strong results driven by favorable overall benefits experience in Long-Term Care and Closed Disability Block, and high investment income due to higher than expected miscellaneous investment income, which will be detailed shortly.
Within the Closed Block, the LTC Block continues to yield results that are quite favorable compared to our long-term projections.
The interest-adjusted loss ratio in Q3 was 74.8% and averaged 71.8% over the past four quarters, both significantly below our long-term expectation of 85% to 90%.
In Q3, we continued to observe higher mortality rates in the claimant block, with accounts approximately 5% higher than anticipated, similar to our Q2 experience.
LTC submitted claims activity increased in Q3, although much of the increase has not resulted in significant ongoing claim costs.
Looking towards the end of 2021 and into 2022, we expect the interest-adjusted loss ratio for LTC to trend closer to, but slightly favorable to, our long-term assumption range as mortality and incidence trends normalize from COVID impacts.
For the Closed Disability Block, the interest-adjusted loss ratio was 58.2% in Q3 compared to 69.6% in Q2, both very favorable outcomes for this line.
The underlying experience on the retained block, which largely reflects the active life reserve cohort and certain other smaller claim blocks we kept, performed very favorably relative to our expectations, primarily due to lower submitted claims again this quarter.
Overall, the Closed Block segment demonstrated very strong performance again this quarter.
Higher miscellaneous investment income continues to contribute to the segment's strong adjusted operating income, driven by both higher than average bond call premiums and strong performance in our alternative asset portfolio.
Looking ahead, we estimate the quarterly adjusted operating income for this segment will range between $45 million to $55 million over time, assuming more normal trends for investment income and claim results in the LTC and Closed Disability lines.
Firstly, we observed a high level of bond calls again this quarter as many companies refinanced higher coupon debt and capitalized on today's favorable credit market conditions.
We recorded approximately $20 million in higher investment income from bond calls this quarter compared to our historical quarterly averages.
The Closed Block and Colonial Life segments were the primary beneficiaries of higher investment income this quarter.
Unum US was in line with historical averages, but lower this quarter than what we received in Q2.
While these calls enhance current period investment income, they fluctuate from quarter to quarter.
Secondly, we continue to see strong performance in our alternative investment portfolio, which earned $38.2 million in Q3, following earnings of $51.9 million recorded in Q2.
Both quarters significantly exceeded the expected quarterly income on the portfolio of $12 million to $14 million.
The higher returns this quarter were generated from all three of our main sectors: credit, real estate, and private equity, reflecting strong financial markets and robust economic growth.
It's challenging to predict quarterly returns for miscellaneous investment income, but for Q4, we believe they will moderate to our expected quarterly returns.
Turning to capital, the company's financial position remains strong, providing significant financial flexibility.
The weighted average risk-based capital ratio for our traditional U.S. insurance companies improved to approximately 380%, and holding company cash was $1.6 billion at the end of Q3, both well above our targeted levels.
Additionally, leverage has decreased with equity growth and is now 25.7%.
As Rick mentioned, we're pleased to clarify our capital deployment plans for the remainder of 2021 and for 2022.
For context, given the capital measures I just discussed, we are in a very strong capital position with substantial financial flexibility.
Our deployment strategy remains unchanged and our priorities are consistent, including: first, funding growth in our core businesses; second, supporting our LTC Block; third, executing opportunistic acquisitions that support our long-term growth; and fourth, returning capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
We began implementing our plans last week with the announcement of our Board of Directors' authorization to repurchase up to $250 million of our shares by the end of 2022.
We plan to initiate this program with an accelerated share repurchase of $50 million in Q4.
We also intend to allocate capital to accelerate the recognition of the premium deficiency reserve for the LTC Block by a similar amount by the end of 2022.
We believe this combination strikes a good balance between repurchasing our shares at what we consider very attractive prices, while also fully funding the PDR ahead of the original 2026 target to help reduce the valuation drag on our stock from the LTC exposure.
With this additional capital deployment, we continue to project a very solid capital position at the end of 2022, with holding company cash around $1 billion and an RBC ratio well above our target.
Changing topics, I wanted to provide a brief update on our progress in adopting ASC 944 or Long Duration Targeted Improvements.
As a reminder, this accounting pronouncement applies only to GAAP basis financial statements and has no economic, statutory accounting, or cash flow impacts on the business.
We remain confident about our readiness to adopt the pronouncement as of January 1, 2023, and will be sharing some qualitative information in our Form 10-Q filing later today.
Although we continue to evaluate the effects of complying with this update, we expect that the most significant impact at the transition date will be the requirement to update our liability discount rate with one that is generally equivalent to a single A interest rate.
We anticipate this will result in a substantial decrease to accumulated other comprehensive income, primarily driven by the difference between the expected interest rates from our investment strategy and interest rates indicative of a single A rated portfolio.
As we continue to progress our work, we plan to provide updates to you in 2022 as we approach adoption.
Let me conclude with an update on our expectations for the remainder of 2021.
With COVID-related mortality expected to increase further in Q4 to approximately 100,000 nationwide deaths, we anticipate seeing similar, if not slightly worse, trends for mortality impacts on our life insurance businesses in Q4 compared to Q3.
The Unum US group disability benefit ratio is also likely to remain elevated due to continued high levels of STD claims.
Additionally, we do not expect miscellaneous investment income to be as strong in Q4 as it was this quarter.
These factors will likely put pressure on our Q4 results relative to what we experienced in Q3.
As Rick mentioned, we plan to update you on our 2022 outlook during Q1 2022 when we expect to have a more informed view of COVID mortality and infection trends.
We are confident that premium growth in our core business segments in 2022 can build upon the momentum that began to reemerge this year, and we will also see the benefits of executing our share buyback authorization.
However, future COVID trends will be a crucial factor in our expected benefits experience.
We continue to be pleased with the company's operational performance through this extraordinary environment.
We believe we are well-positioned to benefit from today's strong business conditions, but we must remain vigilant as COVID-related mortality and infection rates persist.
Summary:
