input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:AMETEK's SEC filings contain a thorough examination of potential risks and uncertainties that could impact our future performance.
I will now hand the meeting over to Dave.
AMETEK experienced another exceptional quarter, surpassing expectations in sales growth, operational efficiency, and earnings.
We achieved new highs in sales, EBITDA, operating income, and earnings per share during the quarter.
Strong demand across our diverse market segments led to significant order growth and a record-breaking backlog.
Despite ongoing challenges in global supply chains and logistics, our businesses have excelled in managing these issues and delivering results beyond our expectations.
Based on our third quarter performance and fourth quarter outlook, we are once again raising our full-year sales and earnings projections.
This impressive overall performance reflects the outstanding efforts of all AMETEK employees and the robustness, adaptability, and sustainability of our growth model.
The proven AMETEK business model is fundamental to our commitment to creating a sustainable future for all stakeholders.
We take great pride in the significant steps we're taking to enhance sustainability throughout AMETEK.
We recently published our latest Corporate Sustainability Report, showcasing our efforts in this area.
This report details our sustainability initiatives, the considerable progress we've made, and our commitments to building a better future.
Let's now review our third-quarter results.
Third-quarter sales reached a record $1.44 billion, representing a 28% increase compared to the same period in 2020 and exceeding our expectations.
Organic sales grew by 17%, acquisitions contributed 11 percentage points, and foreign currency had a slight positive impact during the quarter.
Overall orders in the third quarter totaled $1.55 billion, marking a 37% increase over the previous year.
Organic orders showed an impressive 30% growth in the quarter.
We concluded the quarter with a record backlog of $2.62 billion, an increase of over $800 million since the beginning of the year.
Third quarter operating income hit a record $338 million, a 25% increase compared to the third quarter of 2020, with operating margins at 23.4%.
Excluding the dilutive effect of acquisitions, core operating margins were 24.7%, an improvement of 70 basis points compared to the third quarter of 2020.
EBITDA for the third quarter reached a record $415 million, up 25% from the previous year, with EBITDA margins of 28.8%.
This exceptional performance resulted in record earnings of $1.26 per diluted share.
This represents a 25% increase over the third quarter of 2020 and surpasses our guidance range of $1.16 to $1.18.
We continue to generate robust cash flow, with third-quarter operating cash flow of $307 million and free cash flow conversion at 109% of net income.
Overall, these are outstanding results in a challenging operational environment.
Now, I'll provide more detailed information at the operating group level.
Starting with the Electronic Instruments Group.
AIG sales reached a record $982 million, a 31% increase compared to last year's third quarter.
Organic sales grew by 15%, acquisitions added 16%, and foreign currency had a slight negative impact.
While growth was widespread, it was particularly strong in our Ultra Precision Technologies and Power and Industrial businesses.
AIG's third-quarter operating income hit a record $245 million, up 20% compared to the same quarter last year, with operating margins at 25%.
AIG's core margins, excluding acquisitions, were excellent at 27.2%, matching the previous year's performance.
The Electromechanical Group demonstrated remarkable sales growth and exceptional operational efficiency.
Sales in the third quarter rose by 21% compared to the same period last year, reaching $459 million.
Internal sales grew by 20%, with currency exchange rates contributing an additional percentage point to overall growth.
All sectors of the MG continued to show strong performance, with our automation divisions particularly excelling during the quarter.
EMG's quarterly operating income hit a new high of $115 million, showing a significant 36% increase from the previous year.
EMG's operating margins improved dramatically, expanding by 270 basis points to reach a record 25%.
Let's now discuss our acquisition strategy.
AMETEK has had a remarkable year, deploying a record amount of capital to acquire five strategically important companies.
So far this year, AMETEK has invested approximately $1.85 billion in acquisitions, demonstrating the effectiveness of its acquisition strategy and its ability to identify and purchase highly strategic businesses.
Our proven operational expertise enables us to implement significant improvements across our acquired companies, resulting in exceptional returns on invested capital.
Achieving strong returns on deployed capital is crucial for long-term sustainable growth and is a key component of AMETEK's strategy.
AMETEK's robust cash flow generation continues to support its capital deployment strategy, with a very active acquisition pipeline and the M&A team working diligently to identify attractive opportunities, expecting to remain busy in the coming quarters.
We also maintain our focus on reinvesting in our businesses to support their organic growth initiatives, including their new product development efforts.
In the third quarter, we allocated over $75 million to RD&E.
For the entire year of 2021, we now anticipate investing approximately $300 million, or about 5.5% of sales.
These investments enable our businesses to develop unique and highly differentiated solutions that address our customers' most complex challenges.
A prime example is a new product introduction from AMETEK Gatan.
Gatan is a leading provider of direct detection technology for electron microscopy, supporting advanced research in materials and life sciences applications.
Gatan recently launched The Stela hybrid pixel camera, the only fully integrated hybrid pixel electron detector with the Gatan microscopy suite.
This new product reinforces Gatan's leadership position by offering the highest quality TEM diffraction camera, allowing users to perform 4D stem analysis with rapid speed and high dynamic range.
Gatan's new camera builds upon a long history of disruptive and award-winning technology.
In August, The Stela camera received the 2021 R&D 100 Innovation Award and was recognized as one of the ten game-changing products and methods.
I'd like to congratulate the Gatan team for the recent launch of The Stela camera and their continued support of important research applications.
Now, let's address the supply chain issues.
The global supply chain remains challenging, with extended lead times for a wide range of materials and components, as well as logistics issues and labor shortages adding to the complexity.
Despite these difficulties, we surpassed our sales estimates for the quarter and are effectively navigating the challenging environment thanks to our agile operating approach.
The supply chain issues are contributing to higher inflation.
However, due to our differentiation, we're able to more than offset this inflation with higher pricing, resulting in a strong price-inflation spread.
While we expect these challenges to persist into 2022, we remain well-positioned to address these issues, given the strength and flexibility of the AMETEK growth model.
Let's move on to our updated outlook for the remainder of 2021.
Based on our exceptional third-quarter results, ongoing strong order momentum, and record backlog, we have once again increased our 2021 sales and earnings projections.
We now anticipate overall sales for the year to increase in the low 20% range, compared to our previous estimate of approximately 20% growth.
We now project organic sales to grow by low double-digit percentages over 2020, up from our earlier forecast of about 10%.
We now expect diluted earnings per share for 2021 to range between $4.76 and $4.78, representing an increase of roughly 21% over 2020 on a comparable basis, surpassing our previous guidance of $4.62 to $4.86 per diluted share.
We expect overall sales in the fourth quarter to increase by approximately 20% compared to the same period last year.
We anticipate fourth-quarter earnings per diluted share to be between $1.28 and $1.30, representing a 19% to 20% increase over the previous year's fourth quarter.
AMETEK delivered outstanding results in the third quarter.
Our teams continue to perform well, and our businesses are thriving.
Our ability to perform well in challenging conditions demonstrates the resilience and strength of AMETEK's growth strategy.
Our asset-light business model, leading positions in attractive niche markets, and exceptional workforce will continue to drive long-term, sustainable success.
The effectiveness of AMETEK's growth model continues to yield long-term benefits for all of the company's stakeholders.
As mentioned earlier, AMETEK achieved excellent results in the third quarter, with continued robust sales and order growth, along with exceptional operational performance.
I will now provide some additional financial details for the quarter.
General and administrative expenses for the third quarter were $22.1 million, an increase of $4.8 million from the previous year, primarily due to higher compensation costs.
G&A expenses as a percentage of total sales remained steady at 1.5% for the quarter, unchanged from the previous year.
For 2021, we expect general and administrative expenses to increase by approximately $18 million, primarily due to higher compensation costs, but remain at about 1.5% of sales, consistent with the previous year.
Other income and expense in the third quarter improved by about $4 million compared to the same quarter last year, driven by a $6 million (or approximately $0.02 per share) gain from the sale of a small product line during the quarter.
This gain was more than offset by a higher effective tax rate of 19.5% in the quarter, up from 17.5% in the same period last year.
For 2021, we now anticipate our effective tax rate to be between 19.5% and 20%, though actual quarterly tax rates can vary significantly, either positively or negatively, from this full-year estimate.
Working capital in the quarter was 14.9% of sales, a decrease of 210 basis points from the 17% reported in the third quarter of 2020, reflecting our businesses' excellent management of working capital.
Capital expenditures in the third quarter were $26 million, and we continue to expect capital expenditures to total approximately $120 million for the full year.
Depreciation and amortization expense in the third quarter was $75 million, and for the entire year of 2021, we expect depreciation and amortization to be approximately $295 million, including after-tax, acquisition-related intangible amortization of about $138 million or $0.60 per diluted share.
We continue to generate strong cash flows due to our asset-light business model and effective working capital management.
In the third quarter, operating cash flow was $307 million, and free cash flow was $281 million, with free cash flow conversion at 109% of net income.
Total debt at the end of the quarter was $2.65 billion, an increase of less than $250 million from the end of 2020, despite having spent approximately $1.85 billion on acquisitions so far in 2021.
Offsetting this debt with cash and cash equivalents of $359 million, our gross debt to EBITDA ratio was 1.6 times, and our net debt to EBITDA ratio was 1.4 times at the end of the quarter.
We maintain excellent financial capacity and flexibility with approximately $2.25 billion in cash and existing credit facilities to support our growth initiatives.
In conclusion, our businesses delivered outstanding results in the third quarter and throughout the first nine months of 2021.
Our strong balance sheet and exceptional cash flow generation have positioned the company for significant growth in the coming quarters and years.
Summary:

q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.26.
q3 sales rose 28 percent to $1.44 billion.
sees q4 overall sales to be up in low 20% range compared to q4 of 2020.
sees q4 adjusted earnings per share to be in range of $1.28 to $1.30, up 19% to 20% over same period in 2020.
sees fy 2021 adjusted earnings per share to be in range of $4.76 to $4.78, increase of 21% over prior year comparable basis.
sees fy 2021 overall sales to be up in low 20% range with organic sales up low double digits on a percentage basis versus 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our combined profits for Q1 2021 were $0.98 per diluted share, an increase from $0.72 in Q1 2020.
I will now hand over to Dennis for further discussion.
We understand that returning to offices or establishing a new routine may still take some time.
In the interim, we will continue offering support and understanding to those facing financial difficulties through energy aid programs, payment plans, and even COVID-19 financial assistance grants.
I'm incredibly impressed by our staff who, despite these challenging circumstances, have shown great adaptability and continue to advance our company on all fronts.
The financial results we're presenting today showcase their commitment and resolve to accomplish our objectives.
We have recently initiated measures to progress towards an environmentally friendly energy future.
A short while ago, we declared our ambitious target to decrease our carbon emissions from natural gas by aiming to become carbon-neutral by 2045, with an intermediate goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2030.
Our plan to achieve reduced emissions involves investing in innovative technologies such as renewable natural gas (RNG), hydrogen, or other sustainable biofuels.
We are assessing the best methods to incorporate RNG into our gas supply and investigating hydrogen as an alternative renewable fuel source.
Additionally, we will concentrate on decreasing consumption through conservation efforts and energy efficiency measures, as well as upgrading our infrastructure.
We acknowledge that this is a significant challenge.
Several crucial elements need to align in the coming years for success.
The cost of technology must decrease, new innovations must emerge, and regulatory backing will be essential for us to reach these objectives.
As we develop our strategies, maintaining affordable costs will be a key consideration.
We are dedicated to pursuing this goal in ways that ensure affordability and reliability for our customers.
Our natural gas objective demonstrates that our vision of a clean energy future encompasses both electricity and natural gas resources.
We are committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the energy we provide to our customers.
We are also making progress towards our clean electricity goal of providing carbon-neutral electricity by the end of 2027 and carbon-free electricity by 2045.
Recently, we entered into an agreement with the Chelan County Public Utility District to increase the amount of renewable hydropower in our electricity generation portfolio.
This contract aligns with the strategies outlined in our recently filed 2021 Electric Integrated Resource Plan and supports the objectives of Washington State's Clean Energy Transformation Act (CETA).
We've had a promising start to 2021 regarding our quarterly results, and we're on track to achieve our full-year earnings goals.
Avista Utilities' earnings surpassed expectations, AEL&P's earnings were in line with projections for the first quarter, and our other ventures performed better than anticipated.
The recently enacted legislation will facilitate the shift in electric and natural gas company regulation towards multi-year rate plans and initiate the process of performance-based rate-making.
This significant legislation's passage offers advantages such as mandating multi-year rate plans spanning two to four years, with the rate plan's foundation established using methods the commission may employ to reduce regulatory lag.
While current and future commissioners will need to implement these changes, we believe this is a crucial initial step in advancing the regulatory model in Washington State.
Now, let me provide an update on our regulatory submissions from January.
We submitted two-year general rate cases in Idaho, one for electricity and another for gas.
In 2020, we filed general rate cases in Washington, again one each for electricity and gas.
We are continuing to navigate the regulatory process in these jurisdictions.
We plan to file a rate case in Oregon during the latter half of 2021.
We achieved a notable milestone in our electric transportation efforts when the Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission approved three tariffs allowing us to proceed with various programs outlined in our transportation-electrification plan.
The UTC's approval enables us to establish optional general service and large commercial electric vehicle rates, which will help facilitate and accelerate fleet electrification for commercial clients like the Spokane Transit Authority.
Our transportation electrification plan and newly approved tariffs will serve as a valuable model for others to follow.
This exemplifies our industry's role in electric transportation and our clean energy future.
Avista continues to be at the forefront of these developments.
Moving forward, we remain committed to operating an excellent utility and continuing to invest wisely in maintaining and upgrading our infrastructure to provide reliable energy services to our customers.
We are reaffirming our earnings guidance for 2021 through 2023.
Unfortunately, my Blackhawks were eliminated from the playoffs last night.
We have five games remaining in the season, but we no longer have a chance for postseason play this year.
It's a disappointing day for me, but on a positive note, we had an excellent first quarter, with Avista Utilities contributing $0.92 per diluted share compared to $0.68 last year.
Relative to the previous year, our earnings improved due to increased utility margins.
We experienced growth in our customer base and implemented general rate hikes.
The initial quarter of this year included an accrual, while the same period last year had negative accruals related to the Washington remand case from 2015, Colstrip disallowances, and an accrual for the Colstrip community fund.
These factors negatively impacted earnings in 2020.
The ERM in Washington provided a pre-tax benefit of $4.3 million in Q1 this year, compared to $5.2 million in Q1 2020.
We remain dedicated to investing necessary capital in our utility infrastructure, with Avista Utilities' capital expenditures expected to reach approximately $415 million in 2021.
Regarding liquidity, we repaid the outstanding balance of our one-year credit agreement on April 5, 2021, which we had entered into in April 2020 to ensure sufficient liquidity at the pandemic's onset.
As of April 30, we had $182 million available under our $400 million credit line, which we plan to extend into a multi-year agreement in Q2.
We anticipate issuing about $120 million in long-term debt and $75 million in equity in 2021.
We are reaffirming our earnings guidance for 2021, 2022, and 2023 with consolidated ranges of $1.96 to $2.16, $2.18 to $2.38, and $2.42 to $2.62 per diluted share, respectively.
This projection puts us on track to achieve our allowed return by 2023.
Our guidance assumes timely and appropriate rate relief across all jurisdictions.
The 2021 earnings guidance accounts for unrecovered structural costs, estimated to reduce our return on equity by about 70 basis points.
Additionally, our 2021 guidance factors in a regulatory timing lag, estimated to decrease our equity return by approximately 100 basis points.
This results in an expected return on equity of about 7.7% for Avista Utilities in 2021.
We project annual customer growth of roughly 1% for Avista Utilities.
For 2021, Avista Utilities is anticipated to contribute between $1.93 and $2.07 per diluted share at the midpoint of our guidance range, excluding any expense or benefit under the Energy Recovery Mechanism.
We currently expect to be in the 75% customer, 25% Company sharing band, which is projected to add about $0.06 per diluted share.
In 2021, we expect AEL&P to contribute between $0.08 and $0.11 per diluted share, with our outlook for both Avista Utilities and AEL&P assuming normal precipitation and slightly below normal (about 92%) hydroelectric generation for Avista Utilities.
For 2021, we anticipate our other businesses to range between a loss of $0.05 to $0.02 per diluted share.
Our guidance generally assumes normal operating conditions and excludes unusual or non-recurring items until their effects are known and measurable.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q1 earnings per share $0.98.
q1 earnings per share $0.98.
confirming 2021, 2022, and 2023 earnings guidance.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The conference call will be directed by the CEO, Doug Dietrich, and the CFO, Matt Garth.
I'd like to draw attention to the Safe Harbor disclaimer displayed.
Forward-looking statements made by team members are subject to these restrictions, warnings, and stipulations.
We thank you for joining us today and hope you're all keeping well.
Allow me to provide a brief outline of the call's agenda.
I'll start by reviewing our third quarter highlights, including improving sales trends, enhanced operational and financial standing, and advancements in business development.
I want to address the 8-K we filed this week regarding a recent ransomware attack that affected access to some of our company's IT systems.
We have established protocols for such incidents.
Upon detecting the issue, we immediately implemented our comprehensive cybersecurity response plan, including steps to isolate and carefully restore our network to resume normal operations as quickly as possible.
We've informed law enforcement and are collaborating with leading cybersecurity experts to conduct a thorough investigation.
Throughout this incident, we maintained safe facility operations and met our customer obligations.
Before delving into the third quarter review, I'd like to express my satisfaction with our global team and businesses' performance in this ongoing complex and challenging environment.
We continue to prioritize employee safety, efficient plant operations, and delivering value-added products to our customers.
Our employees' dedication, engagement, and resilience have been exceptional during these times.
Let me walk you through our third quarter performance.
As anticipated in July, demand conditions in our end markets improved following the second quarter's acute COVID-19 impacts, largely playing out as expected with our readiness to respond to volume recovery leading to sequential sales growth across nearly all product lines.
Overall, we had a strong quarter operationally and commercially.
These results reflect our team's disciplined execution in cost control, pricing, and productivity, resulting in higher sequential and year-over-year operating margins.
We also demonstrated how our robust product portfolio and end market mix enabled us to capture opportunities with existing and new customers.
Financially, total quarterly sales were $388 million, a 9% sequential increase but still lower than last year.
As indicated in our previous call, July sales were trending upward and demand conditions in several markets continued to strengthen throughout the quarter.
We generated $52 million in operating income with earnings per share of $0.92.
Additionally, we delivered $54 million in cash from operations, maintaining our solid cash generation profile.
After experiencing volatile conditions in our industrial-related end markets through the second quarter, we saw significant demand improvements in the third quarter, along with continued strength in our consumer-oriented product lines.
Let me highlight some key points.
Our Metalcasting business continued to rebound as North American foundry customers increased production to meet rising automotive sector demand.
By the end of the third quarter, our Metalcasting facilities were operating at about 95% of last year's levels, a notable improvement from earlier reduced levels.
Furthermore, our pre-blended products' penetration maintains a strong growth trajectory in China, with sales increasing 20% over last year, a momentum expected to continue.
Sales in our consumer products portfolio, including Pet Care, Personal Care, and Edible Oil Purification, remained resilient, led by 11% year-over-year growth in Pet Care.
We continue to strengthen our robust private label Pet Care portfolio in North America and Europe, expanding our presence through partnerships with several new customers.
Our global PCC business benefited from satellite restarts in India and North America, combined with an improved demand environment from the second quarter's low levels.
As indicated previously, July volumes were trending approximately 15% higher compared to June, and these dynamics continued through the third quarter.
Notably, Paper PCC sales in China continue to deliver solid performance with 18% growth over last year.
Additionally, Specialty PCC sales increased sequentially as automotive and construction demand strengthened, while food and pharmaceutical applications remained strong.
Other areas of strength included our Talc and GCC business, with improved demand for products used in residential and commercial construction, as well as automotive applications.
In our Refractories business, we saw U.S. steel utilization rates increase from a second-quarter low of 50% to 65% by the end of September.
While many businesses returned to a positive trajectory, we faced challenges in project-oriented businesses like Environmental Products, Building Materials, and Energy Services, which still experience volatile order patterns and timing delays.
Energy Services was further impacted by several Gulf of Mexico hurricanes during the quarter.
As volumes trended upward through the quarter, we leveraged these sales into income, resulting in overall operating and EBITDA margin improvement both sequentially and year-over-year.
We've maintained our focus on operational efficiency, including variable cost adjustments and structural overhead savings, as well as continued pricing increases, capturing favorable raw material costs, and increasing sales of higher-value products.
As markets continue to recover, we are well-positioned to further expand margins on increased volumes.
Strengthening our financial position remains a priority, emphasizing tight control of our cash generation cycle and creating more flexibility in our capital structure.
We delivered another quarter of strong cash flow generation, primarily used to pay down debt.
While navigating the current environment, we've remained focused on advancing our growth initiatives, making further progress this quarter on several fronts.
Let me provide more detailed highlights of these advancements.
The commissioning of two new PCC satellites scheduled for the fourth quarter continues to progress, with production ramping up at our 45,000-ton facility in India, and our 150,000-ton satellite in China expected to be operational by December.
We will also resume production in November at our previously closed satellite in Wickliffe, Kentucky, to support Phoenix Paper's mill restart.
During the quarter, we made a small acquisition of a hauling and mining company to further strengthen our vertically integrated position at our Wyoming bentonite mines.
This transaction improves our cost position and enhances our mining and transportation flexibility in the region.
In our Refractories business, we signed two new five-year contracts to supply refractory and metallurgical wire products in the U.S., totaling approximately $50 million or about $10 million of incremental annual revenue.
Our new product development efforts are progressing well as we aim to accelerate commercialization and drive new revenue opportunities.
We've commercialized 36 value-added products so far in 2020, with contributions from each business.
Twelve of these products were introduced in the third quarter.
We've maintained a similar pace to last year while conducting many product development activities virtually.
Overall, there are numerous positives about our quarterly performance, especially our execution as a company while navigating difficult conditions.
Challenges remain ahead.
With strong momentum across many businesses and an enhanced cost profile, we expect to continue delivering improved profitability as volumes recover.
I will now examine our results for the third quarter, the performance of our four divisions, and our cash flow and liquidity positions.
Let's begin our analysis of the third quarter results.
Sales for the third quarter reached $388.3 million, representing a 9% increase from the previous quarter but a 14% decrease compared to last year.
Our gross margin, EBITDA margin, and operating margin all showed improvement both sequentially and year-over-year, driven by our ongoing pricing strategies and productivity enhancements.
SG&A expenses remained unchanged from the second quarter, also contributing to the expansion in margins.
Excluding special items, earnings per share were $0.92, and we incurred special charges of $3.2 million after-tax in the third quarter, equivalent to $0.09 per share.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 19.8%, compared to 19.1% in the previous year and 16% in the preceding quarter.
Looking ahead, we anticipate our effective tax rate to be around 20%.
Let's now examine the changes in sales and operating income in greater detail.
This slide presents year-over-year comparisons of sales and operating income on the left, and sequential quarter comparisons on the right.
Third quarter sales decreased by 13% compared to the previous year on a constant currency basis.
The economic slowdown caused by the COVID-19 pandemic continued to affect our volumes year-over-year during the quarter.
The operating income bridge on the bottom left demonstrates our ability to significantly offset the impact of lower sales compared to the previous year through favorable pricing and cost performance driven by actions we've taken over the past year.
These measures resulted in a higher operating margin compared to the previous year despite lower volume.
Sequentially, we observed a significant improvement in demand, with sales increasing by 7% when adjusted for currency and 9% overall.
Conditions improved across most of our end markets, and we maintained pricing levels throughout the company.
During our last call, we mentioned that July sales rates were trending approximately 5% higher than June, and this trend accelerated throughout the third quarter.
Daily sales rates in August were 6% higher than July, and September was 7% higher than August.
Operating income increased by 18% sequentially on a constant currency basis, primarily due to improvements in our end markets and continued cost control.
The operating margin for the quarter was 13.3%, compared to 13.2% in the previous year and 11.8% in the second quarter.
Let's take a closer look at the operating margins and their improvement on the next slide.
This slide shows year-over-year and sequential operating margin bridges for the third quarter.
Comparing to the previous year, our pricing and cost actions contributed 190 basis points of improvement, more than offsetting the unfavorable volume impact.
Sequentially, we leveraged additional volume into 60 basis points of margin improvement, and our continued cost control contributed another 70 basis points of favorability.
Our actions regarding pricing, productivity, cost control, and new product development have positioned us well to leverage incremental volumes into improved margins going forward.
Another notable margin highlight for the third quarter was the 70 basis point improvement in EBITDA margin compared to both the previous year and the previous quarter.
Let's now move on to the segment review, starting with Performance Materials.
Performance Materials sales increased by 10% sequentially but were 8% lower than the previous year.
Metalcasting sales grew 26% sequentially as foundry production improved in North America and demand remained strong in China.
The improvement in North America was primarily driven by the ramp-up of automotive production.
China Metalcasting sales grew 11% sequentially and 20% compared to the previous year due to continued strong demand from our customers and increased penetration of our specially formulated blended products.
Household, Personal Care, and Specialty Product sales remained resilient, increasing 7% sequentially and remaining flat compared to the previous year due to continued strong demand for consumer-oriented products.
Environmental Products and Building Materials continued to experience COVID-19-related project delays, with sales remaining below previous year levels.
The segment's operating income was $28.2 million, up 34% sequentially and 5% compared to the previous year.
Operating margin was 14.8% of sales, an increase of 270 basis points from the second quarter and 180 basis points from the previous year.
Continued pricing actions, strong cost control, and expense reductions more than offset the operating income impact of lower sales compared to the previous year.
The chart on the bottom right shows daily sales rates by month this year compared to the previous year.
This segment experienced a clear rebound in demand, with sales increasing steadily throughout the third quarter.
We would typically expect a seasonal decrease in sales for this segment between the third and fourth quarters, driven by our construction and environmental end markets.
However, this year, we expect to offset the typical seasonality with continued positive momentum in our other markets.
Overall, we anticipate fourth quarter sales to be similar to the third quarter, despite the usual seasonal effects.
It's worth noting that we experience higher mining and energy costs while operating in colder months, which will temporarily impact segment margins in the fourth quarter.
Now let's move on to Specialty Minerals.
Specialty Minerals sales totaled $125.1 million in the third quarter, up 14% sequentially but 13% below the previous year.
PCC sales increased 14% sequentially as paper mill capacity came back online in the U.S. and India following temporary COVID-19-related shutdowns.
Paper PCC sales in China grew 11% sequentially and 18% compared to the previous year due to continued penetration and strong customer demand.
Specialty PCC sales increased 16% sequentially as automotive and construction demand improved throughout the quarter, while consumer-oriented products remained strong.
Processed Minerals sales increased 13% as end markets steadily improved throughout the quarter.
Operating income, excluding special items, was $18 million, up 18% sequentially but 17% below the previous year, representing 14.4% of sales, compared to 13.9% in the second quarter and 15.2% in the previous year.
The impact of lower volume compared to the previous year was partially offset by continued pricing actions and cost control.
Daily sales rates for this segment also show improving conditions throughout the third quarter, and we expect this trend to continue into the fourth quarter as paper production in the U.S., Europe, and India continues to ramp up.
Additionally, we are bringing new capacity online in the coming months, with most of this capacity becoming operational late in the fourth quarter.
The sequential improvement in Paper PCC will offset the typical seasonality we experience in the residential construction markets served by the other product lines.
Overall, for the segment, we expect fourth quarter sales to be similar to the third quarter.
Now let's turn to Refractories.
Refractories segment sales were $59.3 million in the third quarter, up 6% sequentially as steel mill utilization rates gradually improved from second quarter levels in both North America and Europe.
Segment operating income was $7.3 million, up 24% from the previous quarter, representing 12.3% of sales.
Daily sales rates showed improvement throughout the third quarter.
We anticipate further progress in Q4 as steel usage increases and laser equipment purchases rise.
For the segment overall, we predict a slight sequential uptick in Q4 sales compared to Q3.
Let's now discuss Energy Services.
The Energy Services division faced major project postponements in Q3.
These delays stemmed from COVID-19 restrictions and several weather-related shutdowns in the Gulf of Mexico during an active hurricane season.
Consequently, Q3 sales were $13.3 million with breakeven operating income.
The daily sales rates graph indicates a strong year start, followed by sales levels remaining low compared to the previous year.
We see a robust pipeline of activity and expect this business to improve sequentially in Q4.
Now, let's examine our cash flow and liquidity highlights.
As Doug mentioned, Q3 cash from operations was $54 million and free cash flow reached $40 million.
We maintained a balanced approach to cash deployment, reducing debt by $30 million and resuming share buybacks, acquiring $3 million of shares in Q3.
We continued repurchasing shares in October, completing the expiring program with $50 million of shares under the $75 million authorization.
As stated earlier, the Board has approved a new one-year $75 million repurchase program.
Our net leverage ratio stands at 2.1 times EBITDA with $682 million in liquidity, including over $375 million cash on hand.
Before handing back to Doug for the market outlook, I'll summarize our Q4 expectations for each segment.
In our Minerals businesses, we anticipate ongoing improvement in many markets to offset typical seasonality, with sales expected to match Q3 levels.
Margins will remain strong year-over-year, though sequentially they'll be affected by seasonally higher mining and energy costs.
In our Services business, we expect gradual improvement in Refractories as utilization rates increase and sequential improvement in Energy Services as delayed projects resume and activity picks up.
Overall, we anticipate MTI's Q4 sales to be comparable to Q3.
Before starting the Q&A session, I'd like to provide more insight into conditions across our businesses and growth opportunities we see.
The improving market trends seen in most of our businesses will likely continue through year-end, while project-oriented businesses may face ongoing challenges with unpredictable customer order patterns.
Additionally, as we build on Q3 momentum, we're executing various attractive growth projects that will contribute to 2021 revenue.
Let me walk you through each business segment, beginning with Performance Materials, our largest and most diverse segment.
Our Household and Personal Care product line will maintain its strong sales trajectory as demand remains high and we leverage expanded channels and new customer relationships.
Specifically, we're growing our premium Pet Care products portfolio in North America and Europe by expanding online retail channels with larger customers and introducing new products like our 100% carbon-neutral Eco Care product in Europe, satisfying customer preferences while contributing to sustainability efforts.
Additionally, sales of our Edible Oil Purification products have more than doubled since last year as we expand this business through a broader global customer base.
In Metalcasting, we expect to continue benefiting from the automotive demand rebound in North America.
As mentioned earlier, we expanded our customer base in China through increased penetration of higher-value blended products, leading to 20% sales growth over last year.
This solid growth trend will continue through year-end and into 2021.
I'll discuss Environmental Products and Building Materials together as they face similar dynamics.
While both maintain robust, active pipelines and continue introducing specialized products, these businesses have been impacted by timing delays in customers starting larger remediation and waterproofing projects.
Moving to the Specialty Minerals segment, starting with Paper PCC.
As paper demand in North America and Europe gradually improves, we expect sequential volume growth across all regions in Q4.
Asia, particularly China, will maintain its solid growth trajectory.
We'll also benefit from our satellite ramp-up in India, and our new Chinese satellite should be operational in December.
Looking ahead, we have two new facilities coming online in the first half of 2021: one for packaging in Europe and another for standard PCC in India.
Overall, we're bringing 285,000 tons of new PCC capacity online over the next three quarters.
We also maintain a very active business development pipeline across our PCC technologies portfolio, including high filler, packaging, and recycling.
Each of these could increase our overall volume next year.
In Specialty PCC, GCC, and Talc, sales for pharmaceutical and consumer products, including food applications, will remain strong.
Demand for high-performance sealant and plastic products used in automotive applications should strengthen as build rates continue improving in North America and Europe.
Sales for products used in residential and commercial construction applications should remain steady.
For Refractories, current steel utilization rates in North America and Europe are around 70% and 65% respectively, expected to gradually improve in coming quarters.
Our laser measurement equipment order book remains strong for Q4.
As mentioned earlier, we've recently signed two five-year contracts totaling $50 million to supply refractory and metallurgical wire products, contributing to revenue growth in 2021.
Lastly, in Energy Services, we maintain an active offshore services pipeline.
While COVID-19 and adverse weather have led to early demobilizations or postponements of larger offshore projects, some have been rescheduled for Q4.
We've also recently won new large projects in the Gulf of Mexico, expected to start over the next few quarters.
We're focused on navigating a highly dynamic environment, and our continuous improvement culture positions us well.
Over the past six months, we've successfully implemented virtual tools to enhance productivity, efficiency, and connectivity with employees and customers.
I'm impressed with how quickly we've adapted to the changing environment.
These tools have enabled smooth business operations, allowing seamless connections with operating facilities for meetings and site visits, conducting problem-solving Kaizen events, and efficiently collaborating and communicating with our global customer base.
Many of these new daily operational methods will become permanent, balanced with in-person activities.
Looking ahead to 2021, I'm confident in our direction, our solid foundation to leverage improved market conditions, and our growth projects.
While COVID-related uncertainties persist, our end markets continue showing signs of improvement.
Our operational actions position us well to drive improved profitability.
Additionally, our strong, flexible balance sheet provides solid resources to support both organic and inorganic growth opportunities.
Let's now open the call for questions.
Summary:
output:
compname reports third quarter 2020 earnings of $0.83 per share, or $0.92 per share, excluding special items.
q3 earnings per share $0.92 excluding items.
q3 sales $388 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $386.1 million.
incurred special charges of $3.2 million after-tax in q3, or $0.09 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:As I examine the previous quarter and provide insights into our current quarter's operations, I want to emphasize that we will be making comparisons to both 2020 and 2019
Due to the periods of quarantine and stimulus that affected the business in waves last year, we are using 2019 as a benchmark to illustrate underlying business trends
I am satisfied with our second quarter results as we continue to show strong growth compared to 2019, validating our Operation North Star strategies, showing progress in our core product range, and highlighting the relationships we are building with existing and new customers, both online and in-store
During the quarter, we observed strong double-digit, two-year comparative growth in Furniture, Soft Home, Hard Home, and Apparel, Electronics & Other
Consumables also showed a positive two-year comparison, while Food decreased by mid-single digits, reduced on a square footage basis by our pantry reorganization last autumn
Consequently, while down 13% compared to last year, comparable sales for the second quarter increased 14% compared to 2019
Furthermore, we achieved diluted earnings per share of $1.09 within our projected range, despite ongoing supply chain and distribution challenges that were more significant than anticipated at the start of the quarter and cost us at least 1 point of comparative growth
While the Big Lots team is always occupied, we were exceptionally busy over the past quarter engaging with customers, expanding our store count, enhancing our omnichannel offerings, streamlining our e-commerce channel, introducing a new warranty offering through Allstate, expanding additional Lot and Queue Line stores, preparing to launch two new forward distribution centers and Project Refresh at the beginning of the third quarter, further expanding our BIGionaire's brand activation campaign, and navigating a challenging supply chain market
While addressing these initiatives and macro forces, our teams remained steadfastly focused on our customers' needs, continuing our mission to help them live big and save lots
We are currently dealing with and navigating the dynamic and ever-changing complexities of the supply chain
However, we are simultaneously investing in our future and our promising long-term growth opportunities
I speak on behalf of all Big Lots leadership when I express our gratitude to the over 30,000 Big Lots team members
We remain very enthusiastic about the vast growth opportunities ahead of us, and recognize that investing in our customers, our people, and our infrastructure will be crucial to realizing that growth potential
Freight challenges impacted gross margin for the quarter, and additionally, our performance was affected by labor issues in two of our regional distribution centers
This situation is improving as we enter Q3, and pressure on our network will be further alleviated by the opening of our first two forward distribution centers
To address immediate supply chain pressures and maintain speed to market, we have established a flexible and adaptable temporary DC bypass program for the fourth quarter that will enhance the efficiency of our DCs and increase our network capacity
Meanwhile, we remain enthusiastic about our merchandising opportunities, and we are focused on offering customer-centric deals every day
We continue to expand our ability to source closeout products in most areas of the store
We are working diligently to find great deals and big buys for our customers, whether we source them from closeouts, engineered closeouts, or just exceptional value products we find in the market
We anticipate the potential for closeout opportunities to grow in 2022
As we focus on item merchandising and key value messaging, our customers are responding positively
For instance, our increased investment in apparel is leading to the acquisition of customers who are exploring more of the Big Lots product range
Additionally, this is an excellent example of increasing merchandised productivity within the store, driving incremental sales with a strong initial markup and expanding our brand recognition with quality products
Regarding our category performance, Food and Consumables both declined compared to Q2 2020 as we lap last year's COVID impact
Consumables were positive on a two-year basis and both categories exceeded our expectations at the beginning of the quarter
In Food, we have continued to observe a shift away from grocery and baking categories and towards more snacks, beverages, energy drinks, and on-the-go food
In consumables, we saw a rebound in the household chemicals category as well as cosmetics, while paper sales, demand for bath tissue and paper towels continue to be somewhat challenged, driven by previous COVID-related stockpiling
A year ago, we reset Food and Consumables across the store, and this is performing well
As we approach the anniversary of this reset, we continue to see opportunities to improve overall productivity and enhance values with big deals, own brands, and everyday low prices on brand names
Our Seasonal assortment, which includes patio, lawn and garden, and summer categories like coles, and 4th of July themed goods, was challenged for the quarter due to shipping delays and inventory availability
The overall category experienced a 15% decrease in comparable sales compared to last year, but a 4% increase compared to Q2 2019
Moving into Q3, our inventory situation has improved, and we have seen a resurgence in sales with early strength from our Halloween and Harvest assortment
Although supply chain pressures related to Asian port and manufacturing disruption will continue to create challenges, we are much better prepared for the crucial holiday season
Soft Home comparable sales were up 14% compared to 2019
While we saw softness in fashion bedding, all other categories met expectations
Bath rugs and towels, patio rugs, and floor mats were particularly strong this quarter
Also noteworthy were the candle collection categories within home decor, with strong double-digit growth compared to 2019
Hard Home comparable sales were up 13% compared to 2019, exceeding our expectations with appliances and home organization delivering double-digit increases compared to 2019
Key classifications such as floor care, kitchen appliances, storage, dinnerware, and cookware continued to trend strongly, partially offset by lower, but positive comparable sales to 2019 in tabletop, food prep, and home maintenance
Closeouts in Hard Home were up even more compared to 2020, with appliances, cookware, and home organization all performing very well
Toys, now included in our Hard Home category following our merchandising reorganization, also performed quite well and ahead of expectations
Furniture delivered another very strong quarter, with comparable sales down 10% compared to last year, but up 30% compared to 2019
The furniture team did an outstanding job of mitigating inventory challenges, primarily resulting from chemical shortages affecting foam production, and we achieved our strategic goal of winning Memorial Day weekend with positive comparable sales to both last year and two years ago
Upholstery was particularly strong in Q2, delivering flat comparable sales to 2020 and up almost 40% compared to 2019, driven by high demand for sofas and sectionals
Anchored by the Broyhill brand, which continues to gain market share, it now accounts for over 40% of total upholstery sales
Apparel, Electronics & Other also performed very strongly, up 15% compared to 2020
Apparel delivered a 90% comparable sales increase for the quarter, with casual and athletic lifestyle dressing dominating the women's business
Although tops remain strong, we saw high sell-through rates in capris and shorts as well
Men's active tops and shorts performed well
Closeouts continued to expand within the assortment, offering value, breadth, and new classifications
Accessories saw nice increases in hair and jewelry
Additionally, luggage was introduced as a new category in July with strong sales results that will provide additional growth as we look toward the latter half of the year and into 2022
The Lot continues to strengthen, delighting our customers with fun, innovative treasures perfect for life's occasions while contributing nearly 2% of the Company's sales in the quarter
We executed a camping theme set and a nostalgia set during the quarter, both of which resonated well with big hits from national brand camping suppliers, novelty small appliances, and unexpected finds such as popcorn-themed items, a TV projector, large video game units, and novelty pet styles
I would now like to discuss our longer-term growth strategy
We remain excited about the tremendous progress we are making under Operation North Star, where our growth drivers are expanding our customer base, improving our e-commerce conversion, enhancing merchandise productivity, and increasing our store count
Regarding customer growth, we are thrilled with the continued rollout of our "Be A BIGionaire" brand campaign that we previewed last quarter
This program is based on extensive consumer insights into why customers love to shop with us
Our customers see us as the destination for hunting exceptional bargains and surprising treasures
I'm delighted to share that this campaign is driving a 2% increase in transactions in the markets where we have introduced it
New BIGionaires visiting Big Lots for the first time are driving 60% of these incremental transactions
The campaign has also increased brand awareness, consideration, and purchase rates, demonstrating that we are gaining relevance
Our first campaign featured Retta, who successfully transferred her relatability and humor from Good Girls and Parks and Recreation into our BIGionaire campaign
As we prepare for the holiday season, you can expect to see additional stars hunting for bargains and treasures at their neighborhood Big Lots
In the near future, viewers will see Eric Stonestreet, renowned for his part in the popular sitcom Modern Family, and Molly Shannon, famed for her memorable characters on Saturday Night Live.
Eric and Molly fully embodied the Big Lots spirit.
We're excited to provide more information in the coming days.
We're delighted that the campaign is striking a chord with younger consumers.
Our customer age distribution has shifted, with a 6% increase in new customers aged 25-39, moving away from those 55 and above.
Discerning shoppers across all age groups are discovering Big Lots and appreciating our comprehensive home offerings that combine exceptional value and superior style.
Our rewards program continues to drive business growth, with active membership up 8% compared to Q2 2020, adding 1.8 million new members last quarter, bringing total membership to 21.5 million.
Moreover, rewards customers spent 16% more overall than last year and 7% more per individual.
Over 72% of our Q2 sales were linked to our rewards program.
This sales penetration is up 4% compared to the same quarter last year.
We're also seeing great success in reactivating lapsed members through targeted win-back campaigns.
Demand rose 10% compared to Q2 2020, representing over 400% growth from Q2 2019.
While in-store traffic decreased compared to Q2 2020, as we move past the peak of 2020's pandemic response, this was more than offset by increases in conversion rates and average purchase amounts.
Demand for our seasonal lawn and garden products and furniture continued the strong momentum from Q1.
E-commerce growth is supported by our investments in improving search, purchase, and fulfillment capabilities, including buy online pickup in store, curbside pickup, ship from store, and same-day delivery via Instacart and Pickup.
These services have been very successful, accounting for over 60% of our demand fulfillment.
To support the holiday season, we're increasing the number of stores offering ship-from-store fulfillment to 65.
We're further streamlining transactions by introducing PayPal as our third mobile wallet payment option for the holidays, joining Apple and Google Pay, and we plan to launch a new buy now, pay later option later this quarter.
We've also updated our website's appearance to align with and enhance our brand's upbeat image and the BIGionaire campaign.
Our Broyhill product line continued to show strong momentum, generating $194 million in Q2 sales.
This represents a $77 million increase from Q2 2020, when we had just launched the brand.
We're thrilled with Broyhill's trajectory and anticipate continued strong growth, with over $400 million in year-to-date sales, surpassing last year's full-year performance and on track to become a $1 billion brand.
It's worth noting that Broyhill is just one aspect, albeit a major focus, of our own brand strategy.
We're also heavily investing in Real Living, a private label in our furniture and home goods department with a lower price point than Broyhill.
We're seeing early growth in this brand by consolidating our unbranded goods and transitioning from other private labels currently in the store.
We're also introducing new products to ensure a complete offering under the Real Living brand.
Real Living has quickly ramped up, generating over $400 million in year-to-date sales, and we're confident it will also become a $1 billion own brand for Big Lots.
Our Lot and Queue Line front-end strategies are now implemented in approximately 1,225 stores.
These initiatives serve as innovation labs, introducing new products that enhance the rest of the store's assortment and strengthen customer engagement.
The Lot and Queue Line continue to drive a combined 3% incremental lift in store performance.
Both have become established aspects of the Big Lots shopping experience, with transactions containing items from the Lot tending to be of higher value, include more items, and connect to more of the store's assortment, while the queue lines are driving strong incremental impulse purchases at checkout.
In previous calls, we introduced our next-generation furniture sales team test, which places dedicated furniture-focused associates on the sales floor to educate customers about our home furnishings range and quality.
I'm excited to announce that this test, now in over 80 stores, continues to perform well, delivering around a 15% increase in furniture sales.
We plan to roll out this next-generation model to several hundred stores in 2022, expected to deliver at least a 1% comp increase to the total company on an annualized basis.
Regarding store count, our growth is accelerating this year and will further accelerate in 2022 and beyond.
Based on recent work, we're confident there's potential to increase our store count by hundreds of stores in the coming years, with two to three times the net store growth in 2022 compared to the net increase of around 20 stores we expect this year.
Simultaneously, we expect to continue slowing our closure rate due to our store intervention program, which will only affect around 15 stores this year.
All these growth drivers are supported by key enabling investments.
Earlier this year, we announced plans to open two forward bulk and furniture distribution centers mid-year to support our growth and relieve pressure on our current regional distribution centers.
We're pleased to announce that our first FDC opened in early August, and our second will begin receiving inventory next week.
We're also pleased with the performance of our new transportation management system, which has been crucial in mitigating pressures within our distribution network.
During Q2, we initiated a multi-year program called Project Refresh to upgrade approximately 800 stores not included in our 2017 to early 2020 Store of the Future program.
These stores will receive new exterior signage, interior repainting and floor repair, a new vestibule experience, remodeled bathrooms, and interior wall graphics, all at a much lower cost than our previous Store of the Future conversions.
This will create a consistent brand experience across our stores and enhance our brand for the long term.
The average cost per store will be around $100,000, significantly lower than the previous Store of the Future program.
As I hope I've conveyed, both in this quarter's discussion and in previous calls, we have a strong belief in our growth potential and in the continued opportunities that Operation North Star presents.
The underlying progress we're making is increasingly evident.
Before handing over to Jonathan, I want to revisit the supply chain and distribution challenges we've discussed, which we expect will continue to impact our business in Q3 and Q4.
Before the recent global COVID resurgence, we were seeing increased import costs driven by a global increase in demand for ocean freight.
Over the past few months, this situation has been exacerbated by the temporary shutdown of the port at Yantian, China, and temporary factory and port closures elsewhere in Asia.
Vietnam, where segments of our furniture and seasonal categories are sourced, is currently under COVID restrictions that impact our suppliers' ability to produce at scale.
The Vietnamese government is targeting September 15th as the date to ease restrictions.
Additionally, the port of Ningbo, China experienced a terminal closure in mid-August, although it has now reopened.
These developments highlight the fluidity of the situation and the ongoing uncertainties caused by COVID-19.
While these pressures are expected to be temporary, they are resulting in both cost increases due to an imbalance of container supply and demand, as well as sales impacts due to delayed inflow of products, particularly from Vietnam.
The guidance that Jonathan will cover shortly incorporates our current estimates of these impacts.
In summary, we face some near-term challenges, but our underlying business remains strong, as evidenced by our strong two-year comps in the second quarter, which have continued into Q3.
We remain confident that our Operation North Star strategies will drive significant growth in the coming years, supported by key investments we are making.
As Bruce mentioned, we accomplished a great deal this quarter as our teams remained focused on providing an excellent experience, assortment, and value to our customers.
Net sales for the second quarter were $1.457 billion, an 11.4% decrease compared to $1.644 billion a year ago.
The decline was driven by a 13.2% decrease in comparable sales as we lap stimulus impacts in 2020 and the peak of last year's nesting activities, partially offset by a 180 basis point impact from net store openings and relocations.
Our comp result was slightly below our negative low-double digit guidance, due to labor challenges at two of our regional distribution centers, which adversely impacted store inventories.
Total sales were up 16% compared to 2019's $1.252 billion, with a two-year comp of 14% driven by basket size.
Note that when we reference two-year comps going forward, we will be using a multiplied rather than an additive basis.
The company's net income in Q2 was $37.7 million, compared to $110.1 million in Q2 2020 and $20.6 million in 2019
Quarterly diluted earnings per share reached $1.09, falling within the anticipated range
Last year, we reported adjusted earnings per share of $2.75, excluding the profit from selling our four distribution centers
This year's Q2 earnings per share reflected effective expense management, offsetting a slight sales shortfall
Share repurchases during the quarter provided an additional benefit of approximately $0.03
The Q2 gross margin rate was 39.6%, a decrease of 200 basis points from last year and 20 basis points below 2019, aligning with our projections
Our margin rate was impacted by freight challenges, partially offset by cost benefits, price increases, and strategic markdown management
Freight expenses were higher than initially projected, causing nearly 200 basis points of gross margin reduction year-over-year
Total quarterly expenses, including depreciation, were $524 million, down from $534 million last year and slightly below initial expectations, despite distribution and transportation cost pressures
The quarter's operating margin was 3.7%, compared to 9.1% last year and 2.6% in 2019
Excluding freight challenges, our operating margin would have been around 5.7%, a 300 basis point improvement over 2019
Quarterly interest expense was $2.3 million, down from $2.5 million in Q2 last year
On June 7th, we paid off the remaining $44.3 million principal balance on our 2019 term note secured by Apple Valley distribution center equipment
We incurred a $0.4 million prepayment fee and recognized a $0.5 million loss on debt extinguishment in Q2 due to this prepayment
The Q2 income tax rate was 26.7%, up from 25.8% last year, primarily due to the impact of Section 162(m) executive compensation add back
Total inventory increased by 32% to $943.8 million, slightly exceeding our initial guidance
The inventory increase was due to comparing against unusually low levels at the end of Q2 2020
Inventories were up 8% compared to Q2 2019, maintaining strong two-year turn improvement while supporting Q3 performance
We opened 12 new stores and closed seven during Q2
At the end of Q2, we had 1,418 stores with a total selling area of 32.3 million square feet
Q2 capital expenditures were $45 million, compared to $41 million last year
Depreciation expense for the quarter was $35.3 million, about $1.3 million lower than the same period last year
We ended Q2 with $293 million in cash and cash equivalents and no long-term debt
At the end of Q2 2020, we had $899 million in cash and cash equivalents and $43 million in long-term debt
The year-over-year reduction in cash reflects our use of proceeds from the sale and leaseback of distribution centers for share repurchases and tax payments on the sale and leaseback gain
We repurchased 2.4 million shares for $153 million during the quarter, at an average cost of $63.57 per share, under our $500 million authorization
Approximately $97 million remained in the repurchase program at the end of Q2 2021
To date, we have repurchased 7.3 million shares at an average cost of $55.18, including commission
Our Board of Directors has declared a Q3 2021 quarterly cash dividend of $0.30 per common share
The dividend will be paid on September 24, 2021, to shareholders of record at the close of business on September 10th, 2021
We are facing significant sales and margin challenges due to Asian manufacturing and supply chain disruptions caused by recent COVID issues
We will incur additional expenses in the latter half of the year to ensure competitiveness in hiring and retaining labor in our stores and distribution centers
For Q3, we expect a diluted loss per share between $0.10 and $0.20, compared to $0.76 earnings per diluted share in Q3 2020
We anticipate full-year earnings per share between $5.90 and $6.05
While this is a decline from last year's adjusted diluted earnings per share of $7.35, it represents over 60% growth compared to 2019 earnings
Our guidance does not include any potential share repurchases in Q3 or Q4
We expect comps to be up low double digits on a two-year basis
Q3 has started well, with two-year comps ahead of Q2, but we anticipate some moderation as the quarter progresses due to receipt delays
For the full year, we expect a negative low-single digit comp versus 2020, equating to double-digit comps on a two-year basis
Our full-year sales outlook includes approximately $60 million of adverse impact in Q3 and Q4 related to COVID-related manufacturing shutdowns in Vietnam
We expect the Q3 gross margin rate to be down about 175 basis points from last year, primarily due to freight challenges
Compared to 2019, the Q3 rate is expected to be down approximately 100 basis points, almost entirely due to freight-related issues
Recent shutdowns at the port of Yantian in China have significantly increased container rates, impacting our cost of goods in Q3 and Q4
For the full year, we now expect a gross margin rate impact from freight of about 150 basis points, resulting in a gross margin rate decline of approximately 50 basis points versus 2019 and about 100 basis points versus 2020
We expect freight pressures to decrease moving forward, and we continue to see other areas of gross margin opportunity, including promotional and pricing optimization and shrink reduction
For SG&A, we expect Q3 and the full year to deleverage versus 2020 but show healthy leverage versus 2019 at our projected sales levels
Q3 expense dollars will be slightly higher than last year, driven by incremental investments in labor and forward distribution centers
Full-year SG&A expense dollars will increase compared to 2020 due to various factors, including the full-year impact of distribution center sale and leaseback, additional supply chain expenses, strategic investments, and higher equity compensation expense
These increases will be partially offset by over $30 million in structural expense savings, which remain a focus area
We still expect 2021 capital expenditures to be around $200 million to $210 million, including about 55 store openings, with around 20 being relocations
Our capex outlook includes the first wave of store upgrades under our new Project Refresh program
We expect a net increase of about 20 stores in 2021
We plan to accelerate store count growth in 2022 and beyond
Our research increasingly supports the opportunity for significant store count growth in coming years, and we are making necessary investments to support this
We continue to expect inventory to increase significantly versus 2020, reflecting very low levels a year ago
We are seeing strong early sales for our late fall and early holiday assortment, supported by higher inventory levels
We expect Q3 ending inventory to be up around 10% versus 2019, continuing to reflect healthy turn improvement
We anticipate a similar two-year inventory increase at the end of Q4, including some accelerated lawn and garden receipts to support Q1 sales and minimize further supply chain disruption risks
We aim to recapture seasonal sales lost over the past 12-18 months
Early Q4 receipts will drive around $6 million of additional supply chain expense
Q3 will be challenging due to supply chain issues, resulting sales impacts, and cost increases
However, we expect our underlying business, measured by our two-year comp trend, to remain strong, with healthy margins after adjusting for freight effects, supported by continued strong expense management
We are working hard to be well-positioned for the crucial holiday season
We look forward to continuing to demonstrate strong underlying performance in 2022 and beyond
