input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The Company has no obligation to provide updates on new information.
Whitestone's Q1 earnings report and supplementary operational and financial data have been submitted to the SEC and can be accessed in the Investor Relations area of our website, www.whitestonereit.com.
I will provide a concise summary of Whitestone and an update on our operations and recent events in Q1.
After my presentation, Dave Holeman will take over to give a financial update on our Q1 performance, followed by a Q&A session.
This quarter's results were enhanced by our strategic decision to position our portfolio in rapidly expanding Sunbelt markets, where we're at the forefront of the nation's economic reopening.
This strategic positioning contributed to our strong leasing performance, demonstrating the robustness of our business model and corporate culture.
Our operations team continues to exhibit flexibility and adaptability, supported by our robust financial infrastructure.
At the close of Q1 this year, our operating portfolio occupancy stood at 89.1%, up 0.5% from the previous quarter and only 0.6% lower than the same period last year.
Our rent collection rates continue to place us among the top performers in our industry peer group.
In Q1, we maintained strong collections, receiving approximately 95% of our rents for the quarter and for April.
We signed 46 new leases in Q1, a significant increase from 28 in the previous quarter, with a total lease count of 94, 12% higher than the preceding quarter.
Our blended leasing spread was 7.8%, a full percentage point higher than last quarter's 6.8%.
Our same-store net operating decrease of 4.3% remained unchanged from last quarter, yet still ranked among the best in the industry.
Furthermore, in Q1 we raised our quarterly dividend by 2.4% and have consistently paid monthly dividends to shareholders for 120 consecutive months.
Our staff have safely returned to work at our properties, and tenant businesses are ramping up with increased customer foot traffic as consumers resume their daily routines and visit our properties, while migration to our markets continues.
Our strategically located portfolio consists of high-quality, open-air real estate properties that generate predictable cash flow.
Our properties are situated near affluent communities and house tenants including grocery stores, pharmacies, and restaurants.
Our centers feature e-commerce-resistant tenants providing essential goods and services.
These tenants generate consistent foot traffic 18 hours a day, 7 days a week at our properties.
Consequently, our centers have remained operational throughout the past year, with most tenants continuing to operate, some even surpassing their pre-pandemic sales levels.
We remind shareholders that Whitestone was established during the 2008-2010 recession, and we've incorporated many lessons from that period into the company's core structure.
Our company has grown by acquiring properties in business-friendly states, rapidly expanding and densely populated cities, and high-income communities.
We've developed an internet-resistant business model focusing on consumer services and essential needs.
We've created a diverse portfolio of entrepreneurial tenants and structured leases with tenant owner recourse and minimal co-tenancy approval rights.
By offering yearly rent hikes of 2% to 3%, passing through triple net expenses, and concentrating on training and developing our staff for continuity, we aim to achieve our goals.
Our quick action to COVID-19 a year ago bolstered our balance sheet, liquidity, and financial flexibility to effectively manage the economic consequences of the pandemic.
Looking ahead to the initial quarter of 2021.
We are implementing our strategic expansion plan.
We are preparing for upcoming redevelopment and development initiatives.
We have lowered our overall debt, increased our dividend, and are continuing to expand our infrastructure.
Our past practice has been to expand our portfolio through individual off-market, value-added acquisitions in four specific markets.
Austin, Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, and Phoenix-Scottsdale.
We plan to maintain this approach to accumulate valuable properties in areas where tenants desire to lease and consumers want to visit.
By expanding in this manner, we have built a substantial portfolio of value-added properties.
In fact, we are in the process of acquiring a property in one of our target markets, our first purchase since the pandemic began, and we anticipate closing the deal this summer.
This acquisition will add nearly 200,000 square feet and is expected to immediately boost Whitestone's FFO per share and positively contribute to Whitestone's long-term objectives related to debt, leverage, and G&A coverage.
Moreover, our regional management team is in place, providing us with operational efficiencies as we expand our infrastructure.
We look forward to sharing more details as we progress throughout the year.
Moving ahead, Whitestone is well-positioned with an improving balance sheet, enhanced liquidity, a strong focus on increasing occupancy and revenue growth through leasing, leveraging our deep understanding of our markets, properties, and opportunities, along with our business model to provide and curate a tenant mix that appeals to credit-worthy entrepreneurial businesses.
This is how we generate long-term value for our shareholders.
First, I'd like to offer some additional context on the strength of our markets.
Our targeted focus on top MSAs in the Sunbelt continues to yield excellent results.
Texas and Arizona continue to experience significant population growth and corporate relocations, creating jobs from other parts of the country.
This is best demonstrated by our first quarter leasing activity, occupancy levels, leasing spreads, and our average base rent per leased square foot.
Our leasing activity in the quarter was robust, with 46 new leases representing 117,000 square feet of newly occupied space.
This volume of new lease square footage was 90% higher than our average quarterly lease volume for the previous three-year period.
It was also 21% higher than the highest quarter over the past three years.
In terms of total lease value, this quarter was more than double our average quarterly lease volume for the previous three-year period and 38% higher than the highest quarter over the past three years.
Regarding occupancy, our operating portfolio occupancy stood at 89.1%, up 1.5% from the fourth quarter and down only 0.6% from a year ago, with our Austin market leading the way with almost 4% increase in occupancy from Q4.
Leasing spreads on a GAAP basis have been positive 9% over the last 12 months, and first quarter leasing spreads increased 5.3% on new leases and 9.6% on renewal leases signed.
At the quarter's end, our yearly base rent per square foot on a GAAP basis increased by 1% to $19.71 from $19.58 in the previous quarter, aligning with our pre-COVID ABR from the prior year.
Core funds from operations were $0.23 per share in Q1, compared to $0.24 per share last year.
As mentioned, our collections approached normal pre-COVID levels, with 95% of contractual rents collected in Q1.
Our largest tenant category, restaurants and food service, comprising 23% of our ABR and 17% of leased square footage, performed exceptionally well, maintaining 95% rent collection in the quarter. We also observed positive trends in some affected customer types, with entertainment, representing only 2% of our ABR and leased square footage, paying 73% of their rents in Q1, up from 48% in Q4.
We had minimal rent deferrals during the quarter, accounting for 45% of our total contractual billings.
Our same-store net operating income decreased by 4.3% compared to the same quarter last year, but we anticipate same-store growth to resume throughout the rest of the year and into 2022.
Our reserve for uncollectible revenue was $529,000 or 1.8% of revenue, down from 4% in Q4, reflecting continued portfolio improvement. For perspective, our Q1 reserve is only 9% of the full-year 2020 reserves.
Interest expense was 8% lower than last year, due to $15 million less average debt and a decrease in overall interest rate from 3.9% to 3.6%.
The first quarter provides an encouraging start to 2021, highlighting the resilience of our forward-thinking business model and the strength of our strategically chosen high-growth markets.
Let me provide more details on our collections and related receivable balances.
Page 27 of our soft data breaks down our tenants by type. All credit categories had over 89% collection in Q1, except for entertainment, which I mentioned earlier. Our three largest categories - restaurants, grocery, and financial services - collected 95%, 100%, and 99% respectively.
At quarter's end, we had $23.3 million in accrued rents and accounts receivable, including $16.9 million of accrued straight-line rents and $1.8 million of agreed-upon deferrals. Our agreed-upon deferral balance decreased 18% from year-end, reflecting tenants honoring their payment plans.
Since early last year, we've implemented various measures to strengthen our liquidity and navigate economic pressures caused by the pandemic. Our total net debt is $632 million, down $17 million from a year ago, and our liquidity, representing cash and credit facility availability, stands at $39 million at quarter-end.
We continue progressing towards our publicly stated goal of reducing leverage. In April, we paid down an additional $10 million of our corporate credit facility. Currently, we have $140.5 million of undrawn capacity and $25.9 million of borrowing availability under our credit facility. We are in full compliance with all debt covenants and expect to remain so.
As mentioned earlier, 2021 has started promisingly. These results demonstrate the resilience of Whitestone's business model. We are encouraged by the recovery and look forward to resuming our growth strategy and continuing to deliver value to all Whitestone stakeholders.
We will now take questions. Operator, please open the lines.
Summary:
output: qtrly ffo core of $0.23 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In the second quarter, income and adjusted EBITDA grew by 17.5% and 23% respectively compared to the same period last year, mainly due to ongoing improvements in solid waste pricing, volume expansion, and robust recovered commodity values
These patterns led to a year-to-date adjusted EBITDA margin increase of 110 basis points and adjusted free cash flow exceeding $585 million, up 18.5% from last year, enabling us to revise our full-year projections upward for revenue, adjusted EBITDA, adjusted EBITDA margin, and adjusted free cash flow due to anticipated continued momentum and margin growth
The year 2021 may also see an exceptionally high level of acquisition activity
So far this year, we have finalized or agreed to 14 acquisitions with total yearly revenue of about $115 million, including $75 million from franchise operations in California, Nevada, and Oregon expected to be completed later this year
We are witnessing unprecedented levels of seller interest, leading to increased acquisition discussions, and as we've indicated throughout the year, we anticipate most of these transactions to be finalized in the latter half of the year, which will further boost our improved outlook for the year and provide strong growth momentum into 2022
During the call, we will examine non-GAAP metrics such as adjusted EBITDA, adjusted net income attributable to Waste Connections in both dollar amounts and per diluted share, and adjusted free cash flow
The management team employs certain non-GAAP measures to assess and monitor the ongoing financial performance of our operations
Different companies may calculate these non-GAAP measures using different methods
In Q2, solid waste price plus volume growth of 11.4% surpassed our projections by nearly 150 basis points, primarily due to higher-than-anticipated volumes as the recovery trends that started in Q1 persisted throughout the quarter, with landfill tons and roll-off pulls returning to levels comparable to or exceeding pre-pandemic figures
Overall pricing of 4.9%, a 70 basis point increase from the previous quarter, exceeded our forecast due to higher core pricing of 4.7%, once again demonstrating the robust pricing retention we observed in Q1, plus approximately 20 basis points in fuel and material surcharges
Our second quarter pricing varied from 2.6% in our predominantly exclusive Western region to between 4.5% and 7% in our more competitive regions
Looking forward, we are set for higher sequential pricing growth in the second half of the year due to additional price increases we have already implemented to counteract certain cost pressures
Reported volume growth of 6.5% in Q2 showed a sequential improvement of about 1,000 basis points from Q1 and was spearheaded by regions where markets were most severely impacted during the pandemic, including the Northeast U.S. and Canada
Every region displayed sequential improvement from Q1, and all reported positive volumes in Q2
Volumes ranged from approximately 4% in our Central region, where comparisons to the previous year were more challenging as many markets were relatively less affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, to almost 10.5% in Canada, one of our most impacted regions where the volume recovery has been remarkably strong, arguably outpacing the reopening activity, especially considering that many restrictions in Canada extended through Q2 of this year
Also noteworthy is our Western region, where volumes led our other regions going into the pandemic and continue to be the strongest in the U.S. at about 8.5% in Q2
Examining year-over-year results for the second quarter on a same-store basis, all lines of business increased by double digits Commercial collection revenue rose by 16% compared to the previous year
Roll-off pulls grew by over 11% year-over-year, led by Canada with an increase of almost 20%, returning to above pre-COVID-19 levels
In the United States, pulls increased by about 10%, and all regions showed year-over-year improvement, most notably in our more impacted markets, including the Northeast
Landfill tons increased by 17% year-over-year, with MSW tons up 11%, C&D tons up 20%, and special waste tons up 33%
Consequently, landfill tons have returned to above pre-pandemic levels in all of our regions, except the Eastern region, which was slightly below prior levels due to delayed reopening activity in Northeast markets
Taking a closer look at the results, as mentioned, all waste types experienced double-digit percentage increases year-over-year
However, the exceptionally high amount of special waste activity was particularly notable, as Q2 activity pushed tons back to 13% above pre-pandemic levels, with all regions showing year-over-year growth, possibly due to some activity being pulled forward from Q3
Examining Q2 revenues from recovery commodities, which include recycled commodities, landfill gas, and renewable energy credits (RINs), excluding acquisitions, they collectively increased by about 95% year-over-year, resulting in a combined margin boost of approximately 130 basis points, with 90 basis points from recycling and 40 basis points from landfill gas and RINs
Increases in recycling revenue were propelled by higher commodity prices, with old corrugated containers rising 25% and both plastics and metals more than doubling.
Year-over-year volume increases also contributed, reflecting the impact of the pandemic.
In Q2, OCC prices averaged approximately $135 per ton, while RIN pricing averaged about $2.72.
Let's now discuss E&P waste activity.
E&P waste revenue in the second quarter was $31.2 million, showing a 26% sequential increase from Q1 due to increased activity across multiple basins.
Turning to acquisition activity.
We have already signed or completed 14 acquisitions with annual revenue of about $115 million, nearing what we consider an average amount of activity for a full year.
These deals include several West Coast franchise markets, which align with our core strategy and offer unique opportunities to expand our exclusive contract portfolio.
Furthermore, our pipeline indicates record levels of seller interest, potentially leading to above-average activity in 2021, primarily due to tax-related considerations.
Nevertheless, we remain selective and disciplined in our acquisition approach, recognizing the importance of creating value for shareholders, as well as market selection and asset positioning.
I'll now hand over to Mary Anne to provide a more detailed review of the second quarter's financial highlights, our increased outlook for the year, and a detailed forecast for Q3.
I will then conclude before moving to the Q&A session.
Second quarter revenue totaled $1.534 billion, exceeding our projection by about $44 million, mainly due to higher-than-expected solid waste growth and recovered commodity values.
Year-over-year revenue increased by $228 million or 17.5% on a reported basis, including acquisitions completed since the previous year, which contributed approximately $47.6 million in revenue for the quarter, or about $44.1 million net of divestitures.
Commodity-driven impacts accounted for roughly 100 basis points of margin expansion, after accounting for a 30 basis point impact from higher fuel costs, with diesel rates up almost 20% year-over-year.
Excluding fuel, solid waste collection, transfer, and disposal margins expanded by 50 basis points, offsetting a 60 basis point increase in incentive compensation costs, 50 basis points from higher medical expenses, and 50 basis points from increased discretionary expenses.
Acquisitions completed since the previous year accounted for about 10 basis points of margin dilution.
Regarding discretionary expenses, we have begun returning to a more normalized operating environment, including in-person training, meetings, and other activities we consider crucial for maintaining our culture and expanding our talent pool for future growth.
Given the challenging labor market, we have proactively implemented supplemental wage adjustments in many areas to anticipate or combat labor constraints.
These intentional wage and discretionary cost additions, along with higher incentives, medical, and other expenses resulting from more typical activity levels, largely replaced last year's COVID-19-related frontline support costs, most of which did not recur this year.
As mentioned earlier, we have already implemented additional price increases to address these higher costs, resulting in a full-year 2021 price increase of approximately 5%, up from 4% in our original outlook.
We achieved adjusted free cash flow of $585 million through Q2, up 18.5% year-over-year, representing 20% of revenue and putting us on track to meet our revised adjusted free cash flow outlook of approximately $1 billion.
I will now discuss our outlook for the third quarter of 2021 and our updated full-year forecast.
Before proceeding, we'd like to remind everyone once again that actual results may vary significantly based on risks and uncertainties outlined in our safe harbor statement and filings with the SEC and similar regulatory authorities in Canada.
We encourage investors to carefully review these factors.
Our outlook assumes no significant changes in underlying economic trends, including those resulting from or related to the COVID-19 pandemic or the delta variant of the coronavirus.
The forecast excludes potential effects from future acquisitions and transaction-related expenses for the rest of the year.
Let's begin with the third quarter.
Q3 revenue is projected to be around $1.56 billion.
We anticipate solid waste price and volume growth of roughly 7% in Q3, with pricing at about 5%.
Recovered commodity values and E&P waste income are expected to remain stable, with RINs similar to Q2 and OCC slightly increasing.
Q3 adjusted EBITDA is estimated at about $495 million, or 31.7% of revenue, showing a 60 basis point increase year-over-year and a sequential rise from Q2.
Third quarter depreciation and amortization expense is projected to be approximately 13.3% of revenue, including intangibles amortization of about $33.8 million or $0.10 per diluted share after taxes.
Net interest expense is estimated at around $40 million.
The projected Q3 effective tax rate is about 21.5%, subject to some fluctuation.
The 2021 revenue forecast has been raised to approximately $5.975 billion, $175 million above our initial projection, mainly due to an additional 150 basis points of solid waste price and volume growth, higher recovered commodity values, and $25 million from acquisitions completed this year.
The full-year adjusted EBITDA is now estimated at about $1.875 billion, or 31.4% of revenue, $75 million above our initial forecast.
The full-year adjusted EBITDA margin guidance is 40 basis points higher than our initial outlook, showing a 90 basis point increase year-over-year.
Our 31.4% adjusted EBITDA margin outlook indicates continued year-over-year margin expansion in the latter half of 2021, despite wage and inflationary pressures and tougher year-over-year comparisons.
The 2021 adjusted free cash flow is now expected to reach about $1 billion, over 53% of EBITDA and $15 million above our initial projection, despite a $50 million increase in capex from our original forecast.
We recently secured a new $2.5 billion credit facility, increasing our borrowing capacity by nearly $300 million, lowering borrowing costs, and providing more flexibility for continued growth.
Our strong financial position and increased capacity set us up for potentially above-average acquisition activity and increased returns to shareholders.
We've already returned over $400 million to shareholders this year through share repurchases and dividends.
We're in the process of renewing our normal course issuer bid, allowing us to repurchase up to 5% of our outstanding shares annually.
We'll continue to approach share repurchases opportunistically and plan to announce another double-digit percentage increase in our cash dividend per share in October.
Our broad-based strength continues to drive results ahead of expectations as we benefit from reopening activities in a supportive economic environment, including tailwinds from recovered commodity values.
We've again demonstrated the importance of being selective about markets and intentional about driving results.
The quality of revenue and comparative price retention across markets are crucial factors.
We're very pleased to be able to raise our full-year outlook.
We're positioned for continued margin expansion through the second half of 2021 as proactive, unbudgeted price increases offset wage and inflationary pressures.
We're on track to achieve adjusted free cash flow of about $1 billion and adjusted EBITDA margins exceeding pre-COVID-19 levels.
We expect to announce another double-digit percentage increase in our regular quarterly cash dividend in October and are well-positioned for a potential significant increase in acquisition spending to drive further growth in 2021 and beyond.
Thank you for your time today.
Summary:
output:
qtrly revenue of $1.534 billion, up 17.5% year over year.
waste connections inc - provides full year 2021 outlook for revenue of approximately $5.975 billion.
q2 revenue rose 17.5 percent to $1.534 billion.
sees fy revenue is estimated to be about $5.975 billion.
compname says for q3 of year, estimate revenue to be about $1.56 bln.
for q3, estimate expect solid waste price plus volume growth to be about 7%, with price growth of about 5%.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Tim Gokey, our CEO, and Edmund Reese, our CFO, are participating in today's call.
The second and third pages of the slides contain a summary of risks, with a more detailed description available in our annual report on Form 10-K.
We'll be discussing several non-GAAP measures that we believe offer investors a more comprehensive understanding of Broadridge's core operating performance.
I'll start by highlighting our key messages and providing an update on our third quarter results, including our progress towards our strategic goals.
Broadridge is in an exciting phase, and we have plenty to discuss, so let's begin.
I'm happy to report that Broadridge had a strong third quarter performance.
Both recurring revenues and adjusted operating income increased by 8%.
Long-term trends such as increasing digitization, mutualization, and the democratization of investing are driving our results in both ICS and GTO.
These trends are leading to robust new business growth, record increases in shareholder numbers, and higher trading volumes.
We're also making good progress on our strategic growth plan across governance, capital markets, and wealth and investment management.
I'll discuss some of these initiatives shortly.
Our strong results and continued execution of our growth plans are giving us confidence to keep investing in our business.
We've maintained funding for attractive investments in our products, platforms, and people, including the upcoming acquisition of Itiviti.
We're significantly raising our guidance for fiscal year 2021 in terms of both revenue and earnings.
We now anticipate recurring revenue growth of 8% to 10% and adjusted earnings per share growth of 11% to 13%.
While the new guidance includes the impact of Itiviti, most of this increase is organic, as Edmund will explain.
The overall outcome of our strong third quarter results, ongoing internal and M&A investment, and outlook for fiscal 2021 is that Broadridge is performing well and is on track to achieve the higher end of our 3-year financial goals, including 8% to 12% adjusted earnings per share growth.
We remain committed to delivering long-term growth driven by secular trends and consistent investment across our governance, wealth, and capital markets businesses, ultimately generating consistent, sustainable top-quartile shareholder returns.
Broadridge's ability to generate these attractive returns stems from executing our clear long-term growth strategy.
Let me update you on some recent progress highlights on Slide five.
Starting with ICS, recurring revenues grew 11% to $586 million, driven by new sales revenue and very strong equity record growth.
New sales revenue was the primary driver of ICS's strong growth, and I'm pleased to see our recent investments impacting our results.
Let me provide two examples of how our focus on product investment and strong execution is directly translating into increased revenue growth.
The first is the Shareholder Rights Directive II. Over the past two years, we've established a shareholder communications hub connecting millions of EU investors with hundreds of wealth managers, acquiring almost 300 new clients in the process. As we enter proxy season, we're beginning to see these efforts generate new revenues, contributing to over 80% growth in our international proxy business.
Virtual shareholder meetings continue to exemplify how product investment leads to new revenues. Over the past year, we've enhanced our VSM capabilities with state-of-the-art video and audio technology, improved Q&A functionality, one-click shareholder authentication, and seamless proxy voting. These upgrades have helped retain existing clients and driven additional growth. We're now on track to serve nearly 1,900 virtual shareholder meetings this proxy season, up from 1,400 last spring.
The second factor driving ICS was exceptionally strong equity record growth, which reached 20% for the quarter.
It's evident that the move to reduce trading commissions has sparked a significant expansion in market participants, contributing to the increase in equity record growth.
This strong growth has been widespread across our broker clients but most pronounced among online brokers.
It has also been broad-based across issuers, with 20% growth in both widely held stocks and those with medium-sized shareholder bases.
We observed large increases in a few names, including so-called meme stocks like GameStop, but these increases only contributed one percentage point to the overall growth.
Commission-free trading is the latest step in a long-term trend that includes the rise of ETFs, lower trading costs across all participants, and changes in investor interfaces. This trend has driven high single-digit equity and fund record growth over the past decade.
Broadridge has invested in scaling its capabilities to meet this rising demand, increase the digitization of critical regulatory communications, and ensure both new and existing investors receive the information needed to understand risks and participate in the governance of their investments.
Looking ahead, we expect strong record growth to continue into the fourth quarter, with our testing indicating 25% stock record growth for Q4.
To conclude the governance section, let me briefly touch on regulatory matters.
I'd like to congratulate Commissioner Gensler on his confirmation as SEC Chairman.
As we have with every chair and administration from both parties over the past 40 years, we look forward to assisting by investing in next-generation technology to help the SEC fulfill its mandate of better informing and protecting investors, while reducing costs for registrants and creating a fair return for our shareholders.
Let's now turn to our capital markets franchise.
Capital markets' recurring revenues decreased by 1% as steady international growth was offset, as expected, by lower license revenues.
We anticipate this period of flat revenue to continue through the fourth quarter before picking up again in fiscal '22 as we onboard our very healthy backlog.
Strategically, our planned acquisition of Itiviti represents a significant enhancement of our ability to deliver value to our clients.
For those who may have missed our call a few weeks ago, let me reiterate why we believe this transaction is such an exciting step forward for our global capital markets franchise.
As a leading provider of order management and trade execution technology and connectivity solutions for financial institutions, Itiviti presents Broadridge with a compelling opportunity to expand our capital market service offering.
Combining Itiviti's front-office trading solutions with Broadridge's leading post-trade back-office capabilities will allow us to serve our clients' entire trade lifecycle from order to settlement.
With the increasing prevalence of high-frequency and algorithmic trading, it's becoming more crucial to serve clients across traditional boundaries.
This combination will bring critical data from the back to the front office to improve trading decisions, and it will enable our clients to simplify and enhance their front-to-back technology stack and operating model.
The merger also strengthens our joint capabilities across equities, exchange-traded derivatives, and fixed income, while substantially extending our global reach, creating significant cross-selling opportunities and enhancing our relationships with blue-chip clients.
The acquisition nearly doubles our business in APAC and further expands our presence in Europe.
This expanded footprint and scale positions us to capitalize on growing mutualization trends in both EMEA and Asia.
Itiviti adds over $6 billion to Broadridge's total addressable market and will drive stronger growth, margins, and earnings, as Edmund will discuss in his remarks.
Initial feedback from our clients has been overwhelmingly positive, reinforcing our confidence in our front-to-back thesis and our near-term to medium growth outlook.
Another noteworthy development in our capital markets franchise is the continued progress of our LTX fixed income trading platform.
LTX recently completed the first-ever multi-buyer digital block trade.
Enabling a single seller to simultaneously access the aggregated liquidity from multiple buyers is a milestone for the fixed income market, and hopefully one of many steps toward creating a more liquid corporate bond market.
To date, 10 dealers and over 40 asset managers have joined the LTX platform.
Additional 14 institutions are in the process of joining, including a major fixed income manager.
Our wealth and investment management division saw a 7% revenue increase, attributed to new clients and higher stock trading volumes.
Expanding sales of component solutions is a crucial aspect of our growth plan.
We're pleased to see new clients adopting a wide range of our wealth and investment management offerings.
Progress continues on our top-tier wealth management platform, aiding clients in digitally transforming their wealth operations.
We've successfully launched our average daily balance billing solution, marking an industry milestone.
Select advisors are currently testing our phone office workstation, paving the way for extensive platform testing before full implementation.
We're making good progress in our sales and marketing efforts to bring new clients onto this platform.
Clients recognize that utilizing the Broadridge wealth platform for digitization will boost their top and bottom lines by enhancing advisor and client capabilities while streamlining operations.
Developing a strong partner network is another key element of our wealth strategy to integrate cutting-edge capabilities.
We've recently partnered with Fligoo for predictive analytics, Anchor Bank for securities-based lending, and established a wealth management fintech accelerator.
These partnerships are steps towards building a network enabling our clients to swiftly adopt new technologies.
A year ago, when I addressed you at the end of our fiscal third quarter, the economic outlook was uncertain and much of the world was in lockdown.
My focus then was on safeguarding our associates and meeting client needs during unprecedented times.
Now, after a challenging year, significant hurdles remain, especially for our 3,000+ associates in India and their loved ones.
However, the global outlook has improved, with economic growth aligning with increasing vaccination rates.
The pandemic has accelerated trends like digitization, mutualization, and next-generation resiliency.
Reduced costs and barriers to investing are attracting millions of new investors.
These shifts are significantly impacting wealth management, governance, and capital markets.
Financial services leaders are rapidly adopting next-generation technologies as a result.
Broadridge is developing capabilities to help them navigate and succeed in this changing landscape.
We're in a strong position to do so.
We began the fiscal year expecting 2-6% recurring revenue growth and 4-10% adjusted earnings per share growth.
Our initial focus was on cutting expenses to fund crucial growth investments.
Nine months later, we're set to achieve 8-10% recurring revenue growth, driven by strong sales and healthy financial markets.
Having met our expense targets, we're now heavily investing in new product capabilities, enhancing our global post-trade platform, and developing next-generation solutions across various areas.
We're also expanding our talent pool and investing in our people to make Broadridge the top workplace for industry talent.
We're close to finalizing our $2.5 billion acquisition of Itiviti, expanding our capital markets presence and strengthening our global footprint.
Despite these investments and short-term dilution from Itiviti, we're on track to deliver 11-13% adjusted earnings per share growth.
Broadridge is proactively pursuing opportunities we see ahead.
It's been an exceptional year.
Looking forward, we're on course to achieve the upper end of our 3-year growth objectives, driving strong recurring revenue and double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth.
We anticipate long-term trends will continue to drive demand for our services.
Our investments are creating new growth opportunities beyond our current 2-year objectives.
Broadridge's future is brighter than ever.
Our team has risen to the challenges of the past 12 months and delivered.
They've remained client-focused, helping to improve financial lives for millions.
Broadridge delivered another strong quarter, as shown in the Q3 financial summary on Slide seven.
Recurring revenue grew 8% to $900 million.
Adjusted operating income also increased by 8% to $284 million.
Margins decreased by 60 basis points to 20.4% as we invested in our technology platforms, products, and people as discussed last quarter.
A higher tax rate in Q3 '21 partially offset our operating income growth.
Adjusted earnings per share grew to $1.76, up 5% from Q3 '20.
Let's examine the quarter's details, starting with recurring revenue growth.
Recurring revenue grew 8%, driven by 7% organic growth, within our typical mid- to high single-digit growth range.
We're raising our full-year recurring revenue growth guidance to 8-10%, up from our previous projection of growth at the higher end of 3-6%.
Looking at recurring revenue growth by business on Slide nine, our ICS segment grew 11% to $586 million.
Regulatory revenues increased 20% to $290 million, driven by 20% equity record growth, higher mutual fund and ETF communications volumes, and new sales.
We expect strong regulatory revenue growth to continue in Q4, with current testing indicating 25% equity record growth.
Issuer revenue growth is expected to slow as we begin to lap the increased VSM activity that started in Q4 '20.
Fund solutions revenue was flat, with data and analytics growth offset by lower interest income from custodied accounts.
Customer communications revenues were also flat, with digital product growth offset by lower print volumes.
We anticipate growth in data-driven solutions and customer communications to improve in Q4 as these headwinds ease.
Wealth and investment management revenues grew 7%, driven by new component sales and higher retail trading.
Capital markets revenues decreased 1% as international sales growth was offset by lower license revenues.
We expect flat revenue growth to continue in Q4 '21 before improving in fiscal year '22.
Page 10 shows more detail on volume trends.
Broadridge's recurring revenue growth benefits from underlying volume growth, including stock record growth.
Over the past decade, record growth across equity, mutual funds, and ETFs has grown 6-8%.
Recently, equity record growth has accelerated, reaching 20% in Q3 '21, surpassing our January estimates.
We expect this growth trend to continue, reaching 25% in Q4 '21.
The expansion of mutual fund and ETF records accelerated to 7%, aligning more closely with our historical growth trends.
We anticipate a return to more moderate mid-single-digit growth across both equity and mutual fund/ETF records for fiscal year 2022, with stronger growth in the first half and more modest growth in the second half.
Briefly addressing trade volumes, which are shown at the bottom of this slide.
This marks the fifth consecutive quarter of overall double-digit volume increase.
This increase reflects the heightened volatility and retail investor engagement over the past year, which remained robust well into the third quarter.
More recently, trading volatility decreased during the latter half of March, and we anticipate more challenging trading volume comparisons in Q4.
Let's examine Slide 11 for a detailed look at the factors driving our recurring revenue.
Organic growth, at a robust 7%, continues to be the primary component of our recurring revenue growth, with new sales being the main driver, showing strong growth contributions from both ICS and GTO.
We have maintained our long-standing record of revenue retention above 97%.
Internal growth contributed an additional three points as growth in ICS regulatory volumes outweighed the decline in GTO license revenue.
We have now fully incorporated all of our fiscal year 2020 acquisitions.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect Itiviti to contribute three points to recurring revenue growth.
Overall revenue growth this quarter was exceptionally strong at 11%, with distribution revenue contributing three points due to increased mailings corresponding with high record growth and increased event-driven activity.
Going forward, we anticipate the low to no-margin distribution revenue to decline over time as we focus on increasing higher-margin digital revenue across our governance business.
Event-driven communications remain a crucial part of our client offering.
Event-driven revenues have increased over the past four quarters to align more closely with our historical average of about $50 million per quarter, reaching $74 million in the third quarter, significantly higher than last year's unusually low $39 million.
Broadridge benefited from an increase in mutual fund proxy activity as well as a rebound in proxy contest volumes and capital markets transactions.
We expect fiscal 2021 event-driven revenue to be more in line with the average we've seen over the past seven years.
For modeling purposes, we're assuming $50 million to $60 million of event-driven revenues in the fourth quarter.
Moving to Slide 13.
Adjusted operating income grew by 8%.
Our adjusted operating income margin decreased by 60 basis points, reflecting ongoing investments in our technology platforms and product capabilities as highlighted in our previous quarterly call.
These investments, which support our long-term growth, have a short-term impact on margin expansion, but we remain on track to deliver approximately 50 basis points of margin expansion for the full year, aligning with our fiscal year 2021 guidance and 3-year growth objectives.
This approach of foregoing near-term margin expansion and consistently investing in our technology platforms and products to drive long-term sustainable recurring revenue growth will continue to be a key aspect of our business management strategy.
As a Chief Financial Officer focused on long-term growth, it's encouraging to see these types of investments across all our product lines, building momentum for future growth.
Our $124 million in closed sales year-to-date are comparable to our performance over the same period last year.
We continue to see strong demand for our ICS solutions, including regulatory and issuer communications and data solutions.
We remain on track to achieve our full year guidance of $190 million to $235 million for closed sales, which implies a fourth quarter range of $66 million to $111 million.
Historically, closed sales performance in the last quarter of the year has been influenced by the timing of larger deals.
A few larger signings could propel us to the top end of our guidance range, while delays could put us at the lower end.
We continue to feel positive about our recurring revenue backlog, which was 12% of our fiscal 2020 recurring revenues as of Q4 2020, providing excellent visibility into our top-line growth.
Turning to capital allocation on the next slide.
We generated $136 million of free cash flow year-to-date, an increase of $54 million over the first nine months of fiscal year 2020, driven by higher earnings and strong working capital management.
During the first nine months of the fiscal year, we invested $205 million in developing our industry platforms and an additional $71 million in capex and software spending.
Our M&A investment through the first nine months of the year was zero, but that will change with our announced $2.5 billion acquisition of Itiviti, which I'll discuss shortly.
Even after completing the Itiviti acquisition, Broadridge will maintain a balanced capital allocation policy, prioritizing internal investment, growing our dividend, M&A, and returning excess capital to shareholders.
Importantly, we are committed to maintaining an investment-grade credit rating, which means we'll prioritize debt reduction over share repurchases and expect to limit ourselves to smaller tuck-in M&A opportunities over the next several quarters.
Given our strong free cash flow, we believe we can comfortably achieve our new 2.5 times leverage target by the end of fiscal year 2023.
Regarding capital returns on the right side of the slide, our dividend has grown and remains in line with our historical 45% payout ratio.
On Slide 16, we are on track to close the Itiviti acquisition in the coming weeks.
Let me provide some additional clarity about the expected impact Itiviti will have on our financial performance.
Starting with fiscal year 2021, we expect Itiviti to add $25 billion to $30 billion or one point to our full-year recurring revenue growth, which equates to three points to our fourth quarter growth.
The acquisition is expected to be slightly dilutive to our adjusted earnings per share growth.
In fiscal year 2022, we expect Itiviti to add approximately $250 million or about eight points to our recurring revenue growth.
We anticipate the acquisition to be accretive by approximately two to three points or roughly $0.10 to $0.15 to adjusted earnings per share growth.
Please note that Itiviti's results in both fiscal year 2021 and fiscal year 2022 will be negatively impacted by the accounting treatment of acquired revenue, which will reduce revenue recognition by approximately $30 million in total, with two-thirds of that impact in fiscal 2022.
This revenue adjustment is incorporated in the figures I just shared.
Finally, I want to reiterate the commentary I provided when we announced the deal, regarding the impact on our 3-year growth objectives.
We expect Itiviti to add 2.5 to three points to our 3-year recurring revenue growth CAGR and, after interest, more than two points to our 3-year adjusted earnings per share CAGR.
Turning to guidance on Slide 17.
We are raising our outlook for fiscal 2021 recurring revenue growth to 8% to 10% from the higher end of 3% to 6%, including one point of growth from Itiviti.
We are raising our guidance for total revenue growth to 8% to 10% from the higher end of 1% to 4%.
We continue to expect our adjusted operating income margin to expand to approximately 18%, up from 17.5% in fiscal year 2020, as we balance near-term returns with continued investments to sustain long-term growth.
We expect adjusted earnings per share growth of 11% to 13%, up from the higher end of 6% to 10%, including a 1-point drag from Itiviti.
Lastly, as mentioned earlier, we continue to expect closed sales in the range of $190 million to $235 million.
The Broadridge Financial model is proving effective.
We are on track to deliver strong 8% to 10% recurring revenue growth.
This growth is enabling us to both invest and expand margins.
Simultaneously, our robust free cash flow business model allows us to pursue balanced capital allocation, commit to a rising dividend, fund investments in our platform and products, and make a significant M&A investment to grow our capital markets franchise.
The result is that we're on track to deliver at the higher end of our 3-year financial objectives of 7% to 9% recurring revenue growth and 8% to 12% adjusted earnings per share growth.
This exemplifies how we manage our business to drive sustainable revenue growth, steady and consistent adjusted earnings per share growth, and historically top-quartile TSR.
Summary:

q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.76.
sees 2021 total revenue growth of 8% - 10%.
sees 2021 non-gaap adjusted earnings per share growth 11% - 13%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm delighted to announce that we began the year on a high note, delivering another robust quarter.
Both divisions had a promising beginning.
As an organization, we generated $222 million in revenue and exceptional bottom-line results, with GAAP earnings of $0.85 per share or $0.87 per share on an adjusted basis.
Our first-quarter cash flow generation was particularly impressive.
We continue to reduce our debt and maintain a strong balance sheet, allowing us to invest in future expansion.
I'm especially impressed by our employees' continued performance throughout the pandemic.
While adhering to our COVID-19 protocols and safety measures, our operational teams are implementing process improvements using Lean Kaizen.
Our research and development teams are working on next-generation materials and products, and we continue to provide excellent delivery, quality, and service to our customers.
Our Machine Clothing segment had its best quarterly top-line performance since 2015, with revenues increasing by nearly $12 million year-over-year and strong order activity in Q1, which is promising for this year.
In fact, apart from the secular decline in publication grades, Machine Clothing end-market demand in packaging, tissue, pulp, and engineered fabrics was all positive in Q1.
In addition to a solid backlog, our engineering teams are diligently developing new technology belts for our customers, which is crucial to our success and value proposition.
We have encountered some instances of isolated supply constraints affecting raw material pricing and delivery timing in this segment, and we continue to actively manage our supply chain, securing the materials necessary to meet our customers' demands.
In conclusion, our Machine Clothing segment continues to perform admirably.
We serve customers worldwide as the recognized global leader in supplying these critical consumable components to the paper industry.
This accomplishment is the result of disciplined execution of our long-term strategy.
In Aerospace, as we reported last quarter, our Engineered Composites segment will be working through a year of destocking excess inventory in the channels for LEAP, Boeing 787, and F-35 products.
Nevertheless, Engineered Composites is on track with their plan and prepared for the upturn as commercial air transport improves, inventory in the channels is consumed, and our production aligns with aircraft OEM production.
We're involved with promising platforms that we anticipate will recover, and we continue to view this as an opportunity to further enhance our operations.
We're prepared and eagerly anticipating the upturn.
We're collaborating closely with Safran to coordinate our operations as LEAP engine production ramps up, supporting the Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX.
With domestic air travel recovering first and driving demand for narrow-body aircraft, the A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX are ideally positioned for the air transport recovery.
In Engineered Composites, looking beyond our current portfolio of programs, our opportunity pipeline is more robust than ever.
We're developing a wide range of capabilities to become the next-generation supplier of advanced composite materials.
This spans from our proprietary 3D woven composites currently used on LEAP engine fan blades and hand cases to automated fiber placement composite wing skins for Lockheed Martin's F-35 Joint Strike Fighter to complex components on the Sikorsky CH-53K helicopter.
We continue to develop applications for the Wing of Tomorrow program with Airbus Industries, and we're increasing our investment this year in R&D projects with new customers and new platforms using advanced materials such as our 3D woven composites for a variety of exciting applications, including unmanned hypersonic and electric aircraft.
The combination of these efforts advances our goal to diversify and expand our customer base and enhance our material science capabilities.
As I mentioned, we have a robust balance sheet and strong free cash flow generation.
These allow us to maintain our investment in technology and customer programs that expand and strengthen our competitive position in both segments.
Our primary focus for capital allocation is to invest in organic growth programs across both business segments and then to pursue acquisitions that align with our long-term strategy.
Our reputation for reliability, service, and technical excellence is well-established in the Machine Clothing segment, and our brand is growing in aerospace as a dependable supplier and engineered materials partner, and we're optimistic about the long-term prospects in both segments.
I will begin by discussing the quarterly results and then comment on the business outlook for the remainder of the year.
The company's total net sales for the first quarter decreased by 5.7% to $222.4 million compared to $235.8 million in the same period last year.
When accounting for currency translation effects, net sales saw an 8.2% year-over-year decline in the quarter.
In the Machine Clothing segment, after adjusting for currency translation effects, net sales increased by 4.9% year-over-year, achieving the highest first-quarter revenue for the segment since 2015, as previously mentioned by Bill.
Growth was observed in all major product categories except for publication grades.
Publication-related revenue decreased by 10% in the quarter, comprising only 16% of Machine Clothing's revenue for this period.
Revenue in packaging and tissue grades, when adjusted for currency, showed high single-digit growth in the quarter, driven by strong orders received in the previous quarter.
Engineered Composites net sales, after currency adjustments, decreased by $26.2 million, mainly due to significant reductions in LEAP and Boeing 787 program revenue, partially offset by growth in F-35 and CH-53K platforms.
The ASC LEAP program generated slightly under $27 million in revenue during the quarter, a small increase from the approximately $24 million in Q4 2020, but significantly lower than the roughly $39 million in Q1 of the previous year.
The company's first-quarter gross profit decreased by 1% to $88.5 million compared to the same period last year.
Overall gross margin increased by 190 basis points from 37.9% to 39.8% of net sales.
In the Machine Clothing segment, gross margin decreased from 53.2% to 51.5% of net sales, mainly due to higher fixed costs and lower absorption.
The Engineered Composites segment's gross margin declined from 17% to 16.4% of net sales, primarily due to changes in estimated profitability of long-term contracts.
In the first quarter of the previous year, the company recognized a net favorable change in estimated profitability of long-term contracts of nearly $1 million.
This year, the net change in estimated profitability of long-term contracts for the first quarter was negligible.
First-quarter selling, technical, general, and research expenses decreased from $49.2 million to $46.7 million compared to the same period last year, remaining relatively stable as a percentage of net sales at about 21%.
The reduction in expenses was attributed to the absence of severance costs from the previous year, lower additional accounts receivable reserves, and reduced travel expenses, partially offset by lower foreign exchange gains.
As anticipated and in line with full-year plans, R&D expenditures increased in both segments this quarter.
The company's total operating income rose to $41.8 million from $39.6 million in the same quarter of the previous year.
Machine Clothing operating income increased by $3.2 million due to higher gross profit, partially offset by higher STG&R expenses, while Engineered Composites operating income decreased by $4.7 million due to lower gross profit.
Other income and expense in the quarter resulted in a net expense of $600,000, compared to an expense of $15.6 million in the same period last year.
The previous year's results included a significant charge related to a foreign currency revaluation loss.
The income tax rate for this quarter was 26.7%, compared to an unusually high 62.1% rate recorded last year.
The primary reason for the lower tax rate was the non-deductibility of the previous year's foreign currency revaluation loss.
Additionally, favorable income tax adjustments reduced income tax expense by $1.3 million this quarter, compared to an increase of $5.1 million from similar adjustments in the same quarter last year.
The company's net income for the quarter increased by $18.5 million to $27.6 million, up from $9.1 million last year.
The increase was mainly due to the absence of the previous year's foreign currency revaluation loss and higher operating income.
Earnings per share rose to $0.85 this quarter from $0.28 last year.
After adjusting for foreign currency revaluation gains and losses, restructuring expenses, CirComp acquisition and integration costs, and severance expenses in the prior year period, adjusted earnings per share increased to $0.87 this quarter from $0.78 last year.
Adjusted EBITDA grew by 2.6% to $60.7 million for the most recent quarter compared to the same period last year.
Machine Clothing adjusted EBITDA increased to $54.9 million or 37.1% of net sales, up from $49.2 million or 36% of net sales in the prior year quarter.
Engineered Composites adjusted EBITDA decreased to $16.7 million or 22.6% of net sales, down from $22.1 million or 22.3% of net sales in the previous year.
Let's examine our debt situation.
Our overall debt, comprising long-term debt and its current maturities on our balance sheet, decreased from $398 million at the conclusion of Q4 2020 to $384 million by the end of Q1 2021.
Cash reduced by slightly more than $3 million in the quarter, leading to a net debt reduction exceeding $10 million.
The first quarter typically sees our lowest cash flow generation due to seasonal working capital fluctuations and quarterly incentive compensation payouts.
This year, we exceeded our usual expectations, generating $21.1 million in free cash flow (defined as operational cash flow minus capital expenditures), compared to a $19 million deficit in the same period last year, primarily due to AEC working capital improvements.
We were satisfied with the AEC segment's cash flow performance this quarter, which shifted from a significant deficit to substantial cash generation compared to the same period last year.
Q1 capital expenditures in both years were around $13 million.
Our current absolute net leverage ratio is 0.65, providing us with a robust balance sheet that allows us to pursue organic and acquisition-based growth opportunities.
Looking ahead to the remainder of 2021, the Machine Clothing segment's outlook remains positive.
MC orders decreased by 2% compared to the same quarter last year.
However, it's worth noting that near the end of Q1 2020, orders surged from customers concerned about supply availability due to the emerging pandemic.
Additionally, our backlog position entering Q1 2021 was stronger than in 2020.
Overall, we're confident about our previously stated revenue guidance for the segment, ranging between $570 million and $590 million.
The Machine Clothing segment delivered another strong quarter in terms of profitability, with adjusted EBITDA margins exceeding 37%.
It's important to note that some of the anticipated challenges for this year, particularly the return to normal travel levels and the absence of foreign exchange benefits we experienced mid-last year, have not yet affected our comparative results.
Nevertheless, we're pleased with our quarterly performance.
While maintaining our adjusted EBITDA guidance of $195 million to $205 million for the segment, we're currently trending towards the higher end of that range.
Shifting focus to Engineered Composites.
We're observing the anticipated impact of 787 frames channel destocking in our top-line results.
This quarter, we generated less than $1 million in revenue from the 787 frames program, compared to over $12 million in the same quarter last year.
As mentioned earlier, the ASC LEAP program also declined by about $12 million during the quarter.
These two programs account for nearly all of the year-over-year decrease in AEC revenue we experienced this quarter.
Due to these declines, the proportion of AEC revenue from defense programs increased to over 48% during the quarter.
However, we'll still see the previously disclosed revenue impact from F-35 channel destocking in the second and third quarters.
Consequently, I expect the defense program share of AEC revenues to decrease somewhat over the next couple of quarters.
This will also make the second and third quarters particularly challenging for the segment overall.
The year is unfolding as expected for the segment, and we're maintaining our guidance range of $275 million to $295 million for segment revenues.
In terms of profitability, our performance to date largely aligns with our expectations, and we're maintaining our AEC adjusted EBITDA guidance of $55 million to $65 million.
We're also maintaining all of our previously issued guidance ranges for company-level performance, except for GAAP earnings per share guidance, which has been updated to reflect non-GAAP adjustments recorded in Q1.
Current guidance is as follows: revenue between $850 million and $890 million; effective income tax rate of 28% to 30%; depreciation and amortization between $70 million and $75 million; capital expenditures ranging from $50 million to $60 million; GAAP earnings per share between $2.38 and $2.78, slightly down from prior guidance of $2.40 to $2.80; adjusted earnings per share between $2.40 and $2.80; and adjusted EBITDA between $195 million and $220 million.
Overall, we're very satisfied with how the year is progressing and hope to see continued movement towards normalcy in the remaining months.
Greg, I'll hand it over to you.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In this instance, core refers to specific financial metrics that don't include the effects of the recent S::can and ATI acquisitions.
We consider this benchmark crucial for comparing year-over-year performance.
To sum up, I'm satisfied with our quarterly performance, showing growth in sales and earnings per share, improved margins, and strong cash flow.
The most encouraging aspect was the record-breaking orders for our intelligent water solutions across both business segments, as customers embrace the underlying growth drivers of our digital offerings.
The widely reported and pervasive shortages in electronic components restricted our ability to convert these record orders into sales during the quarter.
This limited core sales growth but resulted in a record-high order backlog at the start of the second quarter, which is promising for the rest of the year.
Our newly acquired businesses achieved strong top-line results, with expected lower net profitability due to purchase accounting factors.
Overall, the integration of our acquisitions is progressing as anticipated.
I'll discuss the current market conditions and our outlook later in the call.
As shown on Slide 4, total sales for the first quarter reached $117.8 million, up 9% from $108.5 million in the same period last year.
In the utility water segment, overall sales grew by 12%, reflecting the addition of the s::can and ATi acquisitions, which contributed about $10 million in sales for the quarter.
Excluding acquisitions, core revenues in the utility water product line remained relatively unchanged year-over-year despite record orders, due to Internet and electronic component shortages and logistical challenges that constrained manufacturing output.
The scarcity of electronic components is a widespread market issue affecting numerous industries and is not unique to Badger Meter.
We saw growth in overall meter sales and BEACON software as a service revenue, and we benefited from strategic value-based pricing initiatives.
As Ken mentioned, we concluded the quarter with strong order momentum and a record backlog, giving us confidence in our future sales outlook.
As anticipated, the flow instrumentation sales rate of change improved sequentially from a 10% decline last quarter to a 3% year-over-year decrease, with most served end markets experiencing recovering demand trends.
We expect to return to overall growth moving forward due to improving demand conditions and easier comparisons.
We are pleased with the improvement in operating profit, achieving a 30 basis point increase in margins to 15.1% from 14.8% in the previous year.
The quarter's gross margin was 41.9%, a substantial 200 basis point increase year-over-year.
The core business delivered higher gross margins due to a favorable sales mix, particularly higher SaaS revenues, along with advantageous pricing, which continued to offset the impact of increased brass costs in the quarter.
Margins also benefited from a favorable acquisition mix.
From our previous discussion last quarter, we mentioned that the s::can and ATi water quality acquisitions had higher gross margins than average, along with higher SEA as a percentage of sales, resulting in a mid-teens net EBITDA range for the combined businesses.
The positive impact on gross margins from the acquisitions was lessened by the amortization of inventory fair value step-up in the quarter, but this issue is mostly resolved going forward.
Since our last earnings call in late January, copper prices have continued to rise from an average of $3.60 per pound to nearly $4.20 per pound.
This increase potentially raises the estimated cost headwind for the year from $4-5 million to $7-8 million year-over-year if prices remain around $4.20 per pound.
Our first quarter results demonstrate our successful implementation of appropriate pricing strategies to counter inflation, and we will continue to be flexible and proactive in addressing inflationary pressures.
SEA expenses for the first quarter totaled $31.6 million, an increase of $4.3 million compared to the previous year.
This increase includes a full quarter of SEA spending for both s:can and ATi, as well as higher amortization of acquired intangible assets.
Excluding the impact of acquisitions, the increase in personnel costs was more than offset by reductions in travel, trade show, and other pandemic-affected expenses, which we will begin to anniversary starting next quarter.
The income tax provision for the first quarter of 2021 was 22.2%, slightly lower than the previous year's rate of 25.6%.
Overall, earnings per share for the first quarter of 2021 were $0.47, representing a 15% increase from the prior year's earnings per share of $0.41.
Working capital as a percentage of sales decreased to 24.3% from 25.5% at the end of the calendar year, despite the addition of ATi, primarily due to working capital initiatives implemented during the quarter.
Our free cash flow of $28.8 million remained consistent with the previous year.
We allocated $44 million, net of acquired cash, for ATi in early January and currently have approximately $51 million in cash on our balance sheet.
Combined with our untapped revolver, we have significant financial flexibility to execute our growth strategies.
Regarding Slide 5, while we don't provide guidance, we believe it's important to highlight the increased unevenness we expect to see in our top line as the year progresses.
I'd like to briefly discuss comparative sales data to provide a clear picture of the various factors influencing quarterly sales growth trends and share our optimism for our results for the remainder of the year and beyond.
This chart shows the quarterly sales growth rate of our core business in 2020 and the first quarter of 2021.
As indicated by the various call-out boxes, we experienced specific dynamics in 2020 due to COVID and now in the first quarter of 2021 that we need to consider when looking at the rest of the year's comparisons.
Specifically, we anticipate an easier comparison for our upcoming Q2 versus the 2020 COVID lockdowns, combined with a portion of the record backlog converting to sales given the expectation of modest improvement in electronic supply.
As we enter Q3, we'll face a challenging comparison based on the post-COVID lockdown order rate and manufacturing recovery from last year.
We maintain strong momentum and robust bid activity, order rates, and backlog, aligning with our long-term projection for mid-single-digit growth.
Acquisitions are performing as expected, matching their historical growth patterns, and our teams are implementing processes to achieve future growth synergies.
Let's discuss our future outlook.
The fundamental market drivers for smart water solutions remain strong, with COVID highlighting the advantages of AMi for addressing common utility challenges like remote work efficiency and automated consumer engagement.
Increasing concerns about water quality and security are driving greater interest in our real-time digital solutions.
Recent climate events in Texas and other Southern U.S. states demonstrated the benefits of our cellular AMi solution, which remained operational due to the critical nature of cellular networks, allowing utilities to obtain real-time data crucial for identifying potential issues and maintaining safe water supply.
Investors frequently inquire about the potential impact of the Biden administration's infrastructure proposal, particularly the $56 billion allocated for upgrading water systems and an additional $10 billion for rural small water systems.
The underlying trends driving demand for our digital water solutions are already evident and growing, with potential stimulus investments possibly accelerating these drivers but not necessary for achieving our long-term growth plans.
As we've mentioned recently, the widespread availability of vaccinations is most relevant to near-term demand patterns.
It's uncertain whether utilities might pause spending to consider the implications of stimulus proposals, but if such a pause occurs, it would likely be temporary and not affect our long-term structural growth.
We will continue to focus on the aspects of our business within our control.
Our teams have effectively managed value-based pricing initiatives to mitigate increased brass costs, while our sourcing and supply chain teams are actively addressing the challenges of electronics shortages and logistics bottlenecks.
Although these challenges are not unique to Badger Meter, we are confident in our ability to support customers despite these obstacles.
We will maintain our focus on managing working capital and generating cash flow to support investments in both organic and acquisition-driven growth.
Our primary goal remains enhancing our product and software offerings for water-related markets and applications globally.
We have established our first greenhouse gas intensity reduction target as part of our ongoing ESG efforts.
This 15% intensity reduction goal by 2030 was developed through a strategic initiative to capture baseline greenhouse gas data globally and identify opportunities to reduce energy consumption and other emissions.
We will set annual goals to monitor progress and report on our efforts in our biennial sustainability report.
Summary:

q1 earnings per share $0.47.
q1 sales rose 9 percent to $117.8 million.
