input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We value your participation today.
This is our internal method for evaluating and overseeing these divisions, and it will now be our external reporting approach as well.
The total revenue from intersegment transactions between divisions and Protiviti is also individually reported.
We are delighted that the results from the third quarter and early October show steady weekly and monthly progressive improvements across our divisions.
Protiviti achieved another remarkable quarter, marking its 12th successive quarter of year-over-year revenue growth, capitalizing on a robust pipeline of varied service offerings, with particularly strong growth in combined solutions with our staffing operations.
We are also content with the quarter-to-quarter growth in our staffing divisions, particularly in our permanent placement and OfficeTeam sectors.
This year continues to be unlike any other.
I'm incredibly impressed by the ingenuity and dedication shown by all our employees as we continue to provide high-quality service to our clients and candidates.
Overall company revenues for the third quarter of 2020 were $1.19 billion, representing a 23% decrease from the same quarter last year on a reported basis and a 24% decrease on an adjusted basis.
The earnings per share for the third quarter were $0.67, compared to $1.01 in the same quarter of the previous year.
Operating activities generated $139 million in cash flow during the quarter, while capital expenditures amounted to $7 million.
In September, we paid a cash dividend of $0.34 per share to our shareholders of record, totaling $38 million in cash disbursement.
We also bought back approximately 450,000 shares during the quarter for $24 million.
We have authorization to repurchase 1 million shares under our Board-approved stock buyback program.
The company's return on invested capital was 25.8% in the third quarter.
Let's begin by discussing revenue.
As Keith mentioned, global revenues for the third quarter totaled $1.190 billion.
This represents a 23% decrease from the same quarter of the previous year on a reported basis and a 24% decrease on an adjusted basis.
Additionally, on an adjusted basis, third quarter staffing revenues declined by 31% compared to the previous year.
U.S. Staffing revenues amounted to $666 million, down 32% from the previous year.
Non-U.S. Staffing revenues were $203 million, showing a 29% decrease year-over-year on an adjusted basis.
We operate 326 staffing locations worldwide, including 88 locations across 17 countries outside the United States.
The third quarter had 64.3 billing days, compared to 64.1 billing days in the same quarter of the previous year.
The current fourth quarter has 61.7 billing days, which is the same as the fourth quarter of last year.
Currency exchange rate fluctuations during the third quarter resulted in a $4 million increase in reported year-over-year staffing revenues.
This boosted our year-over-year reported staffing revenue growth rate by 0.3 percentage points.
Now, let's examine Protiviti's results more closely.
Global revenues for Protiviti in the third quarter were $321 million.
Of this total, $260 million came from U.S. operations, while $61 million was generated from operations outside the United States.
On an adjusted basis, Protiviti's global third quarter revenues increased by 6% compared to the same period last year, with U.S. Protiviti revenues growing by 10%.
Non-U.S. revenues decreased by 8% on an adjusted basis.
Exchange rates caused Protiviti's year-over-year revenues to increase by $2 million and raised its year-over-year reported growth rate by 0.7 percentage points.
Protiviti and its independently owned member firms provide services to clients through a network of 86 locations across 28 countries.
Employees manage their account balances' investments under these strategies, with the company making cash contributions to an investment trust in line with their directions.
The company's deferred compensation obligation to employees fluctuates in tandem with realized and unrealized investment gains and losses.
Nevertheless, the value of the associated investment trust assets also changes by an equal and opposite amount, resulting in no net expense for the company.
In the future, changes in the company's deferred compensation obligations mentioned earlier will still be included in SG&A or direct cost for Protiviti.
However, the corresponding changes in investment trust assets will be shown separately, below SG&A and outside of operating income.
This adjustment does not alter the previously reported pre-tax or after-tax income or cash flows.
Moving forward, we will substitute the discussion of consolidated operating income with the non-GAAP metric of combined segment income.
This will be determined by adjusting consolidated income before income taxes for interest income and amortization of intangible assets.
Let's now examine gross margin.
The third quarter gross margin in our temporary and consultant staffing operations was 37.5% of relevant revenues, compared to 37.9% in the same quarter of the previous year.
The year-over-year decrease in gross margin percentage is mainly attributed to reduced conversion revenues.
Permanent placement revenues accounted for 10% of consolidated staffing revenues in the third quarter, down from 10.7% in the same quarter of the previous year.
When combined with temporary and consultant gross margin, overall staffing gross margin fell by 80 basis points to 43.8% compared to the third quarter of the previous year.
Protiviti's gross margin in the third quarter was $87 million, or 27.1% of Protiviti revenues.
This includes $3.4 million, or 1.1% of Protiviti revenues, in deferred compensation expense related to increases in the underlying trust investment accounts.
In the same quarter of the previous year, Protiviti's gross margin was $88 million, or 29.4% of Protiviti revenues, including $200,000 of deferred compensation expense related to investment trust activities.
Company-wide SG&A costs represented 32.8% of global revenues in the third quarter, up from 31.2% in the same quarter of the previous year.
Deferred compensation expenses related to increases in underlying trust investments raised SG&A as a percentage of revenue by 1.9% in the current third quarter, compared to 0.1% in the same quarter of the previous year.
Staffing SG&A costs were 40.2% of staffing revenues in the third quarter, up from 34.8% in the third quarter of 2019.
Staffing SG&A costs included deferred compensation expense related to increases in the underlying trust investment assets of 2.6% and 0.1% respectively.
The rise in staffing SG&A as a percentage of revenues is primarily due to continued negative leverage resulting from declining revenues.
Protiviti's third quarter SG&A costs were 13% of Protiviti revenues, down from 16.2% in the same period of the previous year.
The quarter's operating income was $77 million, including $26 million of deferred compensation expense related to increases in the underlying investment trust assets.
Consequently, combined segment income for the third quarter was $103 million.
Combined segment margin was 8.6%.
Our staffing divisions generated third quarter segment income of $54 million, with a segment margin of 6.2%.
Protiviti's segment income for the third quarter was $49 million, with a segment margin of 15.2%.
Our third quarter tax rate was 26%, down from 28% a year ago.
The lower third quarter tax rate is mainly due to annual adjustments made to reconcile our tax accounts with the previous year's tax returns as filed.
Our nine-month year-over-year tax rate of 28% aligns with our full-year expectations.
Regarding accounts receivable, at the end of the third quarter, accounts receivable stood at $690 million, with implied days sales outstanding (DSO) at 52.3 days.
Before we discuss fourth quarter guidance, let's review the monthly revenue trends observed in the third quarter and thus far in October, all adjusted for currency and billing days.
During the third quarter, our temporary and consultant staffing divisions experienced a 29.3% decrease in September revenues compared to the previous year, slightly better than the 30.7% decline for the entire quarter.
The initial two weeks of October saw a 27% reduction in revenues compared to the same timeframe in the previous year.
September's permanent placement revenues declined by 30.1% compared to September 2019.
This is an improvement from the 35.7% decrease observed for the full quarter.
Permanent placement revenues for the first three weeks of October were down 31% compared to the corresponding period in 2019.
We are sharing this information to give you an understanding of the trends we observed during the third quarter and into October.
However, these are very short periods of time.
We advise against drawing extensive conclusions from this data.
With this in mind, we present the following projections for the fourth quarter.
We anticipate revenues between $1.155 billion and $1.255 billion, with earnings per share ranging from $0.55 to $0.75.
The middle point of our forecast suggests a 22% year-over-year revenue decline on an adjusted basis, including Protiviti.
The key financial assumptions for these estimates' midpoint are as follows.
Year-on-year revenue growth: staffing down 27% to 30%, Protiviti up 5% to 7%, overall down 21% to 23%.
Gross margin percentages: Temporary and Consultant Staffing 37% to 38%, Protiviti 27% to 29%, overall 39% to 40%.
SG&A as a percentage of revenues, excluding deferred compensation investment impacts: staffing 36% to 38%, Protiviti 14% to 16%, overall 30% to 32%.
Segment income: Staffing 6% to 8%, Protiviti 12% to 15%, overall 8% to 10%.
We anticipate our tax rate to be between 27% and 29%, with 113 million shares.
Our guidance is restricted to a single quarter.
As demonstrated by the growth in our newly reported inter-segment revenues.
The collaboration between Protiviti and our staffing operations continues to be an expanding source of growth for our company.
We have observed particular strength in our services to government and financial services clients.
Furthermore, we've seen increased demand for services and solutions in cloud technology, cybersecurity, data privacy, and digital transformation as enterprise clients continue to invest strategically in these areas.
The significant cost reductions implemented in the second quarter have positively impacted the third quarter and will continue to benefit future periods.
Remote and hybrid work models will persist long after the pandemic no longer necessitates them.
Talent acquisition is no longer restricted by time zones or geographical locations.
Our global talent network and cutting-edge technology tools enable us to provide ideal matches for clients and candidates, regardless of their location.
While economic uncertainty persists due to the ongoing pandemic, there are reasons for optimism.
As the fourth quarter progresses, we should have clarity on the nature, timing, and amount of any additional fiscal stimulus.
Medical solutions for the COVID-19 virus are getting closer to reality, and the NFIB continues to report improving trends in the small business sector.
A recent study revealed that over half of small businesses are actively hiring or attempting to hire, with the vast majority reporting few or no qualified applicants.
We remain confident in our positioning for future growth, backed by the unique strengths of our brands, people, technology, and professional business model.
We request that you ask only one question and a single follow-up if necessary.
If time permits, we'll return to you for additional questions.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:blackhillscorp.com, in the Investor Relations section.
Linn Evans, President and CEO, and Rich Kinzley, Senior VP and CFO, will be leading our quarterly earnings call.
While we believe our expectations are based on reasonable assumptions, actual outcomes may vary significantly.
I'll start with Slide 4, which outlines our main accomplishments in the first quarter.
Safety is the top concern for Black Hills Corporation, which is closely tied to reliability in our predominantly cold climate service areas.
I'm pleased with our team's outstanding and adaptable performance.
The Black Hills team, along with our electrical and gas systems and our power plants, performed admirably during the unprecedented Winter Storm Uri.
We successfully met extraordinary demand, ensuring our customers' safety during life-threatening cold conditions across our service area.
Our diverse mix of power generation resources, including dependable and flexible generation capacity, allowed us to avoid the rolling blackouts experienced elsewhere in the country, even as our South Dakota electric utility met a new winter peak demand.
Our success in serving customers during Winter Storm Uri wasn't accidental, but rather the result of our constant focus on customer needs and ongoing investments in safe, reliable, and resilient infrastructure.
Winter Storm Uri demonstrated the critical importance of energy in our daily lives.
The storm emphasized the need for safe, reliable natural gas utilities and dependable generation capacity when our customers faced temperatures as low as 27 degrees below zero, breaking numerous all-time low temperature records across our communities.
For instance, Lincoln, Nebraska experienced 11 consecutive days of below-zero temperatures in February, with lows in the negative 20s.
Recognizing the vital importance of natural gas during these weather events, we're pleased that four of our six gas states - Arkansas, Iowa, Kansas, and Wyoming - recently passed legislation protecting our customers' freedom to choose their preferred energy type.
Last week, we announced our membership in the ONE Future Coalition of gas utility companies voluntarily working to reduce emissions.
This is in addition to our previously announced participation in the EPA's Methane Challenge as we strengthen our commitment to modernize and improve the resilience of our pipelines.
Moving on with Slide 4.
We continue to be encouraged by the steady growth in new customer connections driven by population migration into our service areas.
Our team also demonstrated our adaptability and the strength of our financing strategy during the first quarter.
Given the unprecedented and unforeseen market pricing for natural gas in February, we promptly bolstered our liquidity with additional short-term financing by securing an $800 million term loan on favorable terms.
This term loan and other ongoing cash conservation measures ensure our ability to continue funding our robust capital investment program.
Slide 5 presents our financial outlook.
Excluding these storm costs, our financial results were otherwise strong.
During the February storm, we immediately implemented expense and cash management initiatives and are pursuing other opportunities to mitigate the storm's impact.
Rich will provide details in his financial update.
Given these ongoing initiatives and the opportunities we see for the rest of this year, our 2021 earnings guidance remains unchanged.
We also reaffirmed our 2022 earnings guidance and remain confident in our long-term growth targets, including 5% to 7% earnings growth for 2023 through 2025 and at least 5% annual dividend growth.
Slide 6 illustrates our disciplined growth plan with potential for upside.
We plan to invest more than $3 billion in capital through 2025 and expect to identify and develop additional projects.
We're also developing other growth opportunities, including less capital-intensive projects such as data center load additions and innovative customer solutions, including renewables and other technologies.
As mentioned earlier, we're observing accelerated population migration into our service territories and are increasingly confident this trend will continue.
The final item on this slide focuses on cost discipline and continuous improvement.
These are long-term initiatives aimed at creating leaner, more efficient processes and utilizing new technologies to improve daily operations.
Advancing to Slide 7.
We've achieved advancements in our regulatory endeavors.
Our group is completing three rate review applications for submission in Q2.
We intend to submit a fresh rate review for Colorado Gas, and we recently concluded a hearing with the commission about our ongoing safety and integrity investment rider.
In Kansas, we're submitting our first rate review in seven years, which renews our five-year system safety and integrity investment rider.
In Iowa, we plan to submit our first rate review in over ten years, including a request for a new system safety and integrity investment rider.
Besides our regular regulatory activities, we're discussing with regulators about recovering costs related to Storm Uri.
Proceeding to Slide 8.
For our electric utilities, resource planning is a crucial focus as we determine the best way to reliably and cost-effectively meet growing customer demand and reach our greenhouse gas emission targets.
We aim to submit our integrated resource plan for our jointly operated South Dakota and Wyoming electric systems in early July.
We're analyzing various scenarios to meet our increasing customer demand.
Initial modeling, which is subject to change, suggests a need for additional renewable energy, dispatchable natural gas generation, battery storage, more transmission, and upgraded pipeline capacity.
These scenarios consider customer impacts while achieving our greenhouse gas emission goals.
We're also modeling a scenario that takes into account the Biden Administration's economy-wide greenhouse gas emission goals and its cost to customers.
I'm enthusiastic about this process as we seek to provide more clarity on these future opportunities in the coming months.
Lastly, on Slide 9, we're well-positioned as an integrated utility with strong long-term growth prospects.
We're implementing our customer-focused strategy and are confident about our future.
Slide 11 provides a summary of earnings per share for the first quarter.
We achieved earnings per share of $1.54 compared to $1.59 as adjusted in Q1 2020.
The effects of Winter Storm Uri overshadowed what were otherwise robust financial results.
The net storm impacts were $0.15 per share, which more than offset weather favorability and the benefit of new rates.
We estimate that weather improved earnings by $0.07 per share compared to normal.
For the quarter, heating degree days were 4% above normal at our electric utilities and 3% above normal at our gas utilities, mainly due to extreme cold in February, counterbalancing warmer than normal weather in January and March.
Compared to Q1 2020, the weather impact was favorable by $0.11 per share, given a warmer than normal first quarter heating season last year.
Slide 12 outlines our approach to addressing Winter Storm Uri impacts.
In the first quarter, we incurred roughly $571 million in additional costs to serve our customers.
This includes $559 million of deferred utility fuel costs recorded as a regulatory asset.
We've had productive discussions with regulators and have filed or expect to file our remaining storm-related regulatory recovery requests in the second quarter.
We've already submitted requests for our gas utilities in Arkansas, Iowa, Nebraska and Wyoming and for South Dakota Electric.
Recovery plans differ by state, with proposed recovery in some states within one year while other states may take up to five years or longer.
In the first quarter, we recorded storm-related net expenses of $12.55 million pre-tax or $0.15 per share after tax.
The largest contributor was $8.2 million of non-recoverable incremental gas purchase costs at Black Hills Energy Services, which serves 52,000 of our regulated utility customers in Nebraska and Wyoming through the Choice Gas program.
This program allows customers to select their gas provider and is supported by a hedging and procurement plan based on historical demand and forecasts.
Delivering Choice Gas services to our customers is a minor, low-risk, and lucrative segment of our operations.
Nevertheless, it was affected by the exceptional market rates and heightened demand resulting from storm Uri.
In our electricity operations, the $3.2 million impact on our wholesale power margin sharing was partly counterbalanced by $1.7 million in power generation advantages.
We also faced $2.1 million in fuel expenses that fall outside our regulatory cost recovery systems, mainly in Montana, where we provide services to two industrial clients under contractual agreements.
This minor segment of our utilities typically carries very little risk but was exposed to the same extraordinary market pricing and increased demand.
In February, we promptly implemented tactics to counteract the $0.15 per share earnings impact from Uri throughout the rest of the year through expense control, ongoing wholesale power marketing possibilities, and identified regulatory proceedings.
Slide 13 depicts the factors influencing the year-over-year change in net income for the first quarter.
All figures presented are post-tax.
The primary factors compared to the previous year were gross margin improvements in our gas utilities, offset by Storm Uri impacts.
Natural gas margin increases were attributed to favorable weather conditions and new base rates and rider recovery on investments for customers.
Electric utility margins were lower than the prior year, mainly due to tax reform benefits that we passed on to our Colorado Electric customers.
We credited over $9 million of tax reform benefits, which reduced revenue and had a corresponding income tax benefit, resulting in minimal overall impact on first quarter results.
The additional quarter-over-quarter tax benefits shown on the far right were primarily related to additional production tax credits from the Corriedale Wind Project that began operations in late 2020.
O&M was affected by higher employee costs and outside services.
Outside services increased over the prior year due to higher Director fees linked to our stock price performance, which was much stronger in Q1 this year compared to last year.
The change in other income expense over the prior year was influenced by market impacts on non-qualified deferred compensation expense.
Additional first quarter details on segment earnings can be found in the Appendix.
Slide 14 illustrates our financial position in terms of capital structure, credit ratings, and financial flexibility.
We have a manageable debt maturity profile and are devoted to maintaining our solid investment grade credit ratings.
At the end of April, we had approximately $530 million of available liquidity on our revolving credit facility.
In February, we secured an $800 million, nine-month term loan to strengthen our liquidity in response to the increased fuel costs related to Storm Uri.
We repaid $200 million of that term loan at quarter-end and are developing the appropriate refinancing strategy for the remaining $600 million as we finalize Storm Uri recovery mechanisms.
I anticipate we will issue debt with a three to five year term in the second or third quarter to align with the recovery period of the majority of the deferred Storm Uri fuel costs.
New debt and deferred recovery of fuel costs temporarily increased our debt to total capitalization ratio to 62% at the end of March.
As we recover storm costs, repay debt, and implement our equity program, we expect to reduce the debt to total capitalization ratio and continue to aim for a debt to total cap ratio in the mid 50s.
Our equity issuance expectations remain unchanged.
We plan to issue $100 million to $120 million in 2021 and $60 million to $80 million in 2022 through our at-the-market equity offering program.
We will continue to assess financing needs as we finalize our storm cost recovery proposals.
Turning to our dividend on Slide 15.
In 2020, we proudly celebrated 50 consecutive years of annual dividend increases, one of the longest records in our industry.
Since 2016, we have increased our dividend at an average annual rate of 6.6%.
Looking ahead, we anticipate raising our dividend by more than 5% annually through 2025 while maintaining our 50% to 60% payout target.
We are uniquely positioned as an integrated utility in favorable jurisdictions with a complementary business mix across stable and growing territories.
We remain well-positioned both operationally and financially to serve all our stakeholders effectively.
Summary:
output:
qtrly earnings per share $1.54.
reaffirming our 2021 and 2022 earnings guidance and five-year capital plan of more than $3 billion.
remain confident in our strategy and opportunities ahead as we target 5% to 7% earnings growth beyond 2022.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will also examine specific non-GAAP financial metrics and provide comparisons between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures.
Today's participants include our CEO Steve Strah, Vice Chairperson John Somerhalder, and CFO Jon Taylor, along with other executives available for questions later.
Our operating earnings of $0.59 per share exceeded the upper limit of our projected earnings range.
These impressive operational outcomes reflect our customer-focused investment approach in regulated distribution and transmission, strong financial management, and increased weather-adjusted demand from residential customers.
We're satisfied with our performance and the significant advancements we've made in transforming FirstEnergy and positioning our company for the future.
We've implemented crucial measures to establish a top-tier compliance program while identifying and pursuing initiatives to create long-term value for all stakeholders.
Our leadership is dedicated to exemplifying the behavior and humility needed to rebuild trust with our stakeholders.
We're eager to continue this work and achieve milestones that will demonstrate our progress.
I'll begin our call with an update on the DOJ and other investigations related to House Bill 6, followed by John Somerhalder's brief discussion on board activities and our compliance program's progress.
We announced yesterday that we've reached an agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Ohio to resolve the DOJ investigation into FirstEnergy.
This deferred prosecution agreement was submitted to federal court.
Under the three-year deferred prosecution agreement, we've committed to pay $230 million from our available cash.
Half of this amount will go to the U.S. Treasury, while the other half will benefit utility customers through the Ohio Development Service Agency.
None of the payment will be recovered from customers.
We also accepted the government's single charge of honest services wire fraud, which will be dismissed if we comply with all agreement terms.
As per the agreement, we will provide regular updates to the government about our compliance program, internal controls, policies, and ongoing efforts to build on the comprehensive compliance initiatives implemented this year.
The behavior that occurred at our company was inappropriate and unacceptable.
Our Board, management team, and entire organization have worked extensively and are committed to making necessary changes to move forward.
Our progress on these efforts, along with the DPA, shows we're making significant strides in navigating this period and are positioned to move forward as a stronger, integrity-focused organization.
We will maintain full cooperation with ongoing investigations, audits, and related matters as we work to resolve these issues and rebuild trust with our employees, customers, regulators, and investors.
We are deeply focused on cultivating a strong culture of compliance and ethics and ensuring robust processes are in place to prevent similar incidents in the future.
In May, we conducted our first compliance town hall with employees to discuss the importance of compliance, ethics, and integrity at FirstEnergy and the significance of fostering a culture where everyone feels comfortable speaking up about potential issues.
Following the town hall, our management team has addressed employee questions and concerns, and we're committed to continuing this dialogue and engagement.
Next week, we plan to hold another town hall meeting to introduce our updated mission statement, emphasizing the role of uncompromising integrity as the foundation of FirstEnergy's identity and business strategies.
We will also update our core values to better reflect the importance of integrity alongside safety, diversity, equity and inclusion, performance excellence, and stewardship.
These values will be integrated into our practices and processes, becoming an integral part of our work culture.
Additionally, we've revised our code of business conduct, which John Somerhalder will discuss shortly.
We continue to strengthen our leadership team with two new hires: Michael Montaque as Vice President of Internal Audit and Soubhagya Parija as Vice President and Chief Risk Officer, effective August 16.
These experienced professionals represent another crucial step in enhancing our key internal functions, and I'm confident they'll help develop best-in-class audit and enterprise risk programs.
John Somerhalder will now provide an update on board matters and other aspects of our compliance program.
Afterward, I'll return to discuss FE Forward and review some regulatory updates.
Our progress with the DOJ builds upon the significant measures we've taken to enhance our Board, strengthen our leadership team, establish a top-tier compliance program, and substantially modify our approach to political engagement as we work to regain stakeholder trust.
I'll begin by reviewing recent Board changes.
Jesse Lynn and Andrew Teno became Board members from Icahn Capital in March, but await regulatory approval for voting rights.
FERC recently approved our request for voting rights.
We have informed the Maryland Commission about FERC's recent decision, and the process there is ongoing.
At our Annual Meeting in May, Melvin Williams joined the Board, and we recently added two more independent directors, Lisa Winston Hicks and Paul Kaleta.
The Special Litigation Committee consists of Jesse, Melvin, Lisa, and Paul.
This committee has complete and binding power to decide the company's actions regarding the ongoing shareholder derivative litigation.
The Board has disbanded the Independent Review Committee following the formation of the Special Litigation Committee.
The company's internal investigation has shifted from proactive to responsive, and given the extensive review and actions taken by the independent review committee, the Board has also dissolved that committee.
The Board and management's proactive measures over the past year have enhanced our governance and positioned us well to address the material weakness in our tone at the top by the time we release our fourth quarter results.
We've been discussing our efforts to improve our ethics and compliance program and reinforce our values with all employees over the past few quarters.
We continue to make steady progress in this area, with our new, more centralized compliance organization taking shape under Antonio Fernandez, who joined as our Chief Ethics and Compliance Officer in April.
We released our updated internal Code of Business Conduct, "The Power of Integrity," yesterday, which will be supported by ongoing education on behaviors and the importance of reporting ethical violations, and we have continued to strengthen our policies, processes, and internal controls, including those related to 501(c)(4)s, other corporate engagement and advocacy, and business disbursements.
While transforming our culture and rebuilding trust with all stakeholders will be long-term efforts, this team has begun building a stronger company founded on ethics, honesty, and accountability.
The comprehensive evaluation and adjustment of our ethics and compliance program has been running alongside FE Forward.
Our transformational effort to increase value for all stakeholders by investing in modern and distinctive experiences will improve our business practices, and we have integrated our efforts to mature our ethics and compliance program into the FE Forward work.
This approach allows us to use FE Forward's rigor to implement changes quickly and efficiently, embed ethics and compliance into our operational culture, and ensure a sustainable, comprehensive transformation well into the future.
FE Forward has entered its third phase, which involves full-scale execution of our implementation plans.
The program is expected to generate value and resilience, including cumulative free cash flow improvements of about $800 million from 2021 through 2023 and annual run rate capex efficiencies of approximately $300 million in 2024 and beyond.
We also expect the program to build on our strong operations and business fundamentals as we reinvest some of our efficiencies into strategic opportunities to better serve our customers and support a smarter and cleaner electric grid.
To ensure our organizational structure supports these improvements long-term, we reorganized our business units last month around five pillars: Finance and Strategy, Human Resources and Corporate Services, Legal, Operations, and Customer Experience.
This new structure reflects a best-in-class model and promotes operational excellence, clear decision-making, accountability, and reduced complexity.
As part of this new organizational structure, we've established a customer experience function to truly understand our customers' evolving expectations and develop solutions that benefit them.
We've also created a new position, Vice President of Transformation, to guide the FE Forward initiatives across our company while developing customer-focused emerging technology opportunities.
The development of executable plans, a best-in-class compliance program, and crucial organizational changes will position the company to move forward in a positive, sustainable direction.
I'll now briefly review recent regulatory matters, starting with Ohio.
In July, the PUCO approved our filing to return about $27 million to our Ohio utility customers, representing all revenues previously collected through the decoupling mechanism plus interest.
Our Ohio utilities have submitted supplemental testimony in the quadrennial review of our ESP IV.
We are dedicated to collaborating with various parties in Ohio to resolve the outstanding issues.
We held our first comprehensive collaborative meeting on March 31 and have since received additional feedback from participants.
We are preparing for another collaborative meeting in the coming weeks.
We are also proceeding with regulatory audits in Ohio, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and at the FERC.
In April, the New Jersey BPU approved JCP&L's three-year $203 million energy efficiency and conservation plan, which includes a return on certain costs and the ability to recover lost distribution revenues.
Regarding our financial results, we are pleased with our strong performance in the first half of the year.
We are reaffirming our 2021 operating earnings guidance of $2.40 to $2.60 per share and expect to be in the top half of that range.
We are providing guidance for the third quarter, projecting earnings between $0.70 and $0.80 per share.
Our priority remains implementing our strategies, controlling our expenses, and capitalizing on our current success.
We are making significant strides in transforming FirstEnergy to align with our principles and create enduring value for all our stakeholders.
On the previous day, we reported GAAP earnings of $0.11 per share and operating earnings of $0.59 per share for the second quarter of 2021.
As Steve pointed out, this surpassed the upper limit of our projected range.
The second quarter of 2021 included exceptional items such as investigation-related expenses, including the impact of the deferred prosecution agreement, along with regulatory fees and changes in state tax legislation.
Comparing our distribution business results for the second quarter of 2021 to 2020, we saw growth from our investment programs, rate increases, and reduced expenses, mainly due to the absence of pandemic-related costs from last year's second quarter, partially counterbalanced by the discontinuation of Ohio decoupling and lost distribution revenues from the second quarter of 2020, which we ceased collecting earlier this year.
Distribution deliveries increased both in actual terms and when adjusted for weather, compared to the second quarter of 2020 when many pandemic-related restrictions were fully in effect.
However, the changes in customer usage patterns resulted in no significant year-over-year impact on earnings.
Weather-adjusted residential sales in the second quarter of 2021 were 6% lower than the same period last year when many of our customers were under strict lockdown orders.
Nevertheless, when examining trends, weather-adjusted residential usage over recent quarters has averaged about 4% higher than pre-pandemic levels, with the second quarter of this year being nearly 8% higher than the weather-adjusted usage observed in the second quarter of 2019.
We believe that more permanent work-from-home arrangements could influence our long-term load forecast, and we will closely monitor whether this structural shift in our residential customer class persists.
Weather-adjusted deliveries to commercial customers rose by 8% and industrial load increased by 11% compared to the second quarter of 2020.
Despite the increase in commercial activity this spring, weather-adjusted demand in this customer class still lags behind pre-pandemic levels by an average of about 6%.
Regarding the industrial class, we are encouraged by the steady recovery in demand over the past year.
In fact, this quarter's industrial load was only slightly below that of the second quarter of 2019.
We continue to observe higher load from the shale gas industry, but this was offset by lower load in other industrial sectors such as steel, automotive, and mining, which have not fully recovered to pre-pandemic levels.
In our Regulated Transmission segment, the impact of higher transmission investment at MAIT and ATSI related to our Energizing the Future program more than offset the higher net financing costs in the second quarter of 2021, primarily related to our revolving credit facility borrowings.
Our transmission investments led to a year-over-year rate base growth of 7%.
The Corporate segment results reflect the absence of discrete tax benefits recognized in the second quarter of 2020, as well as increased interest expense.
For the first half of 2021, operating earnings were $1.28 per share, compared to $1.23 per share in the first half of 2020.
This increase resulted from continued investments in our transmission and distribution systems, weather-related sales, and lower expenses, and consistent with our second quarter results, the positive drivers for the first half of this year more than offset the absence of $0.13 of decoupling and lost distribution revenues that were recognized in the first half of 2020 but are no longer in place this year.
Additionally, our continued focus on financial discipline combined with strong financial results helped drive a $196 million increase in adjusted cash from operations compared to our internal plan and a $264 million increase above the first six months of last year, building on the improvements we noted in our first quarter earnings call.
Regarding capital markets activity, we continue to make good progress on this year's debt financing plan with five of our six debt transactions complete, all with pricing similar to investment grade companies.
In May, we issued $150 million in senior notes at Toledo Edison and MAIT with pricing at 2.65% and 2.55% respectively.
In June, we issued $500 million in senior notes at JCP&L that priced at 2.75%.
Furthermore, we made progress on our commitment to reduce short-term debt during the second quarter by repaying $950 million under our revolving credit facilities, bringing our borrowings down to $500 million as of June 30.
Earlier this week, we repaid the remaining $500 million under these facilities.
Although we obtained a waiver for our credit facilities related to the DPA, this repayment was voluntary and not required by the bank group.
We plan to operate normally going forward and will utilize the revolving credit facilities as needed, as we have done historically.
As you are aware, we have two revolving credit facilities, one for FE Corp, which is shared with our utility companies, and one for FET, both expiring in December 2022.
In the coming months, we plan to collaborate with our bank group to evaluate and refinance these bank facilities, aiming to complete this initiative before the year's end.
Lastly, we continue to explore alternatives for our equity needs.
We are considering options that include a minority sale of distribution and/or transmission assets, which would generate substantial proceeds and eliminate all of our expected non-SIP equity needs, ensure the execution of our balance sheet improvement plans, and provide funding for strategic capital expenditures in customer-focused emerging technologies that support the transition to a cleaner electric grid.
Based on our current timeline, we anticipate providing you with an update in the fourth quarter.
Summary:
output:
reaffirms fy non-gaap operating earnings per share view $2.40 to $2.60.
q2 gaap earnings per share $0.11.
q2 revenue $2.6 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $2.65 billion.
for q3 of 2021, providing a gaap and operating (non-gaap) forecast range of $380 million to $435 million, or $0.70 to $0.80 per share.
operating (non-gaap) earnings were $0.59 for q2 of 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These convictions are vulnerable to recognized and unrecognized hazards and uncertainties, many of which may be outside our influence, including those outlined in our regular SEC submissions.
It's important to recognize that the company's actual outcomes may significantly deviate from those projected, and we are not obligated to revise these declarations.
Questions from the audience will be welcomed at the conclusion of the presentation.
I'm delighted with our achievements in the initial quarter of fiscal year 2022.
Our staff achieved a 17% increase in sales, enhanced our operating profit margin by 160 basis points, and boosted diluted earnings per share by 57%, despite worldwide supply chain difficulties and volatile market circumstances.
Our results show that by focusing on customers, we're driving revenue growth and converting it into operating income, while simultaneously investing in the company's long-term expansion and transformation.
I'd like to begin today's discussion by thoroughly examining the present market conditions.
As you're aware, this is a fluid market with its fair share of contradictions.
The demand across our target markets continues to be robust.
Simultaneously, the accessibility and expense of crucial resources remain problematic.
In essence, it's the best of times and the most demanding of times.
Business is thriving in both ABL and spaces.
Within ABL, demand is strong across all our market channels, with the exception of retail, which we anticipate will improve this calendar year.
In this fluctuating pricing environment, we've been cautious and successful in passing on price increases, while simultaneously providing as much stability as possible to our customers so they can efficiently plan and execute their projects.
Concurrently, input costs and availability remain unpredictable, and we expect this trend to persist.
Evidently, everyone is grappling with this situation.
Our approach to navigating through this has been consistent: prioritize meeting customer demand and ensuring the health and well-being of our employees.
Now, allow me to elaborate on what we mean by satisfying our customer demand.
Firstly, we've decided to honor pricing on all our placed orders.
As I've mentioned before, it's crucial to me that we're known in the industry for keeping our word.
There's typically a time gap between when we receive orders and when we fulfill them, and that gap is even longer now.
Therefore, we believe this stance will benefit us in the long run with specific customers and within the industry.
Furthermore, we're also doing everything in our power to fulfill these orders as swiftly as possible.
While we don't disclose backlog figures, I can say that it's significantly higher than during normal periods.
This is due to increased demand, coupled with fluctuating component availability and general supply chain and transportation challenges.
Again, these issues aren't unique to Acuity.
To combat these challenges, we've prioritized three key activities.
Firstly, we've concentrated on and invested in our strategic relationships with manufacturers and suppliers to secure as much of the available component supply as possible.
We benefit from being the largest and most consistent player in the industry.
Secondly, we've authorized our teams to source components in the spot market, prioritizing speed and access over cost.
This allows us to maintain higher production levels at the expense of some increased costs.
Thirdly, our product, engineering, and manufacturing teams have been continuously redesigning and reengineering existing products based on available components.
To give you an idea of the scale of this effort, our Distech engineers dedicated over half their time in the last quarter to this type of redesign.
Our ABL team made the same commitment in addition to changes and improvements in our manufacturing processes to ensure consistent production.
These efforts also extend beyond our company into our broader ecosystem.
We've been collaborating with suppliers to help them locate necessary components and make engineering changes in the products they supply to us.
The overall effort has been monumental, and our teams continue to remain adaptable and adjust to an ever-changing environment.
The modifications we've implemented over the past two years have enhanced our ability to oversee our business, work across our stakeholders, and improve our service levels.
So, where do we stand on our transformation?
One point I emphasize to our team is that transformation is an ongoing process, not a final destination.
In challenging times, the initial reaction is sometimes to revert to what's familiar.
We are utilizing this period to intensify our transformation initiatives.
Let's begin with discussing the ABL division.
Trevor and his colleagues are concentrating on sustaining high product innovation, enhancing industry service standards, and leveraging technology to set us apart.
In the initial quarter, we introduced several intriguing products to expand our portfolio, such as the STACK PACK and STACK Switch items.
These products represent the latest generation of central LED recessed lighting for commercial indoor environments.
The STACK features a slimmer design and more efficient packaging, resulting in reduced transportation expenses.
It also offers adjustable brightness that can be modified at any time using the STACK Switch.
This eliminates wasted time on-site if configuration changes are necessary.
In the controls sector, we unveiled the CLAIRITY link.
This component of our nLight lighting control system provides remote connectivity capabilities.
The remote features decrease the need for on-site visits, offering swift troubleshooting solutions and lowered maintenance costs.
This product fundamentally alters our approach to project servicing and marks a significant advancement for our clients.
Shifting focus to the Intelligent Spaces Group.
ISG's objective is to employ technology to address spatial issues, making them more intelligent, secure, and environmentally friendly.
We accomplish this through two methods.
We gather data via hardware, such as the Distech controller, then analyze and act upon this data through Atrius-powered software applications.
Our ISG division had a noteworthy quarter.
As mentioned, despite Distech's engineering team dedicating over half their time to redesigning products for available components.
We continued to launch several significant products and product improvements.
The Distech ECLYPSE APEX was released in the first quarter and represents our most advanced controller for HVAC and building automation.
The APEX incorporates artificial intelligence at the edge and enhances computing capacity in buildings, assisting customers in managing energy consumption more efficiently.
We also expanded the availability of our Atrius Building Insights service by enabling it for additional languages and local privacy requirements.
Atrius Building Insights is now accessible in the United Kingdom, Ireland, France, Germany, Spain, and Norway.
We are currently, and anticipate continuing to, operate in unpredictable circumstances.
Input prices and availability can sometimes resemble a game of whack-a-mole, and we are contending with omicron, which emerged only a few months ago.
As we confront these and new challenges, we will maintain our focus on meeting customer demands and ensuring the health and well-being of our employees.
I remain optimistic about 2022 and our ability to effectively manage in this environment.
We have an excellent team executing current tasks while remaining focused on the company's long-term growth and transformation.
I will return for the Q&A session and some concluding remarks.
I continue to be impressed by our team's commitment to our transformational priorities while navigating the day-to-day business operations.
We achieved strong first quarter results.
Net sales reached $926 million, a 17% increase compared to the previous year.
This performance was driven by improved service levels, ongoing recovery in both business segments' end markets, and the benefits of recent price increases.
Gross profit totaled $386 million, an increase of $53 million or 16% over the previous year.
This improvement resulted from revenue growth and offsetting significant increases in material and freight costs through price increases and product and productivity enhancements.
Gross profit as a percentage of sales was 41.7%, a 30 basis point decrease from 42% in the previous year, a notable achievement given the cost environment.
Reported operating profit margin was 12.4% of net sales for the first quarter of fiscal 2022, a 160 basis point increase over the previous year.
Adjusted operating profit margin was 14.4% of net sales, a 120 basis point increase over the previous year.
This was primarily due to improved operating leverage as we continued to balance cost management and growth investments.
The effective tax rate for the first quarter of fiscal 2022 was 19.6%.
In the same period of 2021, the rate was 24.7%.
The decrease in the effective income tax rate was mainly attributed to favorable discrete items recognized in the first quarter of fiscal 2022 related to excess tax benefits on share-based payments.
We anticipate our tax rate for the entirety of 2022 to return to approximately 23%, excluding these specific items.
We observed a notable increase in diluted earnings per share for the initial quarter of the 2022 fiscal year.
The diluted earnings per share of $2.46 showed a rise of $0.89 or 57% compared to the previous year.
The adjusted diluted earnings per share of $2.85 demonstrated an increase of $0.82 or 40% in comparison to the prior year.
Our share buyback program positively affected adjusted diluted earnings per share by $0.07, while the tax impact was roughly $0.16.
Let's discuss our divisions.
In the quarter, our Lighting and Lighting Control division experienced a 17% increase in sales, reaching $884 million compared to the previous year.
This growth was propelled by improvements in our independent sales network, which grew by 14%, and the direct sales network, which expanded by about 12%.
These gains were a direct consequence of our robust go-to-market strategies, an improved demand landscape, and the positive effect of price hikes.
Our corporate accounts channel witnessed a sales increase of roughly 62% compared to the previous year, as major clients resumed previously delayed maintenance and renovation projects.
The performance in this channel fluctuates quarterly and depends on our customers' renovation schedules.
Sales in the retail channel decreased by approximately 16% in the current quarter.
ABL's operating profit for the first quarter of fiscal 2022 rose by 30% to $128 million compared to the previous year, with the operating margin improving by 160 basis points to 12.4%.
The adjusted operating profit of $138 million showed a 28% improvement compared to the previous year, with the adjusted operating margin increasing by 140 basis points to 15.6%.
Now let's examine the results for our Intelligent Spaces Group.
In the first quarter of 2022, sales in spaces grew by approximately 14% to $46 million compared to the previous year, reflecting sustained demand primarily across our building and HVAC controls.
Spaces' operating profit in the first quarter of 2022 increased by about $2 million to $2 million compared to the previous year.
The adjusted operating profit of $6 million rose by approximately $2 million compared to the previous year due to robust sales growth.
Let's now discuss cash flow.
We continue to generate substantial cash flows.
The net cash from operating activities for the initial three months of fiscal 2022 amounted to $84 million.
This represents a decrease of $40 million or 32% compared to the previous year and reflects an increased investment in inventory to drive growth.
Additionally, cash flow was affected by the timing of income tax payments and the previous year's deferral of withholding taxes resulting from the CARES Act.
We invested $9 million, or 1% of net sales, in capital expenditures during the first three months of fiscal 2022.
During the quarter, we continued to implement our capital allocation strategy and bought back approximately 300,000 shares of common stock for around $53 million at an average price of $176 per share.
We have roughly 3.5 million shares remaining under our current board authorization.
Our capital allocation priorities remain unchanged.
We will continue to prioritize investments for growth in our existing businesses, invest in acquisitions, maintain our dividend, and allocate capital to share repurchases when there's an opportunity to create lasting value for our shareholders.
I'd like to briefly address some current topics of interest.
Firstly, regarding the pricing environment.
As Neil mentioned, we are actively managing prices while maintaining balanced relationships with our customers.
We announced another price increase this week, effective for orders placed in February.
We will continue to be strategic and deliberate in our approach to pricing.
Next, I'd like to provide an update on the OSRAM integration.
We've made significant progress in integrating OSRAM.
We acquired the OSRAM North American DS business to ensure control over the technology, expand our OEM channel, and benefit from its integration into our supply chain.
The addition of OSRAM contributed over 300 basis points to our sales growth this quarter.
There was a relatively small dilutive impact on gross profit margin, but OSRAM overall positively contributed to operating profit.
The acquisition is meeting our expectations, and we're thrilled that the OSRAM team is now part of Acuity.
We've included EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA in our reconciliation tables to facilitate easier comparisons and improve consistency around reported adjustments.
As we progress through 2022, we will continue to prioritize our customers to drive sales growth and operating income.
We will also continue to allocate capital in ways that promote long-term growth and create lasting value for our shareholders.
Summary:
output:
q1 adjusted earnings per share $2.85.
q1 earnings per share $2.46.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:You can find information on pb.com by visiting the Investor Relations section.
We have prepared slides summarizing key points for this call, which are available on our Investor Relations website.
I'm thrilled to welcome Ana as our new Chief Financial Officer.
Ana has held executive roles at GE Capital, most recently serving as President and CEO of Global Legacy Solutions and previously as COO and CFO.
Ana's strong financial and operational background makes her an excellent fit for PB's culture.
The events of 2020 were unprecedented, but I'm proud of how our team prepared for and handled the challenges.
Our business made significant progress throughout the year due to our team's efforts and dedication.
If I had to describe our employees in 2020 with one word, it would be determined.
This quality truly embodies our team's spirit.
We ended an extraordinary year with a remarkable fourth quarter.
Revenue grew by 23% at constant currency.
To our knowledge, this is Pitney Bowes' highest modern-day organic growth rate on record.
Shipping-related revenues accounted for 54% of our total revenue.
Global Ecommerce grew by 60% in the quarter, with improved profitability resulting in positive EBITDA.
Presort's flat revenue performance was a significant improvement from previous quarters and exceeded market trends.
SendTech performed strongly, with growth in both revenue and profit compared to the previous year.
This was driven by strong equipment sales, double-digit growth in SaaS-based shipping offerings, and solid performance in our services business.
SendTech, once considered a declining business, has been revitalized through investments in digital channels, products, and expanded shipping offerings.
These achievements would have been hard to imagine a few years ago, but they demonstrate what a determined and focused team can accomplish.
When the pandemic hit, we had two main objectives: prioritize employee health and well-being while maintaining financial strength, and emerge from the crisis as a stronger company.
Economic disruptions often create opportunities, and our team was determined to capitalize on our recent investments.
We adjusted our work protocols and practices, provided necessary PPE to employees, refinanced our debt, and ensured a solid liquidity position.
Once we confirmed the company's financial stability, we focused on emerging stronger from the pandemic, which we are well on our way to achieving.
Global Ecommerce generated $1.6 billion in revenue for the year, growing at a record rate of over 40%.
The business acquired new customers and achieved scale earlier than anticipated, while accelerating our planned network expansion by several years.
Although not always smooth, the business is in a much better position than it was a year ago.
While e-commerce's growth is noteworthy, SendTech's transformation is equally impressive.
The business performed well relative to the mail market and expanded into shipping, a new growth area that leverages our core strengths.
SendTech's transformation is exemplified by the growth in shipping revenue, which now significantly offsets the decline in mail business.
U.S. shipments of low-end and middle-market devices grew 13% for the year, providing new value to clients compared to previous single-purpose mailing machines.
Our strong cash performance in the fourth quarter and throughout the year is particularly impressive.
Increasing operating cash flow significantly during a pandemic and major economic disruption is a remarkable achievement.
Transformations are inherently messy and nonlinear, especially during a pandemic.
The unprecedented surge in e-commerce demand led to cost inflation, particularly in labor and transportation, which negatively impacted our e-commerce profit in the fourth quarter.
This quarter tested capacity throughout the industry.
To meet demand, we more than doubled our labor force and established three new facilities, which handled over a quarter of our total domestic parcels in 2020.
We faced challenges with third-party transportation costs and service, in line with broader industry trends.
To maintain service levels, we proactively upgraded packages at additional cost.
Moving forward, we aim to balance our use of third-party transportation and our own PB fleet assets, which performed well during peak season.
We will continue investing to improve efficiency across all areas.
As I've mentioned before, we now have the ability to manage our cost structure and generate efficiencies internally.
Transformations typically follow a pattern: initial quick wins, ongoing investments, revenue expansion, and ultimately, profitable growth.
The strongest indicators of successful transformations are increased revenue and higher employee engagement.
We've seen consistent revenue growth in recent years, and our employee engagement reached record levels during the pandemic.
Despite ongoing economic uncertainties and pandemic-related challenges, we're well-positioned to enter the final phase of successful transformations: profitable revenue growth.
I'm impressed by the team's achievements.
We all acknowledge there's still work to be done.
I'm enthusiastic about the next phase of our transformation journey.
We're on the verge of achieving something few companies have managed to accomplish.
I'll begin by summarizing our annual results, then provide details on our fourth quarter performance.
Our full-year revenue reached $3.6 billion, representing an 11% increase from the previous year and marking our fourth consecutive year of revenue growth at constant currency.
The Global Ecommerce division grew by 41%, Presort Services saw a slight decline of less than 2%, and SendTech decreased by 7%.
Adjusted earnings per share were $0.30, while GAAP earnings per share showed a loss of $1.06.
It's worth noting that the GAAP earnings per share includes a non-cash goodwill impairment charge recorded in the first quarter.
GAAP cash from operations totaled $298 million, and free cash flow amounted to $279 million.
Free cash flow increased by $91 million compared to the previous year.
Throughout the year, several significant factors contributed to the improvement in free cash flow.
Our emphasis on collections led to a significant improvement in our Days Sales Outstanding (DSO).
We also observed higher levels of customer deposits in Presort and PB Bank, partly due to initiatives supporting our clients.
Additionally, finance receivables declined more rapidly, particularly in the second quarter, due to reduced placements of SendTech equipment during the pandemic.
This trend began to improve as our SendTech business gained momentum in the latter half of 2020 when businesses started reopening.
When the pandemic first emerged, we made a prudent decision to reassess our investment priorities and reduce spending, given the market uncertainty at that time.
While there were various fluctuations throughout the year, as is typical, these areas are crucial for understanding the strong free cash flow we generated for the year.
Examining our balance sheet and capital allocation, we concluded the year with $940 million in cash and short-term investments.
During the year, we utilized free cash flow to return $34 million to shareholders through dividends.
Our capital expenditures totaled $105 million, reflecting investments in new and existing facilities, technology, and products throughout the year.
As part of our ongoing transformation, we also made $20 million in restructuring payments.
Within Pitney Bowes Bank, customer deposits grew to $617 million, and Wheeler Financial funded $16 million in new deals for the year.
Regarding our debt position, we ended the year with $102.6 billion in total debt, a reduction of $175 million from the previous year.
In terms of net debt, when accounting for our cash, short-term investments, and finance receivables, our implied net debt position on an operating company basis was approximately $550 million at year-end.
Moving on to the fourth quarter details.
We achieved $1 billion in revenue, representing a 23% growth.
Global Ecommerce grew by 60%, while both Presort and SendTech remained stable compared to the previous year.
For the quarter, adjusted earnings per share were $0.13, and GAAP earnings per share were $0.11.
The quarter's EPS includes a $0.03 tax benefit, mainly related to deferred tax balances in certain international tax jurisdictions.
GAAP cash from operations for the quarter was $111 million, and free cash flow was $97 million.
Free cash flow increased by $16 million compared to the previous year, primarily due to the timing of working capital.
During the quarter, we used free cash flow to reduce debt by $31 million, invest $24 million in capital expenditures, and pay $9 million in dividends.
Analyzing the P&L, starting with revenue performance compared to the previous year.
Business services grew by 43% and equipment sales increased by 15%.
Support services declined by 4% and rentals by 8%, while financing and supplies both decreased by approximately 10%.
Gross profit was $311 million, with a gross margin of 30%.
This represents a decline of about nine points from the previous year, largely reflecting the changing mix of our portfolio and higher service costs driven by increased parcel demand in Global Ecommerce.
SG&A expenses were $242 million, or just under 24% of revenue, a six-point improvement from the previous year.
Within SG&A, unallocated corporate expenses were $54 million, $2.5 million higher than the previous year.
It's important to note that full-year unallocated corporate expenses were $200 million, $11 million lower than the previous year, primarily due to reduced employee-related expenses.
R&D expenses were $9.5 million, or about 1% of revenue, representing a half-point improvement from the previous year.
EBIT was $62 million, with an EBIT margin of 6%.
Compared to the previous year, EBIT declined by $3 million and EBIT margin decreased by about 2%, largely due to lower gross profit.
Interest expense, including financing interest expense, was $38 million, relatively unchanged from the previous year.
The provision for taxes on adjusted earnings was less than $1 million, and our tax rate for the quarter was 1%, bringing our annual tax rate to 13%.
Average diluted weighted shares outstanding at the end of the quarter were approximately 177 million.
Let me now discuss the performance of each of our business segments this quarter.
In Global Ecommerce, revenue reached $518 million, representing 60% growth over the previous year and marking the first time we achieved over $500 million in quarterly revenue.
Compared to the previous year, volumes grew by 50% or more across all our lines of business.
Domestic parcel volumes increased by 76% to just under 65 million parcels.
Digital volumes grew by 50%, and cross-border volumes increased by 76%.
Examining EBIT, we experienced a deficit of $15 million.
This represented a $3 million betterment from the previous year and a $5 million improvement from the preceding quarter.
The EBIT margin also saw an enhancement of three percentage points compared to last year and two percentage points from the previous quarter.
EBITDA reached $3 million, showing progress from both the prior year and earlier quarters.
The year-over-year revenue growth was boosted by considerable demand.
This was counterbalanced by increased expenses, partially due to market conditions, including notably higher transportation spot market rates and labor costs.
The surge in peak demand also negatively impacted our productivity.
We plan to keep investing in our network to enhance efficiency, decrease expenses, and upgrade client services, partly through network-wide automation.
We're restructuring our workforce by transitioning from temporary to permanent employees, which should result in a more efficient labor force.
We're also evaluating our transportation network and exploring opportunities to reduce our reliance on the spot market where feasible, while improving our ability to secure deeper postal discounts.
Furthermore, like others in the market, we'll implement a surcharge in 2021, along with our yearly general rate increase.
In the Presort Services division, revenue remained steady at $135 million compared to the previous year.
Overall daily volume average decreased by 2%.
First Class Mail volumes dropped by 3%, while Marketing Mail volumes increased by 2%.
Marketing Mail Flats and Bound Printed Matter volumes saw a 26% increase.
As previously mentioned, this remains a relatively small part of our portfolio but represents a new source of revenue and profit for us.
EBIT amounted to $13 million with a margin of 10%.
EBITDA reached $21 million with a margin of 16%.
EBIT and EBITDA margins were similar to previous quarters but declined from the prior year, mainly due to higher medical claims, increased labor costs, and COVID-related expenses for worker health and safety.
Moving on to our SendTech segment.
Revenue was $376 million, unchanged from last year when excluding currency effects, and showing a 1% growth on a reported basis.
Marc discussed our investments in SendTech's digital capabilities, including our channel and products.
We're delivering new value to clients through multi-purpose devices and using our digital channel to attract new customers to our offerings.
In Q4, SendTech's shipping-related revenues grew by nearly 30% to $35 million, and our SaaS-based SendPro online offering saw a 70% increase in paid subscriptions.
Shipping, which currently contributes about 10% to SendTech's overall revenue, is a high-margin stream with significant future growth potential.
The impact of shipping is also evident in our financing portfolio, with clients increasing their shipping volumes by 65% compared to last year.
Equipment sales rose by 15% year-over-year, driven by strong placements of our SendPro C and MailStation multipurpose products.
Our value proposition continues to resonate with our clients.
The SendPro MailStation serves as a replacement option for lower-volume mailers and is ideal for remote setups or branch offices of larger organizations.
Since its April launch, we've shipped about 20,000 MailStation units.
The growth in equipment sales marks a significant improvement from previous quarters, especially compared to the 32% decline we experienced in Q2 during the peak of COVID lockdowns.
Supplies declined by 10%, which is an improvement from earlier quarters due to increased usage and demand.
In the U.S., 70% of our supplies transactions were conducted online in Q4, up nine percentage points from the same period last year.
Support services decreased by 4%, also an improvement from recent quarters.
Combined rentals and financing revenues fell by 9% in the quarter.
We achieved strong EBIT performance of $118 million, representing a $5 million increase over the previous year.
EBIT margin was 31%, improving by one percentage point year-over-year and falling within our long-term model's projected range.
EBITDA reached $126 million with a margin of 34%, both showing improvement over the prior year.
Our financing portfolio remains healthy, with delinquency rates decreasing from the initial small uptick we observed earlier in the year due to the pandemic.
We continuously monitor delinquency rates and take a disciplined approach to managing credit risk.
Let me conclude with an update on 2021.
Due to ongoing market uncertainty surrounding the pandemic and unpredictable macroeconomic conditions, we'll provide a broader outlook for 2021.
We anticipate annual revenue growth in the low-to-mid single-digit range compared to the previous year, making 2021 the fifth consecutive year of constant currency growth.
We also expect adjusted earnings per share to increase year-over-year.
Within our segments, we project Global Ecommerce revenue to grow in the low double-digit range and anticipate significant profit improvement in this business.
We expect the momentum observed in SendTech during the second half of 2020, particularly in shipping capabilities and new multipurpose devices, to continue through 2021, helping to partially offset the decline in recurring related revenues.
We also anticipate the improvement in volume trends seen in Presort during the second half of 2020 to persist through 2021.
There are some year-over-year headwinds to be aware of that will partially offset overall business unit improvements.
In 2020, we recorded RIV insurance proceeds.
For 2021, we expect higher employee-related costs concerning variable compensation.
Additionally, we anticipate our annual tax rate on adjusted earnings to be in the 23% to 27% range, which is higher than our 2020 end rate.
We expect lower free cash flow in 2021, primarily due to specific items I discussed earlier that benefited 2020 but are not expected to continue at the same level in 2021.
Regarding timing throughout the year, our portfolio continues to shift towards growing markets, particularly in shipping.
Consequently, the fourth quarter will remain our largest quarter of the year.
Specifically for the first quarter, we expect revenue to grow in the high single-digit to low double-digit range compared to the previous year, with earnings per share relatively in line with the prior year.
Summary:

q4 adjusted earnings per share $0.13.
q4 gaap earnings per share $0.11.
expects 2021 revenue to grow over prior year in low-to-mid single digit range.
expects 2021 adjusted earnings per share to grow over prior year.
