input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We examine alternative financial metrics, such as core funds from operations (core FFO), adjusted funds from operations (AFFO), and net debt to recurring EBITDA.
We're delighted to announce that our strong performance continued, with a record-breaking investment volume exceeding $750 million in the initial half of 2021.
Substantial and superior investment activity further enhanced our investment grade concentration and increased our ground lease exposure to an unprecedented level of nearly 13%.
Our investment endeavors this quarter were bolstered by over $1 billion in strategic capital market transactions, which strengthened our industry-leading balance sheet and positioned us for future growth.
In the second quarter, we allocated approximately $366 million to 59 premium retail net lease properties across our three external growth strategies.
We sourced 54 of these properties through our acquisition platform, representing a purchase volume of over $345 million.
The 54 properties acquired in the second quarter are leased to 32 tenants operating across 18 different retail sectors, including top-tier companies in off-price, home improvement, auto parts, general merchandise, dollar stores, convenience stores, craft and novelties, grocery, and tire and auto service industries.
The newly acquired properties had an average capitalization rate of 6.2% and an average lease duration of 11.8 years.
In the first half of this year, we've invested a record $756 million in 146 retail net lease properties across 35 states and 24 retail sectors.
Our acquisition platform generated approximately $732 million of our investment activity.
About 75% of the annualized base rents acquired in the year's first half come from leading investment-grade retailers, while nearly one-third of annualized base rent is generated from ground-leased assets.
These figures highlight our ongoing focus on premium opportunities with leading omnichannel retailers, while still achieving record results.
Given our unprecedented acquisition activity to date and our pipeline visibility, we are raising our full-year 2021 acquisition forecast to between $1.2 billion and $1.4 billion.
This past quarter, we executed several unique and notable deals, including a new small-format Target on the University of Georgia campus in Athens.
We are thrilled to expand our relationship with Target and add another distinctive street retail asset to our growing portfolio.
We maintained our investment in dominant grocery chains during the quarter.
The most significant was a five-store sale-leaseback transaction with Kroger for approximately $68 million.
The stores are situated in Texas, Michigan, Ohio, and Mississippi, with each location subject to a new 15-year net lease.
With this transaction, Kroger has become one of our top 10 tenants, representing 3.2% of annualized base rents.
Kroger is undoubtedly a leader in the grocery industry.
Their robust balance sheet, strategic omnichannel initiatives, and substantial investment in e-commerce fulfillment align perfectly with our investment strategy.
Furthermore, we finalized the purchase of a ShopRite, owned and operated by Wakefern, in New Rochelle, New York.
ShopRite is an exceptional operator, and the property's location at a strategic interchange of I-95 exemplifies the thorough bottom-up analysis we conduct for every asset we acquire.
Lastly, you may recall we acquired our first Wegmans Ground Lease in Chapel Hill, North Carolina during the fourth quarter of 2020.
We've built on that momentum this quarter by acquiring our second property ground-leased to Wegmans.
The store, located in Parsippany, New Jersey, spans over 100,000 square feet and was constructed at Wegmans' expense.
In the first six months of the year, we've acquired 45 ground leases, totaling an investment of over $240 million.
The second quarter contributed 14 ground leases to this total, representing an investment volume exceeding $113 million.
Other notable ground lease acquisitions during the quarter included our first Capital Grille in Whippany, New Jersey.
We also acquired a Walmart Supercenter and Lowe's in Hooksett, New Hampshire, our first Cabela's in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and three additional Wawa assets, increasing our Wawa portfolio to 25 properties, including their flagship store in downtown Philadelphia.
As mentioned earlier, our overall ground lease exposure reached a company record of 12.7% of annualized base rents at quarter-end, including unique assets leased to the country's top retailers.
Including our second quarter acquisitions, the ground lease portfolio now generates nearly 90% of rents from investment-grade tenants and has an average lease term of 12.5 years.
Most of the portfolio includes rent escalators resulting in average annual growth of close to 1%, while the average rent per square foot is only $9 and $0.65.
This expanding portfolio continues to offer exceptional risk-adjusted returns when considering the lease term, credit quality, underlying real estate attributes, and the free building and improvements if a tenant were to vacate.
We anticipate continuing to utilize our industry connections and proven execution capabilities to identify potential additions to this growing and diverse sub-portfolio.
As of June 30, our portfolio's total investment grade exposure reached nearly 68%, marking a substantial year-over-year increase of about 670 basis points.
Over a two-year period, our investment grade exposure has shown improvement by more than 1,300 basis points.
The ongoing expansion of our ground lease portfolio and investment grade exposure showcases our disciplined approach to building the nation's premier retail portfolio.
Regarding our Development and Partner Capital Solutions platforms, we continue to discover promising opportunities with our retail partners.
During the first half of the year, we had six development and PCS projects either finished or in progress, representing a total capital commitment exceeding $36 million.
In the second quarter, we completed three projects: a grocery outlet in Port Angeles, Washington, a Gerber Collision in Buford, Georgia, and a Floor & Decor in Naples, Florida.
I'm happy to report that we also began construction on our second development with Gerber Collision in Pooler, Georgia, during the quarter.
Upon completion, Gerber will enter a new 15-year net lease, with rent expected to commence in the first quarter of 2022.
We are working on additional opportunities with Gerber Collision that we expect to announce later this year and into next year.
Construction progressed during the quarter on our first development with 7-Eleven in Saginaw, Michigan.
We expect delivery to occur in the first quarter of next year, at which point 7-Eleven will enter a new 15-year net lease.
We remain committed to leveraging our full capabilities to expand our relationships with these leading omnichannel retailers.
I look forward to updating you on our ongoing progress in future quarters.
While enhancing our top-tier retail portfolio through record investment activity, we were also quite active in property dispositions during the quarter.
We continued reducing our Walgreens exposure and franchise restaurants, selling seven properties for gross proceeds of about $28 million at a weighted average cap rate of 6.7%.
In the first six months of the year, we sold a total of 10 properties for gross proceeds exceeding $36 million at a weighted average cap rate of approximately 6.7%.
Based on our disposition activities in the first half of the year, we are increasing the lower end of our disposition guidance to $50 million for the year, while the upper end remains at about $75 million.
Our asset management team has been proactively addressing upcoming lease expirations.
Their efforts have reduced the remaining 2021 maturities to just three leases, representing 20 basis points of annualized base rents.
In the second quarter, we executed new leases, extensions, or options on roughly 209,000 square feet of gross leasable area.
We are particularly pleased to have signed a new 15-year net lease with Gardner White to occupy our only former Loves Furniture store in Canton, Michigan.
This was the Art Van flagship we developed before the company's acquisition by TH Lee.
We handed over the space to Gardner White in June, and rent began in July, allowing us to recover nearly 100% of previous rents with just over a month of downtime.
It's worth noting that this is the second time we've released this asset with essentially full recovery since the Art Van bankruptcy.
Gardner White is a Michigan-based, family-owned and operated business that has been one of the state's leading furniture retailers for over a century.
The company is led by Rachel Tronstein, one of the furniture retail industry's brightest minds and a former high school classmate of mine.
We are thrilled to have Rachel and her team as partners in this flagship asset.
I'm also excited to announce the addition of Burlington to Central Michigan Commons in Mount Pleasant, Michigan, one of only two remaining legacy shopping centers we decided to keep during our portfolio transformation.
So far, we have redeveloped the former Kmart space for Hobby Lobby and Alta, and added Texas Roadhouse on an outlot via ground lease.
These transactions demonstrate our ability to unlock hidden value within the portfolio and support our decision to retain this well-located legacy shopping center across from Central Michigan University's main campus.
In the first six months of the year, we executed new leases, extensions, or options on approximately 275,000 square feet of gross leasable area.
As of June 30, our expanding retail portfolio comprised 1,262 properties across 46 states, including 134 ground leases, and remains nearly fully occupied at 99.5%.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Simon, and then we can open it up for questions.
Regarding earnings, core funds from operations for the second quarter were $0.89 per share, representing a record 17.3% year-over-year increase.
The quarterly adjusted funds from operations per share reached $0.88, showing a 15.9% year-on-year growth.
Our diluted share count includes treasury stock before settlement when ADCs stock price exceeds the deal price of our outstanding forward equity offerings.
These offerings had a minimal dilutive impact of less than $0.005 in Q2.
According to FactSet, analysts project full-year AFFO per share between $3.40 and $3.53, suggesting 6% to 10% annual growth.
We believe this growth rate is attainable and expect to finish the year near the upper end of this range, considering our current investment pipeline and overall operating conditions.
This projection, combined with our 6% AFFO per share growth in 2020, indicates a two-year cumulative growth in the mid-teens.
Q2 general and administrative expenses amounted to $6.2 million.
G&A costs represented 7.6% of total revenue, or 7.1% excluding non-cash amortization of above and below-market lease intangibles.
Despite ongoing investments in personnel and systems to support our expanding business, we expect G&A as a percentage of total revenue to be in the lower 7% range for the full year 2021, excluding lease intangible amortization impact on total revenues.
As previously noted, our acquisitions team's G&A expenses vary based on yearly acquisition volume, and our current G&A expense forecast reflects an acquisition volume within our updated guidance range of $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion.
The second quarter's total income tax expense for 2021 was approximately $485,000.
We continue to anticipate total income tax expense to be around $2.5 million.
In May, we issued a $650 million dual-tranche public bond, consisting of $350 million in 2% senior unsecured notes due in 2028 and $300 million in 2.6% senior unsecured notes due in 2033.
We terminated related swap agreements of $300 million that hedged the 2033 Notes, receiving about $17 million upon termination.
Taking into account the terminated swap agreements, the effective rates for the 2028 and 2033 Notes are 2.11% and 2.13% respectively.
We used part of the net proceeds to repay all $240 million of our unsecured term loans, incurring termination costs of approximately $15 million.
These one-time termination costs have been excluded from our core FFO and AFFO calculations.
This bond issuance and term loan repayment extended our weighted average debt maturity to about nine years and lowered our effective weighted average interest rate to roughly 3.2%.
In June, we completed a follow-on public offering of 4.6 million common stock shares, generating net proceeds of approximately $327 million.
During Q2, we entered into forward sale agreements through our ATM program to sell about 1.2 million common stock shares, expecting net proceeds of approximately $81 million.
In May, we settled around 164,000 shares, receiving net proceeds of about $10 million.
At quarter-end, we had roughly 3.9 million shares remaining to be settled under existing forward sale agreements, expected to raise net proceeds of approximately $259 million upon settlement.
Including anticipated net proceeds from outstanding forward offerings, cash on hand, and credit facility availability, we had nearly $950 million in liquidity at quarter-end.
Our balance sheet remains a significant strength.
As of June 30, our pro forma net debt to recurring EBITDA was about 3.6 times, including outstanding forward equity offerings.
Excluding unsettled forward equity, our net debt to recurring EBITDA was approximately 4.5 times.
Total debt to enterprise value at quarter-end was around 25%, while fixed charge coverage remained at a record five times.
In Q2, we declared monthly cash dividends of $0.217 per share for April, May, and June.
This monthly dividend reflected an annualized amount of $2.60 per share, an 8.5% increase over the $2.40 per share annualized dividend for Q2 of last year.
Our Q2 payout ratios were a conservative 73% of Core FFO per share and 74% of AFFO per share.
After the quarter ended, we declared a monthly cash dividend of $0.217 per share for July.
This monthly dividend reflects an annualized amount of $2.60 per share, an 8.5% increase over the $2.40 per share annualized dividend from Q3 2020.
Summary:

compname reports core ffo per share of $0.89.
agree realty corp - qtrly core ffo per share $0.89.
agree realty corp - qtrly affo per share $0.88.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:After our comments, we will allow analysts to ask questions.
Please ask only one question with a single follow-up.
We outline these risks and uncertainties in our risk factor disclosures and other sections of our Form 10-K and Form 10-Q filed with the SEC.
Our presentation will also include non-GAAP financial measures.
I wish everyone good health and safety.
We had an exceptional second quarter performance with strong product demand.
This led to our fourth straight quarter of double-digit sales growth and sixth consecutive quarter of margin improvement and double-digit EPS growth.
I'm very proud of our team's ability to overcome numerous supply chain obstacles to achieve this growth.
Sales grew by 24% for the quarter.
Sales increased by 18% when excluding acquisitions, divestitures, and currency effects.
Operating profit rose by 27% and margins expanded by 60 basis points to 20.1%, mainly due to strong volume leverage.
Earnings per share showed an impressive increase of 34%.
Our overall performance showcases the strength of our diverse portfolio of lower-cost repair and remodel products, which are spread across different regions and channels, catering to both consumers and professionals.
In our plumbing segment, sales grew by 48% excluding currency effects, driven by outstanding growth in our North American and international faucet and shower businesses, as well as our spa business.
International plumbing sales increased by 50% in the quarter, excluding currency effects, with Hansgrohe experiencing a sharp rebound in nearly all markets.
Strong operational execution and new products like Hansgrohe's Rainfinity shower systems led to market share gains in many areas.
New product launches will continue with the introduction of the award-winning AXOR One collection in the second half of the year.
This collection was created by Barber Osgerby, an internationally renowned London-based industrial design studio.
This furthers Hansgrohe's tradition of combining cutting-edge contemporary design with innovative functionality.
North American plumbing reported strong growth of 47%, excluding currency effects, in the second quarter, led by approximately 75% growth at Watkins Wellness and robust double-digit growth at Delta.
Delta faucet achieved another record quarter with growth across all channels, particularly in the professionally-oriented trade channel.
We continue to invest in new products for North American plumbing as well.
Two days ago, we launched a Frank Lloyd Wright collection by Brizo, furthering the brand's commitment to distinctive design and innovative products.
Lastly, in plumbing, we acquired Steamist at the beginning of July, another bolt-on acquisition for Delta.
Steamist is a leading manufacturer of residential steam bath products that will complement our strong trade and e-commerce product offering and aligns with our bolt-on acquisition strategy.
In our decorative architectural segment, sales decreased by 5% compared to a healthy 8% growth in the second quarter of 2020.
While bath and cabinet hardware, lighting, and propane grew in the quarter, demand for DIY paint moderated.
Material availability and other supply chain issues also affected our overall coatings business, as nearly all of our resin suppliers were operating under force majeure declarations during the second quarter.
Due to these issues, sell-through of our coatings products exceeded sell-in, and inventories in the channel decreased during the quarter.
Because of lower than expected second quarter sales and our anticipation that material availability issues will persist but gradually improve, we are reducing our DIY sales forecast from flat to a low-single digit decline for the full year.
However, with the acceleration we observed in our propane business during the quarter, we are more optimistic and are raising our expectations to low-double digit growth from high-single digit for the full year for our propane business.
For the decorative segment as a whole, we now project growth to be in the range of 2% to 5% for the full year.
Regarding innovation in the decorative segment, we continue to invest in new products and are excited to introduce a new high-end paint line called Behr Dynasty at Home Depot in the third quarter, targeting both DIY and professional painters.
Dynasty is our most durable, stain-resistant, scuff-resistant, one-coat hide paint ever.
It's low VOC, Greenguard and LEED certified, fast-drying, and features an anti-microbial mildew-resistant paint finish.
This exemplifies how our innovation teams continue to focus on customer needs to deliver leading innovation and value for both consumers and professionals.
Regarding capital allocation, we continued our aggressive share buyback program during the quarter, repurchasing 6.6 million shares for $447 million.
As part of the accelerated share repurchase agreement executed during the quarter, we will receive approximately 900,000 additional shares in July to complete that agreement, bringing our total shares repurchased year-to-date to 13.1 million shares for $750 million.
This represents about 5% of our outstanding share count at the start of the year.
Highlighting our strong financial position and confidence in the future, we now plan to deploy an additional $250 million in the second half of the year for share repurchases and acquisitions, totaling approximately $1 billion for the full year.
Let me provide an update on our experience with inflation and supply chain constraints, similar to last quarter's report.
We're witnessing rising inflation across most of our cost categories, including transportation, plastics, titanium dioxide, and packaging materials.
The cost of shipping containers incoming to our facilities nearly tripled during this period.
We anticipate our overall cost inflation to reach high single-digit percentages for the entire year in both our plumbing and decorative divisions, with low double-digit inflation expected in the latter half of the year.
The coatings sector is likely to see inflation rates in the mid-teens towards the end of the fourth quarter.
To counter this inflation, we've implemented price increases across both segments and are planning further price adjustments throughout our operations to address these ongoing cost increases.
We're also collaborating with our suppliers, customers, and internal teams to implement additional efficiency measures to help offset these expenses.
Despite the increased inflation, we still anticipate achieving a balance between price and cost by the end of the year.
While cost inflation has certainly been a challenge, the availability of materials has also impacted our operations.
Our teams have excelled at finding new suppliers, creating material alternatives, and adjusting production to adapt to this changing environment and meet customer needs.
However, these raw material shortages have restricted our ability to build inventory for many of our products and the markets we serve.
We expect material availability to gradually improve in the second half of the year, allowing us to replenish inventory to appropriate levels over time.
The market demand for our products remains robust.
Given the improved outlook for plumbing due to continued strong performance in both our North American and international operations, we are raising our full-year earnings per share projection to between $3.65 and $3.75, up from our previous estimate of $3.50 to $3.70.
As mentioned by Dave, my remarks today will focus on adjusted performance, excluding the impact of restructuring and other one-time items.
Moving to Slide 7.
We delivered another outstanding quarter by capitalizing on strong consumer demand, resulting in continued growth and increased order backlogs.
Consequently, sales grew by 24%, with currency and net acquisitions each contributing 3% to this growth.
In local currency, North American sales increased by 15%, or 12% excluding acquisitions.
Strong volume growth in North American faucets, showers, and spas led this exceptional performance.
In local currency, international sales saw a robust increase of 50%, or 49% excluding acquisitions and divestitures.
Gross margin for the quarter was 36.3%, an increase of 50 basis points as we leveraged the strong volume growth.
Our SG&A as a percentage of sales improved by 10 basis points to 16.2% due to our operating leverage.
During the quarter, certain expenses such as headcount, marketing, and travel and entertainment increased as planned.
We anticipate SG&A as a percent of sales to increase in the third and fourth quarters as these costs normalize.
We achieved strong second quarter operating profit of $438 million, an increase of $94 million or 27% from last year, with operating margins expanding by 60 basis points to 20.1%.
Our earnings per share for the quarter was $1.14, a 34% increase compared to the second quarter of 2020, due to volume leverage, reduced interest expense, and lower share count.
Turning to Slide 8.
Plumbing growth accelerated in the quarter with sales up 53%.
Currency contributed 5% to this growth and acquisitions, net of divestitures, added another 4%.
North American sales increased by 47% in local currency, or 41% excluding acquisitions.
Delta led this outstanding performance, delivering another quarter of robust double-digit growth.
With strong brand recognition and market leadership, Delta continues to drive strong consumer demand across all its product categories and channels.
Watkins Wellness also significantly contributed to growth in the quarter with both demand and our backlog remaining strong.
International plumbing sales increased by 50% in local currency, or 49% excluding acquisitions and divestitures.
Hansgrohe delivered robust growth as demand continues to improve across Europe and numerous other countries.
Hansgrohe's key markets of Germany, China, UK, and France all grew strong double digits in the quarter.
Segment operating margins expanded by 230 basis points to 20.6% in the quarter, with operating profit of $274 million, up $115 million or 72%.
The strong performance was driven by incremental volume, favorable mix, and cost productivity initiatives, partially offset by an unfavorable price/cost relationship and higher spend on items such as travel and entertainment, marketing, and growth initiatives.
During the quarter, we also completed the divestiture of HUPPE, a small shower enclosure business based in Germany.
HUPPE's sales were approximately €70 million in 2020.
The transaction concluded on May 31 with negligible net proceeds.
In light of our Q2 results and current demand patterns, we now project the plumbing segment's 2021 sales growth to range between 22% and 24%, an increase from our previous forecast of 15% to 18%.
Due to our improved sales outlook, we are raising our full-year margin expectations to approximately 18.5%, up from our earlier estimate of around 18%.
Let's move to Slide 9.
Decorative architectural saw a 5% decline in the second quarter, or 6% when excluding acquisition benefits.
The DIY paint business experienced a double-digit decline this quarter compared to a strong high-teens performance last year, due to slowing demand and raw material supply issues caused by ongoing production challenges at resin plants affected by storms in the Texas Gulf Coast region in Q1.
We anticipate these raw material challenges to continue in Q3 and now expect our DIY paint business to show a low-single digit decline for the full year.
To address these issues, we're collaborating with existing suppliers and qualifying new material sources to meet our customers' persistent strong demand.
Our PRO paint business achieved strong double-digit growth this quarter as consumers become more comfortable allowing professional paint contractors into their homes.
We expect demand in this channel to remain robust and now anticipate low-double digit growth for the PRO paint business for the full year, up from our previous projection of high-single digits, as PRO paint contractors' order books continue to expand.
Our builders' hardware and lighting businesses both grew this quarter, capitalizing on increased consumer demand.
Segment operating margins were 22.1% and quarterly operating profit was $188 million, affected by lower volume but partially offset by cost productivity initiatives.
For the full year 2021, we now project decorative architectural segment's sales growth to be between 2% and 5%, down from 4% to 9%, due to lower than expected Q2 sales and ongoing raw material constraints.
We still anticipate segment operating margins of about 19% as productivity initiatives and pricing help counterbalance higher input costs.
Let's move to Slide 10.
Our balance sheet is robust with a net debt to EBITDA ratio of 1.3x.
We concluded the quarter with approximately $1.8 billion in balance sheet liquidity, including full availability of our $1 billion revolver.
Working capital as a percentage of sales, including our recent acquisitions, was 16.9%, an improvement of 120 basis points over the previous year.
As mentioned last quarter, we terminated and annuitized our U.S. qualified defined benefit plans in Q2, making a final cash contribution of about $100 million to complete this process.
This removes roughly $140 million of pension liabilities from our balance sheet and will improve our free cash flow by approximately $50 million through reduced cash contributions, starting in 2022.
Additionally, we received about $166 million from redeeming our preferred stock related to the recent sale of our former cabinet business.
As Keith mentioned earlier, we've repurchased 13.1 million shares in 2021 for $750 million as of today.
We plan to deploy an additional $250 million for share repurchases or acquisitions for the remainder of this year.
These actions collectively demonstrate our confidence in our business and our commitment and ability to further strengthen our balance sheet while aggressively returning capital to shareholders.
Regarding our full year guidance, we've summarized our updated 2021 expectations on Slide 11.
Based on our Q2 performance and continued strong demand, we now expect overall sales growth of 14% to 16%, up from 10% to 14%, with operating margins of approximately 17.5%, up from 17%.
Lastly, as Keith mentioned earlier, our updated 2021 earnings per share estimate range of $3.65 to $3.75 represents 19% earnings per share growth at the midpoint of the range.
This assumes a 252 million average diluted share count for the full year.
Additional modeling assumptions for 2021 can be found on Slide 14 in the earnings deck.
We had an exceptional second quarter driven by our strong brands, innovation pipelines, and most importantly, our people, as evidenced by the outstanding execution of our supply chain teams.
Our strong performance demonstrates the strength of Masco's balanced and diversified business.
Masco offers a wide range of lower-ticket, repair and remodel-oriented home improvement products.
Our products are widely distributed across geographies and channels for both consumers and professionals.
Moreover, our markets remain strong, and we expect home remodeling expenditures to drive growth in 2022.
The fundamentals of our repair and remodel business are robust, with year-over-year home price appreciation exceeding 15% in May and existing home sales up over 23%.
Both metrics strongly correlate with our sales on a lag basis.
The consumer is in a strong position, with nearly $2 trillion in savings and an increased desire to invest in their homes.
We continue to invest in our business and are well-positioned for long-term growth.
We're introducing new, innovative products to the market, fueling our growth and expanding our leading market share.
With our industry-leading margins and strong free cash flow, we will continue to deploy capital to reinvest in our business, acquire complementary bolt-on companies, and return cash to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, all to drive long-term shareholder value.
We're now ready to take questions.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The third quarter demonstrated our ongoing strategy to invest in North American assets, aiming for reduced costs, sustainable cash flow, and improved returns over extended mine lifespans.
The quarter was marked by numerous important developments and choices.
Our performance aligned with internal projections, positioning us to end the year strongly and meet our initial production targets.
While Mick will provide a detailed operational overview soon, I'll briefly mention a few key points.
Wharf excelled, achieving near-record operating and free cash flow since its acquisition 6.5 years ago.
Palmarejo and Kensington performed as expected and are set for robust fourth quarters, while Rochester made steady progress despite dedicating 45% of the quarter to preparing the new Stage VI leach pad.
It's notable that Rochester's year-to-date results reflect limited stacking on the legacy Stage IV pad due to prioritizing the POA 11 expansion.
Exploration results continue to justify our increased investment in this area.
We invested $20 million in exploration during the quarter.
Our drilling commitment has resulted in significant reserve and resource growth in recent years, and we hope to report further increases by year-end.
We plan to invest $70 million in exploration in 2021, nearly 40% more than last year's record, making it one of the largest programs in our industry.
We're on track to meet our annual drilling targets while spending slightly less than anticipated, reflecting efficiencies from these expanded programs.
We'll provide another exploration update before year-end, focusing on new findings in Nevada, including Rochester and the Crown district in Southern Nevada.
Regarding our expansion projects, let's start with an update on the Rochester POA 11 expansion.
This project remains our top priority and will significantly boost our production and cash flow.
Progress is steady, with 42% completion at the end of the third quarter.
Besides finishing the over-liner for the new Stage VI leach pad, we began foundation work for the Merrill Crowe plant and crusher corridor.
Like many companies, we're experiencing inflationary pressures on remaining unawarded work.
We've secured most contracts before the recent cost increases and supply chain disruptions.
We're trying to mitigate some impacts by reassessing and rebidding unawarded contracts, but we expect a 10% to 15% overall increase in POA 11 construction costs.
We've begun detailed engineering and are considering implementing process improvements, which could extend the crusher completion and commissioning timeline by three to six months.
We plan to install pre-screens on the existing crusher in the first half of next year to gain experience for potential incorporation into the new crusher design.
Regarding Silvertip, the current inflationary environment and pandemic-related disruptions make it challenging to start a new capital project quickly, despite high zinc and lead prices.
Fortunately, the Silvertip expansion and restart is in its early stages, giving us flexibility.
Despite higher-than-expected capital estimates for an accelerated expansion, we're confident in the Silvertip deposit's quality and potential.
Exploration results and new discoveries have led us to consider a larger Silvertip expansion on a potentially longer timeline.
Given the high-grade and significant resource, a 1,750 ton per day facility may not be sufficient to maximize Silvertip's value.
We'll take more time to evaluate a larger design's economics and flexibility.
This approach allows for continued drilling and resource growth, gives time for macroeconomic factors to stabilize, and lets us focus on delivering POA 11 without straining our finances.
We are excited to announce our agreement with Avino Silver & Gold for the sale of the La Preciosa project in Durango, Mexico.
This deal has the potential to create valuable synergies with their nearby Avino mine.
The transaction aligns with our strategic goals of improving our geopolitical risk profile, diversifying our metal mix, and optimizing our development timeline.
We can allocate some of the guaranteed cash payment towards expanding Rochester and funding our promising exploration initiatives.
The deal offers significant growth potential through our equity stake, conditional payments, and two retained royalties.
Let me draw your attention to a series of slides beginning on Slide 17 that showcase our outstanding corporate culture and diversity initiatives at Coeur.
A successful organization requires alignment between its culture, strategy, and capabilities, which I believe we have achieved in recent years.
I'd like to commend our HR Director, Emilie Schouten, for her work on diversity, equity, and inclusion, and for her recent S&P Global Platts Rising Star Award in the industry.
We are continuously incorporating our ESG efforts into our strategic planning and decision-making processes.
Before Mick provides an operational update, I'd like Hans to expand on my Silvertip remarks by presenting a brief overview of the exploration results and explaining our optimism about its future.
We acquired Silvertip in late 2017, recognizing its significant growth potential.
We've now identified 3.5 kilometers of potential growth based on step-out drilling, more than tripling our knowledge since 2017, as shown on Slide 8.
This year, we're conducting the most extensive exploration program in the project's history.
Notably, Silvertip accounts for about 25% of our total $70 million budget at Coeur.
The on-site team, led by Ross Easterbrook, has done an exceptional job managing the 1,000-meter drilling program.
Underground drilling has allowed us to explore year-round and examine various parts of the ore body from different angles, which has been crucial to Silvertip's growth narrative.
Early 2021 underground drilling led to the discovery of Southern Silver Zone vertical feeder structures and thick manto ore zones, and more recently, vertical feeder structures beneath the Discovery South Zone.
These structures indicate significant resource tonnage potential and demonstrate excellent upside.
We currently have two active underground rigs and plan to add a third early next year.
We also intend to continue using three surface rigs to explore resource growth southward in the 1.5-kilometer gap between Southern Silver and Tour Ridge zones.
With this year's larger drilling budget, we anticipate continued significant growth at Silvertip, giving our development team confidence to appropriately scale future operations to match the potentially increased ore body size.
The team recently reported drilling the best hole to date, containing 11 mineralized manto horizons.
This hole is located beneath Silvertip Mountain, approximately 500 meters or 1,500 feet south of the Southern Silver and Camp Creek zones, in an area currently without defined resources.
This new step-out hole is a significant indicator of the growth potential we expect for 2022 and beyond.
I'll now hand over to Mick.
Before delving into operational results, I want to acknowledge the team's continued prioritization of health and safety and their drive for continuous improvement in this area.
Referring to Slide 24, I'm proud to announce that we recently received the NIOSH Mine Safety and Health Technology Innovation Award for our cross-functional COVID-19 response efforts.
I'm truly honored to be part of such an exceptional team that is unwavering in its commitment to collaboration and ensuring the well-being of our people.
Now, turning to Slide 5 to discuss operations, starting with Palmarejo.
The team excelled at maintaining high throughput levels and maximizing recoveries to compensate for the lower grades we've encountered with our revised mine plan.
We've also continued advancing development while focusing on increasing rehabilitation rates across the mine, which helps ensure we've appropriately prioritized workforce health and safety.
Quarterly operating costs remained within guidance, helping to offset lower realized prices and generate $15 million in free cash flow.
We anticipate a strong conclusion to the year at Palmarejo and are eager to see how much production growth we can achieve in this fourth quarter.
Transitioning to discuss Rochester.
We processed slightly under 1.3 million tons of over-liner for the new Stage VI leach pad in the quarter, fulfilling the necessary requirements for POA 11.
It's worth mentioning that while producing over-liner, we weren't crushing materials placed on the existing Stage IV leach pad, which affected production in the third quarter.
Although there was a short-term impact on production, the time and resources used to finish crushing overlay now was a crucial step towards completing this highly anticipated expansion project.
Now moving on to Kensington.
Output increased slightly during the quarter as improved grades helped compensate for reduced mill throughput caused by stope sequencing and drill parts availability issues.
We expect more high-grade Jualin material in the coming months and have already received the needed spare parts for stope drills, positioning us well for strong production growth in the fourth quarter.
The Kensington team excellently managed multiple priorities and maintained good cost controls throughout the quarter, helping generate nearly $15 million in free cash flow.
Concluding with Wharf, I'd like to acknowledge a significant achievement.
On October 3, the Wharf team celebrated a full year without a recordable safety incident, which is a remarkable accomplishment.
Regarding results, Wharf delivered another excellent quarter, marking consecutive periods of strong performance.
Gold production increased by 17% and cash flow was the second highest since Coeur's acquisition in 2015.
I'll now hand over to Tom.
I wanted to provide some context on the non-cash adjustments that affected our third quarter earnings.
We wrote off $26 million of Mexican VAT refunds, which we strongly believe we're entitled to, but like many other multinational companies operating in Mexico, we've faced significant challenges from SAT and the Mexican courts in obtaining these payments.
We also had a mark-to-market adjustment on our equity investments, mainly related to Victoria Gold.
However, the investment's carrying value remains above our initial cost.
Moving to Slide 4, I'll briefly review our quarterly consolidated financial results.
Revenue of $208 million was driven by relatively stable metal sales and a lower average realized silver price compared to the second quarter.
Operating cash flow totaled $22 million, which was lower than last quarter but also negatively impacted by changes in working capital.
Excluding working capital, operating cash flow improved by over 10% quarter-over-quarter.
Like most companies, we've experienced cost pressures related to consumables and labor across all our operations.
With stronger expected Q4 production, we anticipate operating cash flow levels to continue rising as we end the year.
Turning to Slide 12 and examining the balance sheet, we finished the quarter with approximately $330 million of liquidity, including $85 million in cash and $245 million available under our revolving credit facility.
It's worth noting that these figures don't include the $140 million of equity investments on our balance sheet.
We made a modest drawdown on the revolver.
We ended the period with a net debt to EBITDA leverage ratio of 1.4 times.
We'll continue adhering to our disciplined capital allocation framework and remain focused on keeping net leverage below 2 times and maintaining liquidity of at least $100 million throughout the entire Rochester construction period.
However, we expect the revised timeline for Silvertip, along with the current strong metals price environment, will leave us well positioned to maintain a robust and flexible balance sheet.
I'll now return the call to Mitch.
Before moving to the Q&A, I want to quickly highlight Slide 13 that outlines our short-term priorities as we approach year-end.
With production guidance reaffirmed and a strong expected fourth quarter underway, we're confident about our 2021 results and our ability to carry this momentum into next year.
We'll continue striving for a higher standard and execute at a high level to deliver consistent results and industry-leading organic growth from our balanced portfolio of North American-based precious metals assets.
Summary:
output:
q3 revenue $208 million versus $229.7 million.
reaffirms production guidance; updates cost and capital expenditure guidance.
full-year 2021 capital expenditures are expected to be slightly lower at about $35 million - $40 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am Rebecca Gardy, serving as the Vice President of Investor Relations.
Within 24 hours, a written record of this financial results conference call will be accessible to investors.
Let's move on to the third slide.
These claims are based on projections and calculations that may be imprecise and involve potential risks.
The fourth slide displays our meeting agenda.
Joining us for today's discussion are Mark Clouse, who holds the positions of President and CEO at Campbell's, along with our CFO, Mick Beekhuizen.
Mark will provide his insights on our overall performance and market presence for each division in the first quarter.
Mick will provide a more detailed analysis of the quarter's financial results and review our projections for the second quarter.
We will conclude the call by answering questions from analysts.
I feel particularly appreciative this year for everyone at Campbell, especially our factory workers and distribution teams who have been producing and delivering to meet the increased demand caused by the pandemic, while prioritizing employee safety and adhering to our enhanced plant protocols.
Our impressive revenue growth, combined with improved gross margins and cost-saving synergies, led to better-than-anticipated adjusted EBIT growth of 18% and a 31% increase in adjusted earnings per share to $1.02, despite ongoing COVID-19 related expenses.
We also executed well this quarter, improving our supply levels to help retailers boost their inventory in preparation for the critical soup and holiday season.
Furthermore, our Board approved a 6% increase in our quarterly dividend, reflecting our strong financial performance, cash flow, and growing confidence in our long-term growth prospects, as well as our ongoing commitment to providing returns to shareholders.
Organic sales in the first quarter grew by 8%, led by a 12% organic sales increase in Meals & Beverages, reflecting our continued investment in our brands to attract and retain new households as retailers also replenished their inventory.
Our Snacks Division performed well, with organic sales increasing by 4%, showing sales growth across most of our nine power brands.
Our diverse and unique snack portfolio remained highly sought after as at-home consumption rapidly increased.
We strategically chose to postpone some promotions from the first quarter to later in the year to alleviate supply constraints, particularly in the Meals & Beverages division.
While these decisions led to mixed share results as anticipated, we ended the first quarter in a much better position regarding retailer inventories and are witnessing accelerating market performance as promotional activities ramp up for the key holiday season.
We anticipate that the pressure of high demand on supply will persist in the short term, but we are expanding our supply chain capacity and capabilities to help us better manage this pressure and maximize availability while protecting and growing market share.
For the sixth consecutive quarter, our total Company in-market dollar performance grew in measured channels, increasing by 7%, with growth across nearly the entire portfolio.
Continuing the momentum from the latter half of fiscal 2020, October marked the ninth consecutive month of year-over-year growth in household penetration.
In our first quarter, we attracted millions of new households, with the most significant increase coming from younger consumers.
We also continued to see high repeat purchase rates, with over 70% of households gained since the start of the pandemic buying our products again.
As we've mentioned in previous calls, we believe this represents a lasting change in behavior, and given the strengthening consumer trends like quick-scratch cooking and at-home eating and snacking, we remain confident that we will retain a significant number of these households beyond the pandemic.
In the Meals & Beverages division, soup net sales increased by 21% with growth across all segments.
This reflects retailer inventory recovery, market gains, and reduced promotional activity.
We increased our household penetration in overall soup by 1.3 percentage points.
In addition to gaining new customers, we are retaining these new buyers as evidenced by higher repeat purchase rates.
Among millennials, we grew our share of the total US soup market by nearly 1 percentage point, including significant growth of 2.7 points in condensed soups and over 1 point in ready-to-serve varieties, demonstrating the continued relevance of our core products with younger consumers.
Our condensed soups were the standout performer of the quarter, with double-digit net sales growth, market share gains led by cooking products, and 4 million new households purchasing this quarter compared to the previous year.
We continued to introduce new ideas and recipes to consumers who are cooking more frequently at home.
As these novice cooks gain confidence, we believe they will likely continue to use these skills to prepare more meals at home, even after the pandemic.
Our recipe solutions continue to resonate with consumers, as we saw a 20% increase in overall recipe-related page views in the first quarter compared to the previous year.
In the ready-to-serve category, we saw solid consumption growth, but supply pressure and our decision to reduce promotions as previously mentioned resulted in some short-term market share loss.
However, as supply has improved, we are seeing positive trends, supported by our Chunky NFL sponsorship activation, our Slow Kettle Crunch innovation, and our Well Yes! brand.
We expect all these factors to have a very positive impact in the second quarter.
Our Pacific Foods growth engine performed well as we continued to expand, with nearly 22% dollar consumption growth in soup and broth during the quarter.
Pacific soup and broth increased market share for the fourth consecutive quarter, including strong gains among millennials.
Pacific has also increased its distribution points and grew household penetration as we launched our first-ever national advertising campaign.
Overall, we continue to feel very positive about the progress we've made in our Win in Soup strategy, as evidenced by our success in expanding into millions of new households, attracting younger consumers, and growing all of our core brands.
Regarding the performance of our Snacks power brands, they grew dollar consumption by 6% in the quarter.
The most notable was Late July, which grew consumption sales by 26% and increased market share by nearly 2 percentage points.
Throughout the quarter, we maintained the company's inaugural nationwide advertising campaign.
Late July exemplifies how our leading brands are enhancing consumers' snacking experiences.
We elevate a common category like tortilla chips by offering superior quality products with organic credentials, relevant innovations, and top-notch marketing to engage customers better, enabling them to upgrade their snacking experience.
This strategy has been effectively applied to other products, such as Kettle Brand chips and Snack Factory Pretzel Crisps, both of which experienced double-digit growth in dollar consumption during the quarter.
We made considerable progress with Goldfish in the quarter, improving both supply and service levels.
We've also shifted our marketing focus towards at-home snacking options and resumed promotional spending near the end of the quarter.
These actions have resulted in improved consumption and market share in recent periods.
We're pleased with our Snacks division's performance and the consistent growth it delivers, supported by a robust core business.
Furthermore, we remain on track to achieve the synergy-related cost savings we initially outlined following our acquisition of Snyder's-Lance.
Our investment in expanding capacity for both Goldfish and our chips demonstrates our confidence in the long-term growth potential of our brands.
We're still addressing some supply constraints, including a challenge in cookies where demand and COVID-19-related labor issues have negatively impacted supply.
Despite these isolated challenges, we're confident in our ability to meet long-term demand driven by the expected sustained growth in consumer snacking behavior.
Given the rapid growth of e-commerce in the food sector, I'd like to discuss our overall performance in this channel during the quarter.
Our e-commerce in-market dollar consumption results were once again impressive, growing 85% compared to the previous year.
Consumers' use of e-commerce, particularly click-and-collect for groceries, has increased significantly in recent months, and we believe this trend will continue.
Consequently, we're investing to enhance our capabilities and support key partnerships to serve the millions of consumers shopping online.
Considering our overall financial results and the actions we've taken at the start of the year, we're well-positioned across our entire portfolio heading into Q2 and the key soup and holiday season.
As Mark just mentioned, we had a strong start to fiscal 2021 with another quarter of robust sales growth, driven by increased consumer demand, gross margin expansion despite COVID-19 cost challenges, and substantial adjusted EBIT and adjusted earnings per share growth exceeding expectations.
I'll now provide a more detailed review of our first quarter results and offer guidance for the second quarter.
In the first quarter, reported net sales increased 7% to $2.3 billion.
Organic net sales grew 8% in the quarter, excluding the impact of the European chips business sale.
Adjusted EBIT rose 18% to $463 million, as higher sales volumes, improved adjusted gross margin performance, and lower selling expenses were partially offset by increased marketing and slightly higher adjusted administrative expenses.
Adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations increased by 31%, or $0.24, to $1.02 per share, reflecting an increase in adjusted EBIT and lower net interest expense.
Analyzing our net sales performance for the quarter, organic net sales increased 8% from the previous year.
This performance was driven by a 6-point gain in volume across most of our retail brands, partially offset by declines in foodservice.
Reduced promotional spending in both segments contributed a 2-point gain.
The divestiture of the European chips business negatively impacted net sales by 1 point, while currency translation had a neutral impact.
Overall, our reported net sales increased by 7% compared to the previous year.
Our adjusted gross margin improved by 100 basis points in the quarter to 34.8%.
Favorable product mix, primarily due to increased contribution from soup products in our Meals & Beverages segment, drove a 30 basis point improvement in our adjusted gross margin.
We estimate a 60 basis point gross margin improvement from better operating leverage within our supply chain network, as we significantly increased overall production, mainly in Meals & Beverages.
Net pricing led to a 120 basis point improvement, due to reduced promotional spending in the quarter.
Inflation and other factors negatively impacted the margin by 270 basis points, driven by cost inflation, as overall input prices increased by approximately 2%, as well as other operational costs and ongoing COVID-19 related expenses.
This was partially offset by our continuing supply chain productivity program, which contributed a 150 basis point improvement, including initiatives in procurement and logistics optimization.
Our cost savings program, which is separate from our ongoing supply chain productivity program, added 10 basis points to our gross margin expansion.
Regarding other operating items, marketing and selling expenses increased 1% in the quarter to $208 million.
This increase was primarily due to our planned increase in advertising and consumer promotion expenses, which rose 17% compared to last year.
These investments mainly reflect increased support for soup to drive usage, inspire meal solutions, build brand awareness among younger households, and support innovation.
These investments were partially offset by the benefits of our cost savings initiatives, lower marketing overhead, and reduced selling expenses.
Adjusted administrative expenses increased by $11 million or 9% to $137 million, driven by higher benefit costs and general administrative expenses, including additional consulting charges related to supply chain optimization, as well as inflation, partially offset by the benefits from our cost savings initiatives.
We have continued to successfully deliver on our multi-year enterprise cost savings initiatives.
In the first quarter, we realized $15 million in additional year-over-year cost savings, including synergies from Snyder's-Lance.
Our total savings for the program have reached $740 million so far.
We anticipate an extra $60-70 million in savings for the remainder of fiscal 2021 and are on schedule to meet our cumulative savings goal of $850 million by the end of fiscal 2022.
We're providing an adjusted EBIT comparison to showcase the main factors influencing this quarter's performance.
As mentioned, adjusted EBIT increased by 18%.
This growth was primarily due to higher demand for our products, with sales increases contributing $53 million to EBIT growth.
The overall adjusted gross margin improvement of 100 basis points added $23 million to EBIT growth, which surpassed the $2 million increase in marketing and selling expenses resulting from our A&C investments, partially offset by reduced selling costs.
The combined effect of other factors, including adjusted administrative expenses, R&D, and adjusted other income, was insignificant.
Our adjusted EBIT margin grew by 180 basis points year-over-year, reaching 19.8%.
The following diagram illustrates the breakdown of our adjusted earnings per share growth between operational performance and below-the-line items.
Adjusted earnings per share rose by $0.24, from $0.78 in the previous year's quarter to $1.02 per share.
Adjusted EBIT contributed a positive $0.18 impact on adjusted EPS.
Net interest expense decreased by $25 million year-over-year, providing a $0.06 positive impact on adjusted EPS, as we used proceeds from completed divestitures and our strong cash flow to reduce debt.
The impact of the adjusted tax rate was minimal, completing the explanation for the $1.02 per share figure.
In the Meals & Beverages segment, organic net sales grew by 12% to $1.3 billion, reflecting double-digit increases across most U.S. retail products, including gains in U.S. soups (including Pacific Foods soups and broth), Prego pasta sauces, V8 beverages, Campbell's pasta, and Pace Mexican sauces, as well as growth in Canada, partially offset by declines in foodservice.
Volume increased in U.S. retail and Canada, driven by higher demand for at-home food consumption, partially offset by the negative impact on foodservice due to changes in consumer behavior and ongoing COVID-19 related restrictions.
U.S. soup sales, including Pacific, increased by 21% compared to the previous year due to retailers restocking inventory for the upcoming soup season, in-market gains in condensed soups and broth, and reduced promotional spending.
Operating earnings for Meals & Beverages increased by 18% to $333 million.
The increase was mainly driven by sales volume growth and improved gross margin, partially offset by increased marketing investment.
Gross margin performance was affected by lower promotional spending and favorable mix, as productivity improvements and improved operating leverage were offset by other operational costs, cost inflation, and COVID-19 related expenses.
In the Snacks segment, organic sales grew by 4%, primarily due to reduced promotional spending and healthy velocity across most of the base business.
We observed volume gains in fresh bakery products, Late July snacks, Pop Secret popcorn, Pepperidge Farm cookies, Snack Factory Pretzel Crisps, and Kettle Brand potato chips, which partially offset declines in Lance sandwich crackers.
Goldfish cracker sales remained relatively stable during the quarter, as increased demand for family-size products was offset by reduced away-from-home consumption.
Operating earnings for Snacks increased by 11%, driven by lower selling expenses, reduced marketing overhead, and sales volume gains, partially offset by higher administrative expenses.
Gross margin performance was consistent with the previous year, as lower promotional spending was offset by higher net supply chain costs, with productivity improvements, cost-saving initiatives, and improved operating leverage being outweighed by cost inflation and COVID-19 related expenses.
Now, I'll discuss our cash flow and liquidity.
Operating cash flow was $180 million, comparable to the previous year, as changes in working capital were largely offset by higher cash earnings and lower other cash payments.
Cash from investing activities decreased by $341 million, mainly due to the absence of net proceeds from divested businesses in the prior year.
Capital expenditures totaled $74 million, $24 million lower than the previous year due to discontinued operations, and in line with our previously communicated full-year expectation.
Cash outflows for financing activities were $245 million, compared to $453 million a year ago.
The reduced cash outflow reflects lower debt repayments.
Dividend payments of $108 million were comparable to the previous year, reflecting our current quarterly dividend of $0.35 per share.
We ended the quarter with $722 million in cash and cash equivalents.
Now, I'll discuss our guidance.
As reviewed, the Company's strong first quarter fiscal 2021 results were influenced by increased demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The ongoing impact of the pandemic on the Company's fiscal 2021 results is uncertain, making it challenging to provide a full-year outlook at this time.
Based on our expectation of continued elevated demand and increased investment in our brands, we are providing the following guidance for the second quarter of fiscal 2021.
We anticipate year-over-year net sales growth of 5% to 7%, as growth aligns more closely with consumption, reflecting improved inventory, strong programming, and improving market share positions.
We expect adjusted EBIT growth to be in line with year-over-year sales growth for the quarter as we invest to succeed in the season and continue fueling the retention of new households behind key consumer trends.
We anticipate the combination of healthy EBIT growth and the benefit of significantly reduced interest expense year-over-year to result in adjusted earnings per share growth of 12% to 15%, or $0.81 to $0.83 per share.
While it remains challenging to provide more guidance for the rest of the year, our outlook continues to strengthen as time progresses.
In conclusion, our first-quarter results marked a strong start to the year.
I am proud of the continued strong execution by our teams throughout the organization.
Summary:

q1 adjusted earnings per share $1.02 from continuing operations.
increases quarterly dividend by 6% to $0.37 per share.
qtrly organic net sales increased 8%.
sees q2 2021 net sales up 5% to up 7%.
sees q2 2021 adjusted earnings per share $0.81 to $0.83.
remains on track to deliver annualized savings of $850 million by end of fiscal 2022.
