input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We eagerly anticipate sharing our Q3 2021 results with you today.
Alan Colberg (CEO), Keith Demmings (President), and Richard Dziadzio (CFO) are participating in Assurant's conference call.
We released a statement announcing our Q3 2021 results after the market closed yesterday.
You can find the press release and accompanying financial supplement on our website, assurant.com.
The call will begin with comments from Alan, Keith, and Richard, followed by a question-and-answer session.
We will reference non-GAAP financial measures during today's call, which we consider important for assessing the company's performance.
Our Q3 results were impressive, with Global Lifestyle experiencing double-digit growth in operating earnings.
The performance of our Global Automotive and Connected Living offerings continues to support our long-term strategy of concentrating on our higher-growth, fee-based, and capital-light businesses.
We are making strides in creating a more sustainable company for all stakeholders.
Several key achievements were made during the quarter.
Assurant received its first Bronze accreditation from EcoVadis, a major sustainability ratings firm, placing us among the top 50% of 75,000 participating companies.
We also increased transparency regarding our progress towards a more diverse and inclusive workplace by disclosing our EEO-1, which provides gender, race, and ethnicity data by job category for our U.S.-based employees.
We believe that a diverse and inclusive workforce is essential for fostering innovation, which is crucial for maintaining our long-term outperformance.
Examining our financial performance for the year so far, net operating income per share, excluding reportable catastrophes, was $8.75, a 12% increase compared to the same period last year.
Net operating income and adjusted EBITDA, both excluding catastrophes, increased by 10% to $528 million and $862 million, respectively.
These results support our full-year forecast of 10% to 14% growth in net operating income per share, excluding reportable catastrophes, marking our fifth consecutive year of strong profitable growth.
Based on year-to-date results and our expectations for Q4, we anticipate finishing the year closer to the upper half of this range.
We have also completed our three-year $1.35 billion capital return objective from our 2019 Investor Day, one quarter ahead of schedule.
Following the sale of Global Preneed in August, we have made significant progress in returning an additional $900 million to shareholders.
Our 2021 earnings per share outlook is based on at least high single-digit net operating income growth, excluding catastrophes, as well as share repurchases.
Regarding our business performance, Global Lifestyle is on track to achieve double-digit adjusted EBITDA growth in 2021 from $637 million in 2020, driven by Global Automotive and Connected Living.
We have benefited from the stable recurring revenue stream of our installed base of mobile subscribers and our success in launching additional offerings and capabilities for mobile carrier, cable operator, OEM, and retail clients globally.
Our mobile trade-in upgrade business and expanded service delivery options are increasingly important to our profitability and providing a differentiated and superior customer experience.
In Global Automotive, we have benefited from increased scale, growing the number of vehicles we protect by 20%, to over 52 million since The Warranty Group acquisition in 2018.
We believe Auto will continue to be one of our key growth businesses in the future.
Global Housing is on track for another year of better than market returns, with an annualized operating ROE of nearly 15% for the first nine months of this year.
This includes $113 million of catastrophe losses, demonstrating the superior returns of this differentiated business.
Our counter-cyclical lender-placed insurance business remains an integral part of the U.S. mortgage industry framework.
As we renew existing clients and add new partners in lender-placed insurance, we will continue to enhance the experience through the ongoing rollout of our single-source processing platform.
Our Multifamily Housing business now supports over 2.5 million renters across the U.S. and has more than doubled earnings since 2015 through our strong partnerships with affinity and property management company clients.
Our investments in digital capabilities, such as our Cover 360 property management solution, continue to drive more value for our partners and enhance the customer experience.
We believe our portfolio of high-growth, fee-based, capital-light offerings and high-return Specialty P&C businesses sets us apart as a long-term outperformer and sustained value creator for our shareholders.
I am humbled by our 15,000 employees, whose dedication to serving our clients and 300 million customers worldwide has successfully transformed Assurant.
Together, we have significantly strengthened our Fortune 300 company, which should continue to deliver above-market growth and superior cash flow.
With our President, Keith Demmings, succeeding me as CEO in January, I am confident Assurant will accelerate our strategy and continue to differentiate our superior customer experience, further deepening client relationships.
I have been fortunate to have had a front-row seat and a role in supporting Alan's vision and the transformation of Assurant.
Alan has continued to evolve the purpose of our company to drive value for all stakeholders: customers, employees, communities, and shareholders.
His impact on our people and the overall culture of our company has been exemplary.
I appreciate Alan's personal mentorship and partnership and wish him the best in his retirement.
As we build on Assurant's momentum over the long-term, I believe our talent and innovation will be critical factors in achieving success and growth, especially as we focus more on the convergence around the connected consumer.
Assurant has developed a deep and diverse bench of internal leaders.
I recently announced our refreshed Management Committee effective in January, including two new leadership appointments demonstrating our strong bench.
Keith Meier, our current President of International, will succeed Gene Mergelmeyer as Chief Operating Officer, as Gene will be retiring at year-end.
Gene's significant contributions to Assurant over the last 30+ years, including as COO for the past five years, have been instrumental in creating market-leading positions, producing profitable growth, and transforming the organization.
Keith Meier brings nearly 25 years of experience at Assurant to the COO role.
Since 2016, as President of Assurant International, he has driven growth across our global markets, most recently with strong success in Asia Pacific.
In his new role, Keith will focus on advancing Assurant's business strategy and market leadership positions, as well as identifying additional opportunities to deliver a superior customer experience.
Martin Jenns will become President of Global Automotive.
With over 30 years of experience, he currently leads the transformation and growth strategy for Auto and has been instrumental in introducing innovative new products like EB-1, our electric vehicle warranty protection.
In addition to emerging opportunities and innovation, Martin will focus on driving growth and improving the customer experience, including working with our partners to deliver best-in-class dealer training.
These two new appointments, along with recent appointments of Biju Nair as President of Connected Living and Manny Becerra as our Chief Innovation Officer, as well as the other management committee members, represent a strong team to help lead us into the future.
Innovation, alongside talent, is a crucial asset for the organization's strength.
The company's growth and expansion are facilitated not just by creating new digital products for clients, but also through novel approaches.
This quarter, innovation played a significant role in Connected Living, particularly through ongoing improvements to mobile service delivery options.
As part of a recently extended multi-year agreement with T-Mobile, Assurant is broadening its services to enhance the experience for millions of T-Mobile customers.
Starting November 1st, Assurant is collaborating with T-Mobile to launch nationwide in-store device repair services at about 500 locations, provided by Assurant's certified repair specialists.
We have also moved all former Sprint protection subscribers to the new T-Mobile Device protection plan.
Consequently, our mobile device count has significantly increased, reaching approximately 63 million as of November 1st.
The expansion of our service delivery options is vital for maintaining our competitive edge.
We recently renewed a multi-year contract with Spectrum Mobile, continuing to offer a comprehensive mobile solution and Pocket Geek on-device diagnostic tool.
The renewal also includes expanding the offering to include Pocket Geek privacy, allowing consumers to better safeguard and control their personal information online through various features.
This exemplifies how we can grow by enhancing services and capabilities for existing clients.
Furthermore, the mobile business continues to see high attachment rates due to increased reliance on mobile devices and rising device prices.
Our fee-based trade-in and upgrade business, including the recent acquisitions of Hyla and Alegre, has performed exceptionally well this year as we enter the early stages of the 5G upgrade cycle.
Nearly a year after the Hyla acquisition, I'm pleased to report that it has exceeded expectations, performing better than the low-teens forward EBITDA it was valued on.
With the increasing availability and popularity of 5G-enabled smartphones, we anticipate continued growth in our 30-plus trade-in and upgrade programs.
Our progress is evident in our ability to manage large-scale programs with superior technology.
This is further bolstered by improving our attach rates for trade-in programs as our clients' promotional efforts encourage consumers to upgrade.
Overall, we have processed nearly 18 million devices so far this year, reducing electronic waste and increasing digital access with high-quality, affordable phones.
The scale and capabilities of our trade-in and upgrade programs provide an additional source of profits and improve client economics and customer retention.
This quarter, we are delighted to announce a multi-year contract extension with AT&T to manage their device trade-in program.
This includes providing analytics as well as device collection and processing for all of AT&T's sales channels, including retail, B2B, dealer, and direct-to-consumer.
AT&T was a key client acquired through the Hyla acquisition, and we look forward to continuing our partnership, especially as we support the growing adoption of 5G-enabled devices.
In Global Automotive, policies increased by 4 million or 8% year-over-year, with production well above pre-pandemic levels as we leverage our scale and talent.
So far this year, the business has also benefited from strong used car growth, which tends to generate earnings faster than new car sales.
This, combined with the fact that earnings from the business are recognized over multiple years, provides good visibility into the future performance of the business.
As we drive innovation within Auto, we continued the global rollout of EV-1, an electric vehicle and hybrid protection product, to North America.
EV-1 has now been launched in seven countries.
Although the electric vehicle market is still in its early stages, our EV-1 product will allow Assurant to better assess customer demand and use our insights to position us well for the expected increase in electric vehicle adoption in the future.
Our Multifamily Housing business grew policies by 7% year-over-year, driven by growth in our affinity partners and PMC relationships, where we continue to roll out our innovative Cover 360 product.
Additionally, we have seen other digital investments create opportunities for future growth.
Our newly designed digital sales portal, which simplifies and accelerates the process for residents to sign up for a policy, is driving significantly higher product attachment rates.
Our new portal has seen an increase in conversion rates compared to our legacy website since its introduction last year.
In conclusion, our ability to strengthen insurance talent and innovation, supported by critical investments, has and should continue to drive momentum for the future.
As Alan mentioned, we are pleased with our third quarter performance, which reflects strong growth across Global Lifestyle and solid earnings in Global Housing.
For the quarter, we reported net operating income per share excluding reportable catastrophes of $2.73, a 5% increase from the prior year period.
Excluding catastrophes, net operating income and adjusted EBITDA for the quarter each increased 4% to $162 million and $262 million, respectively.
Let's now discuss segment results, starting with Global Lifestyle.
This segment reported net operating income of $124 million in the third quarter, with continued earnings expansion within Connected Living's mobile business.
In Global Automotive, earnings increased $8 million or 21% due to continued global growth in our U.S. national dealer and third-party administrator channels, including contributions from our AFAS and international OEM channels.
Better loss experience in select ancillary products and higher investment income also contributed to earnings growth in the quarter.
Connected Living earnings increased by $6 million or 9% year-over-year.
The increase was primarily driven by continued mobile subscriber growth in North America and improved performance in Asia Pacific, as well as higher trading volumes, led by contributions from our Hyla acquisition and carrier promotions.
This quarter, Global Automotive and Connected Living results also included a modest one-time tax benefit that improved earnings.
For the quarter, Lifestyle's adjusted EBITDA increased 17% to $177 million.
This reflects the segment's increased amortization resulting from higher deal-related intangibles from more recent transactions in mobile and Global Automotive.
IT depreciation expense also increased, stemming from higher investments.
Regarding revenues, Lifestyle revenues increased by $158 million or 9%.
This was primarily driven by continued growth in Connected Living and Global Automotive.
Within Connected Living, revenue increased 10%, boosted by mobile fee income driven by strong trade-in volumes, including contributions from Hyla.
Trade-in volumes were supported by new phone introductions and carrier promotions related to the introduction of new 5G devices.
Higher revenue from growth in domestic mobile subscribers was offset by declines in run-off mobile programs.
The number of mobile subscribers increased slightly compared to the previous year but remained stable year-to-date, as moderate growth in North America was counterbalanced by declines elsewhere due to three main reasons.
The first factor was the loss of 750,000 subscribers from a discontinued European banking program, which is not expected to significantly impact profitability.
Secondly, existing programs in Asia Pacific experienced slower subscriber growth.
Thirdly, Latin America's recovery from the pandemic has been slower than anticipated.
In the Global Automotive sector, revenue grew by 8%, reflecting robust sales of vehicle service contracts in previous periods.
The automotive industry maintained high sales levels in the third quarter, benefiting our business as evidenced by a 12% increase in our net written premium compared to last year.
However, we have observed this trend beginning to normalize as we enter the fourth quarter.
For the entire year, Lifestyle revenues are projected to show modest growth compared to last year's $7.3 billion, primarily driven by expansion in Global Auto and Connected Living.
We continue to anticipate Global Lifestyle's net operating income for 2021 to grow by high single digits compared to 2020.
The segment's adjusted EBITDA is expected to increase by double digits year-over-year, outpacing the growth of segment net operating income.
As previously disclosed, we initiated our investment in [Technical Issues] capability this quarter.
Nevertheless, due to the timing of the implementation, the majority of the associated start-up costs will be incurred in the third quarter.
These expenses are primarily related to hiring technicians and sourcing parts.
We anticipate these costs will have a significant impact on Connected Living's profitability as we conclude the year.
Furthermore, we expect our effective tax rate to return to a more typical level of approximately 23%.
Looking forward to 2022, we anticipate continued earnings growth, albeit at a more moderate pace as we continue to invest in expansion, including additional implementation and start-up costs for in-store service and repair.
In the Global Housing segment, net operating income excluding catastrophe losses was $81 million for the third quarter, while including the $78 million of pre-announced catastrophe losses mainly from Hurricane Ida, net operating income totaled $3 million.
Excluding catastrophe losses, earnings decreased by $19 million due to expected higher non-catastrophe losses, which returned to levels more consistent with historical averages.
It's important to note that the favorable non-catastrophe losses in 2020 were not representative of historical trends, and the third quarter of 2020 marked the lowest point of that year, primarily driven by loss experience within lender-placed and specialty products.
The year-over-year earnings decline was almost entirely due to unfavorable non-catastrophe loss experience resulting from several factors.
The primary driver, accounting for nearly half of the increase, was the anticipated normalization of the non-catastrophe loss ratio.
The remainder of the decline was evenly split between increased reserves related to our Specialty P&C offerings, mainly in our on-demand sharing economy business, and higher claims severity.
Claims severity included moderate impacts from inflationary factors such as increased labor and material costs.
While there is typically a delay, if this trend persists, we expect higher loss costs to be offset by increased rates over time.
In Multifamily Housing, underlying growth was counterbalanced by increased investments to enhance our customer experience, including our digital-first capability.
Global Housing revenue decreased slightly year-over-year due to lower Specialty P&C revenues, a catastrophe reinstatement premium resulting from Hurricane Ida, and lower REO volumes in lender-placed insurance.
This decline was partially offset by higher average insured values and premium rates in lender-placed insurance, as well as growth in Multifamily Housing.
We maintain our expectation that Global Housing's net operating income, excluding catastrophes, will remain flat for the full year compared to 2020.
For the fourth quarter and into 2022, we anticipate non-catastrophe losses to continue exceeding 2020 levels but aligning with year-to-date 2021 experience, which is consistent with long-term trends.
We continue to monitor REO foreclosure moratoriums and any potential additional extensions that may be announced.
At the Corporate level, the net operating loss was $21 million, an improvement of $4 million compared to the third quarter of 2020.
This improvement was driven by two factors.
First, there were lower employee-related expenses and third-party fees.
Second, we realized expense savings associated with reducing our real estate footprint.
In the fourth quarter, we anticipate a higher loss due to the timing of expenditures.
For the full year 2021, we now project the Corporate net operating loss to be approximately $80 million, driven by favorable year-to-date results, mainly from one-time tax and real estate joint venture benefits in the second quarter.
This is an improvement from our previous estimate of $85 million.
Looking ahead to 2022, we expect our net operating loss in Corporate to be closer to $90 million, more in line with historical trends.
Regarding holding company liquidity, including the net proceeds from the sale of Preneed in August, we concluded the third quarter with over $1.3 billion, significantly above our current minimum target level.
In the third quarter, dividends from operating segments totaled $127 million.
In addition to our regular corporate and interest expenses, we had outflows from three main items: $323 million in share repurchases, $39 million in common stock dividends, and $11 million primarily related to Assurant Ventures investments.
We have not only completed our 2019 Investor Day objective of returning $1.35 billion to shareholders from 2019 through 2021 but have also completed approximately one-quarter of our goal to return $900 million in Global Preneed sale proceeds through share repurchases.
For the year overall, we continue to expect dividends to approximate segment earnings, subject to business growth, rating agency and regulatory capital requirements, and investment portfolio performance.
I'd like to provide a brief update on Assurant Ventures, our venture capital arm.
In the third quarter, three investments in our portfolio went public via SPACs.
We are pleased with the results, as the three investments exceeded a 7 times multiple on investment capital under their respective SPAC transaction terms.
These transactions, combined with strong performance in the broader ventures portfolio, resulted in a $75 million after-tax gain flowing through net income in the quarter.
Beyond strong returns, these investments also provide valuable insights into emerging technologies and capabilities within our Connected Consumer businesses.
In addition to positioning Assurant for long-term success and growth, he has fostered an environment of inclusion and community, truly representative of our core values of common sense and common decency.
Alan, we wish you all the best in your well-deserved retirement.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I would like to provide some high-level observations about our company's performance over the past year.
We began 2020 with strong momentum, achieving 5.6% organic growth in Q1, but the COVID-19 pandemic then significantly impacted the US economy.
Despite uncertainty, we were confident in our team's resilience and ability to innovate solutions for our customers.
We successfully transitioned over 10,000 employees to remote work within a week, allowing them to continue serving clients effectively.
Our growth slowed in Q2 due to pandemic effects on new business and revenue adjustments for liability policies, though margins still expanded.
We delivered excellent results in Q3 with robust organic growth and margin improvements.
Q4 performance was similar to Q3, ending the year on a strong note with good momentum for 2021.
Given the circumstances in April, I would have considered it unlikely but possible that we'd achieve full-year organic growth and significant margin expansion.
We are very satisfied with our 2020 results.
Our employees' hard work and customer dedication enabled us to achieve these outcomes.
2020 demonstrated our commitment to providing innovative risk solutions.
We anticipated M&A activity would decrease for several quarters until economic stability returned.
The slowdown lasted only about one quarter, with industry-wide activity now back to pre-pandemic levels.
Despite uncertainty, we completed 25 acquisitions totaling $197 million in annual acquired revenue.
I'd like to highlight two key acquisitions: CoverHound in Q4 and O'Leary Insurances announced in Q4 and finalized on January 14th.
The CoverHound acquisition will benefit us in several ways.
It will enhance our technology investments, drive innovation, and improve carrier connectivity.
It will allow us to more efficiently provide quotes and coverage for our National Programs segment.
It will help us better serve smaller retail segment customers.
These improvements aim to enhance customer experience by offering tailored quotes that best meet their needs.
We believe these new capabilities are unmatched in the market.
We began 2020 by acquiring Special Risk in British Columbia and concluded with O'Leary Insurances in Ireland.
O'Leary was Ireland's largest independently-owned retail broker.
This acquisition bolsters our European operations, which we plan to expand in coming years.
Our new team members and capabilities will create many future opportunities.
We're very proud of our 2020 results and delivering over 20% total shareholder returns.
Steve Boyd will become our Wholesale President.
Steve's experience in National Programs operations and technology brings valuable skills to the Wholesale leadership as we continue growing through innovative solutions.
I'm eager for Tony and Steve to collaborate on driving future growth.
Let's now review our quarterly and annual results.
Referring to Slide 3, we achieved strong results this quarter with total revenue of $642 million, growing 10.9% overall and 4.7% organically.
I'll provide more details on segment performance shortly.
Our EBITDAC margin was 27.1%, up 10 basis points from Q4 2019.
Note that Q4 2019 included a business sale gain that improved the prior year margin by about 100 basis points.
Q4 net income per share was $0.34, a 25% increase as reported.
Adjusted net income per share, excluding changes in estimated acquisition earn-out payables, was $0.32, up 14.3% year-over-year.
Our team excellently managed profitable revenue growth and expenses in response to COVID-19 challenges.
We completed nine more acquisitions this quarter with approximately $80 million in annual revenues.
For the full year, total revenues grew 9.2% with 3.8% organic growth.
This is an exceptional performance given the economic challenges throughout most of the year.
We improved our EBITDAC margin by 110 basis points to 31.1% compared to 2019, leveraging organic revenue growth and managing expenses during the pandemic.
Full-year 2020 net income per share increased 20.7% to $1.69 from $1.40 in 2019.
Adjusted net income per share, excluding acquisition earn-out changes, rose 19.3%.
Lastly, we had another strong M&A year, closing 25 acquisitions with about $197 million in annual revenue, adding many excellent businesses and team members.
Moving to Slide 5, we've previously discussed factors affecting economic recovery, including elections, vaccine approval and distribution, and additional stimulus measures.
Vaccine rollout timing and further stimulus approval will most impact economic recovery and influence business leaders' confidence in rehiring and investment.
In Q4, we continued to see some companies thriving while others struggled significantly.
We've observed improving new business, and our retention remains good.
However, we anticipate a choppy recovery through at least late 2021, possibly into early 2022.
Regarding rates, Q4 was very similar to Q3, with most standard rates up 3-7% and E&S rates up 10-25% year-over-year.
As mentioned before, loss experience remains the primary driver of rate increases.
Commercial auto rates are still up 10% or more, while workers' compensation rates are declining less rapidly than before but remain negative.
There's been considerable discussion about workers' compensation rates turning positive in recent quarters.
Nevertheless, we haven't observed this trend universally yet.
From an E&S standpoint, coastal properties, including both wind and earthquake coverage, have seen increases of 15% to 25%.
Professional liability coverage has generally risen by 10% to 25%, varying based on the specific industry and coverage type.
We still notice exceptions to the desired coverage.
Personal insurance in California, Florida, and Gulf Coast states remains under significant pressure as insurers aim to reduce their exposure due to fires and tropical events in 2020.
We anticipate the decrease in personal lines capacity will persist throughout 2021.
Securing coverage for many lines, certain industries, or clients with substantial losses continues to be difficult.
This includes excess or umbrella coverage, where insurers may seek a combination of lower limits and higher premium rates.
We don't foresee this trend changing significantly in 2021.
Let's examine the performance of our four segments.
Our Retail segment experienced organic revenue growth of 1.5% in the fourth quarter.
As mentioned in our third quarter earnings call, timing factors benefited growth by about 100 basis points in the third quarter but negatively affected growth in the fourth quarter.
Our fourth quarter results were driven by new business, improved customer retention, and premium rate increases, but were impacted by reduced exposure units due to the pandemic.
We consider the fourth quarter performance good, given our 7% organic growth in the same quarter last year and considering the timing headwind mentioned earlier.
Full-year organic revenue growth was 2.4%, which we view as a good result given the challenging economic environment.
Our National Programs segment achieved 14.1% organic growth, delivering another exceptional quarter.
Our growth was fueled by strong new business, retention, and rate increases.
Some top-performing programs included lender-placed insurance, commercial and residential earthquake, wind, and personal property coverage.
For the full year, our National Programs segment achieved impressive organic growth of 12.3%.
Our Wholesale Brokerage segment saw 5.8% organic growth for the quarter.
We experienced strong new business and continued rate increases across most coverage lines.
Brokerage was again the fastest-growing area, while our binding authority and personal lines businesses faced ongoing challenges due to economic conditions and carrier appetites mentioned earlier.
For the full year, our Wholesale Brokerage segment achieved 5.5% organic growth, marking another successful year.
Organic revenue for our Services segment decreased by 50 basis points in the fourth quarter, showing significant improvement from recent quarters.
The main factors suppressing growth continue to be lower claims volume in our Social Security and Medicare Set-aside advocacy businesses.
This decline was largely offset by revenue generated from processing claims related to weather events in the third and fourth quarters.
For the full year, organic revenue decreased by 10.9%, primarily due to fewer claims in our Social Security Advocacy business, certain terminated customer contracts, and the pandemic's impact.
While not yet positive, we believe the fourth quarter marked a turning point, and we expect modest organic growth in 2021.
Our profit margin before taxes expanded by 1.3 percentage points and increased more rapidly than EBITDAC, primarily due to adjustments in projected acquisition payouts.
Let's proceed to Slide 11.
The National Programs division boosted overall revenue by $25.3 million or 18.9%, with organic revenue growth of 14.1%.
The rise in total revenue was attributed to recent acquisitions and robust organic growth across numerous programs.
The 19% growth rate aligned with the increase in total revenue.
The benefits of strong organic revenue growth and efficient variable cost management were counterbalanced by higher internal IT charges and reduced contingent commissions.
Pre-tax income rose by $20.3 million or 54%, outpacing EBITDAC growth due to decreased acquisition earn-out liabilities, partially offset by increased internal interest expenses.
Moving to Slide 12.
The Wholesale Brokerage division achieved total revenue growth of 19.2% and organic revenue growth of 5.8%.
Total revenue increased faster than organic revenue due to recent acquisitions, while contingent commissions remained largely unchanged year-over-year.
EBITDAC grew by 17.1% with a slight margin decrease of 0.4 percentage points compared to the previous year, despite good organic growth and reduced variable expenses in response to COVID-19.
These gains were more than offset by changes in foreign exchange rates and, to a lesser extent, higher internal IT charges.
Our pre-tax income increased by 6.2%, which was lower than total revenue growth, mainly due to higher internal interest expenses.
Proceeding to Slide 13.
Both total and organic revenues for the Services segment declined by approximately 0.5%, driven by the factors Powell mentioned earlier.
Quarterly EBITDAC rose by 9.7% due to increased weather-related claims, partially offset by higher internal IT expenses.
Pre-tax income decreased by 23.6% due to a $2.5 million credit in the fourth quarter of 2019 for changes in estimated acquisition earn-out payables that did not recur in 2020.
Moving on to Slide 14.
This slide presents our GAAP results for the full years of 2020 and 2019.
In 2020, we generated revenues of $2.6 billion, a 9.2% increase, and earnings per share of $1.69, a 20.7% increase.
Our EBITDAC grew by 13.5% and our EBITDAC margin expanded by 1.1 percentage points.
For the year, our share count increased slightly compared to the previous year, and our dividends paid in 2020 rose by 7.1% compared to 2019.
Proceeding to Slide 15.
This slide shows our results excluding changes in estimated acquisition earn-out payables for both years.
For the full year 2020, on an adjusted basis, our pre-tax income grew by 18.1%, outpacing EBITDAC growth due to lower interest expenses, and our adjusted net income per share increased by 19.3%.
In addition to strong income performance metrics, we also had another robust year for cash conversion due to the strength of our operating model and the diversity of our businesses.
We generated $721.6 million in operating cash flow, representing a continued strong conversion rate of 27.6% of revenue.
We concluded the year with a strong liquidity position, holding $817 million in cash and cash equivalents, as well as $800 million in accessible capital on our credit facility.
With this capital and the cash we expect to generate in 2021, we are well-positioned to fund continued investment in our company.
We have a few additional comments regarding our outlook for 2021.
During the third quarter, we were asked about potential margins for 2021 in relation to the COVID-19 savings we experienced in 2020.
Now, with the year completed and improved visibility into 2021, we anticipate EBITDAC margins could remain stable or increase slightly, considering our variable costs will likely rise as we resume travel and face-to-face customer interactions.
As in the past, our leaders will focus on growing profitability.
Regarding contingent commissions, we expect them to remain relatively flat or decrease slightly in 2021.
For taxes, we project our effective tax rate for 2021 to be between 23% and 24%.
This estimate does not account for potential changes in federal tax rates being discussed by the new administration.
We anticipate interest expenses to increase by $7 million to $9 million compared to 2020, driven by the new bonds issued in September 2020.
Regarding capital expenditures, we expect a decrease in 2021 to approximately $40 million to $45 million, as we have largely completed the development of our new Daytona Beach campus.
In my opening remarks, I mentioned there are still some unresolved issues for the coming quarters.
We will closely monitor the successful vaccine rollout and additional stimulus measures to assist those in need.
Both factors will influence the pace of economic recovery in the coming quarters.
Regarding insurance rates, we expect increases in the first half of 2021 to be similar to those seen in 2020.
Ultimately, the rate of increases will be driven by losses sustained in 2020 from the record-setting number of tropical storms and millions of acres burned.
The question remains how long and at what pace rates need to increase to achieve targeted returns.
We believe the market is approaching an inflection point for certain lines over the coming year, which will lead to some rate moderation.
The pace of acquisitions appears to be as active as ever, with competition between private equity and long-term strategic buyers remaining strong.
We expect aggressive pricing for deals by private equity firms to continue in the near future.
However, we are well-positioned with our low leverage, capital on our balance sheet, and access to additional funding to support our M&A activities.
Our pipeline remains strong, and we will maintain our disciplined approach to M&A, which has proven highly successful.
However, as you know, we don't count on anything until it's finalized.
Lastly, technological innovation continues to be at the forefront of creating new products and enhancing customer experiences.
We will continue to digitize our data, automate processes, and prioritize technology investments in the following areas: optimizing and enhancing our data and analytics programs; expanding our digital delivery capabilities for products and services; and engaging in initiatives designed to improve efficiency and speed in our underlying processes.
As we achieve these goals, we anticipate new growth opportunities that will allow us to better serve our customers.
We had an excellent 2020 on many fronts and have strong momentum heading into 2021.
I am extremely proud of how our team has served our customers through extremely challenging times.
We have a great team and a highly diversified business, both of which have performed well in the past and are expected to continue doing so in the future.
Ultimately, our financial performance is only possible through the combined efforts of our nearly 11,000 team members and our commitment to serving our customers.
Summary:

qtrly adjusted earnings per share $0.32.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations may be revised based on new information or future occurrences.
Assured Guaranty has reached a significant milestone, with its adjusted book value exceeding $100 per share for the first time, alongside record-breaking shareholders' equity per share and adjusted operating shareholders' equity per share.
We accomplished this while also achieving our highest direct new business insurance production for a second quarter since acquiring AGM in July 2009.
Our financial guaranty PVP of $96 million was 71% greater than the same quarter last year.
Our achievement is a result of years of preparation for unforeseen circumstances.
Our team performed exceptionally well, working entirely remotely under unprecedented economic and market conditions.
We had the necessary technology, procedures, and training in place to thrive during this pandemic, demonstrating not only our employees' competence and dedication but also the resilience of our business model and the advantages of our value proposition.
The virus created market and economic uncertainty, causing bond yields to increase and credit spreads to widen at the beginning of the quarter.
Investors became more focused on credit quality, for which our financial guaranty insurance provides a solution, as well as ratings stability, trading value consistency, and market liquidity, all of which our product tends to enhance.
This resulted in increased demand for bond insurance.
Consequently, we experienced the strongest second quarter and first half direct U.S. public finance production in over ten years, generating direct PVP of $60 million and $89 million, respectively.
I can confirm that the surge in demand for our guaranty has continued, with our July municipal insured par volume surpassing $2 billion.
At the industry level, more than $9.1 billion of U.S. public finance primary market par was sold with bond insurance in the second quarter, the highest for any quarter since mid-2009, and industry insurance penetration reached 8.7% of total new issue par sold, the highest quarterly level since 2009.
The six-month industry insured volume is 43% higher than in the first half of 2019.
In this improved municipal bond insurance market, Assured Guaranty was chosen to insure 63% of the insured new issue par sold in the second quarter.
Compared to the second quarter of last year, Assured Guaranty's primary market production increased by 58% to $5.8 billion in insured par sold and by 22% to 318 new issue transactions.
The increased par volume was partially driven by large transactions, but we remain the preferred insurer.
We insured substantial tax-exempt and taxable deals across various sectors and underlying rating categories, including A-rated healthcare issues and AA-rated general obligations.
We guaranteed 11 transactions exceeding $100 million in insured par during the quarter, with the largest being a $385 million school district transaction with the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York, rated Aa3 by Moody's and AA- by Fitch.
The high value investors place on our guaranty was evident among credits with underlying S&P or Moody's ratings in the AA category, where we insured over $1 billion of primary market par in the second quarter.
We are also observing increased demand for our secondary market insurance.
In the second quarter, we insured $533 million of secondary market par, compared to $233 million in the first quarter and $327 million in the second quarter of 2019.
In total for the primary and secondary markets, Assured Guaranty provided insurance on $6.3 billion of municipal bonds, 58% more than in the second quarter of last year.
Although municipal yields had approached the historic lows seen in March by quarter-end, credit spreads generally remained wider than pre-pandemic levels, which is one reason, along with very strong issuance volume, for our successful performance.
We also had an excellent second quarter in our international infrastructure business, generating $28 million of direct PVP, more than triple last year's second quarter PVP and the second-highest quarterly direct PVP in the sector since before the Great Recession.
Notable transactions included our third solar bond wrap in Spain, modifying terms of an existing investment-grade insured transaction to provide additional flexibility to the issuer, and a secondary market guarantee to a European financial institution for a public sector credit.
The impact of COVID-19 has been mixed for the international business.
On one hand, fewer transactions are coming to market, especially in transport and social infrastructure.
Some transactions in our pipeline have been delayed, though none have been canceled.
On the other hand, credit spreads widened significantly and have not fully returned to previous tighter levels, which increases the value of our guarantees.
Additionally, we continue to see an increased variety of incoming new transaction inquiries, some of which are directly related to COVID-related investor concerns.
Our global structured finance business also performed well in the second quarter, contributing $8 million of PVP from various transactions, including an insurance securitization and two whole business securitizations.
The pandemic has slowed both asset-backed issuance and progress in some of our transactions under development, but it has also widened credit spreads and created new opportunities.
We are seeing an increased number of investor-led opportunities related to portfolios of corporate credit exposure.
In our last call, I explained in detail how our insured portfolio is well-positioned to weather this economic disruption.
We have continued our due diligence and reached out to almost all the obligors we identified in the vulnerable section to learn how they plan to manage their resources.
Based on our research and the additional information provided by obligors, we continue to expect no material pandemic-related liquidity claims.
To date, we have not received any financial guarantee claims that we attribute to the COVID-19 pandemic.
For below investment grade insured obligations, which we have identified as already under stress, we have updated assumptions to account for the added stress of the pandemic.
We continue to believe that for the remainder of the portfolio, which is 96% of par exposure that is investment grade, there should be no material losses caused by the pandemic.
In any case, as I mentioned before, we have demonstrated the resilience of our business model.
For example, from 2008 through the second quarter of 2020, we paid $11 billion in gross claims, $5 billion net, and returned more than $4.3 billion to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
Yet our claim-paying resources were virtually the same at the end of the period compared to the beginning.
Meanwhile, we have significantly reduced our total par exposure and cut our insured leverage by more than half, measured by various ratios.
We are in a better position today than before the Great Recession.
I encourage you to review two reports S&P published since the pandemic began.
I mentioned one in our last call, S&P's April 3rd report on the bond insurance industry.
The second was S&P's annual review of Assured Guaranty, released on July 16th.
The common theme of these reports was that, despite the current macroeconomic environment.
S&P considers the risk profile to be minimal for both the bond insurance industry and Assured Guaranty specifically, which is a highly favorable assessment
S&P reaffirmed the AA ratings with a stable outlook for all of our insurance divisions in June
In the subsequent annual review, S&P reiterated that our robust capital position, exceptional liquidity, and proven business model support our financial strength rating
S&P also noted the growing demand for Assured Guaranty's products since the COVID-19 outbreak began
They stated that investors' preference for quality and wider credit spreads should continue to provide us with opportunities for primary and secondary market underwriting
S&P attributed the strong secondary market demand we've experienced in U.S. public finance to institutional investors finding bond insurance economically appealing as a risk mitigation tool
In the same report, S&P mentioned running a COVID-19 sensitivity stress test, concluding that even under increased loss assumptions, our capital adequacy assessment would remain excellent, and described our financial risk profile as very strong, noting that our insured exposures outperform relative to the market segments we underwrite during periods of economic stress due to our underwriting and risk management guidelines
S&P does not release a figure for our excess capital under their AAA depression stress model
We estimate having $2.6 billion in capital exceeding S&P's AAA requirement as of the end of 2019, accounting for our capital management program, BlueMountain acquisition, elimination of an excess of loss credit facility, and continued payment of Puerto Rico debt service claims
Another report I read was issued by Kroll Bond Rating Agency on July 30th
They provided an in-depth analysis of the recent increase in activity and demand for bond insurance
KBRA also made a positive observation in the report, stating their belief that the pandemic should remain largely a liquidity event for bond insurers, with Puerto Rico being the exception
Regarding Puerto Rico, we continue to seek a consensual resolution while defending our rights in the Title III bankruptcies
COVID-19 and the upcoming gubernatorial election may be slightly slowing progress
Recently, PREPA hired a private U.S.-Canadian consortium to manage its electricity transmission and distribution system
This appears to be a positive step, but the crucial action to restore and improve the power system is to finalize the restructuring support agreement that all relevant parties have agreed to
We concur with the Oversight Board's statement that PREPA will not have effective access to capital markets to fund critical grid modernization and improvement plans as long as it remains in Title III
The Title III Court denied our request to lift the stay on asserting our property rights regarding Highways and Transportation Authority Revenue bonds
We plan to appeal this decision
At least two Oversight Board members have announced their imminent resignations, and all members are subject to replacement or renomination
We hope congressional leadership and the President select Board members who are more familiar with municipal government and finance
Supply chain management has become a major issue in Congress, creating an opportunity for legislation that could allow the country to fully utilize Puerto Rico's extensive history and well-established capabilities in producing pharmaceuticals, medical supplies, and medical devices
This could address the current public health crisis, enhance national security and preparedness, and simultaneously revitalize a key part of the island's manufacturing sector, stimulating its economic recovery
Assured Investment Management, our asset management division, benefited from a strong rally in credit markets during the second quarter and profitably sold CLO debt tranches
As CLO issuance gained momentum, we purchased newly issued investment-grade CLOs, and in June, Assured Investment Management priced its first CLO issuance since the market disruption
While the current market environment has delayed the realization of this business line's potential in the short term, we remain confident in its diversification strategy
We announced an important leadership change in our Asset Management business yesterday
Andrew Feldstein, Chief Investment Officer and Head of Asset Management, has decided to leave the company
David Buzen, BlueMountain's Deputy Chief Investment Officer, will take over Andrew's responsibilities as CEO and CIO of BlueMountain and Head of Asset Management and CIO at Assured Guaranty
Andrew will continue to serve on the boards of BlueMountain funds and support a smooth transition
He will remain with the company as Senior Advisor to David through the end of October 2020
We are confident in the long-term prospects of our Asset Management business under David Buzen's leadership and the talented senior management team
I want to emphasize that this leadership transition does not indicate any change in Assured Guaranty's strategy regarding Assured Investment Management
We continue to support the business's growth and have allocated $1 billion of our investment portfolio to investments it manages, aiming to generate even greater value for our investors and policyholders
I look forward to seeing our Asset Management business make a significant contribution to Assured Guaranty's value, and I am certain Dave is the right person to lead this effort
He was the lead executive in our acquisition of BlueMountain and has been involved in every aspect of our Asset Management strategy and operations
David is a consummate financial professional who has served in top executive roles at several financial companies
We have worked with David for a long time, and his over 30 years of experience includes senior positions at ACE Financial Solutions, which acquired Capital Re when David was its CFO, a company now known as Assured Guaranty Corp
We are in the midst of an unprecedented year, where a previously unknown disease has affected millions of people, caused hundreds of thousands of deaths, and disrupted economies worldwide
Congress, the administration, and the Fed have taken action to provide financial support to people in need, inject monetary liquidity to help businesses survive, and support capital markets
State and local governments are addressing the challenges of providing essential services, administering social programs, and meeting financial obligations amid sharp revenue reductions
They deserve additional direct federal assistance to prevent large-scale layoffs of government employees and a potential cascade of economic hardships
We have been impressed by the determination of our insured issuers and public officials to maintain essential services while recognizing the imperative to meet debt obligations and preserve their access to capital markets
As a company, Assured Guaranty is better positioned than most to thrive in this environment
By definition, our main product is designed to instill confidence in investors when the future is uncertain
Credit-conscious investors have driven increased demand for our guaranty, providing issuers a way to reduce financing costs when they most need to do so
We have abundant capital and liquidity, supporting a 96% investment-grade insured portfolio consisting of transactions carefully selected to perform better under economic stress than others in their respective sectors
Our capacity as a guarantor enables us to assist issuers experiencing temporary cash flow issues or seeking reasonable modifications, helping them through severe financial difficulties while maintaining productivity and ensuring employee and client safety.
I'm delighted with our quarterly performance and progress on our strategic initiatives.
Our business model demonstrated resilience amid ongoing market volatility, and we achieved substantial advancements in all three areas of our strategic focus.
In the Insurance division, we saw robust new business growth, which is replenishing our unearned premium reserve and balancing out the scheduled amortization of existing business.
The Asset Management division introduced a new liquid asset strategy and resumed CLO issuance near the end of the second quarter.
We're ahead of schedule in our capital management plan regarding share repurchases, which helped boost our adjusted book value per share to a record high exceeding $100.
Second quarter 2020 adjusted operating income was robust at $190 million or $1.36 per share.
This includes $154 million from Insurance, a $9 million loss from Asset Management, and a $26 million loss from Corporate, which accounts for holding company interest and other corporate expenses.
Insurance segment adjusted operating income was $154 million, compared to $161 million in the same quarter last year.
Net earned premiums and credit derivative revenues in Q2 2020 were $125 million, slightly down from $127 million in Q2 2019.
Structured finance net earned premiums and credit-driven revenues decreased to $13 million due to portfolio decline.
Public finance net earned premiums increased in Q2 2020 compared to Q2 2019, driven by higher accelerations and a slight rise in scheduled net earned premiums from increased premium writings in recent quarters.
Total accelerations from refundings and terminations were $32 million in Q2 2020, up from $29 million in Q2 2019.
The reassumption of a previously ceded book of business from our largest reinsurer also contributed to our growing unearned premiums reserve.
This reassumption resulted in a $38 million commutation gain.
Insurance segment net investment income was $82 million in Q2 2020, down from $110 million in Q2 2019.
The decrease mainly stemmed from a significant non-recurring benefit in 2019 from the favorable settlement of a troubled insurance transaction, which reduced the loss mitigation portfolio size.
Settlement proceeds were reinvested in lower-yielding assets.
The externally managed portfolio's average balance also declined, partly due to a shift into alternative investments, including Assured Investment Management funds, which are recorded at fair value in a separate line item rather than net investment income.
Q2 2020 Insurance segment adjusted operating income includes a $21 million after-tax mark-to-market gain on investments in Assured Investment Management funds.
These investments are marked-to-market each reporting period, with fair value changes recorded as part of adjusted operating income under equity in earnings of investees.
The Q2 2020 fair value gains on Assured Investment Management fund investments were driven by the overall market recovery.
As of June 30, 2020, insurance companies were authorized to invest up to $500 million in Assured Investment Management-managed funds, with $354 million invested by that date.
We anticipate future adjusted operating income will be more volatile as we shift investments from fixed income securities.
Our long-term outlook on enhanced returns from Assured Investment Management funds remains positive.
Insurance segment loss expense was $39 million in Q2 2020, primarily related to economic loss development on certain Puerto Rico exposures.
In Q2 2019, we recorded a $50 million benefit, mainly due to higher projected recoveries for previously charged-off loans for second lien U.S. RMBS.
Increased excess spread, improved performance, and loss mitigation efforts partially offset economic loss development on certain Puerto Rico exposures.
Q2 2020 net economic development was $34 million, primarily consisting of $30 million loss development in the U.S. public finance sector, mainly attributable to Puerto Rico exposures.
U.S. RMBS net economic loss development of $1 million mainly comprised increased delinquencies, offset by higher projected excess spread across both third and second lien transactions.
The Asset Management segment reported an adjusted operating loss of $9 million.
We had previously announced our strategy to shift the investment focus and business model of our Assured Investment Management platform to core strategies, including the orderly wind-down of certain hedge funds and legacy opportunity funds.
Before the current market disruptions, we had made significant progress in winding down legacy funds, with $541 million in outflows during Q2.
We expect restructuring to continue throughout 2020, but the pandemic's duration and market impact may extend the execution timeline.
We launched a new liquid asset strategy focused on municipal securities investments near the end of Q2 2020.
Additionally, in Q2 2020, AGM, AGC, and MAC entered into investment management agreements with Assured Investment Management to oversee a portfolio of their general account municipal obligations and CLOs.
As of June 30, 2020, insurance subsidiaries have allocated $250 million to municipal obligation strategies and $100 million to CLO strategies, with authorization for an additional $200 million in CLO strategies.
We believe the pandemic's effect on market conditions and increased volatility may present attractive opportunities for the alternative asset management industry that Assured Investment Management could capitalize on.
Our long-term outlook for the asset management platform remains positive.
In the Corporate division, holding companies currently have approximately $70 million in cash and investments available for liquidity needs and capital management activities, with $80 million in AGL.
The Corporate division's adjusted operating loss was $26 million in both Q2 2020 and Q2 2019.
This mainly comprises interest expense on U.S. holding companies' public long-term debt and intercompany loans to insurance companies, primarily used to fund the BlueMountain acquisition.
It also includes Board of Directors and other corporate expenses.
On a consolidated basis, the effective tax rate may vary between periods based on the proportion of income in different tax jurisdictions.
In Q2 2020, the effective tax rate was 14.2%, compared to 21% in Q2 2019.
Regarding our capital management strategy, we repurchased 6 million shares for $164 million in Q2 2020, at an average price of $27.49 per share.
Since the quarter's end, we've purchased an additional 800,000 shares for $90 million, bringing our year-to-date repurchases to over 10 million shares.
Since January 2013, our successful capital management program has returned $3.5 billion to shareholders, resulting in a 60% reduction in total shares outstanding.
Future share repurchases depend on available free cash, our capital position, and market conditions.
These repurchases have benefited adjusted operating shareholders' equity by approximately $23.56 per share and adjusted book value per share by about $42.76.
This has driven these important metrics to new record highs of $71.34 in adjusted operating shareholders' equity per share and $104.63 in adjusted book value per share.
Summary:

compname reports q2 adjusted operating earnings per share of $1.36.
q2 adjusted operating earnings per share $1.36.
