input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Joining me on the call are our CEO Dr. Jeffrey Graves, CFO Jagtar Narula, and Chief Legal Officer Andrew Johnson.
Outcomes may vary significantly from expectations.
This time last year, we were just starting to see signs of what we hoped would be a lasting recovery from the worst of the COVID pandemic.
Simultaneously, 3D Systems was in the process of implementing our four-stage transformation plan.
We divided our company into two divisions: Healthcare and Industrial Solutions.
We have streamlined our organization to improve efficiency.
We had also begun divesting non-essential assets.
As we speak to you today, one year later, these initial three phases have been completed.
We are now a company exclusively focused on additive manufacturing, with a streamlined operating structure, global presence, and an unmatched range of metal, polymer, and biological technologies in the industry.
These characteristics, combined with an intense focus on our customers' most challenging applications, have proven to be a powerful driver of value creation, as evidenced by our organic growth rates, profitability, and operating cash performance, all of which we will summarize for you shortly.
While we're satisfied with this performance, we're even more excited about entering the fourth and final stage of our transformation: investing for growth.
Since our last update, we've completed our final divestments, paid off our debt, and accumulated over $500 million in cash reserves.
We subsequently announced two acquisitions that exemplify our strategic focus on growth, which aims to invest in businesses that promote the adoption of additive manufacturing, address customers' most complex application needs, and generate high-margin recurring revenue streams crucial for sustained value creation.
The first of these acquisitions was Oqton, a unique software company that has emerged as a recognized leader in developing a new type of intelligent, cloud-based manufacturing operating system.
The motivation for this acquisition is straightforward; customers across our Industrial and Healthcare segments are now eager to accelerate their adoption of additive manufacturing in full-scale production environments.
However, in doing so, they face significant challenges in integrating these technologies into their existing enterprise systems.
Until now, they have relied heavily on spreadsheets and highly skilled engineers to manage production applications.
This approach is clearly too slow, inefficient, and expensive to scale as production volumes increase.
While we and others have made progress in optimizing and somewhat automating the performance of single printers or even groups of similar printers working in parallel, our customers' challenges extend beyond this.
They require a manufacturing system that can easily and intelligently incorporate a diverse fleet of printers, often from various manufacturers, as well as integrate all surrounding digital production systems on the shop floor, such as post-print thermal and mechanical processing, robotic motion systems, and automated inspection systems.
Oqton not only provides this integration but goes further by applying cloud-based AI to optimize the entire workflow and then connects this workflow to customers' existing enterprise software like those provided by Salesforce, Oracle, Microsoft, or SAP.
The result is that Oqton not only links, optimizes, and tracks the customers' unique operational workflow at an individual component level from raw material to finished and inspected parts, but also builds in future flexibility to incorporate new printing, finishing, and automation technologies that will inevitably be introduced in the coming years.
These features, unique to the Oqton platform, will remove a significant barrier to the large-scale adoption of additive manufacturing in production environments.
For this reason, we've opened the system to the entire industry, which we hope will accelerate market growth for everyone.
Additionally, for the first time in our history, we will now make our full range of market-leading metal and polymer printing software platforms available to others in the industry, which we hope will speed up the introduction of new printing technologies to customers worldwide.
Importantly, as with all software platforms that span an entire industry, we are committed to Oqton continuing to operate independently, with a supreme commitment to customer data protection and confidentiality.
I'm pleased to inform you that we finalized the Oqton acquisition on November 1, and the response from our customers and partners has been very positive.
Before I discuss our most recent and incredibly exciting acquisition, let me explain how we view our company holistically, which I believe is quite different from others in this industry.
In the decade since 3D printing was invented, we and our competitors have typically defined ourselves as hardware and material developers, with our products sold widely to customers around the world.
While this is natural when an industry is young and the product is mainly used in small quantities by labs or prototype facilities, as the industry matures and targets production environments, successful companies will need to adapt their entire operating model to reflect their deeper integration with specific markets and customers.
If you don't, you will remain simply a vendor and not a true partner to your customers, which will ultimately be reflected in your organic growth rate and profit margins.
With this in mind, at 3D Systems, starting a year ago, we changed how we define ourselves by reorganizing our entire company around key markets, and within those markets, key vertical segments that we believe will derive the most value from adopting additive manufacturing.
We began by creating two business segments, Healthcare and Industrial Solutions.
Using a strong application focus, these two businesses each integrate our printer, material, and software technologies in unique combinations to solve customers' product needs.
Once complete, our customers can then ask us to scale the process for them to a certain production level.
As demand increases, they can choose to have us enable a manufacturer of their choice to continue scaling to high volumes.
This transfer of the workflow involves providing printing systems, materials, and software along with the process definition.
It results in a seamless transfer of capability to the chosen manufacturer, whether it's the OEM themselves or a contract manufacturer of their choosing.
Fast-forwarding to this year, with the acquisition of Oqton, we expanded our software capabilities into what we broadly call digital manufacturing software, which, as we described earlier, enables rapid and efficient adoption of additive manufacturing in high-volume production environments.
This operating model has been very well received by our customer base, and we expect it to fuel exciting organic growth in the years ahead.
Most recently, we've added a strong biotech organizational focus and invested significantly to bring our emerging biological technologies to laboratory and human applications, details of which we'll cover shortly.
In summary, these are our five core market segments that you'll hear us discuss moving forward.
While each of the five will adapt to the needs of their customers, each will also leverage our core technologies of hardware, software, and materials in the unique manner needed to fulfill their customer application needs.
Let me illustrate this approach using our Healthcare business as an example.
In the mid-1990s, 3D Systems pioneered Medical Modeling, which involves printing highly detailed anatomical models from digital images.
These models have proven instrumental in supporting complex surgical procedures.
In a highly publicized application of our modeling technology, beautifully documented by CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta, we created several medical models to assist in separating conjoined twins, Jadon and Anias McDonald, who were born with the extremely rare craniopagus condition, where twins are joined at the head, sharing not only the skull and vasculature but portions of the brain itself.
The modeling used for surgical planning was vital to the success of Dr. James Goodrich and his team in separating the twins, both of whom are alive and living independently today, many years later.
To date, our medical modeling technology has supported dozens of similarly complex operations worldwide, along with hundreds of others, and continues to expand each year.
Building upon this foundation and investing in point-of-care infrastructure to support this growth, we deepened our surgical support over the next decade.
By 2005, we were working with surgeons to design and manufacture customized patient-specific surgical guides and instruments using 3D printing.
As this portion of the business grew, we expanded our scope once again, this time to include actual patient-specific implants, which offered an even larger market opportunity.
Today, we offer the broadest range of FDA-cleared capabilities for modeling surgical planning and patient-specific medical implants, which inspires our customers to continue expanding their partnership with us year after year.
While we're very proud of our progress, by now redefining ourselves as a healthcare business in this example and leveraging both our critical infrastructure and channel partner relationships, we can broaden our scope more aggressively to now include other parts of the human skeletal structure, and importantly, to advance these applications in parallel instead of in series as we have in the past.
This allows us to extend benefits to a much broader group of patients at an accelerated pace compared to before.
Redefining ourselves as a healthcare company rather than just a printing technology supplier for healthcare clients demonstrates the potential of this shift.
Notably, our Healthcare division experienced growth exceeding 28% in the latest quarter, and over 44% organically when excluding divested businesses.
This exceptional growth rate demonstrates our increasing traction in this promising market.
Building on our discussion of the Healthcare business, I'd like to conclude my remarks today by addressing the emerging field of bioprinting and our recent acquisition of Volumetric Biotechnologies.
Under Dr. Jordan Miller's visionary leadership, this company brings specialized expertise in biomaterials and regenerative medicine, combining synthetic chemistry, 3D printing, microfabrication and molecular imaging to guide human cells in forming more organized, complex structures of living vessels and tissues.
Since 2017, 3D Systems has been at the forefront of our industry by dedicating resources to regenerative medicine.
We initiated a collaborative development program with United Therapeutics Corporation to create the ability to print scaffolds for human lungs using a process we call printer profusion.
Once developed, this bioprinting technology can be applied to other major organs in the human body as well as various human and laboratory applications.
We've made considerable progress with this novel technology.
Consequently, we recently announced an expansion of our development program with United Therapeutics, which includes increased funding and extension to two additional organs.
This program expansion reflects the advancements our joint team has achieved in this groundbreaking endeavor.
By acquiring Volumetric, we're enhancing our 3D Systems team with crucial skills that perfectly complement our own, bringing strong biological expertise and cellular engineering capabilities along with highly innovative bioprinting systems to our development group.
As this is a completely new area for many who have followed our company, let me briefly summarize our regenerative medicine strategy and the market opportunities we're pursuing through our unique bioprinting technology.
The initial opportunity involves printing human organs, starting with the lung and expanding to two additional organs.
We're pursuing this as a joint program with our partner United Therapeutics.
The ambitious goals we've set for this program are driving significant advances in our technology and establishing the foundation for our other regenerative medicine efforts.
In our second regenerative medicine market opportunity, we're applying the core disruptive technologies developed for human organ bioprinting to other parts of the human body.
There are numerous applications ranging from printing human skin for burn victims to soft tissue for breast reconstruction and repair, critical blood vessel and bone replacements, and many more.
We're now forming partnerships focused on each application area where we can combine our bioprinting expertise with relevant application experts to provide unique and highly impactful solutions for those in need.
We refer to this second market vertical within regenerative medicine as human non-organ bioprinting.
Our final market opportunity involves extending our bioprinting technologies to research labs, providing advanced printing systems and unique biological materials to those studying regenerative medicine fundamentals and pharmaceutical laboratories where the ability to print precise, three-dimensional vascularized cell structures can be used to develop new, more effective drug therapies.
Acquiring Volumetric and their unique capabilities, combined with our own, will allow us to accelerate our efforts in all three of our regenerative medicine markets.
It's astounding to consider these revolutionary applications enabled by our 3D printing technologies; applications that we are uniquely positioned to deliver given our extensive history in advanced 3D printing technologies, materials expertise, application development experience, deep understanding of FDA and other regulatory processes, and now our biological and cellular engineering capabilities.
We anticipate that in the coming years, bioprinting will become a significant business for our company, providing crucial relief to patients requiring life-saving procedures and delivering substantial value to our employees and shareholders.
Shifting from our strategic growth investments to our most recent quarterly performance, I'm pleased to report that we've continued to execute well in our core business.
With sustained strong demand, our operational challenges have primarily revolved around global supply chain and logistics issues, which continue to affect most companies worldwide.
Our solid execution in the face of these challenges during the third quarter resulted in strong double-digit growth, with revenues increasing by 15% before accounting for divestitures.
When adjusting for these divestitures, which more accurately reflects our core business performance, revenues increased over 36% compared to 2020 and over 20% compared to our pre-pandemic 2019 third quarter, a benchmark we consider highly significant.
Examining our major business segments, our Industrial Solutions segment continues to rebound, with strong performance particularly in jewelry, automotive and transportation, and general manufacturing.
In Healthcare, we observe ongoing strong demand for personalized health services as well as solid performance in dental.
As Jagtar will discuss shortly, in addition to the strong revenue performance, our EBITDA increased by over 125%.
We generated positive cash from operations for the fourth consecutive quarter, the first time this has occurred in four years.
With our cash generation and proceeds from divestitures, we accumulated a substantial cash balance by the end of Q3.
A portion of these funds will be used to finance the strategic growth initiatives I mentioned earlier, but we will still have significant liquidity remaining to pursue additional opportunities.
I am clearly very excited not only about our accomplishments over the past year but even more so about the future, as our focus on growth in this final stage of our transformation has only just begun.
For the third quarter, we reported revenue of $156.1 million, a 14.6% increase compared to the third quarter of 2020.
Our organic revenue growth, which excludes divestitures completed in 2020 and 2021, was 35.9% in Q3 2021 versus Q3 2020.
Since the third quarter of 2020 marked the beginning of the economic reopening following COVID-related shutdowns, we believe it's valuable to compare our results to Q3 2019, which was unaffected by the pandemic.
Again, excluding divested businesses to ensure an apples-to-apples comparison, our revenue in the third quarter of 2021 was 21.2% higher than pre-pandemic Q3 2019.
As previously discussed, with the completion of our Simbionix and on-demand manufacturing divestitures in Q3 2021, we have finalized our planned divestitures and are now focused on the performance, growth, and investment of our core additive manufacturing business.
It's worth noting that post-divestitures, we continue to generate nearly two-thirds of our revenue from recurring revenue streams.
These high-margin lines of business highlight the strength and diversity of our core business, our ability to navigate various economic cycles, and around which we will continue to make strategic investments.
We reported GAAP net income of $2.34 per share in the third quarter of 2021 compared to a GAAP loss of $0.61 in the third quarter of 2020.
The year-over-year improvement was driven by gains on divested businesses as well as the goodwill impairment charge we recorded in the third quarter of 2020.
For our non-GAAP results, we reported non-GAAP income of $0.08 per share in the third quarter of 2021 compared to a non-GAAP loss of $0.03 per share in the third quarter of 2020.
The year-over-year improvement reflects higher revenue with lower non-GAAP operating expenses resulting from the cost-cutting measures we implemented last year.
Now I will discuss revenue by market.
Healthcare grew 28.3% year-over-year and decreased 7.8% compared to the previous quarter.
The decrease was primarily due to the divestiture of the Simbionix medical simulation business during the quarter.
Adjusted for divestitures, Healthcare revenue increased 44.5% year-over-year due to strong demand for dental applications in both printers and materials.
In fact, the last four quarters have seen the highest level of dental material sales ever compared to any prior four-quarter period.
Our Industrial segment generated revenue growth of 4% to $79.7 million compared to the same period last year and remained flat compared to the previous quarter, reflecting the divestiture of the on-demand manufacturing parts business during the quarter.
After adjusting for divestitures, Industrial revenue grew 28.1% compared to last year and 2.1% from the previous quarter.
The growth was fueled by increased demand for printers and materials across various sectors, particularly jewelry, automotive, transportation, and general manufacturing.
Let's now discuss gross margin.
In Q3 2021, we reported a gross profit margin of 41.2%, down from 43.1% in Q3 2020.
The non-GAAP gross profit margin was 41.5%, compared to 43.2% in the same period last year.
The decrease in gross profit margin was primarily due to businesses sold off in 2020 and 2021.
Excluding the impact of these divestitures, gross margins improved by 80 basis points in Q3 2021 compared to the same period last year, driven by cost-cutting measures in 2020 and higher revenue leading to improved capacity utilization.
As demonstrated by our strong performance this year, there continues to be robust demand for our products across both business segments.
The main challenge we face is not unique to our company.
Everyone is aware of the supply chain issues affecting businesses of all sizes and individuals alike.
In fact, our Q3 revenue, while impressive, was affected by limited availability of certain products.
Similar to last quarter, we continue to experience tightening costs and availability for specific components used in our products.
Our team is doing an outstanding job managing these challenges.
Supply chain constraints, rather than end-customer demand, remain the primary obstacle in our business and are our main focus as we close out the year.
We have implemented measures to reduce the economic impact, such as finding alternative suppliers for key components where possible.
We have experienced some cost increases due to supply chain constraints, particularly in shipping charges, and have implemented a temporary surcharge for customers on certain purchases starting in the fourth quarter.
Our year-to-date non-GAAP gross profit margin was 42.6%, and we anticipate full-year gross profit margins to range between 41% and 43%.
GAAP operating expenses for the quarter were $81.5 million, a 35.4% decrease compared to Q3 2020.
This year-over-year reduction reflects a goodwill impairment recorded in Q3 2020.
Our Q3 non-GAAP operating expenses were $54.1 million, an 8% decrease from the same quarter last year.
Compared to Q2 2021, non-GAAP operating expenses decreased by 2%, mainly due to lower R&D spending.
Adjusted EBITDA, defined as non-GAAP operating profit plus depreciation, was $16.3 million or 10.5% of revenue, compared to $7.2 million or 5.3% of revenue in Q3 2020.
Our disciplined approach to growth, cost management, and focus on our core business is resulting in continued strong adjusted EBITDA.
Regarding the cash flow statement and balance sheet, we are pleased to report $502.8 million in cash, an increase of $418.4 million since the beginning of the year.
This increase was primarily due to proceeds from selling our on-demand parts business and medical simulation business, but was also significantly supported by our exceptionally strong cash generation from operations.
We generated $20.7 million in cash from operations during the quarter, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of positive operating cash flow.
This is the first time in four years that the company has achieved four straight quarters of positive operating cash flow, reflecting a strong transformation of our business.
Having demonstrated consistent profitability and cash generation, along with $0.5 billion in cash on hand post-divestiture, we are well-positioned to continue growing the company by taking a disciplined approach to investing in organic and inorganic solutions that will address customers' complex needs, drive adoption of additive manufacturing, and generate high-margin recurring revenue streams.
We have previously announced some of these growth opportunities, namely our acquisitions of Oqton, which closed on November 1, and Volumetric Biotechnologies, expected to close in Q4.
The cash considerations for these acquisitions will total approximately $130 million, leaving roughly $370 million in cash.
These acquisitions will position the company for strong growth and are central to our strategies in both high-margin software to enable additive manufacturing adoption and advanced 3D printing technologies in regenerative medicine, where we believe we will be a market leader.
As I conclude my remarks, I want to reflect on the past year.
I joined the company at the beginning of Q3 2020, when the company was just starting its transformation.
We had just announced Q2 2020 results that included negative operating cash flow of $21 million for the first half of that year, only $64 million in cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet, and $22 million in debt.
Fast forward to this year, and the transformation we've undergone is remarkable.
We have generated over $60 million in operating cash this year through Q3 and ended the quarter with over $500 million in cash and cash equivalents with no debt.
We are fully focused on additive manufacturing and growing strongly in our core markets.
We can make smart and strategic investments to support our core business and are rapidly advancing our key technologies into new segments such as regenerative medicine.
I continue to believe that we are uniquely positioned in our industry with a strong balance sheet, growth, cash generation, and a suite of technologies that remain in demand by our customers.
Lastly, we wanted to provide an update on our Investor Day event.
You may recall that we had scheduled an event for September 9 in the Denver, Colorado area.
Out of an abundance of caution for the safety of our investors, analysts, and employees, we postponed the planned Investor Day as COVID infection rates increased this past summer due to the Delta variant.
We are now seeing encouraging signs of progress, with declining infection rates once again, the rollout of booster shots, and a newly announced pill that seems to offer promise in dramatically reducing hospitalization rates from this infection.
As a result, we are in the early stages of planning an updated Investor Day, aiming for the first half of 2022.
We will provide an update as soon as possible and look forward to sharing our long-term growth strategy in more detail with the investment community.
Jagtar and I have covered the remarkable progress we've made over the last year.
We've created value for our investors, customers, and employees by transforming the business.
Our growth and profitability set us apart in the industry and have made us a key partner for a growing number of organizations considering additive manufacturing.
At the same time, our transformation has also made us a more exceptional place to work to drive the future of additive manufacturing, and as a result, more talented individuals are joining the new 3D Systems every day.
However, as much as we've accomplished this last year, it's more about the future.
We will continue to be a valuable solutions partner with customers and deeply integrate with them as they adopt our solutions and technologies.
We will also invest in our business and drive our solutions capabilities in the five key areas I mentioned earlier.
I'm truly excited about the depth and breadth of technology we bring to our markets and our application expertise.
Summary:

on a non-gaap basis company expects 2021 gross profit margins to be between 41% and 43%.

3D Systems has completed its four-stage transformation plan, which has streamlined its organization, divested non-essential assets, and accumulated over $500 million in cash reserves. The company has also made two acquisitions, Oqton and Volumetric Biotechnologies, to invest in growth and expand its capabilities in additive manufacturing and regenerative medicine. 3D Systems has reported strong revenue growth, with a 35.9% increase in organic revenue growth in the third quarter of 2021 compared to the same period last year. The company has also reported a significant increase in cash generation, with $20.7 million in cash from operations in the third quarter of 2021. 3D Systems is well-positioned to continue growing the company by taking a disciplined approach to investing in organic and inorganic solutions that will address customers' complex needs, drive adoption of additive manufacturing, and generate high-margin recurring revenue streams. The company is planning an updated Investor Day event for the first half of 2022. Bullet points:
• 3D Systems has completed its four-stage transformation plan
• The company has accumulated over $500 million in cash reserves

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Rubun Dey, Head of Investor Relations, is joined by Horacio Rozanski, President and CEO, and Lloyd Howell, Executive Vice President, CFO and Treasurer, to discuss business and financial results.
Today's presentation will cover some non-GAAP financial measures and other metrics that we believe are valuable for investors.
We have provided explanations and reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures in our fourth quarter fiscal year 2021 presentation materials.
We are currently viewing Slide 5.
The company experienced an unprecedented year in its 107-year history.
Before delving into recent results and the current year's outlook, it's worth noting that the fiscal year ending March 31 also marked the conclusion of the three-year period outlined in our investment thesis.
In June 2018, we pledged to achieve 50% growth in adjusted diluted earnings per share over three years.
We anticipated this growth would result from our unique market position and a combination of industry-leading organic revenue growth, improved adjusted EBITDA margins, and significant capital deployment.
With our fiscal year 2021 results now finalized, Booz Allen has considerably surpassed our three-year financial goals.
ADEPS nearly doubled during this period, reaching $3.90 in fiscal year 2021.
The average annual revenue growth exceeded the middle of the 6% to 9% range we initially projected.
Adjusted EBITDA margin surpassed 10% in each of the three years, and we deployed $1.3 billion in capital.
Most of this was accomplished through increased dividends and an extensive share repurchase program.
During this three-year span, we navigated significant budget uncertainties, including the longest government shutdown in history, a tumultuous presidential transition, and an unprecedented global pandemic.
Throughout these challenges, we continued to invest in our workforce, notably setting aside $100 million in response to the pandemic to support our employees and assist the most vulnerable in our communities.
We also maintained our investment in key technologies and developed elements of our option value portfolio.
While the past three years demonstrate our outstanding financial performance, more importantly, it forms the foundation for our optimistic business outlook.
Over the last decade, we have further distinguished Booz Allen's brand and market position, becoming a trusted provider of advanced technology solutions that deliver both speed and mission scale for federal and commercial clients.
Our unique blend of consulting expertise, mission knowledge, innovation, and technology serves as a strategic catalyst for both our company and our clients.
I've frequently stated that Booz Allen continuously learns and evolves.
Our upcoming strategy and long-term financial outlook, which we plan to reveal in the fall, will build upon Vision 2020's growth and transformation.
We are confident in our trajectory as we anticipate the opportunities of the next decade.
Our recent agreement to acquire Liberty IT Solutions, LLC exemplifies our confidence in our strategic direction.
As discussed when announced on May 4, this acquisition aligns perfectly with our strategy.
Liberty is an exceptional company with highly skilled talent, trusted client relationships, proximity to mission, strong growth potential, and digital transformation capabilities that complement Booz Allen's extensive offerings.
The transaction is expected to conclude this quarter, subject to standard closing conditions.
We eagerly anticipate officially welcoming the Liberty team to the Booz Allen family.
Lloyd and I are proud of our team's performance in an unprecedented year, meeting or exceeding all metrics outlined in our updated guidance from late January.
For the full year, organic revenue growth was strong, albeit slower than recent years due to the pandemic and some delays in funding and awards following the election.
We also delivered excellent bottom-line results.
Full-year earnings, profit margins, and cash flow all surpassed expectations.
As the market began to stabilize post-transition, our team excelled in capturing opportunities, achieving a record book-to-bill ratio in the fourth quarter and a year-end backlog of $24 billion.
Underlying demand for our services and solutions remains robust, with our defense and civil businesses delivering excellent organic growth in fiscal year 2021, while intelligence and global commercial continue to reshape their portfolios.
Lloyd will provide more detail about market dynamics shortly.
I'm pleased to report that the Department of Justice has concluded the criminal investigation we first disclosed in June 2017.
The civil DOJ and SEC investigations are ongoing, and we continue to cooperate with the government to reach appropriate resolutions.
Let's now consider our approach to the business in the coming year.
As we begin fiscal year 2022, we are focusing on several near- and mid-term priorities.
First and foremost, to fully capitalize on our strong backlog and demand pipeline, we need to accelerate our recruiting efforts.
Second, we must leverage the reshaped portfolios in intelligence and commercial to drive growth in both sectors.
Third, we will carefully manage the transition to a post-COVID environment by investing in our people and the advanced capabilities necessary for the future.
Fourth, having launched our next-generation financial system on April 1, we are making significant progress and will remain focused on a seamless implementation.
Fifth, upon closing the Liberty acquisition, we will work closely to ensure a smooth and successful integration.
Looking further ahead, we are also focused on positioning for growth beyond the current fiscal year.
Our primary goal is to accelerate into the next wave of market changes.
From monetizing the option value portfolio to investing in new areas like Low Code, 5G, AI, or quantum, to finalizing our strategic review, Booz Allen is committed to leading the way in helping our clients scale new technologies into their missions faster than ever before.
Regarding our fiscal year 2022 outlook, Lloyd will provide detailed guidance shortly.
However, I'll note that the growth pattern will differ from recent years due to various factors including productivity and PTO trends, the Liberty acquisition, and the timing of headcount increases.
We expect these factors to produce a revenue profile with low single-digit growth in the first half, followed by significant acceleration in the second half.
We anticipate the full year to deliver another year of substantial revenue growth in FY'22.
Continued excellence in operational performance is also expected to yield strong EBITDA growth, sustained cash generation, and strategic capital deployment.
In conclusion, I am excited and optimistic about the coming year and beyond.
Our customers have distinct priorities and can allocate resources accordingly.
We possess an outstanding group of professionals who have proven their mettle in both prosperous and challenging periods.
Our financial position is robust.
Our steadfast dedication to our workforce over the past year has enhanced our already strong reputation in the talent market.
Everyone in our organization is devoted to and concentrates on providing excellent service to clients while adhering to our purpose and values.
Although we may encounter some turbulence and need to address hiring challenges in the coming months, I am extremely confident in our team's capacity to achieve growth in both the short and long term.
I'll begin by reinforcing Horacio's remarks on the conclusion of our investment strategy.
The previous quarter marked the end of a three-year period with a 96% increase in ADEPS, primarily driven by robust organic revenue growth and sustained margin expansion.
This achievement stemmed from investments related to Vision 2020 and our early positioning in key areas of increasing client demand.
Booz Allen has demonstrated its ability to outperform competitors even in some of the most challenging economic environments.
Going forward, we will maintain a keen focus on positioning Booz Allen for long-term success, building upon the excellent performance of the past three years.
Reflecting on the past year, we are proud of the resilience and dedication displayed by our team in close collaboration with our clients.
Their exceptional work resulted in another year of strong operational and financial performance.
As we enter fiscal year 2022 and anticipate transitioning to a post-pandemic operational rhythm, we expect some fluctuations, but we have clearly defined operational focus areas.
Our confidence in continued success is rooted in our track record of consistent performance and the strong foundation we've established to meet both near- and long-term objectives.
Let's examine our fiscal year 2021 results.
Revenue increased by 5.3% for the full year, reaching $7.9 billion.
Revenue, excluding billable expenses, grew by 7.1% to $5.5 billion.
This organic top-line growth largely reflects strong execution amid sustained demand for our services, aided by higher-than-normal staff utilization in the first half of the year.
As a reminder, we adjusted our revenue guidance in January to a range of 4.8% to 6% due to three factors: programmatic shifts during the presidential transition, a return to more typical PTO usage, and lower expectations for billable expenses as a percentage of revenue, which fell at the low end of our 29% to 31% range.
These factors played out as anticipated in the fourth quarter.
Let me review the market performance.
Full-year revenue growth was led by our defense and civil businesses, which grew by 9% and 8%, respectively.
Defense growth slowed in the second half of the year due to the factors mentioned earlier.
However, long-term demand for our services and solutions remained strong, as evidenced by recent business wins and continued tactical sales execution.
Growth in our civil business also decelerated in the second half of the year.
This was primarily due to a pause on a large cyber program caused by funding availability issues, which began in the third quarter and continued into the fourth quarter.
Given the program's importance and criticality for the client, we believe work will increase again in the coming quarters.
Revenue from our intelligence business declined by 3% for the full year.
Our focused effort to reshape that portfolio continues, and we are pleased with the results thus far.
We anticipate our intelligence business will return to growth this fiscal year as we ramp up recent contract wins.
Additionally, the pandemic-related challenges we faced in fiscal year 2021, including the inability to bill for fees, will continue to diminish as more employees return to work at client facilities.
Lastly, revenue in global commercial, which accounted for approximately 3% of our total revenue in fiscal year 2021, declined by 22% year-over-year.
This decrease was primarily driven by our decision to exit parts of our Middle East business due to market dynamics and geopolitical trends, and to focus strategically on our US-based cyber business.
We are pleased with our excellent book-to-bill performance for both the quarter and the full year.
Our fourth-quarter book-to-bill ratio of 1.38 times set a record, resulting in a full-year book-to-bill of 1.42 times.
Total backlog grew by 16%, yielding our largest-ever fiscal year-end backlog of $24 billion.
Funded backlog increased by 3% to $3.5 billion.
Unfunded backlog rose by 35% to $6.1 billion, and priced options grew by 13% to $14.4 billion.
Throughout the year, our team maintained our historical win rates for both recompete and new work, despite navigating the pandemic and a presidential transition period.
As previously noted, we continue to supplement our traditional foundation of diversified smaller awards by pursuing larger and more complex bids, which inherently cause quarter-to-quarter volatility in book-to-bill ratios.
Our record backlog reflects ongoing robust demand for our services, the quality of our people, and our close alignment with client missions.
Turning to headcount, as of March 31, we had 27,727 employees, an increase of 554 or 2% year-over-year.
Excluding the impacts of our contract divestiture in the third quarter, headcount would have grown by 2.4%.
As Horacio emphasized, we are focused on accelerating headcount growth to meet strong demand signals and execute our backlog.
Moving to the bottom line, adjusted EBITDA for fiscal year 2021 was $840 million, up 11.4% from the previous year.
This increase was primarily driven by our top-line growth, strong cost management, and lower-than-expected billable expense mix in what was truly an anomalous year.
As a result, our adjusted EBITDA margin for the full year was 10.7%.
Full-year net income, diluted earnings per share, and ADEPS also grew significantly.
Net income increased by 26% year-over-year to $109 million.
Adjusted net income was $542 million, up 21% from the previous year.
Diluted earnings per share increased by 28% to $4.37 from $3.41 the year prior.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased by 23% to $3.90 from $3.18 the year prior.
These increases were primarily driven by strong operating performance, a lower effective tax rate, and a lower share count in fiscal year 2021 due to our share repurchase program.
Regarding our effective tax rate, during the fourth quarter, we recognized a tax benefit under the CARES Act that allowed tax loss carrybacks to prior tax years.
We identified roughly $77 million in tax benefit reassessment this quarter, which was not included in our adjusted net income and earnings per share calculations.
Three years ago, we implemented a strategy to enhance our cash generation capabilities.
We are incredibly pleased with our team's achievements this year, which we view as the culmination of our multi-year efforts.
Our operating cash flow for fiscal year 2021 reached $719 million, representing a 30% increase compared to the previous year.
This exceeded our projected range, and we concluded the year with $991 million in cash reserves.
The robust cash performance was primarily driven by collections growth outpacing revenue growth, while increased cash taxes were offset by reduced expenditures related to operating during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our capital expenditures for the year amounted to $87 million, aligning with our expectations as we continued investing in infrastructure and technology to support remote work.
April was a crucial month for us as we launched our new NextGen Financial System.
Our year-end reporting process went smoothly, and we have not encountered any significant issues so far.
As expected, we faced a few minor challenges, which were promptly addressed.
We have already begun to reap the benefits in the form of improved data access and increased productivity.
We anticipate this will lead to cost savings over time, which will be reinvested to drive future growth.
I will revisit this topic when discussing our outlook for fiscal year 2022.
In fiscal year 2021, we continued to implement a prudent capital allocation strategy aimed at delivering both short-term and long-term value for shareholders.
We distributed approximately $181 million to shareholders through quarterly dividends, including a 19% year-over-year dividend increase in the fourth quarter.
This marked the eighth consecutive fiscal year of double-digit growth in our quarterly dividend.
We also bought back 4.1 million shares for $318 million during the fiscal year, with 2.3 million shares repurchased for $185 million in the fourth quarter.
Combined with our third quarter investment in Tracepoint, we allocated a total of $571 million in capital during fiscal year 2021.
Moving forward, our capital allocation priorities remain consistent: reinvesting in our business, maintaining our quarterly dividend, pursuing strategic acquisitions, and repurchasing shares.
We are also announcing that our Board has approved a regular dividend of $0.37 per share, payable on June 30 to stockholders of record on June 15.
Dividends continue to be an important element of our strategy to create value for shareholders.
Lastly, I want to briefly mention our recently announced acquisition of Liberty IT Solutions.
This transaction, once completed, will be our largest acquisition to date and will immediately contribute to revenue growth, adjusted EBITDA margin, and adjusted diluted earnings per share.
For us, this transaction embodies exactly what we seek in acquisitions: cultural, strategic, and financial alignment.
Looking ahead, we are focusing on three objectives: first, ensuring a smooth and successful integration; second, continuing to hire to support Liberty's recent contract wins; and third, maintaining excellence in contract delivery.
As Horacio mentioned, we are excited about the acquisition and the long-term value it will create for our shareholders and the people of both Booz Allen and Liberty.
We look forward to providing updates in the coming months.
Regarding guidance, please refer to Slide 9.
Fiscal year 2021 presented unprecedented challenges for our people and clients.
This resulted in several factors affecting our fiscal year 2021 financial results, which influence year-over-year comparisons as we enter fiscal year 2022.
Most of these factors are temporary in nature.
However, we expect them to limit top-line growth for the next couple of quarters before accelerating in the latter half of the fiscal year.
Let me explain these factors.
First, there is a natural ramp-up period required for both executing work on recently won contracts and for recruiting and hiring.
As Horacio noted, we are focused on both of these priorities.
They take time to gain momentum, which leads to a build-up towards the latter half of the year.
Second, we experienced unusually high productivity in the first half of fiscal year 2021, driving up revenue growth, then slowing growth in the second half as staff utilization and PTO trends normalized.
This dynamic will create challenging comparisons in the first half of fiscal year 2022.
Third, we expect PTO trends to continue impacting results for the next few months.
Although we successfully implemented a one-time PTO buyback program in the fourth quarter, we know that many of our employees still have higher balances due to the pandemic.
With increasing vaccinations and some travel restrictions easing, we expect and have been encouraging our people to take well-deserved time off.
Lastly, our implementation of the new financial system will result in minor timing differences in labor costing.
We do not expect this to significantly impact our full-year results.
However, we forecast approximately 50 basis points of revenue growth headwinds in each of our second and third quarters, offset by roughly 100 basis points of tailwind in the fourth quarter.
Considering all these factors, we expect organic top-line growth in the low single-digit range in the first half of fiscal year 2022, with a significant increase in the third and fourth quarters.
From an EBITDA perspective, a return to more normal indirect spending patterns and billable expense mix post-pandemic will cause some fluctuations in our quarterly margin profile.
Now, let me outline our fiscal year 2022 guidance.
We expect total revenue growth between 7% and 10%, which includes a partial year contribution from our announced Liberty acquisition, assuming a first quarter 2022 close.
The difference between the high and low ends of our revenue growth outlook will largely depend on the successful execution and timing of our hiring and onboarding efforts.
We anticipate adjusted EBITDA margin to remain in the mid-10% range.
We expect adjusted diluted earnings per share to be between $4.10 and $4.30.
This range reflects strong organic growth, additional D&A expense related to our new financial system, a higher effective tax rate, and $0.20 to $0.24 of anticipated accretion from our acquisition of Liberty IT.
We expect operating cash flow to be between $800 million and $850 million, primarily driven by our operational performance, lower cash tax payments, and contributions from Liberty IT.
Lastly, we expect capital expenditures to be between $80 million and $100 million as we continue investing in infrastructure and technology.
We have once again demonstrated our ability to effectively manage the business, invest in our people, and deliver strong returns to our shareholders.
We accomplished all of this while navigating a challenging macro environment, which reinforces our confidence in our strategy and positioning to succeed in any market condition.
Operator, please open the lines for questions.
Summary:
output: sees 2022 adjusted earnings per share $4.10 - $4.30.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Numerous efforts have been made to encapsulate the events of 2020, and I won't contribute to those summaries here.
It's sufficient to say that we're all relieved to move past 2020.
Nevertheless, it's a year we shouldn't rush to dismiss from memory.
Rather than focusing on the difficulties 2020 presented, we should emphasize our reactions to these challenges and our resolve in pursuing our goals.
The operational and tactical adjustments we implemented, starting in 2019 and continuing through 2020, have significantly influenced our processes and are yielding positive results on our performance.
You'll soon hear specifics about these enhancements.
One clear consequence of these efforts has been the impact on our revenue.
Our revenue decreased in 2020 as we critically evaluated some of our recent business ventures.
This reduction doesn't indicate a lack of growth intentions.
We do aim to expand.
We simply want to ensure our growth is profitable.
The recent decline in our revenue is a consequence of this approach.
Despite the challenging loss environment at this point in the cycle, we're not merely waiting out the storm, but taking time to strategize before proceeding.
For Q4, we reported non-GAAP operating income of $3.3 million, or $0.06 per share.
This reflects increased equity earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries and a significant quarter-to-quarter improvement in our underwriting results.
While we still have progress to make before we're content with our results, this quarter demonstrated that the changes implemented over the past 18 months are substantially benefiting our operational performance.
For the entire year, we reported a non-GAAP operating loss of $27.7 million, attributed to the pre-tax net underwriting loss of $45.7 million from a tail policy issued to a major national healthcare client and a pre-tax $10 million IBNR reserve related to the pandemic, both recorded in Q2.
Our Q4 consolidated net loss ratio was 74.9%, a notable quarter-over-quarter decrease primarily due to the effects of the large national healthcare account in the previous year's quarter.
More importantly, it also reflected our reunderwriting and rate strengthening efforts over the past year.
The annual net loss ratio was 83.4%, a 5.6 percentage point decrease mainly due to favorable reserve development and a reduction in the current accident year net loss ratio, driven by improvements in our Specialty P&C segment.
However, the Q2 tail policy and pandemic IBNR reserve largely obscured this improvement.
Our consolidated underwriting expense ratios for the quarter and year, 30.9% and 30% respectively, were relatively unaffected by our contracting revenue from reunderwriting efforts, demonstrating that our strategic initiatives to improve our underlying expense structure have been effective.
The annual expense ratio also reflected one-time restructuring costs and transaction-related expenses associated with our planned NORCAL acquisition, partially offset by reduced travel expenses due to the pandemic.
From an investment standpoint, our consolidated net investment result increased quarter-over-quarter to $26.3 million, driven by $10.1 million in income from unconsolidated subsidiaries.
We invest in various LPs and LLCs, with results typically reported on a quarter lag, so the current quarter's earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries represent the value recovery of our LPs and LLCs in Q3.
Consolidated net investment income was $16.1 million for the quarter, down from the previous year primarily due to a reduced allocation to equities and lower yields from short-term investments and corporate debt securities, given the Federal Reserve's interest rate reductions in response to COVID-19.
Net investment income was also lower for the year due to these factors.
The Specialty Property & Casualty segment continues to implement a comprehensive business strategy to address our operating and underwriting results.
Despite recording an underwriting loss for the quarter and year, we remain encouraged by the improvement in both expense and net loss ratios, excluding the underwriting loss associated with the large national healthcare account in 2019 and 2020.
Due to the aggressive restructuring, reunderwriting, and expense reductions implemented throughout 2019 and 2020, we're confident we've established a strong foundation for the future and positive momentum.
As anticipated, gross premiums written decreased in the quarter and full year, reflecting our reunderwriting and rate strengthening efforts in the competitive environment across our operating territories.
However, our gross premiums written remained relatively consistent year-over-year in our Medical Technology Liability business.
Additionally, gross premiums written in the quarter reflected renewal timing differences of $4.6 million in our Specialty business and the non-renewal of a $2.8 million policy in our Standard Physicians business.
We'll continue to prioritize underwriting discipline and achieving our long-term profit objectives, managing the segment's revenue as necessary to improve our bottom line.
Premium retention improved quarter-over-quarter, largely due to improvement in our specialty business.
Full-year retention was 79%, reflecting the reunderwriting in specialty and rate strengthening efforts in standard positions over the past year.
Premium retention results in our Small Business Unit and Medical Technology Liability business remained relatively consistent with historical trends.
We achieved higher premium retention and renewal price increases of 8% in the segment this quarter, with 10% increases in both our Standard Physician and Specialty business
For the entire year, we saw 9% renewal price increases, with 15% increases in Specialty and 11% in Standard Physicians business
We also significantly improved rate adequacy in specialty by enhancing product structure terms and conditions, in addition to price increases
New business writings reached $5.3 million this quarter compared to $4.6 million in Q4 2019, driven by our Medical Technology Liability business
Full-year new business writings were $23 million, down from $43 million in 2019, reflecting careful risk selection, disciplined underwriting, and slower submissions due to pandemic disruptions
The current accident year net loss ratio decreased 6.3 percentage points year-over-year, excluding the impact of a large national healthcare account and COVID-19 IBNR reserve
This decrease mainly reflects improvements from our reunderwriting efforts that began in Q3 2019
We observed significantly reduced claims frequency compared to 2019 in both the quarter and full year, likely partly due to the pandemic
We've remained cautious about recognizing these favorable frequency trends due to our long-tail business lines and COVID-19 uncertainty
Regarding COVID-19 business impact, we established a $10 million pre-tax IBNR reserve in Q2 for reported incidents
As of year-end 2020, we haven't seen additional suits emerge from the reported incidents, with only five suits filed
After reviewing pandemic-related claim activity, no additional IBNR reserves have been booked since Q2
Premium deferrals and discounts have seen minimal changes since Q3
Despite challenging loss conditions, we recognized net favorable development of $6.8 million in Q4 and $27.5 million for the full year, a significant improvement from 2019
The Specialty Property & Casualty segment reported expense ratios of 23.8% in Q4 and 23% for the full year, improvements of 1.4 and 1.1 percentage points respectively compared to 2019
This was achieved despite lower net earned premiums and $4 million in one-time restructuring charges
We achieved approximately $12 million in expense savings in 2020 through organizational restructuring, office consolidations, and staff reductions
The reinsurance market continues to firm due to social inflation and severity claim trends
We successfully renewed our reinsurance treaty in October, mitigating potential cost increases by raising our retention from $1 million to $2 million for certain liability businesses
Regarding the NORCAL transaction, the California Department of Insurance has completed its review of conversion documents
NORCAL will now begin soliciting policyholder votes on converting from a mutual to a stock company
Policyholders can choose to take their ownership share as NORCAL stock, which ProAssurance will offer to buy through a tender offer
We expect materials to be mailed to eligible policyholders by late February
We now anticipate closing the transaction in Q2 2021, subject to meeting prerequisites
We remain excited about combining the companies and the strategic value of this transaction
We look forward to continued progress on our business plan in 2021
The Workers' Compensation Insurance segment generated $6 million in income and a 97.8% combined ratio for 2020, including $2.1 million in income and a 96.3% combined ratio in Q4
The segment recorded $47 million in Q4 and $247 million in full-year gross premiums written, decreases of 13.6% and 11.4% compared to 2019
Renewal pricing in 2020 decreased 4% for both Q4 and the full year, reflecting ongoing competitive pressures in our underwriting territories despite COVID-19 and economic conditions
Premium renewal retention improved to 82% for the quarter and 84% for the year in 2020, up from 76% and 83% respectively in 2019
We are observing higher premium retention and reduced new business during the COVID-19 crisis
New business writings fell to $4.4 million in Q4 2020 from $5.5 million in Q4 2019, and decreased to $27.4 million for full-year 2020 from $30.8 million in 2019
The company received $700,000 in additional audit premium for Q4 2020, down from $2.2 million in 2019, and $700,000 for the full year, a decrease from $5.7 million in 2019
The reduction in audit premium reflects COVID-19's economic impact on policyholders' payrolls
We anticipate continued downward pressure on premiums in upcoming quarters due to changes in payroll estimates
The calendar year net loss ratio rose in both Q4 and the full year, due to ongoing soft market conditions in workers' compensation, resulting in lower renewal rates, reduced audit premiums, and decreased net favorable reserve development, partially offset by positive 2020 accident year claim outcomes
The accident year loss ratio for 2020 was 69%, compared to 68.4% in 2019
Net favorable loss reserve development for Q4 2020 was $2 million, down from $4.4 million in 2019, and $7 million for the full year, compared to $7.8 million in 2019
We are maintaining our practice of reserving for all claims as if injured workers were receiving medical treatment in the same manner as before the pandemic
Non-COVID claim frequency decreased by 35% during the pandemic, with only $2.2 million in gross undeveloped incurred losses from 1,375 COVID claims at the end of 2020
By the end of January 2021, 87% of the 2020 reported COVID claims had been closed, highlighting the shorter-tailed nature of workers' compensation insurance compared to healthcare professional liability
Management remains cautious in assessing the 2020 accident year loss ratio due to the numerous uncertainties surrounding the pandemic
Our claims professionals continue to work effectively remotely, closing 61% of 2019 and prior claims during 2020, in line with historical claim closing rates
Many legislative enactments or proposals to expand workers' compensation claim coverage expired on December 31, but new legislative sessions starting in January may revive these efforts
The underwriting expense ratio in Q4 was 32.7%, up from 29.8% in 2019, reflecting the decrease in net premiums earned
The underwriting expense ratio decreased by 2.5 percentage points from Q3 2020 due to restructuring efforts and a one-time expense of $900,000 in Q3
For the full year 2020, the expense ratio was 32.9%, compared to 30.4% in 2019
The Segregated Portfolio Cell Reinsurance segment reported income of $1.6 million for Q4 and $4.4 million for 2020
Premium trends in the SPC Reinsurance segment were similar to those in the Workers' Compensation Insurance segment
All alternative market programs available for renewal were renewed during the current quarter and for the year, with one new program added in 2020
The SPC segment recorded favorable development of $9 million in Q4 2020, up from $2.3 million in 2019, and $16.6 million for the full year, compared to $10.1 million in 2019
As of December 31, 2020, there were 1,090 reported COVID claims for this segment with $1 million of gross undeveloped incurred losses
The Lloyd's Syndicates segment experienced natural catastrophe losses in Q4 related to hurricanes Laura and Sally and Midwest windstorms in August
Our participation in Syndicate 1729 and 6131 results led to a loss of just under $1 million in Q4
The Q4 loss and reduced participation in Syndicate 1729 for the 2020 underwriting year contributed to an overall lower income of approximately $2.1 million for the year
Losses from storms and other natural catastrophes in the last three months of 2020 are expected to result in a segment loss of approximately $2.5 million in Q1
For the 2021 underwriting year, our participation in Syndicate 1729 has been reduced from 29% to 5%, and in Syndicate 6131 from 100% to 50%
These changes will be reflected in our results starting in Q2 2021
The decision to further reduce our participation in the syndicates is driven by our desire to support and grow our core insurance operations and reduce volatility in our underlying performance
Duncan Dale and his team at Dale Underwriting Partners remain valued partners to ProAssurance, and the syndicates were able to secure participating capital to replace our own without difficulty
The significant improvements made in the past 12 months contribute substantially to our goals of operational excellence and sustainable profitability
Summary:

For the entire year, we reported a non-GAAP operating loss of $27.7 million, attributed to the pre-tax net underwriting loss of $45.7 million from a tail policy issued to a major national healthcare client and a pre-tax $10 million IBNR reserve related to the pandemic, both recorded in Q2.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We truly value your participation in today's discussion of Graham's financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal 2022.
The releases and slides can be accessed on the Company's official website if you don't have them.
He's participating in the call and will deliver some formal statements.
Jeff Glajch, our CFO, and Dan Thoren, our President and COO who will become our new CEO after Jim's retirement, are also present.
Jim will begin with an overview and then summarize the quarterly results.
Jeff will then provide a detailed financial analysis, followed by Dan's closing remarks.
These potential risks, uncertainties, and other factors are detailed in the release, slide, and other documents submitted by the Company to the SEC.
You can find these documents on our website or at sec.gov.
During today's call, we may also discuss some non-GAAP financial measures that we believe are helpful in assessing our performance.
We've provided comparisons of GAAP to non-GAAP measures in the tables accompanying today's release.
I'll start my presentation at Slide 3 with a quick overview of the financial results before discussing my upcoming retirement.
The quarter's revenue was $20.2 million, with $16.7 million from organic growth and $3.5 million from the Barber-Nichols acquisition that concluded on June 1.
Defense revenue accounted for 35% of total revenue this quarter.
We anticipate defense revenue to reach nearly 50% of total quarterly revenue with Barber-Nichols fully integrated in future quarters.
This acquisition and revenue mix shift represent a significant transformation for Graham and substantially advanced our diversification strategy.
Organic revenue remained similar year-over-year, but for different reasons.
Our first quarter last year operated at about 50% capacity due to COVID-19, affecting revenue and profitability through under-absorption.
In the most recent quarter, our workforce utilization was at full capacity, but the mix was very different.
Orders from our crude oil refining and chemical/petrochemical markets were very low during the third and fourth quarters of last fiscal year, with non-Navy orders totaling $17.5 million for both quarters.
As a result, more production resources were allocated to Navy backlog, which has lower margins due to first article work and contract structure for a large order in backlog.
These challenges will be resolved over the next few quarters and largely behind us as we exit this fiscal year.
Organic revenue and profitability are expected to improve throughout the fiscal year.
First quarter orders totaled $20.9 million, mostly organic, with Barber-Nichols contributing $200,000 for June.
Encouragingly, we received strong orders from the crude oil refining market, totaling $11.5 million.
We secured a significant contract for a domestic refinery upgrading their facility to enhance crude oil feedstock processing flexibility.
This win was particularly satisfying for me, as I remember losing the original order to a domestic competitor in the mid-1990s.
Now, 25 years later, we've won back the installation and replaced the original supplier with our own vacuum systems.
Consolidated backlog as of June 30 was $236 million, with 80% in defense.
Importantly, as we work through the more challenging margin backlog affecting the current fiscal year, the margin potential for our defense backlog improves significantly.
The Barber-Nichols acquisition adds market diversity to our profile and introduces backlog for new markets including space and advanced energy industries.
While we invested considerable cash in acquiring Barber-Nichols to strengthen and diversify revenue and earnings, our balance sheet remains strong and our opportunity to improve return on assets increases.
As announced earlier today and mentioned by Debbie, I'm pleased to confirm my retirement effective August 31, with Dan Thoren succeeding me as President and CEO of the corporation.
He will also join our Board of Directors at that time.
It has been a great honor and privilege to serve Graham shareholders and the corporation as its Principal Executive Officer since 2006.
I believe I'm departing on a high note, as this is an incredibly exciting time for the Company, considering our strong organic defense strategy, success in price-focused international markets, investments in IT tools and systems, and the transformational acquisition of Barber-Nichols.
I've had the opportunity to work with Dan through the acquisition process for nearly three years and most recently during his onboarding with the Graham team.
I believe Dan is well-equipped to lead Graham and has an excellent vision for the Company's next growth phase.
I'm thrilled that this acquisition has proven to be as transformative as we had envisioned.
The leadership team's bench strength is being enhanced as part of the transformation.
In recent months, it became evident that this has also provided for my succession plan.
I'm delighted the Board recognized the same potential in Dan that I had observed.
As a Graham shareholder, I'm eager to benefit from Dan's strategic leadership.
You have my complete backing, not just during this transition, but for the long term.
I've valued our numerous discussions over the years and greatly appreciated your continued support.
Please advance to Slide 4.
As Jim noted, we experienced a very challenging first quarter.
While discussing that first quarter, please note that our full year guidance remains unchanged.
We anticipate improvements as the year progresses and expect sequential quarterly growth for the remainder of fiscal 2022.
Revenue in the quarter increased by $3.5 million due to our one-month ownership of Barber-Nichols.
The comparable quarter last year occurred early in the COVID pandemic.
We operated at half capacity during that quarter, as Jim mentioned.
However, we recognized a $5 million project on a completed contract basis in that quarter, which had shifted from fiscal 2020 to Q1 2021 due to COVID.
Gross profit and earnings per share were significantly impacted by an unfavorable project mix and some timing and cost issues.
We incurred liquidated damages due to COVID in the quarter and experienced some timing of expenses pulled into Q1.
We also had minor acquisition expenses of about $169,000 pre-tax and the first month of purchase price accounting related costs for Barber-Nichols.
To clarify, the purchase accounting amortization costs were $225,000 before taxes in June.
We anticipate approximately $2.7 million pre-tax and $2.15 million after-tax related to acquisition purchase accounting.
90% of this is amortization costs, with the remainder being increased depreciation and inventory valuation.
We'll file an 8-K later this week providing more details on the purchase accounting and pro forma income statements.
We expect similar amortization amounts in fiscal 2023 as fiscal 2022 since we'll have 12 rather than 10 months of amortization in fiscal 2023.
It will decrease in future years and stabilize at approximately $1.1 million pre-tax.
Let's move to slide 5.
The Barber-Nichols acquisition has significantly improved our balance sheet efficiency.
We've added $20 million of low-cost term debt for the acquisition and now have access to a larger revolving credit line.
This term loan and credit line will provide ongoing flexibility.
We expect the Barber-Nichols acquisition to be accretive in fiscal 2022, even with the additional $2.15 million or roughly $0.20 per share in amortization costs.
We'll continue seeking both organic and M&A growth opportunities, believing we have the financial strength to invest in both areas.
The addition of Barber-Nichols presents excellent opportunities in both domains.
Moving to slide 6.
Orders in commercial markets increased in Q1 from a very low base in the previous two quarters.
Our $236 million backlog positions us well for long-term growth.
80% of that backlog is in the defense market, providing an excellent baseline for our business in coming years.
Before handing over to Dan, I must acknowledge Jim's 37 years of service at Graham, including 15 years as leader.
He transformed Graham from a capacity-limited company with minimal growth engines to a broader organization with strong positions in defense and Asian energy markets, complementing our long-standing presence in the United States and Middle East.
Graham equipment can be found in world-class refining and petrochemical facilities globally and plays a crucial role on US Navy vessels supporting national defense.
I've known Dan for three years, including negotiating the acquisition with him.
Dan is a high-integrity leader with an impressive track record at Barber-Nichols, and I expect similar success at Graham.
When Board members sought my opinion on Dan as a potential CEO, I was and remain unequivocal in my belief that Dan is the right leader to take Graham forward.
Now that I've set high expectations, I'll turn the call over to Dan.
Thank you for the kind introduction and words.
I've spent two and a half years getting acquainted with Graham, its leadership, and its business at a high level.
Indirectly, I've gained insight into their culture, people, customers, and Board.
Over the past two months, I've met with the executive team, managers, employees, customers, and the Board to gain a deeper understanding of the Company.
These interactions have helped me appreciate Graham's proud engineering and manufacturing heritage, its importance to the Batavia, New York community, and how it has become a trusted partner to customers worldwide in critical process industries.
As I present my slides, I'll outline our strategy to build upon our strong legacies while leveraging opportunities in the defense and space industries.
We'll focus on generating sustainable earnings growth, reducing earnings volatility, improving operational performance, generating strong cash flows for business reinvestment, and providing dividends to stockholders.
Our ultimate goals are to deliver acceptable returns to our stockholders and benefit all our stakeholders.
Let's now examine slide 7.
Following the acquisition of Barber-Nichols, Graham Corporation acknowledges that each company has unique strengths in their respective markets, which we aim to preserve.
Our aim is to utilize the strengths of each company as foundations for both internal growth and external acquisitions.
Consequently, both Graham and Barber-Nichols operations function under the umbrella of Graham Corporation.
When considering future investments, we intend to incorporate new businesses and technologies with related engineered products that can operate independently while also collaborating on larger projects.
We plan to share best practices among experts in the companies, distribute services across organizations, and create career advancement opportunities for key staff members.
By implementing these strategies, each subsidiary can maintain its focus and adaptability while achieving more than it could on its own.
Slide 7 illustrates our two platforms for growth.
Barber-Nichols primarily operates in the space and defense sectors.
Graham manufacturing currently serves the Defense, Energy, and Petrochemical industries.
We believe there are acquisition opportunities in the expanding space industry as it attracts more private investment.
We will seek small, easily integrated acquisitions as well as medium-sized, self-sustaining acquisitions that complement our existing businesses.
We are also investing internally to develop new products and technologies for the space industry.
Both Graham and Barber-Nichols are well-established in the defense industries.
We will explore new areas to add value and consider internal investments and acquisitions to expand into new and more advanced product lines.
Graham has been a global leader in vacuum and heat transfer products for energy and chemical/petrochemical applications.
As previously discussed by Jim and Jeff, the domestic market is stagnant while international markets show potential for growth.
We plan to concentrate on our domestic installed base and provide customers with the necessary support to maintain optimal plant operations.
We will continue to invest in international markets and expand our global presence through our proven shared margin strategy.
Recently, both companies have identified opportunities in the alternative and clean energy markets for turbomachinery and heat transfer products.
Clean energy is an area where synergy between the companies is possible.
Strategically, we aim to maintain and grow our established business while developing engineering and new product capabilities to participate in emerging alternative and clean energy markets.
Each of these markets has its own risk and reward profile.
Having dedicated teams for each area is crucial, and we have made significant progress in implementing the organizational changes needed to successfully execute our strategies in each market.
Let's proceed to slide 8.
As Jim and Jeff mentioned earlier, we view fiscal '22 as a transitional year, starting off challenging but improving sequentially each quarter.
Meanwhile, we're observing a stronger pipeline with increased inquiries and new orders in the second quarter.
Graham manufacturing has received $9.5 million in orders to date in the second quarter, while Barber-Nichols has secured $9.1 million.
Based on the timing of customers' projects, we are maintaining our revenue guidance at $130 million to $140 million, with Barber-Nichols expected to contribute between $45 million and $48 million.
Combined, the Defense segment is projected to account for nearly half of the revenue, and EBITDA is anticipated to be in the $7 million to $9 million range.
Capital expenditures are planned to be between $3.5 million and $4 million, including Barber-Nichols' capital expenditure.
Let's move on to slide 9.
As mentioned in my opening remarks, we are transforming Graham Corporation.
The acquisition of Barber-Nichols was the initial transformative step.
We will seek to strengthen the Barber-Nichols investment through further development of its platform to enable growth in the defense and space industries, as well as other sectors as opportunities arise.
Coinciding with the acquisition, we believe we are at or near the bottom of the energy and petrochemical cycle.
We have been preparing for an upcoming expansion that we anticipate will begin in FY 2023.
Our welder training program has been highly successful in replenishing our pipeline of future employees.
We are qualifying additional suppliers to increase our capacity in anticipation of a potential upswing.
Our plans include expanding our international offices with sales, quality, and project management personnel.
Both Barber-Nichols and Graham hold leading market positions and strong brand recognition.
We believe that robust engineering, close collaboration with customers on challenging applications, and delivery of high-quality products on time will allow us to maintain our brand strength and market leadership.
As we progress with our transformation, we will enhance our market presence through linked and updated websites and social media.
We believe this will broaden our exposure to a wider audience that may not yet recognize our growth and earnings potential.
Personally, I am committed to being an exemplary corporate citizen and working with all our stakeholders to build a better, stronger business for everyone involved.
With the Barber-Nichols acquisition, Graham has put its substantial cash reserves to work and created a more efficient balance sheet.
As we continue to improve our business and further develop our strong cash-generating capabilities, we intend to make intelligent decisions in allocating capital for future growth, with a keen focus on returns.
We are very optimistic about this new combination and the future it presents for all of us.
When you have a talented team capable of identifying customer problems, collaborating on solutions, and adapting to market changes, success is inevitable.
At Graham Corporation, we possess this ability and will continue to expand upon it.
Summary:

fiscal 2022 guidance remains unchanged.
expects about 35% to 40% of backlog will convert to revenue in last nine months of fiscal 2022.
about $25 million to $27 million of backlog related to defense industry is expected to convert to sales in fiscal 2022.
