input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Details required by SEC Regulation G concerning these non-GAAP financial metrics can be found in the Investors area of our website, www.fortive.com, under the Investors quarterly results section.
On October 9, 2020, we finalized the division of our former Industrial Technologies segment by spinning off Vontier Corporation.
Consequently, we have classified the results of the Industrial Technologies segment as discontinued operations.
All mentions of year-over-year increases or decreases and financial metrics refer to ongoing operations.
We were highly satisfied with our second quarter performance.
As illustrated on slide three, our results once again demonstrated the advantages of our strategy to deliver specialized connected workflow solutions for our clients, establishing a portfolio with increased stability and long-term profit potential.
During the quarter, we took advantage of improving point-of-sale trends across several of our major businesses, sustained growth from our software offerings, and better conditions in our primary end markets.
In this environment, we achieved core revenue growth and adjusted operating profit margins that surpassed the upper limit of our forecast, resulting in exceptional earnings growth and free cash flow conversion.
As we emphasized at our Investor Day on May 19, we are building upon our strong hardware positions and expanding our software capabilities to address our customers' crucial workflow requirements and speed up their ongoing digital transformation.
In the second quarter, our SaaS offerings grew by low double digits, and we also achieved significant improvements across our professional services offerings.
We continue to observe strong momentum at eMaint, including growing demand from its expansion into the food and beverage, pharmaceutical, and healthcare sectors.
Gordian and Accruent both had strong quarters as they capitalized on opportunities provided by increasing demand from facility owner operators and improved access to customer sites.
Both companies are well-positioned to benefit as customers focus on post-COVID return to work challenges and digital transformation priorities.
Centers also performed exceptionally well in the quarter as access to hospital customers improved, capitalizing on strong demand for its SaaS offerings among existing and new independent delivery network customers.
Examining the entire portfolio, we remain enthusiastic about our expanding range of EHS workflow solutions, which are well-positioned to meet our customers' significant long-term sustainability requirements.
ISC and Intellect performed well, taking advantage of strong broad-based growth across end-markets and key geographical regions.
Simultaneously, we are excited about the early progress at ehsAI, where the company secured its largest deal to date in its first joint marketing campaign with Intelex and generated strong growth in its sales pipeline.
Throughout the second quarter, we continued to apply the Fortive Business System across the portfolio to drive innovation, growth, and market share gains.
Implementation of our lean portfolio management toolset, which significantly accelerates the efficiency and impact of R&D investments, achieved a greater than 40% increase in our on-time program delivery.
The application of FBS and digital analytics and search optimization generated 25% growth in digital traffic from pre-pandemic levels across the portfolio.
Meanwhile, the use of FBS growth tools has accelerated innovation at Fluke Health Solutions over the past 18 months and continues to drive excellent top-line performance.
We have created good early momentum in our partnership with Pioneer Square Labs, including the recent spin-in of TeamSense, a provider of innovative workflow solutions to streamline communications with hourly workers.
This marks the first business incubated at Pioneer Square Labs to be integrated into the Fortive portfolio.
While still in its early stages, we are pleased with the progress thus far at TeamSense and are excited to develop additional technologies that accelerate safety and productivity solutions for customers within our core markets.
In early July, we announced the acquisition of ServiceChannel.
The transaction brings a differentiated high-growth software business with an integrated service provider network and significant proprietary data assets to the portfolio, enhancing our ability to meet the evolving needs of facility owners around the world.
Following the expected closing of the acquisition in Q3, we will have significant balance sheet capacity supported by our strong and resilient free cash flow generation.
As we highlighted at our Investor Day, we see substantial opportunities across our $40 billion served market for disciplined capital allocation to accelerate our strategy.
Turning to a brief summary of the results in the quarter on slide four, we generated year-over-year total revenue growth of 26.7% as revenue strength exceeded the high end of our guidance.
Adjusted operating margin was 22.2% while adjusted earnings per share was $0.66, representing a year-over-year increase of 53.5%.
Given the outperformance for both top line and our adjusted operating margin, we delivered $282 million of free cash flow, which represented 118% conversion of adjusted net income.
On slide five, we take a closer look at the Intelligent Operating Solutions segment.
iOS posted total revenue growth of 31.2% in the second quarter.
This included mid-20% core growth in North America, low 30% core growth in Western Europe, and low 20% core growth in China.
Fluke's core revenue increased in the mid-30% range.
Fluke also grew by mid-single digits on a sequential basis as we continue to see robust demand across its businesses, highlighted by growth at Fluke Industrial.
Fluke Industrial generated market share gains across a range of key channel partners and retail accounts as point-of-sale accelerated through the quarter.
Fluke's broader ii900 Acoustic Imaging product line also continues to perform very well, as revenue approximately doubled in the quarter on strong growth across both Western Europe and North America.
Fluke Networks' performance was boosted by the introduction of its LinkIQ product line, which has surpassed initial projections related to office reopenings and network changes.
In terms of Fluke reliability, efforts to enhance Pruftechnik's performance are gaining momentum as we capitalized on rising demand for alignment and other services, while eMaint also had another impressive quarter.
Due to the quickened pace of orders at Fluke, we experienced some backlog accumulation because of supply chain responsiveness.
Industrial Scientific grew by mid-teens, propelled by strong performance in instruments and rental as demand from oil and gas markets recovered and the business continued to expand into new markets.
The company's iNet offering remained strong, growing by mid single-digits with customer retention rate firmly above 100%.
Intelex experienced high single-digit growth in Q2, reporting its highest revenue quarter to date.
Intelex continues to utilize FBS and has improved lead generation and funnel conversion.
During the second quarter, Intelex also announced multiple deals for its enhanced ESG platform to assist customers in launching, scaling, and optimizing their sustainability programs and meeting increased demand for transparency on a growing set of critical non-financial reporting metrics.
Accruent grew by mid single-digits in the second quarter, with low double-digit growth in its SaaS business.
Accruent generated strong sales and bookings for its Meridian solution for engineering document management and its maintenance connection, CMMS offerings.
The business also took advantage of the strong demand for its EMS event, workspace and resource scheduling offerings as companies plan and implement their return-to-work strategies.
The company continues to acquire new customers and improve growth in recurring bookings.
Notably, Accruent also showed improved performance in its professional service business, which achieved mid single-digit growth as customer site access continued to improve.
Gordian grew by mid-teens, driven by low 20% growth in the procurement business and high teens growth in estimating.
Gordian achieved a record month for procurement revenue in June with accelerating timelines for key projects across several large customers.
This included increased project spending by the New York City Department of Education and School Construction Authority.
Let's move on to Slide six.
The Precision Technologies segment recorded a total revenue increase of 25.1% in the second quarter.
This included low 20% growth in North America, mid-20% growth in Western Europe and mid-teens growth in China.
Tektronix grew by approximately 30%, with another quarter of strong demand across its product businesses, including accelerating point-of-sale trends in each of its major regions.
Both mainstream and performance oscilloscopes had a strong quarter with high demand for semiconductor, industrial manufacturing and communications applications.
Tektronix's service business once again demonstrated its stability and resilience, increasing by low teens.
Tektronix continues to benefit from its accelerated focus on driving innovation, with Q2 new product introductions performing very well, including its family of automated test solutions for high-speed data transfer.
In the second quarter, Tektronix held six regional innovation forum events, which stimulated the adoption of its tech scope platform, resulting in accelerated funnel creation for the company's broader hardware and software offerings.
Sensing Technologies grew by low teens in the second quarter, with growth driven by the continuation of the broad market recovery.
Sensing performed exceptionally well in China with another quarter of mid-teens growth, driven by demand for factory automation solutions.
Elsewhere, Anderson-Negele continues to make progress with the approval of its paperless process recorder IoT solution aimed at the dairy industry, with broader commercial rollout expected in the second half of the year.
Sensing also continues to gain market share elsewhere across its portfolio, particularly in critical environment solutions and strong demand across its HVAC customers.
PacSci EMC grew in the low 20% range, with the business experiencing some relief from the COVID-related shutdowns and approval delays that impacted shipments in previous quarters.
PacSci EMC continues to see good growth in the commercial space market with the resumption of launches by OneWeb providing recurring revenue for smart controllers and initiators.
Additionally, on July 20, we were excited to watch the company's mission-critical technology ensure safe and reliable separation of Blue Origin's New Shepard capsule from its booster during its maiden voyage.
Let's move on to Advanced Healthcare Solutions on Slide seven.
Total revenue increased 21.8%, including 11% core growth.
This included high single-digit core growth in each of North America, Western Europe and China markets.
ASP grew by high single digits in the second quarter, led by strong growth in Western Europe and China.
ASP also experienced improved growth in North America, highlighted by high single-digit growth in the US.
Overall, ASP increased its consumable revenue by high teens as the rate of elective procedures across most geographies continued to improve.
Although elective procedure volumes increased year-over-year, Q2 volumes were slightly lower than expected at approximately 93% of pre-COVID levels, which was consistent with the Q1 exit rate.
ASP expanded its worldwide installed base of terminal sterilization equipment, which increased at a 3.5% annual rate during the second quarter.
The ongoing growth in installed base is expected to provide additional support for consumable revenue as procedure volumes return to normal in the future.
Censis experienced growth in the mid-20% range, with its CensiTrac SaaS offering growing in the mid-teens and strong performance in its professional services division.
Many hospitals are now permitting vendor access, resulting in a significant uptick in activity during the second quarter, especially with integrated delivery networks.
Fluke Health Solutions grew by low double digits despite facing a substantial COVID-related revenue boost in the previous year.
FHS witnessed high-teens growth from its Optimize and OneQA software solutions, benefiting from increased growth investments over the past 18 months.
I'll now hand over to Chuck, who will provide more details on our margins, free cash flow, and balance sheet.
We achieved solid margin performance in Q2, primarily due to strong follow-through on our revenue outperformance.
Adjusted gross margins reached 57.3%, a year-over-year increase of 100 basis points.
This improvement reflected 130 basis points of price realization as we continued to effectively manage price cost across the portfolio.
Q2 adjusted operating profit margin was 22.2%, exceeding the high end of our guidance by 170 basis points, also driven by higher volume and associated strong follow-through.
We reported 240 basis points of core operating margin expansion, including 570 basis points of core OMX in the iOS segment.
Both Fluke and Tektronix achieved strong core operating margin expansion through disciplined application of FBS to drive sales conversion as demand increased across their end markets.
Additionally, strong contributions from acquired companies such as ISC, Gordian, Censis, and LANDAUER contributed to margin outperformance across segments.
In the second quarter, we generated $282 million in free cash flow, representing a 118% conversion of adjusted net income.
Free cash flow over the past 12 months increased by 15% to $943 million.
Currently, our net leverage is approximately 1 times, and we anticipate it to be around 1.2 times by year-end, including the funding for the Service Channel acquisition but excluding any additional M&A.
This provides us with significant capacity to continue deploying capital towards our key allocation priorities.
Given our strong second-quarter performance and improved outlook for the rest of the year, we are raising our 2021 guidance once again.
For the full year, we now expect adjusted diluted net earnings per share to be between $2.65 and $2.75, representing year-over-year growth of 27% to 32% on a continuing operations basis.
This projection assumes total revenue growth of 13.5% to 15%, adjusted operating profit margins of 22.5% to 23.5%, and an effective tax rate of 14% to 14.5%.
It also assumes total revenue growth of 8.5% to 11% in the second half of 2021.
We continue to expect free cash flow conversion to be approximately 105% of adjusted net income for the full year.
We are initiating third-quarter adjusted diluted net earnings per share guidance of $0.62 to $0.66, representing year-over-year growth of 24% to 32%.
This assumes total revenue growth of 11.5% to 14.5%, adjusted operating profit margin of 21.5% to 22.5%, and an effective tax rate of 14% to 14.5%.
For the third quarter, we expect free cash flow conversion to be approximately 105% of adjusted net income.
I'll now hand it back to Jim for some concluding remarks.
Before moving to questions, I'd like to provide a brief update on our sustainability and inclusion and diversity efforts, as shown on slide 11.
During our Investor Day program on May 19, we introduced an accelerated greenhouse gas reduction goal, now targeting a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas intensity for Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions by 2025 relative to our 2017 base year.
In the second quarter, we also released our 2021 sustainability report, which included Fortive's second annual GRI index, first annual SASB index, and the 2017 to 2020 greenhouse gas emissions profile.
During the quarter, we also became a signatory to the UN Global Compact, committed to aligning with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures by 2022, and announced our 2025 aspirational inclusion and diversity goals.
We continue to make significant progress and are highly committed to accelerating our sustainability and inclusion and diversity efforts in the coming years.
Across all three of our strategic segments, we are building upon strong established positions with offerings that address the critical workflow needs of our customers and markets with attractive long-term growth drivers.
Our strong earnings and free cash flow performance in the first half of this year clearly demonstrated the benefits of this strategic focus and the momentum building in our portfolio.
Looking ahead, we will continue to invest in expanding the capabilities of the Fortive Business System as we accelerate operating improvements and innovation to increase the value we offer to our customers.
With strong free cash flow and significant M&A capacity, we are well-positioned to pursue key organic and inorganic growth initiatives that will drive consistent double-digit earnings and free cash flow growth in the years to come.
That concludes our formal comments.
Summary:
output:
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $2.65 to $2.75 from continuing operations.
sees q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.62 to $0.66 from continuing operations.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The information is also mentioned on the second page of our financial supplement.
Let's begin our conference call with introductory remarks from Dave Nunes, our President and CEO.
I'll start with some general observations before handing it over to Mark to discuss our overall financial performance.
Next, I'll invite Doug Long, our Senior Vice President of Forest Resources, to speak about our timber results in the U.S. and New Zealand.
After reviewing our timber performance, Mark will present our real estate outcomes and our projections for the remainder of 2021.
We entered 2021 with positive momentum across all our operations, showcasing the robustness and variety of our timber markets and the strategic positioning of our real estate holdings.
In Q1, we achieved an adjusted EBITDA of $70 million and pro forma earnings of $0.08 per share.
Our adjusted EBITDA surpassed the previous year's quarter by 47%, with favorable outcomes in New Zealand Timber, Pacific Northwest Timber, and Real Estate segments compensating for a slight decrease in adjusted EBITDA from our Southern Timber segment.
Reflecting on Q1, we're satisfied with our team's collaborative efforts to capitalize on robust domestic markets, improving real estate trends, and increasing demand for logs from China.
Let's examine our various operational divisions.
Our Southern Timber division produced an adjusted EBITDA of $32 million for the quarter, 5% lower than Q1 of the previous year.
A 7% rise in net stumpage prices and stronger nontimber sales were outweighed by an 18% reduction in harvest volumes due to the front-loaded nature of 2020 harvest activities and weather-related disruptions earlier this year.
In our Pacific Northwest Timber division, we attained an adjusted EBITDA of $18 million, an 81% improvement compared to the same quarter last year.
This strong performance can be attributed to a significant increase in log pricing driven by strong domestic demand and robust lumber markets, as well as higher volumes resulting from the Pope Resources acquisition.
In our New Zealand Timber division, Q1 adjusted EBITDA more than doubled to $21 million.
This year-over-year increase in adjusted EBITDA was due to considerably higher harvest volumes and sawtimber pricing, as Q1 2020 was severely impacted by COVID-19-related challenges.
Lastly, our Real Estate division generated an adjusted EBITDA of $5 million.
This year-over-year improvement was driven by an increase in acres sold, excluding the large disposition in 2020, amid growing buyer demand, as well as a 9% increase in weighted average prices.
While improved compared to the previous year's quarter as we anticipated entering the year, Q1 Real Estate activity was relatively light in the context of our full-year expectations due to the timing of closings.
Let's begin with page five, which displays our financial highlights.
Quarterly sales totaled $191 million, while pro forma sales amounted to $180 million.
Operating income was $29 million, and net income attributable to Rayonier was $11 million, or $0.08 per share.
After adjusting for the operating income attributable to the noncontrolling interest in our Timber Funds segment, pro forma operating income was $27 million.
Q1 adjusted EBITDA of $70 million exceeded the prior year quarter as higher results in our New Zealand Timber, Pacific Northwest Timber, and Real Estate segments more than offset a slightly lower contribution from our Southern Timber segment.
At the bottom of page five, we provide an overview of our capital resources and liquidity at quarter-end, along with a comparison to year-end figures.
Our cash available for distribution (CAD) for the quarter was $47 million, compared to $27 million in the prior year quarter, primarily due to higher adjusted EBITDA and lower capital expenditures, partially offset by higher cash taxes and interest.
A reconciliation of CAD to cash provided by operating activities and other GAAP measures is available on page seven of the financial supplement.
In line with our flexible approach to capital allocation, we raised $37 million through our at-the-market (ATM) equity offering program during Q1 at an average price of $33.31 per share.
As previously discussed, we view the ATM program as a cost-effective tool to opportunistically raise capital, strengthen our balance sheet, and match-fund bolt-on acquisitions.
In summary, we ended the quarter with $78 million in cash and $1.3 billion in debt, both excluding cash and debt attributable to the Timber Funds segment, which is nonrecourse to Rayonier.
Our net debt of $1.2 billion represented 21% of our enterprise value based on our closing stock price at the end of Q1.
Let's begin with page eight, focusing on our Southern Timber segment.
Q1 adjusted EBITDA of $32 million was $2 million below the prior year quarter.
The decrease compared to the previous year's quarter was largely due to an 18% reduction in harvest volumes, resulting from the front-loaded timing of 2020 activities and weather-related disruptions earlier this year.
Specifically, winter snowstorms in the Gulf region and wet ground conditions in Georgia led to lost production days compared to Q1 2020.
The decline in volumes during Q1 was partially offset by higher net stumpage prices and nontimber income.
Specifically, average sawlog stumpage pricing was approximately $28 per ton, a 3% increase compared to the prior year quarter.
Sawlog pricing is gradually improving as we successfully leverage continued lumber market strength into higher sawlog prices in certain U.S. South markets.
Furthermore, increased pricing tension due to growing demand for export-grade logs is becoming more apparent in our coastal markets.
However, pricing trends continue to vary significantly by region, underscoring the importance of local timber market dynamics.
Pulpwood pricing increased by 7% from the prior year quarter, reflecting the weather conditions that restricted supply during Q1 as well as a favorable mix shift toward our coastal Atlantic markets.
Overall, weighted average pine stumpage prices rose 8% compared to the prior year quarter, based on higher sawtimber and pulpwood prices as well as a more favorable mix of sawtimber.
Q1 nontimber sales of $8 million were $2 million above the prior year quarter.
The surge in comparison to the previous year's quarter was primarily due to a substantial pipeline easement sale.
Let's move on to discussing our Pacific Northwest Timber segment, which can be found on page nine.
Adjusted EBITDA reached $18 million, surpassing the prior year quarter by $8 million.
The year-on-year improvement was mainly attributed to strong domestic lumber markets, resulting in significantly better pricing.
The harvest volume in the first quarter exceeded that of the previous year's quarter by 13%.
This year-over-year increase was primarily driven by the additional volume from the Pope Resources acquisition last year.
Our average delivered sawlog price in the first quarter was $91 per ton, representing a 21% increase from the same quarter last year.
Despite domestic mills in the region maintaining sufficient log inventories, robust pricing persisted throughout the quarter.
In contrast, pulpwood pricing declined by 23% in the first quarter compared to the same period last year, due to an abundance of sawmill residuals amid increased lumber production.
It's worth noting that the Pacific Northwest is experiencing improved demand from the export market.
The restricted flow of European spruce salvage logs due to transportation constraints, combined with China's ban on Australian log imports, is resulting in increased demand for exports from the Pacific Northwest.
With domestic log demand already robust due to strong domestic lumber markets, we anticipate that increased export market demand will provide additional pricing support, particularly for whitewood species.
I'd like to briefly comment on the impact of last year's wildfires in the Pacific Northwest.
As a reminder, our fee timber properties were not directly affected by the fires, although approximately 10,000 acres of Timber Fund properties experienced some fire damage.
Consistent with our February update, our operations in the region have not been significantly impacted by others' salvage efforts.
There have been some localized increases in hauling costs in areas directly affected by the fires.
However, the location of our timberland, strong demand for green logs from many of our customers, and the consistent business we've provided to our logging crews in the region have resulted in minimal impact on our operations.
Overall, we are well-positioned to capitalize on strong domestic demand trends, improving export market conditions, and the favorable pricing environment we currently see in the Pacific Northwest, especially following last year's successful integration of Pope Resources.
Page 10 displays the results and key operating metrics for our New Zealand Timber segment.
The first quarter's adjusted EBITDA of $21 million was more than twice the $10 million reported in the same quarter of the previous year.
The increase in adjusted EBITDA was driven by significantly stronger pricing and a more normal level of harvest activity compared to the prior year period, which was constrained by COVID-19 disruptions.
Higher volumes and pricing were partially offset by reduced carbon credit sales.
We chose to postpone carbon credit sales during the quarter, anticipating further price appreciation due to recent changes in New Zealand's climate change goals and proposed modifications to the country's emissions trading scheme.
Export sawtimber average delivery prices rose by 28% from the prior year quarter to $120 per ton, reflecting improved trade demand and escalating trade tensions between China and Australia.
New Zealand log export pricing continues to benefit from China's ban on Australian log imports.
As previously noted, Australia was supplying approximately 10% of the total volume imported by China before the ban.
Furthermore, while the abundant supply of European spruce continues to compete for market share in China, availability has been temporarily constrained by higher shipping costs and container shortages.
Consequently, we have seen significant pricing upside in New Zealand on the export front, although this has been partially offset by substantially higher shipping costs.
We expect these costs to remain elevated given the global economic recovery and shipping demand for various commodities.
Turning to the New Zealand domestic market, average delivered sawlog prices increased by 16% from the prior year period to $81 per ton.
The increase in U.S. pricing was primarily driven by foreign exchange rates, as New Zealand domestic pricing improved by a more modest 4% in the first quarter compared to the prior year quarter.
Average domestic pulpwood pricing rose by 19% compared to the same quarter last year.
In summary, despite the recent increase in shipping costs, we believe our New Zealand operations are well-positioned to benefit from further strengthening of the Chinese economy, any prolonged reduction in log imports from Australia, and continued healthy domestic demand.
I'll now briefly discuss the results from our Timber Funds segment, highlighted on page 11.
The Timber Funds generated consolidated EBITDA of $7 million in the first quarter on a harvest volume of 145,000 tons.
Adjusted EBITDA, which reflects the look-through contribution from the Timber Funds, was $1 million.
Lastly, in our Trading segment, we reported $200,000 of adjusted EBITDA in the first quarter.
As a reminder, our trading activities typically generate low margins and are primarily designed to provide additional economies of scale to our fee timber export business.
As detailed on page 12, real estate closings were relatively modest during the first quarter, which aligned with our expectations and the guidance we provided earlier this year.
Specifically, sales totaled just over $10 million on approximately 2,400 acres sold at an average price of nearly $4,200 per acre.
Real estate adjusted EBITDA was $5 million in the first quarter.
The majority of first quarter sales were in the rural category.
Sales of rural land amounted to approximately $2,400, with 2,400 acres sold at an average price of nearly $4,100 per acre.
There has been a significant increase in demand for rural properties, as buyers are attracted to the space, privacy, and recreational opportunities these lands offer.
We anticipate this positive trend to continue, and we remain committed to achieving prices significantly higher than timberland values.
Improved development sales totaled about $250,000, comprising three residential lots in our Wildlight development project near Jacksonville, Florida, selling for an average of $84,000 per lot, or $406,000 per acre.
Although development closings were few this quarter, we are very optimistic about the pipeline we've built for the remainder of 2021.
The team is taking advantage of the growing demand for rural land and residential lots, as well as commercial parcels within our development projects.
We are confident that a combination of demographic shifts, record-low mortgage rates, and an increased need for space will benefit our various real estate sales categories.
Compared to the first quarter, we anticipate a substantial increase in the EBITDA contribution from our Real Estate segment over the next few quarters.
Specifically in development, there is currently strong demand from homebuilders for lots and entitled land with infrastructure.
We are pleased to announce that in February, Publix, a popular Florida-based supermarket chain, will anchor a new shopping center in Wildlight.
We expect that as this community becomes more established, interest from builders will continue to increase.
We are also encouraged by the potential opportunities for our properties in Richmond Hill, Georgia and the West Puget Sound area of Washington.
Let's now discuss our outlook for the year.
Given our strong start to 2021 and our expectation of a significant increase in real estate closings as the year progresses, we believe we are on track to achieve full-year adjusted EBITDA near the higher end of our previous guidance range of $285 million to $315 million.
In our Southern Timber segment, we expect to meet our full-year volume guidance of 6.2 million to 6.4 million tons, as we anticipate continued strong demand from lumber mills and improved export demand in select U.S. South markets.
We also continue to expect a slight improvement in weighted average pricing compared to last year, with quarterly variations primarily due to geographic mix.
For our Pacific Northwest Timber segment, we expect to achieve our full-year volume guidance of 1.7 million to 1.8 million tons.
However, since we advanced some volume into the first quarter to capitalize on favorable demand and pricing, we anticipate lower quarterly harvest volumes for the rest of the year.
We also expect that robust domestic lumber markets and increased export demand will maintain pricing at or above first quarter average prices throughout the year.
In our New Zealand Timber segment, we expect to meet our full-year volume guidance of 2.6 million to 2.8 million tons with higher quarterly harvest volumes for the remainder of the year.
We anticipate continued strong export and domestic demand, and we expect that the restriction on Australian log imports into China will limit competing log supplies.
We believe this positive operating momentum will result in log prices remaining near or above levels seen in the first quarter, partially offset by higher shipping costs.
For our Real Estate segment, we anticipate a significant increase in closings over the rest of the year based on our current pipeline of opportunities.
Our pipeline has expanded considerably as we've progressed through 2021, driving our increasingly optimistic sales outlook for residential and commercial properties within our real estate development projects.
Although first quarter closings were relatively low as expected, we remain confident that we will meet or exceed our previous full-year adjusted EBITDA guidance.
As we approach the one-year anniversary of the Pope Resources acquisition, which closed last May, we continue to be very satisfied with the integration process and the benefits realized from this transaction.
The addition of these high-quality assets and the integration of Pope's personnel into the Rayonier family has significantly increased our operational flexibility and market reach within the Pacific Northwest.
We've leveraged these improvements to our team and portfolio as market conditions have continued to improve over the past year.
Alongside the Pope integration, we've also continued to focus on other opportunities to grow and enhance our portfolio.
To this end, we completed $30 million of negotiated bolt-on timber acquisitions across the U.S. South at the beginning of 2021.
We also released our inaugural carbon report in March.
This report detailed the 5.7 million metric tons of net carbon sequestered by our forest operations in 2019 and demonstrates the crucial role that working forests play in combating climate change.
Rayonier's business model provides a natural solution to climate change.
Our trees absorb carbon from the atmosphere during their growth cycle.
After harvesting, a significant portion of this carbon remains stored for an extended period in downstream wood products.
Building on our inaugural carbon report, we plan to publish a comprehensive sustainability report this summer.
We believe our mission of providing industry-leading financial returns to our shareholders while acting as a responsible steward of our lands aligns well with the holistic approach embodied by greater adherence to ESG principles.
We are proud of the progress we've made in enhancing our ESG disclosures.
We look forward to further engagement on these important topics with our shareholders and other stakeholders in the future.
In conclusion, we are benefiting from strengthening end markets and continuing to make progress on several important strategic priorities.
I am very proud of our people's accomplishments and their unwavering commitment to building long-term value for our shareholders.
Despite the unprecedented challenges faced over the past year, our team is working diligently to better position the company for long-term success.
Summary:

in our pacific northwest timber segment, expect to achieve full-year volume guidance.

Progress on strategic priorities and long-term value creation

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our financial presentations provide a comparison between standard and adjusted financial measurements.
Essential refers to specific financial indicators that don't include the effects of the recent s::can and ATi purchases.
We consider this benchmark crucial for comparing performance from one year to the next.
I'm extremely impressed with our team's commitment and performance in supporting our clients and achieving record-breaking sales despite widespread supply chain inflation and logistical issues.
The strong order momentum from Q1 continued into Q2, and even with that robust performance, our backlog hit another all-time high as we concluded the second quarter.
Our newly acquired water quality businesses, s::can and ATi, exceeded our expectations with strong revenue growth and positive impact on earnings per share.
The quarter was exceptional, largely due to the consistent daily efforts and activities.
As shown on Slide 4, Q2 total sales reached $122.9 million, a 35% increase from the coronavirus-affected low of $91.1 million in the same period last year.
The overall utility water sales grew by 38%.
Excluding the roughly $12 million in sales from s::can and ATi acquisitions, core utility water revenues rose by 22% compared to the previous year.
When compared to the pre-COVID affected second quarter of 2019, core utility water sales increased by 11%.
As Ken mentioned, we continue to see strong orders, but supplier limitations on certain electronic components and other parts, along with logistical challenges, again restricted manufacturing output and deliveries.
We saw growth in overall meter sales and BEACON software as a service revenue, and we benefited from strategic value-based pricing strategies.
We ended the quarter with another record-high backlog, which is promising for our future sales projections.
As expected, the flow instrumentation product line's sales growth rate turned positive with a 22% year-over-year improvement, influenced by stabilizing demand across most global markets and applications, as well as an easier comparison base.
We were satisfied with the operating profit margins achieved in the quarter, considering the significant and diverse inflationary pressures.
The quarter's operating margin was 15.2%, representing a 130 basis point increase year-over-year.
The gross margin for the quarter reached 40.8%, a 150 basis point improvement compared to the previous year.
Margins benefited from favorable acquisition mix, higher volumes, positive product sales mix (particularly higher SaaS revenues), and successful value-based pricing implementation.
These factors collectively mitigated the cost pressures arising from increased brass prices and inflation in other components and logistics.
Examining copper more closely, prices have stabilized around $4.30 after reaching approximately $4.80 earlier in the quarter.
This aligns with our most recent estimate of the year-over-year cost increase, which was about $7 million to $8 million annually before mitigation efforts.
Our profit margins show that we've successfully implemented pricing strategies to counteract this inflation, and we'll continue to monitor prices closely in response to inflationary pressures.
Let's move on to SEA expenses.
Q2 expenditure of $31.4 million was consistent with Q1 2021's $31.6 million and shows an $8.2 million increase from the previous year.
You may remember that the previous year benefited from various cost-cutting measures implemented at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, including temporary layoffs.
The current SEA rate includes both s::can and ATi, along with increased amortization of acquired intangible assets, and aligns with our long-term expectations of normalized SEA leverage in the 25% to 26% range.
The second quarter 2021 income tax rate was 25%, slightly above the previous year's 24.3%.
To summarize, earnings per share reached $0.48 in Q2 2021, a 45% increase from $0.33 in the same period last year.
Working capital as a percentage of sales remained steady at 24.3% compared to the previous quarter.
Inventory levels rose due to manufacturing constraints and commodity inflation as mentioned earlier.
Free cash flow of $11.9 million was lower than the previous year, resulting from higher cash tax payments and increased inventory.
Year-to-date free cash flow conversion of net earnings stands at 147%.
We seized the opportunity to expand the facility to $150 million and enhance flexibility through leverage covenants and an accordion feature, among other improvements.
Our robust cash flow and borrowing capacity provide sufficient liquidity to fund our ongoing capital allocation priorities.
Let's move to Slide 5.
We've updated the chart introduced last quarter with actual Q2 data.
Given the numerous variables affecting both current and previous year comparisons, we believe this chart can help explain the uneven results we've experienced and will continue to see in our sales.
Our strong growth this quarter, excluding acquisitions, was driven by sustained high order rates and a record-high backlog at the start of the period.
This growth was partly due to easier comparisons with last year's second quarter, which was heavily impacted by COVID-19.
Our positive growth outlook for the latter half of the year is supported by continued strong orders and our record-high backlog.
The third quarter will face tough comparisons in sales and profitability due to last year's post-lockdown recovery in manufacturing output and orders.
Our supply chain team is working hard to address various shortages in electronic and other components.
While we don't anticipate a return to normalcy, we expect to convert more of our backlog as the year progresses.
We're pleased with the performance of our recent water quality acquisitions, which contributed over $12 million in revenue this quarter and showed double-digit pro forma growth.
The success of these acquisitions and our integration efforts supports our strategy of combining water quantity and quality solutions to accelerate our customers' digital transformations.
The significant increase in order rates over recent quarters confirms the strong market demand for smart water solutions that monitor, manage, and improve efficiency across water distribution systems.
We are well-positioned to serve both utility and industrial customers with our comprehensive range of intelligent water solutions for both quantity and quality.
Having a record backlog is a positive challenge that we expect to persist as we move through the second half of the year and beyond.
Component suppliers are making progress in rebuilding capacity, but the recovery will remain uneven until inventory levels can fully meet demand.
Despite challenges in component availability, inflation, and logistics, our teams are working to build supply chain resilience and maintain clear communication with suppliers and customers to manage expectations.
Our effective sourcing strategies, market-driven innovation, and operational flexibility are supporting Badger Meter's profitable growth and delivering value to shareholders.
We've added new ESG-related disclosures to our website, including how we align our efforts with UN Sustainable Development Goals and a SASB-focused report with annual metrics for 2020.
Badger Meter continues to advance its ESG initiatives, working to understand and mitigate the most significant risks of climate change and protect the world's water resources.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We always value your continued interest.
Our Chief Financial Officer, Brent Wood, is also joining us for this call.
We trust everyone is having a pleasant autumn season.
They maintain excellent performance and are benefiting from a highly favorable environment.
Our results for the third quarter were impressive, showcasing the durability of our portfolio and the industrial market.
The team's achievements include funds from operations exceeding expectations, showing a 14% increase compared to the same quarter last year and surpassing our projections.
This represents the 34th straight quarter of improved FFO per share compared to the corresponding quarter in the previous year, indicating a sustained long-term trend.
Our average quarterly occupancy reached 97.1%, an improvement of 50 basis points from the third quarter of 2020, and at the end of the quarter, we surpassed expectations with 98.8% leased and 97.6% occupied.
Our occupancy rates are improving due to a robust market driven by growing e-commerce and last-mile delivery trends.
Quarterly releasing spreads hit unprecedented levels at 37.4% GAAP and 23.9% cash, while year-to-date figures stand at 31% GAAP and 18.5% cash.
Lastly, cash same-store NOI increased by 5.2% for the quarter and 5.6% year-to-date.
In conclusion, I'm delighted with our team's performance, delivering one of the strongest quarters in our company's history.
Currently, we're capitalizing on the market's strength and the demand for industrial properties from both users and investors by concentrating on creating value through development and value-add investments.
I'm pleased that we concluded the quarter with a record-high 98.8% leased rate, and to illustrate the market's robustness, our past four quarters have marked the highest quarterly rates in our company's history.
Regarding Houston, we've achieved a 96.7% leased rate.
It now accounts for 12% of our rental income, a decrease of 140 basis points from last year, and is expected to continue declining.
Our company's development initiatives are driven by market demand, as previously mentioned.
We are increasing our projected starts to $340 million for 2021, given the current market strength we are observing.
This figure represents a new annual record for our company's development starts.
To meet this market demand, we have purchased several new locations and have more in the pipeline, along with value-add and direct investment opportunities.
We will provide more information as we finalize each of these deals.
Brent will now discuss various financial topics, including our guidance for 2021.
Our third quarter results showcase our team's excellent execution, the strong overall performance of our portfolio, and the continued success of our proven strategy.
The third quarter FFO per share surpassed our guidance range at $1.55, representing a 14% increase compared to $1.36 in the third quarter of 2020.
This outperformance is primarily due to our operating portfolio performing better than expected, especially in terms of occupancy and rental rate growth.
Regarding capital, we issued $49 million of equity during the third quarter at an average price exceeding $176 per share.
We paid off a maturing $40 million senior unsecured term loan in July.
In September, we refinanced a $100 million unsecured term loan, reducing the effective fixed interest rate from 2.75% to 2.1%, with a remaining term of five years.
As part of our ongoing commitment to enhance our ESG efforts, we included a sustainability-linked metric in the amended terms.
These actions, combined with our already robust and conservative balance sheet, maintained our position of financial strength and flexibility.
Our debt to total market capitalization was under 17%, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 4.7 times, and our interest and fixed charge coverage ratio improved to over 8.5 times.
Our rent collection performance has been equally impressive.
Uncollectible debt for the initial nine months of the year shows a positive balance of $346,000, attributed to tenants who previously had reserved balances but are now current, surpassing new tenant reserves
This pattern continues to demonstrate the reliability, financial strength, and varied nature of our tenant portfolio
Looking ahead, we anticipate FFO for the last quarter of 2021 to range between $1.54 and $1.58 per share, with a yearly estimate of $6.01 to $6.05, representing a $0.15 per share improvement from our earlier projection
The 2021 FFO per share median indicates a 12.1% growth compared to 2020
Our updated 2021 forecast includes significant changes such as: raising the cash same-property median by 8% to 5.6%, reducing reserves for uncollectible rent by $900,000, boosting projected development initiations by 24% to $340 million, and increasing combined equity and debt issuance by $95 million
To conclude, we are very satisfied with our performance in the third quarter
We will continue to leverage our financial robustness, our team's expertise, and the prime location and quality of our portfolio to maintain our momentum throughout the year
Marshall will now provide some concluding remarks
As we near the end of 2021, I'm thrilled with our current position
We're surpassing our initial projections and carrying this positive trend into 2022
Our company, team, and strategy are performing excellently, as demonstrated by our quarterly results
I'm most enthusiastic about EastGroup's future prospects
Our approach has proven successful in recent years
We're observing an acceleration in several positive trends for our properties and within our markets
Simultaneously, our core traditional tenants continue to require and will keep needing last-mile distribution facilities in rapidly expanding Sunbelt markets
These factors, combined with our team's composition, our operational strategy, and our market presence, make us optimistic about what's to come
Summary:

q3 ffo per share $1.55.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Craig Lampo, Amphenol's Chief Financial Officer, is speaking.
I'm joined by Adam Norwitt, our Chief Executive Officer.
I'll provide some financial insights, after which Adam will give a business overview and discuss current trends.
We'll then open the floor for questions.
Note that all share and per-share data mentioned in this earnings call reflects the post-split figures, following our two-for-one stock split on March 4, 2021.
In Q1, the company achieved sales of $2.377 billion, with GAAP and adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.53 and $0.52, respectively.
Compared to Q1 2020, sales grew by 28% in U.S. dollars, 25% in local currencies, and 23% organically.
Compared to the previous quarter, sales decreased by 2% in U.S. dollars, 3% in local currencies, and 4% organically.
The quarter's orders totaled $2.734 billion, showing a 27% increase from Q1 2020 and a 9% sequential increase, resulting in a robust book-to-bill ratio of 1.15:1.
Let's break down our sales by segment.
The interconnect business, accounting for 96% of sales, saw a 28% increase in U.S. dollars and a 25% increase in local currencies compared to Q1 last year.
Our cable business, making up 4% of sales, experienced a 17% increase in U.S. dollars and an 18% increase in local currencies compared to Q1 last year.
Adam will provide more details on market trends shortly.
Q1 2021 operating income reached $465 million.
The operating margin of 19.6% decreased by 100 basis points sequentially compared to Q4 2020's adjusted operating margin, but increased by a substantial 260 basis points compared to Q1 2020.
The year-over-year margin improvement was primarily due to normal operating leverage on higher sales volumes and reduced COVID-19 related costs, partially offset by a more challenging commodity and supply chain environment.
The sequential margin decline was attributed to normal conversion on lower sales levels and the aforementioned challenging commodity and supply chain conditions.
In the interconnect segment, Q1 2021 margins were 21.5%, up from 19.1% in Q1 2020 but down 100 basis points sequentially.
The cable segment saw margins of 8.8%, an increase from 7.6% in Q1 2020 but a decrease from 10.3% in Q4.
We're extremely proud of the company's performance given the ongoing challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our team's ability to navigate this crisis effectively is a direct result of our entrepreneurial management team's strength and commitment, fostering a high-performance, action-oriented culture that has allowed us to capitalize on numerous opportunities for incremental sales while driving strong operating performance in this dynamic market environment.
The company's Q1 GAAP effective tax rate was 23.9%, compared to 15.9% in Q1 2020.
On an adjusted basis, the effective tax rate was 24.5% in Q1 of both 2021 and 2020.
GAAP diluted earnings per share increased by 33% to $0.53, up from $0.40 in the same period last year.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share rose by 49% to $0.52, compared to $0.35 in Q1 2020.
The company continues to demonstrate excellent cash generation abilities.
Q1 cash flow from operations totaled $321 million, or 97% of GAAP net income.
After accounting for capital spending, free cash flow was $243 million, or 74% of net income.
Regarding working capital, inventory days, days sales outstanding, and payable days were 85, 73, and 59 days respectively, all within normal ranges.
During Q1, the company bought back 2.4 million shares of common stock for approximately $153 million.
In April, the company repurchased the small remaining amount of stock authorized under the existing stock repurchase plan.
The high cash balance at the end of Q1 was due to borrowings under the company's U.S. commercial paper program in anticipation of the MTS acquisition closing in early April.
Total debt stood at $4.6 billion, with net debt at $2.3 billion.
Total available liquidity at quarter-end was $4.1 billion, including cash and short-term investments on hand.
Q1 2021 EBITDA was $559 million, with a net leverage ratio of 1.0 times.
On April 7, following the quarter's end, we finalized the MTS acquisition, which Adam will discuss in more detail later.
The MTS acquisition was funded through a combination of cash and cash equivalents on hand, along with additional borrowings under the company's U.S. commercial paper program.
Including the MTS acquisition and the anticipated divestiture of the test and simulation business, pro forma total available liquidity and net leverage as of March 31, 2020, would be $3.2 billion and 1.4 times, respectively.
Until the sale of the MTS test and simulation business is complete, we will report it as a discontinued operation.
As such, the expected sales and earnings from this business are not included in our guidance.
Our guidance also excludes approximately $85 million or $0.12 per share in cash and non-cash expenses related to the MTS acquisition, to be expensed in Q2.
These expenses include costs related to early debt extinguishment, non-cash purchase accounting-related expenses, external transaction expenses, severance, and other costs.
The company will incur additional cash tax-related and other acquisition-related costs in connection with the test and simulation business divestiture, which will not be included in income from continuing operations.
Our guidance incorporates the expected results of the MTS Sensors business, which is anticipated to generate $350 million in sales and $0.05 in diluted earnings per share in the first 12 months after closing, as previously announced.
I sincerely hope that you, your loved ones, friends, and colleagues are staying safe and healthy.
As Craig mentioned, I'll now highlight our Q1 achievements.
I'll then discuss our trends and progress across our diverse served markets.
To conclude, I'll share some thoughts on our second quarter outlook.
We'll open the floor for questions and answers afterwards.
Our first quarter performance significantly exceeded our projections, surpassing the upper range of our guidance for both revenue and adjusted earnings per share.
Revenue expanded robustly by 28% in USD and 25% in local currencies.
Organic revenue growth reached 23%.
We experienced organic growth across nearly all our market segments, with particularly strong performance in automotive, mobile devices, industrial, and IT datacom sectors.
We achieved record bookings of $2.734 billion in the quarter, resulting in an impressive book-to-bill ratio of 1.15:1.
Despite ongoing pandemic-related operational challenges and increased costs due to commodity and supply chain pressures, our operating margins remained healthy at 19.6%, representing a 260 basis point improvement year-over-year.
Our adjusted earnings per share saw a substantial 49% increase compared to the previous year, showcasing the Amphenol organization's strong execution.
We generated operating and free cash flows of $321 million and $243 million respectively in the first quarter, clearly demonstrating the high quality of our earnings.
I'm extremely proud of our team's performance this quarter.
Our results once again highlight the discipline and adaptability of our entrepreneurial organization as we continue to excel in a dynamic and challenging environment.
I'd like to discuss our recent acquisitions.
We successfully completed the acquisition of MTS Systems earlier than anticipated, as announced on April 7.
We've agreed to sell the MTS test and simulation business to Illinois Tool Works for $750 million, subject to post-closing adjustments and excluding transaction-related expenses.
We anticipate this sale to finalize upon receiving all necessary regulatory approvals.
We're particularly excited about the combined strength of our complementary sensor product portfolios, which we believe will allow us to offer customers an expanded range of innovative technologies across multiple markets.
We expect the MTS Sensors business to contribute approximately $350 million in sales and $0.05 in adjusted earnings per share in the first year after closing.
More importantly, we look forward to realizing the long-term benefits of the combined strengths of Amphenol and MTS Sensors for years to come.
This significant acquisition has positioned Amphenol as one of the most diverse and comprehensive sensor companies in the industry.
We also completed two smaller acquisitions in the first quarter.
In February, we acquired Euromicron, a German manufacturer of advanced fiber optic interconnect solutions for mobile networks and IT datacom markets, with annual sales of about $25 million.
In March, we acquired Cabelcon from Corning Inc., a Denmark-based designer and manufacturer of high-tech connectors and interconnect assemblies for the European broadband market, also with annual sales of approximately $25 million.
Our ability to identify, execute, and successfully integrate acquisitions remains a core competitive advantage for our company.
Regarding trends across our served markets, we continue to benefit from our balanced and diverse end market exposure.
This diversification helps mitigate the impact of volatility in individual markets while exposing us to leading technologies across the electronics industry.
In the military market, which represented 11% of our quarterly sales, we saw 3% growth year-over-year, with flat organic growth.
We expect low double-digit growth in the second quarter, benefiting from the addition of MTS Sensors and increased demand for interconnect products.
The commercial aerospace market, accounting for 2% of our sales, experienced a significant 47% decline year-over-year due to pandemic-related disruptions.
We anticipate sequential improvement in the second quarter, aided by our recent acquisitions.
The industrial market, representing 24% of our sales, saw strong 33% growth in both U.S. dollars and organically.
This growth was driven by robust performance across various segments, including battery and electric heavy vehicles, rail mass transit, heavy equipment, instrumentation, factory automation, alternative energy, and medical applications.
For the upcoming second quarter, we anticipate the industrial market to grow by low double digits compared to the first quarter.
We expect to benefit from incorporating MTS Sensors while gaining traction in various industrial market segments.
The MTS Sensors acquisition has broadened our industrial sensor portfolio, adding sensors for position, vibration, force, and shock used in numerous industrial applications.
Combined with our existing sensor operations, we now offer a diverse range of sensors covering nearly all segments of the industrial market we serve.
I continue to be extremely proud of our global team working in the industrial market.
Our advanced interconnect, antenna, and sensor offerings put us in a strong position with customers who are increasingly adopting electronics across all applications.
The automotive sector accounted for 22% of our quarterly sales, significantly outperforming expectations with 52% growth in U.S. dollars and 44% organic growth, as our team executed well during a strong and widespread recovery in the automotive market.
We observed particularly robust growth in our products used in electric and hybrid electric vehicles during the quarter.
This serves as excellent validation of our global team's long-term efforts to integrate high-voltage and other interconnect and sensor products into these crucial next-generation platforms.
Our sales increased by 6% compared to the fourth quarter.
The automotive industry is currently facing various supply chain challenges, as widely reported.
Consequently, we anticipate a slight sequential decrease in sales for the second quarter due to temporary impacts on certain areas of new vehicle production caused by global supply chain disruptions.
I'm extremely impressed by our automotive market team's performance.
They have demonstrated remarkable flexibility and resilience during these turbulent times, thereby solidifying the company's position with our automotive market customers.
We anticipate reaping the benefits of their efforts well into the future.
The mobile devices market represented 12% of our quarterly sales.
Sales in this market increased by a better-than-expected 51% year-over-year, with strength across all product types, particularly in wearables and laptops.
Sequentially, our sales declined by 35%, slightly better than our expectations and within the typical range of first quarter seasonality for the mobile devices market.
Looking ahead to the second quarter, we expect a further sequential sales decline in the high single digits, which is also not unusual for this market during the second quarter.
Although mobile devices will always remain one of our most volatile markets, our exceptional and uniquely adaptable team is ready to seize any opportunities for additional sales that may arise in 2021 and beyond.
Our leading range of antennas, interconnect products, and mechanisms continues to enable various next-generation mobile devices, positioning us favorably for the long term.
Turning to the mobile networks market, it accounted for 6% of our quarterly sales, with a 4% growth in U.S. dollars and 1% organic growth year-over-year, as strength in products sold to OEMs was partially offset by a moderation in sales to network operators.
We were pleased to achieve better-than-expected sequential growth of 19% in the mobile networks market this quarter as mobile network operators increased spending on next-generation networks.
For the second quarter, we anticipate a modest increase in sales from first quarter levels, aided by the addition of Euromicron, which expands our offerings for mobile network operators in Europe and positions us well to support future network upgrades.
Our team continues to work aggressively to expand our position in next-generation equipment and systems worldwide.
As our customers ramp up investment in these advanced networks, we look forward to benefiting from the increased potential that comes from our unique position with both original equipment manufacturers and mobile network service providers.
The information technology and data communications market represented 19% of our quarterly sales.
Sales in this quarter exceeded expectations, increasing by 25% in U.S. dollars and 24% organically year-over-year, driven by broad-based strength across networking, storage, and server applications.
While we had anticipated a decline from the fourth quarter, we were pleased to achieve a sequential growth of 6% as customers continued to increase demand for our high-technology products used by service providers and in data centers worldwide.
Looking ahead to the second quarter, we expect a further mid-single digit increase in sales from these levels as customer demand continues to accelerate.
We remain very encouraged by the company's outstanding technology position in the global IT datacom market.
Our customers worldwide are undoubtedly continuing to push their equipment to higher performance levels to manage the dramatic increases in demand for bandwidth and processing power.
In response, our team remains singularly focused on enabling this ongoing revolution in IT datacom with our unique high-speed, power, and other interconnect products.
The broadband market accounted for 4% of our quarterly sales, with a robust 16% growth year-over-year as broadband spending levels remained elevated.
Sales grew slightly from the fourth quarter on a sequential basis.
We anticipate a high-teens sequential sales increase in the second quarter as customers continue to upgrade their network capacity to support the significant increase in bandwidth demand and as we benefit from recent acquisitions, including Cabelcon.
The addition of Cabelcon expands our offering for broadband customers in the European market, allowing us to provide a more diverse range of products for their next-generation networks and related upgrades.
We look forward to continuing to offer this expanded product range to broadband service operators worldwide, all of whom are working to increase bandwidth to support the expansion of high-speed data applications for homes and businesses.
Regarding our outlook, considering the current dynamic market environment and assuming no new material disruptions from the COVID-19 pandemic and constant exchange rates, we expect second-quarter sales in the range of $2.415 billion to $2.475 billion and adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $0.53 to $0.55.
This would represent strong sales growth of 22% to 25% and adjusted diluted earnings per share growth of 33% to 38% compared to the second quarter of last year.
It's worth noting that the second quarter of last year was already a strong recovery quarter for the company following the first quarter.
I remain confident in our outstanding management team's ability to adapt to ongoing market challenges and capitalize on the many future opportunities to grow our market position and expand our profitability.
The entire Amphenol organization remains committed to delivering long-term sustainable value while prioritizing the continued safety and health of each of our employees worldwide.
Summary:
