input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am joined today by Todd Bluedorn, the Chairman and CEO, along with Joe Reitmeier, our CFO.
Todd will highlight key aspects of the quarter, and Joe will present the company's financial results and projections for 2021.
To ensure everyone has a chance to inquire during the Q&A session, please restrict yourself to a couple of questions or follow-ups and rejoin the queue for any additional inquiries.
All comparisons made today are in relation to the same period last year.
For details about these risks and uncertainties, please refer to Lennox International's publicly accessible SEC filings.
During the first quarter, we observed continued strong performance in our Residential segment, along with significant improvements in Commercial and Refrigeration, leading to new first quarter records for the company in revenue, profit, and earnings per share.
The company's overall revenue increased by 29% to a new first quarter high of $931 million.
Revenue grew by 28% when adjusted for constant currency.
GAAP operating income reached a first quarter record of $114 million, increasing by 213%.
GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations hit a first quarter record of $2.20, growing by 588%.
The total segment profit surged by 208% to a first quarter record of $116 million.
The total segment margin expanded by 720 basis points to 12.4%, and adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations increased by 305% to a first quarter record of $2.27.
Examining our business segments for the first quarter, we achieved double-digit revenue growth and margin expansion across all three divisions.
In the Residential segment, we established new first quarter records for both revenue and profit.
Residential revenue increased by 37%.
The segment's profit rose by 197%, and its margin expanded by 850 basis points to 15.9%.
The replacement business grew by over 40%, while new construction increased by more than 25%.
Comparing our Lennox and Allied businesses, Lennox revenue grew by about 25%, while Allied revenue increased by approximately 70%.
Allow me to elaborate on the strong performance we witnessed in the Residential segment this quarter.
Firstly, our Residential team is effectively leveraging their operational capabilities to meet contractor and distributor demand, resulting in market share gains.
Following the 2018 tornado and the initial impact of the 2020 pandemic, we have resumed our offensive strategy in production, distribution, and market share growth.
Secondly, the Residential segment benefited from colder winter weather, with heating degree days increasing by 13% compared to the first quarter of last year.
It's worth noting that we experienced a weak first quarter in 2020.
Thirdly, I'd like to point out that we had a 6% revenue boost due to additional days in this quarter compared to last year.
This adjustment occurs every four years as we realign the calendar.
Conversely, the fourth quarter will face a 6% headwind due to fewer days this year.
This applies to all our business segments, including Residential.
Accounting for the additional days, Residential growth was 31%, with Lennox growing nearly 20% and Allied growing about 65%.
Furthermore, Allied experienced approximately $25 million in early sales this quarter due to different distributor loading patterns compared to last year.
Adjusting for both the additional days and this early sales activity, Allied's growth was approximately 35% for the quarter.
Considering all these factors, and adjusting for the additional days and early sales in our Allied business, which sells to independent distributors, the overall Residential segment revenue increased by about 25%.
We believe this outperforms the industry's mid-teen sell-through, partly driven by the favorable cold weather I mentioned earlier.
Our performance above the industry average is attributed to market share gains.
As previously stated, we have resumed our offensive strategy in production, distribution, and market share growth.
The team has demonstrated strong operational execution to drive this outperformance, and we are well-prepared for the upcoming summer season and our most significant quarters.
In the Commercial segment, we achieved first quarter records for revenue, segment profit, and margin.
Revenue increased by 12%.
When adjusted for constant currency, revenue grew by 11%.
Segment profit rose by 47%, and the segment margin expanded by 330 basis points to 13.8%.
During the first quarter, we observed broad strength in the Commercial segment, with year-over-year growth turning positive across all our businesses.
At constant currency, Commercial equipment revenue grew by mid-teens in the quarter.
Within this category, replacement revenue increased by mid-teens, with planned replacement up by mid-teens and emergency replacement up by high teens.
New construction revenue grew by high single digits.
Analyzing revenue from another perspective, regional and local business revenue increased by mid-teens, and national account equipment revenue also grew by mid-teens.
Our team secured three new national account equipment customers during the quarter.
The revenue from National Accounts Services on the service side increased by mid-single digits.
VRF revenue grew by approximately 35%.
There are several noteworthy points to discuss regarding Commercial.
We are particularly interested in expanding our presence in the education sector.
We have allocated specific sales personnel and product offerings to capitalize on a long-term growth opportunity in this market.
Currently, K-12 schools account for slightly less than 10% of equipment revenue in this segment.
This sector experienced over 20% growth for us in Q1.
Given the recent stimulus package supporting HVAC and indoor air quality improvements in schools, we anticipate K-12 schools will be a growing vertical for us in the future.
Improving indoor air quality remains a key priority for us through our building better air initiatives.
The majority of interest and activity we're observing is in the K-12 school segment, but discussions are occurring with clients across various industries.
We've introduced our new Model L Rooftop unit, maintaining our leadership in energy efficiency.
The Model L incorporates variable speed technology and a cutting-edge control system.
We're experiencing strong customer interest in this industry-leading product for 2021 and beyond.
Overall, Commercial is entering Q2 with positive momentum, evidenced by double-digit backlog growth and robust order rates.
Refrigeration revenue increased by 21% in Q1.
At constant currency, revenue grew by 17%.
North American revenue rose by over 25%.
European Refrigeration revenue increased by low single digits at constant currency, while European HVAC revenue grew by mid-single digits at constant currency.
Refrigeration segment margin improved by 560 basis points to 6.3%.
Segment profit increased to $8 million from $1 million in the same quarter last year.
Similar to Commercial, Refrigeration is entering Q2 with strong momentum, as evidenced by double-digit backlog growth and robust order flow, particularly in North America.
Due to the company's strong Q1 performance and positive outlook for Q2 and the full year, we are revising our 2021 guidance upward.
We now anticipate 7% to 11% revenue growth and adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations of $11.40 to $12.
We are also increasing our free cash flow guidance to $375 million for the full year.
We now expect about 55% of earnings to occur in the first half of the year, compared to our previous guidance of about 50%.
This adjustment reflects the strong Q1 performance and Q2 outlook.
We repurchased $200 million of stock in Q1 and plan to repurchase another $200 million, totaling $400 million in our guidance for the year.
I will provide additional comments and financial details on the business segments for the quarter, beginning with Residential Heating & Cooling.
Residential Heating & Cooling revenue reached a Q1 record of $606 million, up 37%.
Volume increased by 32%.
Price rose by 1% and mix improved by 4%.
Foreign exchange had no impact on revenue.
Residential profit hit a Q1 record of $96 million, up 197%.
Segment margin expanded by 850 basis points to 15.9%.
Segment profit was primarily influenced by higher volume, favorable price and mix, increased factory productivity, sourcing and engineering-led cost reductions, distribution and freight savings, and favorable foreign exchange.
These were partially offset by higher commodity, warranty and other product costs, as well as increased SG&A.
Moving on to our Commercial Heating & Cooling business.
Commercial revenue reached a Q1 record of $199 million, up 12%.
Volume increased by 15%.
Price remained flat and mix decreased by 4%.
Foreign exchange contributed a positive 1% to revenue growth.
Commercial segment profit achieved a Q1 record of $27 million, up 47%.
Segment margin was a Q1 record 13.8%, an increase of 330 basis points.
Segment profit was primarily influenced by higher volume, lower material costs, and reduced SG&A.
These were partially offset by unfavorable mix.
Refrigeration revenue reached $125 million, showing a 21% increase.
The volume increased by 15%.
There was a 1% rise in both price and product mix.
Currency exchange contributed positively to revenue growth by 4%.
The Refrigeration segment's profit in Q1 was $8 million, compared to $1 million in the same period last year.
The segment's margin improved by 560 basis points, reaching 6.3%.
The segment's profit was mainly influenced by increased volume, better pricing and mix, reduced material costs, and improved factory efficiency.
Increased SG&A expenses partially offset these gains.
The company reported net after-tax charges of $2.7 million in Q1, including a $2 million net charge for tax-related items, a $1.9 million net charge for various other items, and a $1.2 million benefit from excess tax advantages related to share-based compensation.
Corporate expenses in Q1 were $16 million, up from $14 million in the same quarter last year.
SG&A expenses totaled $145 million, an increase from $131 million in the previous year's quarter.
SG&A as a percentage of revenue decreased to 15.6% from 18.1% in the prior quarter.
The company used $18 million in cash from operations in Q1, an improvement from the $99 million used in the same period last year.
Capital expenditures remained steady at approximately $24 million in both Q1 of this year and last year.
Free cash flow was negative $42 million in Q1, better than the negative $123 million in the previous quarter.
The company distributed about $30 million in dividends and bought back $200 million worth of stock during the quarter.
At the end of Q1, total debt stood at $1.17 billion, with a debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.8.
Cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments totaled $40 million at the quarter's end.
The company now anticipates high single-digit growth in shipments for Residential, Commercial Unitary, and Refrigeration markets for the full year, up from the previous expectation of mid-single-digit growth.
The company has increased its 2021 revenue growth guidance from a 4-8% range to a new range of 7-11%, with foreign exchange still expected to have a neutral impact on revenue for the year.
The company has raised its 2021 GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations guidance from $10.55-$11.15 to $11.33-$11.93, and adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations from $10.55-$11.15 to $11.40-$12.
Let's review the key changes and consistencies in our guidance assumptions for 2021.
We've announced a second round of price increases and now expect a $90 million benefit from pricing, up from the previous $50 million estimate.
Our residential mix projection has improved to a $10 million benefit, up from our earlier neutral mix forecast.
We anticipate a $15 million benefit from sourcing and engineering-led cost reduction initiatives, down from the previous $25 million estimate due to supplier-driven inflationary pressures.
We now project a $55 million headwind from commodities, an increase from the earlier $30 million estimate.
Corporate expenses are expected to reach approximately $95 million, up from the previous $90 million forecast, mainly due to higher incentive compensation.
We maintain our expectation of a $20 million benefit from factory productivity.
With 30 new Lennox Stores planned this year, our distribution investments will return to a more typical level compared to last year.
We still anticipate a $5 million headwind each from freight and tariffs.
We plan for a 7% increase in SG&A, representing a headwind of about $45 million.
Within SG&A, we're investing in R&D and IT to maintain our leadership in products, controls, eCommerce, and factory automation and productivity.
We continue to expect neutral foreign exchange impact.
Interest and pension expenses are still projected to be around $35 million.
We maintain our expectation of an approximately 21% effective tax rate on an adjusted basis for the full year.
Capital expenditures are still planned at about $135 million this year, with $30 million allocated for the third plant at our Mexico campus.
We expect to complete construction by the end of 2021 and have the plant fully operational by mid-2022, anticipating nearly $10 million in annual savings from this expansion.
We've increased our free cash flow target to approximately $375 million for the full year, up from the previous $325 million, based on strong Q1 earnings and our current outlook.
We maintain our expectation of a weighted average diluted share count between 37 million to 38 million for the full year, incorporating our plan to repurchase $400 million of stock this year.
Let's proceed to the Q&A session.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Dan Amos, the Chairman and CEO of Aflac Incorporated, will commence by providing an overview of the company's operations in Japan and the United States
Fred Crawford, Aflac Incorporated's President and COO, will then briefly discuss the quarterly conditions and key initiatives, including the company's approach to managing the pandemic
The Q&A portion of the call will include several members of Aflac's US executive management team, as well as executives from Aflac Life Insurance Japan
Some statements in this teleconference are forward-looking as defined by federal securities laws, but their accuracy cannot be guaranteed due to their prospective nature
Actual outcomes may differ significantly from today's discussion, and we encourage reviewing our Annual Report on Form 10-K for various risk factors that could materially impact our results
Our website, aflac.com, provides reconciliations of certain non-US GAAP measures
Dan will now take over the call
During our first quarter conference call a year ago, we were in the early stages of the pandemic, and I shared the actions we took to protect our employees, distribution partners, policyholders, and communities
Our response to these challenging times and our ability to handle them make me proud
Our "People First" philosophy embodies our corporate culture, which we call the Aflac Way
We are encouraged by the production and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines, but we recognize that vaccination efforts are still in early stages globally
Our thoughts are with those affected, and we remain cautiously optimistic while staying vigilant
I consistently emphasize to our management team the importance of controlling what we can and continuously monitoring what we can't control to be ready to adapt
This approach allows us to respond most effectively
In the first quarter, adjusted earnings per diluted share rose by 26.4%, largely due to low benefit ratios associated with pandemic conditions
Pandemic conditions in the first quarter continued to affect our sales results, earned premiums, and revenues in both the United States and Japan
We anticipate these conditions to persist through the first half of 2021, with improvement expected in the second half as communities and businesses open up more, allowing increased face-to-face interactions
Despite suppressed sales due to limited face-to-face opportunities, we continued to progress in integrating our accelerated investment in our platform while maintaining strong earnings performance
Aflac Japan generated solid financial results in the first quarter, with a profit margin of 23.1%, exceeding the outlook range provided at the Financial Analyst briefing
Aflac Japan also reported strong premium persistency of 95%
First quarter sales in Japan were essentially flat, following the January launch of our new medical product, despite ongoing pandemic conditions
We are encouraged by the reception of the new medical product by both consumers and the sales force
Japan Post Group's announcement to resume proactive sales in April paves the way for gradual improvement in Aflac Cancer Insurance sales in the second half of the year
We are actively preparing the platform with Japan Post, recognizing that returning to full strength will take time
We continue to navigate evolving pandemic conditions in Japan, including the recent reinstatement of a state of emergency in Tokyo, Osaka, and two other prefectures from April 25th to May 11th
Restrictions will be tightened to limit people's movement and group activities during the major holiday known as Golden Week
In the US, we saw a strong profit margin of 27.3%, and Aflac US reported very strong premium persistency of 80%
Current pandemic conditions continue to significantly impact our sales results, primarily due to reduced face-to-face activity
As expected, we observed modest sequential sales improvement in the quarter, with an overall decrease of 22.1%
Small businesses in the US are still in recovery mode, which we expect to continue for most of 2021
Larger businesses remain focused on returning employees to the workplace rather than modifying employee benefits
We aim to be where people want to purchase insurance in both Japan and the United States
Traditionally, this meant face-to-face meetings to understand individual situations, propose solutions, and close sales
While face-to-face sales remain the most effective way to convey the financial protection Aflac products provide, the pandemic has clearly demonstrated the need for virtual, non-face-to-face sales methods
We had been working on building our virtual capacities even before the pandemic, and we have since accelerated investments to enhance tools available to our distribution in both countries
We continue to integrate these investments into our operations
We are also expanding the US product portfolio with previously acquired businesses that serve as a foundation for Aflac network dental and vision, as well as group absence management and disability
Although these acquisitions have a modest near-term impact on the top line, they better position Aflac for future long-term success in the United States
Our core earnings drivers, including persistency, underwriting profits, investment income, and expense ratios, continue to drive strong pre-tax margins in both the United States and Japan
Both Japan and the US experienced sequential sales growth in January, February, and March
Assuming no setbacks in pandemic conditions, we forecast a sequential increase in absolute sales for the second quarter compared to the first quarter in both the US and Japan
We prioritize maintaining strong capital ratios in the US and Japan for the benefit of our policyholders and shareholders
We remain committed to prudent liquidity and capital management
In March, we issued our first sustainability bond, aiming to allocate proceeds to reinforce our commitment to social and environmental initiatives while balancing purpose and profit
We value our 38-year track record of dividend growth and are committed to extending it, supported by our strong capital and cash flows
We will continue to tactically repurchase shares and focus on integrating the growth investments we've made in our platform
By doing so, we aim to emerge from this period in a continued position of strength and leadership
I've always believed that true strength is demonstrated by how one handles adversity
The events of the past year have reinforced my belief in Aflac's strength, flexibility, and resilience.
We aim to sustain long-term growth while fulfilling our commitments to policyholders.
Our goal is to emerge from this period maintaining our strong position and industry leadership.
I believe our success is linked to our focus on doing right by our policyholders, shareholders, employees, sales teams, business partners, and communities.
In my view, success and ethical conduct are inseparable.
I take pride in our ability to balance purpose with financial performance.
This approach has ultimately resulted in robust, long-term value for shareholders.
I'll now hand over to Fred.
I'll briefly discuss the current pandemic situation in Japan and the US, then focus on our efforts to rebuild our production platform in 2021.
Since the start of the pandemic, Japan has recorded about 575,000 COVID cases and 10,000 confirmed fatalities.
From the beginning of the outbreak through Q1 2021, Aflac Japan has handled roughly 10,500 COVID-related claims, totaling JPY1.9 billion in incurred claims.
We're still seeing fewer claims for non-COVID medical conditions, as people avoid routine hospital visits.
Our strategy to return to pre-pandemic production levels in Japan focuses on three main areas.
We're updating our traditional products, boosting online sales productivity during the pandemic, and actively working with Japan Post to revive cancer insurance sales.
As Dan mentioned, our revised medical product has been well-received.
This product was designed to be more competitive in the independent agent channel, where we had been losing market share before 2020.
Medical insurance sales have increased by 34% compared to Q1 2020 and by 8% compared to Q1 2019.
Our new product, EVER Prime, offers enhanced benefits that typically result in 5% to 10% higher premiums per policy compared to our previous medical product.
The product also includes a low-claims bonus feature that has attracted younger customers.
We've implemented technology allowing agents to switch from face-to-face to virtual sales, providing a fully digital customer experience.
The agent remains involved in the process.
Agents can complete the entire sales process online, from initial contact to policy issuance, without face-to-face interaction.
We introduced this capability in October 2020, and in November, we processed 1,600 applications using this digital platform.
By March, this number had doubled to about 3,200 applications.
As expected, younger demographics are adopting this technology more quickly.
On March 26, we launched a national ad campaign promoting this capability and anticipate increased usage.
We expect this feature to boost productivity even after the pandemic subsides.
Regarding Japan Post, as Dan noted, we expect sales volume to gradually recover in the second half of 2021.
Aflac Japan is actively supporting the revival of cancer insurance sales, independently of Japan Post's efforts.
This includes reinforcing communication about Japan Post's sales policy at the postal branch level, providing training on our latest cancer products, developing sales proposal strategies, and identifying existing cancer policyholders in the Japan Post system to explain their current benefits and potentially offer upgrades.
It's crucial to remember that the Japan Post sales force has been inactive for 18 months.
Therefore, product training and sales coaching will be critical in the coming months.
In the US, the CDC reports approximately 32 million COVID-19 cases and 575,000 deaths.
As of Q1 end, we've had about 38,000 COVID-related claimants since the start of the pandemic, with incurred claims totaling $130 million.
While infection rates have decreased from 2020 peak levels, our data indicates lower hospitalization rates and shorter hospital stays.
However, infection hotspots persist in some areas of the US.
As in Japan, there are concerns about a potential fourth wave of infections.
Executive orders mandating premium grace periods remain in effect in nine states, with six states having open-ended expiration dates. Persistency has improved.
However, this improvement is largely due to a combination of state orders and lower overall sales, as we typically see higher lapse rates in the first year after a sale.
Regarding recovery efforts, our agent channel and small business benefit franchise have been impacted by the pandemic.
It's worth noting that about 390,000 of our 420,000 US business clients have fewer than 100 employees. Key investment areas include recruiting, training, technology advancement, and product development. Important recovery indicators include agent and broker recruiting, average weekly producer numbers, and the success of our dental and vision product rollout.
In Q1, we're operating at about 70% of the average weekly producer level compared to the same pre-pandemic period in 2019.
Trends are positive, and we expect to narrow this gap throughout the year, assuming pandemic conditions improve.
We're seeing favorable recruiting numbers, have reopened training centers that were closed during the pandemic, and veteran agents are re-engaging after a challenging year.
We're in the early stages of our national rollout of Aflac network dental and vision.
Our dental product is approved in 43 states, and vision in 41 states, with more states coming online throughout the year.
Network dental and vision are crucial in the small business market and key to agent productivity, along with new account growth, retention, and increased employee coverage at existing employers.
This month, we're completing national training programs, making select product refinements, and reinforcing incentives to drive new dental accounts.
We're also upgrading our administrative platforms to prepare for increased volumes.
2021 is a year for launching, learning, and adjusting, and we expect to see our pipeline, close rate, and new accounts gradually increase throughout the year.
Our premier life and disability platform, acquired from Zurich, is now operating under the Aflac brand.
We've started to see our quoted pipeline grow in the last 45 days.
However, many employers are hesitant to change critical benefit plans while figuring out return-to-work strategies and adapting to changing workforce dynamics.
Additionally, benefit consultants often proceed cautiously in the year or so following an acquisition.
We need to remain patient over the next few years as we establish ourselves in this new line of business.
Our competitive advantage lies in the proven premier service and technology capabilities of the acquired platform, combined with Aflac Group's leadership in supplemental workplace benefits.
We won't resort to relaxed underwriting or pricing standards to win business in this highly competitive market.
Lastly, we recently launched our new e-commerce direct-to-consumer platform, Aflac Direct.
We offer critical illness, accident, and cancer coverage, approved in about 30 states, with more states and products coming online throughout the year.
This platform targets individuals, self-employed workers, gig workers, and part-time employees who typically don't have access to traditional workplace benefit packages.
We're actively developing a licensed agent call center to improve conversion rates and control overall costs.
With a modest marketing budget, we're attracting about 500,000 monthly visitors to aflac.com, resulting in 120,000 leads for call center conversion this year.
We're currently achieving a 15% conversion rate in the call center.
This is a data-driven business, and core metrics will improve as the model matures.
Regarding the contribution of these businesses to overall sales in 2021, we expect these three growth initiatives to account for roughly 10% of sales, up from less than 5% in 2020.
We maintain our commitment to the revenue growth goals outlined at our November investor meeting.
These initiatives are anticipated to generate additional revenue exceeding $1 billion in the coming five to seven years.
As these individual initiatives progress, they build upon and enhance each other.
Our network dental and vision offerings boost agent recruitment and productivity, employer-sponsored benefits increase supplemental workplace sales, and our direct-to-consumer approach expands our market reach while also providing workplace leads to our field agents.
In the long term, as employees leave their workplaces, maintaining a digital relationship with Aflac directly aids in customer retention and satisfaction.
As mentioned by Dan, we launched our first sustainability bond, raising $400 million to support our goal of achieving net zero emissions by 2050 and to fund initiatives promoting climate action, diversity, and inclusion.
The bond issuance itself is a significant step, as it necessitates formal procedures for reporting, monitoring, and auditing qualified sustainable investments.
This rigorous approach benefits the control environment surrounding our company-wide ESG reporting and accountability.
Furthermore, Aflac Global Investments recently announced a partnership with Sound Point Capital Management to establish a new asset management business focused on the transitional real estate loan market.
As part of this collaboration, we have made an initial $1.5 billion general account allocation to the newly formed Sound Point Commercial Real Estate Finance, LLC, with $500 million dedicated to providing transitional and other debt financing to support economically disadvantaged communities designated as qualified opportunity zones.
Aflac will hold a 9.9% minority stake in this new investment LLC, with the option to increase our ownership over time as the venture grows.
I will now hand over to Max to provide a more detailed discussion of our financial performance.
Allow me to follow up with an overview of our Q1 performance, focusing on the development of our core capital and earnings drivers.
In the first quarter, adjusted earnings per share rose by 26.4% to $1.53, including a positive $0.02 impact from foreign exchange.
This quarter's strong performance was primarily driven by reduced utilization during the pandemic, particularly in the U.S., and a lower tax rate compared to the previous year.
Variable investment income exceeded our long-term return expectations by $24.5 million.
Adjusted book value per share, including foreign currency translation gains and losses, increased by 20.6%, and the adjusted ROE, excluding the foreign currency impact, was a robust 16.7%, significantly higher than our cost of capital.
Beginning with our Japan segment.
Total earned premium for the quarter decreased by 3.6%, reflecting the impact of paid-up first sector policies, while earned premium for our third sector products declined by 2.2% due to sales pressure in 2020.
Japan's total benefit ratio was 68.4% for the quarter, down 100 basis points year-over-year, and the third sector benefit ratio was 58%, also down 100 basis points year-over-year.
We experienced a slightly higher than normal IBNR release in our third sector block as actual results continue to be favorable compared to initial expectations.
This quarter, it was primarily due to pandemic conditions limiting utilization.
Persistency remains strong at 95%, up 50 basis points year-over-year.
Our expense ratio in Japan was 21.3%, up 130 basis points year-over-year.
With increased sales activity, expenses naturally rise, and our technology-related investments in converting Aflac Japan to a paperless company continue, which also includes higher system maintenance costs.
Adjusted net investment income increased by 6.9% in yen terms, mainly due to favorable returns on our growing private equity portfolio and lower hedge costs, partially offset by lower reinvestment yields on our fixed and floating rate portfolio.
The pre-tax margin for Japan in the quarter was 23.1%, up 60 basis points year-over-year, marking a very good start to the year.
Moving to the US, net earned premium decreased by 4.1% due to weaker sales results.
Persistency improved by 240 basis points to 80%, as our efforts to retain accounts and reduce policy lapses show early positive results.
As Fred mentioned, nine states still have premium grace periods in place, so we are closely monitoring these developments.
Breaking down the 240 basis point persistency rate improvement further, 70 basis points can be attributed to the emergency orders in place, 90 basis points to lower sales as first-year lapse rates are roughly twice the total in-force lapse rates, and the remaining 80 basis points include conservation efforts implemented last year.
Our total benefit ratio was significantly lower than expected at 39.1%, a full 900 basis points lower than Q1 2020.
In the quarter, we experienced lower paid claims, especially in January, as pandemic conditions influenced our policyholders' behavior.
This aligns with 2020 disclosures indicating a negative correlation between infection levels and claims-generating activities like accidents, elective surgeries, and physical exams.
This low activity level for non-COVID claims accounted for most of the year-over-year decrease in the benefit ratio.
Our total incurred COVID-related claims were also lower than expected due to an IBNR release.
We estimated new COVID claims at approximately $42 million, which was offset by an IBNR release of $41 million.
As we accumulate more experience, we have refined our assumptions, leading to this IBNR reserve release.
We anticipate the benefit ratio to gradually increase throughout the remainder of the year as normal activity resumes in our communities and among our policyholders.
For the full year, we now expect our benefit ratio to be toward the lower end or slightly below our guided range of 48% to 51%.
Our expense ratio in the US was 38.5%, up 10 basis points year-over-year, but with numerous contributing factors.
Weaker sales performance negatively impacts revenue.
However, the effect on our expense ratio is largely offset by lower DAC expenses.
Higher advertising spending increased the expense ratio by 70 basis points, along with our continued development of growth initiatives in group life and disability, network and innovation, and direct-to-consumer.
These contributed to a 110 basis point increase in the ratio.
The strategic growth initiative investments are largely counterbalanced by our efforts to reduce core operating expenses as we strive to be the low-cost producer in the voluntary benefit space.
Overall, despite many moving parts, Q1 expenses are tracking according to plan.
In the quarter, we also incurred $6 million in integration expenses not included in adjusted earnings associated with recent acquisitions.
Adjusted net investment income in the US decreased by 0.6% due to a 22 basis point contraction in the portfolio yield year-over-year, partially offset by favorable variable investment income.
Profitability in the US segment was very strong, with a pre-tax margin of 27.3%, primarily driven by the low benefit ratio.
With Q1 now complete, we are raising our pre-tax margin expectations for the full year.
Initial expectations were for us to be toward the low end of 16% to 19%.
We now anticipate ending the full year toward the high end of this range.
In our Corporate segment, we recorded a pre-tax loss of $26 million as adjusted net investment income was $20 million lower than last year due to lower interest rates at the short end of the yield curve.
Other adjusted expenses were $7 million lower as our cost reduction activities are showing results.
Our capital position remains robust, with an SMR above 900% in Japan and an RBC of approximately 563% in Aflac Columbus at the end of the quarter.
Unencumbered holding company liquidity stood at $3.9 billion, $1.5 billion above our minimum balance, excluding the $400 million proceeds from the sustainability bond issued in March, which reinforced our ESG initiatives and our belief that sustainable investments are also sound long-term investments.
Leverage, including the sustainability bond, increased but remains at a comfortable 23%, in the middle of our leverage corridor of 20% to 25%.
During the quarter, we repurchased $650 million of our own stock and paid dividends of $227 million, offering attractive relative IRR on these capital deployments.
We will continue to be flexible and tactical in managing our balance sheet and deploying capital to drive strong risk-adjusted ROE with a significant spread to our cost of capital.
With that, I'll turn it over to David to begin the Q&A session.
Summary:
output: q1 adjusted earnings per share $1.53.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These declarations and materials rely on numerous assumptions and factors subject to risks and uncertainties.
Our CFO, Ray Young, will present financial highlights, company results, performance drivers, and our outlook.
Vince Macciocchi, SVP and President of Nutrition, will provide an update on our Nutrition division and its growth prospects.
We announced third quarter adjusted earnings of $0.89 per share yesterday, an increase from $0.77 in the same period last year.
Adjusted segment operating profit reached $849 million, an 11% year-over-year increase, and our trailing four-quarter adjusted ROIC was 8.3%.
Our strategic initiatives have enabled our global teams to continue demonstrating their expertise and capabilities.
I'm impressed by how our employees are supporting customers and achieving strong results.
The team has excellently managed the daily and sometimes hourly challenges we've faced in 2020.
This resilience allows us to deliver exceptional results today while simultaneously pursuing strategic improvements to enhance our company and advance our growth and transformation.
Allow me to highlight some of our achievements.
In our optimized pillar, the Ag Services & Oilseeds team continued to enhance returns, reducing invested capital by another $100 million in the third quarter.
Since 2017, Ag Services & Oilseeds has improved its capital position by divesting non-strategic assets, including 71 grain origination sites, six oilseed facilities, 14 Golden Peanut and Tree Nuts locations, and seven oceangoing vessels.
We've also witnessed firsthand how improvement initiatives have supported business continuity.
Besides the pandemic, we've recently experienced multiple hurricanes in the US and a derecho storm that affected the Midwest.
In our drive pillar, we're accelerating our 1ADM business transformation by expanding the implementation of procurement, contract labor, and sales and marketing modules, which are driving efficiencies and growth while providing valuable data for enhanced analytics and decision-making.
Our Decatur corn complex's ongoing strong performance from grind to gluten to workplace safety continues to showcase the benefits of our centralized operations organization.
Our Supply Chain Center of Excellence is also delivering results; using enhanced processes, tools, and integrated planning between commercial, supply chain, and operations, we recently tested changes at a nutrition facility that are expected to increase production capacity by over 20% at that site.
These improvements have already led to better customer service without additional capital expenditure.
We plan to implement similar improvements at other locations.
In our expand pillar, we continue to reap the benefits of our investments.
For instance, our Algar Agro acquisition has tripled its year-over-year operating profit year-to-date.
Algar has quickly become a crucial part of our South American operations.
We've successfully expanded production of high-quality USP grade alcohol in Peoria and Clinton to meet increased demand for hand sanitizer.
We announced plans to build a cutting-edge production facility in Spain that will significantly increase our capacity to meet growing demand for probiotics and other health and wellness consumer products.
We also entered into a long-term agreement with Japanese startup Spiber Inc.
This project leverages our innovative spirit and capabilities, creating value across our supply chain from corn procurement to dextrose production to our investments in science and manufacturing technology.
It addresses a critical market need for sustainable consumer and industrial products.
Our transformation, growth, and confidence in the future wouldn't be possible without readiness.
By the end of the third quarter, our team identified and implemented readiness initiatives that unlocked nearly $1.2 billion in run rate benefits.
I'm pleased to announce that we're on track to achieve $1.3 billion by year-end.
Readiness encompasses and supports our entire company.
It drives the strategic imperatives that help us fulfill our purpose, such as sustainability.
We're advancing our sustainability efforts on multiple fronts.
These include our Strive 35 goals to improve our performance on greenhouse gases, energy, water, and waste.
Readiness creates growth enablers.
For example, we're continuing to enhance our commercial excellence with innovative tools like consumer insight programs and virtual customer technologies.
Readiness is also a key element powering the growth algorithm we outlined at the beginning of the year. Due to its success, along with significant progress in our harvest and improve initiatives, we now expect to meet or exceed the high end of our $500 million to $600 million target for improvements in 2020.
In 2014, we embarked on a new journey with the acquisition of WILD Flavors and the launch of a comprehensive nutrition business offering customers a wide range of products and services.
I'm extremely proud of the growth we've achieved since then.
Nutrition has delivered its fifth consecutive quarter of over 20% year-over-year operating profit growth.
Revenue has increased by 5.7% on a currency-adjusted basis for the first nine months of the year.
Since acquiring WILD, we've nearly tripled operating profit in the flavors business.
As we've been receiving more inquiries about that business and its growth potential, we decided it was an opportune time to provide an update and further explain the business.
As Juan mentioned, adjusted earnings per share for the quarter were $0.89, up from $0.77 in the same quarter last year.
Excluding specific items, adjusted segment operating profit was $849 million, an 11% increase.
Our trailing four-quarter average adjusted ROIC was 8.3%, 255 basis points higher than our 2020 annual WACC.
Our trailing four-quarter adjusted EBITDA was approximately $3.7 billion.
Our cash flows are robust, generating about $2.3 billion from operations before working capital in the first nine months of the year.
The third quarter's effective tax rate was a benefit of roughly 13%, contrasting with a 19% expense in the previous year.
Our third quarter tax rate was influenced by our debt retirement activities, the sale of our Walmart shares, and increased Walmart earnings and U.S. tax credits compared to the previous year.
Excluding the impact of earnings per share adjusting items, our effective tax rate was approximately 11%.
We anticipate our adjusted tax rate for the fourth quarter to be comparable to this adjusted third quarter effective tax rate.
As we disclosed at various times during the third quarter, we've implemented several measures over the past few months to both utilize and improve our robust balance sheet.
These actions weren't related to cash flow or liquidity concerns, as we had nearly $10 billion in cash and available credit at the quarter's end.
The measures were aimed at creating balance sheet flexibility for future transactions while maintaining a strong credit rating profile.
We converted part of our Walmart investment into cash through a block sale of Walmart stock and issued bonds that can be exchanged for Walmart shares at a later date.
As we've stated, we consider our substantial remaining Walmart stake to be strategic and have no plans to sell additional shares.
Taking advantage of our strong cash position, we also adjusted our balance between long-term and short-term debt, economically retiring higher-interest debt through positive net present value transactions and reducing future interest payments.
These combined actions provide us with the flexibility to make strategic investments, pursue additional acquisitions, or repurchase shares when appropriate, all while continuing to reduce our balance sheet leverage and maintain our single A credit ratings.
These actions were also a major factor in determining our tax rate.
Capital return for the first nine months totaled $724 million, including approximately $115 million in opportunistic share repurchases, mostly executed earlier this year.
We ended the quarter with a net debt to total capital ratio of about 27%, down from 30% a year ago.
Capital expenditure for the first nine months was approximately $560 million.
We expect capital spending for the year to be around the previously indicated $800 million, which is significantly below our depreciation and amortization rate of about $1 billion.
Other business results were lower than the same quarter last year, due to reduced ADM investor services earnings and captive insurance underwriting losses, including a $17 million settlement impact for the high water claim with Ag Services and Oilseeds.
In the corporate category, unallocated corporate costs of $196 million were higher year-over-year, primarily due to variable performance-related incentive compensation accruals, which were low in the previous year.
This quarter's corporate results also included $396 million related to the early debt retirement charges mentioned earlier, which is an earnings per share adjustment item.
Net interest expense for the quarter was comparable to the same period last year.
Looking ahead, we expect unallocated corporate expenses to align with our initial $800 million guidance for the calendar year and fourth quarter net interest expense to be slightly lower than the third quarter.
We also anticipate a loss of about $50 million in other business in the fourth quarter due to expected intercompany insurance claim settlements.
Ag Services and Oilseeds results surpassed those of the third quarter of 2019.
In Ag Services, we observed excellent execution globally.
The North American team effectively capitalized on strong industry export margins and volumes, while the global trade team had another strong quarter, maintaining their focus on customer service.
Ag Services also benefited from a $54 million settlement related to the 2019 US high water insurance claims, partially offset by an expense in captive insurance.
The crushing team also performed exceptionally well in a robust demand environment.
Both Ag Services and Crushing experienced expanding margins during the quarter, resulting in approximately $155 million in total negative timing effects, leading to lower results.
These timing impacts are expected to reverse in upcoming quarters.
Refined Products and Other performed significantly better year-over-year, driven by improved biodiesel margins globally.
Equity earnings from Wilmar were substantially higher compared to the same period last year.
Looking forward, we expect strong North American exports and global crush margins in the fourth quarter to contribute to a very strong Ag Services and Oilseeds performance.
Results are projected to be significantly higher than the third quarter of this year, though lower than the fourth quarter of 2019, which included a $270 million benefit from two years of the retroactive biodiesel tax credit.
Carbohydrate Solutions results were significantly higher compared to the previous year.
The Starches and Sweeteners sub-segment performed substantially better, driven by strong risk management and improved net corn costs, as well as a balanced ethanol industry supply and demand environment.
Reduced foodservice demand affected sweetener and flour volumes, but we're observing good demand recovery for starches in North America.
The Vantage Corn Processors team effectively executed on wet mill fuel ethanol distribution and capitalized on higher year-over-year industry margins, while managing the fixed costs from two temporarily idled dry mills.
Increased volumes and margins on USP grade industrial alcohol to support the hand sanitizer market also contributed to higher year-over-year profits.
Looking ahead, we expect the fourth quarter for Carbohydrate Solutions to be close to the third quarter of this year and substantially higher than the fourth quarter of 2019, driven by improved year-over-year fuel ethanol margins and higher industrial-grade sales.
While Sweetener and Flour volumes will still be impacted by weaker food service demand, we expect the year-over-year percentage decline to be smaller than it was in the third quarter.
Nutrition delivered its fifth consecutive quarter of over 20% year-over-year profit growth.
Human Nutrition results were substantially higher compared to the same quarter last year, with strength across the entire pantry, including flavors, plant-based proteins, and probiotics.
Animal Nutrition also performed better year-over-year, driven by continued delivery of Neovia synergies, strength in livestock, and year-over-year improvement in amino acids, partially offset by softer aquaculture feed demand and negative foreign currency impacts.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect Nutrition to deliver another quarter of over 20% year-over-year operating profit growth, with a typically seasonally weaker fourth quarter in human nutrition offset by seasonally stronger animal nutrition.
I'd now like to hand over to Vince Macciocchi, President of our Nutrition business, for an update and overview of the business.
Vince, congratulations to you and your team for not just a great quarter, but for consistently delivering strong growth.
I'm proud of the team who have excelled in so many ways.
When I reflect on the progress we've made and the journey we're still on, I keep coming back to our purpose: to unlock the power of nature to enrich the quality of life.
I find it remarkable how these few words encapsulate not just what we do, but why our work is so crucial.
Worldwide population is increasing, and consumer habits are evolving in unexpected ways compared to a decade or so ago.
The magnitude of this shift and the potential for ADM is immense.
Worldwide sales of specialized ingredients for human and animal nutrition amount to approximately $85 billion and are expanding at a rate of 5% to 7% annually.
These specialized ingredients, comprising the majority of the nutrition portfolio excluding fees, contribute to a wide range of consumer nutrition products for humans and animals, many of which are expected to see significant growth in the coming years.
The worldwide market for functional beverages could reach $190 billion by 2024.
The global market for dietary supplements might be valued at over $77 billion during the same period.
Worldwide retail sales of alternative proteins currently constitute a $25 billion market, with an anticipated growth rate of 14% per year.
Global retail sales of pet food are expected to increase by 4% annually, reaching $120 billion by 2024.
These figures represent more than just statistics.
They indicate significant long-term shifts in people's choices regarding food, beverages, and other products, driven by a global population that values health and sustainability.
Given our portfolio, presence, capabilities, and talent, no other company is better positioned than ADM to meet these needs and lead in these industries.
We embarked on this journey six years ago.
During this time, we have constructed or expanded over 16 facilities, ranging from our pea protein complex in the US to our network of feed mix plants in China.
We have improved our scientific and technological capabilities, invested in market research and consumer insights, and developed new interactive ways to engage with customers.
These include our more than 50 global customer innovation centers and daily virtual innovation and tasting sessions.
We have made platform acquisitions and added bolt-ons.
In total, we have invested just over $6 billion to establish our global leadership position in nutrition.
These investments are yielding results.
Since 2014, we have increased our annual revenue by $3 billion.
By the end of this year, we will have grown operating profits by more than $300 million over those six years, more than doubling them.
Our human nutrition division can provide customers with ingredients, flavor systems, or complete product development solutions, supporting them throughout the process from concept to prototype to market launch in record time.
In Animal Nutrition, only 18 months after completing our Neovia acquisition, we can reflect on a successful integration where we surpassed our synergy goals and established a global business offering a comprehensive portfolio of trendy items, from pet treats to enzymes to aquaculture ingredients, meeting evolving customer needs.
In our health and wellness division, which is part of our human nutrition subsegment, our scientists are expanding the range of pro, pre, and postbiotics and other functional products to meet growing demand for standalone supplements and ingredients that enhance our array of human and animal solutions.
Collectively, our extensive portfolio of ingredients and solutions can add value for customers across both human and animal nutrition sectors.
For example, taste and color are now as crucial for animal nutrition customers as they are for food and beverage customers.
Functional ingredients are important in both Human and Animal Nutrition, and this applies across our entire product range.
We then incorporate the rest of ADM's capabilities.
In plant-based protein, for instance, we have the unique advantage of ADM's broad and integrated value chain, from sourcing and transporting soybeans and peas to transforming them into high-protein ingredients at our own facilities.
We then add colors, flavors, oils, and other key elements to create the perfect taste, appearance, juiciness, and sizzle for delicious finished plant-based products.
We are proud of our progress in just six years, but our focus is on the future.
We are optimistic about continuing our growth trajectory.
This begins with the global category trends I mentioned earlier.
It continues with our extensive and ongoing research into consumer behavior and needs.
Earlier this week, we released our latest analysis of the top consumer trends for 2021, based on research that includes our proprietary Outside Voice consumer insights program.
Our findings indicate that recent events are accelerating and intensifying fundamental market shifts, including consumers taking a more proactive approach to nourishing body and mind, recognizing the microbiome as a gateway to wellness.
There is also continued growing demand for plant-based foods.
Sustainability has become a key factor in purchasing decisions, and transparency is essential for building consumer trust.
The final piece of the puzzle is how our team combines everything for our customers, merging unparalleled customer support and service with our extensive value chain to deliver ingredients, systems, and solutions that align perfectly with market trends and needs.
These factors contribute to our expectation of continued industry leadership, outpacing the market in operating profit growth, and we remain confident in achieving $1 billion in operating profit in the medium-term future.
Congratulations to you and the entire ADM team for another exceptional quarter.
Throughout the company, we continue to advance our efforts to enhance quality of life and meet crucial needs for consumers worldwide.
In a time of heightened concern about food security, ADM's robust global value chain is helping ensure that countries and families can continue to access nutritious, delicious foods.
As consumers increasingly focus on proactive approaches to health, we are expanding the boundaries of groundbreaking functional ingredients and supplements for people with conditions like migraine and atopic dermatitis.
We are also paving the way for a new era of precision nutrition, personalized for each individual.
As sustainability becomes a key driver of consumer decisions and business success, we are taking a leading role in transitioning our industry to a low-carbon economy.
We are dedicated to our purpose, and our team continues to deliver for our customers, shareholders, and all who depend on us.
This is why we are confident in a strong conclusion to 2020 and expect positive momentum to continue through 2021.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We explicitly state that we have no obligation to revise prior statements with new information, unless mandated by law.
Despite most employees working remotely due to COVID-19, Hilltop achieved an exceptional quarter, with unprecedented mortgage profits compensating for a substantial and prudent reserve increase at the Bank.
I'd like to begin with Slide 3 and provide an update on our COVID-19 response before discussing the quarterly results.
Operationally, we've benefited from strengthening Hilltop over the past three years by establishing a robust holding company and integrating the functional departments of our operating entities.
This has allowed us to maintain business continuity while prioritizing employee health and safety.
We continue to have most of our staff working from home, allowing essential personnel to work safely in our offices.
We're monitoring all COVID-19 cases to ensure affected employees quarantine and impacted offices are sanitized for prompt reopening.
We're also maintaining frequent, open communication to ensure everyone follows safety protocols and feels connected.
Although employee cases increased last quarter, the overall number remains low and hasn't significantly impacted our operations.
Since the pandemic began, we've been in constant communication with our clients to continue meeting their needs, particularly providing relief and support where necessary.
The Bank has granted deferrals on $1 billion in loans by collaborating with borrowers affected by COVID-19, including $619 million for principal only and $349 million for both principal and interest for the most severely impacted borrowers.
As the initial 90-day deferrals expire, the Bank has already received requests for about $120 million in second-round modifications.
We'll examine each request individually to ensure they're necessary and assess their viability.
Certain sectors, such as hospitality and food service, have been more severely affected, so we expect a large portion of those loans to request second deferrals.
Additionally, the Bank issued over 2,800 PPP loans totaling $672 million, a significant effort by our bankers to assist many customers in need.
As the pandemic continues, we'll keep offering personalized banking assistance, including fee waivers, increased daily spending limits, and suspended residential foreclosure activities.
Turning to Slide 4.
In Q2 2020, Hilltop reported net income of $128.5 million or $1.42 per diluted share, resulting in a 3.3% return on average assets and a 23% return on average equity.
Net income from continuing operations was $97.7 million.
The results for National Lloyds this period and the gain from its sale are included in discontinued operations, as noted at the bottom of the page.
This quarter demonstrates the strength of our businesses and the importance of diversification, with the mortgage and broker-dealer segments delivering strong fee income growth that offset the impact of the Bank's provision.
Favorable market conditions contributed to our results, but I'm most proud of our team for collaborating closely and capitalizing on emerging opportunities.
The sale of National Lloyds to Align Financial closed on June 30 for total cash proceeds of $154 million, resulting in a non-taxable net gain of $32 million.
This was a positive outcome for both parties.
Hilltop also achieved a significant strategic milestone this quarter with the successful issuance of $200 million in subordinated debt, further strengthening our liquidity and capital to weather the current recession and position ourselves to leverage future opportunities.
Regarding risk management, net charge-offs for the period were $16.4 million, including $12.5 million from an oil and gas credit reserved for in Q1 2020.
The allowance for credit losses increased by $49.6 million this quarter as Hilltop built its loan reserve to reflect the worsened economic outlook from Q1 2020.
We also continued to enhance our liquidity position, ending the period with $6.6 billion in cash, securities, and secured borrowing capacity.
Moving to Slide 5.
PlainsCapital Bank reported a pre-tax loss of $17.5 million, primarily due to a substantial CECL provision of $66 million, partially offset by stable net interest income and reduced operating expenses.
The Bank's pre-provision net revenue grew 5% compared to Q2 2019.
Notably, Jerry and the Bank team did an excellent job growing PPNR while working tirelessly to process PPP loans and borrower deferral requests.
PrimeLending had an exceptional quarter, generating pre-tax income of $138 million, a $116.5 million increase from Q2 2019.
This was driven by a 54% rise in origination volume and a 35 basis point increase in gain on sale margins.
Steve Thompson and the entire PrimeLending team worked overtime to handle the overwhelming volumes and capitalized on the industry's oversupply by raising prices and retaining servicing.
HilltopSecurities increased pre-tax earnings by $6 million to $28 million, driven by profitable growth in the fixed income services and structured finance divisions.
Brad Winges and the HilltopSecurities team are well underway in elevating the caliber and profile of the firm to become the leading municipal-focused investment bank.
Additionally, they completed a major system conversion for HilltopSecurities during the quarter.
Turning to Slide 6.
Hilltop has developed a synergistic and resilient business model, which we've been working towards throughout our company's history.
Through acquisitions, we initially integrated our company for capital and funding purposes.
Over the past three years, we've largely implemented our platform for growth and efficiency initiatives by integrating shared services departments and executing efficiency projects to build a scalable platform.
With the sale of National Lloyds, we've solidified our business model, which is a franchise anchored by PlainsCapital Bank and enhanced by powerful fee income businesses in PrimeLending and HilltopSecurities.
We've made significant investments in talented professionals and systems, and believe we're well-positioned to grow these core businesses.
Let's begin on Page 7.
As Jeremy mentioned, for Q2 2020, Hilltop reported consolidated net income attributable to common stockholders of $128.5 million, or $1.42 per diluted share.
Income from continuing operations attributable to common stockholders was $97.7 million or $1.08 per diluted share.
Hilltop's continuing operations generated $202 million of pre-provision net revenue (PPNR) during Q2, bringing the first half of 2020 total PPNR to $302 million.
PPNR increased by $125 million or 162% compared to the same period last year.
Growth versus the prior year was driven by diversified revenue streams, led by strong mortgage originations.
In Q2, revenue related to purchase accounting was $3.3 million and expenses were $1.3 million, resulting in a net purchase accounting pre-tax impact of $1.9 million for the quarter.
In the current period, purchase accounting expenses primarily represent amortization of deposit and other intangible assets related to previous acquisitions.
We expect revenue from purchased loan accretion to continue declining as the purchase loan portfolio runs off.
Furthermore, we anticipate revenue from purchased loan accretion will average between $3 million and $5 million per quarter for the remainder of 2020.
Given the significant earnings growth, along with the successful sale of National Lloyds and the subordinated debt issuance completed in Q2, Hilltop's capital position has been substantially strengthened as we address the ongoing impacts of the pandemic and position the company to capitalize on future opportunities.
Hilltop's Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was 18.46% and Tier 1 leverage ratio was 12.6% at the end of the period.
Let's move on to Page 8.
Net interest income from continuing operations decreased by $2.7 million to $104.6 million in Q2 compared to the same quarter last year.
The reduction in net interest income was caused by a $3.2 million drop in purchase loan accretion, which was partially offset by increased interest income from higher loan held for sale and loans held for investment during the quarter.
In the second quarter, Hilltop's consolidated average earning assets grew by $1.9 billion due to significant increases in customer deposits across all product categories.
The rise in deposits, along with planned actions including Hilltop's $200 million subordinated debt issuance, a $550 million increase in acquired brokered deposits, and proceeds from selling National Lloyds, contributed to a $1.2 billion increase in cash deposited at the Federal Reserve compared to the previous quarter.
Additionally, the Bank issued $672 million in PPP loans, minus approximately $21 million in deferred fees that will be recognized over the loans' lifetimes.
Finally, the mortgage warehouse lending business grew by about $120 million compared to the previous quarter, as mortgage volumes surged in Q2.
Hilltop's consolidated net interest margin in Q2 was 280 basis points, a 61 basis point decrease from the previous quarter.
This decline was attributed to the aforementioned growth in average earning assets, increased liquidity, and lower yields on loans, securities and deposits.
We anticipate continued pressure on NIM in Q3, followed by a modest recovery beginning in Q4 and continuing into Q1 2021.
A key factor in this improvement will be our efforts to reduce our cash and liquidity position to between $5 billion and $6 billion in the second half of the year.
We are continuously monitoring capital markets, Hilltop's mortgage volumes, and overall market conditions related to liquidity, and we will continue to balance our excess liquidity against risk over time.
Let's move to Page 9.
The table in the bottom right of Page 9 shows the Bank's liquidity as of June 30.
The Bank ended the period with over $6.6 billion in liquidity, including cash, securities, and secured borrowing sources.
Additionally, at period end, the parent company held $388 million in cash, which is approximately 4 times annual expenses, dividends, and debt service.
Moving to Page 10.
Noninterest income for Q2 was $468 million.
During this period, mortgage applications and locks were very strong, with PrimeLending locking approximately $7.4 billion in new mortgages.
This record-breaking quarter for rate locks reflected the impact of lower rates and better-than-expected demand for purchase mortgages across our markets.
The combination of strong lock-in origination volume and improving gain on sale spreads led to a $176 million increase in mortgage production and fee income compared to the same period last year.
In Q2, gain on sale margins in our mortgage business expanded by 43 basis points compared to Q1 2020.
We expect gain on sale margins to increase further in Q3 to between 430 and 450 basis points.
We anticipate that spreads will remain higher than historical levels but begin to moderate during Q4 2020.
In Q2, the securities business showed solid progress with fixed income capital markets delivering revenue growth of approximately $12 million, while structured finance saw improved market conditions and revenue increased by $6.5 million compared to the previous year.
At the end of the period, the mark on the structured finance loan pipeline was $15 million.
It's important to note that results from our fixed income and structured finance businesses can be volatile as market rates, spreads, and volumes can change significantly from period to period.
Let's move to Page 11.
Noninterest expenses increased by $66 million to $370 million compared to the same period last year.
The growth in expenses versus the prior year was primarily due to a $56 million increase in variable compensation at both PrimeLending and HilltopSecurities.
This increase in variable compensation was directly linked to strong fee revenue growth in the quarter compared to the same period last year.
Non-variable personnel expenses rose by $8 million compared to the previous year, driven by increases in overtime hours worked, particularly in our mortgage operations, as well as deferred compensation and project labor spending during the period.
Over the past nine quarters, we've continued to align our businesses with current market conditions and drive efficiencies across the franchise.
Through these efforts, headcount, professional service costs, and marketing and development expenses have continued to decrease as we make progress towards our efficiency objectives.
In Q2, Hilltop incurred $3.5 million in costs on $5.6 million of spending related to our ongoing core system improvements.
During Q2, we continued to make progress and are entering the final stages of implementing our three core system installations.
The new core loan system has been installed throughout the mortgage business.
The securities team completed Phase 1 implementation of the new operating platform at HilltopSecurities.
We have now begun the final deployment of the new general ledger and ERP system across Hilltop.
We expect that all of these implementations will provide significant value to our franchise and position Hilltop for profitable growth in the future.
Let's turn to Page 12.
Total average held for investment loans grew by 9% compared to Q2 2019.
Growth versus the same period in the prior year was driven by $672 million of net PPP loan originations, along with growth in our mortgage warehouse lending business, which experienced an increase of approximately $219 million compared to the previous year.
Other business loans declined compared to Q1 2020, as customer demand has remained weak.
Loan yields have decreased over the past four quarters and continued to decline in Q2.
Lower market rates, including prime rate and LIBOR rates, combined with lower purchase loan accretion, have contributed to the yield decline.
We expect that loan yields will continue to face pressure in the coming quarters as market rates remain low and we've added $672 million in PPP loans that yield 100 basis points.
Lastly, our loan pipeline remains stable, but many clients are postponing pricing and funding on new loan commitments until they have more clarity on the economic impact of the pandemic.
Moving to Page 13.
During Q2, Hilltop continued to build excess liquidity to prepare for potential disruptions caused by the pandemic and support increased mortgage origination activity.
Q2 average total deposits were approximately $11.2 billion, an increase of $2.2 billion or 25% compared to Q1 2020.
During the quarter, the bank transferred approximately $200 million in deposits back to the securities business, as the securities business can achieve a better return on those funds than the bank can earn on excess cash.
Excluding growth from PPP deposits, the subordinated debt issuance, and the proceeds from National Lloyds, customer deposits have continued to grow as customers retain cash until there is more clarity regarding economic activity.
As shown in the graph, the bank has been able to increase noninterest bearing deposits, which grew by approximately $600 million or 21% compared to Q1 2020 on an ending balance basis.
Let's turn to Page 14.
In Q2, net charge-offs totaled $16.4 million, or 92 basis points of total bank held for investment loans on an annualized basis.
Charge-offs during the quarter largely represent the final disposition of a single energy credit and the writedown of assets related to real estate properties that were all reserved for during Q1.
While non-performing assets improved as a percentage of criticized loans in Q2, it's important to note that the Bank approved $968 million in COVID-19-related loan modifications during Q2, and these deferrals are not reflected in the graph on this page.
Furthermore, in the graph on the bottom right, Hilltop's allowance for credit losses for the Bank's loans held for investment increased to 2.1% during the quarter.
Excluding PPP balances and collateral maintenance loans, the allowance to credit loss to bank loans ratio coverage equates to 2.6% at the end of the period.
I'm reviewing Page 15.
The economic outlook worsened considerably in Q2 compared to Q1, impacting the evaluation of allowance for credit losses.
A table at the bottom of the page presents key comparative metrics.
Our base case for CECL modeling as of June 30 anticipates a significant GDP decline in Q2, followed by a substantial Q3 rebound and gradual improvement through 2021. It also predicts US unemployment remaining between 8-10% until at least Q4 2021.
These economic changes resulted in a $60 million net allowance increase this quarter. Including economic impacts, charge-offs, and specific reserves, the allowance for credit losses grew by about $50 million in Q2.
We added model adjustments to account for reopening efforts, potential impacts on high-risk portfolio segments including COVID-19 loan modifications, and government stimulus effects.
Predicting future economic reactions to the ongoing pandemic remains challenging.
Assuming our current base case economic outlook holds, credit portfolio changes and new loan originations will be the main factors affecting allowance over time.
As previously mentioned, allowance for credit losses may fluctuate significantly due to potential major shifts in economic outlook between reporting periods.
Moving to Page 16.
We've updated our COVID-19 impacted portfolio view to focus on loans that received payment deferrals, which we consider the highest risk related to the pandemic.
The Bank approved $968 million in loan deferrals, about 13.5% of the total loan portfolio excluding PPP loans. This included $619 million in principal-only deferrals and $349 million in principal and interest deferrals.
The table shows how the $968 million is distributed across industries and the associated allowance for credit loss as of June 30. The ACL loan coverage for this portfolio is 7.1% at period end.
As of July 24, we've received requests for additional deferrals on $122 million in loans, which we'll evaluate in Q3. Of these, 56% are from restaurants and bars, and 36% from hotels.
We anticipate many hotel clients requesting further deferrals due to ongoing significant stress.
Our primary goal remains protecting the bank's principal while assisting clients through these unprecedented times. Any additional deferrals will be need-based, aiming for 90-day extensions.
Proceeding to Page 17.
The energy portfolio decreased by $42 million in Q2, due to customer repayments and the resolution of a large energy credit mentioned in Q1 2020.
The energy portfolio now comprises $104 million in outstanding balances and $59 million in unfunded commitments, totaling $163 million in exposure.
As of June 30, our allowance for credit losses on the energy portfolio is $9 million, or 8.7% of the outstanding balance.
On Page 18.
PlainsCapital Bank reported a pre-tax loss of $17.5 million in Q2 2020, primarily due to a $66 million provision expense.
The quarter showed stable net and noninterest income and continued improvement in operating expenses. The efficiency ratio was 54%, reflecting ongoing efforts to reduce costs and drive prudent revenue growth.
We suspended single-family mortgage retention by the Bank in Q1 due to pandemic-related economic uncertainties. We plan to resume retaining PrimeLending originated mortgages in the second half of 2020, assuming market stability and consistent consumer credit.
Turning to Page 19.
PrimeLending generated a $138 million pre-tax profit in Q2 2020, driven by strong origination volumes that increased by $2.1 billion or 54% year-over-year.
Gain on sale margins expanded in Q2 compared to the previous year due to market volumes and pricing actions.
Refinance activity accounted for 47% of total originations. We expect the refinance portion to remain elevated in Q3 compared to historical levels.
Hilltop retained about 89% of mortgage servicing rights for loans sold in Q2. The mortgage servicing asset is now approximately $82 million and could grow to $150-$175 million by year-end.
Our mortgage business performed well in Q2 despite challenging circumstances.
Moving to Page 20.
HilltopSecurities reported a $28 million pre-tax profit in Q2 2020.
Fixed income services saw solid revenue growth as traders successfully navigated challenging pricing and liquidity conditions.
The structured finance business grew by $6.5 million year-over-year as secondary markets for mortgage-related bonds improved following March's market disruption.
It's important to note that fixed income and structured finance results can be volatile due to fluctuations in market rates, spreads, and volumes.
The securities team made significant progress in launching their new operating system in Q2, with ongoing enhancements planned for coming quarters.
On Page 21.
Given economic uncertainties related to the pandemic, we're updating our 2020 commentary without providing specific guidance or outlook.
The economic rebound's timeline and nature remain unclear, likely dependent on virus management and outbreak control.
We remain focused on controllable factors, including ensuring the safety of our associates and clients, helping clients navigate pandemic-related challenges, executing platform growth and efficiency initiatives, and meeting our 2021 commitments.
Our primary goal is to deliver prudent growth across all business lines while maintaining a moderate risk profile and creating long-term shareholder value.
Summary:

q2 earnings per share $1.08 from continuing operations.
q2 earnings per share $1.42 including items.
