input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Here are the paraphrased sentences:
A quick note for those joining by phone.
The call recording will be available on our website if you can't listen to the entire call today.
Let's start with our standard precautionary statement.
Factors like weather, regulations, competition, and other risks detailed in SEC filings can impact results.
We thank you for your ongoing support and interest in our company.
I'll provide a brief overview of our financial performance and market conditions.
Next, I'll discuss the global supply chain, a topic of great interest across industries.
David will then provide an in-depth look at our finances and operations.
I'll conclude with an update on our green solutions and precision application initiatives.
At the end of Q2's call, we presented a scorecard comparing our first half performance to our initial targets.
I'll now update that through Q3 and year-to-date.
Our revenue growth remains at 25% through three quarters.
Our gross profit margin is holding steady at 39%, compared to 38% last year.
Operating expenses have decreased from 34% to 33% of sales year-to-date.
Interest expense is down 20%, tracking below 2020 and likely to outperform our initial forecast.
Our tax rate is now 27% versus 20% last year, but we expect it to decrease in Q4 to meet our mid-20% target.
Our debt to EBITDA ratio has dropped from 2.5 to 2.1 times and may fall below our 2 times target.
Net income growth is similar at 87%, outpacing our 25% revenue growth.
EBITDA has increased 39% compared to last year.
We saw strong performance across all sectors, with our domestic crop business leading the way due to several factors.
Let's first examine commodity prices, starting with cotton.
We compared prices per pound from September 27, 2020 to September 27, 2021, seeing a dramatic 59% increase.
This has encouraged farmers to invest more heavily in cotton.
We've benefited from strong sales of our cotton insecticide Bidrin in Q3.
Our cotton defoliant Folex also performed well in Q3, with orders continuing into October.
Soybean prices rose 26% from $10.21 to $12.85 per bushel over the year.
Our improved soybean portfolio, including recently acquired herbicides, has made soybeans a growing crop segment for us.
Corn prices increased from $3.79 to $5.42 per bushel.
Our corn products, including Aztec soil insecticide and IMPACT herbicide, have shown strong performance.
We've also launched new corn herbicides like IMPACT CORE and SINATE.
Overall, our US crop sector grew by 38%, despite logistics issues affecting our soil fumigant products.
OHP continues to perform well, particularly in horticulture and greenhouse markets.
AMGUARD is recovering well in the professional pest market.
Our Australian business AgNova has tripled compared to last year.
Agrinos is contributing incremental new business.
Mexico is performing well, as are Brazil and Central America.
These sectors combined for a 17% increase over last year.
Regarding supply chain issues, there are currently 540,000 containers backlogged at Long Beach Harbor.
The port can unload about 18,000 containers daily, but 29,000 new containers arrive each day, worsening the backlog.
This situation stems from shifts in buying patterns due to COVID, limited port capacity, and container shortages.
Trucking shortages further complicate moving containers once unloaded.
To address these issues, companies must focus on production planning, sourcing strategies, and logistics management.
China has closed several factories due to environmental concerns and other factors, not necessarily related to production.
The government is prioritizing energy usage, leading to restrictions on production for certain high-energy products.
This is causing a worldwide supply squeeze.
The first concern is whether you can actually place and fulfill a purchase order.
Some suppliers have demanded higher prices for ordered products, and in some cases, they're unable to ship anything.
The primary issue is determining if you can produce or obtain the product itself.
The second concern is logistics, with container shipping costs skyrocketing from $2,500-$3,000 last year to $26,000 this year, just for US entry.
Additional challenges include moving goods from ports to factories or production sites, and then to final destinations, complicated by trucker shortages.
This often results in bidding wars for transportation services, rather than standard pricing.
It's crucial to quickly calculate the true cost of goods, assuming you can obtain them.
Factory costs are also increasing due to rising labor wages.
We're collaborating with our finance team to analyze all SKUs in real-time, ensuring our commercial product managers understand their cost of goods sold.
Companies that can navigate this process effectively will likely perform best.
There's no clear timeline for when this disruption will end, and it will affect different areas to varying degrees in cycles.
Adaptability is key to understanding and responding to these changes.
On a positive note, our six North American production sites give us a stronger position to handle supply chain disruptions.
Only about 8% of our portfolio relies on materials from China.
We began sourcing from outside China a few years ago due to tariffs reaching up to 31%.
We manufacture 46% of our portfolio within our six North American factories, providing greater independence and flexibility to respond to market conditions.
We order overseas goods sporadically, unlike many consumer businesses that rely on constant imports.
We're working closely with logistics partners to ensure smooth transportation and are ordering goods further in advance while considering less congested ports.
So far, we've managed supply chain conditions well and are optimistic about continuing without significant interruptions.
Regarding our public filing, we expect to submit it within the next 30-45 minutes.
Our industry is considered critical in all our operating jurisdictions, allowing our business, customers, and suppliers to operate without major disruptions throughout the pandemic.
Our quarterly sales performance shows a 25% increase over the previous year, totaling $147 million.
US sales increased by 33% ($22 million), while international sales grew by 16% ($8 million).
The strong US performance led to international sales reducing to 40% of total sales, down from 43% last year.
Our third-quarter production performance in 2021 exceeded expectations, positively impacting gross margin performance.
The crop business saw a 50% improvement in gross margin, while non-crop business margins remained relatively flat due to significant mix changes compared to the previous year.
International sales gross margin improved, primarily due to higher-margin businesses acquired in late 2020.
A graph illustrates the impact of factory performance on our results, showing a significant improvement in factory costs as a percentage of net sales.
Operating expenses increased by 24% ($9 million), with newly acquired businesses accounting for 14% of the increase and freight for 17%.
Operating income in the third quarter was up 112% compared to last year.
Interest expense is about 24% lower than the previous year.
The tax rate is slightly higher due to strong taxable income.
Net income is $5.5 million, up 88% from the previous year.
For the first nine months of 2021, sales increased by 25%, with gross margin up 27%.
Operating expenses increased primarily due to new businesses acquired in late 2020, performance-linked incentives, legal costs, and volume-related expenses.
Overall, operating costs increased by 22% compared to the 25% net sales increase.
Interest expenses reduced by 23% due to cash generated over the last 12 months.
Net income increased by 87%.
Cash generated from operations increased by 56% in the third quarter compared to the same period last year.
Inventories at the end of September 2021 were $167 million, down from $176 million the previous year.
Excluding acquired products and entities, base inventory decreased by 11% from last year.
The current inventory target for the end of the financial year is $155 million, compared to $164 million at the end of 2020.
Consolidated EBITDA for the trailing four quarters to September 30th, 2021, was $66 million, up from $49 million for the same period in 2020.
This, combined with existing debt, results in available borrowing of $95 million at September 30th, 2021, compared to $45 million a year prior.
The chart demonstrates our effective debt management throughout the annual cycle while continuing to invest in future business growth.
In summary, for Q3 2021, we achieved a 25% sales increase, improved overall margins, managed operating expenses which rose in absolute terms but decreased as a percentage of sales, and saw an 88% increase in net income.
The first nine months of 2021 show a similar pattern: 25% sales growth, 24% increase in gross margins, reduced operating costs relative to net sales, lower interest expense, and an 87% improvement in net income.
Regarding the balance sheet, accounts receivable grew due to strong sales, inventories were well-managed, working capital remained stable during the quarter, and debt is lower than last year.
This was achieved despite three acquisitions in the past 12 months.
Our liquidity position has notably improved.
I'll now turn it over to Eric.
In recent quarterly earnings calls, we've provided updates on our two strategic growth initiatives: green solutions and prescriptive application technology.
Let's discuss green solutions.
We previously mentioned expanding our green solutions technology, and now have 100 different products in our growing portfolio.
This slide categorizes our offerings by function.
We offer a balanced range of solutions, emphasizing bio-fertilizers, bio-stimulants, bio-pesticides, and micronutrients.
Our portfolio now includes traditional crop protection products as well as beneficial plant nutrition and soil health amendments.
Green solutions has shown consistent recent growth, as illustrated in this slide.
Q3 saw a $10 million increase, representing 26% growth from Q2.
Much of this growth came from increased sales in Latin America, Brazil, India, and Australia.
Year-to-date revenue stands at $27 million, and we've revised our full-year forecast from $32-35 million to $35-37 million.
Latin America contributes about $10 million, our largest market so far.
Our expansion efforts include ongoing registrations in Latin America, completed transition of the Columbia business, building a pipeline for further distribution in Europe and Africa, and identifying opportunities for significant growth in the US in 2022.
The 1,500 spot trials conducted in 2021 are expected to yield benefits in 2022.
We've integrated this with our SIMPAS trials, introducing iNvigorate, a promising nitrogen fixation product.
Our turf and ornamental trials are nearing completion, with large-scale customer demo plots underway.
AMGUARD, our bioherbicide product for consumer and professional pest use, shows potential for agricultural applications.
This is particularly significant given Bayer's decision to exit the consumer market through Scotts, with RoundUp being the leading herbicide in that space.
We see strong demand for solutions and believe we're well-positioned in this market.
Greenplants, acquired as part of Agricenter in late 2017, had strong products for expansion, but integrating them into other areas took time.
We've recently introduced products in China and Colombia, and see strong growth potential in Australia.
Bi-PA, a Belgian consortium we joined about six or seven years ago, has produced its first product: Vintec, a biofungicide originally developed for European grapes.
We've seen strong results in almonds and recently received California registration.
With over 1 million acres of almonds in California, we see a good fit for biotreatment of canker disease.
We're also testing it on bananas in Central America with promising results and hope to secure registrations there as well.
We've slightly increased our 2021 target by a few million dollars, aiming to double it in the next couple of years and again in the following years.
It's an aggressive growth plan, but given our product range, development work, and high demand for solutions in this space, we're confident in our forecast.
Moving to SIMPAS, this graphic illustrates how the system works.
Our revenue forecast for SIMPAS through 2025 remains unchanged from our last call.
Since then, we've reached out to progressive retailers to focus on precision farmers shifting to prescription application of crop inputs.
We've identified several retailers fitting this profile, with over a dozen agreements for SIMPAS distribution so far.
We expect this number to double in the coming months, with 26 retailers identified, mostly in the Midwest and five in the South.
These retail partners provide agronomy and prescription software capabilities for targeting SIMPAS inputs in crop protection, plant nutrition, and soil health enhancements.
This allows SIMPAS to dispense ingredients that maximize yield, minimize cost, improve return on investment, and produce beneficial environmental outcomes.
These precision ag services strengthen the grower-retailer relationship, fostering long-term business loyalty.
The Ultimus software's data retention capabilities, part of SIMPAS, enable concrete documentation of beneficial agricultural practices through MDR.
In the emerging carbon credit market, this ability to validate such practices can help offset the investment in technologies like SIMPAS.
We're collaborating with the USDA on this technology, which led to an invitation to apply for a grant under the Agricultural Innovation Center Program.
We submitted the grant at the end of September, with a decision expected by Q2 2022.
The grant focuses on nitrogen reduction using the SIMPAS Ultimus system, decreasing synthetic fertilizer use and applying soil health products instead.
Ultimus provides carbon credit programs a way to verify, measure, and validate grower practices for credit qualification.
Its blockchain-based permanent ledger creates an immutable record of all field applications by volume and location.
To our knowledge, no one else in our industry has climate-friendly technology as comprehensive as our SIMPAS Ultimus system, especially when used with our green solutions.
To conclude, here's a quote from Jason Ore of Ore Farms in Iowa, a satisfied SIMPAS user: "The opportunities are endless. I foresee dozens of SIMPAS-supplied solutions being applied this way in the future. This will change how we producers approach in-furrow application."
Let's open the floor for questions.
Summary:

american vanguard corp - qtrly net sales up 25% to $147 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We aim to accommodate as many questions as possible within our scheduled time frame.
We kindly request that you limit yourself to one initial question.
Virgil has been an esteemed colleague at Nike, Jordan, and Converse since 2016.
He was an innovative and brilliant creative force who inspired multiple generations by challenging norms and introducing new perspectives.
Virgil's humility and compassion were what impressed me most on a personal level.
We extend our sympathies to all those who had a connection with Virgil.
His presence will be greatly missed.
The second quarter's strong performance demonstrates the effectiveness of our strategy, even as we navigate global economic challenges.
Our team's creativity and adaptability helped deliver another robust quarter.
During times of uncertainty, I focus on the essentials, which for Nike means prioritizing the consumer and leveraging our long-term competitive advantages.
These include our innovation-driven culture, strong brand connection with consumers through compelling storytelling, unmatched sports marketing portfolio, and our emerging digital advantage that allows us to directly engage with consumers at scale.
We continue to benefit from pandemic-accelerated trends.
These include a global shift towards health and fitness, increased demand for athletic footwear and apparel in everyday life, an expanding definition of sport, and a fundamental change in consumer behavior towards digital platforms, which aligns with our growing digital capabilities.
As I've mentioned before, challenges create opportunities for strong brands to become even stronger, and that's exactly what's happening here.
We are in a significantly stronger competitive position now than we were 18 months ago, and this trend is ongoing.
Our brand's strong connection with consumers is driving impressive holiday sales, particularly in North American Digital, which led the industry during Black Friday week with nearly 40% growth.
Our Singles Day performance in Greater China showcased our brand strength as we gained 13 million new members and maintained our position as the top sports brand on TMall.
This holiday season has demonstrated the power of our digital transformation globally.
Digital capabilities are driving our Consumer Direct Acceleration strategy.
The second quarter was exceptional for sports, featuring our extensive roster of athletes and teams.
Following exciting conclusions to the WNBA and MLB seasons, enthusiasm continues with the NBA, NFL, European soccer, and upcoming college football bowl games, where Nike teams dominate the top rankings.
When these leagues are thriving, our business benefits.
Nike athletes continue to lead in various sports, with notable achievements including Alexia Putellas winning the Ballon d'Or, Marcus Rashford receiving his MBE, and Cristiano Ronaldo reaching 800 career goals.
Shalane Flanagan's remarkable feat of completing six World Marathon Majors in six weeks, each under 2 hours and 47 minutes, while wearing Nike Air Zoom Alphafly Next%, serves as an inspiring reminder of the joy and determination in sports.
We continue to differentiate ourselves as the most innovative sports brand by consistently introducing new products that set industry standards.
We're aligning our efforts with key growth areas such as Women's, Jordan, and Apparel, while maintaining our commitment to sustainability.
In the Women's category, we launched the Nike Air Sesh, a shoe designed specifically for dancers by Tinker Hatfield in collaboration with professional dancers and choreographers.
The shoe combines style and performance with a mid-cut leather upper and cushioned foam underfoot.
We initially released the Air Sesh exclusively to Nike members, with a wider release planned soon.
This launch allows us to deepen our connection with women consumers and sharpen our focus as we expand our definition of sport.
This quarter also saw the debut collection from the Serena Williams Design Crew, our apprenticeship program promoting diversity in design.
The collection uniquely combines innovation, design, and purpose, driven by our commitment to women's sports across performance and lifestyle.
Serena recently joined us to inaugurate the Serena Williams Building at our World Headquarters.
Along with the LeBron James Innovation Center, these facilities represent the world's most significant investment in sports innovation.
The Jordan Brand introduced the AJ36, Nike Inc.'s first shoe using leno-weave technology.
This process creates a material that is strong, lightweight, and adaptable to various foot shapes, making the AJ36 one of the lightest Air Jordans ever produced.
We plan to incorporate this innovation in future designs.
Our apparel designs are generating market excitement by resonating with consumers.
The latest NBA City Edition and MLB City Connect uniforms exemplify how we're growing sports culture by engaging with local team communities and using thoughtful design to celebrate the game.
We also launched FIT ADV, our next-generation performance apparel that combines weather-resistant technology with innovative design to help athletes perform in extreme conditions.
This represents the pinnacle of Nike apparel innovation and is currently available in our performance apparel collections, with plans to extend to lifestyle products across all platforms next year.
In sustainability, we introduced the Alphafly Next Nature, our most sustainable performance shoe and first sustainable performance running shoe.
Building on the progress made with our Cosmic Unity sustainable basketball shoe, it contains more than 50% recycled content by weight.
We plan to apply learnings from the Alphafly Next Nature across our running line to create higher-performing products with more sustainable materials.
We remain committed to protecting the future of sport, which depends on a healthy planet.
We are creating the marketplace of the future by providing consumers with seamless, consistent, and premium experiences through One Nike Marketplace.
Nike membership allows us to know and serve our consumers across a connected marketplace.
I'd like to highlight three examples from this quarter that demonstrate how Nike is enhancing the member experience across the marketplace.
First, we recently added new wellness content and workouts featuring Megan Thee Stallion to our Nike Training Club app.
Megan's content drove record engagement, doubling daily active users in NTC, and her curated product selections saw more than twice the demand compared to other product content during the same period.
Second, before Singles Day in Greater China, we introduced a new member experience on TMall and improved the onboarding process.
As a result, the Nike Flagship store on TMall led in new member recruitment across sports brands, achieving a 20 percentage point increase in member demand penetration this year.
Third, we recently announced a partnership with Dick's Sporting Goods, a strategic retail partner who shares our vision for the future of retail.
This partnership allows shoppers to link their Nike and DSG accounts to access exclusive offers, products, and experiences.
I recently visited one of DSG's newest concept stores, the House of Sport in Rochester, NY, and was impressed by its unique service model, interactive sports experiences, and enhanced product showcasing.
This store creates a true destination for consumers and will shape future retail expectations.
Our partnership with DSG represents a new model for brand-retailer collaboration, delivering products, experiences, and services that delight consumers at scale.
We are realizing our vision of providing consumers with greater access to Nike through connected member experiences and inventory, powered by integrated data and technology.
This approach offers more speed, convenience, and brand connection than ever before.
Looking ahead, we see even more opportunities to connect consumers with Nike across digital platforms that integrate sport, innovation, culture, and commerce.
For example, we recently opened a new space in our New York digital studio to produce weekly Sneakers livestreams, which are achieving industry-leading engagement metrics.
Weekly content includes launch previews in our Sneakers Live Heating Up show and a new Jordan franchise called J-Walking, presented from the perspective of female Jordan fans.
Our narratives delve deeply and foster two-way community engagement.
Consequently, our viewer involvement is triple the industry norm for live broadcasts.
Regarding Sneakers and Jordan, the initial batch of AJ11 Cool Grey invitations was distributed to the largest female-focused group to date, selling out within the first 60 minutes.
The group was chosen using our newly developed Dedication Score, designed to benefit member groups with strong product affinity.
We continue to observe exclusive access as a key marketing tool for connecting with customers.
In the second quarter, we also introduced the 3D immersive environment of NIKELAND on Roblox.
Nike is engaging young athletes wherever they are, inspiring their imagination and incentivizing real-world movement through novel virtual experiences.
The Nike, Jordan, and Converse brands have consistently flourished at the intersection of athletics, creativity, innovation, and culture.
The RTFKT acquisition enables us to broaden our reach to satisfy and delight consumers and creators in both tangible and virtual realms.
We will support the talented RTFKT team, creator community, and cutting-edge innovation to deliver next-generation experiences involving the RTFKT and NIKE Inc. brands.
Currently, we are more robust than before the pandemic, and I'm incredibly enthusiastic about the opportunities ahead.
This quarter's results demonstrate the effectiveness of our strategy.
Throughout our challenges, this team has collaborated with creativity and resilience to serve our consumers and communities.
As we've stated previously, Nike is a growth-oriented company with limitless potential.
Our Consumer Direct Acceleration strategy is revolutionizing our operating model by fostering deeper, more direct consumer connections through digital means.
Our teams continue to navigate unprecedented volatility with flexibility, agility, and poise, utilizing the operational playbook we developed at the pandemic's onset to maintain focus on what's most important.
We've embraced new work methods, promoted experienced individuals to new leadership roles, restructured the company to enhance consumer focus, and developed new capabilities to serve customers directly with speed and scale.
Nike's second quarter financial performance aligned with the expectations we set 90 days ago, driven by continued brand momentum, strong product franchise performance with exceptional full-price realization, and robust season-to-date holiday sales, counterbalanced by reduced inventory supply relative to market demand.
As John mentioned, we had a remarkable Black Friday week, with Nike Direct in North America and EMEA growing over 20% compared to the previous year, building on last year's significant gains.
I'm particularly proud of our supply chain teams' efforts in achieving this.
In late October, I visited our North America distribution centers in Pennsylvania, Tennessee, and Mississippi to review our expanding digital fulfillment capabilities and holiday readiness plans.
Our teams are executing these plans precisely, optimizing available inventory to meet demand with improved service levels and reduced carbon impact, all enabled by technology and automation.
Continuing on the topic of supply chain, factory reopening in Vietnam is proceeding as planned.
Nearly all affected factories began reopening in October.
Currently, all factories are operational, and employee attendance rates have improved, with weekly footwear and apparel production now at approximately 80% of pre-closure volumes.
In total, Vietnam factory closures caused us to cancel production of roughly 130 million units due to three months of lost production volume and several months required to return to full production.
Compared to 90 days ago, we are increasingly confident that supply will normalize as we enter fiscal '23.
Regarding our digital business, Nike's digital growth is outpacing comparisons and is fueled by our member-centric focus.
Nike Digital grew 11% in the quarter on a currency-neutral basis, setting the industry standard.
Nike Digital now represents 25% of total NIKE Brand revenue, up 3 percentage points from the previous year and more than double the digital mix in fiscal '19.
Enhanced onboarding experiences are attracting millions of new members to the top of the funnel, and we are heavily focused on member engagement and purchasing.
Member engagement increased by 27% and repeat buyers grew by 50% compared to last year, driving overall higher Average Unit Retail, Average Order Value, and member purchase frequency.
40% of total digital demand this year is coming from our mobile apps, highlighting the strength of our digital platform.
We now have over 79 million engaged members across our Nike ecosystem.
As Nike's digital ecosystem continues to expand, we are beginning to see the compounding benefits of scale, from brand awareness and consumer connection to data-informed personalization and inventory utilization, to loyalty.
This quarter, we held our first globally coordinated Member Days event, setting records in member engagement.
From member-exclusive product offerings to our first livestreamed member events from Nike Town London and Passeig de Gracia Store in Barcelona, we created a distinct member experience and set a record for weekly active users on the Nike App in North America.
Connecting with today's consumer means providing them with the products they want, when and where they want them.
Consumers desire a premium, seamless, and personalized experience with minimal friction throughout their journey to explore, engage, connect, and purchase products from the brands they love.
As previously discussed, Nike is focused on creating One Nike Marketplace that elevates the brand by establishing direct consumer connections through fewer, more impactful wholesale partners, with a connected mobile digital experience at the center built for Nike members.
Over the past four years, North America has reduced the number of wholesale accounts by approximately 50%, while delivering strong growth and recapturing consumer demand through Nike Direct and our strategic wholesale partners leading the way for Nike.
In the second quarter, North America Digital grew 40% compared to the previous year, pushing Nike Digital to 30% of total North America marketplace, bringing Nike Direct to 48% of total.
To enable this growth and drive the shift in marketplace composition, we have accelerated investment to evolve our distribution network and scale a digital-first supply chain, leveraging advanced analytics, automation, and technology.
We have opened two new regional service centers on both coasts, capable of delivering more units to consumers with shorter delivery times.
We have also enabled ship-from-store capabilities across our store fleet, all leveraging advanced analytics from our Celect acquisition.
Regarding automation, we have added more than 1,000 robots in our distribution centers to handle digital growth.
In our digital distribution center in Memphis, robots handled over 10 million units that would have otherwise required manual labor.
We continue to scale O2O consumer services across our store fleet, including buy online, pick up in store, and digital order returns in store.
While volumes are relatively small today, we have significant opportunity to scale.
We have also established new fulfillment models with key strategic partners to create inventory visibility across the marketplace and optimize full-price digital demand.
When we execute this correctly, the consumer benefits.
The progress in creating One Nike Marketplace has accelerated North America's revenue growth and gross margin expansion for another quarter, demonstrating how Consumer Direct Acceleration will fuel Nike's growth and profitability toward the fiscal '25 outlook we shared in June.
Now, let me discuss the details of our second quarter financial results and operating segment performance.
NIKE, Inc. revenue grew 1% and remained flat on a currency-neutral basis, led by 8% growth in Nike Direct offset by a 6% decline in wholesale due to optimization of available inventory supply.
Nike Digital grew 11% and Nike-owned stores grew 4% with significant improvements in traffic and higher conversion rates.
Gross Margin increased 280 basis points compared to the previous year, primarily driven by higher Nike Direct margins due to lower markdowns, higher full-price mix, and foreign currency exchange rates, partially offset by increased freight and logistics costs.
SG&A grew 15% compared to the previous year, primarily due to normalization of spending on brand campaigns, digital marketing investments to support heightened digital demand, strategic technology investments, and wage-related expenses.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 10.9% compared to 14.1% for the same period last year, due to a shift in our earnings mix and the effects of stock-based compensation.
Second quarter diluted earnings per share was $0.83, up 6% compared to the previous year.
Before discussing operating segment results, I want to reiterate a few points I made last quarter regarding the impact of Vietnam factory closures on the short-term performance of each of our geographies, beginning in the second quarter.
North America and EMEA finished the first quarter with high levels of in-transit inventory, resulting in prior season supply arriving late due to longer transit times, which could be sold in the second quarter.
We observed this in our Q2 results.
Greater China and APLA experienced a decline in units sold during Q2 due to reduced production and limited inventory, despite being closer to the sourcing base with shorter transit times.
This impact was evident in our second quarter results.
Let's now examine the performance of our operating segments.
North America saw a 12% increase in revenue and a 21% rise in EBIT during the second quarter.
Nike's popularity remained exceptionally high, with holiday retail sales across the market growing by double digits, fueled by the revival of sports and a strong start to the holiday season.
Sports performance categories showed strong double-digit retail sales growth, particularly in Running, Fitness, and Basketball, despite lower inventory levels.
Women's retail sales increased significantly, growing at more than twice the rate of men's, with strong performance in both footwear and apparel.
Nike Direct had an exceptional quarter, growing by 30% compared to the previous year.
As mentioned earlier, Digital sales continued to thrive, growing by 40% and setting new records during Black Friday week.
Nike-owned stores also achieved strong double-digit growth, with foot traffic approaching pre-pandemic levels and significant increases in Average Unit Retail due to reduced clearance inventory and improved markdown rates.
Despite strong retail sales momentum in the wholesale channel, revenue decreased by 1% as marketplace inventory remained low, and factory closures in Vietnam along with extended transit times disrupted inventory supply to meet market demand.
In EMEA, Q2 revenue grew 6% on a currency-neutral basis, while EBIT increased 22% as reported.
Holiday retail sales across the market grew by double digits, with strong performance across all consumer segments.
The region was energized by the start of the global football season and the Champions League tournament.
Nike athletes continued to dominate on the field, with the Mercurial boot being the top scorer in several European professional leagues.
There was a strong consumer response to the Mercurial boot and the launch of the Champions League third kit.
Wholesale revenue increased by 6% on a currency-neutral basis, compared to the previous year's market closures.
Nike Direct also grew by 6%, led by double-digit growth in Nike-owned stores as they compared to previous year's closures, with improved foot traffic due to increased tourism and back-to-school holidays.
Nike Digital sales decreased by 1% when compared to the extraordinary levels of discounted sales in the previous year, as the region had used digital channels to clear excess inventory.
This quarter, our full-price Digital business grew over 20%, resulting in a 30-point improvement in full-price sales mix, double-digit growth in Average Unit Retail, and improved markdown rates.
These factors contributed to significant year-over-year expansion in gross margin and return on sales profitability.
In Greater China, Q2 revenue declined 24% on a currency-neutral basis, and EBIT decreased 36% as reported, although holiday retail sales across the market have shown more favorable trends.
The quarter's results were as anticipated, as we managed reduced full-price product supply due to factory closures in Vietnam.
Wholesale revenue was disproportionately affected, declining 27% on a currency-neutral basis.
Nike Direct decreased by 21%, with declines in both digital and physical retail channels.
COVID-related lockdowns continued to cause fluctuations in retail traffic, although foot traffic occasionally recovered to pre-pandemic levels during the quarter.
Digital sales declined 27%, partly due to delayed product launches on Sneakers.
During the 11.11 shopping event, we achieved stronger digital performance with significant member acquisition and higher Average Order Value through improved consumer engagement.
Despite challenges, we continue to apply our operational strategies and remain optimistic about the long-term prospects in Greater China.
This quarter, we expanded our Joy of Sport brand campaign, featuring local influencers, Olympians, and other athletes from Nike's leading sports marketing portfolio in Greater China.
The Jordan brand added excitement by announcing their first female athlete signing in Asia, basketball player Yang Shu Yu.
To support these activities and normalize our marketing investment, we increased our spending on demand creation by over 40% compared to the previous year.
Our local team remains dedicated to creating unique and authentic connections with Chinese consumers.
We celebrated Nike's 40th anniversary in China by reintroducing the original Nai-ke collection through the Express Lane, with comprehensive storytelling about the history and heritage of these iconic products.
During the initial launch, all products sold out within the first hour.
We plan to expand the Express Lane to offer more unique, localized products, leveraging our most popular global product lines to generate distinctly Nike energy in the marketplace.
We observe encouraging signs in Greater China, and although inventory supply has significantly disrupted the market, we still expect fiscal year 2022 to be a year of recovery.
We anticipate sequential improvement starting in the third quarter.
Moving on to APLA, Q2 revenue declined 6% on a currency-neutral basis, and EBIT decreased 8% as reported.
Double-digit revenue growth in SOCO was offset by declines in Asia Pacific territories, which were more heavily impacted by Vietnam factory closures and the business model shift in Brazil.
Holiday retail sales across the market grew compared to the previous year, despite supply disruptions and store closures in SEA&I and Pacific regions.
Nike Direct grew by 6%, led by Nike Digital growth of 25%.
Our teams capitalized on market opportunities, with all territories successfully executing Member Days and locally relevant promotions, including Singles Day in Southeast Asia, Buen Fin in Mexico, and Cyber Week in Japan.
Mexico's digital business more than doubled as we implemented a localized assortment and improved fulfillment capabilities through the Nike App.
APLA continues to leverage the Express Lane, its digital ecosystem, and global partnerships to create locally relevant products and meaningful engagement with consumers worldwide.
Consumers in APLA are highly connected, and our team continues to innovate with digital experiences that are locally relevant.
The Dia De Los Muertos footwear collection saw 100% sell-through, and this story was expanded globally through our new partnership with Roblox.
Let's now discuss our financial outlook.
As we near the end of the pandemic's second year, comparing quarters and fiscal years becomes increasingly challenging due to multiple waves of COVID-related disruptions affecting the consumer marketplace and supply chain at different times.
We expect the operating environment to remain unpredictable as COVID variants continue to disrupt business operations.
Our fiscal 2022 financial outlook reflects inventory supply significantly lagging consumer demand across Nike's brand portfolio.
However, Nike's long-term market opportunity is greater than ever, so we remain focused on managing short-term challenges while pursuing our Consumer Direct Acceleration strategy and working towards our fiscal 2025 financial goals.
For fiscal 2022, we continue to expect revenue to grow mid-single-digits compared to the previous year, consistent with our guidance from 90 days ago.
For Q3, we anticipate revenue to grow low single-digits versus the prior year, due to ongoing impacts from lost production caused by COVID-related disruptions in Vietnam.
We are increasing our gross margin guidance to expand 150 basis points compared to the previous year.
We expect to continue benefiting from exceptional demand in a lean marketplace inventory environment.
Full-price realization will remain above our long-term target, with lower channel markdowns.
However, we anticipate product costs to rise in the second half due to higher macro input costs.
We are also planning for supply chain costs for the full year to increase relative to our estimates from 90 days ago, with a greater impact in the second half.
Lastly, we now expect foreign exchange to provide a 55 basis point tailwind compared to the previous year.
We continue to expect SG&A to grow mid-to-high teens for the full year as demand creation spending normalizes and we invest in capabilities to support our consumer-led digital transformation.
We now anticipate our effective tax rate to be in the low teens for the full year.
Consumer Direct Acceleration is driving our business forward and transforming our financial model.
We continue to demonstrate our ability to manage through uncertainty and volatility in the current operating environment, but we are doing more than just managing through - we are building Nike for the future with deeper consumer connections, a pipeline of product innovation to meet the needs of modern athletes, and new operational capabilities required to serve consumers directly and digitally at scale.
We have a clear vision of our brands' long-term future, so we remain focused on what is necessary to succeed over the long term.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am Rubun Dey, the Head of Investor Relations.
Joining me to discuss our company's performance and financial results are our President and CEO Horacio Rozanski, along with our Executive VP, CFO and Treasurer Lloyd Howell.
In this presentation, we will examine some non-GAAP financial measures and metrics that we believe offer valuable insights for our investors.
We provide explanations and reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures in our Q1 FY2022 presentation slides.
We have now reached slide number four.
Lloyd and I are delighted to present our most recent financial results and highlight the exceptional work of Booz Allen's 28,000+ employees.
Our sector, and indeed the entire economy, is transitioning back to more in-person work as we emerge from the COVID-19 pandemic.
At Booz Allen, we are enthusiastic about the opportunities this shift presents for both our employees and clients.
Following my introduction, I will hand over to Lloyd to provide a more detailed analysis of our financial performance.
Let me begin with a summary of the quarter.
During our previous call in late May, we discussed our short and medium-term objectives and our outlook for fiscal year 2022.
We anticipated another year of substantial revenue growth, robust earnings growth, continued cash generation, and strategic capital deployment.
We also mentioned that the year's pattern would likely differ from recent years, with slower revenue growth in the first half and significant acceleration in the second half.
This pattern is influenced by several factors, including pandemic recovery, implementation of a new financial system, and our acquisition of Liberty IT Solutions.
We are pleased to confirm our guidance for the full fiscal year.
Operationally, we are returning to pre-pandemic business routines.
Our Defense and Civil divisions are aligned with our government's top priorities, have a strong pipeline, and secured several significant wins this quarter.
These two segments represent 75% of our revenue and continue to show solid growth.
In our intelligence division, hiring is progressing well, and our portfolio restructuring has resulted in some important contract wins.
The first quarter revenue decline was mainly due to reduced billable expenses, but we still expect growth in this division for the year.
Global Commercial accounts for 2% of our revenue.
Ongoing declines are related to our portfolio restructuring and pandemic impacts.
We anticipate year-over-year growth in the second half of the fiscal year for this segment.
Overall, our entire business portfolio achieved low single-digit revenue growth year-over-year, as anticipated.
The relatively slow growth was primarily due to a return to more typical staff utilization and PTO trends compared to Q1 of last fiscal year, when the country was largely under lockdown.
Our bottom-line results, including adjusted EBITDA, adjusted EBITDA margin, and adjusted diluted earnings per share, exceeded our expectations.
The book-to-bill ratio for the quarter was also strong, and we are excited about the high-quality mission-centered work we are winning.
Cash from operations was lower than expected, mainly due to one-time costs associated with the Liberty transaction.
Lloyd will provide a detailed breakdown of all financial figures shortly.
As you may recall from our previous call, we outlined several near and mid-term priorities crucial to our success.
Our optimism for the year is largely due to the significant progress we've made on these priorities.
Let me briefly review them.
Our top priority is recruitment, and in Q1, we began to see results from our intense focus in this area.
We are observing sequential month-over-month growth and expect this momentum to build throughout the year.
Secondly, we continue to reshape our intelligence and global commercial portfolios.
We believe the tactical and strategic changes we're implementing will lead to year-over-year growth.
Thirdly, we are very pleased to have completed the Liberty acquisition in mid-June.
Our teams are collaborating closely, and everything we've seen since the closing confirms this was an excellent deal for both Booz Allen and Liberty.
We are very excited about the strategic opportunities to enhance each other's strengths.
Fourthly, our NextGen financial system successfully launched on April 1st and is performing very well, thanks to the outstanding efforts of our team.
After more than three years of preparation, launching the system and completing the first quarter close without major disruptions were critical milestones.
Lastly, we continue to invest in our people and capabilities as we carefully manage the transition to a post-COVID environment.
Consistent with this, creating the best possible experience for our talent remains a constant focus for us.
I'd like to take a moment to share how Booz Allen is approaching the future of work.
We are cautiously optimistic that the worst of the pandemic is behind us in the United States and most locations where Booz Allen operates.
As such, we are preparing to fully reopen our offices the day after Labor Day, provided health and safety conditions allow.
As we move towards reopening, we plan to incorporate the best practices learned over the past 16 months to create work methods that better serve our talent, clients, and the critical missions we support.
Going forward, our workforce will operate under three models.
We've always maintained a small group of fully remote employees, which we anticipate will remain relatively constant in size.
There's a segment of our workforce that operates full-time at government and company facilities, which will continue but is expected to decrease proportionally from previous levels.
Our clients have demonstrated remarkable ingenuity throughout the pandemic.
Many clients are now interested in flexible work models that better align with their objectives while reducing the number of full-time on-site staff.
The hybrid workforce model is the third option, which we predict will eventually encompass the majority of our employees.
Hybrid workers will spend less time in Booz Allen and client offices than before, instead splitting their time between remote work and in-person collaboration.
This arrangement offers employees greater flexibility in their personal and professional lives while maintaining our culture and strong connections with clients, the company, and colleagues.
The most exciting aspect of our internal and external discussions about the future of work is the universal recognition of the potential for increased flexibility.
There's an expectation that we must adopt new work methods due to technological advancements and the competitive nature of talent acquisition.
To thrive now and in the future, employers in both government and private sectors must cultivate a workforce that is more dispersed, digitally-oriented, and diverse.
Booz Allen is at the forefront of this shift, collaborating with government clients to reimagine and restructure their approach to fulfilling critical missions.
Many clients believe that current global conditions and future needs necessitate fundamental changes in how federal agencies conduct business on behalf of the public.
In keeping with our identity, we will proactively embrace these opportunities for change.
As we look towards autumn and beyond, our company has numerous reasons for optimism and excitement.
We are dedicating significant effort to supporting our employees, expanding our business, serving clients, and positioning Booz Allen for future success.
Our primary objective remains creating both short-term and long-term value for our investors and all stakeholders.
Lloyd, I'll now hand it over to you.
Before delving into the financial details, I'd like to highlight that this has been an incredibly busy quarter for us.
Some key achievements include finalizing our acquisition of Liberty and initiating the integration process, refinancing our balance sheet through the bond market.
We invested in Latent II, a strategically important and rapidly expanding company in the AI and machine learning sector.
We've intensified our recruitment and hiring efforts with promising outcomes.
We've implemented our next-generation financial system.
Additionally, we've engaged in company-wide discussions about our strategic review and future investment strategy.
We're energized by the rapid pace of activity and look forward to sharing more information in the coming months.
Now, let's review our first quarter performance.
As we mentioned in May, we anticipated some initial fluctuations in our top-line results as we transition to a post-pandemic operational rhythm.
However, we maintained strong performance in adjusted EBITDA and ADEPS through careful cost management.
We're also encouraged by our solid bookings performance and recruitment pace.
Operating cash flow fell short of our initial forecast, but we view most of the contributing factors as either one-time or temporary.
Overall, today's results align with the expectations we set last quarter, and we remain confident in our plan for the full fiscal year.
Regarding top-line performance, revenue increased by 1.7% year-over-year to $2 billion in the first quarter.
Liberty contributed approximately $16 million to revenue growth.
Revenue excluding billable expenses grew by 1.9% to $1.4 billion.
Revenue growth was driven by solid operational performance, primarily offset by higher-than-normal staff utilization in the same period last year.
The quarter's top-line performance met our expectations.
As a reminder, we forecast constrained low single-digit top-line growth in the first half of the year, driven by four factors: First, the need to ramp up contract work and hiring; second, a more normalized utilization rate compared to the high staff utilization in the first half of fiscal year 2021, which we estimate accounts for about 300 basis points of growth.
Third, high PTO balances at the start of the fiscal year, with the expectation that employees will take more time off; and fourth, minor timing differences in labor costing resulting from the implementation of our new financial system.
As previously stated, we expect growth to accelerate throughout the year.
Now, let's examine performance at the market level.
In the defense sector, revenue grew by 4.4%, with strong growth in revenue excluding billable expenses, partially offset by significant materials purchases in the prior year period.
In the civil sector, revenue increased by 6%, led by strong performance in our health business and the addition of Liberty.
We expect momentum to build throughout the year as more administration priorities gain traction and we continue to capture opportunities, building on our strong win rates.
Revenue from our intelligence business declined by 6.4% this quarter.
Revenue excluding billable expenses grew in line with our expectations but was more than offset at the top-line by lower billable expenses.
We are excited about several critical recent wins in the portfolio and believe we have the right leadership and strategic direction in place to achieve growth this year.
Finally, revenue in the Global Commercial sector declined by 27.4% compared to the same quarter last year.
We expect growth in the latter half of the year, which largely depends on recruiting more staff to meet increasing demand and overcoming challenging previous year comparisons internationally.
Our quarterly book-to-bill ratio was 1.3, while the 12-month ratio stood at 1.2.
The overall backlog increased by 16.5% year-over-year, including Liberty, reaching a new high of $26.8 billion.
The funded backlog grew by 1.6% to $3.5 billion.
The unfunded backlog increased by 91% to $9 billion, while priced options decreased by 3.7% to $14.3 billion.
We are pleased with our first quarter booking performance, following a seasonally strong fourth quarter.
We believe our consistent long-term book-to-bill ratio shows ongoing strong demand for our services and the high value placed on our understanding of client needs.
As of June 30th, our workforce consisted of 28,558 employees, an increase of 1,177 or 4.3% from the previous year.
Our main focus for the year is to accelerate hiring to meet the high demand for our services.
We are optimistic about how we ended the first quarter and expect to see improvement throughout the year.
Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $238 million, an 11.8% increase from the same period last year.
This growth was mainly due to our ability to bill for fees in our intelligence business and the timing of unallowable expenses within the fiscal year.
These factors, along with continued low billable expenses as a percentage of revenue, pushed our adjusted EBITDA margin to 12%.
We anticipate an increase in billable expenses and unallowable spending as the year progresses.
First quarter net income dropped 29% year-over-year to $92 million, primarily due to Liberty transaction-related expenses of about $67 million.
Adjusted net income rose 12.3% to $146 million from the previous year, mainly driven by the same factors that led to higher adjusted EBITDA.
Diluted earnings per share decreased 27% to $0.67 from $0.92 in the same period last year.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share increased 15% to $1.07 from $0.93.
The improvements in our non-GAAP metrics, which exclude transaction-related costs, were primarily due to operational performance and a lower share count this quarter resulting from our share repurchase program.
Cash flow from operations was negative $11 million in the first quarter.
This decline was mainly due to lower collections, largely attributable to timing issues related to receivables associated with the integration of our new enterprise financial system.
As our employees and clients adapt to the new invoicing system, we expect to return to normal collection patterns in the coming months.
Operating cash flow was negatively impacted by approximately $67 million in transaction costs paid in the first quarter, including about $56 million cash payment at the closing of the Liberty acquisition.
These cash payments represent a reallocation of part of the overall $725 million purchase price, before adjustments, from investing cash flows to operating cash flows.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $9 million, down $11 million from the previous year, primarily due to lower facility expenses.
We still expect capital expenditures to fall within our projected range for the year.
During the quarter, we issued $500 million of 4% senior notes due in 2029.
We also extended the maturity of our Term Loan A and revolving credit facility to 2026 and increased our revolver capacity by $500 million to $1 billion total.
These actions support our disciplined capital deployment strategy.
We will continue to use our balance sheet strategically.
During the quarter, we paid $52 million in quarterly dividends and repurchased $111 million worth of shares at an average price of $83.91 per share.
In total, including the Liberty acquisition, we deployed $889 million.
We are announcing that our Board has approved a regular dividend of $0.37 per share, to be paid on August 31st to stockholders of record on August 16th.
Our actions this quarter demonstrate our commitment to preserving and maximizing shareholder value through a disciplined, balanced capital allocation approach.
Please refer to slide seven.
We are reaffirming our fiscal year 2022 guidance.
As discussed last quarter, the first half/second half dynamics we outlined continue to guide our full-year growth expectations.
We expect total revenue growth between 7% and 10%, including Liberty.
Our contract and hiring progress will determine where we fall within that range.
We continue to anticipate revenue growth accelerating throughout the year.
We expect adjusted EBITDA margin in the mid-10% range.
We project adjusted diluted earnings per share to be between $4.10 and $4.30, based on an effective tax rate of 22% to 24% and 134 million to 137 million weighted average shares outstanding.
The ADEPS guidance includes both Liberty and additional interest expense from our $500 million bond offering.
We expect operating cash flow to grow to $800 million to $850 million, including the aforementioned $56 million in cash payments related to the Liberty transaction.
Due to these one-time payments, we expect to end the year at the lower end of our range, partially offset by a combination of working capital management and operational performance.
Lastly, we expect capex in the $80 million to $100 million range.
In conclusion, we are starting the year as expected and look forward to a successful year ahead.
We took on the ambitious task of executing both a major acquisition and a company-wide rollout of our financial systems in the same quarter.
With that, Rubun, let's open the line for questions.
Please open the line, operator.
Summary:

reaffirms fiscal 2022 guidance.
