input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Mike Lukemire, the president and COO, will join us for the Q&A portion.
I encourage you to review our Form 10-K filed with the SEC to understand the full scope of risk factors that could affect our performance.
Recently, I've been contemplating the main points I wanted to address today and carefully considering my target audience for these remarks.
While I won't dwell on the past quarter or year, it's noteworthy that we've achieved our third consecutive record year and remain very positive about the future.
The consumer segment faced a 24% comparison, while Hawthorne's 39% growth was measured against a 64% comparison.
I'm aware there are some obvious issues we need to discuss.
We'll address our pricing strategy, commodity outlook, excess inventory in the cannabis market, and our thoughts on capital allocation.
We'll cover these topics and share our perspective on fiscal year 2022.
As a public company CEO for two decades, I've observed how short-term concerns can often overshadow the bigger picture.
I'd like to focus mainly on more than just our current performance.
To be honest, there are many exciting developments at the company right now, some of which I can't disclose.
Our business is at a crucial turning point that could significantly alter our appearance five years from now.
We have the chance to strengthen our company, broaden our competitive advantage, and allow a new generation of leaders to shape it through their perspective, not just mine or my executive team's.
We view the current market volatility as an opportunity.
Those willing to be proactive during these times can seize opportunities others can't and further enhance their competitive advantages, which ultimately drives long-term shareholder value.
I want the main takeaway from today to be a clearer understanding of the path we're on.
To be frank, my intended audience is quite specific.
To our sell-side colleagues, I understand the need to refine your models and share that information with your clients. We'll provide what you need, but my remarks aren't directed at you.
My comments are also not aimed at short-term investors.
I won't get bogged down in discussions about quarterly breakdowns, commodity spot prices, or year-over-year SG&A comparisons.
However, I do want to address those investors who see the long-term potential in SMG shares.
I want to convey our direction and why we're confident our efforts will create shareholder value.
I'll address key questions about fiscal 2022, but I'll integrate them into a broader context of how we're running the business rather than focusing solely on P&L impacts.
To look forward, I need to briefly look back.
For the five-year period ending September 30, our strategic plan assumed a relatively mature core business and overall growth of about 4% to 6%, driven by higher growth at Hawthorne.
We aimed to achieve consistent shareholder returns of 10% to 12% through P&L leverage, share repurchases, and maintaining a roughly 2% dividend yield.
We also set a five-year target of $1.5 billion in cumulative free cash flow.
We surpassed all of these goals.
While we're proud of this achievement, we recognize that this strategy has run its course as opportunities have changed. We've changed too.
The next phase in our evolution will reflect these new realities.
We've identified five distinct growth pillars for the next five years.
Three of these pillars relate to the U.S. consumer business, while the other two are connected to Hawthorne.
First, we anticipate higher sustainable growth with our existing brands in our core business, largely due to our ability to reach a new generation of consumers.
Second, there's potential for further growth in our direct-to-consumer efforts if we invest in people, brands, partnerships, and infrastructure.
Third, live goods remain a significant growth opportunity and a way to establish a more direct relationship with gardeners.
Our aim is still for consumers to view us as a gardening company, not just a gardening supply company.
Fourth, to support Hawthorne's future growth, we must continue to prioritize the commercial grower in everything we do.
This means further strengthening our model, driven by innovation and technical solutions.
Fifth, the cannabis industry will undoubtedly continue to evolve and grow.
Companies that are creative and bold enough to enter this market early have the potential for a first-mover advantage.
We demonstrated this willingness when we created Hawthorne, and we plan to do so again.
As we pursue these pillars, we're strengthening our team.
We're focusing on succession planning and ensuring our ESG efforts are integrated into our operations and better understood by key stakeholders.
We debated as a team and with our board whether to pursue all these opportunities simultaneously.
We agreed we had to, but we recognize that succeeding in all these areas requires reorganization and empowering a new generation of leaders.
While there are no plans for me or any current team member to step down, nearly every member of my team has made changes to their organizations.
The level of oversight needed to succeed in these efforts requires Mike Lukemire to focus more on strategy and implementation in the fastest-growing areas of the business.
He has restructured his organization so that each of these pillars reports directly to him.
Josh Peoples and Dave Swihart will effectively co-lead the consumer segment.
On the corporate side, Cory has strengthened his leadership team with new outside talent.
Denise Stump and Jim King have realigned their teams to better meet business needs.
Additionally, most of the M&A opportunities we're pursuing include management teams that can further strengthen our own.
If all the opportunities we see come to fruition, we could potentially double the size of Scotts Miracle-Gro within five years.
That's not necessarily the goal; we want smart growth, not growth for its own sake, but the potential magnitude of the opportunity could be transformative.
Let me briefly explain how we plan to execute these pillars, or at least discuss them in the context of our expectations for next year.
We believe the U.S. consumer segment can achieve sustainable long-term growth of 2% to 4% annually between the first two pillars.
Our previous strategic plan assumed growth of 0% to 2%.
If we can maintain growth at this higher level, those additional two points provide significant P&L leverage and improved cash flow.
It's worth noting that our guidance for next year assumes flat to slightly declining growth in the U.S. consumer segment.
This is based on an assumed reset of the business in a post-COVID world.
Specifically, we're planning for a decline in unit volume offset by pricing.
You'll recall from our Q3 call that we implemented about five points of pricing in August.
Recently, we've informed our retail partners of a second price increase effective in January.
This more targeted increase will range from mid-single to low double-digits depending on the product line.
In total, we now expect pricing in 2022 to be in the high single-digit range, aiming to cover commodity prices.
While we believe our sales assumption for 2022 is prudent, current trends suggest a better outcome.
Consumer POS in units for fiscal 2021 was six points higher than in 2020.
More importantly, it was 21 points better than fiscal 2019 and actually strengthened later in the year.
Consumer volume during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2021, while down seven points from last year's record performance, was 35 points higher than the same period in fiscal 2019.
Consumers are demonstrating that lawn and garden is an essential part of their lives.
Every data point shows they've remained engaged with the category and our brands throughout the past season.
These trends continued in October.
While it's a relatively small month, it's an important conclusion to the season, especially in the Midwest and Northeast.
POS in units was up 4% in October compared to last year's record result and up 42% compared to fiscal 2019.
As we enter the off-season, the POS numbers won't be very informative until February.
Obviously, we won't know until next summer how much of the COVID bump we've retained.
But I'm confident we'll have a significantly higher base to grow from.
We continue to invest with that in mind.
Millennial homeowners have clearly become a demographic tailwind, more than offsetting baby boomers leaving the category.
This group of consumers cares more about gardening than their parents and sees the category as more rewarding and purpose-driven.
A 30-year-old couple buying a home today and entering our category for the first time has the potential to stay with us for 20 years or longer.
We must operate with that timeframe in mind.
We don't want our marketers to worry about hitting a target for Wall Street.
Their job is to drive consumer engagement, brand loyalty, and market share.
We're going to give Josh Peoples and his team the tools to achieve that.
The same applies to our direct-to-consumer pillar.
This area is approaching 10% of our U.S. consumer sales and will only grow larger.
When we think about direct-to-consumer, it goes beyond selling items on our website.
It also means collaborating closely with our retail partners to support their online efforts.
It also involves finding new partners who can help boost the appeal of gardening and have their own digital platforms we can leverage.
Patti Ziegler, one of our brightest and most creative leaders, directs our direct-to-consumer effort.
In addition to the efforts I've already mentioned, she and her team have launched native online brands like Green Digs, Knock Knock, and Instead.
One of their greatest successes has been with AeroGrow.
Patti has championed the potential of our direct-to-consumer platform from the beginning and continues to reimagine the future of this business.
Succeeding in our direct-to-consumer effort also requires improving our IT and supply chain infrastructure.
Dave Swihart, whose role has recently expanded to lead both supply chain and R&D, is driving towards that goal.
We need to enhance our ability to ship directly to consumers, especially in categories like live goods, which has significant online potential.
Until recently, our direct-to-consumer efforts didn't warrant much attention, but that's changed.
While it's still too early to gauge the ultimate potential of this pillar, it will be a significant contributor to growth moving forward.
I'm equally convinced our third pillar, live goods, will be even more important.
Living plants serve as an entry point to the lawn and garden sector, but have traditionally been localized, poorly promoted, and standardized.
We think we can improve upon this situation.
We've made a promising start with Bonnie and its chief executive, Mike Sutterer, and we're collaborating with Bonnie's other owner, Alabama Farmers Coop (AFC), to explore additional growth opportunities with significant potential.
AFC shares our vision of establishing a nationwide branded enterprise across various categories of living plants.
We believe our combined efforts can better address the needs of gardeners and our retail partners through innovation, marketing, and supply chain improvements.
We've already made significant strides in enhancing the Bonnie business, though there's still much more to be done.
The remaining two strategic components are associated with Hawthorne.
Chris will provide more details about the current market conditions, but I want to assure you that I'm not fixated on fourth quarter sales or first quarter projections.
I'm confident that Chris and his team have a good grasp of the current situation.
More importantly, I believe they're navigating the market fluctuations while maintaining focus on long-term opportunities.
If market challenges persist for a few quarters, expect them to capitalize on the situation.
We won't chase sales, but we will take an aggressive stance to further strengthen Hawthorne and its market position.
For instance, anticipate increased efforts in innovation.
I recently visited our new research and development facility in British Columbia.
I've also toured field stations in Oregon, Florida, and Ohio.
The key takeaway is that our research in hemp and cannabis is revolutionizing the industry.
From lighting to nutrients to growing media, our research aims not only to improve our product offerings but also to help growers achieve better and more cost-effective results.
Our unique understanding of plant science and indoor cultivation nuances is unparalleled.
No other company in the industry is doing what Hawthorne is doing, and our competitors can't even attempt to replicate our model.
This is an important point to keep in mind.
We're also likely to use this period as an opportunity to increase our merger and acquisition efforts.
We continue to be cautious in our M&A approach, but the economics of some deals have become more attractive recently.
The final component of our strategy is incorporated into the recent establishment of a new subsidiary called the Hawthorne Collective.
I've been hinting for months about opportunities to invest in emerging areas of the cannabis industry, but this is my first chance to discuss the effort in detail.
It begins with our recent investment in RIV Capital, a Canadian-based publicly traded company that owns or invests in various cannabis-related businesses.
We share a common vision with RIV's other major investors to create a fully integrated business based on acquiring licenses for cultivation and distribution.
From there, RIV can partner with some of the most well-managed brands in the cannabis industry.
There's much speculation about the potential for new brands to succeed as the market expands into categories like beverages.
However, too few people are focusing on existing brands in traditional categories.
This is already a multi-billion dollar market, with brands operating within individual states.
We're convinced there's tremendous potential for some of these brands to thrive more broadly as the market expands, and our investment in RIV reflects that belief.
We believe our unique expertise in the cannabis industry gives us an advantage in areas beyond our existing portfolio.
However, we currently cannot make direct investments in those areas.
In fact, we can't even have a direct ownership stake in a company that does, but we can create an ownership option, which is what our convertible loan to RIV Capital represents.
In the short term, we don't expect to see an impact from the RIV investment on our profit and loss statement, and the $150 million we've invested doesn't affect our ability to invest in other areas or return cash to shareholders.
In the medium term, RIV may seek additional capital infusions.
We might be interested, depending on the opportunities, but I won't speculate on how much we might invest.
The honest answer is that it depends.
But just as we did when we acquired General Hydroponics, Botanicare, Gavita, and Can-Filters, we're willing to make investments others might avoid until there's more clarity about the future.
If you're a short-term investor, you may not like this approach.
But the long-term potential is real and significant.
Eventually, if we convert our financial interest in RIV into equity, which is definitely the goal, it may prompt us to reassess our current capital structure.
Many of you have asked if we'll spin off Hawthorne as a separate company.
I've said we'd only consider doing that for strategic reasons, not to chase valuation, and that's still true.
Over the past year, we've worked to understand what a potential separation would require, and I believe we're capable of executing such a move if we decided it made sense.
Let me be clear: we have no near-term plans to do this.
But could it become a viable option?
I think the possibility is growing.
As I hand over to Cory, I want to emphasize that I'm just as confident about our near-term plans as I am about our long-term strategy.
The U.S. consumer business is performing well, and our customers continue to demonstrate the importance of this category in their lives.
At Hawthorne, while we expect continued top-line pressure through Q1, I'm confident in our team's ability to persevere, and we still anticipate sales growth on a full-year basis.
Are there more challenges now than a year ago?
Am I thrilled with the current stock price?
But we're on a path to build a better and stronger business, and we won't be distracted by external noise.
I mentioned earlier that we exceeded all the financial targets set in our previous strategic plan.
Our goal is to remain on a path that allows shareholders to continue benefiting from the opportunities outlined in our new plan and the pillars I've discussed.
The confidence we all have is part of our decision to increase our share repurchase efforts.
I told you last quarter we had allocated $250 million for that purpose.
We now expect to add another $100 million to that total, and we hope to acquire as many of those shares as possible in the next two quarters.
Cory, please take it from here.
I'll spend a few minutes discussing the main themes from our fourth quarter results, particularly regarding sales and gross margin.
In between, I'll hand over to Chris to provide some insight on Hawthorne.
U.S. consumer sales performed better than expected, finishing up 11% compared to the 7% to 9% growth we anticipated.
At $3.2 billion, sales have grown by nearly $900 million in the last two years.
The supply chain team deserves significant credit for their ability to deliver this growth.
The targeted investments we have made and will continue to make in this area will prove crucial.
Consumer engagement remained extremely strong through the fourth quarter, keeping our retailers equally engaged.
In the consumer segment, sales declined 28% in Q4, but we were up against a 92% increase from the previous year.
Also, remember that Q4 had six fewer days this year than last year.
Adjusting for that, sales in the quarter would have declined 23%.
At Hawthorne, the calendar shift cost us seven points for the quarter.
While year-over-year sales declined 2%, the segment would have been up 5% on a comparable basis when adjusting for the calendar.
The U.S. Hawthorne business grew by over 10% last year in Q4 given the same comparison.
Finally, recall that Hawthorne was up against a 64% increase in the same period a year ago.
On a full-year basis, Hawthorne grew 39% to $1.4 billion.
I'll remind you that number was $640 million in fiscal 2019.
We have more than doubled the sales of that business in two years, and all of that growth was organic.
On the segment profit line, Hawthorne earned $164 million in fiscal 2021, for an operating margin of 11.5%.
The profit was up 46% from last year and more than 200% from 2019.
We've said repeatedly that we're trying to strike a balance between growth and improved profitability.
I think the results speak for themselves.
As many of you know, I served as a finance lead at Hawthorne, almost since the inception of that business, before joining the corporate team as CFO.
As you look at the Hawthorne results, I encourage investors to look deeper than the numbers.
While the growth and profit improvements have been impressive, the improvements we've made to how the business operates tell an even better story.
From the integration of seven separate businesses to the implementation of SAP, the revamping of our sales force, and the creation of the world's only cannabis-focused R&D program, the efforts of this team have been outstanding.
I know all of you want to know more about the current state of the business.
I'll leave the details around the numbers to Cory, but I know you're wondering about the current state of the industry and how we're navigating it.
So let me address that for a few minutes.
We're obviously seeing some disruption in the market right now, but we expect it to be temporary.
Our field sales team began seeing signs of a potential slowdown in late June.
We gained more insight into the issues in July, which allowed us to share some of those insights on our third quarter conference call in August.
That's when we cautioned that growth would be significantly slower in Q4 than we'd seen for the rest of the year.
Since then, many of you have been asking whether this will be a replay of 2018.
We don't see it that way at all, and we're not alone.
Some of you were in Las Vegas a couple of weeks ago for the MJBiz conference.
It's the largest cannabis trade show in the world.
If you were there, you saw firsthand that this is not an industry that's worried about the future.
Consumer demand for cannabis products continues to grow, and the market continues to expand.
Regarding the current environment, what was clear to me in Vegas was that the industry is becoming increasingly adept at navigating the inevitable choppiness in a market like this.
What's happening right now is actually pretty straightforward.
In California, there was simply too much cannabis harvested in the past few months, especially from outdoor growers in the northern part of the state.
On top of a strong harvest from the first crop turn earlier in the year, many growers harvested their second cannabis crop earlier this season due to concerns about wildfires, drought, and, in the case of the legacy market, fear of increased enforcement efforts.
The combination of too much product and relatively poor quality has put downward pressure on wholesale cannabis prices.
However, that issue should resolve itself once the current supply makes its way through the marketplace.
Because the legacy market remains a big part of what's happening in California, the available data isn't great.
Providing a precise answer regarding the duration for the current oversupply to resolve itself in the market is challenging.
This is why we're predicting a decrease in Hawthorne sales for the first quarter.
Nevertheless, the most crucial point is that the cannabis end market continues to expand, and we anticipate renewed growth in the coming calendar year.
This trend is expected to persist for the foreseeable future.
In fact, many premium growers have informed us that current market conditions aren't affecting them at all, and they continue to thrive.
Another crucial point to remember is that, unlike in 2018, there are currently no regulatory obstacles.
Three years ago, California severely hindered the launch of the recreational market.
That was the primary issue impacting the market at that time.
Obtaining a legal operating license was extremely difficult, whether for cultivators or dispensaries.
While California's current market remains more expensive and bureaucratic than other states, it has significantly improved from the past, and the legal market there continues to grow.
Some of you are also curious if the current situation will lead to consolidation.
The answer is straightforward.
Yes, it certainly will.
However, these types of fluctuations are precisely what we anticipate.
This occurred in Colorado in 2015, in Oregon when it legalized, and is likely to happen to some extent in California.
In fact, we're observing this in Oklahoma right now.
Like many new markets, Oklahoma experienced rapid initial growth and may have become somewhat overbuilt.
So we expect a pause there before growth resumes.
We have consistently informed you over the years that this industry is likely to experience occasional turbulence.
This isn't the first time the industry has seen an oversupply of cannabis, and it certainly won't be the last.
What's crucial for Hawthorne is that we maintain our strategy.
Long-term growth will be present.
I'm not concerned about that.
Instead, I want to ensure we're doing everything necessary to outpace our competitors.
Jim has already mentioned that we won't slow down our innovation efforts, which extend far beyond just new product development, bringing me back to the MJBiz conference in Vegas a couple of weeks ago.
Like most major trade shows, MJBiz was canceled last year due to COVID.
So we haven't seen the entire industry in one place for over two years.
What was evident to us, and frankly almost everyone we interacted with, is how much progress Hawthorne has made in those two years and how much we've distanced ourselves from the competition.
We have fundamentally transformed our sales approach, and that transformation is ongoing.
We've introduced new products that have improved growers' results by both increasing yields and reducing their operating costs.
We've also used innovation to help us in more qualitative ways, such as establishing the Hawthorne Social Justice Fund within our corporate foundation.
While I understand the questions you need to ask about our declining growth rate, I urge you not to lose sight of the bigger picture.
There's no doubt that we're the clear industry leader.
There's no doubt that our competitive advantages are unique, and there's also no doubt that the cannabis industry still has substantial growth potential ahead.
So looking ahead to fiscal '22, I'm not worried about a few obstacles.
Instead, I'm excited to see how much further we can push this business and continue to lead the way in an industry that remains poised for years of growth.
Let's now examine the gross margin line on the P&L.
Like nearly all other CPG companies, we've continued to face pressure from higher commodity and distribution costs.
However, the year-over-year change in the margin rate during Q4 requires some additional context.
In Q4 of fiscal '21, the adjusted gross margin rate was 17.4% compared to 24.3% in 2020.
Company-wide sales in Q4 of last year increased by nearly 80%.
So the fixed cost leverage in a relatively small quarter led to a significant improvement in the margin rate.
If you compare the Q4 gross margin rate in '21 versus '19, the difference is only 100 basis points, attributable to a combination of segment mix and higher commodity costs.
For the full year, the gross margin rate decreased by 270 basis points to 30.3%.
The primary reason for the decline was the year-over-year increase in commodity costs of about $85 million, almost all of which was anticipated, followed by higher distribution costs.
As you know, we didn't adjust our prices this year until August in the U.S. consumer business.
So we had limited ability to offset the commodity inflation during the first three quarters of the year.
This situation will change significantly in fiscal '22, which I'll explain further when I discuss our guidance for next year.
Higher volume was able to drive improved fixed cost leverage and conversion, helping to offset the commodity cost increases.
SG&A decreased by 2 percentage points in fiscal '21 to $743 million.
It declined 21% in the quarter to $161 million.
Lower variable compensation was the main factor.
Additionally, in Q4 of 2020, we used some of our strong earnings upside to significantly increase our annual contribution to The Scotts Miracle-Gro Foundation, which we did not repeat in fiscal '21.
Interest expense was $5 million higher in Q4 compared to a year ago, but essentially flat on a full-year basis.
Remember, we issued $900 million of bonds in the second half of the year, which drove an increase in the quarter.
On the bottom line, adjusted net income, which excludes restructuring, impairment, and one-time items, increased by 28% to $528 million or $9.23 per share.
That's just $0.01 shy of a $2 per share increase in a single year and more than double the $4.47 per share we earned in 2019.
The earnings per share figure is at the high end of the revised range we set in early June, and is a significant achievement given the difficult comparisons and some of the cost challenges we've had to overcome in the second half of the year.
Rather than delving further into those details, I want to shift focus and share our thoughts about fiscal '22.
This assumes the U.S. consumer segment is flat to minus 4%, and that Hawthorne grows 8% to 12%.
None of these ranges account for the potential impact of acquisitions.
For the consumer segment, we're entering the year assuming unit volume will decline by high single digits.
Roughly half of that decline is expected from lower shipments in the first half of the year.
Remember that last year's Q1 was up nearly 150%, as retailers worked hard to replenish depleted inventory levels.
Since current retail inventory levels remain higher than a year ago, we likely won't see a repeat of that kind of initial stock-up.
We're also, for planning purposes, assuming modest declines in consumer takeaway in fiscal '22, mostly driven by the difficult comparisons we face in the first half.
As Jim has already indicated, consumer POS has been stronger than we expected in recent months, and has actually been positive for the fall season.
It's easy for us to ramp up to meet higher consumer demand if it materializes, but the prudent approach is to assume a slight decline.
Most, and perhaps all, of the planned unit volume decline should be offset by pricing.
You should see some benefit from pricing in Q1 from the August price increases, with the balance taking effect during our Q2.
Regarding Hawthorne, we're planning for 8% to 12% growth on a full-year basis.
We expect to see continued pressure in Q1.
As Chris mentioned, it's difficult to be precise about the current inventory supply issues in the industry, but we hope to see a return to growth sometime in Q2.
Let's move on to gross margin.
We expect to see the gross margin rate decline by 100 to 150 basis points on a full-year basis.
We are cautiously optimistic that our pricing moves will offset expected commodity pressure.
That said, we expect about 65% to 70% of our costs to be locked in by the end of the calendar year.
So we'll still have some exposure if costs increase more than the planned increases we are assuming.
The two biggest pressures on the rate next year will come from lower fixed cost leverage and segment mix.
We anticipate some leverage from SG&A, meaning this line can range from a 6% year-over-year decline to a slight increase of maybe 2%.
There are no major changes in SG&A, and we remain committed to investments we believe will drive the business, not just in fiscal '22, but in the years to follow.
Below the operating line, interest expense should be roughly $25 million higher, based on the full-year impact of our recent bond offering.
Our guidance also assumes no offsetting earnings impact from acquisitions, which is a fairly conservative starting point.
All of this results in a guidance range for adjusted earnings per share of $8.50 to $8.90.
I also want to discuss cash flow for a moment.
For the year we just completed, free cash flow, which is operating cash flow minus capex, came in at $165 million.
While that is low by historical standards, there are three main reasons for the year-over-year decline.
First was variable compensation that was earned in fiscal '20 but paid out in fiscal '21.
That was about a $60 million impact.
Second, we increased capex by about $45 million.
Third, inventory levels increased by $500 million from fiscal '20.
While most of this increase was paid during the year, we did rely more on our vendor partners than in the past to achieve extended payment terms.
Looking ahead to fiscal '22, we're aiming for free cash flow of up to $300 million.
We expect capex to increase again, and we also expect inventory levels, while flat on a unit basis, to be higher overall due to increased costs.
These investments are necessary to continue meeting the required service levels for our customers, which is the higher priority.
Regarding inventory, we find ourselves in a very good position right now.
In both U.S. consumer and Hawthorne, we believe some competitors will struggle to meet demand.
In the consumer business, we expect the market to experience shortages of grass seed and sphagnum peat moss, a key ingredient used in growing media.
We do not anticipate being impacted by these issues, and we do not expect to have any problems getting our customers to appropriate inventory levels.
I agree with Jim's assessment.
We have many moving parts right now and several active initiatives that could require us to update our outlook as we progress through the year.
But even in the unlikely event that none of those efforts come to fruition, I believe the business is in an excellent position.
The challenges we're facing on the cost of goods line are fairly consistent with what you've been hearing from other companies over the past two weeks.
And as we said we would, we've taken aggressive action to stay ahead of all those challenges and protect the profitability of the business.
When I consider how far this business has come in such a short time, it's hard not to feel optimistic about our current position.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I am deeply appreciative of our colleagues' ongoing dedication and hard work, particularly those still experiencing the pandemic's devastating effects.
A uniform recovery has not yet occurred, as many regions worldwide continue to be severely impacted by the pandemic.
India is currently facing an especially critical situation, as many are aware.
We are deeply concerned for our colleagues and customers in India, working closely with our team there to ensure employee and family safety, while supporting our customers as much as possible.
I will briefly outline our first quarter operating results and update you on our three-phase transformation plan, which focuses on initiating commercial momentum, enhancing organizational leadership and performance management, and aligning our portfolio with growth areas.
I will then share some thoughts on how our business is positioned for sustainable growth.
Mike will subsequently provide a detailed review of our financial results and comments on our updated financial outlook for the second quarter and full year.
In the first quarter, revenue increased 31% as reported, 27% in constant currency, with non-GAAP adjusted earnings per share growing 99% year-over-year.
This strong start was driven by growth across all end markets, continued strength in pharma, earlier-than-expected recovery in non-pharma spending, new product traction, and strong commercial execution.
Examining our top-line results more closely:
All our end markets experienced double-digit growth in the first quarter.
Our largest market category, pharma, grew 28% in constant currency, industrial grew 24%, and academic and government grew 29%.
Regarding sales performance by geography, in constant currency, Asia sales grew 41% with China up 109%, Americas sales grew 14% with the US growing 13%, and Europe sales grew 25%.
Our Waters division grew 26%, while TA grew by 28% on a constant currency basis.
Customer activity improved in the first quarter, with pharma leading the way, driving better-than-expected trends in recurring revenues and significant growth in instrument revenue.
Recurring revenues grew 15%, with services growing 14% and chemistry consumables revenue growing 18%, driven by combined pharma strength and improved industrial demand.
LC instruments grew across all major geographies and market categories, with over 40% growth.
Both HPLC and UPLC instrument units saw double-digit growth, driven by pent-up demand, integration of the Arc HPLC, and strong execution of our LC replacement initiative.
The Arc HPLC launch in the general purpose HPLC space has been remarkably successful, and the ACQUITY PREMIER has been well-received by customers since its February launch.
Mass spec sales were strong in the first quarter, growing over 50% due to robust pharma market demand and rebounds in clinical, food, environmental, and biomedical research markets.
Tandem quad demand was solid in Europe and China, particularly in pharma and food sectors.
Revenue grew 28% as demand rebounded in the core industrial business, with continued strength in pharma medical devices and semiconductors.
Growth was robust across all major geographies and product lines, with particular strength in thermal and electrophoresis.
All major regions experienced double-digit growth.
China's performance built on last quarter's strength, more than doubling sales year-over-year, with strong results across all end markets as the country continued recovering from last year's COVID disruptions.
China's pharma sector was particularly strong, driven by triple-digit growth in both contract labs and traditional Chinese medicine.
China's food business saw meaningful growth, driven by a significant rebound in contract testing organizations to levels above those seen in 2018 and 2019.
India's sales grew double-digits for the third consecutive quarter, despite worsening conditions and ongoing pandemic challenges.
Europe experienced broad-based strength across all customer end markets, including meaningful sequential improvements in both industrial and academic and government markets.
In the US, both pharma and industrial markets showed strong growth, while demand in the academic and government market remained soft, lagging behind other markets in reopening.
We had an excellent start to the year with strong year-on-year growth that was more broadly based than last quarter, demonstrating impressive performance across all regions, end markets, and product categories.
Pharma demand remains strong, and many non-pharma markets are now recovering, giving us greater confidence for the remainder of the year.
I'd like to discuss our business and its future direction more broadly, including the company's strengths, the effectiveness of our target markets, and our deep commitment to innovation as we look beyond this quarter into the long term.
Our three-phase transformation plan focuses on initiating commercial momentum, strengthening organizational leadership and performance management, and aligning our portfolio with growth areas.
Regarding our first priority of initiating commercial momentum, I'll review some previously mentioned initiatives.
Our instrument replacement initiative delivered a significant acceleration in instrument revenue growth to 45%.
The February launch of the ACQUITY PREMIER system, combined with the successful placement of Arc HPLC launched in June 2020, has created new opportunities for instrument replacements.
We've also gained traction with customers in replacing aging tandem quad mass spec instruments with newer models.
Our CROs CDMO expansion initiative has seen revenue growth accelerate to strong double digits in both customer segments.
Customers continue to view us as a strong technical partner for method transfer from originators and as a collaborator rather than a competitor.
Our e-commerce initiative has begun to deliver tangible results, with search engine optimization and paid search leading to search impressions increasing by more than 40% year-on-year.
While not every click translates to immediate revenue, increasing traffic is a crucial first step in our e-commerce efforts.
We are focusing on driving launch excellence.
I'll begin with a discussion of liquid chromatography.
Although the Arc HPLC is a top performer in the general purpose HPLC market, I'd like to highlight the ACQUITY PREMIER.
We introduced the ACQUITY PREMIER Columns in the previous year and followed up with the ACQUITY PREMIER System in the last quarter.
Despite being in the early phases of revenue growth for both the Columns and System, sales of ACQUITY PREMIER Columns are significantly surpassing previous successful chemistry launches, including the original ACQUITY Columns.
Now, let's discuss mass spectrometry.
In 2019, we unveiled the BioAccord, Cyclic IMS, SYNAPT XS, TQ-S cronos, and an updated version of our TQ-S micro.
Combining our tandem quad with ACQUITY PREMIER results in industry-leading reproducibility and sensitivity for challenging assays.
We've maintained our focus on delivering a versatile, user-friendly, and robust LCMs system to the QA-QC space while expanding BioAccord applications.
In Q1, we introduced a complete workflow for peptide multi-attribute method on the new Waters Connect platform to enable quality attribute monitoring at the peptide level.
This complements existing simple-use applications for peptide mapping impacts of unit mass analysis, released glycan profiling, and oligonucleotide mass confirmation.
Over the past year, we integrated the BioAccord into workflows for characterizing mRNA molecules that have since become vaccines.
BioNTech acknowledged Waters for our support in their COVID-19 vaccine development and relief efforts.
Cyclic, launched in September 2019, targets the most advanced high-resolution mass spec users.
By enhancing traditional LCMs with high-resolution ion mobility, we can differentiate molecules with identical molecular weight based on their varying shapes.
This capability is particularly relevant for analyzing structural changes in the sugar pattern of the SARS-CoV-2 virus spike protein.
We acknowledge that our mass spec informatics applications need improvement, and we're addressing this through the development and implementation of our Waters Connect software platform across our entire mass spec portfolio.
Currently, Waters Connect supports biopharma characterization and monitoring workflows with various capabilities on the BioAccord, Xevo QTof, and [Indecipherable].
The Q1 launch of our RDa Benchtop Tof also enables small molecule workflows on Waters Connect.
We appreciate the trust and partnership of our customers as we develop new applications and beta test upcoming products and software.
Now, let's discuss our TA Instrument division.
Last year, we introduced the X3 DSC, offering unique advantages for routine high-throughput labs and R&D, particularly in pharmaceuticals, electronics, and advanced materials.
The X3 DSC's ability to deliver highly sensitive physical property measurements more rapidly than comparable products allows for broader deployment in manufacturing processes, enabling scientists to evaluate multiple combinations in parallel and reduce time to market.
The more I interact with our R&D colleagues and customers, the more impressed I am by the strength of our deeply technical culture.
Moving on to our second priority.
We've already announced planned leadership transitions last month.
Amol Chaubal will join as CFO on May 12th, bringing extensive experience in pharmaceuticals and diagnostics, having led many transformations through organic and inorganic growth in previous roles.
Mike will continue as our Corporate Controller and will also assume the role of Chief Accounting Officer.
We've established a dedicated Innovation Board, which I will lead, including leaders from R&D, Business Development, and Marketing.
The Innovation Board will evaluate unmet needs in our target markets, assess technology proof of concepts, and monitor the execution of top R&D programs.
Although their retirements are effective July 2, they've kindly offered to serve as consultants for a period to ensure a smooth transition.
Both Jon and Jianqing have extensive commercial and transformation experience in global leadership roles in rapidly growing markets such as molecular diagnostics and bioprocessing.
I'm excited about our new team and look forward to introducing them to you in the coming months.
Our third priority is aligning our portfolio with high-growth areas.
While maintaining focus on commercial execution as our top priority, we've recently begun our strategic planning process.
I'd like to share some high-level thoughts on our current position.
Our primary focus is strengthening our core business, including LCMs and materials characterization instruments, informatics, service, and consumables.
Secondly, we aim to expand into faster-growing adjacent markets where we can leverage our strength in managing compliant data without directly competing with our customers.
These opportunities include increasing our exposure to biologics through reagents, other instrument technologies, or bioprocessing, as well as accelerating LCMs into diagnostics or other high-growth markets.
Lastly, we will maintain our disciplined approach to financial management, capital structure, and capital deployment, focusing on maintaining top-tier ROIC.
In the coming year, I look forward to sharing more details about our strategy and the data points that give us confidence in our foundation for sustainable growth in this attractive market.
I'll now hand over to Mike Silveira for a more detailed review of the first quarter financials and our outlook for the remainder of 2021.
In the first quarter, we recorded net sales of $609 million, representing a 27% increase in constant currency.
Currency translation boosted sales growth by approximately 4%, resulting in 31% sales growth as reported.
Examining product line growth, our recurring revenue, which combines precision chemistry products and service revenue, increased by 15% for the quarter, while instrument sales grew by 45%.
Chemistry revenues rose by 18% for the quarter, driven by strong pharmaceutical market growth and improving industrial demand.
Our service business saw a 14% revenue increase as customers continue to reopen labs and catch up on performance maintenance, professional services, and repair visits.
As mentioned in our previous earnings call, recurring sales were impacted by five additional calendar days in the quarter, primarily affecting service revenues.
Looking ahead, compared to 2020, there is no year-over-year difference in the number of calendar days for this year's second or third quarter.
The fourth quarter of this year has six fewer calendar days.
A more detailed breakdown of first quarter operating segment sales shows Waters Division sales increased by 26%, while TA Instrument sales grew by 28%.
LC and LCMs instrument sales combined rose by 47%, and TA system sales increased by 34%.
Let's discuss our first quarter non-GAAP financial performance in comparison to the previous year.
The quarter's gross margin reached 58.2%, a 3.5 percentage point increase from 54.7% in Q1 2020, mainly due to higher sales volume and favorable effects.
Let's examine the first quarter profit and loss statement.
Operating expenses rose by about 9% on a constant currency basis and 11% as reported.
The increase was primarily due to higher labor incentive compensation costs and increased depreciation from recent IT investments.
Our effective operating tax rate in Q1 was 14%, higher than last year, as the previous year's comparable period included some favorable one-time items.
The quarter's net interest expense was $7 million, a decrease of roughly $3 million, as expected due to lower average outstanding debt balances.
Our average share count was 62.6 million shares, unchanged from Q1 of the previous year.
Our non-GAAP earnings per fully diluted share for Q1 increased by 99% to $2.29, compared to $1.15 last year.
On a GAAP basis, our earnings per fully diluted share rose to $2.37 from $0.86 last year.
I'd like to summarize our Q1 results and activities regarding free cash flow, capital deployment, and our balance sheet.
We consider free cash flow as cash flow from operations minus capital expenditures, excluding certain special items.
In Q1 2021, free cash flow increased by 60% year-over-year to $193 million, after allocating $40 million for capital expenditures.
The free cash flow calculation excluded $14 million related to investment in our Taunton precision chemistry operation.
In Q1, this resulted in $0.32 of every dollar of sales being converted into free cash flow.
Our improved free cash flow primarily resulted from sales growth and better operating margins compared to the previous year.
In Q1, accounts receivable days sales outstanding was 84 days, a decrease of 15 days compared to Q1 of last year.
Inventory decreased by $16 million compared to the prior year's quarter, despite higher sales volumes.
Waters maintains a robust balance sheet, access to liquidity, and a well-structured debt maturity profile.
Regarding returning capital to shareholders, we bought back about 600,000 shares of common stock for $173 million in Q1.
These capital allocation activities, along with our free cash flow, resulted in $810 million in cash and short-term investments and $1.7 billion in debt on our balance sheet at the end of Q1.
This led to a net debt position of $893 million and a net debt to EBITDA ratio of approximately 1 at the end of Q1.
Our capital deployment priorities remain consistent: invest for growth, maintain balance sheet strength and flexibility, and return capital to shareholders.
We remain committed to deploying capital against these priorities, and as Udit mentioned earlier, we have begun a new strategic planning process.
As we continue to execute our priorities, we will consider deploying capital to enter attractive adjacent markets.
Looking ahead to the rest of the year, I'd like to provide some updated context for our 2021 outlook.
While the business environment remains volatile, we're seeing good momentum in our market segments, which will help us surpass 2019 levels.
We believe this momentum will continue into Q2, but the strong double-digit growth will mainly occur in the first half of the year due to more challenging comparisons in the second half and the six fewer calendar days in Q4.
We still expect all major geographies to perform better this year than in 2020, led by growth in China.
Our near-term growth initiatives are expected to continue ramping up, led by our LC replacement initiative, which we anticipate will contribute increasingly to our performance.
These factors support our updated full-year 2021 guidance for constant currency sales growth of 8% to 11%.
At current rates, positive currency translation is expected to add approximately 1 to 2 percentage points to 2021 sales growth.
Full-year gross margin is expected to be between 57.5% and 58%.
Each year, we aim to balance growth, investment, and profitability.
Accordingly, we expect 2021 operating margins of 28% to 29% based on a combination of investments, normalization of COVID-related costs, and disciplined expense controls.
Moving below the operating income line, other key assumptions for the full-year guidance are: net interest expense of $35 million to $38 million; a full-year tax rate between 14.5% and 15.5%; and the net impact of our 2021 share repurchase program resulting in an average diluted share count of 61.5 million to 62.0 million shares outstanding.
Throughout the year, we will evaluate our share repurchase program and provide quarterly updates as appropriate.
Combining all these factors, on a non-GAAP basis, full-year 2021 earnings per fully diluted share are now projected to be between $9.85 and $10.05, assuming a positive currency impact on full-year earnings-per-share growth of about 3 percentage points.
For Q2 2021, we expect constant currency sales growth of 14% to 16%.
At current rates, currency translation is expected to increase Q2 sales growth by approximately 3 percentage points.
Q2 non-GAAP earnings per fully diluted share are estimated to be between $2.15 and $2.25 as the significant prior year COVID cost-saving measures start to normalize.
At current rates, the positive currency impact on Q2 earnings-per-share growth is expected to be approximately 1 percentage point.
In summary, there's much to be pleased about regarding our Q1 results, driven by strong growth across all major end markets, with pharma leading the way.
Our transformation plan is progressing well, with commercial momentum and a strong leadership team in place.
We now focus on developing a new strategy as we work to align our portfolio more closely with higher-growth areas of the market.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Various uncertainties and risks exist, including potential impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on our operations, market sectors, and financial performance.
We are happy to announce another successful quarter of results.
We performed effectively and continue to excel in serving our customers across multiple areas, including quality, delivery service, and technological collaborations.
Our supply chain personnel work tirelessly around the clock to surmount unprecedented logistical hurdles and material shortages to maintain our factory's supply.
I am particularly pleased that we achieved unparalleled safety performance, a goal our teams worldwide have been striving towards.
The company reported GAAP earnings of $0.95 per share, or $0.83 adjusted, on revenue of $232 million, representing a nearly 10% increase from the same quarter last year.
Our Machine Clothing division continues to perform exceptionally well, with sales growth of 11% compared to Q3 last year, demonstrating excellent profitability and cash flow generation.
Engineered composites showed top-line growth of almost 7% and performed well as we anticipate the recovery in commercial aerospace.
Our financial performance was robust, with 40% gross margins, 19% operating margins, and 26% adjusted EBITDA margins, while maintaining strong free cash flow generation of over $40 million in the quarter.
Our company has low debt and a strong balance sheet, and we anticipate continued solid performance from our Machine Clothing segment and gradual improvement in commercial aerospace.
As previously noted, long-term market trends are favorable, and Albany's market positions, global presence, and product development capitalize on these trends.
In our Engineered Composites division, we anticipate a gradual improvement in commercial aerospace, with demand for narrow-body aircraft recovering before wide-body demand.
As a result, we are recruiting employees and preparing for increased LEAP production driven by growth in Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX production.
We are working with Safran to increase production at our three LEAP facilities in the United States, France, and Mexico.
We observe positive indicators in international travel bookings as borders reopen and people resume international travel, although we do not expect any immediate increase in wide-body production demand, such as for our Boeing 787 composite frames line, due to existing inventory and slow recovery in international travel.
Our AEC businesses continue to perform well on military platforms including the Sikorsky CH-53K helicopter, Lockheed Martin's F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, and Jazan missile programs.
We are fortunate to be involved in excellent programs, and our teams are executing them effectively.
We persist in our efforts to attract new customers and applications for advanced composites.
During the quarter, we announced a technology collaboration with Spirit AeroSystems to apply our advanced 3D woven composite technology to hypersonic vehicles, leveraging our proprietary 3D woven composites in high-temperature environments to provide structural strength and thermal protection, building on our proven ability to industrialize 3D woven composites at high volumes.
This exemplifies the intense collaboration our teams excel at, working closely with our technology partners in the design, development, and commercialization of cutting-edge composite applications.
In addition to collaborating on engine component applications with our partner Safran, we continue to develop wing applications with the Airbus Wing of Tomorrow program and other composite programs in commercial and defense applications.
Our Machine Clothing segment maintained its exceptional performance.
Our engineers and sales and service teams in MC collaborate closely with key customers to develop next-generation belt materials for improved operational efficiency, performance, and durability.
Customers value our service, technical expertise, and innovation.
We observed strong demand for new products across all product lines during the quarter.
Demand in MC's end markets has remained resilient, particularly strong in packaging in the Americas.
Tissue markets have remained stable, although demand is mixed and overall flat as tissue machine utilization is below long-term averages and tissue producers are working through disruptions caused by the pandemic's effect on away-from-home paper markets.
This situation should improve as workers return to offices and students return to school.
In other end markets, demand was strong for corrugators, nonwovens, and building products during the quarter.
Even the publication sector showed improvement this quarter, likely a temporary pause in the long-term decline of printing and writing paper grades.
We are facing significant logistical challenges and price inflation for various raw materials and wages.
Thus far, our supply chain management and operations teams have performed admirably.
They have managed to secure the materials necessary for our operations with only moderate cost increases.
Generally, we aim to offset inflationary costs through productivity improvements.
However, this situation may be different, as we do not anticipate inflationary pressures subsiding soon.
If anything, conditions became more challenging during the third quarter.
Allow me to comment briefly on corporate governance and capital allocation before handing the call over to Stephen.
In early August, the company moved closer to a single-class share structure following the secondary offering of nearly all the Standish Family's ownership in the company, with the remaining few shares converted to Class A common stock.
Consequently, there are now more than 32.3 million shares of Class A common stock outstanding and fewer than 1,200 shares of Class B stock outstanding, held by two former employees.
This transaction effectively created a conventional single-class governance structure for our shareholders.
As previously mentioned, our priority is to use our balance sheet first for organic growth investments where we can add value for our customers, followed by acquisitions that align with our strategy and enable us to build on our technology leadership and market positions in both segments.
In addition to these options, Albany's Board of Directors has authorized a $200 million share repurchase program, expanding our available capital allocation alternatives.
We continue to seek acquisitions that enhance our technology and market position at a fair price, focusing on value creation from both organic and inorganic investment perspectives.
In conclusion, we had another successful quarter.
Our businesses are performing well, we continue to push the boundaries in our technology development with new products in both segments, and secular trends in our end markets are favorable.
With that, I'll now pass the call to Stephen to provide more detailed financial information.
I'll begin by discussing the quarterly results and then provide an outlook for our business for the remainder of the year.
In the third quarter, our company's total net sales reached $232.4 million, showing a 9.6% increase compared to $212 million in the same period last year.
When adjusted for currency translation effects, net sales increased by 8.8% year-over-year this quarter.
In Machine Clothing, after accounting for currency translation effects, net sales rose by 9.9% compared to the previous year.
The year-over-year increase in net sales was driven by all major product categories, with engineered fabrics and packaging grades leading the way.
Engineered composites' net sales, after adjusting for currency translation effects, increased by 6.7%, primarily due to growth in LEAP and CH-53K programs, partially offset by anticipated declines in the 787 and F-35 platforms.
The ASC LEAP program generated approximately $25 million in revenue during the quarter, similar to the first two quarters of this year, but about $9 million higher than the third quarter of last year.
We're satisfied with the reduction in our LEAP-1B finished goods inventory.
In the most recent quarter, we decreased that inventory by over 30 engine shipsets, bringing it down to about 140 engine shipsets on hand.
Given the current rate of inventory consumption for that program, we don't plan to let the inventory level drop below approximately 100 engine shipsets, so we can see progress in terms of inventory destocking.
I'm eagerly anticipating an earnings call where I won't need to discuss LEAP-1B inventory at all.
We anticipate returning to more normal production levels for LEAP-1B, comparable to current LEAP-1A production rates, in early 2022.
However, we are somewhat concerned about the rate at which Boeing is depleting its inventory of finished 737 MAX aircraft, so there's still some uncertainty regarding 2022 build rates.
We hope to provide better insight during our fourth quarter call.
During the quarter, we generated less than $3 million in revenue from the 787 program, slightly lower than the second quarter, but down from almost $9 million in the same quarter last year.
The company's third quarter gross profit was $92 million, an increase of over 5% from the same period last year.
Overall gross margin decreased by 160 basis points from 41.2% to 39.5% of net sales.
In the MC segment, gross margin remained steady at 51.5% of net sales, as improved absorption benefits were offset by year-over-year foreign currency changes and rising input costs.
The AEC segment's gross margin declined from 21.6% to 16.1% of net sales due to a smaller impact from changes in estimated long-term contract profitability, a shift in program mix, lower fixed cost absorption from reduced 787 and F-35 revenues, and the impact of sharing a portion of The Aviation Manufacturing Jobs Protection grant with our customers.
The $5.8 million benefit from this grant is reflected in the corporate portion of the results, while the reduced profitability from sharing part of the grant with customers is reported in the segment results.
We recognized a net favorable change in the estimated profitability of AEC's long-term contracts of about $2 million this quarter, compared to a net favorable change of about $3.5 million in the same quarter last year.
Third quarter Selling, Technical, General, and Research expenses were $47.4 million, slightly down from $47.8 million in the prior year quarter, and decreased as a percentage of net sales from 22.6% to 20.4%.
Although R&D expenses increased by over $1 million this quarter and we incurred higher travel expenses, these were more than offset by a foreign currency revaluation gain this quarter compared to a foreign currency revaluation loss in the same quarter last year.
The company's total operating income was $44.5 million, up from $38.8 million in the prior year quarter.
Machine Clothing operating income increased by $9.8 million, driven by higher gross profit and lower STG&R expenses.
AEC operating income decreased by $3.9 million due to lower gross profit and higher STG&R expenses, partially offset by lower restructuring expenses.
The income tax rate for this quarter was 29.4% compared to 24.7% in the same quarter last year.
This year's higher rate was due to a larger share of our global profits generated in jurisdictions with higher tax rates and less favorable discrete income tax adjustments.
We reported over $2 million in expenses under other income expense this quarter, primarily due to an adjustment of indirect taxes in a foreign jurisdiction.
The company's net income for the quarter was $30.9 million, an increase of over $1 million from $29.6 million last year.
This increase was mainly due to higher operating profit, partially offset by higher interest expenses and a higher tax rate.
Earnings per share were $0.95 this quarter compared to $0.92 last year.
In addition to our usual non-GAAP adjustments for foreign currency revaluation gains and losses, restructuring expenses, and expenses related to the CirComp acquisition and integration, we are also adjusting for the impact of The Aviation Manufacturing Jobs Protection grant this quarter, as we don't believe it reflects ongoing profitability.
After making these non-GAAP adjustments, adjusted earnings per share were $0.83 this quarter compared to $0.96 last year.
Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 2.6% to $60.2 million for the most recent quarter compared to the same period last year.
Machine Clothing adjusted EBITDA was $59.2 million or 38.4% of net sales, up from $52.6 million or 37.9% of net sales in the prior year quarter.
AEC adjusted EBITDA was $16.3 million or 20.8% of net sales, down from last year's $19.5 million or 26.6% of net sales.
Regarding our debt position, total debt, consisting of amounts reported on our balance sheet as long-term debt or current maturities of long-term debt, remained steady at $350 million.
We have a floating to fixed interest rate swap in place at the debt level for the duration of the current credit agreement and currently don't plan to reduce total debt below that level.
Cash increased by about $33 million during the quarter, resulting in a reduction in net debt by the same $33 million.
Capital expenditures in the quarter were approximately $9 million, similar to the same quarter last year.
Regarding capital deployment, as Bill mentioned, our priorities remain unchanged.
Our top priority is organic investments, followed by disciplined and targeted acquisitions, and then returning capital to shareholders.
Our fundamental strategy remains the same.
The Board of Directors has approved a $200 million share buyback program, considering our modest debt and strong cash flow outlook.
We consider this program the most efficient and effective way to provide additional value to our shareholders.
While we can't guarantee full or partial execution of this authorization, we intend to utilize it depending on market conditions and acknowledging the inherent constraints on implementing such a large program quickly.
If fully implemented, the share repurchase program would slightly increase our net debt by less than one times EBITDA, leaving us with ample resources for further strategic initiatives.
The Machine Clothing segment's outlook for the rest of 2021 remains positive.
Third-quarter revenues increased by over 11% compared to the previous year, partly assisted by favorable currency effects, mainly due to a strong euro.
Long-term growth is primarily driven by packaging and tissue sectors.
Although we observed a significant recovery in publication revenue during the third quarter, due to people returning to offices and schools, the continuation of this trend is uncertain because of the Delta variant surge, which has temporarily halted some return-to-office plans.
Furthermore, once we move past the pandemic's effects, we anticipate the long-term decline in the publication market to persist.
It's worth noting that the MC segment's growth rate this quarter was unusually high due to the timing of customer demands.
Year-to-date segment orders have increased by about 6% compared to last year, and the backlog entering the fourth quarter is only slightly higher than the same period last year.
We typically generate between 23% and 25% of the segment's revenue in the fourth quarter, and we expect this year to follow a similar pattern.
Consequently, we are increasing our previously announced revenue guidance for the segment to between $600 million and $610 million, up from the earlier range of $585 million to $600 million.
In terms of profitability, Machine Clothing delivered another strong quarter, with adjusted EBITDA margins of nearly 39%.
We are experiencing increased pressure from various input costs, particularly logistics, and expect these pressures to continue rising through the end of the year.
However, as previously mentioned, many of these cost increases, which began in Q2 and accelerated in Q3, have not yet significantly impacted our results due to our supply agreement terms and the roughly six-month delay between acquiring raw materials at higher costs and those costs being reflected in the segment's cost of goods sold.
We will see more impact from these cost pressures in Q4, but the full impact won't be evident until 2022.
Additionally, in late Q3 and early Q4, we've noticed some easing of travel restrictions in certain regions and are starting to see an increase in customer visits, which will result in slightly higher SG&A expenses in the fourth quarter.
Primarily due to strong revenue performance, we are raising our adjusted EBITDA guidance for the segment to a range of $215 million to $225 million, up from the previous range of $210 million to $220 million.
Regarding Engineered Composites, we delivered a strong quarter that met expectations.
Last quarter, we predicted Q3 profitability would be similar to Q1, and it was within a few hundred thousand dollars of that level.
We were pleased to receive an Aviation Manufacturing Jobs Protection grant of $5.8 million during the quarter, acknowledging the challenges we and the industry have faced due to the COVID pandemic.
However, we have excluded the effects from both Q3 adjusted results and segment guidance for the year as it doesn't reflect ongoing operational performance.
While unlikely to significantly impact the remainder of 2021, we are concerned about the slow recovery of the Boeing 787 program, as Boeing has indicated they will continue to produce at a low rate for the foreseeable future.
As of the end of Q3, we had about five shipsets of 787 product in either finished goods or work-in-progress, which is not unusually high.
However, substantial quantities of our finished goods exist in Boeing's overall supply chain, which, combined with Boeing's low production level, will likely lead to very low production levels for us in the foreseeable future and may even result in significant production gaps.
Any impact in 2021 would be modest as we're not anticipating any significant recovery on the program this year, but it will likely delay any meaningful recovery on the program until after 2022.
As you know, our F-35 production levels have been uncertain this year, as our customer has dealt with issues elsewhere in the supply chain over the past 18 months and with lower depot consumption of aftermarket parts.
We are confident in our outlook for the rest of the year, but I'll note that Lockheed Martin and its government customer have established a new program production outlook that plateaus at 156 aircraft in 2023, a lower rate and earlier date than previously planned.
The F-35 remains a very good and profitable program for us.
This programmatic change doesn't affect this year, but it will likely temper the revenue upside in the program for us in future years.
Overall for the AEC segment, the year is progressing largely as we expected when we last issued guidance, though we are now less concerned about downside risk.
Therefore, we are raising the lower end of our guidance range for segment revenues, resulting in a range between $310 million, up from the previous range of $290 million to $310 million.
From a profitability perspective, given the year is progressing largely as expected, we are maintaining the previously issued guidance range for AEC adjusted EBITDA of between $65 million and $70 million.
We are also updating our previously issued guidance ranges for company-level performance, including revenue of between $900 million and $920 million, increased from prior guidance of $880 million to $910 million.
The effective income tax rate remains at 28% to 30%, unchanged from prior guidance.
Depreciation and amortization of about $75 million, unchanged from prior guidance.
Capital expenditures in the range of $40 million to $50 million also unchanged from prior guidance.
GAAP earnings per share of between $3.23 and $3.38, increased from prior guidance of $2.84 to $3.14.
Adjusted earnings per share of between $3.15 and $3.30, increased from prior guidance of $2.19 to $3.20 and adjusted EBITDA of between $230 million and $240 million, increased from prior guidance of $225 million to $240 million.
Overall, while the pandemic is not yet behind us and risks still remain across our business, we are very pleased to be able to raise guidance again, reflecting the hard work and dedication of our teams worldwide.
The coming years will continue to be challenging as we and the rest of the industry slowly recover from the severe downturn in commercial aviation and as the machine clothing market finds its new post-pandemic normal.
We also recognize the risks ahead in terms of supply chain constraints and inflationary pressures, should the recent and current increases be more than temporary.
However, our track record of operational excellence and continuous improvement positions us well to address these challenges.
Summary:

compname reports q3 adjusted earnings per share of $0.83.
