input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today's discussion will reference certain non-standard financial metrics, including operating income and accident share loss and combined ratios, excluding catastrophes.
I'll start by addressing our Q2 financial highlights in relation to the current business and economic climate.
Next, I'll provide a strategic overview of each segment's performance during the quarter.
Jeff will delve deeper into our financial results and offer insights on upcoming quarters.
We're thrilled to report exceptional Q2 results, featuring strong growth with net written premium increases of 11.7% or 8.6% adjusted, excluding 2020 premium returns, driven by gains across all segments.
We achieved operating income of $104 million or $2.85 per share, an operating return on equity of 14.7%, and a combined ratio of 94.4%.
Our robust underwriting performance demonstrates our ability to capitalize on emerging market opportunities while navigating the complexities of this dynamic underwriting landscape.
From my viewpoint, there are two key takeaways from the Q2 results.
Firstly, our growth has surpassed pre-COVID-19 levels in all segments.
Secondly, we continue to achieve widespread profitability with strong underlying underwriting results across our businesses.
Let me briefly elaborate on each of these points.
Regarding growth, we saw a significant increase in premium across all business segments compared to Q1 this year.
All major segments now exceed pre-COVID-19 growth levels due to our disciplined pricing strategy, strong retention, and robust new business production metrics.
Our strong relationships with agent partners provide opportunities for solid future growth as we focus on our most profitable market sectors and leverage cutting-edge technology platforms.
We're also enhancing our claims data and analytics sophistication, including real-time driving pattern and inflation monitoring tools.
I'm more confident than ever in our ability to grow profitably.
In Personal Lines, we achieved 11.6% growth in the quarter, or 5% excluding prior year premium returns.
Our continued growth momentum reflects sustained agent and customer interest in our account offerings, targeted pricing actions, strong market position, and ability to adapt to a competitive marketplace.
We grew our Commercial Lines business by 11.7%, driven by strong performance in our specialty portfolio and small commercial business, which benefited from economic recovery and our new quote-and-issue platform, TAP sales.
We're well-positioned to continue driving growth across all segments and expect mid- to high single-digit growth for the rest of the year.
Regarding loss trends, we're still experiencing lower auto loss frequency, likely due to flexible working arrangements for many customers.
Our data indicates reduced traffic and less congested rush hours in many areas as lingering pandemic effects.
We expect frequency to reach a new normal in 2021, potentially resulting in persistently lower accident frequency in certain areas given our mix and customer profile.
This benefit may be partially offset by increased severity from materials inflation and more severe accidents, including elevated fatalities.
We delivered strong Commercial Lines profitability, despite some elevated property losses in other commercial, which we don't believe are recurring or indicative of a trend.
We've been monitoring overall property large loss activity for several quarters and believe it aligns with market trends.
We see room for additional rate increases in property lines and remain prudent in our loss selections.
We're mindful of potential increased social inflation, medical information and treatment delays, and other inflationary trends.
We're closely watching the economic recovery, business activity acceleration, and court system reopening in many jurisdictions.
While the impact and duration of inflation on our business remain uncertain, we believe our comparatively short reserve duration positions us well to manage potential exposure.
With this background, I'll share recent highlights by business, starting with Personal Lines.
Our selective rate adjustments have been successful, as shown by sequential PIF growth of 1.8% in auto and 1.7% in home during the quarter.
New business growth exceeded expectations, with significant sequential improvement in retention.
Our preferred customer focus and value-based approach provide competitive advantages as agents become more strategic with their Personal Lines models and carrier placement decisions.
Account business comprises over 85% of our book, leading to high retention and business stability.
Personal Lines retention improved by over two points in Q2 compared to Q1, demonstrating our agile approach and successful strategy in this dynamic environment.
In Personal Auto, we expect claims frequency to gradually approach new normal levels as the year progresses.
While pricing remains competitive, we see clear signs that rate deceleration has bottomed out and the industry is looking to increase rates.
This aligns with historical Personal Lines pricing cycles, where Personal Auto rates adjust quickly to loss trends.
We believe we're well-positioned due to our prudent pricing strategy during the pandemic, requiring less significant rate increases and customer disruption in the near future.
We're gaining momentum with Hanover Prestige, our full account offering for customers with higher value homes, autos, and complex insurance needs.
This growing segment of the Personal Lines market further positions us as a strategic partner with agents.
The offering's contribution to overall growth increases each quarter, boosting Q2 new business growth by three points.
In Commercial Lines, we executed well on strategic priorities, posting 12% growth in Specialty and 11% in Core Commercial, driven by increased new business, rate increases, and exposure growth.
Strong topline growth in Core Commercial is expected to continue, driven by economic reopening, continued rate increases, and the successful launch of TAP Sales, our small commercial quoting platform.
In Q2, we launched TAP Sales in nine additional states, bringing the total to 20, and we'll complete nationwide implementation for our first product, Business Owners Advantage, by year-end.
This multi-year investment delivers comprehensive capabilities, including a new agent front-end, new products and endorsements, new states, sophisticated pricing algorithms, a new policy administration system, and new self-service capabilities.
In states where TAP Sales was deployed in Q1, submissions significantly increased and our hit ratio improved.
Agents have praised the product's ease of use and simplified quoting process, calling it best in market.
Efficiency gains are substantial, enabling single location risk quoting and issuance in 50% less time than before.
Our infrastructure modernization and capability enhancements are being realized as agents consolidate and acquire agencies with substantial small commercial books, forcing more strategic carrier partnerships.
Our strategic focus, user-friendly tools, and diverse product range are enhancing agent efficiency and increasing our value to them
We're optimistic that our comprehensive offerings will drive further expansion and agency adoption in upcoming quarters
We also achieved significant growth in our Specialty segment
We saw double-digit growth in our Marine, E&S, and management liability lines during the quarter, which are among our most profitable sectors
We're also expanding our products and capabilities in financial institutions and retail E&S areas
We're advancing our total Hanover strategy by increasing the use of our specialty offerings across our Commercial Lines customer base
As agents offer more specialized products to clients, we expect our Specialty business to continue driving crucial growth
We're satisfied with the commercial rate environment and exposure trends in our markets
We implemented 6.5% rate increases in Core Commercial while maintaining strong retention at 84.9%
We continued applying double-digit rate increases in Commercial Auto and high single-digit increases in property, using detailed pricing segmentation and risk-based pricing and retention strategies
Exposure growth exceeded historical norms this quarter, which is promising for our future growth prospects
We achieved 8.5% rate increases in Specialty, up from 7.5% in the previous quarter
Specialty rates can vary quarter-to-quarter due to large account renewals and other unique factors, but overall pricing in our Specialty markets has been robust with increases outpacing loss trends
Several factors support the strong rate environment in Commercial Lines, including potential social inflation, property loss pressures from materials costs, higher reinsurance costs, and low interest rates
We believe our focus on smaller accounts and unique offerings will protect us from significant pricing slowdowns that can occur in larger brokered accounts
In conclusion, our exceptional growth this quarter reflects the strong momentum across our business and sets the stage for continued profitable expansion
We're performing exceptionally well in an uncertain environment, leveraging our unique distribution capabilities, customer-focused strategies, disciplined underwriting and pricing, and diverse product offerings
As we enter the second half of the year, we're encouraged by our performance and confident in our ability to execute our strategy and capitalize on growth opportunities
We're incredibly proud of our team's efforts during this health crisis, fulfilling our commitments and maintaining or improving our service levels
As we drive our business forward for sustained profitable growth, we're being thoughtful and opportunistic, aiming to emerge as a better insurance company, employer, and corporate citizen
We're closely monitoring changing employment trends and practices, as well as employee preferences, to strengthen our culture, which has been a key competitive advantage in attracting and retaining talent
We've started inviting employees back to work voluntarily and plan to fully reopen our offices in the fall, health conditions permitting
We're planning to adopt a flexible hybrid model that will allow us to serve agents and customers effectively while providing employees with an engaging work environment for career growth
These are exciting times for those ready to embrace the challenge
For Q2, we reported net income of $128.5 million or $3.52 per diluted share, compared to $115.2 million or $3.01 per diluted share in Q2 2020
After-tax operating income was $104 million or $2.85 per share, compared to $62.7 million or $1.63 per share in the prior year quarter
The difference between net and operating income is due to increased fair value of equity securities
Book value per share rose 4.8% in the quarter, driven by earnings and increased unrealized gains in our fixed income portfolio
With widespread lockdowns last year, many business lines experienced historically low claim frequency
We refunded some premiums to auto policyholders due to reduced driving, affecting our reported net written premiums and underwriting ratios
Business exposures, payrolls, and receipts were exceptionally low in 2020
As the economy reopens and people return to normal activities, we believe our recent growth trajectory and loss experience, along with our original 2021 expectations, are better indicators of our performance
We're pleased with our overall combined ratio of 94.4% in Q2 2021, compared to 96.2% in the prior year quarter, which included several large catastrophe events, including social unrest losses
In Q2 2021, we incurred catastrophe losses of $76.8 million or 6.5% of net earned premium, 40 basis points above our quarterly expectation, mainly due to severe weather events in the Midwest in June
Michigan, our largest Personal Lines state, was heavily impacted by rain and flooding events in late June, particularly in homeowners insurance
Michigan is typically very profitable for us with a low 90s combined ratio, but we do see losses during adverse weather events
We also experienced some favorable catastrophe development from prior years, demonstrating our prudent reserving approach
Prior year reserve development, excluding catastrophes, was favorable, adding $12.6 million to the bottom line, mainly reflecting continued favorability in workers' compensation, Personal Auto, and several Specialty lines
We remain cautious in our Commercial Auto reserving due to extended loss patterns and prior bodily injury development
Given the pandemic's effect on 2020 loss patterns, we remain vigilant in assessing ultimate loss costs
With the economic recovery, we're mindful of potential reserving uncertainties related to social and economic inflation, delayed medical procedures and information, and ongoing court delays
We've focused on strengthening our balance sheet over recent years, and it's now stronger than it has been in a long time
COVID-19 related claims activity remains very manageable, and we're holding substantial IBNR in that area
Our Q2 2021 expense ratio was 31.2%, in line with expectations and consistent with Q2 2020, improving from Q1 this year
We're confident we can achieve a 30 basis point expense ratio improvement for full year 2021
Our overall current accident year combined ratio excluding catastrophes was 89% in the quarter, reflecting our diverse business mix, earned rate increases, and some lingering frequency benefit in Auto Lines
Our Commercial Lines combined ratio, excluding catastrophes, was 89.5%, up 2.7 points from Q2 last year, mainly due to comparison with an exceptionally low loss level in Q2 2020
Our CMP current accident year loss ratio, excluding catastrophes, was 57.6%, consistent with recent trends but slightly higher than expected due to increased property large losses
We believe our experience aligns with industry trends, supporting our expectation for further property rate increases
We achieved substantial CMP property rate increases in Q2 and expect this trend to continue
The current accident year loss ratio for other Commercial Lines, excluding catastrophes, was 55.3%.
A significant loss and associated reinstatement premium in our profitable Hanover Specialty Industrial business impacted this outcome.
The overall favorability in our specialty business during the quarter counterbalanced this particular loss, bringing total loss amounts generally in line with expectations.
Our specialty industrial business consistently maintains a long-term combined ratio below 80%.
We are optimistic about our underwriting abilities and anticipate strong future performance in this sector.
The Commercial Auto current accident year loss ratio, excluding catastrophes, remains relatively stable compared to recent quarterly results.
We continue to implement substantial rate increases to address industry-wide liability issues affecting this line over multiple years.
Shifting focus to workers' compensation.
The current accident year loss ratio was 61.5%, which aligns with recent historical outcomes.
Our second quarter 2020 ratio was unusually low due to widespread stay-at-home orders across the country.
While underlying trends in this line remain largely positive, we maintain a cautious approach to our loss picks considering the rate environment and potential new risks associated with office reopenings for certain businesses.
Commercial Lines net written premiums experienced exceptional growth of 11.7% in the second quarter, driven by our small commercial and Specialty businesses.
We achieved strong operational metrics, including improved rates, significant increases in exposures, a return to robust new business growth, and a solid core commercial retention of 84.9%.
Overall, despite some minor and anticipated variability in losses, we are very pleased with Commercial Lines trends and underwriting returns for the quarter.
Shifting to Personal Lines.
Our combined ratio, excluding catastrophes, was quite low at 85.3%, but increased from 76.8% in the same period last year, reflecting the benefit of COVID-19 related auto claims frequency reductions.
Our Personal Lines auto current accident year loss ratio, excluding catastrophes, was 62.2%, below historical trends but slightly up from 60% in the first quarter.
While industry-wide frequency trends are rapidly approaching historical norms, our business still benefits slightly from lower frequency.
We anticipate a modest long-term frequency benefit due to changing driving patterns resulting from work-from-home flexibility among our customer base.
We are closely monitoring these trends and continue to effectively manage the balance between growth, rate, and profitability.
The current accident year loss ratio in our homeowners line remained relatively consistent with prior results but slightly exceeded our expectations.
Elevated property loss activity and higher material costs indicate the need for future rate increases.
We are observing a significant push for rate increases in homeowners within the independent agency space.
Personal Lines net written premiums grew 11.6% in the quarter, or 5% when adjusted for last year's premium returns.
This strong result was driven by a significant acceleration in new business.
We also regained momentum in our renewal premiums due to lower rate increases in certain areas and improved retention.
The strength of our data and analytics team and swift communication of market trends across our businesses allows us to opportunistically grow when market conditions are favorable and make well-informed adjustments when necessary.
We are pleased to see Personal Lines largely return to its pre-COVID-19 growth levels.
We have complete confidence in Personal Lines' strong growth and profitability prospects.
Turning to investment performance.
Our net investment income was $75.6 million for the quarter, an increase of $17.9 million or 31% from the prior year period.
This is primarily due to an unusual fluctuation in partnership income between periods.
Net investment income in the second quarter of 2020 was negatively impacted by a $4.6 million loss on limited partnerships, while partnership income in the second quarter of 2021 was $16 million, surpassing our expectations by $9 million.
Our partnership results for the first half of 2021 do not alter our outlook for investment partnerships or overall net investment income for the remainder of the year.
New money yields continue to exert pressure on our overall net investment income.
However, we have been able to significantly offset this with robust cash flows from operations.
We anticipate cash generation from our underwriting operations to remain strong.
Cash and invested assets at the end of the second quarter totaled $9.1 billion, with fixed income securities and cash representing 85% of the total.
Our fixed maturity investment portfolio has a duration of five years and is 96% investment grade.
We maintain a high-quality portfolio with a weighted average rating of A plus.
Net unrealized gains on the fixed maturity portfolio at the end of the second quarter 2021 were $357.8 million before taxes.
Regarding our equity and capital position.
Our book value per share of $88.23 reflects a 4.8% increase in the quarter.
We continue to be responsible stewards of our shareholders' capital and deliver on our capital allocation strategy.
Through July 26, 2021, we repurchased approximately $10 million of stock, leaving about $395 million of capacity under our stock repurchase authorization, which the Board expanded in May.
Additionally, during the quarter, we paid a regular cash dividend of approximately $25 million.
Our capital priorities remain unchanged.
Firstly, we aim to maintain our strong capitalization and liquidity; secondly, we continue to prioritize organic growth, for which we generate ample capital; and thirdly, we maintain our policy of returning excess capital to shareholders through cash dividends and share repurchases.
We will continue to remain flexible and actively manage our capital with shareholders' best interests in mind.
Looking ahead, we now anticipate net written premium growth in the mid- to high single digits in the second half of the year.
Based on our strong results in the first half of the year, we believe upper mid-single-digit growth for the full year is achievable.
With two quarters of better-than-expected ex-CAT combined ratio performance, we are improving our full year 2021 ex-CAT combined ratio outlook from 90% to 91% to 89% to 90%.
As mentioned earlier, we remain on track to reduce our expense ratio by at least 30 basis points in 2021 to 31.3%, and we expect our third quarter cat load to be 5.2%.
We are very pleased with our underlying performance and our ability to maintain our positive momentum in the quarter.
We are well-positioned to sustain our robust growth momentum and top quartile profitability, delivering value to our agents, customers, and shareholders.
Furthermore, we are excited to announce that we will be hosting a Virtual Investor Day on September 23, where we will discuss the key aspects of our differentiated strategy, future growth drivers, and long-range financial targets.
We will provide additional details in the coming weeks and look forward to your participation.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The Toro Company achieved record-breaking results for the third quarter.
We experienced strong demand across both our Professional and Residential divisions, and our operations team excelled despite global supply chain difficulties affecting product availability.
Our staff and channel partners remained focused on meeting customer needs.
Consequently, overall net sales for the third quarter increased by 16% compared to the previous year.
The Professional segment's net sales grew by 15%, marking the second consecutive quarter of double-digit growth for this division.
We observed ongoing strength in landscape contractor and golf markets globally.
There were increased pre-season deliveries of BOSS snow and ice management products, along with high demand for our rental and specialty construction equipment and Ventrac products.
Our range of innovative products, coupled with strong business confidence, fueled robust demand.
Residential segment net sales increased by 23%, building upon a 38% growth rate in the third quarter of the previous year.
The quarter's growth was driven by strong retail demand for our zero-turn and walk power mowers.
Customers continued to respond positively to our all-season Flex-Force 60-volt product line, which offers power and durability without compromising performance.
Our recent efforts to introduce innovative new products, revamp marketing, and expand mass retail distribution have strengthened the Toro brand and yielded positive outcomes.
As mentioned in the previous quarter, we anticipated supply chain constraints and inflationary pressures to intensify faster than could be fully mitigated in the short term through pricing and other actions.
Despite these challenges, both segments achieved solid earnings growth in the third quarter, with Professional earnings increasing by 7.6% and Residential earnings rising by 10.5%.
I will now discuss some of the key themes for the quarter.
Firstly, we continue to observe robust and widespread demand across our global markets.
This has been driven by consumer and business confidence, as well as customer investment priorities focused on outdoor environments.
We continue to capitalize on these drivers through our commitment to investing in new product development, our industry-leading distribution, and our talented teams.
Secondly, there was a continued escalation of global supply chain and inflationary challenges.
This included component availability constraints as well as material, freight, and wage-related cost increases.
Our operations team took extraordinary measures to enable us to source and produce as effectively as possible in this incredibly dynamic environment.
We also continued to execute our productivity and synergy initiatives, demonstrated disciplined expense control, and implemented market-aligned pricing actions.
Regardless of how long these pressures persist, we remain focused on managing the factors within our control.
Thirdly, in line with general economic trends, we experienced an increasingly challenging labor market, including wage pressures and workforce availability limitations in some of our manufacturing locations.
Across the enterprise, we have talented and dedicated teams committed to serving our customers.
We're focused on having the workforce and other resources in place to put ourselves in the best position to meet demand and deliver our products to the right places at the right time.
Our innovative product portfolio, outstanding team, and deep relationships with our channel partners and end customers set us apart and position us well for long-term growth.
We have the financial capacity to invest in the future and we continue to allocate capital to best drive value for all stakeholders.
This fiscal year, we've made strategic investments in key technologies, both organically and through acquisitions, to advance our priority areas of alternative power, smart, connected, and autonomous solutions.
Our healthy cash flow has also allowed us to return capital to shareholders while maintaining ample liquidity.
Looking ahead, we will continue to execute our enterprise strategic priorities of accelerating profitable growth, driving productivity and operational excellence, and empowering people.
I'll discuss our outlook further following Renee's more detailed review of our financial results.
As Rick mentioned, our record results for the third quarter were driven by robust demand in both our professional and residential segments.
Against the backdrop of increasing supply chain, inflation, and labor pressures.
We increased net sales for the quarter by 16.2% to $976.8 million.
Reported earnings per share was $0.89 per diluted share, up from $0.82 last year, and adjusted earnings per share was $0.92 per diluted share, up 12.2% from $0.82 in the prior year.
Both of our segments achieved record top and bottom line third quarter results.
Professional segment net sales increased by 15.2% to $718.5 million.
This growth was driven by widespread demand in landscape contractor, golf, snow and ice management, rental and specialty construction, and Ventrac products.
This was slightly offset by lower sales of underground construction equipment due to supply chain disruptions that affected product availability.
The Professional segment's earnings increased by 7.6% to $122.3 million in the third quarter.
When calculated as a percentage of net sales, there was a decrease of 120 basis points to 17%.
This decline was primarily attributed to increased material and freight expenses, partially mitigated by net price adjustments and efficiency enhancements.
The Residential segment's net sales grew by 23% to $252.1 million in the third quarter.
This growth was mainly due to high retail demand for zero-turn and walk power mowers.
Earnings for the Residential segment rose by 10.5% to $31.5 million in the quarter, but when expressed as a percentage of net sales, it fell by 140 basis points to 12.5%.
This reduction was primarily caused by the same factors affecting the Professional segment.
Let's examine our operational results for the quarter.
We reported a gross margin of 33.9%, which is a 110 basis point decrease compared to the same period last year.
The adjusted gross margin was 33.9%, showing a 130 basis point decline on a comparative basis.
These reductions were largely due to the same factors that impacted Professional and Residential earnings.
SG&A expenses as a percentage of net sales for the quarter increased by 20 basis points to 21.4%.
This rise was mainly due to more normalized spending compared to the third quarter of last year and a legal settlement in this year's third quarter.
Operating earnings as a percentage of net sales for the third quarter decreased by 130 basis points to 12.5%.
Adjusted operating earnings as a percentage of net sales fell by 80 basis points to 13.1%.
Interest expenses decreased by $1.3 million to $7 million for the quarter, due to lower debt levels and reduced interest rates.
The reported effective tax rate for the third quarter was 18%, while the adjusted effective tax rate was 19.3%.
Now, let's look at the balance sheet and cash flow.
Accounts receivable amounted to $301.2 million, a 2.2% decrease from last year, primarily due to changes in channel mix.
Inventory remained relatively unchanged from last year at $665.6 million.
However, finished goods inventory was significantly lower due to strong retail demand, while work-in-process inventory was higher.
This reflected supply chain variability and our efforts to secure higher levels of key components when available.
Accounts payable increased by 53% from last year to $411.4 million.
This was mainly due to the timing of purchases and more normalized spending compared to last year.
Year-to-date free cash flow was $429 million with a conversion ratio of 123%.
This positive performance was largely due to higher earnings and lower working capital, primarily driven by increased payables.
At the end of the quarter, our liquidity remained at $1.1 million.
This included $535 million in cash and cash equivalents and full availability under our $600 million revolving credit facility.
Our cash balances are higher than pre-pandemic levels, mainly due to our desire to ensure adequate liquidity at the start of the pandemic.
Our cash position was further strengthened by accelerated demand and related working capital impacts.
Over the past nine months, we utilized the majority of cash generated year-to-date, including funding the Turflynx and Left Hand Robotics acquisitions, increasing our regular dividend with $85 million paid out so far this year, resuming share repurchases with $177 million through the third quarter, and paying down $100 million in debt.
We also increased our capital expenditure budget, reflecting our commitment to invest in key technologies and ensure we have the capacity to meet future demand.
We maintain a disciplined approach to our capital allocation strategy, supported by our strong balance sheet.
Our priorities remain unchanged and include reinvesting in our businesses to support sustainable long-term growth both organically and through acquisitions, returning cash to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, and maintaining our leverage goals to support financial flexibility.
As we enter the final quarter of our fiscal year, we are benefiting from strong demand momentum and our leadership position in the markets we serve.
At the same time, customer demand continues to exceed supply and production capabilities.
We are not immune to the challenges facing companies worldwide and remain focused on serving our customers, succeeding in our markets, and managing the factors within our control.
We previously indicated that operational challenges would be most significant in the third quarter.
Due to the collective efforts of our team to meet additional demand, we were able to deliver stronger third quarter results than anticipated.
This resulted in lower finished goods inventory heading into the fourth quarter.
We are committed to obtaining necessary resources to boost production despite challenges in supply chains, inflation, and labor.
We are revising our financial projections for the 2021 fiscal year.
Our revised forecast indicates a net sales increase of approximately 17%, an improvement from the previous estimate of 12% to 15%.
We expect the Professional segment to grow at a rate comparable to the company's overall growth, while the Residential segment is projected to outpace it.
We now anticipate that the overall adjusted operating earnings as a percentage of net sales for the entire year will be comparable to fiscal 2020.
We anticipate that the professional segment's operating margins will be similar to the previous year.
We project that Residential margins will decrease compared to last year, but will still remain significantly above historical averages.
This projection takes into account our volume leverage and strong operational performance to date, balanced against increasing pressures from supply chains, inflation, and labor costs.
We are actively implementing measures to mitigate these market challenges.
Based on our current outlook, we now project full-year adjusted earnings per share to range between $3.53 and $3.57 per diluted share, an increase from our previous estimate of $3.45 to $3.55.
This upward revision in earnings per share guidance reflects our strong performance year-to-date, robust demand, and continued solid business execution, while also considering the previously mentioned challenges.
Overall, we are well-positioned to capitalize on this period of profitable growth as we continue to execute our long-term strategic priorities.
The guidance just presented reflects ongoing strong demand across our markets and our current operational outlook.
We are monitoring global key demand drivers for the remainder of this fiscal year and into fiscal 2022, including consumer and business confidence levels, COVID-19 developments, customer prioritization of outdoor environment maintenance and improvement, continued strong momentum in golf, and government support for infrastructure investments.
These market factors are expected to drive strong demand in the fourth quarter and into next year.
Our primary challenge remains our production capacity to meet retail demand across all markets given the current operating environment.
We anticipate that constraints will begin to ease as we see improvements in key material and component availability, logistics channels, and other COVID-related factors.
Our operations team is committed to doing everything possible to meet increased production requirements and grow market share in this challenging environment.
As operating constraints begin to ease, we expect to be in a better position to replenish field inventory from our current historically low levels.
We continue to focus on driving productivity and synergies, carefully managing expenses, and implementing market-based pricing actions when appropriate.
We are well-positioned to capitalize on long-term growth opportunities due to our strong cash flow, market leadership, investments in innovation, and trusted relationships.
Recent examples highlighting our commitment to innovation and relationships include receiving a Partner of the Year Award from Tractor Supply Company for the second consecutive year, this time as an omnichannel partner.
Green Industry Pros selected three of our products for their 2021 Editor's Choice Award, citing innovation and utility as factors.
In August, two of our rental and specialty construction offerings received Editor's Choice Awards from Rental magazine.
The International Sustainable Irrigation Expo recently recognized our Aqua-Traxx Azul micro-irrigation solution as a new product of the year.
Our innovative products have been showcased at recent high-profile events, including the Euro Cup Championship, the Open Championship, and this summer's events in Tokyo.
Our mission to deliver superior innovation and customer care is deeply rooted in our purpose of helping customers enhance the beauty, productivity, and sustainability of the land.
Our long-standing focus on sustainability extends to our communities, where we have a strong legacy of giving back.
We recently partnered with Better Futures, an organization that supports formerly incarcerated men and Minnesota's environment, by donating equipment and training resources.
On a national level, we've collaborated with the American Rental Association Foundation on a community impact project to improve green spaces across the US.
These examples illustrate how our company and employees give back, promote sustainability, and support our customers and communities, which is integral to our culture and identity.
As we conclude fiscal 2021 and enter 2022, we remain optimistic while acknowledging the ongoing dynamic environment.
We believe our updated guidance appropriately reflects both the risks and opportunities we face.
Our businesses have strong fundamentals and momentum, positioning us well to capitalize on future growth.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Scott Wells, CEO of Clear Channel Outdoor Americas, will join the Q&A session.
Management's expectations, beliefs and projections about performance are presented and represent their current views.
There is no guarantee that management's expectations, beliefs or projections will be realized or that actual outcomes won't differ from expectations.
We will present certain non-GAAP performance metrics during today's call.
These provide detailed information on foreign exchange impacts, non-cash compensation expenses, segment revenues, adjusted EBITDA, and other key data.
We request that you look at each slide as William and Brian discuss them.
This marks our third quarter hosting the call remotely.
We kindly ask for your patience in case of any technical difficulties during the call.
Many of us have experienced an unprecedented year, and like you, we continue to feel the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on our operations.
However, the past quarter has demonstrated the resilience of our business and its ability to rebound quickly when some semblance of normalcy returns.
Our third quarter consolidated revenue exceeded expectations, with reported revenue declining 32% year-over-year, a significant improvement from the 55% drop reported in the second quarter.
Excluding China and currency effects, the decline would have been 27%, surpassing our early August guidance of a low 30% decrease.
Our European performance surpassed expectations and showcased the strength of our medium.
As people returned to the streets, advertisers came back to our platforms.
The US market also showed gradual improvement, aligning with our projections.
Concurrently, we continued to implement measures to align our operating costs with revenue.
Considering the pandemic, the third quarter results, particularly in Europe, were encouraging.
We are utilizing our investments in digital displays, technology, and our network to navigate the crisis and maintain flexibility amid the uncertainty as governments across our markets address ongoing COVID-19 challenges.
Our commitment to long-term growth investments is evident in our recent successful bid for advertising rights in New York and New Jersey airports.
We are thrilled and honored to have secured this significant contract, and I commend Scott Wells and his team for their achievement.
I will provide more details about the contract and its value to our business later.
Looking ahead, based on current information, we anticipate a slight sequential improvement in Americas revenue and adjusted EBITDA margin for the fourth quarter.
However, we are unable to provide fourth quarter guidance for our European segment.
Recent mobility restrictions in our European markets, particularly in the UK and France over the past 10 days, have created volatility in customer booking activity, significantly limiting our visibility.
I am proud of our team's exceptional work in reinforcing our strong foundation and driving operational efficiencies amid rapidly changing business conditions.
Next, I will provide an overview of our business, the current landscape, and our outlook for the out-of-home market.
Please refer to Page 4.
In the Americas segment, year-over-year revenue declined 32% in the quarter, an improvement from the 39% drop reported in the second quarter.
Our Americas business focuses on the top 20 markets, which drove significant growth up to and including the first quarter of this year before COVID-19.
Although our audience levels are returning to normal, the largest markets in the top 20 are most affected by advertisers reducing out-of-home spending, especially on the East and West Coast, where national advertisers tend to concentrate.
Please turn to Page 5.
European reported revenue decreased 13% year-over-year, and excluding foreign exchange effects, it declined 18%, which is a substantial improvement from the 62% drop in the second quarter.
The improvement in digital, accounting for about 30% of European revenue and declining 17% excluding currency effects, was even more significant due to advertisers' ability to quickly launch campaigns as business resumed after lockdowns eased.
As I've mentioned before, our investment in digital is a crucial part of our strategy.
Our digital network is a dynamic medium that allows advertisers to engage in real-time, tactical, contextual, and flexible advertising.
I want to highlight the strength of our sales team across Europe, who have responded with agility.
As markets reopened, our audiences began moving around again, and advertiser interest returned.
We also benefited from our strategic focus on roadside locations, which historically account for about two-thirds of our total European revenue and are less affected by COVID-19 restrictions than transit environments, which represent approximately 10% of our European revenue.
Our UK business exemplified this, with about 80% of revenue historically coming from roadside inventory.
From mid-July until the recent announcements of new restrictions, our customer booking activity actually surpassed bookings made in the same period last year.
Moving to Page 6 and the Americas business.
With an improving outlook in the Americas, we remain cautiously optimistic for the near term.
Our long-term focus remains on returning to growth, which we believe we can achieve in 2021.
As we enter the fourth quarter, our visibility remains limited.
However, we have shifted from a defensive to an offensive strategy, leveraging the investments we've made and continue to make in technology.
Despite the uncertainty created by recent COVID-19 spikes, we believe our organization is better positioned to manage through market instability.
In light of this instability, we have expanded our client-direct selling initiatives.
We are focusing on selling creative ideas rather than specific billboard locations.
As advertisers realign their campaigns, we've found that CMOs are more willing to join a Zoom call to hear a great idea.
Our ability to get a foot in the door is constantly improving.
We continue to demonstrate to advertisers how our RADAR suite of solutions can help them.
While audience levels are returning to normal, travel patterns have changed.
People are spending more time close to home and less time in city centers, but they're still out and about.
With RADAR, we can quickly adjust to these new travel patterns to help our customers understand the best inventory and roadways to reach their target audience, target those customers via mobile ads, and measure campaign success.
More specifically, in the fourth quarter, we are seeing continued sequential improvements in our business.
For the first time since March, we've outperformed comparisons in several weeks so far this quarter.
In our national business, the number of RFPs is improving and approaching 2019 levels.
Local business continues to improve, and we are seeing continued strength in our permanent inventory.
We're currently in the renewal season, and most clients are keeping their locations.
However, we are still waiting for more data to better understand the strength of the holiday season compared to previous years, as advertisers continue to delay buying decisions.
Our largest category, business services, is holding up well and performing at levels equal to last year.
We are seeing increases in beverages, with continued weakness in amusements and entertainment.
Additionally, revenue generated by our programmatic platform has rebounded faster than the rest of our business, although programmatic still represents a small percentage of total revenue.
Moving to Page 7 for a review of Americas technology initiatives and new contracts.
During the past quarter, we continued to invest in technology and our digital footprint in America.
We added 19 new digital billboards this quarter, bringing the total to 57 new digital billboards this year, giving us more than 1,400 digital billboards in total.
We also partnered with Tremor Video to enhance our RADAR offering, which now provides advertisers a coordinated out-of-home and all-screen video solution that seamlessly extends into TV, digital, or social video campaigns to reach consumers when and where they're ready to engage with brands.
This is the latest enhancement to the RADAR suite, and we expect to continue adding customer-friendly capabilities to RADAR in the coming months.
Our data analytics capabilities have expanded with the introduction of a new audience impressions methodology for airport advertising, developed in collaboration with Geopath. This innovation provides advertisers with a more accurate understanding of consumer advertising journeys and behaviors in airports.
The new approach shifts from measuring campaigns solely on passenger count to a more comprehensive understanding of audience behavior and likelihood of exposure to airport advertising, utilizing the same Geopath data used for traditional roadside out-of-home advertising measurement.
Advertisers will be able to access this data through both Geopath and RADAR.
We are pleased to announce that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Board has awarded us the largest airport advertising contract in the US, allowing us to transform JFK, LaGuardia, Newark and Stewart airports into state-of-the-art digital media platforms.
This significant win demonstrates our confidence in our business fundamentals and our focus on long-term profitable growth opportunities beyond the temporary impact of the pandemic.
The 12-year contract is subject to execution by both parties, which we expect to occur in mid-November.
We anticipate the contract will become effective on December 30, 2020.
We collaborated with the Port Authority to create contract terms that align our interests and enable both parties to achieve their goals under current conditions and in the future, potentially establishing a new industry standard.
The agreement includes a two-year transition period to account for COVID-19's impact and traffic recovery at Port Authority airports.
The actual Minimum Annual Guarantee (MAG) and capital expenditure after the transition period will be based on total passenger traffic.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey airports serve as gateways to the world.
As the region and travel industry recover, we believe our team is best equipped to lead this historic transformation.
By adding these high-value, prominent airport assets to our portfolio, brands will have the unique opportunity to execute comprehensive campaigns reaching consumers as they drive, walk, or fly throughout the New York and New Jersey metropolitan area.
In Europe, we are observing varied performances across our markets due to the resurgence of COVID-19 cases.
Historically, about two-thirds of our revenue in the region comes from roadside displays.
In October, we continued to see strength in our street furniture and billboard inventory, as audiences were still present on the streets.
While transit advertising remained weak, our largest categories, FMCG and retail, showed sequential improvement.
Fashion and beauty advertising are also benefiting from the holiday season.
However, visibility into November and December has been affected by the spike in new cases and new restrictions, causing some advertisers to pause their activities.
We are closely monitoring the recent developments regarding the second wave of COVID-19 in Europe.
Although the new restrictions and uncertain environment will impact our business in the near term, they are not expected to last as long or be as limiting in terms of movement as those we experienced in March and April.
Consequently, we believe the second wave will have a less significant impact on revenue in the fourth quarter compared to the second quarter.
More importantly, the resilience of the business is evident.
When audiences return, out-of-home advertising rebounds strongly.
In the UK and other markets, we've seen bookings equal to or better than the previous year in many weeks during the past quarter.
In Europe, we continue to assist brands in navigating the audience and environmental impact of changing COVID-19 restrictions through the application of smart data.
For example, the UK's Return Audience Hub has become a popular planning tool for advertisers.
The hub monitors a vast anonymized mobile data set to learn and openly share how our portfolio is delivering audiences compared to pre-lockdown levels.
Clear Channel RADAR is now operational in both Spain and the UK, enhancing our ability to help brands effectively engage audiences as mobility patterns evolve.
We are seeing early benefits from our implementation of RADAR.
For instance, in Spain, we've booked campaigns for PepsiCo using proximity to stores and more targeted audience demographic and behavioral data, allowing us to respond to new audience behaviors and mobility patterns resulting from COVID-19.
We continue to expand our digital footprint, adding 383 digital displays in the third quarter and 699 year-to-date, bringing our total to over 15,000 screens now live.
As we expand our digital reach across European cities, we are well-positioned to offer increased flexibility and enhanced contextual relevance at scale, improving our ability to meet brands' needs.
This is evidenced by the improving digital revenue trend in the third quarter.
Throughout our digital transformation, we are committed to making Clear Channel inventory more accessible to both new and existing advertisers.
As in the US, we are developing our programmatic capabilities at an accelerated pace while securing and expanding partnerships with leading supply-side platform partners.
Recently, in Spain, we successfully ran our first fully programmatic campaign for car brand Cupra in partnership with SSP Broadsign Reach.
Broadsign Reach is already live across Holland and Switzerland.
In the UK, we just announced a new programmatic partnership with SSP Hivestack.
Across Clear Channel Outdoor, we strive to create products and provide services that excite and engage our consumers, communities, advertisers, and business partners.
As a result, we believe we are well-positioned to return to growth in 2021.
At the same time, we recognize the pressures of the current environment and will continue to take steps to preserve liquidity, including balancing the need to defer capital expenditures and reduce costs while still investing in strengthening our platform.
Consolidated revenue for the quarter decreased 31.5% from last year to $448 million.
Adjusting for foreign exchange, it was down 33.1%.
Excluding China and adjusting for foreign exchange, the decline in revenue was 27%, which was better than the low 30% decline we had projected in early August.
Our better-than-expected results are due to a stronger than anticipated rebound in Europe.
Consolidated net loss declined $77 million to $136 million in the third quarter of 2020 compared to $212 million in the third quarter of 2019.
Adjusted EBITDA was $31 million in the quarter, down 78.4% and excluding FX, was down 78.9%.
The Americas revenue was down 31.8% during the third quarter from $328 million in 2019 to $224 million.
This is an improvement over the second quarter results, which were down 39%.
Revenue declines in national and local, as well as digital, improved relative to the second quarter, while the decline in airports increased.
In general, our airport inventory is considered premium space.
While advertisers did not immediately reduce airport advertising campaigns at the beginning of the second quarter, they began pulling ads in the latter half of the quarter and into the third quarter.
Local, which accounted for 64% of revenue was down 27.6%, and national, which accounted for 36% of revenue was down 38.2%.
Digital accounted for 30% of revenue and was down 34.8%.
This compares to a 53.7% decline in the second quarter.
Our long-term contracts for print large format billboards, which we refer to as perms, continue to hold up well, even though total print ad revenue was down.
Both direct expenses and SG&A were down 19% in the quarter, primarily due to lower site lease expenses and lower compensation costs, as a result of the decline in revenue and cost reduction initiatives.
Adjusted EBITDA was $71 million, down 48% from the prior year.
As we have stated previously, our business has high fixed costs, and although we are working on reducing expenses throughout the organization, the decline in revenue resulted in a larger reduction in adjusted EBITDA.
Turn to Page 12 for a review of Europe's performance.
Europe's revenue declined by 13.4%.
Revenue decreased by 17.9% in the third quarter when excluding foreign exchange effects.
This represents a significant improvement from the 62% drop reported in the second quarter, with all markets contributing to the recovery.
France experienced growth in the quarter due to the new Paris street furniture contract and a partial recovery in the underlying market.
Digital revenue made up 30% of total revenue, which fell by 16.6% excluding foreign exchange, slightly less than the overall decline.
Adjusted direct operating expenses and SG&A expenses decreased by 8.9%.
The decrease is attributed to reduced site lease expenses and lower compensation costs, primarily related to the revenue decline and cost-cutting measures.
Adjusted EBITDA showed a loss of $8 million, resulting from the revenue decline and high fixed cost base.
In August, we issued senior secured notes through our indirect, wholly owned subsidiary, Clear Channel International BV (CCI B.V.), with the net proceeds providing additional liquidity for our operations.
Our European segment comprises the businesses operated by CCI B.V. and its consolidated subsidiaries.
The revenue for our Europe segment is equivalent to CCI B.V.'s revenue. Europe segment adjusted EBITDA excludes an allocation of CCI B.V.'s corporate expenses that are subtracted from CCI B.V.'s operating income and adjusted EBITDA.
As mentioned, Europe and CCI B.V. revenue fell by $34 million in the third quarter of 2020 compared to the same period in 2019, which was $217 million.
After adjusting for an $11 million impact from foreign exchange rate movements, Europe and CCI B.V. revenue decreased by $45 million.
CCI B.V. reported an operating loss of $38 million in the third quarter of 2020, compared to a $16 million operating loss in the same period of 2019.
Let's move to Page 13 for a brief overview of other segments.
Our other segment includes Latin America and Clear Media.
The 2019 results include Clear Media, which was sold in Q2 of 2020.
Latin America's revenue was $7 million in the third quarter, a $15 million decrease from the previous year.
The COVID-19 surge in Latin America began later in the year, and controlling the virus spread is taking longer in the region.
Direct operating expenses and SG&A were $13 million in the third quarter, a $4 million reduction from the previous year.
Adjusted EBITDA showed a loss for the quarter.
Let's proceed to Page 14 to discuss capital expenditures.
Capital expenditures totaled $26 million in the third quarter, a $34 million decrease from the previous year, as we actively reduced our capital spending to maintain liquidity and divested our stake in Clear Media.
Despite this significant reduction, we continued to invest in digital technology in key locations, adding 19 new digital billboards in the US and 383 new digital displays in Europe.
Please turn to Page 15.
Clear Channel Outdoor's consolidated cash and cash equivalents totaled $845 million as of September 30, 2020, including $417 million held outside the US by our subsidiaries.
During the third quarter, we transferred a portion of the Clear Media sale proceeds to the US.
Our debt stood at $5.6 billion, an increase of just over $500 million during the year, resulting from drawing on our cash flow revolver at the end of March and issuing the CCI B.V. notes in August.
Cash paid for interest on the debt during the third quarter was $147 million, slightly higher than the previous year due to interest payment timing, partially offset by lower interest rates.
The company anticipates approximately $21 million in cash interest payments for the fourth quarter of 2020, and $350 million in 2021, including interest on the new CCI B.V. secure notes, with the first payment due in April 2021.
Let's move on to Page 16.
As William mentioned, we continue to focus on managing our cost base and enhancing our liquidity and financial flexibility, while driving improvements in top-line trends to return the business to its pre-COVID trajectory.
This includes proactive steps to right-size the business.
In addition to the temporary cost-saving measures implemented in the second quarter, we've also initiated restructuring plans throughout the company.
These plans are expected to generate annualized pre-tax savings of approximately $32 million upon completion, with total charges ranging from $23 million to $26 million to achieve these savings.
While we remain confident the business will return to pre-COVID levels, we still lack visibility on timing.
Given the uncertainty, we deemed it prudent to take appropriate steps to align the cost base with the current business environment.
Additionally, during the third quarter, as previously discussed, we issued $375 million in senior secured notes in August through our indirect wholly owned subsidiary CCI B.V.
We continue negotiating site lease contracts with landlords and municipalities to better align fixed site lease expenses with revenue reductions.
We generated rent abatements of $24 million during the third quarter and $53 million year-to-date.
We continue to benefit from compensation cost reductions through actions enacted in the second quarter, most of which are temporary.
We obtained European government support and wage subsidies of $7 million in the third quarter and $15 million year-to-date.
We eliminated and reduced certain discretionary expenses.
We deferred capital expenditures, as mentioned earlier, and we deferred site lease expenses and other payments to optimize working capital levels.
From a liquidity standpoint, based on current knowledge, we believe we have sufficient liquidity, including the $845 million cash at quarter-end, to fund the business needs as the economy and our operations recover.
Please turn to Page 17.
As William mentioned, we expect to see a slight improvement in revenue and adjusted EBITDA margin for the Americas on a sequential basis.
In Europe, we saw strong sequential improvement in the third quarter.
However, our visibility for the fourth quarter has been impacted by recent mobility restrictions in some of our largest European markets, particularly in the UK and France.
These restrictions have created volatility in customer booking activity, significantly limiting our visibility and ability to provide guidance.
As mentioned, our team continues to work exceptionally hard through this challenging environment, and we are seeing the results of our efforts.
We're encouraged by advertisers returning to our inventory in the last quarter, demonstrating the resilience of our medium and the value of our locations.
They're benefiting from our continued investments in technology and expansion of our digital footprint, and we're proud of securing new contracts, especially winning the New York and New Jersey Port Authority airports.
We remain focused on the strong medium and long-term opportunities within our sector and are confident Clear Channel is well-positioned to capitalize on these improving trends.
To conclude my remarks, I want to reiterate a few points.
First, as Brian mentioned, the actions we took earlier in the year provide what we believe to be sufficient liquidity to manage through the pandemic, even with the spikes we've seen in the US and Europe.
Second, we will continue to identify both temporary and permanent cost reductions to better align our expenses with the current economic environment and expand on our restructuring plans.
Third, in the third quarter, we delivered better-than-expected results, with a strong rebound in Europe demonstrating the underlying resilience of our business.
In recent weeks, in both some European markets and the US, we have at times equaled or bettered prior year performance.
When infection rates decline and restrictions are lifted and our audience returns, our markets recover.
Looking ahead, the course of the pandemic remains unclear with the second wave in Europe and continued uncertainty in the US.
Although we expect the next few quarters to remain challenging, we believe in the underlying fundamentals of our industry and our business.
As both Brian and I stated, given the resilience of our team, investments in our business, and strength of our platform, we expect to deliver a slight sequential improvement in Americas revenue and adjusted EBITDA margin in the fourth quarter.
We are not providing fourth quarter guidance for Europe, given the recent mobility restrictions creating significant volatility in our booking activity.
However, we remain cautiously optimistic that we will return to growth in 2021.
Lastly, as we've stated before, we always remain open to dispositions and opportunities that accelerate our path to creating enhanced value for shareholders.
However, given the current economic environment, our focus remains on continuing to own, operate and enhance the value of the current portfolio of assets to drive shareholder value as the economies rebound.
I look forward to providing updates regarding our progress.
Summary:
output:
q3 revenue fell 31.8 percent to $223.7 million.
clear channel outdoor - committed to restructuring plans to reduce headcount with expected pre-tax annual cost savings of about $32 million.
