input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We thank you for joining us and hope you are safe and healthy.
We are happy with the strong beginning of 2021 and ongoing recovery in our car and industrial sectors.
The GPC team remained committed to effective execution and delivering strong financial outcomes through improving sales patterns, increasing operational efficiency and enhancing value for customers.
Throughout the quarter, we operated carefully with our employees' physical and mental wellbeing as the top priority, as our over 50,000 GPC team members are crucial to our success.
Let's now review our first quarter financial results.
Total revenue for the quarter was $4.5 billion, a 9% increase from last year and a significant improvement from the 1% sales decline in the fourth quarter of 2020.
Gross margin was also positive, marking our 14th consecutive quarter of year-over-year gross margin growth, and our field teams continued to excel at managing our expenses through ongoing cost measures and the continuation of expense reductions implemented last year.
These outcomes led to a 41% increase in operating profit and an 8.1% operating margin, up 180 basis points from the first quarter of the previous year.
Our strong operational performance resulted in net income of $218 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.50, an 88% increase.
We also continued to strengthen our balance sheet, ensuring adequate liquidity and solid cash flow.
We are proud of our teams and encouraged by our results, and we plan to build on this momentum throughout 2021.
Now let's turn to our business segments.
Automotive represented 66% of total sales in the first quarter, while Industrial accounted for 34%.
By region, 73% of revenues came from North America, 16% from Europe, and 11% from Asia-Pacific.
Global Automotive total sales were $3 billion, a 14% increase from 2020 and a significant improvement from the 1% increase in Q4 of 2020.
Comparable sales increased by 8%, an improvement from the 2% decrease in the fourth quarter, and segment profit margin rose by 250 basis points, driven by strong operating results across all our automotive operations.
Sales were driven by positive comparable sales across all our operations, with 15% growth in Europe and Asia-Pacific, 7% in the US, and 3% in Canada.
The ongoing global economic recovery, including financial stimulus in the US, improved inventory availability, favorable weather conditions, and our focus on key growth initiatives all contributed to sales growth in the quarter.
We should note that while we continue to expect a reasonable level of inflation as we progress through 2021, price inflation was not a factor in our first quarter sales.
In Europe, sales significantly improved from Q4 as our team capitalized on the strengthening sales environment, despite lockdowns throughout the region.
Additionally, initiatives to grow key accounts, enhance inventory availability, and the ongoing launch of the NAPA brand continued to be effective in driving profitable growth and market share gains.
For the quarter, our teams in France and the UK outperformed in the region with strong double-digit comparable sales growth.
We would also highlight a much improved performance by our team in the Benelux region.
The strong sales recovery combined with excellent expense control produced a 500-basis point improvement in operating margin.
This marks an excellent start to the year for our European operations.
In Asia-Pacific, our Automotive sales remained consistent with the mid-teen growth we experienced through the second half of 2020.
For the quarter, both retail and commercial sales remained strong as the region operated through multiple lockdowns associated with the pandemic.
Retail sales, which represent over 40% of our total sales volume through our Repco stores, continued to outperform, posting a 33% increase in March and a 24% increase for the quarter.
Our commercial sales also continued to accelerate, posting double-digit growth in the quarter.
We continued to benefit from the strength in online sales, which reached record highs at three times pre-COVID levels.
Lastly, building on the NAPA brand name has been well-received, and we remain focused on growing our NAPA presence in the region.
In summary, this group continues to perform exceptionally well on both the top and bottom lines, resulting in a 150-basis point improvement in profit margin for the quarter.
In North America, comparable sales in the US increased by 7%, helping this business post a 180-basis point increase in profit margins.
In Canada, we operated through various regional lockdowns which impacted our larger markets of Ontario and Quebec.
Comparable sales increased by 3% and operating margin rose by 130 basis points.
Sales in the US, which posted its strongest quarterly comparison since the first quarter of 2015, were driven by solid growth in both the retail and commercial segments.
This was our first quarter of positive commercial comparisons since pre-pandemic, and our team produced record sales volumes in March.
Additionally, both ticket and traffic counts were positive for both our retail and commercial transactions, marking our first increase in traffic counts in several quarters.
By region, the Atlantic, Midwest, and West Groups posted the strongest growth, although we would also highlight our Northeast Group, which produced solid growth in the quarter.
This is notable as this region of the US has been most affected by COVID-19 lockdowns over the past 13 months.
Similarly, we would add that product sales in categories such as batteries, tools and equipment, and brakes were strong this quarter.
We are particularly encouraged to see the rebound in our brakes business, which is generally a positive indicator for our commercial business.
On the retail side, which continues to outperform with strong double-digit growth, we continued to drive sales through investments in retail specialists and store refreshes, as well as targeted promotions.
We would also highlight our ongoing omnichannel investments and the increase in B2C online sales, which reached record levels in the quarter and were up 150% from the previous year.
Our commercial sales, our other wholesale category of independent garage customers, continued to generate strong growth.
We have been encouraged by the number of new accounts we are serving.
Clearly, our investments in increasing the number of professional salespeople on the street have been effective in attracting new customers to NAPA.
We were also pleased to see improved sales with our NAPA AutoCare and major account customers, which posted positive sales growth for the first time in several quarters.
Sales to the fleet and government group were down year-over-year but sequentially improved from the fourth quarter, and we anticipate further improvement in sales for this segment.
Looking ahead, we are excited about the growth opportunities we see for our Global Automotive segment.
We expect further improvement in aftermarket fundamentals such as increased miles driven, a growing vehicle fleet, and an increase in vehicles aged six to 12 years, all of which are favorable for the industry.
We can assure you we remain focused on our initiatives to deliver customer value and ultimately sell more parts for more cars.
These plans include further enhancing our inventory availability, strengthening our supply chain, and investing in our omnichannel capabilities.
Additionally, we expect to expand our global store footprint with additional bolt-on acquisitions, changeovers, and new greenfield stores to further enhance our competitive positioning.
Now let's discuss the global Industrial Parts Group.
Total sales for this group were $1.5 billion, flat compared to last year.
Comparable sales decreased by 2%, an improvement from the 4% decrease in Q4 and reflecting the third consecutive quarter of improving sales trends.
March was a standout month, with the North American Motion team posting a 7% increase in average daily sales and achieving record sales volumes.
This was a tremendous accomplishment and another turning point for GPC in our emergence from the pandemic.
The ongoing recovery over the last nine months aligns with the continued improvement in the industrial economy, which can be seen in several key indicators for our business.
For perspective, PMI was 64.7% in March, an increase of 4.2 points from December 31st.
Additionally, industrial production increased by 2.5% in the first quarter, the third consecutive quarter of expansion, following the significant downturn in the second quarter of 2020.
Importantly, we can see these positive indicators translating to more activity with our customers, which are operating at higher run rates and releasing capital project orders.
The strengthening sales environment, along with our initiatives to drive growth and control costs, produced an 80 basis point margin improvement, with segment profit margin at 8.3% versus 7.5% last year.
Diving deeper into our Q1 sales, we'll start by saying that inflation remains a non-factor in our numbers thus far.
That said, we are seeing more pricing activity and expect another year of 1% to 2% price inflation from our suppliers.
For the quarter, we experienced improving sales trends among virtually all product categories and industries served.
We were especially encouraged by the recovery in the equipment and machinery, aggregate and cement, and wood and lumber sectors, all key industry groups for us.
Furthermore, we are seeing continued advantages from expanding our omnichannel capabilities, with online sales doubling compared to Q1 2020.
A major contributor to our digital expansion is our internal sales department, which is bringing in additional revenue from new Motion clients.
Though it currently represents a small portion of overall revenue, we are optimistic about its future growth potential.
We are also concentrating on expanding our services and solutions offerings to broaden our expertise and sales opportunities in areas like equipment repair, conveyance and automation.
We have made several small acquisitions to increase our scale in these areas, and our services and solutions capabilities remain an important consideration in our overall M&A strategy for the Industrial segment.
To ensure profitable revenue growth, we are continuously improving our pricing and category management approaches.
We also intend to further optimize our supply chain network and boost productivity while maintaining excellent customer service.
To wrap up our Industrial segment discussion.
We remain optimistic about our Motion business and are pleased to see this division returning to growth.
I will now conclude my remarks with a brief update on our ESG initiatives.
As detailed in our Corporate Sustainability Report, GPC is committed to innovating in ways that benefit our environment, employees, and the communities where we operate.
In the first quarter, we expanded our training and development programs to support personal growth and enhanced our comprehensive well-being program focusing on the emotional, financial and physical health of our GPC team members.
Moreover, we continue to make progress in advancing our corporate commitment to diversity and inclusion by actively recruiting talent representative of the communities we serve, training our team members to mitigate unconscious bias and model inclusive behaviors, and strengthening partnerships that support our D&I initiatives.
Lastly, we remain dedicated to our mission of being good corporate citizens in the places where we work and live.
Since 1928, we have been giving back to communities and causes that make a difference, and this legacy continues in 2021.
First, I'd like to commend the global GPC team for their performance this quarter.
As Paul mentioned, our team delivered solid results in the first quarter and has strong momentum.
The situation has improved compared to 2020, but we remain cautious as global uncertainty continues to be a part of daily business operations.
Areas of concern for us include COVID-19, inflation, global logistics, and product and labor availability.
We also face more challenging year-over-year comparisons that will require sustained momentum during the second half of the year.
Despite the uncertainty, the GPC team is energized and focused on delivering results.
I'll now provide some additional insight into our ongoing strategic initiatives.
The foundation of our priorities is based on the customer experience, understanding their needs, and striving to exceed their expectations.
We are analyzing and listening to customer feedback and responding to strengths and opportunities.
Put simply, our customers need us to be easy to work with, dependable, and helpful.
This independent data reinforces our priorities and serves as a guiding principle for required action and strategic investment.
To provide a top-tier customer experience, we have opportunities to streamline and integrate our existing operations.
Our global teams are implementing multi-year plans to realign teams, streamline processes, improve operational efficiency, and reduce costs.
These initiatives will not only create operational efficiencies but also enable faster team execution, deliver a better customer experience, and accelerate profitable growth.
I'd like to highlight a few initiatives that demonstrate our efforts to streamline and integrate.
For instance, we're working to optimize our facilities footprint and coverage, simplify and integrate disparate legacy IT systems, streamline back-office support functions, offshore non-customer facing activities, and centralize GPC indirect sourcing processes, among other examples.
As we streamline and integrate, we're simultaneously investing in our core business and positioning for the future.
Our strong cash flow, solid capital structure, and disciplined capital allocation provide the flexibility needed to continue making these investments.
Key areas of our core investments include talent, sales force effectiveness, digital supply chain, and emerging vehicle technologies.
A few highlights of our progress across these key areas during the quarter include:
We continue to take deliberate action globally to identify high-potential talent, bring new capabilities into the organization, and recruit diverse talent representative of the communities we serve.
Examples include roles in category management, digital, emerging vehicle technology, and field leadership, to name a few.
Talent will always be a priority investment area as we strive to be an employer of choice for team members who share our GPC values and want to play a leadership role in our exciting future.
Regarding sales force effectiveness, using data and analytics to understand our unique customer segments, their different needs, and associated strategies to serve each segment is a fundamental element.
Our sales efforts reflect our omnichannel initiatives and include an increasing mix of both traditional and digital selling strategies.
For example, the US automotive team revamped its sales approach with new reporting tools to track customer visits, digital tools to communicate with field sales team members, and enhanced virtual product and skills training.
Additionally, in 2021, the US automotive team adjusted compensation programs to better align incentives with profitable growth.
As mentioned, digital is a fundamental priority as we deliver a top-tier customer experience and accelerate profitable growth.
Our businesses delivered excellent performance via digital channels in the quarter.
We continue to see strong increases compared to the previous year across our global digital channels.
While digital still represents a relatively small portion of our total sales, we're excited about the compelling digital vision our teams are executing.
We also continue to invest in foundational digital elements, including catalog, search, and other critical customer experience aspects, such as ease of ordering, pricing, and analytics.
Our supply chain initiatives focus on ensuring we have the right product available in the right market at the right time.
We are continuously implementing inventory, facility, productivity, logistics, and technology strategies to achieve this goal.
A solid example is the success the US Industrial team enjoyed with recent facility automation investments that delivered a 500% labor productivity improvement.
Other examples include enhanced workforce management and delivery tracking tools in the US automotive business.
Lastly, regarding emerging vehicle technologies, we aim to lead in the opportunities presented by these advancements for our automotive industries.
We believe we have a unique position to leverage, including our scaled global footprint, diverse portfolio, leading global brands, established customer-supplier relationships, and one GPC team approach.
Through our planning process, we developed a multi-faceted strategy to address electric vehicle trends.
A few highlights include aligning talent 100% dedicated to developing and executing EV strategies, product and category management strategies with existing and new SKUs, global supplier councils with existing strategic partners, advisory groups leveraging our 25,000 global repair center relationships, and partnerships with strategic EV market participants.
Finally, strategic bolt-on acquisitions are a key part of our GPC growth strategy.
We use acquisitions to gain new customers, further penetrate existing priority markets, enter new geographies, acquire product and service capabilities, and acquire talent.
We also believe our acquisition capabilities position us well as we selectively consider and test new business models.
Our acquisition pipeline remains active and actionable given the fragmentation of our markets.
We believe our scale, market-leading brands, global footprint, and unique culture position us to be an acquirer of choice.
We will remain selective and disciplined as we execute this important part of our strategy.
Similar to the approach used for our 2019 cost savings plan, the global teams develop tools and a monthly cadence to create visibility and status on initiatives.
This approach not only helps drive performance but also helps to share best practices around the globe as one GPC team.
In summary, I hope today's remarks reinforce our sense of focus and global teamwork.
We will remain adaptable as the global environment continues to evolve.
We will stay focused on what we can control as we execute through the rest of the year and beyond.
I'll now hand it over to Carol to review the financial performance details.
We'll start by reviewing our key financial data and then provide an update on our 2021 full-year forecast.
In the first quarter, GPC's total sales reached $4.5 billion, a 9% increase from the previous year and an improvement from the 0.7% decline in the fourth quarter.
The gross margin rose to 34.5%, a 60-basis point improvement compared to 33.9% in the same quarter last year.
Our ongoing efforts to enhance gross margin continue to show positive results from various initiatives, including our pricing strategies and global sourcing efforts.
We also saw benefits from a shift in sales towards operations with higher gross margins.
It's worth noting that supplier incentives in the quarter were comparable to last year and had no impact on gross margin.
As mentioned earlier, price inflation had minimal effect on our first-quarter sales and gross margin.
Throughout the year, we will continue to implement our strategies to achieve further gross margin improvements through positive product mix changes, strategic pricing tools and analytics, global sourcing advantages, and strategic category management initiatives.
Our selling, administrative, and other expenses totaled $1.2 billion in the first quarter, up 4.6% from last year, or 5.3% from last year's adjusted SG&A.
This represents an improvement to 26.8% of sales this year, down nearly 100 basis points from 27.7% last year.
We've made significant progress, primarily due to cost savings from 2020, ongoing cost control measures, and improved leverage from stronger sales growth.
Our progress was slightly offset by rising freight costs, which we're carefully managing, and planned increases in technology spending to support our strategic initiatives.
Total operating and non-operating expenses were $1.3 billion in the first quarter, up 2.2% from last year or 2.1% compared to last year's adjusted expenses.
The first quarter expenses include approximately $20 million in benefits from real estate sales gains and favorable retirement plan valuation adjustments recorded in other non-operating income.
Overall, our total expenses for the quarter improved to 28.1% of sales, down 190 basis points from 30% in 2020.
First quarter total segment profit was $361 million, a strong 41% increase on the 9% sales growth.
Our segment profit margin rose to 8.1% compared to 6.3% last year, a 180 basis point increase.
Compared to 2019, our segment profit margin has improved by 100 basis points.
This solid improvement represents our strongest first quarter profit margin since 2015, reflecting the positive momentum in our businesses.
Our net interest expense decreased to $18 million from $20 million in 2020 due to lower total debt and more favorable interest rates.
Corporate expenses were $31 million in the quarter, down from $55 million in 2020, primarily due to the favorable real estate gains and retirement plan adjustments mentioned earlier.
The first quarter tax rate was 23.8%, in line with last year's reported rate and improved from the prior year's adjusted rate of 26.5%.
This improvement is mainly due to the favorable tax impact of exercised stock options, as well as the previously mentioned real estate gains and retirement plan adjustments.
Our first quarter net income from continuing operations was $218 million, with diluted earnings per share of $1.50.
This compares to $0.84 per diluted share in the prior year, or an adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.80, representing an 88% increase.
Let's now examine our first quarter results by segment.
Automotive revenue for the first quarter was $3 billion, up 14% from the previous year.
Segment profit increased by 65% to $236 million, with profit margin rising to 8% compared to 5.5% in the first quarter of last year.
The 250 basis point margin increase was driven by the ongoing recovery in the Automotive business and the execution of our growth and operating initiatives.
We're pleased that all our automotive businesses expanded their margins for the third consecutive quarter.
It's encouraging that our first quarter margin also compares favorably to the first quarter of 2019, up 120 basis points.
We're seeing a broad recovery across our operations and anticipate continued progress in the coming quarters.
Industrial sales remained flat at $1.5 billion in the quarter compared to last year, but improved sequentially for the third consecutive quarter, aligning with the strengthening industrial economy.
Segment profit increased by 10% to $125 million, with profit margin rising 80 basis points to 8.3% compared to 7.5% last year.
The improved Industrial margin reflects the third consecutive quarter of margin expansion in both our North American and Australasian industrial businesses and is also up by 90 basis points from the first quarter of 2019.
We expect another quarter of strong operating results for Industrial, with stronger sales growth projected for the remainder of the year.
Now, let's discuss the balance sheet.
We continue to operate with a strong balance sheet, ample liquidity, and the financial strength to support our growth strategy.
As of March 31st, total accounts receivable decreased by 27% from last year, primarily due to $800 million in receivables sold in 2020.
Inventory increased by 6% from the prior year, while accounts payable rose by 14%.
Our AP to inventory ratio improved to 124% from 116% last year.
We're pleased with our progress in improving our overall working capital position and believe there are opportunities for further improvement.
Total debt stands at $2.6 billion as of March 31st, down $1 billion or 28% from last March and $60 million from December 31st, 2020.
We significantly improved our debt position throughout 2020 by issuing new public debt and securing a new revolving credit agreement, providing expanded credit capacity and more favorable rates.
With these positive changes to our debt structure, our total debt to adjusted EBITDA has improved to 1.8 times from 2.5 times last year.
We ended the first quarter with $2.6 billion in available liquidity, up from $1.1 billion at March 31st last year and in line with December 31st.
We continue to generate strong cash flow, with $300 million in cash from operations in the first quarter, up from $28 million in the first quarter last year.
Given our strong start to the year, including increased net income and improved working capital, we still expect cash from operations to be in the $1 billion to $1.2 billion range and free cash flow of $700 million to $900 million.
Our key priorities for cash include reinvesting in our businesses through capital expenditures, M&A, dividends, and share repurchases.
We invested $48 million in capital expenditures in the first quarter, up from $39 million in 2020.
Looking ahead, we plan additional investments in our businesses to drive growth and improve efficiencies and productivity.
We continue to expect total capital expenditures of approximately $300 million for the year.
Strategic acquisitions remain an important component of our long-term growth strategy.
We're cultivating a strong pipeline of targeted names and expect to make additional strategic bolt-on acquisitions to complement both our Global Automotive and Industrial segments in the coming months and quarters.
In the first quarter, we paid a cash dividend of $114 million to our shareholders.
The Company has paid a cash dividend to shareholders every year since going public in 1928, and our 2021 dividend of $3.26 per share represents our 65th consecutive annual increase.
We've actively participated in a share repurchase program since 1994.
While there were no repurchases in the first quarter, the Company is currently authorized to repurchase up to 14.5 million additional shares, and we plan to resume share repurchases in the coming months and quarters.
Regarding our outlook for 2021, we considered several factors including past performance, current growth plans and strategic initiatives, recent business trends, potential foreign currency fluctuations, inflation, and the global economic outlook.
We also considered ongoing uncertainties due to market disruptions such as COVID-19 and its potential impact on our results.
With these factors in mind, we now expect total sales for 2021 to grow by 5% to 7%, an increase from our previous guidance of 4% to 6%.
As usual, these growth rates exclude the benefit of any unannounced future acquisitions.
By business segment, we're now guiding to 5% to 7% total sales growth for the Automotive segment, up from 4% to 6%, and 4% to 6% total sales growth for the Industrial segment, up from 3% to 5%.
On the earnings side, we're raising our guidance for diluted earnings per share to a range of $5.85 to $6.05, representing an 11% to 15% increase from 2020.
This is an increase from our previous guidance of $5.55 to $5.75.
We enter the second quarter focused on our initiatives to meet or exceed these targeted results and look forward to reporting on our financial performance throughout the year.
Looking ahead, the GPC team is excited about the ongoing recovery in the global economy and the growth prospects we see for both Auto and Industrial.
Our strong balance sheet provides the financial flexibility to pursue strategic growth opportunities, and we remain focused on executing our plans to capture profitable growth, generate strong cash flow, and drive shareholder value.
As a result, we're optimistic about delivering strong financial results in the coming quarters.
Summary:

sees 2021 free cash flow $700 million to $900 million.

The strategy involves selecting a few dominant tech giants that are widely popular, then watching as their valuations increase

Questions about the viability of value investing or its redefinition have become increasingly common
This situation is similar to the dot-com bubble of the late 1990s, as described in Michael Lewis's 1999 book "The New New Thing"
Investors now, like those in the past, are captivated by these trends
However, value investing will have its day again, as paying less than the future cash flows' present value remains a successful long-term investment strategy, and current conditions make this approach even more appealing
We believe the factors for reversing today's extremes are evident, especially as our COVID-affected world has entered a recession, which historically signals a shift
Consider these four potential catalysts that may indicate an imminent shift
Firstly, a recession is underway and the path to economic recovery is becoming evident
We analyzed U.S. recessions over the past century and Japanese recessions over 45 years, finding compelling evidence
The United States has experienced 14 recessions in the last 100 years
Examining five-year returns from the start of recessions, value stocks outperformed the broader market by an average of 5% annually
Secondly, when interest rates stop declining, it halts the multiple expansion of growth stocks
Interest rates have been on a downward trend for four decades
This trend has created a situation where value stocks can be bought at P/E ratios of 10, similar to any time in the past 70 years, while average growth stock multiples have risen from 30 to 60 times earnings
Even if rates remain stable, the advantage enjoyed by growth stocks should diminish
Thirdly, the optimistic growth expectations for major tech companies return to normal levels
Let's use Microsoft as an example to illustrate this point
Microsoft's stock price has increased tenfold over the past decade, growing at 25% annually, supported by strong growth in cloud technology replacing on-site hardware demand
This has resulted in 8% annual growth in operating income
To achieve an 8% annual stock price increase in the future, given Microsoft's high valuation, would now require 20 years of 10% operating income growth
However, market analysts estimate that public cloud penetration of data needs has reached 30% to 35%, with a potential maximum penetration of approximately 70%
We've reached approximately half of our capacity.
The source of growth for the next two decades remains uncertain.
The outcome is yet to be determined.
Contrary to popular belief, technological advancements don't always negatively impact existing businesses.
Let's examine the competition between Tesla and Volkswagen in the electric vehicle market.
The prevailing opinion and stock performance suggest Tesla will emerge victorious.
However, is it logical to assume Volkswagen must decline even if Tesla grows?
Tesla's stock has been a top performer, increasing more than tenfold in the past five years.
In contrast, Volkswagen's stock value has remained relatively stable during the same period.
There are only two primary ways to succeed in automobile manufacturing.
The first is to maintain higher prices through brand prestige.
The second is to reduce production expenses.
It appears inevitable that these principles will apply to electric vehicles, and Volkswagen will likely transfer their brand strengths and scale advantages to compete in this market.
In fact, Volkswagen leads all competitors in planned electric vehicle releases over the coming years.
Regarding our financial performance, we concluded the quarter with approximately $1.1 billion in net inflows.
Over the past year, we experienced net positive flows of about $2.1 billion.
We've maintained positive net flows for three consecutive calendar years and six out of the last eight years.
This is a significant achievement given the current skepticism surrounding value investing.
Our diluted earnings for the third quarter were $0.16 per share, compared to $0.13 last quarter and $0.19 per share for the same period last year.
Quarterly revenues totaled $33.9 million with an operating income of $15 million.
Our operating margin this quarter was 44.1%, up from 36.4% last quarter but down from 46.3% in the third quarter of the previous year.
Examining our assets under management, we ended the quarter at $33.3 billion, a 5.7% increase from last quarter's $31.5 billion, but a 7% decrease from $35.8 billion in the third quarter of last year.
The growth in assets under management from the previous quarter was driven by $1.1 billion in net inflows and $0.7 billion in market appreciation, including foreign exchange impact.
The decline from the previous year's third quarter reflects $4.8 billion in market depreciation, including foreign exchange impact, partially offset by $2.1 billion in net inflows.
As of September 30, 2020, our assets under management comprised $13.3 billion in separately managed accounts, $18 billion in sub-advised accounts, and $2 billion in Pzena funds.
Compared to the previous quarter, separately managed account assets increased due to $0.4 billion in market appreciation and foreign exchange impact, slightly offset by $0.1 billion in net outflows.
Sub-advised account assets grew, reflecting $1.3 billion in net inflows and $0.3 billion in market appreciation and foreign exchange impact, while Pzena fund assets decreased slightly due to $0.1 billion in net outflows.
In the third quarter of 2020, mean assets under management reached $33.1 billion, showing an 11.1% rise from the previous quarter but an 8.1% drop compared to the same period last year
Income rose by 12.7% from the previous quarter but fell by 8.4% when compared to the third quarter of the previous year
Revenue changes are mainly attributed to severance, average assets under management, and the effect on performance and fulcrum fees
No performance fees were recognized this quarter or last, unlike the $0.3 million recorded in the same quarter of the previous year
The quarter also saw a reduction in base fees for certain accounts due to fulcrum fee arrangements with a client
These arrangements necessitate a decrease in the base fee if the investment strategy underperforms its benchmark, or allow a performance fee if it outperforms
In the second and third quarters of 2020, $1 million reductions in base fees were recognized for these accounts, compared to a $0.5 million reduction in the third quarter of 2019
These fees are calculated every quarter and compare relative performance over a three-year period
The amount of base fees recognized may change as the three-year performance record of this account fluctuates relative to its benchmark
The weighted average fee rate for the quarter was 41 basis points, compared to 40.4 basis points in the previous quarter and 41.2 basis points in the same quarter last year
Changes in our overall weighted average fee rate are influenced by asset mix and fluctuations in performance and fulcrum fees
Compensation and benefits expenses totaled $15.8 million for the quarter, compared to $15.6 million in the previous quarter and $16 million in the same quarter last year
G&A expenses for the third quarter of 2020 were $3.2 million, down from $3.6 million in the previous quarter and $3.9 million in the same quarter last year, mainly due to reduced travel costs and professional fees
Other income for the quarter was $0.5 million, primarily driven by investment performance
The effective tax rate for unincorporated and other business taxes was negative 6.8% this quarter, compared to positive 4.1% last quarter and negative 5.1% in the same quarter last year
The negative effective tax rate this quarter and in the third quarter of last year reflects benefits from reversing uncertain tax position liabilities and interests due to statute of limitations expiration
The ongoing effective rate for unincorporated and other business taxes of the operating company is expected to be between 3% and 5%
The effective corporate income tax rate, excluding UBT and other business taxes, was 26.5% this quarter, compared to 26.6% last quarter and 24.4% in the same quarter last year
Fluctuations in these effective rates are due to certain permanently non-deductible expenses
The ongoing rate, excluding these items, is expected to be between 23% and 25%
Approximately 78% of the operating company's net income was allocated to non-public members in the third quarter of 2020, compared to 77.7% last quarter and 74.5% in the same quarter last year
These percentage variations result from changes in ownership interest in the operating company
During the quarter, about 102,000 shares of Class A common stock were repurchased and retired for $0.5 million through the stock buyback program
As of September 30, approximately $10.7 million remained in the repurchase program
At quarter end, the company's financial position remained strong with $49.2 million in cash and cash equivalents, and $70.3 million in short-term investments
A quarterly dividend of $0.03 per share was declared
Summary:

q3 gaap earnings per share $0.16.
q3 revenue fell 8 percent to $33.9 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I trust you're all keeping well and remaining safe.
It's clear there are numerous aspects of 2020 that we, like many of you, are eager to move past as we look towards a more secure and healthy 2021.
To conclude, we were satisfied with our fourth quarter performance, which showed the ongoing stability and resilience of our utility water end market.
As expected, flow instrumentation sales improved sequentially but remained lower compared to the previous year.
We achieved improvements in gross margin, maintained cash flow generation, and saw growth in earnings per share, though with several factors at play that Bob will elaborate on.
I'm very proud of our success in completing two significant acquisitions in recent months that serve as strategic growth catalysts for Badger Meter.
We recently acquired Analytical Technologies, Inc, or ATi, which, combined with our November 2020 purchase of s::can, provides us with a solid foundation to develop real-time, on-demand water quality monitoring solutions for both utility water and industrial markets.
Total sales for the fourth quarter reached $112.3 million, a 4% increase from $107.6 million in the same period last year.
This reflects the stabilization we observed in the third quarter, which has largely persisted despite the resurgence of COVID-19 cases and various regional restrictions.
In the utility water sector, overall sales grew by 8% against a challenging comparison from Q4 last year, which had also seen an 8% increase over 2018.
The acquisition of s::can in November 2020 contributed approximately 3 percentage points to the current quarter's revenue growth, with core organic revenues in utility water rising 5% year-over-year.
Organically, this quarter's sales were the second highest in our history, surpassed only by the third quarter of 2020, which included a significant portion of pandemic-induced backlog catch-up, as we discussed previously.
Positive revenue mix trends continued with increased adoption of smart metering solutions, including higher sales of ORION Cellular radios and growth in BEACON software-as-a-service revenue, along with greater ultrasonic meter penetration.
We also benefited from strategic pricing initiatives, which I'll discuss in more detail shortly.
As anticipated, flow instrumentation sales showed improvement sequentially, declining 10% year-over-year compared to the 18% drop experienced in Q3 2020, though activity levels continue to reflect the broadly challenged markets and applications served globally.
Operating profit as a percentage of sales was 15.1%, a slight 10-basis-point decrease from the previous year's 15.2%, with several factors affecting the gross profit and SEA lines that I will examine more closely.
The quarter's gross margin was 39.2%, an increase of 100 basis points year-over-year.
Margins benefited from higher sales volumes, strategic pricing actions, and a favorable sales mix as previously mentioned.
These positive gross margin drivers were offset by a one-time network sunset provision recorded in the quarter, as well as the expected post-acquisition impact on gross margins due to amortization of the inventory fair value step-up for the s::can acquisition.
I'll dedicate extra time today to three key items: price-cost dynamics, the impact of acquisitions on margins, and the one-time network sunset provision, to help clarify their effects on the quarter and beyond, where applicable.
Regarding price-cost, as you may have noticed, copper prices, which serve as a proxy for our recycled brass input costs, have risen significantly.
Currently averaging around $3.60 per pound, this represents over a 30% increase year-over-year.
We've reminded investors that while significant, the impact of recycled brass on our cost structure has been diminishing over time as we sell more software and radios compared to primarily meters in the past.
It's also worth noting that we continue to offer polymer, mechanical, and ultrasonic meters as part of our "choice matters" go-to-market strategy.
To provide some context, if copper prices remain at this level for the entire year, it could potentially result in a cost increase of about $4 million to $5 million year-over-year.
The other side of the price-cost equation is pricing.
Similar to our approach with working capital and operating metrics like SQDC (safety, quality, delivery, and cost), we have developed more robust processes and metrics to actively manage strategic pricing for our evolving and valuable solutions offered to customers.
As a result, we have proactively implemented several strategic pricing actions that yielded a positive net benefit from price in the fourth quarter, ahead of the lagging headwind from input cost increases, primarily copper.
We anticipate being able to largely offset commodity inflation with price throughout the year, potentially experiencing some minor, manageable lag effects.
The second topic is acquisitions and their impact on margins.
s::can's results were incorporated for two months in the fourth quarter.
These two months generated about $2.5 million in revenue, as anticipated.
We noted the usual amortization of inventory fair value step-up and acquired intangible assets, which collectively resulted in a small loss for the brief period in Q4 2020.
Looking ahead to 2021, we anticipate that the integration of s::can and ATi, with total acquired revenue of roughly $37 million, will positively impact earnings per share.
The initial quarter of 2021 will encompass the remaining s::can amortization, along with a complete quarter of ATi inventory step-up amortization, but we foresee normal profitability in subsequent quarters.
Ken will elaborate on the long-term potential of these acquisitions during his presentation.
Lastly, addressing the one-time specific network sunset provision.
This pertains to the phasing out of the CDMA cellular network for early users of our initial cellular radio product.
This sunset is a carrier-driven event, part of the natural progression of technology, and affects various IoT devices across multiple industries.
As pioneers in cellular radios for water metering applications and a company dedicated to customer service, Badger Meter implemented safeguards for such situations.
Until recently, carriers' plans for sunsetting were not definitive.
Now that these plans seem more concrete, we've made this provision, which decreased gross margins in the quarter by approximately 300 basis points to cover future radio upgrades for these early cellular customers.
To be absolutely clear, there is no flaw in the radio itself.
The next logical question arises.
Will cellular radios continue to face this challenge in the future?
The brief answer is no.
The CDMA network was already well-established when Badger Meter introduced its first cellular radio.
These initial networks had been operational for nearly two decades at that point.
Subsequently, we've stayed ahead of the technology curve, as evidenced by the release of ORION LTM in 2019 and our ongoing innovation in cellular radio technologies.
These technologies will be supported by multiple generations of cellular networks.
Regarding SEA expenses, the fourth quarter's expenditure of $27.1 million was $2.3 million higher than the previous year.
This includes two months of s::can's contribution, including the resulting intangible asset amortization.
More broadly, increased personnel costs were partially offset by reduced travel, trade show, and other pandemic-affected expenses.
Incorporating both s::can and ATi in 2021, we anticipate ongoing SEA as a percentage of sales to average between 25% and 26%.
The income tax provision for the fourth quarter of 2020 was 22.6%, slightly below the previous year's rate of 24.3%.
With the additions of s::can and ATi, we don't expect a significant change in our normalized tax rate for 2021, barring any new statutory changes to the US tax code.
In conclusion, earnings per share for the fourth quarter of 2020 were $0.45, a 7% increase from the prior year's earnings per share of $0.42.
Working capital as a percentage of sales was 26%, with approximately 1% attributed to the addition of s::can.
On an organic basis, primary working capital as a percentage of sales decreased by about 200 basis points year-over-year.
Our full-year free cash flow of $80.5 million was 10% higher than the previous year's $73.2 million and represents approximately 163% conversion of net earnings.
We will maintain our focus on cash flow and anticipate free cash flow conversion to exceed 100% in 2021.
However, I caution that we don't expect to see conversion at the robust levels of the past two years, given the structural change in working capital already achieved.
We concluded the year with roughly $72 million in cash reserves after accounting for the s::can purchase
At the beginning of January, we spent $44 million, net of acquired cash, on ATi while maintaining a positive cash balance
We have sufficient financial flexibility to continue implementing our capital allocation strategies, thanks to our full access to an unused $125 million credit line
I'd like to draw attention to two transactions we've completed since our previous earnings call and explain how we believe they add significant value to Badger Meter's portfolio
s::can, acquired in November 2020, and Analytical Technology, Inc. (ATi), purchased recently, are both innovators in providing solutions for real-time water quality monitoring
This approach differs from traditional water quality testing as it captures real-time data through sensors and systems that don't rely on laboratories, reagents, or other consumables, resulting in lower costs for customers
Similar to how water utility billing evolved from manual readings to advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), we anticipate water quality monitoring will shift from lab sample testing to online real-time collection, monitoring, and reporting
Incorporating real-time water quality parameters with Badger Meter's core flow measurement, pressure, and temperature sensing capabilities expands the range of actionable data for utilities to enhance operational efficiency and for industrial customers to monitor both process and discharge water
We anticipate multiple avenues for growth synergies by integrating these two acquisitions into Badger Meter
For instance, in terms of water quality sensors, this combination provides us with a comprehensive product offering of both electrochemical and optical sensors
Geographically, ATi's strength in the US and UK complements s::can's installed base in 50 countries
In terms of scale and coverage, leveraging customer relationships, inside sales, representative networks, and distributors will enhance our ability to cross-sell throughout the water ecosystem, including water utilities, wastewater treatment, and industrial water applications
Realizing these long-term growth synergies will undoubtedly require time and investment
We need to improve our communications to capture quantity and quality data parameters via our industry-leading ORION Cellular radios
We will need to enhance BEACON and EyeOnWater to store, integrate, analyze, and visualize information, providing a comprehensive view of the water network
This is a significant undertaking, but one we are prepared to execute
In the short term, it's business as usual for the two acquired companies
The combined acquired annual sales of approximately $37 million with EBITDA margins in the mid-teens will positively impact our earnings per share
While we had hoped that entering 2021 would also mark the end of COVID-19, that is clearly not the case
Despite ongoing uncertainty, we remain fully prepared to operate safely in support of our customers in the essential water sector, as we did throughout much of 2020
There has been no significant change in customer sentiment regarding utility budgets, with spending focused on critical and necessary activities, including metering solutions required for billing and reducing non-revenue water
As we've mentioned, our large and diverse customer base will have varying needs, circumstances, and priorities
However, overall, utility water bid tenders and awards are largely proceeding with their normal processes, with limited extended timelines or deferrals
While we don't provide guidance, Bob will explain some factors that will impact us in 2021, including price/cost, SEA levels, and the expected impact of recent acquisition activity
Clearly, we experienced significant quarterly fluctuations in top-line performance throughout 2020, so growth rates that are typically uneven will be even more so during 2021
We will continue to prioritize cash flow generation, which fuels investment and growth in our business
This includes both organic and acquisition-driven growth, focusing on additional product and software offerings serving water-related markets and applications
For example, we plan to expand the functionality of our EyeOnWater software app to enhance consumer engagement
We will also continue to advance various ESG priorities, including maintaining a strong focus on employee safety, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, fostering an inclusive culture, and promoting water conservation and quality
Despite the unprecedented backdrop of a health and economic crisis, we have achieved utility water revenue growth, increased SaaS revenue as a percentage of sales to 5%, significantly expanded EBITDA margins, implemented robust working capital management and cash flow strategies, and successfully executed two accretive acquisitions
This performance highlights the critical nature of the water industry and the exceptional capabilities of the Badger Meter team
Summary:
output:
q4 sales $112.3 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $109.2 million.
q4 earnings per share $0.45.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During the call, you'll hear mentions of various non-GAAP financial measures, which we believe offer insight into the company's operations.
You can find reconciliations of non-GAAP figures to their corresponding GAAP numbers in today's materials and on our website.
Slide 3 displays our GAAP financial results for the second quarter at the top of the page.
The adjusted operating results shown below are believed by management to enhance understanding of our business by reflecting core operations' underlying performance and enabling more meaningful trend analysis.
As our release indicated, Ameriprise had another strong quarter, and I'm pleased with our performance at this point in the year.
The US environment continues to improve as the economy reopens more fully and equity markets remain robust.
Recent virus outbreaks are somewhat hindering Europe's recovery.
However, overall, there are many reasons to be optimistic as we look forward.
Considering this landscape, we are executing effectively across our businesses, promoting growth through our lower capital fee-based operations and liberating capital to create shareholder value.
We achieved another quarter of exceptional organic growth in wealth and asset management and high productivity across our system.
This included robust client flows with over $16 billion of inflows in Wealth Management and Asset Management during the quarter, and we concluded with assets under management and administration increasing 28% to $1.2 trillion, setting a new record.
Regarding recent strategic actions, we finalized the RiverSource Life's fixed annuity reinsurance transaction.
This further shifts our mix towards capital-light businesses and releases approximately $700 million of excess capital.
Our acquisition of BMO's EMEA asset management business, announced in April, is expected to close in the fourth quarter.
Let's examine our adjusted operating results for the quarter.
Business momentum continues with revenues reaching $3.4 billion, a 22% increase driven by organic growth in markets.
Earnings rose 34% excluding last year's NOL reversal, with earnings per share up 39% reflecting strong business growth and capital return, while ROE remains exceptionally high at 37.5%.
As usual, we continue to manage expenses effectively.
Let's focus on Advice and Wealth Management, where we consistently generate solid growth.
Our strategic investments remain a crucial aspect of our operations.
Clients are choosing Ameriprise for a high-quality advice experience supported by cutting-edge technology.
Client satisfaction remains high, and clients are engaging with us both personally and through our extensive digital capabilities.
Notably, our advisors are embracing our training, coaching, and powerful suite of tools fully integrated with our CRM platform, and we continue to add features, including testing a new e-meeting tool that helps advisors prepare for client meetings quickly.
Our ongoing investments in the technology ecosystem are helping advisors connect with more clients and prospects and manage their practices more efficiently.
This high level of engagement is resulting in excellent client activity, asset flows, and client acquisition.
Total client inflows increased 54% to $9.5 billion, continuing the positive trends observed over recent quarters.
In line with strong client flows, wrap net inflows were $10 billion, maintaining a very strong run rate.
Transactional activity also grew significantly, up nearly 30% from last year with good volume across various product solutions.
All this momentum, combined with positive markets, led to substantial growth in advisor productivity, up 14% when adjusted for interest rates, reaching a record of 731,000 per advisor.
In terms of recruiting, 42 experienced advisors joined us this quarter, slightly below our usual numbers.
We've heard that advisors have been focused on reopening-related matters and some postponed transitioning firms or delayed start dates.
However, people are returning to a more normal routine.
We are now hosting in-person meetings to complement our virtual recruiting, and we're optimistic about our pipeline for the third quarter.
Regarding the bank, total assets grew to $9.7 billion in the quarter, we continue to transfer additional deposits to the bank, and we've adjusted our investment strategy to extend duration somewhat.
We're also seeing increased demand for our lending solutions.
Loan volumes are steadily rising, led by our pledge product, which presents a good opportunity for future growth.
To summarize, AWM metrics and financials remain very strong.
Margin increased 380 basis points year-over-year, reaching 21.4% in the quarter, demonstrating consistent expansion since the Fed cut short-term rates a year ago.
Turning to retirement and protection solutions, results were positive and we continue to progress with our strategic initiatives.
Regarding annuities, we experienced strong variable annuity sales, with total sales up 88% compared to a year ago.
Increased customer interest in our structured variable annuity and RAVA products without living benefits drove our performance.
This trend accounted for over 66% of sales during the quarter, continuing the strategic shift we're implementing.
In the insurance sector, sales of Life and Health insurance nearly doubled, primarily due to our VUL product, which is well-suited for the current interest rate environment.
Let's turn our attention to Asset Management, where we're experiencing growth in line with our strategic plans.
Assets under management increased to $593 billion, representing a 25% rise from the previous year, fueled by strong business performance and favorable market conditions.
Our investment team continues to deliver outstanding results for clients across various strategies, with over 80% of funds outperforming the median over extended periods on an asset-weighted basis.
We saw net inflows of $6.7 billion this quarter, an increase of $4.1 billion compared to the same period last year.
When excluding outflows from legacy insurance partners, net inflows totaled $8.1 billion.
These figures build upon the positive net flows observed in recent quarters.
Global retail net inflows reached $4.2 billion, primarily driven by another strong quarter in North America.
We maintain excellent relationships with clients and intermediaries.
Sales and flow momentum is widespread, with 15 of our investment capabilities generating over $100 million in net inflows during the quarter, although retail sales in EMEA have been weaker due to a risk-averse environment.
We anticipate EMEA flows to improve in the latter half of the year as post-pandemic reopening and economic recovery progress.
In Global Institutional, we observed a significant improvement with net inflows of $3.9 billion, excluding legacy partner outflows, with wins across various strategies in North America and EMEA.
I'm optimistic about our sales pipeline.
Regarding BMO, as previously discussed, the acquisition will enhance our capabilities and expand our presence in EMEA.
The business continues to experience positive flows, and we're receiving favorable feedback from clients and institutional consultants.
As mentioned earlier, we're on schedule to finalize the deal in the fourth quarter.
Our capital management practices are exemplary.
The business continues to generate substantial free cash flow, and we're unlocking additional capital.
The approximately $700 million from our reinsurance deal essentially covers the cost of the BMO acquisition, providing us with more flexibility to return capital to shareholders at an attractive rate.
In conclusion, Ameriprise is in an excellent position.
We're performing well and achieving strong results.
Our team is expanding our client base and deepening existing relationships.
We're achieving excellent organic growth in both Wealth and Asset Management, and the BMO transaction will provide an additional growth opportunity, while we're accelerating our business mix shift through the reinsurance of the fixed annuity block.
I'd like to conclude by discussing our team.
Our employees have been returning to the office a few days a week this summer and readjusting to the environment.
It's been wonderful to collaborate in person again.
We're looking forward to a more complete return to the office when conditions are safe, while maintaining some level of flexibility.
Ameriprise delivered exceptional financial results across the company, with adjusted operating earnings per share increasing by 39% to $5.27.
We continue to demonstrate outstanding metrics, earnings growth, and margin expansion in our core growth businesses of Advice and Wealth Management and Asset Management.
Sales of our retirement and protection products increased significantly compared to last year, focusing on low-risk and higher-margin offerings.
We're already observing a shift in our in-force block and anticipate this trend to continue.
As Jim mentioned, we continued to advance our strategic priorities this quarter by expanding our growth businesses and reducing our risk profile.
We remain on track to finalize the acquisition of BMO's EMEA asset management business in the fourth quarter, which will enhance our core geographic and product capabilities in attractive and growing market segments.
Additionally, we entered into an agreement to reinsure approximately $8 billion of fixed annuities and completed the RiverSource Life transaction in early July.
As noted, we will free up approximately $700 million of capital, with a minimal projected impact on fixed annuity profitability.
In addition to the reinsurance transaction, we continue to effectively manage our risk profile by shifting our product mix towards lower-risk and higher-margin retirement and protection solutions.
Our diversified business model generates robust free cash flow and strong balance sheet fundamentals.
We returned 92% of adjusted operating earnings to shareholders during the quarter, aligning with our projected 90% target for the full year.
Ameriprise's adjusted operating net revenues and PTI showed significant growth in the quarter, demonstrating exceptional business performance.
Nearly 80% of revenue and earnings came from our capital-light businesses, AWM and asset management, marking a notable shift from the previous year, even when accounting for the unusually high earnings in RPS last year.
We continue to maintain strict control over expenses.
Given the strong business growth in the quarter, G&A expenses were well-controlled, increasing by only 6%.
We delivered another outstanding quarter, highlighting the robustness of our business model that consistently produces strong profitable growth.
Moving on to the next slide.
Advice and Wealth Management achieved excellent organic growth, with total client assets reaching $807 billion, a 28% increase.
Client flows totaled $9.5 billion, marking the third consecutive quarter of flows at or exceeding $9 billion, demonstrating consistent organic growth.
Our aim is not just growth, but profitable growth.
The quarter saw our pre-tax adjusted operating margin rise to 21.4%, up 380 basis points year-over-year and 70 basis points sequentially, despite ongoing low interest rates.
On the next page, Advice and Wealth Management's financial results were impressive, with pre-tax adjusted operating earnings of $423 million, a 56% increase.
Adjusted operating net revenues grew by 29% to 2 billion, driven by strong client flows, a 29% increase in transactional activity, and significant market appreciation.
Revenue showed a healthy sequential increase of 5%.
Ameriprise Bank continued its solid growth, reaching nearly $10 billion after adding $700 million of sweep cash to its balance sheet.
Expenses remain well-controlled, demonstrating our commitment to expense discipline.
G&A expense increased by 3%, reflecting increased activity and the timing of performance-based compensation.
We remain dedicated to managing expenses and margins carefully in the future.
Moving to the next page, Asset Management had another strong quarter, driven by exceptional investment performance and sustained inflows, resulting in outstanding financial results.
Net inflows were 8.1 billion, excluding legacy insurance partners, continuing the trend of improved solid flow.
Adjusted operating revenues increased by 32% to $879 million, reflecting the cumulative benefit of net inflows and market appreciation.
Revenues increased by 6% sequentially.
Our fee rate remained strong at 52 basis points, reflecting the momentum we're seeing across both equity and fixed income strategies.
Expenses were well-managed and in line with expectations given the revenue environment.
G&A expenses grew by 12%, mainly due to the timing of compensation expenses related to strong business performance, foreign exchange translation, and higher volume-related expenses.
As with AWM, we will continue to manage expenses carefully going forward.
Pre-tax adjusted operating earnings grew by 79%, and we achieved a 45% margin.
We anticipate strong financial performance to continue, with margins expected to remain in the mid-40% range in the near term, driven by current robust equity markets.
Turning to the next page, Retirement and Protection Solutions continued to perform as expected in this environment.
Pre-tax adjusted operating earnings were $182 million.
Sales increased significantly compared to the pandemic-affected prior year, surpassing pre-COVID levels and resulting in higher distribution expenses.
The prior year's earnings were positively impacted by lower surrenders and withdrawals due to the pandemic.
We continue to reduce our risk profile by increasing sales of retirement products without living benefits.
Retirement sales increased by 88% during the quarter, with two-thirds of sales in products without living benefits.
This has shifted the overall book, with only 62% of our block now having living benefit riders, down over 200 basis points from a year ago.
In Protection, sales nearly doubled, with a significant increase in higher-margin VUL and a substantial decline in IUL.
This shift in product mix for both Retirement and Protection is expected to continue.
Moving to the final slide on the balance sheet.
Our balance sheet fundamentals remain extremely strong, including a $3 billion liquidity position at the parent company and $2 billion in excess capital, not including the capital release from the recently announced fixed annuity transaction.
Adjusted operating return on equity for the quarter remained strong at 37.5%.
We returned $585 million to shareholders through dividends and buybacks and are on track to return 90% of adjusted operating earnings to shareholders for the year.
Summary:
