input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Brady Corporation reserves all rights to this teleconference and prohibits unauthorized rebroadcasting.
Your involvement in the Q&A portion indicates your agreement to be recorded.
Despite challenges from COVID-19, inflation, and logistics issues, Brady's team performed admirably.
The team's ability to navigate difficult economic conditions and deliver results for customers and shareholders is commendable.
Sales grew by an impressive 16% this quarter, with earnings per share increasing by 4.7%.
Excluding amortization effects, earnings per share rose even more significantly at 9.1%.
Along with strong revenue and earnings growth, we maintain a robust financial position.
We distributed over $30 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases this quarter.
Our net cash position remains strong at over $90 million.
The WPS division experienced a 7.8% decline in sales.
This decrease was primarily due to challenging year-over-year comparisons.
Last year, our WPS team excelled in providing COVID-related products to customers.
The demand for these items, including social distancing signs and personal protective equipment, has since decreased, leading to difficult comparisons.
A more accurate assessment of our WPS business involves comparing current sales to pre-COVID levels in fiscal 2020, which shows growth.
Our Identification Solutions division continues to deliver exceptional results, with 25.4% sales growth and 21.2% segment profit growth.
Excluding amortization expenses, segment profit would have increased by an impressive 26.4%.
The Identification Solutions division remains a strong and high-performing segment of our business.
Moving forward, our main objectives are to drive organic sales growth and maintain excellent customer service despite logistical challenges.
We aim to implement necessary cost and pricing measures to counteract inflationary pressures and restore pre-pandemic gross margin levels.
We're also focused on integrating recent acquisitions and strategically deploying capital to enhance long-term shareholder value.
In our ID Solutions division, we're increasing R&D investments, including those needed to maximize benefits from recent acquisitions.
Our historical focus on R&D is yielding results, with an accelerated rate of new product launches and widening the gap between us and competitors who lack similar resources for R&D investment.
We're enhancing our online presence by upgrading websites and investing in digital marketing talent while expanding our sales force and geographical reach into underserved markets.
We're implementing significant automation improvements in our factories and distribution centers, which is crucial during a time of labor scarcity and rising costs.
Our strong product lineup, sales-driving investments, and efficiency improvements give us confidence in continued strong organic sales growth and healthy margins for our ID Solutions division in fiscal 2022 and beyond.
In our Workplace Safety division, we're leveraging our common web platform to quickly adapt to market changes using improved market intelligence.
We've boosted investments in new product development and increased the pace of product launches to raise the percentage of high-value proprietary products sold, which will positively impact profit margins.
We're significantly increasing advertising spend and headcount in certain underperforming areas to drive future revenue growth.
These investments led to reduced segment profit this quarter but are expected to increase revenues as the fiscal year progresses.
Our Workplace Safety division is on the right track, and I'm confident that our recent changes and investments will foster long-term sales and profit growth.
While investing in organic sales growth, we're also working to streamline our SG&A cost structure to fund sales growth initiatives while reducing overall SG&A expenses.
We're focused on becoming a more efficient manufacturer through automation wherever possible.
In addition to driving organic sales growth and improving organizational efficiency, we're actively integrating three acquisitions completed in the fourth quarter of last year, including expanding our industrial track and trace solutions.
Much of the increased R&D spending is related to investments needed to develop a comprehensive solution that will help us enter faster-growing markets and accelerate sales growth in the coming years.
I'm confident we'll continue to see revenue growth in future quarters.
However, we're experiencing inflationary pressures across various cost categories, from wages to freight to raw materials, and we've faced challenges in securing certain products, including chips and select items sourced from Asia.
Generally, we've overcome these shortages, but it has resulted in increased freight charges due to more frequent use of air freight.
Despite these inflationary pressures, our gross profit margin remained a strong 48.2%, matching the fourth quarter of last year.
However, our cost increases haven't been sufficient to fully offset rising expenses, resulting in a year-over-year gross margin decline of about 70 basis points.
Consequently, we're implementing additional price increases across many product lines to catch up with rapidly rising costs.
We believe these gross margin challenges are temporary and expect to return to our historical gross margin levels of nearly 50% in the near future.
Despite the challenging logistical environment, Brady is well-positioned for the remainder of this fiscal year and beyond.
I'm confident in our ability to deliver results for our customers, employees, and shareholders.
I'll now provide specific commentary on our Identification Solutions and Workplace Safety businesses.
Let's begin the financial review with slide number 3.
First quarter sales reached $321.5 million, a 16% increase compared to the same quarter last year, while GAAP pre-tax earnings rose 5.8% to $44.7 million.
Earnings this quarter were impacted by a significant increase in amortization expense from acquisitions completed at the end of last year.
Excluding amortization expense from all periods, our pre-tax earnings would have increased by 11.3% to $48.5 million.
GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.67, a 4.7% increase over last year's first quarter.
Excluding amortization expense, earnings per share would have increased by 9.1% to $0.72 this quarter, compared to $0.66 in the first quarter of last year.
Overall, Q1 was another strong quarter financially, despite the logistical challenges and inflationary pressures mentioned earlier.
Moving to slide 4, you'll see our quarterly sales trends.
Our 16% sales increase comprised 7% organic sales growth, an 8.3% increase from acquisitions, and a 0.7% increase from foreign currency translation.
Organic sales growth in our ID Solutions Business was a robust 13.2% in Q1.
Our Workplace Safety business faced tough comparables due to strong COVID-related product sales in last year's first quarter.
As a result, we saw a decline in WPS organic sales of 8.6% this quarter.
Comparing our sales levels to the pre-pandemic period (first quarter of fiscal 2020), our total sales are up 12% over pre-pandemic levels.
By division, Identification Solutions is 15.6% above pre-pandemic levels, while Workplace Safety is 1.2% above.
This strong performance against both last year and pre-pandemic periods is a direct result of our ongoing investments and the sales momentum we developed just before the pandemic hit.
If you look at slide 5, you'll notice the trend in our gross profit margin.
Our gross profit margin decreased slightly from 48.9% in Q1 last year to 48.2% this quarter.
As Michael pointed out, we're experiencing inflationary pressures and challenges in recruiting for manufacturing positions.
However, we're implementing automation, improving efficiency, and selectively raising prices to address these issues.
Slide 6 shows the trend in our SG&A expenses.
Our SG&A expenses rose from $83 million in Q1 last year to $96.7 million this quarter.
The increase in SG&A was largely due to expenses from three acquisitions completed near the end of last year and higher amortization costs.
Amortization expenses increased from $1.4 million in Q1 last year to $3.8 million this quarter.
As a percentage of sales, SG&A remained relatively stable at 30.1% this quarter compared to 30% in Q1 last year.
Excluding amortization expenses, SG&A as a percentage of sales actually decreased from 29.5% last year to 28.9% this year.
Slide 7 displays our R&D investment trends.
We invested $13.9 million in R&D this quarter.
We're dedicated to increasing our R&D investments as we see opportunities in our core business and in developing a comprehensive industrial track and trace platform.
These R&D investments are crucial for driving Brady's long-term sales growth and maintaining our gross profit margins.
Slide 8 shows our pre-tax income trends.
Our pre-tax earnings grew by 5.8% on a GAAP basis and by 11.3% when excluding amortization expenses.
Slide 9 illustrates our after-tax income and earnings per share trends.
Our GAAP earnings per share increased by 4.7%, from $0.64 in Q1 last year to $0.67 this quarter.
Excluding the after-tax impact of amortization, our earnings per share would have grown by 9.1%.
Slide 10 provides a summary of our cash generation.
We generated $27.5 million in cash flow from operating activities and $16.2 million in free cash flow this quarter.
While our underlying cash flow was strong, we deliberately invested in inventories and capital expenditures.
We purchased two previously leased manufacturing facilities for $7.6 million, which were ROI positive investments.
We also increased our inventories by about $30 million over the last six months to prioritize customer service and product availability.
Despite returning over $30 million to shareholders through dividends and buybacks, increasing capital expenditures, and boosting inventory levels, we still maintained a net cash position exceeding $90 million as of October 31.
Our robust balance sheet positions us well for additional value-enhancing activities, including R&D investments, acquisitions, and shareholder returns.
Our capital allocation strategy remains unchanged and continues to serve us well.
We prioritize funding organic sales and efficiency opportunities throughout economic cycles, including investments in new product development, sales resources, IT improvements, and automation.
We also focus on returning cash to shareholders through dividends, having increased our annual dividend for 36 consecutive years.
After funding organic investments and dividends, we deploy cash for synergistic acquisitions or share buybacks when we perceive a disconnect between intrinsic value and market price.
Slide 12 outlines our guidance for the fiscal year ending July 31, 2022.
We maintain our full-year diluted earnings per share guidance, excluding amortization, at $3.12 to $3.32 per share.
On a GAAP basis, our guidance remains at $2.90 to $3.10 per share.
This guidance includes an increase in after-tax amortization expense of about $6 million, from $5.5 million in fiscal 2021 to $11.5 million in fiscal 2022.
We expect short-term gross profit margin challenges to persist through Q2, which is typically our lowest quarter.
We anticipate increased benefits from pricing actions and efficiency projects in Q3 and Q4, with the majority of earnings-per-share growth expected in these quarters.
We project total sales growth to exceed 12% for the full year, including both organic growth and growth from recent acquisitions.
We'll continue to invest in organic sales growth, seek strategic acquisitions, and drive efficiency gains while controlling non-revenue-generating expenses.
Our capital allocation strategy includes ongoing investments in our organic business and industrial track-and-trace initiatives, returning funds to shareholders through dividends and opportunistic buybacks, and pursuing acquisitions with clear strategic fit and appropriate pricing.
We bought back $18.9 million worth of shares last quarter and will continue to leverage our strong balance sheet to drive long-term shareholder value.
Potential risks to our guidance include strengthening of the US dollar against major currencies, worsening logistics affecting customer commitments, and further inflationary pressures that we cannot offset quickly enough.
Slide 13 presents the Q1 financial results for our Identification Solutions (IDS) business.
IDS sales grew by 25.4% to $248.6 million, comprising 13.2% organic growth, 11.6% acquisition growth, and 0.6% from foreign currency translation.
Organic sales in IDS were strong compared to both Q1 last year and previous sequential quarters.
Our focus on sustainable efficiency gains partially offset input cost increases.
Segment profit as a percentage of sales decreased slightly from 20.3% to 19.6% year-over-year.
Excluding the increase in amortization, segment profit as a percentage of sales would have increased from 21% to 21.1%.
Regionally, organic sales in Asia showed strong growth, exceeding 15% compared to Q1 last year.
For the fourth consecutive quarter, Asian organic sales have grown by over 10%.
Despite ongoing lockdowns in most of the first quarter, EMEA's organic sales increased by more than 15%.
Our European team excelled in driving sales growth while managing interruptions caused by lockdowns.
The Americas experienced nearly 12% organic sales growth.
We observed growth across all product lines and regions during the quarter, with particular satisfaction in the healthcare product line's recovery, showing approximately 11% organic sales growth.
Overall, sales trends and concepts are highly encouraging.
We continue to prioritize our commitment to research and development.
We've increased our investments to develop a comprehensive industrial track and trace solution.
While we're likely two years away from a complete track and trace solution, we're already seeing positive synergies from recent acquisitions, which we expect to increase due to complementary product portfolios and more complete offerings from Code, Magicard, and Nordic ID.
These acquisitions are exceeding expectations and provide valuable technologies that enhance our product range and increase Brady's value to customers.
We're allocating considerable resources to our track and trace product offerings.
However, we're not neglecting R&D investments in other areas like printers and materials.
We've maintained our consistent introduction of new printers by releasing the J4300 Brady Jet Label Printer.
This inkjet printer, combined with highly efficient proprietary materials, balances safety and compliance label complexity with industrial environment demands.
Our industrial inkjet printers help customers save time by quickly creating durable, high-quality labels, signs, and tags for safer, more efficient workplaces.
Brady's combination of top-tier printers and high-performance materials distinguishes us from competitors, ensuring crucial information remains visible and secure in any environment.
In essence, Brady's printers and materials are designed for optimal performance in the most challenging conditions.
Our R&D pipeline is robust, and we continue to introduce innovative solutions that help customers solve problems and improve efficiency and effectiveness.
I'm enthusiastic about our ID Solutions business developments and how the acquisitions of Code, Nordic ID, and Magicard will further boost our growth.
We're enhancing customer service, investing in our future, and optimizing our cost structure.
These positive revenue trends, coupled with strong cost discipline, will help counteract inflationary pressures and create a promising outlook for our IDS division.
Slide 14 provides a summary of Workplace Safety's financial performance.
WPS sales decreased by 7.8%, comprising an organic sales decline of 8.6% and a 0.8% increase from foreign currency.
This sales decline was mainly due to challenging comparisons with last year's first quarter.
Our WPS business performed exceptionally well during the pandemic last year, supplying customers with numerous COVID-19-related products, but demand for these items has significantly decreased since then.
This quarter's WPS sales of $72.9 million surpassed pre-pandemic levels from the first quarter of fiscal 2020.
Despite periodic shutdowns, our European WPS team excelled in expanding its customer base.
For customers who initially purchased COVID-related products, our team successfully introduced them to our core safety and identification products.
Our Australian business performed similarly to our European operations.
During the pandemic, our Australian business grew organic sales by over 10% in last year's first quarter.
Considering the challenging comparisons, we were pleased with this quarter's sales volumes, which exceeded pre-pandemic levels.
We've expanded our Australian customer base over recent quarters and continue to find ways to enhance our digital marketing approach to retain new customers and convert them into long-term repeat clients.
North American sales of COVID-related products also declined this quarter, and this decrease was not fully offset by our non-COVID product offerings, resulting in a decline in organic sales in the Americas.
As mentioned earlier, we've invested in improving certain underperforming WPS businesses, including our US operation serving micro businesses.
We've incurred start-up costs for a new US facility, invested in personnel, and increased advertising spending.
These incremental investments totaled approximately $2.5 million.
While these investments negatively impacted WPS profitability this quarter, we believe they are crucial for achieving sustainable, long-term profitable growth in our WPS business.
In addition to these investments, our WPS business experienced gross margin compression due to raw materials, freight, and wage inflation.
Like our IDS business, we're taking steps to counter these cost increases.
WPS segment profit was $2.3 million, compared to $8 million in last year's first quarter.
This profit reduction was directly related to decreased sales volumes, the incremental investments mentioned, and significant cost pressures.
Our WPS team members are attentive to customer needs, modifying marketing campaigns to reach new customers and industries, and working diligently to address underperforming businesses within the portfolio.
Our Workplace Safety business faces one more quarter of moderately difficult comparisons, but we're establishing a foundation for a strong recovery.
I'm proud of Brady's role in the ongoing fight against COVID-19.
Identification Solutions and Workplace Safety products assist companies with social distancing.
Our products help schools reopen safely, and our safety and identification products are used by frontline workers worldwide.
Now, our products are helping customers increase efficiency to meet their own customer demands.
The pandemic is not over, and its financial impacts persist.
Throughout the pandemic, we've invested in growth and efficiencies, and this continuous investment will enable us to maintain our strong positive momentum.
Brady is in a favorable financial position.
We've achieved record earnings per share.
Our earnings are up, and our balance sheet is robust.
We maintain a net cash position even after completing three acquisitions last year and returning over $30 million to shareholders through buybacks and dividends this quarter.
We will continue investing in R&D, sales-generating resources, and capacity-enhancing capital expenditures, while tightly controlling non-revenue-generating expenses and addressing global logistical issues and inflationary pressures.
I'm very proud of our team's performance during this challenging period.
Their ability to handle uncertainty, think creatively, and solve problems quickly, all while maintaining a long-term perspective, has built a solid foundation for Brady's future.
Let's now begin the Q&A session.
Operator, please provide instructions to our listeners.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'll begin by discussing the environment and economy before delving into our financial results.
In the past three months, three significant events have occurred that have reduced uncertainty, which is always beneficial.
The most important development from last year was the vaccine's release in November, which is now being administered.
The election uncertainty we faced previously has been resolved.
We also received a stimulus package, which, while less significant than the other two events, is still positive news.
We hadn't anticipated a stimulus being approved until the new administration took office.
I'm pleased it was passed a few weeks ago.
Looking ahead to 2021, it appears to be a year with strong potential in the latter half, possibly starting as early as the second quarter.
However, I anticipate a slow first quarter as the positive news needs time to translate into reality.
The main risk remains vaccine distribution and, to some extent, new coronavirus variants.
There is still some uncertainty, but significantly less than 90 days ago.
We feel confident as we prepare our budget for the year.
We've assumed a slow first quarter, which is typical for us, but this year will be particularly slow for the reasons I mentioned.
We expect the pipeline to grow and our growth strategy to begin implementation in the second quarter, with full execution in the second half of the year.
Reflecting on this quarter, I'm pleased with our results of $0.89 per share or $85.7 million in earnings.
This is an improvement from $0.70 last quarter.
Compared to the fourth quarter of 2019, which seems like a long time ago, we earned $0.91 per share.
Considering what we've been through this year, it's impressive to be so close to our fourth quarter 2019 earnings per share.
Net Interest Income was approximately $193 million, which is $6 million more than last quarter and about $8 million more than the fourth quarter of 2019.
Pre-Provision Net Revenue decreased by $10 million compared to last quarter but showed a slight increase compared to the fourth quarter of the previous year.
Leslie will explain some unique items in the expense category, mainly related to compensation.
We significantly reduced our variable compensation accrual in the second and third quarters.
We've adjusted it upwards, though not completely, as variable compensation will still be lower than in previous years, but not as low as we were accruing in the second and third quarters.
We also made a policy change to provide rollover paid time off to our employees due to the current circumstances, which cost a couple million dollars.
The main story continues to be deposit generation and deposit costs.
We had another strong quarter.
Total cost of deposits decreased by 14 basis points.
We were at 57 basis points last quarter and ended this quarter at 43 basis points.
Our spot cost of funds as of December 31 was 36 basis points.
We're starting this quarter at 36 basis points and expect to decrease from there.
I'm confident that this quarter will be another strong one in terms of reducing cost of funds.
I believe we'll end up in the low 30s and on a spot basis, I'm confident we'll end up with a two handle.
Our average non-interest-bearing demand deposits grew by $966 million, which is very strong.
I always emphasize that one quarter doesn't establish a trend.
It's best to look at four-quarter averages or 12-month numbers to get a true sense of business performance.
However, no matter how you analyze it, the last four quarters, or even just the last quarter, have shown very strong performance in deposits.
Our non-interest-bearing demand deposits now represent over 25% of total deposits.
A year ago, we were at 18%.
We still have more work to do and expect this trend to continue into next year, with the goal of slowly working towards 30% non-interest-bearing demand deposits.
As we predicted, risk rating migration has slowed significantly.
In the first nine months of 2020, there was downward rating migration on $2.1 billion in loans.
This quarter, it was only $169 million.
Provisioning decreased substantially.
In fact, we had a small net recovery of $1.6 million.
We had reported $3.6 billion in loans on deferral during the summer.
That number has now decreased to $207 million, or about 1% of total loans.
We have $587 million in loans that were modified under the CARES Act.
These modifications don't appear as Troubled Debt Restructurings (TDRs) under the CARES Act.
Most of these modifications are interest-only modifications for 9 to 12 months.
Many of these modifications are in the Commercial Real Estate (CRE) and hospitality portfolios, particularly hotels.
We believe we've identified most borrowers who will need temporary relief or deferral at this point.
Non-performing loans increased slightly to $244 million, which is about 1.02% of loans.
Excluding government-guaranteed SBA loans in this category, it's about 80 basis points.
In our Commercial and Industrial (C&I) sub-segment, non-performing loans actually decreased.
The net charge-off rate remained stable at 26 basis points for the year.
Regarding Net Interest Margin (NIM), it was 2.33% for the quarter, a slight improvement from 2.32% last quarter.
Total loans grew by $87 million, and deposits increased by $899 million, of which $219 million was non-interest-bearing demand deposits.
These are end-of-period numbers, whereas earlier I provided average demand deposit figures.
Book value has increased to $32.05, higher than $31.33 at this time last year.
Our capital position is strong.
The board met yesterday and reinstated our share buyback program.
We had about $45 million left in the program, which has now been unfrozen.
The board wants us to complete this before discussing additional repurchases.
Our Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio is 12.6% at the holding company level and 13.9% at the bank level.
We declared our usual $0.23 per share dividend.
Regarding our return-to-work strategy, not much has changed.
We're still working remotely and expect to continue doing so for at least the next two or three months before reassessing.
We've had more COVID-19 cases in the company this quarter compared to previous quarters, but none severe enough to impact our operations.
Looking forward, we're eagerly anticipating increased economic activity and our participation in the next business cycle, which seems to be starting now.
Our focus remains on building a relationship-based commercial bank serving small and middle-market businesses.
We'll continue to emphasize building core business through non-interest-bearing demand deposits, identifying niche markets that larger banks overlook, and investing in technology and innovation rather than just branches and locations.
The focus has shifted to technology and solving customer pain points through innovation.
We haven't forgotten about our 2.0 initiatives.
It wasn't just a temporary exercise but aimed at changing our culture, which we'll continue to push forward.
We launched a new initiative called iCARE (Inclusive Community of Advocacy Respect and Equality) earlier last year.
This has been in development since last summer and was announced internally about two and a half months ago, receiving positive feedback.
It represents our organizational effort to build a culture that celebrates and intentionally promotes diversity within the bank.
This is not just rhetoric.
We are taking concrete actions to back up our words and implement initiatives.
We believe that if everyone contributes even a small amount towards positive change, it can collectively make a significant societal impact.
This initiative has us very enthusiastic.
Our staff members are eager about this project and there will be more developments to come.
Allow me to check something.
I'll hand it over to Tom now.
He will provide more details on the business aspects before Leslie delves into the financial figures.
Let me begin by discussing deposits and providing more information about our deposit portfolio.
As Raj stated, total deposits increased by $899 million this quarter, with non-interest-bearing demand deposits growing by $219 million.
The composition of our deposits continues to improve.
We allowed higher-cost deposits to decrease this quarter, continuing a trend from previous quarters, as time deposits fell by $1.1 billion.
Let me provide more details about our funding costs.
The total cost of funds plus cost of deposits decreased to 43 basis points this quarter.
At the end of December, the annual percentage yield on total deposits was 36 basis points, down from 49 basis points at the end of September and 142 basis points a year ago.
We continue to make progress in this area.
The rate on interest-bearing deposits was 48 basis points as of December 31, compared to 65 basis points on September 30 and 171 basis points a year ago.
We're observing reductions in deposit costs across all business segments and products, which is a widespread trend.
As of December 31, 2020, we had $1 billion in certificates of deposit with an average rate of 1.61% that hadn't been repriced since the last Federal Reserve rate cut in March 2020.
In the first quarter of this year, a significant portion of that, just under $800 million, will be repriced.
Additionally, some CDs that matured and were repriced early in the cycle will be repriced downward again at their next maturity date.
There's a substantial difference between these rates and our current rates, which are around 25 basis points.
We currently see strong pipelines and opportunities for core deposit growth across all business lines.
It's more challenging to estimate deposit pipelines and the timing of new treasury management relationships, but we expect continued growth in non-interest-bearing demand deposits at current levels.
We'll likely see more time deposits decrease while the overall composition of the portfolio continues to improve.
Some maturing CDs are moving into money market accounts, but at significantly lower rates.
Regarding loans, as Raj mentioned, total loans grew by $87 million in the fourth quarter, while operating leases decreased by $13 million.
To provide more details on specific segments, the residential portfolio increased by $408 million in the fourth quarter, with $330 million of that in the Ginnie Mae EBO segment.
The mortgage warehouse sector continued to perform well.
Total commitments grew by $90.5 million for the quarter, ending the year at slightly over $2.1 billion in mortgage warehouse commitments, making the entire quarter and year very strong in this area.
Overall, commercial real estate loans decreased by $89 million for the quarter, with multi-family loans declining by $171 million, of which $151 million was in the New York market.
Beyond that, we saw expansion in other real estate business segments.
When looking at loans and operating leases in the Business Finance Group, including both franchise and equipment, we saw a decrease of $124 million this quarter due to COVID-19's impact, particularly on the franchise portfolio.
We've focused on portfolio management and exposure reduction rather than new production over the last few quarters.
Looking ahead to 2021 and breaking down our expectations for different business lines:
We anticipate continued strong growth in Ginnie Mae EBO and mortgage warehousing businesses.
We expect the Commercial and Industrial business to return to more normal growth as the economy improves and vaccines are distributed, projecting high single-digit growth for 2021, mainly in the latter half of the year.
We forecast a low single-digit decline in Commercial Real Estate for 2021.
We still have concerns about valuations in certain portfolio segments, with hotel and retail sectors likely facing challenges for much of this year.
We expect good growth in small business lending in 2021, having invested significantly in technology and time to expand this area.
In the franchise sector, we anticipate continued runoff, probably around 20% in 2021, as we work through that portfolio.
Pinnacle is expected to decline slightly, in the mid-single digits, but this could change if corporate tax rates are adjusted, given the current competitive landscape from an interest perspective.
Regarding the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), the overall process is going well.
We're in the forgiveness stage for 3,500 loans made in the first round, which is proceeding smoothly.
About 700 loans have been forgiven so far, and we expect this to continue in the first quarter of 2021.
We're participating in the Second Draw program for eligible businesses that received First Draw PPP loans, which recently opened and will be available to clients in that phase.
We're expecting about 50% to 60% of clients from the First Draw to request Second Draw loans.
Overall, the PPP process is progressing well.
Regarding loans with granted deferrals, I'd direct you to slide 16 in the supplemental deck for more details.
Starting with commercial loans, only $63 million were still under short-term deferral as of December 31.
$575 million of commercial loans had been modified under the CARES Act.
Combined, this totaled $638 million, or approximately 4% of the total commercial portfolio as of December 31.
As expected, the Commercial Real Estate Hotel segment was most impacted, with $343 million or 55% of the segment modified as of December 31.
Most of our hotel exposure is in Florida, primarily in leisure properties, which we expect to rebound sooner.
We've seen occupancy rates improve in recent months, and surveys suggest companies are returning to business travel.
While our hotel portfolio isn't focused on business travel, we anticipate overall travel markets improving as we progress through 2021.
In the franchise sector, 8% or $46 million of the portfolio was on short-term deferral or had been modified as of December 31, compared to $76 million or 12% on short-term deferrals as of September 30, and 74% that were granted initial 90-day payment deferrals.
$48 million or 67% of our cruise line exposure has been modified under the CARES Act as of December 31.
Nearly 80% of total commercial deferrals and modifications and almost 60% of loans rated substandard or doubtful are from portfolio segments initially identified as needing heightened monitoring due to potential pandemic impacts.
These same segments continue to be the focus of this activity, and we don't currently see significant difficulties arising in other segments.
For residential loans, excluding the Ginnie Mae early buyout portfolio, $144 million are on short-term deferral, with an additional $12 million modified under longer-term CARES Act repayment plans as of December 31.
This represents about 2% of the residential portfolio.
Of the $525 million in residential loans initially granted payment deferrals, $144 million or 27% are still on deferral, while $381 million or 73% have rolled off.
Of those that have rolled off, $362 million or 95% are now making regular payments, with only 5% or $19 million not resuming a regular payment program.
To clarify, when we refer to loans modified under the CARES Act, we mean loans excluded from modifications other than short-term deferrals, which would likely be classified as Troubled Debt Restructurings (TDRs) if not for the CARES Act.
Most of these have taken the form of 9 to 12 months interest-only deferrals.
As Raj mentioned, we're still seeing good overall rent collections in the office market.
Depending on the location, we're seeing about 90% collection rates in New York and 97% in Florida.
Multi-family collections are at 90% in New York and about 96% in Florida, while larger retail loans are seeing collection rates in the low 90% range.
Regarding hotel occupancy in the Hospitality segment, all our Florida properties are now open, as are two of the three properties in New York.
In Florida, we continue to see improvements in occupancy, with an average rate of about 46% for the quarter.
December is typically a stronger travel month in Florida, and we're entering the peak season.
In December, we saw occupancy rates as high as 60% in some areas, but generally in the upper 40s to low 50s range.
The Hotel segment is gradually showing some improvement.
More details are needed about what's happening in the franchise and fitness spaces.
Concepts with significant drive-through and delivery capabilities tend to be performing well.
Popular quick-service restaurant concepts like pizza and chicken are doing very well, with many posting double-digit same-store sales increases.
In-dining concepts are still facing challenges and showing weakness.
Some segments are mixed depending on whether locations have delivery-based economic models or are situated in malls.
Overall, the franchise area is seeing improvement.
The fitness sector has made progress since our previous update.
Nearly all our stores are now open, except for those in California, particularly around Los Angeles.
Approximately 90% of our stores are currently operational, though not all at full capacity.
This is the highest rate of openings we've seen since the pandemic began.
Out of our 280 stores, 90% are open, with California being the main exception.
This provides a good overview of the situation in the restaurant and fitness sectors.
Let's begin with the popular topic of CECL and the reserve.
The provision for credit losses this quarter was a net credit or recovery of $1.6 million, compared to a $29.2 million provision last quarter.
This $1.6 million included a $1.2 million provision for funded loans and a $2.9 million recovery related to unfunded commitments.
The allowance for credit losses (ACL) decreased from 1.15% to 1.08% of loans this quarter, mainly due to charge-offs, which is expected under CECL.
Slides 9 through 11 of the supplemental deck provide details on reserve changes and the composition of the provision and allowance.
Charge-offs totaled $18.8 million for the quarter, reducing the reserve.
$13.8 million of this was related to marking down loans that were sold or moved to held for sale at quarter-end and sold in January.
A $34.1 million decrease in the reserve and provision was due to improved economic forecasts.
This was offset by a $32.8 million increase related to specific reserve increases and risk rating migration.
We reduced qualitative overlays by $11.4 million, which is expected as more information about individual borrowers becomes available and is incorporated into quantitative modeling.
There was also a $15.2 million increase due to more conservative modeling assumptions for certain residential borrowers who had been on payment deferrals.
The lower reserve percentage also reflects the larger proportion of Ginnie Mae EBO mortgages in total loans, which carry virtually no reserve.
Key economic forecast assumptions include national unemployment at about 6.7% for Q1 2021, remaining stable through the year and trending down to 5.4% by the end of 2022.
Real GDP growth is expected to reach 4.1% in 2021 and 4.7% by the end of 2022.
The S&P 500 Index is forecast to remain relatively stable around 3,500, with the Fed funds rate staying near zero into 2023.
The franchise finance portfolio has the highest reserve level at 6.6%, followed by CRE at 1.5% and C&I at 1.3%.
The residential portfolio's reserve remained relatively stable quarter-over-quarter, with reductions from improved economic forecasts offset by changes in modeling assumptions.
Risk rating migration details are provided on slides 23 through 26 of the deck.
We saw additional downward migration this quarter, though at a slower pace, as expected.
The largest categories of migration to substandard accrual were in CRE, specifically hotel, multi-family New York, and retail segments, along with some cruise line credits.
In franchise, the level of criticized and classified assets actually declined, but some fitness concepts moved from special mention to substandard.
Non-performing loans increased by about $44 million, with the largest increases in multi-family, residential (as some loans failed to resume regular payments after deferral), and a small amount in franchise finance fitness.
The investment portfolio's fair value mark continued to recover, now showing a net unrealized gain of $85.6 million, with no expected credit losses.
The net interest margin (NIM) increased by 1 basis point to 2.33%, with the yield on earning assets declining by 12 basis points, a smaller decrease than the previous quarter.
The cost of deposits decreased by 14 basis points quarter-over-quarter, with nearly $800 million in time deposits set to mature and reprice lower in Q1.
We adjusted variable compensation accruals by $6.6 million due to better-than-expected operating results in the second half of the year.
A $2.2 million accrual was made for rollover vacation time due to the COVID pandemic.
There was also an increase in accruals for RSU and PSU awards resulting from the stock price increase.
Looking ahead to 2021, we expect mid-single digit loan growth, concentrated in the second half of the year, excluding PPP loan runoff.
We anticipate mid-single digit deposit growth, with mid-teens non-interest DDA growth as we continue to optimize the portfolio mix.
The NIM is expected to increase for the year, with a boost in Q1 from PPP forgiveness, which should largely be a first-quarter event.
Provisions should be modest if economic forecasts remain stable, with higher provisions in the second half as loan growth picks up.
We expect net charge-offs to exceed provisions for the year, leading to a reduction in reserves.
Non-interest income is expected to increase in deposit service charges and commercial card revenue, with lease financing income stabilizing after a decline in Q1.
Expenses are projected to increase by mid-single digits, mainly due to compensation and technology-related costs.
The tax rate is expected to be around 25%, excluding discrete items, assuming no change in the corporate tax rate.
Approximately 3 million dividend equivalent rights will expire in Q1 2021, adding $0.02 to $0.03 per quarter to EPS.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The current discussion is being streamed on our company website, atimetals.com.
Bob Wetherbee, President and CEO, along with Donald Newman, Senior VP and CFO, are joining us for this call.
We won't be using visual aids during Bob and Don's presentation today.
They will concentrate on key points and main takeaways.
Additional information and specifics about our performance and outlook can be found in the slides available on our website.
It's an understatement to call 2020 a difficult year, particularly for those in the commercial aviation sector.
Despite these obstacles, our dedicated ATI team continues to meet the challenge, guided by the strategic priorities we set at the beginning of the pandemic.
We're focusing on controlling what's within our power, thus speeding up cost reductions and improving our position.
Our robust financial position enables us to withstand upcoming challenges and support our expansion.
Let's start with our current situation.
Our close customer relationships continue to provide us with real-time insights into market conditions.
This gives us the confidence to make crucial decisions, adjusting our cost structures and inventory levels to match changing demand expectations.
We've acted decisively and swiftly to restructure ATI for the future.
Our third quarter financial performance significantly surpassed our earlier projections due to these proactive measures.
We fast-tracked benefits from our cost-cutting initiatives through aggressive implementation.
This included reducing capacity, shutting down facilities, and minimizing fixed and variable costs through restructuring programs, aligning expenses with demand declines, and trimming overhead.
We've meticulously reviewed all administrative and non-production related expenses, maintaining only what was essential.
Overall, we've greatly increased the flexibility of our cost structure.
Expenses previously considered fixed can now be adjusted in line with demand, giving us substantial control over our costs.
This will have a lasting impact from the actions we've taken during this crisis.
Throughout all of this, our employees have been remarkable.
They're prioritizing each other's safety while efficiently delivering critical materials and components to our customers.
The frequent production adjustments we've made in response to demand shifts and market forecasts have been challenging for them.
Work schedules and shift patterns have fluctuated as a result.
I deeply appreciate the entire team's effort, dedication, and personal economic sacrifices.
Their ongoing actions demonstrate a shared commitment to ATI's future success.
The deliberate steps we've taken and will continue to take are vital to our ability to emerge as a stronger company as the economy recovers.
Looking ahead, we're confident demand will eventually rebound.
We expect these challenging times to persist for several quarters, but we believe we're nearing the bottom with some signs of upcoming stability.
Now, let's discuss our balance sheet and the strong position it puts us in.
We've worked hard to ensure adequate liquidity levels and a manageable debt maturity schedule.
Our robust financial position gives us confidence to navigate the COVID crisis and fuel our future growth.
We're driving growth in three ways: investing capital based on customer commitments to enable strategic market share gains and new business awards starting in 2021, organically expanding our presence in adjacent high-value markets where our expertise is valued, and pursuing acquisitions when the time and economics are right to rapidly build scale, expand capabilities, and capture profitable core market opportunities.
As we achieve our growth objectives, we'll strengthen our presence in aerospace and defense materials and components.
We'll continue leveraging our material science capabilities and advanced process technologies to generate aerospace-like margins in adjacent markets.
Looking forward, we're confident that demand for commercial aerospace products will recover.
We see it as growth delayed, not lost.
Regardless of the shape of the economic recovery, whether it's V, U, or L-shaped, it's difficult to predict the timeline when you're at the bottom.
But we know we'll get there.
We're positioning ATI to emerge stronger, leaner, and more efficient, regardless of how the recovery unfolds.
Here are some examples of how we're doing this.
We're expanding our presence in growth markets like defense.
We have strong positions in adjacent markets that are likely to recover faster than commercial aerospace and can generate similar profitability.
Finally, our efforts to reduce costs and streamline our manufacturing footprint while investing in growth will yield long-term benefits.
As expected, our Q3 sales across most markets were negatively impacted by the ongoing pandemic and resulting economic downturn.
Defense continues to be a notable positive exception.
Let's provide more details on our expectations for the future.
We'll begin with the commercial aerospace sector.
There was a significant decrease in both jet engine and airframe compared to the previous year.
Overall sales dropped by 60% in Q3, due to well-known factors such as quarantines, travel limitations, and reduced 737 MAX production.
Rapid reduction of jet engine customer inventories in the short term will better match future production with demand.
Jet engine product sales in Q4 will remain relatively low as quarantines slowly ease.
Specialty materials will likely experience a delay for a couple more quarters.
API sales for airframe applications will remain low for the rest of 2020 and likely throughout 2021 as the effects of announced future wide-body production rate reductions impact the supply chain.
In 2021, ATI will benefit from increased engine market share and new airframe contracts.
The positive impact of these gains will grow as aerospace industry volumes recover.
Our second primary market, defense, continues to be a source of strength.
Excluding titanium armor, ATI's diverse defense sales increased by over 20% year-over-year, led by growth in naval nuclear and military aerospace sectors.
Titanium armor plate sales decreased significantly due to timing issues for both domestic and international programs.
We are investing resources to accelerate growth in the defense market, using our material science capabilities and advanced process technologies to develop and produce materials and components for power and protection.
In the short term, we anticipate continued growth in Q4 and into 2021.
Now, let's discuss my thoughts on three important related end markets.
Q3 sales decreased significantly in the energy and medical markets but increased in electronics.
In the energy sector's oil and gas submarket, we observed a lack of end-customer demand and resulting inventory surplus, reducing exploration and downstream processing activities worldwide.
We expect this market to remain weak in Q4.
A positive aspect within energy is the specialty energy submarket, including solution control, nuclear, and renewables.
These sales grew compared to the previous year.
We anticipate the specialty energy market to continue outperforming larger hydrocarbon-based markets in Q4, primarily driven by large international pollution control projects.
Our medical market primarily consists of biomedical implants and MRI materials.
Sales compared to the previous year were lower for customers in both categories, mainly due to challenges presented by COVID.
Patients postponed elective surgeries and hospitals restricted access for equipment suppliers.
Looking ahead, we believe medical sales will increase as patients regain confidence to return to medical facilities, either due to an effective COVID vaccine or improved disease treatment protocols.
Lastly, electronic sales increased compared to the previous year.
This is primarily due to ongoing consumer goods production supporting new product launches and year-end holiday sales.
We anticipate modest growth trends to continue in Q4.
I will now share highlights in three key areas: our better-than-expected Q3 financial performance, our strong balance sheet and cash position, and our expectations for Q4 and 2021.
Regarding performance, the adjusted earnings per share loss of $0.38 in Q3 is significantly better than our previous guidance of a loss between $0.62 and $0.72 per share.
Our Q3 performance reflects accelerated cost reductions and an improved mix in certain parts of our business.
First and foremost, we are managing decisively.
We are maximizing external demand despite market challenges, and we're controlling what we can: our costs and capital deployment.
Consider this: our Q3 revenue decreased by over 40% compared to the previous year, including a 60% decline in our high-value commercial aerospace business.
The revenue drop was largely due to market factors beyond our control.
When market declines became apparent earlier this year, we responded quickly, focusing on cost containment.
The benefits of these efforts are evident in our Q3 results.
Despite the 40% drop in revenue, we posted a 25% year-over-year decremental margin in Q3.
This is a significant improvement from the 28% decremental margins in Q2, showing clear progress resulting from quick action.
Our cost-cutting measures are having a meaningful impact and are accelerating.
As Bob described, we have significantly variabilized our cost structure.
Costs once considered fixed are now variable.
This means we are better prepared to handle future demand fluctuations.
Also, remember that structural cost savings will accelerate profitability during recovery, expanding margins and increasing our cash conversion.
Looking beyond the income statement, our efforts to preserve free cash flow are also producing results.
We expect to be free cash flow positive in 2020.
This is made possible through capital spending discipline and our ability to convert working capital into cash.
Swift measures were implemented to safeguard cash in the short term while maintaining growth potential and readiness for recovery.
The quarter concluded with total liquidity of about $950 million, including $572 million in bank cash.
Our debt maturity schedule further reinforces our financial standing.
The next significant debt repayment isn't due until 2023, three fiscal years from now.
We're concentrating on three key areas to generate cash: cost structures, inventory levels, and capital expenditure.
Anticipate ongoing emphasis on these three aspects in 2021 as we adjust our operations to match fluctuating market demand.
Simultaneously, we'll continue to safeguard our robust balance sheet.
These strategies will allow us to navigate the downturn and seize opportunities during the upcoming upturn.
Regarding future prospects, we foresee increasing stability in commercial aerospace demand for the fourth quarter.
This begins with jet engine manufacturers working to better align production with demand.
Airframe manufacturer inventory reduction is expected to continue in the fourth quarter.
Outside of aerospace, some industrial markets are showing slight recovery.
Others, particularly oil and gas, are likely to remain at low levels.
Consequently, we predict a fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share loss between $0.36 and $0.44, comparable to our third quarter's adjusted EPS.
Shifting to our free cash flow forecast.
Our persistent efforts to generate and conserve cash have yielded concrete results.
We decreased managed working capital by $115 million in the third quarter during the severe economic downturn.
We anticipate further inventory reductions in Q4.
Just as the team swiftly pivoted to cost reductions, we adjusted our capital expenditure to better match demand.
To that end, we're once again lowering our capital spending target for the entire year.
Our revised capex forecast range is $125 million to $135 million, about 60% of the initial 2020 projections.
We're increasing our full year 2020 free cash flow expectations to a range of $135 million to $150 million before pension contributions.
We can achieve this due to successful improvements in working capital, capex, and cost structures, a remarkable achievement in a highly challenging environment.
Looking past the fourth quarter, we will remain vigilant to maintain or even improve upon the gains we made in 2020.
Firstly, we believe working capital presents an opportunity for additional cash flow improvement.
At the end of the third quarter, managed working capital was approximately 50% of revenue.
This contrasts with 30% at the end of 2019.
We know what's required to return to those 2019 levels, and we intend to make further improvements in 2021.
Next, we'll continue to closely monitor our capital spending.
We'll balance the need to fund growth and enhance manufacturing efficiency with ongoing lower demand levels.
Lastly, we will maintain discipline in cost management.
We will carefully preserve our structural reductions and minimize additions as volumes return to the business.
Our current operational approach differs fundamentally from our previous methods.
We will strive to maintain these hard-earned gains.
Your observations were accurate.
It's been a genuine team effort during highly uncertain times, and we greatly appreciate the contributions of everyone at ATI, our customers, and our suppliers.
Our remarks today focused on what's most important to our shareholders and to us.
These priorities are central to our daily leadership approach.
Firstly, we're managing decisively in times of significant market uncertainty.
This includes swiftly and effectively adjusting our cost structures and inventories to match demand, while ensuring our people's safety.
Secondly, we're conserving cash and maintaining liquidity.
We're preserving our ability to deploy cash profitably for our shareholders.
We'll be ready for recovery, capitalizing on industry volume growth as well as our strategic share gains and new business awards.
Finally, we're collaborating with our customers, both new and long-standing, who value our material science capabilities and advanced process technologies.
Our aim is to be crucial to their success, helping them grow, tackling even greater challenges together, and in doing so, earning an ever-increasing share of their business.
We're taking necessary actions to emerge from this crisis as a stronger, leaner, and more focused ATI.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted loss per share $0.38 excluding items.
expect q4 to be negatively affected by the ongoing pandemic.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm accompanied by our CEO Scott Santi, Vice Chairman Chris O'Herlihy, and CFO Michael Larsen.
We'll discuss ITW's Q1 2020 financial performance and how the global pandemic is affecting our business and our response strategy.
Clearly, the operating environment has changed significantly compared to most of Q1.
I'll briefly comment on our Q1 results before moving to our pandemic strategy.
We often mention that our decentralized entrepreneurial culture is a crucial part of ITW's success.
This is fundamental to our identity as a company and proves especially valuable during times of major, rapid change.
Our team's proactive collaboration, creativity and selflessness in quickly adapting to fast-changing conditions and addressing new daily challenges exemplifies ITW at its best.
While we expected our ITW team to respond this way, their performance is still remarkable.
Regarding Q1 results, overall revenue fell 9% year-over-year, with organic revenue down 6.6%, currency impact of -1.5%, -1% from divestitures, and 0.4% from price/cost.
Most of the organic revenue decline occurred in late March, with organic revenue dropping over 20% in the final two weeks.
Geographically, North America declined 5%, Europe 7%, and China 24% for the quarter, though China seems to have bottomed in February and was flat year-on-year in April.
We continued to execute well on factors within our control despite challenging demand.
Though revenues fell 9%, operating margin held steady at 23.6%, with 5 of 7 segments expanding margins, largely due to enterprise initiatives contributing 120 basis points to operating margin.
After-tax return on invested capital was 27% and free cash flow reached $554 million, converting 98% of net income.
Let's now discuss how we'll manage ITW through the global pandemic.
Despite unusual and sometimes unprecedented challenges, we continue to execute at a high level with our typical focus and discipline across the company.
Due to our work implementing our enterprise strategy over the past 7 years and progress towards our full potential, ITW is well-positioned to handle the pandemic's effects.
Today's ITW centers on our powerful proprietary business model, with our people more skilled than ever at executing it.
ITW's 80/20 methodology and laser focus on key performance drivers in each business has served us well in good times and bad for many years.
I'm confident this unique ITW capability will be a major asset as we navigate the COVID-19 pandemic and its aftermath.
As mentioned, we benefit greatly from our long-standing decentralized structure and entrepreneurial culture.
Our people think and act like owners, take accountability, and deliver results.
They are deeply trained in our model, strategy and values. Even in unprecedented times, they don't wait to be told what to do.
We've worked hard to shape our portfolio and drive consistent high-quality execution across all businesses, positioning ITW for steady top-tier long-term earnings growth in favorable conditions while building in margin cushion and diversification for resilience in tougher times.
Our strong margins and unique business model attributes generate robust free cash flow. Combined with disciplined capital allocation, this gives us an extremely strong balance sheet and top credit ratings.
With this foundation, our pandemic management strategy focuses on four priorities: 1) Protect our colleagues' health and well-being, 2) Maintain excellent customer service, 3) Preserve financial strength, liquidity and strategic flexibility, and 4) Leverage ITW's strengths to fully participate in the recovery.
Chris will expand on priorities 1 and 2, Michael on priority 3, and I'll cover priority 4.
This is a challenging time as the world grapples with the pandemic's impacts. We've all been affected in unimaginable ways. ITW as a company and community is certainly impacted.
That said, our divisional leaders' owner mindset allows quick reactions to protect our people and serve customers - a key advantage in major challenges.
To protect our colleagues, we implemented practices to minimize COVID-19 exposure and spread, following CDC, WHO and local guidelines.
Our teams redesigned processes for social distancing, adjusted schedules for those with childcare needs due to school closures, and implemented aggressive cleaning and sanitation.
We're fully compensating quarantined employees. Our sourcing team is coordinating PPE procurement to protect all employees.
Our containment efforts have largely limited infections to isolated cases at a minority of locations, demonstrating our colleagues' commitment to safety practices.
Regarding customer service, our teams have worked hard to keep factories safely operational. Most ITW businesses are designated as critical/essential where shelter-in-place orders exist.
Some directly support COVID-19 response: our welding equipment makes hospital beds, structural products build temporary medical facilities, test & measurement products check medical equipment, Polymers & Fluids sanitize workplaces, and food service equipment feeds hospital patients.
Other businesses are critical for supporting vital industries.
They are crucial for the well-being and economic vitality of our societies.
While some facilities face mandatory closures, approximately 95% of our worldwide manufacturing capacity remains operational to serve our clients.
We are maintaining full availability of our service networks, especially in food equipment and test and measurement, to ensure support for essential businesses and healthcare facilities.
Across all divisions, we continue to deliver industry-leading performance in product and service quality and availability.
We are actively managing our supplier relationships to address immediate supply risks for vital materials and components, and to position ourselves for success in various recovery scenarios.
The primary goal of our enterprise strategy, developed over the past seven years, has positioned ITW with substantial financial strength to handle highly disruptive events like this global pandemic.
ITW is designed to thrive in challenging times like these.
Throughout the pandemic, we will maintain our financial strength, liquidity, and strategic flexibility to capitalize on our solid financial foundation and resilient profitability during the recovery phase.
ITW possesses ample financial strength and resilience to endure the economic shock the global economy is experiencing over the coming months.
We are ready for this challenge.
We will overcome it.
We will emerge strongly positioned for the recovery.
Based on our current assessment one month into the quarter, we anticipate Q2 revenues to decrease by 30% to 40% compared to last year.
There is considerable uncertainty about how May and June will unfold, but this is our present outlook.
This projection is unsurprising, given that most of our automotive OEM customers in North America and Western Europe have been essentially inactive since mid-March and are only beginning to resume production in early to mid-May.
Our automotive OEM division will likely be the most severely impacted, with potential revenue declines of 60% to 70% year-over-year.
Such a sudden and significant decline in quarterly revenue is almost unheard of.
Despite the challenging outlook, we expect ITW to generate an operating profit of $200 million to $400 million, produce over $500 million in free cash flow, and conclude Q2 with approximately $1.5 billion in cash on hand.
With our financial strength ensuring our ability to weather the coming months, our top priority becomes positioning ourselves to take advantage of the recovery.
Our robust margin profile gives us a significant advantage in this area.
The pace of recovery, whether rapid or gradual, V-shaped or U-shaped, doesn't significantly impact our performance over the next few quarters.
In a rapid recovery scenario, we might end the year down 15% with margins of 19% to 21%.
In a slower recovery, revenues could be down 25%, but our margins would still be a strong 17% to 19%.
This contrasts with many of our competitors who entered the pandemic with margins at half of ours or less.
Consequently, some may need to make significant cutbacks to survive the pandemic, potentially creating opportunities for us to gain market share during the recovery.
Our strong margin cushion allows us to be less concerned about the speed of demand recovery in Q3 or Q4.
We can be fairly confident it will improve from Q2, but beyond that, it doesn't greatly affect our strategy.
This enables us to think long-term and position ourselves for maximum participation in the recovery.
Ensuring we can fully support our customers as their businesses begin to accelerate and capitalizing on opportunities to take market share from struggling competitors are central to our pandemic response planning across all divisions.
We will need to make strategic adjustments to capacity and cost structures in businesses where we anticipate prolonged recovery periods or permanent demand impacts from the pandemic.
As always, we will entrust these decisions to our divisional leaders, who are best positioned to assess the recovery trajectory in their respective markets.
Moving to slide 11.
The financial advantages of our enterprise strategy, combined with our efforts to optimize capital efficiency, structure, and allocation over the years, have put ITW in a very strong position entering this crisis.
At the end of the quarter, we had over $1.4 billion in cash and cash equivalents on hand.
This remains true as of today.
We currently have virtually no short-term debt and have not issued any commercial paper.
The reason is simple: we don't need the cash.
We have access to a $2.5 billion undrawn credit facility if needed in the future, bringing our total liquidity to around $4 billion at present.
Our net leverage is only 1.7 times, and our next debt maturity is a relatively small $350 million, not due until September 2021.
High-quality earnings and strong free cash flow are hallmarks of ITW.
We consistently generate more cash than needed for internal purposes, with our annual conversion rate from net income consistently exceeding 100%.
We expect this trend to continue as we navigate the pandemic.
Our Tier 1 credit ratings, the highest in our peer group, demonstrate our continued excellent access to credit markets if needed.
It's worth noting that our pension plans remain in excellent condition during this period of market volatility.
We have consistently funded and de-risked our plans over the years, and our largest U.S. plan is currently funded at 104%.
Moving to slide 12.
Let's discuss how we're adjusting our capital allocation approach during the pandemic.
First, regarding the dividend.
We acknowledge the significance of ITW's dividend to our long-standing investors.
Our dividend has a lengthy track record, growing for over 56 years.
We're among a select few companies known as dividend aristocrats, one of about 18 firms that have raised their dividend for more than half a century.
The dividend is considered a crucial element of ITW's overall shareholder return strategy.
From 2012, we've raised the annual dividend from $1.52 per share to the current $4.28 per share, representing a cumulative yearly growth of 16%.
To put it simply, we remain deeply committed to our dividend and currently don't foresee any scenario where we'd need to reduce it.
Regarding strategic flexibility, we're in a strong position with substantial balance sheet capacity.
We're open to potential opportunities that may arise due to the pandemic.
These could include more reasonably priced assets we were already interested in, as well as unique chances with quality companies that might struggle financially during the pandemic.
Our financial strength and ample resources put us in an advantageous position to act on any high-quality strategic opportunities that may emerge.
We will continue to fully finance all internal investments and capital expenditure projects meeting our criteria, as always, but the total spending will likely decrease in the short term due to reduced need for capacity expansion in the coming quarters.
It's unsurprising that we've halted share repurchases until market conditions stabilize and the recovery path becomes more evident.
Our fourth priority involves leveraging our strengths to ensure all our businesses are well-positioned to fully participate in the recovery.
In essence, we aim to meet all our customers' needs as their businesses start to accelerate and be prepared to seize any market share opportunities that may arise.
The food equipment sector performed well with 2% organic growth year-over-year, despite a challenging comparison to 5% organic growth the previous year.
The service business showed solid performance, increasing by 4% in the quarter.
Equipment growth of 1% reflects double-digit growth in retail and a slight decline in institutional and restaurant sectors, compared to strong performance in the previous year.
Operating margin increased by 90 basis points to 27.5%, primarily due to enterprise initiatives.
The test and measurement and electronics sector had a very strong quarter, with test and measurement up 6% and 13% growth in our Instron business.
The segment also saw a significant increase in demand from semiconductor customers.
Electronics grew by 2%.
The highlight was the margin, as the team expanded operating margins by 330 basis points to a record 28.1%, the highest in the company this quarter, driven by strong contributions from enterprise initiatives and volume leverage.
During the quarter, we also divested an electronics business with approximately $60 million in 2019 revenues.
Despite an unprecedented demand contraction in Q2, as Michael mentioned earlier, we will still generate operating income in the hundreds of millions of dollars and over $500 million in free cash flow.
We will carefully manage discretionary expenses, but we don't need to immediately start cutting into our core operations.
We want to avoid doing so before we have some indication of the recovery pattern and pace in each of our businesses.
With this principle in mind, we are currently providing full compensation and benefits support to all ITW colleagues worldwide.
We aim to maintain this level of support for all our employees at least through the end of Q2.
We're doing this because we're able to support our people during a time of great personal and family stress and uncertainty.
We believe it's the right thing to do.
We're also doing it to protect the significant investment we've made in training and developing excellent ITW employees and leaders over the past seven years.
As Michael mentioned, we may need to make some staffing adjustments to align with prolonged or permanently lower demand in some of our businesses due to the pandemic.
We are committed to supporting all our employees during the worst of this crisis, and we will take time to make any necessary long-term adjustments thoughtfully.
Our second principle is to lean into potential upside by maintaining our investment in structure to capture additional demand.
Given the profitability of our core businesses and our strong financial position, we believe the greater risk for ITW would be carrying extra costs for a few months rather than cutting too much and being unable to fully serve our customers' needs and gain market share from competitors as the recovery accelerates.
We plan to execute our recovery strategies accordingly.
The third principle is to leverage ITW's strengths to protect investments in areas of strategic importance for our long-term strategy.
We're in the early stages of planning for these areas.
As an example, before the pandemic, we invested over two years in our strategic sales excellence initiative, including significant investments in new sales and sales leadership talent.
We have the financial capacity to protect these types of long-term strategic investments.
Doing so is more valuable to the company in the long term than a few extra percentage points of margin in the short term.
That said, decremental margins should likely be in our normal 35% to 40% range in Q4.
Until then, we'll focus on ensuring ITW is well-positioned to fully participate in the recovery.
This serves as a reminder that our long-term strategic priorities remain unchanged, and we are committed to achieving and sustaining ITW's potential performance, aiming to establish ITW as one of the world's best-performing, highest-quality, and most respected industrial companies.
At present, it's impossible to predict the severity or duration of this crisis, or how quickly our customers and markets will recover.
What I can say is that the strength and resilience of ITW's business model and our people put us in as strong a position as an industrial manufacturing company can be to handle whatever unfolds in the coming weeks and months.
I'm confident that ITW will overcome these challenges, as we have throughout our 108-year history.
Our strong financial position and margin profile allow us to make strategic moves now to position the company for full participation across various recovery scenarios, and to emerge ready to continue our path towards ITW's full potential performance.
For reference, please consult the appendix in today's slide deck for the usual segment details from the first quarter.
Summary:
output: illinois tool works inc - suspending previously announced annual guidance for 2020.
