input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These convictions are vulnerable to recognized and unrecognized hazards and ambiguities, many of which may be outside our influence, including those detailed in our regular SEC reports.
Kindly be aware that the company's actual outcomes may diverge substantially from those projected, and we assume no responsibility to revise these declarations.
He will offer an overview of our plan and notable events from the previous quarter.
And Karen Holcom, senior vice president and chief financial officer, who will guide us through our earnings results.
There will be a chance for questions and answers at the conclusion of the call.
For those taking part, please restrict your comments to one inquiry and one follow-up, if needed.
Our group delivered another robust performance in the second quarter of fiscal 2022.
For the second consecutive quarter, we achieved net sales growth of 17%, and we sustained our gross profit margin at 41.7%, in line with the first quarter.
And in comparison to last year, we boosted diluted earnings per share by 22%.
Despite the cost challenges, we managed to transform our sales growth into operating profit and net income by efficiently leveraging operating expenses.
The global situation remains complex.
While our demand environment is robust, costs continue to fluctuate, and we are constantly dealing with the ongoing pressures stemming from the global component shortages.
Despite this, our team continues to perform well, and this is reflected in our results.
Both ABL and Spaces are performing exceptionally well.
Our decisions to prioritize shipments by investing in electrical components and transportation are yielding higher sales and operating profits, albeit at slightly lower margins.
Now, I'd like to discuss our progress at both ABL and Spaces.
First, regarding ABL, I'm pleased to report that some things are returning to normal.
In March, we hosted our first in-person sales conference in three years, NEXT '22.
It was wonderful to reunite with our independent sales network, who have performed remarkably through the ups and downs of the past two years.
We have the finest agents in the industry, and it was an excellent opportunity to discuss our strategic vision for Acuity Brands Lighting, introduce many new products, and engage our agency partners around our EarthLIGHT initiative.
This was the first time many of our associates and agents had seen each other in person since the pandemic began.
While we have been incredibly productive working virtually with our channel, it was great to spend quality time together face-to-face.
It was impossible not to be impressed by the levels of energy and enthusiasm throughout the event and the consistency of the feedback from our agents.
They stated, "Acuity is delivering".
Our investments in service have allowed us to prioritize fulfilling our customers' needs when others have been unable to.
Simultaneously, our investments in product vitality have enabled us to continue creating compelling new products that are both innovative and market-moving.
As I mentioned last quarter, we have achieved this by focusing on three main areas.
Firstly, by concentrating on strategic supplier relationships, the current environment has reminded us all that it truly matters who you do business with.
As the largest lighting company, we have certain advantages over our direct competitors.
However, those same components are also used by larger industries.
As a result, we are investing in people, time, and resources.
We have recruited a new head of strategic sourcing for ABL.
We are collaborating with our key suppliers on effective planning and allocation management, and we are investing in inventory.
Secondly, by empowering our teams to prioritize access and speed over cost on available components, we have been able to ensure continuity of supply across many of our existing product lines, while also supporting our ongoing product vitality efforts across our product portfolio.
Lastly, as I mentioned last quarter, our engineering teams continue their extraordinary efforts to redesign products to work with available components.
At the same time, these teams have also managed to introduce around 220 new, or significantly upgraded, lighting and lighting control products over the past two years.
We anticipate that the challenges surrounding access to and costs of components will persist into the foreseeable future.
Our strategy regarding product vitality and the adaptability of our engineering teams in responding to the changing requirements of the component shortages have been a significant factor in why we are leading in this market, and we expect to continue these efforts.
Another highlight of the NEXT conference was our focus on EarthLIGHT.
EarthLIGHT is a crucial part of our strategy.
Our efforts to enhance product vitality extend beyond merely improving functionality.
We're also focused on redesigning products to lower customer energy usage, minimize packaging and waste, and enhance transportation efficiency.
This term, we unveiled a new initiative combining technology and sustainability to drastically reduce paper consumption by implementing scannable QR code instructions across our product line.
At NEXT, we expanded our community involvement by assembling a thousand food packages for an Atlanta-based organization alongside our agents.
This activity was a standout moment of the event.
Turning to the Intelligence Spaces Group, Spaces experienced another quarter of robust growth.
Both Distech and Atrius have a promising product pipeline aimed at making Spaces more intelligent, secure, and environmentally friendly.
Distech continues to outperform strong competitors in the building controls market.
With its ECLYPSE Controller products, Distech is leading technological advancements, maintaining a presence in crucial markets and recognized leadership founded on open-protocol technology.
Distech secured projects throughout North America and Canada last quarter, with notable wins in key sectors including education, commercial infrastructure, and data centers.
Distech has now become a primary supplier for two major cloud service providers.
We're still developing the Atrius platform, making progress on Atrius Building Insights, and plan to expand the portfolio in the future.
We continue to bring new talent to this team.
I'd like to provide an update on our capital allocation strategy.
Our priorities for capital allocation remain unchanged.
We plan to continue prioritizing investments for growth in our existing businesses, pursue acquisitions, maintain our dividend, and allocate capital to share repurchases when we see an opportunity to create lasting value for our shareholders.
This quarter, our board of directors approved additional capacity for share repurchases, increasing our remaining authorization from 3 million to 5 million shares.
Since May 2020, we've bought back about 13% of our outstanding shares.
I'm pleased to announce the appointment of Sachin Sankpal as our senior vice president of growth and transformation.
Sach will oversee our technology organization, implement our better, smarter, faster company operating system, and spearhead integration efforts for future acquisitions.
Sach brings distinguished experience from leading companies like Trimble and Honeywell.
We're thrilled to have Sach join our team.
Every quarter presents new challenges, but our team consistently delivers.
Our ongoing focus on service and product vitality allows us to capitalize on the strong demand environment.
I'm consistently impressed by their adaptability and ability to drive results.
We achieved strong performance in the second quarter of 2022.
We increased net sales.
We effectively managed margins despite a volatile cost environment.
We also leveraged our operating expenses.
Net sales reached $909 million, a 17% increase compared to the previous year.
This performance was driven by our emphasis on service levels and product vitality, continued recovery in both business segments' end markets, and the benefits of recent price increases and acquisitions.
Gross profit totaled $379 million, an increase of $43 million or 13% over the previous year.
This improvement was driven by revenue growth and by offsetting significant input cost increases through price adjustments and product and productivity enhancements.
Gross profit as a percentage of sales was 41.7%, a decrease of 170 basis points from 43.4% in the previous year, but unchanged sequentially from the first quarter of 2022.
I'll discuss the current cost environment in more detail later in the call.
Reported operating profit was $102 million, an increase of $11 million or 12% over the previous year.
Reported operating profit margin was 11.3% of net sales for the second quarter of fiscal 2022, a decrease of 40 basis points compared to the previous year.
Adjusted operating profit was $123 million, an increase of $14 million or 13% over the previous year.
Adjusted operating profit margin was 13.5% of net sales, a decrease of 50 basis points compared to the previous year.
Adjusted operating profit margin was lower than the previous year, as the decline in gross profit margins was partially offset by leveraging operating expenses.
In the second quarter of fiscal 2022, we observed ongoing enhancement in diluted earnings per share.
The diluted earnings per share reached $2.13, showing a rise of $0.39 or 22% compared to the previous year.
The adjusted diluted earnings per share climbed to $2.57, indicating an increase of $0.45 or 21% from the year before.
Our program for repurchasing shares positively affected the adjusted diluted earnings per share by $0.06.
Let's now examine our individual segments.
In the quarter, sales in our Lighting and Lighting Controls segment rose by 17% to $863 million compared to the previous year.
This growth was primarily due to improvements in our independent sales network, which expanded by about 12%, and a 5% increase in our direct sales network.
Furthermore, the corporate account channel experienced a sales increase of approximately 105% compared to the previous year.
It's worth noting that last year, customers had suspended their renovation projects due to the pandemic.
As evidenced by this quarter's growth, that activity has now resumed.
We also saw an 83% increase in our other channel compared to the previous year, mainly because of the OSRAM acquisition.
The retail channel experienced a sales decline of about 2% in the current quarter.
This decrease was caused by delays in inventory transit or port holdups, resulting in longer than expected lead times.
We anticipate seeing growth in this channel in the coming quarters.
ABL's operating profit for 2022's second quarter reached $117 million, a 14% increase from the previous year, though the operating margin decreased by 30 basis points to 13.5%.
The adjusted operating profit of $127 million showed a 13% improvement compared to the previous year, with the adjusted operating profit margin dropping by 50 basis points to 14.7%.
ABL has shown its capability to increase sales while optimizing operating expenses.
Now, let's look at the performance of our Intelligent Spaces Group.
In the second quarter of 2022, Spaces sales grew by about 16% to $50 million, reflecting growth in both Distech and Atrius.
Spaces operating profit in the second quarter of 2022 increased by approximately $400,000 to $1.2 million.
The adjusted operating profit of $6 million rose by about $1 million compared to the previous year, due to strong sales growth and ongoing business investments.
Our business model continues to be highly efficient, generating $127 million in net cash flow from operating activities in the first half of fiscal 2022.
This represents a decrease of $85 million compared to the previous year, primarily due to increased investment in working capital, particularly related to inventory.
Inventory days have increased since the end of our fiscal year, with about half of the increase attributed to longer lead times for sourced finished goods, and slightly less due to increased purchases of electronic components.
We are managing our inventory levels to support our growth and protect our production facilities from inconsistent supply availability.
We also invested $24 million, or 1.3% of net sales, in capital expenditures during the first six months of fiscal 2022.
We have continued to buy back shares in the second quarter.
Since May 2020, we have repurchased approximately 13% of our company shares at an average price of about $120 per share.
I'd like to discuss our expectations for the rest of the year.
We anticipate the current environment to persist for the foreseeable future, with strong demand but ongoing challenges in component access and cost.
Our focus will remain on increasing sales and optimizing our operating expenses.
Regarding the recent instability in Europe, we have no direct sales exposure to Russia or Ukraine.
However, the conflict does exacerbate existing supply chain pressures.
We are also experiencing rising transportation costs due to expected increases in oil prices.
In the past 15 months, we have strategically implemented six price increases alongside driving product and productivity improvements.
Before concluding, I want to emphasize our key points.
We have consistently demonstrated strong sales growth and effective management of gross margins in a volatile cost environment.
We have optimized our operating expenses.
Lastly, we have continued to allocate capital effectively.
Summary:
output:
q2 earnings per share $2.13.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $2.57.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Please limit your questions to one per person, as suggested by the operator.
This approach will ensure maximum participation during our allotted time.
We're grateful for your interest in Vulcan Materials and hope you and your loved ones remain safe and in good health.
I'd like to start by noting that our first-quarter performance was an encouraging beginning to the year.
Our markets are seeing improved demand, and our team performed well, as reflected in our financial outcomes.
Adjusted EBITDA, not including the profit from selling our reclaimed California quarry, reached $244 million, showing a 22% increase from the previous year.
This impressive growth was partially due to a 3% rise in aggregate shipments.
Although weather affected Texas and parts of the Southeast in February, we saw an uptick in shipments, with March being particularly strong.
Home construction is speeding up, and highway projects have also increased due to improved contract awards in the third and fourth quarters of last year.
We've noticed an increase in both the number of projects and the pace of shipping in the heavy nonresidential sector, which uses the most aggregates.
Additionally, some projects that were delayed last year have now begun.
With improvements across our operating areas, pricing was the second factor in our EBITDA growth.
Freight-adjusted aggregates pricing grew by 2% during the quarter.
When adjusted for mix, the increase was 1.3%.
This was anticipated as we were fulfilling contracts bid during the pandemic when there was uncertainty and limited visibility on demand.
As our 2021 price increases take effect, we expect to see pricing improvements throughout the year.
The third factor in EBITDA growth, which we have the most control over, was our outstanding cost management during the quarter.
Aggregate total cost of sales per ton was 2% lower than the first quarter of last year.
Cash cost of sales per ton decreased by 3%.
Achieving such cost control requires significant discipline from our operators.
The team focused intensely on operational efficiency.
Consequently, all of our operational metrics in the quarries improved compared to last year.
We were pleased with the significant impact of our four strategic disciplines, which will continue to develop.
The most impressive metric remains our strong unit margin gains across all locations.
Aggregates cash gross profit per ton increased by 9%.
This demonstrates the attractive operational profitability of our aggregates business when demand is combined with strong execution of our four strategic disciplines.
Overall, our operational results this quarter helped improve our return on invested capital by 90 basis points.
Suzanne will provide more details on this and other aspects of our financial performance.
Let's now discuss our view of the end markets and how that influences our outlook for the full year.
Generally speaking, the demand environment has improved significantly over the past few months.
Construction starts, as measured by Dodge, improved along with other leading indicators like the Dodge Momentum Index and ABI.
Construction employment levels also continue to rise.
Residential construction remains the strongest end market.
There is unmet demand for houses and new subdivisions are being constructed with more planned.
Economic conditions, including low interest rates and limited supply, indicate continued market growth.
Vulcan-served markets are experiencing faster growth in housing construction.
The future of our nonresidential markets remains uncertain.
However, increased quote requests and improving leading indicators suggest a market turnaround is underway.
E-commerce and technology-related construction, such as data centers and warehouses, represent the strongest nonresidential sector.
Dodge reports that 90% of this sector's growth will occur in markets served by Vulcan.
While most non-residential projects currently fall into this category, we anticipate that a robust housing market and reopening economy will stimulate demand in other nonresidential areas.
Highway-related state budgets and project lettings are progressing as expected.
Improved lettings from late 2020 are now translating into increased shipments.
COVID-19 relief funds have safeguarded against potential losses in transportation revenue for highway projects.
Our national leaders continue to work on developing an infrastructure package.
Both major political parties have proposed significant increases in highway funding, making it a priority for Democrats and Republicans alike.
In summary, our assessment of end markets indicates improving demand.
We're observing this improvement both through our customer interactions and in data from leading indicators.
Consequently, we've revised our 2021 aggregates volume growth forecast to between 1% and 4% compared to 2020.
Excluding the California property sale gain, we now anticipate full-year adjusted EBITDA to range from $1.38 billion to $1.46 billion.
Looking ahead, we have three avenues for growth with higher returns: organic growth, mergers and acquisitions, and greenfield developments.
Organic growth is crucial to our strategy, offering the most attractive value proposition when adjusted for risk.
We possess the industry's best geographic footprint and operators, but we continually strive for improvement.
Our four strategic disciplines aim to accelerate this organic growth strategy, with clear benefits in increasing our unit profitability.
We consistently evaluate an active list of potential M&A targets.
The M&A market, which was largely inactive last year, has become active again this year.
We have an extensive track record of successfully completing both large and small acquisitions that align with our strategic goals.
Since 2014, we've finalized over two dozen value-enhancing acquisitions in some of the nation's fastest-growing markets.
We also have a long history of successfully developing and launching new aggregate sites.
This strategy allows us to strategically locate aggregate reserves in growing areas where acquisition opportunities are unavailable.
Additional advantages include greater control over capital investment timing and avoiding premium payments for assets.
We prefer maintaining a balance between organic and inorganic growth.
This approach provides significant flexibility and plays a crucial role in our capital allocation process and our ability to improve return on invested capital.
I'd like to begin by emphasizing four key areas for consideration this quarter.
Our unit analyzes profitability growth, investment returns, financial stability, and the sale of land in California.
The gross profit per ton for our aggregates increased 12% to $4.82.
Enhancing operational profitability at existing sites typically requires minimal capital investment compared to other growth strategies.
Substantial value is generated when improvements are sustainable and widespread across operations.
Our strategic approach is yielding results, and we have demonstrated consistent execution.
Our gross profit per ton has grown at a compound annual rate of 7% over the past three years.
Return on invested capital is the second crucial area.
As mentioned earlier, the 90 basis point improvement this quarter raised our return to 14.8% for the 12-month period ending March 31.
While higher returns are always beneficial, the method of achieving improvement is equally significant.
For instance, the first quarter's ROIC gain consisted of a 1% increase in invested capital and a 7% rise in adjusted EBITDA.
This further emphasizes the importance of the previously discussed unit profitability.
Over the past three years, our trailing 12-month ROIC has risen by 280 basis points, driven by a 4% compound annual growth in invested capital and an 11% compound annual growth in adjusted EBITDA.
The balance sheet is the third area of focus.
Our strong financial position provides significant flexibility in considering capital allocation priorities, balancing growth and shareholder returns.
Our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio is 1.4 times, with nearly $900 million in cash reserves.
Our debt has an average maturity of 15 years, without any major near-term repayments due.
We will continue to manage the business with a long-term perspective.
We won't make hasty investment decisions simply because additional capital is available.
The final key area I wanted to highlight was the sale of the rehabilitated quarry in Southern California.
The sale yielded $182 million in net proceeds and a pre-tax profit of $115 million.
One of the advantages of our aggregates-focused business is the multiple opportunities for value creation, as demonstrated by this quarry's life cycle.
Up to this point in the call, we've concentrated solely on the aggregates business.
Let's briefly discuss non-aggregates.
Gross profit in these segments totaled $5.6 million for the quarter, $2 million less than the previous year.
The severe weather mentioned earlier affected asphalt volumes in Alabama, Tennessee, and Texas, as well as concrete volumes in Virginia.
Diesel costs didn't significantly impact the quarter, as the unit price remained relatively unchanged from the previous year's first quarter.
For the full year, we now expect diesel fuel costs to present a challenge of approximately $25 million, reflecting price increases since the beginning of the year.
During our last communication, we anticipated an effective tax rate of 21% for 2021.
We now project the full-year rate to be between 23% and 24%, following a 27% rate in the first quarter.
The higher rate in Q1 and the revised full-year expectation resulted from Alabama's recent law change, which altered how companies allocate income to the state.
This change reduced our ability to fully utilize certain net operating loss carry-forwards in Alabama.
Consequently, we recorded a $14 million charge in the first quarter.
We will continue to manage Vulcan with a long-term perspective.
This involves maintaining focus on strong local execution, driving unit margin expansion, preserving a robust financial position, and improving our returns.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jeff Mezger, Chairman, President and CEO; Matt Mandino, EVP and COO; Jeff Kaminski, EVP and CFO; Bill Hollinger, SVP and Chief Accounting Officer; and Thad Johnson, SVP and Treasurer are participating in the call.
We trust you and your loved ones had a pleasant and safe holiday season.
Our fourth quarter performance was impressive, with notable growth in net orders and expanded gross margins as we concluded 2020 on a high note.
Our margins are significantly improving as we shift towards higher-quality communities, efficiently manage expenses, and decrease our amortized interest, while our balanced strategy of optimizing price and pace in this strong demand environment provides additional support.
We're starting 2021 with positive momentum, as our backlog value has increased by over 60% compared to last year, and we have the potential to generate up to $6 billion in housing revenues this year as we focus on expanding our operations.
We're well-positioned for profitable growth focused on returns, given our backlog composition, a robust pipeline of new community openings, and our streamlined cost structure, all contributing to an expected double-digit operating margin this year.
Our fourth quarter results include total revenues of $1.2 billion and diluted earnings per share of $1.12.
Our year-over-year decrease in deliveries and revenues was anticipated, reflecting the COVID-related disruption in our second quarter net orders and housing starts.
Despite this, our per-unit earnings improved, with a housing gross margin of 21%, excluding inventory-related charges, representing a 110 basis point increase from the previous year.
The robust gross margin was the primary driver of the improvement in our operating income per unit, which rose to over $44,000, a $7,000 increase per home from the previous quarter.
Our financial position is excellent, putting us in a strong position for expanding our operations.
Our top priority for utilizing the substantial operating cash flow we're generating is investing in land acquisition and development.
We increased our land investments by over 60% year-over-year to $650 million in the fourth quarter.
Through disciplined execution, we expanded our lot position by 7,000 lots since the third quarter, ending the year with over 67,000 lots owned and controlled.
Our lot portfolio is well-diversified across and within our regions, with owned lots representing 3.8 years of supply and a higher proportion of option lots now making up 40% of our total.
We own all the lots needed for the significant increase in delivery volume expected in 2021 and own or control all the lots required for further delivery growth in 2022.
In addition to investing in our future, we continue to prioritize increasing shareholder returns, implementing another substantial increase in our quarterly cash dividend in the fourth quarter.
This marks the second consecutive year we've significantly increased our dividend, which is now six times its level from two years ago.
Our goal in expanding our scale is to increase our market position in each of our existing markets.
While we anticipate most of our growth to come from existing markets, we're also selectively entering new markets.
Seattle exemplifies our organic approach to growth.
We began with a small start-up operation less than three years ago, which became profitable by the end of its second year.
This division is now on track to more than double its profit this year and contribute more significantly to our overall performance.
Encouraged by our success in Seattle, we're extending our market strategy to the Carolinas, an area we're already familiar with.
Following improved execution in our Raleigh business over the past couple of years, we've now re-entered Charlotte using a similar start-up approach.
Charlotte is a top 10 homebuilding market, and we've hired an industry veteran with deep local roots and an extensive network to lead this effort, enabling us to quickly secure three land deals.
We anticipate our first deliveries in Charlotte in 2022.
Expanding our community count is our top priority, and we successfully opened 38 new communities in the fourth quarter, including 4 that opened ahead of schedule.
For 2021, we expect our ending community count to reach its lowest point in the first quarter, with sequential growth in each subsequent quarter, resulting in year-over-year community count expansion in our third and fourth quarters.
Looking beyond 2021, we're well-positioned with our owned and controlled lots to sustain growth sequentially throughout 2022, and we're committed to growing our community count by at least 10% next year, a target we believe is achievable given our balance sheet, cash flow, profitability level, and existing infrastructure.
Our monthly absorption pace per community accelerated to 5.6 net orders during the fourth quarter, representing a 51% increase year-over-year.
We achieved this higher pace even as we raised prices in over 90% of our communities, balancing pace and price in each community to optimize our assets and returns.
Our absorption pace has consistently ranked among the highest in the industry for many years.
We believe our success is driven by offering choice and personalization at an affordable price point, which are the foundations of our Built-to-Order model.
Given investors' increased focus on affordability in recent months, I'd like to share our thoughts on this topic.
Our long-standing approach to product positioning is to target the median household income in each submarket and remain flexible in adjusting our product offerings through higher density and slightly smaller footprints to stay close to median income levels.
By doing so, we believe we make homeownership attainable for the largest demand segments: millennials and Gen Z. Our divisions are executing well on our product strategy, enabling us to generate solid margins at our targeted absorption rates, with our average selling price in nearly every division below the median new home price and, in many cases, below the median resale price as well.
This last point is particularly significant, as resale is our largest competitor.
Given these dynamics, we believe our homes remain affordable.
As prices continue to rise, we are well-positioned.
During the buyer pause of late 2018 and early 2019, when both rising home prices and rising interest rates hindered affordability, we proactively took steps to reposition our product offerings.
We quickly introduced smaller square footage plans from our product series as models.
We broadened the range of options for our customers in terms of home size and reduced the level of standard features in most of our developments.
These actions collectively lower the base price in many of our communities, making our homes more affordable to a wider range of buyers.
Currently, we still provide these more compact home designs, with nearly 60% of our developments offering layouts under 1,500 square feet.
Slightly above that size range, over 75% of our communities have plans available that are less than 1,600 square feet.
Homes in the 1,500 to 1,600 square foot range are particularly appealing to the millennial generation.
Our Built-to-Order model offers flexibility in floor plan size and additional options like extra bedrooms, home offices, or dens, catering to the diverse needs of modern homebuyers.
The housing market remains strong, with the pandemic increasing demand for home ownership.
The inventory of existing single-family homes continues to decrease, now at just 2.3 months supply and even lower in many of our markets, especially at our price points.
The limited availability of resale homes, combined with a decade of underproduction of new houses and favorable demographic trends, particularly for first-time buyers, is expected to sustain demand for the foreseeable future.
We consider this trend particularly advantageous for our company, given our expertise in serving first-time buyers, who made up 61% of our sales in the fourth quarter, an increase of eight percentage points from the previous year.
During our last earnings call in September, we reported that our net orders were up 32% for the initial three weeks of our fourth quarter.
Demand remained high throughout the quarter, resulting in a 42% year-over-year increase in net orders to almost 4,000 homes.
Although we experienced some seasonal fluctuations in the quarter, they were minimal, with November's order activity remaining close to October's levels, which is unusual and demonstrates the strong demand for our homes.
Our strong performance was consistent across all four of our regions, with healthy year-over-year growth in each area.
The underlying buyer data for our fourth quarter orders continued to show positive trends, similar to what we observed in the third quarter.
Millennial buyers remained our largest customer group, accounting for 57% of our net orders, a six percentage point increase from the previous year.
Customers also showed a growing preference for Built-to-Order homes, which represented over 90% of our net orders, compared to just under 70% in the same period last year.
The growth in net orders during the fourth quarter led to a 50% year-over-year increase in our net order value, which in turn expanded our backlog value to $3 billion, a 63% increase from the previous year, representing approximately 7,800 units.
This larger backlog gives us confidence in our increased revenue projections for this year.
We increased our pace of home starts in the fourth quarter by 40% compared to the previous year and have continued this trend in the first quarter, aligning our starts with net orders.
Due to the strong net order trends throughout the fourth quarter, a larger portion of our backlog is in the early stages of construction, with about 55% either not started or only at the foundation stage, compared to around 44% in the same quarter last year.
This will affect our backlog conversion rate compared to typical first quarter levels.
However, we anticipate a sequential increase in deliveries in our first quarter, which is unprecedented in my career at KB Home.
Net orders for the first six weeks of the first quarter of 2021 are up 44% compared to the same period last year.
Demand remained strong through the holiday season and into the new year.
As a result, we expect our net order growth to moderate by the end of the quarter from its current level.
Our mortgage joint venture, KBHS Home Loans, had another successful year.
The joint venture's capture rate increased to 81% in the fourth quarter, resulting in a 20% year-over-year increase in income, despite fewer deliveries in the quarter, indicating a more profitable operation.
The joint venture is steadily increasing its contribution to our overall performance, with full-year income growth of over 70% to $21 million.
In conclusion, we ended 2020 on a strong note and are positioned for an excellent 2021, resuming our growth as a larger, more profitable company.
While we remain cautious about the ongoing pandemic and its potential to disrupt our business until it's under control, we are confident in the strength of our position.
We expect to expand our operations with our substantial backlog and continued robust market conditions, potentially reaching up to $6 billion in revenues in 2021.
Several factors support our higher gross margin this year, including our backlog composition, overhead leverage from increased revenue, effective cost management, lower amortized interest, and margin enhancements specific to our Built-to-Order model, such as lot premiums and studio revenue.
As a result, we anticipate our operating margin to reach double digits, driving our projected return on equity to over 17%, compared to approximately 12% in 2020.
In short, we are in our strongest position in over a decade, with an experienced, dedicated team, a solid balance sheet, a healthy lot position, cash flow to invest in community count growth, and a business model that generates high customer satisfaction and has proven appeal to homebuyers.
We are enthusiastic about 2021 and look forward to sharing our results as the year progresses.
I will now discuss the highlights of our financial performance for the fourth quarter of 2020 and provide our outlook for the first quarter and full year of 2021.
In the fourth quarter, we continued to show sequential improvement in our key profitability and credit metrics and achieved outstanding growth in our net orders, contributing to a significant year-over-year increase in backlog value to its highest level in 15 years.
Our housing revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.19 billion, a 23% decrease from the previous year, reflecting a reduction in homes delivered that was partially offset by a 5% increase in the overall average selling price of those homes.
The lower delivery volume was due to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and public health control measures on our second quarter net orders and housing starts.
For the first quarter of 2021, we expect housing revenues to range from $1.14 billion to $1.22 billion.
For the full year 2021, we forecast housing revenues between $5.5 billion and $6 billion, an increase of $450 million at the midpoint compared to our previous guidance.
With a backlog value of about $3 billion at the end of our 2020 fiscal year, we are confident in our ability to achieve this revenue target.
Our overall average selling price for homes delivered in the fourth quarter rose to roughly $414,000.
We expect the average selling price to be around $390,000 in the first quarter of 2021 due to changes in the regional distribution of homes delivered.
We anticipate our overall average selling price for the full year 2021 will fall between $400,000 and $410,000.
Fourth quarter homebuilding operating income was $115.7 million, compared to $162.5 million in the same quarter last year.
The current quarter included $11.7 million in inventory-related charges, compared to $4.1 million a year ago.
Our homebuilding operating income margin decreased by 80 basis points from the fourth quarter of 2019, reaching 9.7%.
When inventory-related charges are excluded, our operating margin remained at 10.7% for both periods, as the improved gross margin in the current year's quarter was completely offset by a higher SG&A expense ratio resulting from reduced operational efficiency due to lower housing revenues.
We expect our homebuilding operating income margin for the first quarter of 2021, excluding any inventory-related charges, to be between 9% and 9.3%.
For the full year 2021, we project this metric to range from 10.4% to 11%, representing a year-over-year improvement of 230 basis points at the midpoint.
Our housing gross profit margin in the fourth quarter of 2020 improved by 40 basis points to 20%.
When inventory-related charges are excluded, our gross margin for the quarter increased by 110 basis points to 21%, up from 19.9% in the same quarter of the previous year.
This improvement was primarily due to higher selling prices, changes in the geographic and community mix of homes delivered, and reduced amortization of previously capitalized interest.
Assuming no inventory-related charges, we forecast a housing gross profit margin for the first quarter of 2021 between 20% and 20.3%, an increase of more than 200 basis points compared to the same period last year.
We expect our full-year 2021 gross margin, excluding inventory-related charges, to be between 20.5% and 21.1%, with margins of 20% or higher in each quarter.
Our selling, general, and administrative expense ratio for the fourth quarter was 10.3%, an increase of 120 basis points from a year ago, mainly due to the negative impact of reduced operational efficiency from lower housing revenues, partially offset by our ongoing efforts to reduce overhead costs.
We predict our SG&A expense ratio for the first quarter of 2021 to be between 10.8% and 11.2%, as we continue to prioritize controlling overhead costs and expect to benefit from increased operational efficiency due to an anticipated year-over-year rise in housing revenues.
We anticipate our full-year 2021 SG&A expense ratio to be approximately 9.9% to 10.3%.
Our fourth quarter income tax expense of $20 million, which was positively influenced by $8.6 million in federal energy tax credits, represented an effective tax rate of about 16%.
We currently expect our effective tax rate for both the first quarter and full year of 2021 to be approximately 24%.
Federal legislation enacted in December extended the availability of energy tax credits for constructing energy-efficient homes through December 31, 2021.
Given our industry leadership in sustainable home building and energy efficiency, the extension of these tax credits will positively impact our 2021 effective tax rate and is reflected in our first quarter and full-year estimates.
We reported net income of $106.1 million, or $1.12 per diluted share, for the fourth quarter, compared to $123.2 million, or $1.31 per diluted share, for the same period last year.
For the full year 2020, our net income of $296.2 million, or $3.13 per diluted share, increased by 10% compared to 2019.
Regarding community count, our fourth-quarter average of 234 was down 8% from 253 in the corresponding 2019 quarter, primarily due to accelerated community closures in the second half of the year, driven by strong net order activity in both the third and fourth quarters.
We ended the year with 236 communities, a 6% decrease from a year ago, with about half of this decline due to a reduction in the number of communities previously classified as land held for future development.
We expect our community count to decrease sequentially in the first quarter, which we believe will be the low point for 2021, as community closures resulting from anticipated continued strong net orders outpace new openings for the period.
Year-over-year, we anticipate our average community count for the first quarter of 2021 will decrease by a low double-digit percentage.
We expect our quarter-end community count to increase sequentially starting in the second quarter and continuing through the rest of the year.
We anticipate ending the year with a mid to high single-digit percentage increase in our community count, supporting additional revenue growth in 2022.
As Jeff mentioned, our goal is to increase our community count by at least 10% in 2022 to support further market share gains and growth in housing revenues.
To drive future community openings, we invested $651 million in land and land development during the fourth quarter, with $376 million, or 58% of the total, representing land acquisitions.
In 2020, we invested nearly $1.7 billion in land acquisition and development and generated $311 million of net operating cash flow.
At year-end, our total liquidity was approximately $1.5 billion, including $788 million of available capacity under our unsecured revolving credit facility.
Our debt-to-capital ratio was 39.6% at year-end, and we expect further improvement in 2021 given our anticipated earnings growth.
We expect to generate significant cash flow in the current year to fund levels of land investment sufficient to support our targeted growth in community count and housing revenues for 2021 and 2022.
Our year-end stockholders' equity was $2.67 billion, compared to $2.38 billion at the end of the previous year, and our book value per share increased by nearly 10% to $29.09.
Given our current community profile and backlog, along with expected continued strength in the housing market, we are very confident in our ability to significantly improve our profitability, credit, and return metrics in 2021.
Throughout the year, we plan to continue executing our returns-focused growth strategy, emphasizing significantly increasing our returns by expanding our community count and revenue, while continuing to improve our operating margin.
In summary, using the midpoints of our guidance ranges, we expect a 39% year-over-year increase in housing revenues and significant expansion of our operating margin to 10.7%, driven by improvements in both gross margin and our SG&A expense ratio.
These anticipated improvements in scale and margin should drive our return on equity to above 17%, an increase of over 500 basis points year-over-year.
These expected results reflect our belief that our continued focus on a returns-focused growth strategy will enable us to further enhance long-term stockholder value.
Please open the lines for questions, Devin.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $1.12.
q4 revenue $1.2 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $1.14 billion.
expects to achieve significant growth in its scale and profits in 2021.
expect meaningfully higher revenue and earnings in 2021 to drive significant expansion of return on equity.
backlog value increased 63% to $3.0 billion at quarter end.
inventories increased 5% to $3.90 billion as of november 30, 2020.
net order value rose 50% in quarter.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The hazards mentioned are detailed in the Risk Factors portion of Hess' SEC-filed annual and quarterly reports
We may discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures during this conference call
A comparison between these non-GAAP financial measures and their closest GAAP equivalents can be found in the additional information provided on our website
I will now discuss our ongoing progress in implementing our strategy
Greg Hill will then speak about our operations, followed by John Riley who will cover our financial results
With COP26 starting this weekend, it's fitting to address the energy transition
Climate change represents the most significant scientific challenge of the 21st century
The world faces two major challenges: increasing global energy supply by about 20% in the next two decades and achieving net zero emissions by 2050
The International Energy Agency recently published its World Energy Outlook, offering four scenarios to illuminate these challenges
It's crucial to note that these are scenarios, not predictions, designed to guide decision-makers in policy and business
Oil and gas will continue to be necessary in the coming decades according to all four scenarios
Considerably more investment will be needed to meet the world's growing energy demands, particularly in renewables and oil and gas
Based on these IEA scenarios, we estimate global oil and gas investment needs to be at least $400 billion annually over the next decade
Last year, that figure was $300 billion
This year's estimate is $340 billion
To ensure a successful and orderly energy transition, we need understanding in climate, energy, and economics
Our strategy aims to expand our resource base, maintain low supply costs, and sustain cash flow growth
By investing only in high-return, low-cost opportunities and delivering top-tier environmental, social, and governance performance and disclosure, we've created a diverse and focused portfolio balancing short-cycle and long-cycle assets
Our cash-generating assets are in the Bakken, Gulf of Mexico, and Southeast Asia, where we have competitive advantages in assets and operations
Guyana is our growth driver and is set to become a significant cash generator in the near future as multiple phases of low-cost oil developments come online
Additionally, by adding a third rig in the Bakken in September and completing the Tioga Gas Plant's turnaround and expansion, the Bakken is expected to generate substantial free cash flow in the coming years
By successfully executing our strategy, our company is positioned to deliver strong and sustained cash flow growth through the end of the decade
According to recent sell-side consensus estimates, our cash flow is projected to grow at a compound annual rate of 42% between 2020 and 2023, which is 50% above our peers and places us in the top 5% of the S&P 500
As our portfolio generates increasing free cash flow, we will prioritize debt reduction followed by shareholder returns through dividend increases and opportunistic share repurchases
We have maintained financial strength while managing risk
As of September 30th, we had $2.4 billion in cash on our balance sheet
In July, we prepaid half of our $1 billion term loan due in March 2023 and plan to repay the remaining $500 million in 2022
This debt reduction, combined with the startup of Liza Phase 2 early next year, is expected to bring our debt to EBITDAX ratio below 2% and allow us to consider increasing shareholder returns
In August, we sold our interest in Denmark for $150 million, effective January 1, 2021, and received $375 million from Hess Midstream's buyback of Class B units from its sponsors Hess Corporation and Global Infrastructure Partners
Earlier this month, our company also received $108 million in net proceeds from the public offering of Hess-owned Class A shares of Hess Midstream
The Denmark sale and these Midstream transactions brought forward significant value and further improved our cash and liquidity position
Guyana, one of the industry's best investments, is key to our long-term strategy
On the Stabroek Block, where Hess holds a 30% interest and ExxonMobil is the operator, we announced the 19th and 20th significant discoveries during the third quarter at Whiptail and Pinktail
On October 7th, we announced the 21st significant discovery on the block at Cataback
These discoveries will support our future low-cost oil developments
We anticipate at least six FPSOs on the Stabroek Block producing over 1 million gross barrels of oil per day by 2027, and up to 10 FPSOs to develop the discovered resources on the block
On October 7th, we increased the estimated gross discovered recoverable resources for the block to approximately 10 billion barrels of oil equivalent, up from the previous estimate of over 9 billion barrels of oil equivalent
We continue to see potential for billions of barrels in future exploration
Regarding our current Guyana developments, gross production from the Liza Phase 1 complex averaged 124,000 barrels of oil per day in the third quarter
The Liza Phase 2 development is on schedule to start up in early 2022 with a gross production capacity of 220,000 barrels of oil per day, and the Liza Unity FPSO arrived in Guyana on Monday
Our third development on the Stabroek Block at the Payara field is on track for first oil in 2024, also with a gross capacity of 220,000 barrels of oil per day
Our three sanctioned oil developments have a breakeven Brent oil price between $25 and $35 per barrel
The development plan for our fourth project on the block at Yellowtail was recently submitted to the Guyanese government for approval
Pending government approvals, the project is expected to have a gross capacity of approximately 250,000 barrels of oil per day with first oil in 2025
We are honored to be recognized as an industry leader in environmental, social, and governance performance and disclosure
Our company recently received a AAA rating in the MSCI ESG ratings for 2021, following A ratings for the previous ten consecutive years
The AAA rating identifies Hess as a leader in managing industry-specific ESG risks compared to peers and reflects our strong practices in reducing carbon emissions and top-quartile performance in areas such as biodiversity and land use, reduction of air and water emissions and waste, and positively impacting the communities where we operate
In conclusion, we remain committed to executing our strategy and achieving strong operational and ESG performance
Our company is uniquely positioned to deliver cash flow growth over the next decade that is not only industry-leading but which we believe will rank among the best in the S&P 500
Once our term loan is settled and our portfolio generates more free cash flow, we will focus on returning capital to shareholders through increased dividends and strategic share buybacks.
In Q3, we maintained strong operational performance, hitting production goals despite hurricane-related delays in the Gulf of Mexico and successfully completing a major overhaul at our North Dakota Tioga Gas Plant.
Excluding Libya, our company-wide net production averaged 265,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily, aligning with our projections.
We anticipate company-wide net production to reach approximately 295,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, excluding Libya, for both Q4 and the entire year of 2021.
In the Bakken region, Q3 net production averaged 148,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily.
This exceeded our projected 145,000 barrels, mainly due to the efficient execution of the Tioga Gas Plant upgrade and expansion, a challenging task during COVID that required strict safety measures for over 650 workers.
We project Bakken net production to range between 155,000 and 160,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily in Q4.
For the full year 2021, we expect Bakken net production to average about 155,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily, slightly lower than our previous estimate of 155,000 to 160,000 barrels.
This forecast accounts for higher NGL prices, which reduce volumes under our percentage of proceeds contracts but significantly boost this year's earnings and cash flow.
We drilled 18 wells and activated 19 new wells in Q3.
For Q4, we plan to drill about 19 wells and activate approximately 18 new wells.
Our full-year 2021 plan remains unchanged: drilling about 65 wells and activating around 50 new wells.
Despite some cost increases, we're maintaining our projected average drilling and completion cost of $5.8 million per well for 2021.
We've been operating with two rigs since February.
However, due to improved oil prices and our large inventory of high-return drilling sites, we added a third rig in September.
Shifting to a three-year, three-rig program will enable us to increase cash flow and production, optimize our local infrastructure, and further reduce our unit cash costs.
Regarding offshore operations, Q3 net production in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico averaged 32,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily, below our projected 35,000 to 40,000 barrels.
This was due to an extended recovery period following Hurricane Ida, which caused power outages at downstream transportation and processing facilities.
All our facilities resumed production by the end of September.
We forecast Gulf of Mexico net production to average between 40,000 and 45,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily in Q4.
Our full-year 2021 Gulf of Mexico net production forecast remains at approximately 45,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily.
In Southeast Asia, Q3 net production was 50,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily, matching our projection of 50,000 to 55,000 barrels, reflecting planned maintenance shutdowns and reduced demand due to COVID.
We project Q4 net production to average about 65,000 barrels of oil equivalent daily, with our full-year 2021 forecast remaining at approximately 60,000 barrels.
Shifting focus to Guyana, Q3 gross production from Liza Phase 1 averaged 124,000 barrels of oil daily, or 32,000 barrels net to Hess.
The flash gas compression system on the Liza Destiny will be replaced with an improved design in Q4, and production optimization work is scheduled for Q1 2022.
These upgrades are expected to enhance production capacity and reliability.
We forecast Liza Phase 1 net production to average about 30,000 barrels of oil daily in Q4 and for the entire year of 2021.
The Liza Phase 2 development will use the Unity FPSO, capable of producing 220,000 barrels of oil daily, which arrived in Guyana on Monday evening.
The next steps involve mooring line installation and connecting umbilicals and risers.
Initial oil production remains on schedule for Q1 2022.
Regarding our third development at Payara, the Prosperity FPSO hull entered the Keppel yard in Singapore on August 1st.
Topside fabrication and development drilling are in progress.
The project is about 60% complete overall.
The Prosperity will have a gross production capacity of 220,000 barrels of oil daily and is on track to start production in 2024.
For our fourth development at Yellowtail, we recently submitted a development plan to the Guyanese government, pending approvals and project sanctioning.
The Yellowtail project will use an FPSO with a gross capacity of approximately 250,000 barrels of oil daily.
Initial production is targeted for 2025.
We've announced three new discoveries since July.
In July, we reported that the Whiptail 1 and 2 wells found 246 feet and 167 feet of high-quality oil-bearing sandstone reservoirs, respectively.
This discovery is located about four miles southeast of well 1 and three miles west of Yellowtail.
In September, we announced that the Pinktail 1 well, situated approximately 22 miles southeast of Liza 1, encountered 220 feet of high-quality oil-bearing sandstone reservoirs.
Earlier this month, we reported the Cataback discovery, located about 4 miles east of Turbot 1.
The well found 203 feet of high-quality hydrocarbon-bearing reservoirs, including approximately 102 feet of oil-bearing rock.
These discoveries support future developments and have contributed to increasing the estimated gross discovered recoverable resources on the Stabroek Block to approximately 10 billion barrels of oil equivalent.
Q4 exploration and appraisal activities will include drilling an exploration well about 11 miles northwest of Liza 1.
This well is a significant step-out test targeting deeper Campanian and Santonian aged reservoirs.
Q4 appraisal activities will include drill-stem tests at Longtail 2 and Whiptail 2, as well as drilling the Tripletail 2 well.
In conclusion, we have once again demonstrated strong execution and delivery, positioning ourselves well to provide significant value to our shareholders.
During my presentation today, I will contrast the outcomes from Q3 2021 with those from Q2 2021.
The third quarter of 2021 saw a net income of $115 million, a significant improvement from the $73 million net loss in the second quarter.
Adjusting for factors affecting earnings comparability between periods, our net income in Q3 2021 was $86 million, up from $74 million in Q2 2021.
The Q3 earnings include a post-tax profit of $29 million from divesting our Danish interests.
Adjusted E&P net income rose from $122 million in Q2 to $149 million in Q3 2021.
The following details the changes in adjusted E&P results' after-tax components between Q2 and Q3 2021.
Earnings increased by $110 million due to higher realized prices for crude oil, NGL, and natural gas.
A decrease in sales volumes led to a $147 million reduction in earnings.
Lower DD&A expenses boosted earnings by $37 million.
Reduced cash costs contributed to a $14 million increase in earnings.
A decrease in exploration expenses resulted in a $10 million earnings increase.
Various other factors collectively improved earnings by $3 million.
Overall, these changes resulted in a $27 million increase in Q3 earnings.
Q3 sales volumes were lower than Q2, primarily due to hurricane-related interruptions in the Gulf of Mexico, scheduled maintenance downtime, reduced nominations in Malaysia, and decreased sales in the Bakken due to planned Tioga gas plant maintenance.
In Guyana, we sold three 1-million-barrel oil cargoes in Q3, up from two in Q2.
Our E&P sales volumes in Q3 were approximately 175,000 barrels less than production, which had a negligible impact on our after-tax results.
The Midstream segment's net income decreased from $76 million in Q2 to $61 million in Q3 2021.
Q3 results included expenses related to the successfully completed Tioga Gas Plant maintenance turnaround.
Midstream EBITDA before noncontrolling interest dropped from $229 million in Q2 to $203 million in Q3 2021.
At quarter-end, excluding Midstream, our cash and cash equivalents stood at $2.41 billion, with total liquidity at $6 billion, including available committed credit facilities, while debt and finance lease obligations totaled $6.1 billion.
We received $375 million from selling 15.6 million Hess-owned Class B units of Hess Midstream and about $130 million from divesting our Danish interests in Q3.
In July, we paid off $500 million of our $1 billion term loan, with plans to settle the remaining $500 million in 2022.
In October, we gained approximately $108 million from publicly offering 4.3 million Hess-owned Class A shares of Hess Midstream.
Our consolidated ownership in Hess Midstream is now about 44%, down from 46% before these recent transactions.
Net cash from operating activities before working capital changes decreased slightly from $659 million in Q2 to $631 million in Q3.
After accounting for changes in operating assets and liabilities, net cash from operating activities dropped from $785 million in Q2 to $615 million in Q3.
Changes in operating assets and liabilities reduced net cash from operating activities by $16 million in Q3, contrasting with a $126 million increase in Q2.
Regarding guidance:
E&P cash costs, including Libya, were $12.76 per barrel of oil equivalent in Q3 2021, and $13.45 excluding Libya.
We anticipate Q4 E&P cash costs, excluding Libya, to range between $12 and $12.50 per barrel of oil equivalent, with full-year costs between $11.75 and $12, up from previous estimates of $11 to $12.
This revised guidance reflects the impact of higher realized selling prices in 2021, which improved cash flow but reduced volumes from percentage of proceeds contracts and increased Bakken production taxes.
Q3 DD&A expense was $11.77 per barrel of oil equivalent including Libya, and $12.38 excluding Libya.
We expect Q4 DD&A expense, excluding Libya, to be between $13 and $13.50 per barrel of oil equivalent, with full-year costs ranging from $12.50 to $13.
Total E&P unit operating costs, excluding Libya, are projected to be $25 to $26 per barrel of oil equivalent for Q4 and $24.25 to $25 for the full year 2021.
Q4 exploration expenses, excluding dry hole costs, are expected to be $50 million to $55 million, with full-year expenses around $160 million, at the lower end of our previous $160 million to $170 million estimate.
The Midstream tariff is projected to be about $295 million for Q4 and $1.95 billion for the full year.
E&P income tax expense, excluding Libya, is expected to be $35 million to $40 million for Q4, with full-year expenses between $135 and $140 million, up from previous estimates of $125 million to $135 million due to higher commodity prices.
We anticipate non-cash option premium amortization of approximately $65 million for Q4.
For 2022, we've purchased WTI collars for 90,000 barrels of oil per day with a $60 floor and $90 ceiling, and Brent collars for 60,000 barrels per day with a $65 floor and $95 ceiling.
The 2022 hedge program costs $161 million, to be amortized evenly throughout the year.
We expect to sell two 1-million-barrel oil cargoes from Guyana in Q4.
Q4 E&P capital and exploratory expenditures are projected to be around $650 million, with full-year guidance unchanged at approximately $1.9 billion.
For Midstream, we expect net income attributable to Hess to be about $70 million in Q4, with full-year projections of $280 million, aligning with our previous guidance of $275 million to $285 million.
Regarding corporate matters, we estimate Q4 expenses to be $30 million to $35 million, with full-year expenses expected to be $125 million to $130 million, down from previous estimates of $130 million to $140 million.
Interest expense is projected to be $90 million to $95 million for Q4, with full-year expenses expected to be $375 million to $380 million, compared to our previous estimate of about $380 million.
This concludes the presentation, and we are ready to address any questions.
Summary:

qtrly net production from bakken was 148,000 boepd compared with 198,000 boepd in prior-year quarter.
qtrly net production from gulf of mexico was 32,000 boepd, compared with 49,000 boepd in prior-year quarter.
q3 2021 e&p results include a pre-tax gain of $29 million associated with sale of corporation's interests in denmark.
on an adjusted basis, corporation reported net income of $86 million, or $0.28 per common share, in q3 of 2021.
