input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:As the pandemic situation continues to evolve, we remain cautiously optimistic yet vigilant while vaccination efforts progress amid uncertainties surrounding new variants.
I'm grateful for our organization's adaptability during this challenging period and continue to keep those affected in my thoughts.
Excluding currency impacts, adjusted earnings per share grew by 24.2% for the quarter and 24.5% for the year.
While first-half earnings have started strongly, it's worth noting they're largely supported by low pandemic-related benefit ratios and better-than-anticipated alternative investment returns.
For the first time since the pandemic began, sales improved year-over-year in the second quarter in both the U.S. and Japan.
Our strategy aims to make insurance available wherever customers prefer to purchase it.
This approach applies to both our Japanese and American operations.
In-person sales remain our most effective method for conveying the unique financial protection Aflac products offer.
Nevertheless, the pandemic has highlighted the necessity for virtual sales channels.
These non-face-to-face options help us reach potential customers and provide them with necessary coverage.
We've continued investing in distribution tools in both countries and integrating these investments into our operations.
Given the uncertain nature of pandemic recovery, we anticipate stronger performance in the latter half of the year in both countries, particularly if communities and businesses continue reopening, allowing more in-person interactions.
I communicate with our employees similarly to how I would with family members, keeping them informed through medical experts and encouraging COVID-19 vaccinations to prevent illness or worse outcomes from the virus or its variants.
Regarding our Japanese operations, Aflac Japan delivered solid financial growth in the second quarter, with a profit margin of 26.5%.
This exceeded the outlook range provided at the 2020 Financial Analyst Briefing.
Aflac Japan also maintained strong premium persistency at 94.7%.
Sales improved year-over-year, increasing by 38.4% for the quarter and 15.7% for the first six months.
These results reflect easier comparisons, improved pandemic conditions, and a boost from our new medical product launched in the first quarter.
While first-half 2021 sales are approximately 65% of 2019 levels, we continue navigating evolving pandemic conditions in Japan.
States of emergency have been declared in specific areas, particularly Tokyo and Okinawa.
However, cases have begun rising in the Tokyo and Osaka metropolitan areas, and we expect the Japanese government to soon decide on expanding the state of emergency to three additional prefectures surrounding Tokyo and Osaka.
Importantly, these states of emergency are less restrictive and limited in scope compared to lockdowns experienced in other countries.
The resumption of proactive sales in Japan since April has contributed to a gradual improvement in Aflac's cancer insurance sales, and we continue strengthening our strategic alliance to create sustained growth for both companies.
In June, Aflac and Japan Post Group entities reached agreements to further their strategic alliance, aligning with Japan Post Group's five-year medium-term management plan announced in May.
While we don't anticipate an immediate impact on sales recovery, this will position our company for long-term growth by addressing customer needs, providing customer-centric services, and creating shared value in resolving societal and local community issues.
In Aflac U.S., we observed a strong profit margin of 25.4% and very high premium persistency of 80.1%.
As anticipated, we saw sequential sales improvement and increased opportunities for face-to-face activities.
Due to softer sales a year earlier and more in-person opportunities, sales increased 64.1% for the quarter and are at 73% of first-half 2019 levels.
In the U.S., small businesses are still recovering, which we expect to continue throughout 2021.
Meanwhile, larger businesses remain primarily focused on returning employees to worksites.
As mentioned earlier, we aim to sell and service customers both in-person and virtually.
Additionally, we continue expanding the U.S. product portfolio with previously acquired businesses, Aflac Network Dental and Vision and Premier Life and Disability.
While these acquisitions have a modest near-term impact on revenue, they better position Aflac for future long-term success in the U.S.
Meanwhile, strong persistency, underwriting profits, and investment income continue driving strong pre-tax margins in both the U.S. and Japan.
We consistently prioritize maintaining strong capital ratios in the U.S. and Japan for the benefit of our policyholders and investors.
We remain committed to prudent liquidity and capital management.
We value our 38-year track record of dividend growth and are committed to extending it, supported by our strong capital position and cash flows.
Simultaneously, we will continue strategic share repurchases and focus on integrating our platform growth investments.
We are well-positioned to work towards long-term growth while ensuring we fulfill our promises to policyholders.
By doing so, we aim to emerge from this period in a continued position of strength and leadership, and look forward to sharing more about our strategic and financial priorities at our financial analyst briefing on November 16, 2021.
I'll now hand the program over to Fred.
I'll concentrate my remarks on efforts to rebuild our production platform and progress on growth strategies.
Starting with Aflac Japan, we're focusing on three areas to restore pre-pandemic production levels: product development, online or digitally-assisted sales, and specific sales initiatives within the Japan Post platform.
Regarding product development, our revised medical product, EVER Prime, continues to receive positive reception.
Medical product sales for the first half of the year have increased by roughly 48% compared to the same period in 2020 and are approaching pre-pandemic levels, down only 4% from the 2019 period.
We're regaining market share in the highly competitive medical market.
Earlier this year, we launched our first short-term insurance product under a newly formed subsidiary called SUDACHI.
This product is a small-amount, substandard medical policy targeting customers who don't qualify for traditional medical coverage.
In the second quarter, we registered nearly 600 agencies with SUDACHI and issued about 230 policies.
While this initiative is in its early stages, we plan to add more short-term health and income support products over time.
We're currently developing a new care product for supplementary elderly care coverage offered by Japan's government.
In the near future, we'll provide details on the strategic context and timing of this product, which we anticipate will become a significant contributor to future third sector sales, given the aging population and expected shift of financial responsibility from the government to individuals.
We've implemented technology enabling our agents to switch from in-person to virtual sales.
We initiated a nationwide advertising campaign on March 26 to promote this capability.
In Q2, we processed over 14,000 online applications, compared to nearly 8,000 in Q1.
Regarding Japan Post, proposal activity has increased monthly as sales training and promotion spreads across the 20,000 branches selling our insurance.
Through June, Aflac Japan has conducted over 35,000 training sessions with Japan Post sales agents nationwide, and provided contact information for nearly 700,000 existing cancer policyholders to inform them about the latest coverage benefits.
Third quarter activities include meeting with regional office managers in the JP system and visiting post offices to reinforce the sales process.
In the U.S., our group voluntary platform is performing well, with sales exceeding pre-pandemic 2019 levels.
Overall sales recovery is centered on rebuilding our agent-driven small business franchise that was impacted by the pandemic.
Key investment areas include recruitment, converting recruits to regular producers, and product development.
We've refocused our recruitment efforts on brokers over the past year, with new appointments surpassing pre-pandemic levels.
Appointing small business brokers takes time to generate production but is essential for expanding our reach and gaining a foothold in the dental and vision markets.
Individual agent recruitment remains challenging, with weekly producer numbers at 70% of pre-pandemic levels.
Agent recruitment is affected by onboarding and training restrictions due to COVID, tight labor markets, and employment subsidy programs, which we expect to improve later in the year.
Our Network Dental product is approved in 43 states and Vision in 42 states, with more states to be added later this year.
We're finishing national training programs and about half of our trained agents have quoted our new dental and vision products.
Although it's early, we're seeing monthly increases in volume, and over half of our dental and vision cases include voluntary benefit sales.
We believe this supports our strategic goal of increasing access to new accounts and deepening relationships with existing ones.
As mentioned last quarter, our 2021 dental and vision strategy can be summarized as a year to launch, learn, and adjust.
Our Premier Life and Disability platform continues to support key client relationships and is building a pipeline of quoted business.
Our service model remains excellent.
Since the acquisition, we haven't lost any significant accounts and have seen early interest from some of our larger voluntary benefit clients.
This new business wouldn't have been possible without our recently acquired group capabilities.
Regarding our e-commerce initiative, Aflac Direct, we offer critical illness, accident, and cancer coverage, now approved in 45 states, including California.
This platform aims to reach customers outside the traditional workplace setting.
Like most digital sales platforms, we see higher conversion rates when a digital lead is transferred to a licensed call center agent.
Currently, most of our leads go to third-party call centers, and we're actively developing an Aflac licensed call center.
Our digital platform overall has a 16% conversion rate on qualified leads, which is generally in line with many digital D2C insurance platforms.
Our consumer market strategy also includes digital distribution and product partnerships, which, while still in early development, are designed to increase access to protection products and drive traffic to our site.
In the first half of 2021, these three new platforms combined for 5% of sales as they are still in early development stages.
We continue to predict a strong second half based on increased activity and expect these three growth initiatives will contribute up to 15% of sales in the second half of 2021.
Aflac Global Investments recently announced an investment partnership with Denham Capital.
Aflac has committed $2 billion over multiple years from its general account to launch a new debt platform focused on investing in senior secured debt of sustainable infrastructure projects.
Aflac will hold a 24.9% minority stake in the newly created Denham Sustainable Infrastructure entity.
We're also committing $100 million to Denham Equity Fund, which focuses on sustainable infrastructure investments.
We're pleased to partner with Denham, a recognized leader in sustainable infrastructure markets.
Under Eric's leadership, this transaction advances our strategy of partnering with external managers.
We seek partnerships with firms that have strong track records in specialized asset classes that play a crucial role in our portfolio.
We then use our capital to take minority stakes to maximize potential benefits.
Combined with our recent Sound Point capital investment, we're advancing our ESG efforts by investing in sustainable infrastructure and distressed communities across the U.S.
I'll now hand over to Max to provide a more detailed discussion of our financial performance.
I'll start my comments by reviewing our Q2 performance, focusing on how our core capital and earnings drivers have developed.
In Q2, adjusted earnings per share rose 24.2% to $1.59.
The slightly weaker yen-dollar exchange rate didn't significantly impact adjusted earnings per diluted share.
This strong quarterly performance was mainly driven by lower claims utilization due to the pandemic, particularly in the U.S. Additionally, variable investment income was $112 million above our long-term return expectations.
Adjusted book value per share, including foreign currency translation gains and losses, grew 20.5%.
The adjusted ROE, excluding foreign currency impact, was a robust 17%, representing a significant spread over our cost of capital.
Turning to our Japan segment, total earned premium for the quarter decreased 3.8%, reflecting the impact of first sector policies reaching paid-up status, while earned premium for our third sector products fell 2.3% due to recent low sales volumes.
Japan's total benefit ratio was 66.9% for the quarter, down 290 basis points year-over-year.
The third sector benefit ratio decreased by 305 basis points year-over-year to 56.5%.
Our third sector block experienced a slightly higher than usual IBNR release as claims continued to be favorable compared to initial reserve estimates.
This quarter's IBNR release was mainly attributed to pandemic conditions limiting healthcare utilization since Q2 2020.
Although claims activity has started to increase, it remains below long-term normal levels.
It can take up to a year for auto claim reporting data to fully mature.
With over a year of pandemic data now available, our estimates have become more accurate, resulting in larger IBNR releases.
Persistency declined slightly by 10 basis points but remained robust at 94.7%.
Japan's adjusted expense ratio increased by 80 basis points year-over-year to 20.8%.
We are continuing to invest in technology to make Aflac Japan paperless, which includes higher costs for system maintenance.
Additional expenses related to remote work also contributed to the higher expense ratio this quarter.
Adjusted net investment income in yen terms grew by 27.4%, primarily due to good returns from our expanding alternatives portfolio and reduced hedge costs, partly offset by lower reinvestment yields on fixed-rate investments.
Japan's pre-tax margin for the quarter rose by 450 basis points year-over-year to 26.5%, which was a very positive outcome.
Based on this quarter's strong financial performance, we now expect Japan's full-year benefit ratio to be at the lower end of the 68.5% to 71% range provided at Fab.
We also expect the pre-tax margin to be at the upper end of the 20.5% to 22.5% range.
For U.S. operations, net earned premium decreased by 3.4% due to weaker sales.
Persistency improved by 180 basis points to 80.1%.
Emergency orders accounted for 63 basis points of the elevated persistency in both Q2 this year and last year, resulting in no net year-over-year impact for the quarter.
Lower sales contributed 80 basis points to improved persistency, as first-year lapse rates are about twice the total in-force lapse rates.
Conservation efforts accounted for another 30 basis points of improved persistency, with the remainder largely due to better experience.
Our total benefit ratio was lower than expected at 43.5%, which is 80 basis points below Q2 2020, a quarter heavily impacted by the initial pandemic.
Reduced claims utilization affects our estimates for incurred claims as data matures throughout the year.
As our data becomes more mature, we rely more on raw data, and with a year of pandemic data available, we lowered our IBNR to reflect decreased utilization.
This quarter, IBNR releases had a 5.6 percentage point impact on the benefit ratio, resulting in an underlying benefit ratio of 49.1% when excluding IBNR releases.
We anticipate the benefit ratio will gradually increase for the rest of the year as normal activities resume in our communities and among policyholders.
For the full year, we now project our benefit ratio to be between 45% and 48%, compared to our initial guidance of 48% to 51%.
The U.S. expense ratio increased by 160 basis points year-over-year to 36.9%, with several contributing factors.
Lower sales negatively impact revenue, but the effect on our expense ratio is balanced by reduced DAC and commission expenses.
Increased advertising spending raised the expense ratio by 60 basis points.
Our ongoing development of growth initiatives in group life and disability, network dental and vision, and direct-to-consumer contributed to a 170 basis point increase in the ratio.
These strategic growth investments are largely offset by our efforts to reduce core operating expenses as we aim to be the low-cost provider in the voluntary benefits market.
Overall, despite many variables, Q2 expenses are in line with our plan.
We also incurred $5.5 million in integration and transition expenses related to recent acquisitions, which are not included in adjusted earnings.
U.S. adjusted net investment income grew by 9.9%, primarily due to favorable variable investment income for the quarter.
The U.S. segment showed strong profitability with a pre-tax margin of 25.4%, driven mainly by a low benefit ratio.
With the first half of the year complete, we are raising our full-year pre-tax margin expectations.
Initially, we expected to be near the lower end of the 16% to 19% range.
We now anticipate finishing slightly above the range indicated at fab.
In our Corporate segment, we recorded a pre-tax loss of $76 million, as adjusted net investment income was $45 million lower than last year due to low short-term interest rates and amortization of certain tax credit investments, which amounted to $30 million this quarter at the corporate level.
Under U.S. GAAP, we recognize a negative impact on corporate NII, offset by a lower effective tax rate for the enterprise.
This creates some reported volatility in our Corporate segment, but the economic returns on these investments exceed our cost of equity capital.
To date, these investments are performing well and meeting expectations.
Our capital position remains strong, with an SMR above 900% in Japan and an RBC of approximately 600% in Aflac Columbus at the end of the quarter.
Unencumbered holding company liquidity was $4.4 billion, which is $2 billion above our minimum balance, excluding the $400 million proceeds from the sustainability bond issued in March to support our ESG initiatives.
Leverage, including our sustainability bond, remains at a comfortable 22.8%, in the middle of our 20% to 25% leverage range.
We repurchased $500 million of our own stock and paid $223 million in dividends during the quarter, providing good relative IRR on these capital deployments.
We will continue to be flexible and strategic in managing the balance sheet and deploying capital to drive strong risk-adjusted ROE with a significant spread to our cost of capital.
Summary:
output:
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.59.
q2 revenue $5.6 billion.
aflac- with respect to q2 sales results in u.s. and japan, we continued to see improvement and expect a stronger second half of year in both countries.
